Gene expression varies between individuals, and regulatory changes can underlie significant phenotypes in evolution and biomedicine. While most studies have focused on the effects of genetic changes on regulatory regions upstream of protein-coding sequences, a recent study investigated the role of RNA 3'-end processing in regulatory variation. The study analyzed transcript ends in lymphoblastoid cells from genetically distinct human individuals and found that transcript end positions did not fall randomly in untranslated regions but preferentially flanked the locations of 3' regulatory elements, including miRNA sites. The usage of these transcript length forms and motifs varied across human individuals, and polymorphisms in polyadenylation signals and other 3' motifs were significant predictors of expression levels of the genes in which they lay. The study suggests that the strategy of integrating observed 3'-end positions with inferred 3' regulatory motifs will be a critical tool in interpreting human genome variation. Overall, naturally occurring genetic differences in gene regulation within populations underlie phenotypes of evolutionary and biomedical interest, and understanding the molecular mechanisms by which DNA sequence variants give rise to expression change is an important area of research.
The live attenuated simian immunodeficiency virus (LASIV) vaccine, SIVΔnef, is one of the most effective vaccines against wild-type lentiviral challenge, though the mechanisms behind its protective efficacy are not well understood. In this study, deep sequencing technology and comprehensive CD8 T cell epitope mapping were used to understand the immune pressure and viral escape, and to delineate the effect of epitope escape on the evolution of the CD8 T cell response in SIVΔnef-vaccinated animals. The results showed that the initial CD8 T cell response in the acute phase of SIVΔnef infection is predominantly mounted against more variable epitopes, followed by widespread sequence evolution and viral escape. Importantly, epitope escape expands the CD8 T cell repertoire that targets highly conserved epitopes, defined as anentropic specificity, and generates de novo responses to the escaped epitope variants during the vaccination period. These findings suggest that SIVΔnef, long the gold standard in HIV/SIV vaccine research, serves as a proof-of-concept vaccine that highlights the significance of the twin principles of anentropic specificity and repertoire depth in successful vaccine design.
In the study of mucosal infections with Candida albicans, it was found that cellular immunity plays a crucial role in host protection, but the process of antifungal immunity induction is not well understood. Using a mouse model of oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC), it was discovered that interleukin-1 receptor (IL-1R) signaling is critical for fungal control at the onset of infection, particularly through its impact on neutrophils at two levels. The recruitment of circulating neutrophils to the site of infection and the mobilization of newly generated neutrophils from the bone marrow depend on IL-1R. In IL-1R-deficient mice, there is impaired chemokine production at the site of infection and defective secretion of granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) in the circulation in response to C. albicans. Endothelial cells were identified as the primary cellular source of G-CSF during OPC, which responded to IL-1α released from keratinocytes in the infected tissue. The IL-1-dependent crosstalk between two different cellular subsets of the nonhematopoietic compartment was confirmed in vitro using a novel murine tongue-derived keratinocyte cell line and an established endothelial cell line. These findings establish a new link between IL-1 and granulopoiesis in the context of fungal infection and identify two complementary mechanisms coordinating the neutrophil response in the oral mucosa, which is critical for preventing fungal growth and dissemination and thus protects the host from disease. Mucosal infections with C. albicans are the most frequent forms of fungal diseases, and the epithelium plays a crucial role in host defense by providing a physical barrier and producing inflammatory mediators and antifungal defense molecules. Neutrophils are critical for preventing invasion of the fungus in underlying tissues and dissemination to the circulation and visceral organs. Neutrophils are generated from granulocyte-macrophage progenitors in the bone marrow under the control of granulopoietic growth factors, primarily G-CSF. During acute infection, granulopoiesis is massively enhanced to comply with the increased demand for neutrophils in host defense. Control mechanisms of this demand-adapted hematopoiesis involve long-distance regulatory feedback loops induced at the site of infection, where neutrophils act, which is usually distant from the production site of neutrophils in the bone marrow. Increased release of G-CSF in response to infectious and/or inflammatory insult plays a key role in this process. Given the potentially harmful effects of dysregulated neutrophils, granulopoiesis and neutrophil trafficking are under tight control and regulated in a tissue-specific manner.
The Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GPELF), which delivered over 1.9 billion treatments to nearly 600 million individuals between 2000-2007, has resulted in significant economic benefits. An estimated $21.8 billion will be gained in direct economic benefits over the lifetime of 31.4 million individuals treated, with an additional $2.3 billion realized by protecting nearly 3 million newborns and individuals from acquiring the disease. The health systems of endemic countries will also save approximately $2.2 billion due to reduced patient services. These savings are a result of preventing 32 million disability-adjusted life years, averting 6 million cases of hydrocele and 4 million cases of lymphedema. The economic rate of return of the GPELF is extremely high, making it a smart investment in global health. This program has significantly improved the health of endemic populations and prevented cases of lymphatic filariasis, while also providing economic benefits to individuals and health systems.
A study investigating the relationship between GBA mutations and Parkinson's disease (PD) used medaka fish, a type of fish commonly used in disease research, to generate GBA nonsense mutant (GBA-/-) medaka that are completely deficient in glucocerebrosidase (GCase) activity. These fish survived for months, enabling analysis of the pathological progression, and displayed the pathological phenotypes resembling human neuronopathic GD including infiltration of Gaucher cell-like cells into the brains, progressive neuronal loss, and microgliosis. However, disruption of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) did not improve the life span, formation of axonal swellings, neuronal loss, or neuroinflammation in GBA-/- medaka. The study revealed that GBA-/- medaka can be used as a novel neuronopathic GD model and found that the pathological mechanisms of α-syn accumulation caused by GCase deficiency have minimal contribution to the pathogenesis of neuronopathic GD.
Listeria monocytogenes, an intracellular bacterium, is known to induce a robust innate and adaptive immune response, with CD8 T cells playing a crucial role in protective immunity. The escape of L. monocytogenes into the host cell cytosol is essential for the induction of long-lived CD8 T cell-mediated protective immunity. A study explored the impact of phagosome-confined L. monocytogenes on the immune response and found that it suppresses the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and leads to the rapid MyD88-dependent production of IL-10. This suppression limits not only the adaptive response to vacuole-confined L. monocytogenes but also negates the response to bacteria within the cytosol. Co-infection with phagosome-confined and cytosolic L. monocytogenes prevents the generation of acquired immunity and limits the expansion of antigen-specific T cells relative to the cytosolic L. monocytogenes strain alone. These findings demonstrate that the presence of microbes within a phagosome can directly impact the innate and adaptive immune response by antagonizing the signaling pathways necessary for inflammation and the generation of protective CD8 T cells. Overall, the study highlights the importance of the intracellular localization of L. monocytogenes in shaping the immune response and the need for further research into the mechanisms underlying this process.
Glaucoma, particularly the common subtype primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), is a leading cause of blindness worldwide. A genome-wide association study found a significant association between POAG and the SIX6 locus, specifically the rs10483727 variant. The SIX6 gene is involved in ocular development and has been associated with optic nerve morphology. Researchers sequenced the SIX6 coding and regulatory regions in 262 POAG cases and 256 controls, identifying six nonsynonymous coding variants. Five of these variants, found primarily in POAG cases, were hypomorphic or null, while the sixth variant, found only in controls, was benign. A clinical feature in POAG patients dependent on SIX6 genotype was also discovered: patients homozygous for the SIX6 risk allele (His141) have a significantly thinner retinal nerve fiber layer than patients homozygous for the SIX6 non-risk allele (Asn141). These findings suggest that SIX6 risk variants disrupt the development of the neural retina, leading to a reduced number of retinal ganglion cells and increasing the risk of glaucoma-associated vision loss.
"In the human intestinal pathogen Clostridium difficile, flagella promote adherence to intestinal epithelial cells and impact the production of glucosylating toxins, which are crucial for diarrheal disease development. The flgB operon, which contains early stage flagellar genes, is regulated by a 154 bp invertible sequence called the ""flagellar switch."" The orientation of this switch controls downstream flagellar gene expression and production of flagella and swimming motility, as well as the transcription of toxin genes and the production of glucosylating toxins. This regulation occurs post-transcription initiation and is mediated by the recombinase RecV. The flagellar and toxin phase variation in C. difficile may provide an advantage during infection of the gastrointestinal tract as a bet-hedging strategy. The flagellar operon (flgB) has a single transcriptional start site and a σA consensus sequence, with a class I (GEMM) c-di-GMP riboswitch named Cd1 in its 5' untranslated region. A 154 bp region of reduced sequence identity was found in the 5' UTR of the flgB operon in some C. difficile strains, including the 027 ribotype associated with epidemics of CDI. This region contains near perfect 21 bp inverted repeats, suggesting a regulatory mechanism involving phase variation by site-specific DNA recombination. This ""flagellar switch"" undergoes DNA inversion via site-specific recombination, resulting in a heterogeneous population of bacteria with the flagellar switch in the published or inverse orientation. This inversion affects flagellar gene transcription and swimming motility, as well as toxin gene expression and the production of glucosylating toxins."
Endosporulation is an ancient bacterial differentiation program leading to the formation of highly resistant endospores, which is crucial for survival under harsh conditions. This process is widely studied in the model organism Bacillus subtilis, where two cells participate: the forespore and the mother cell. Each cell type has its unique RNA polymerase sigma factors (σF, σE, σG, and σK) that control gene expression during spore development. These sigma factors are sequentially activated, and their activities are interconnected through cell-cell signaling pathways. In this study, researchers investigate the function and regulation of the sporulation sigma factors in Clostridium difficile, an obligate anaerobe and intestinal pathogen.Compared to B. subtilis, C. difficile shows significant differences in the activity and requirement of the sporulation sigma factors. Although the main periods of activity are conserved, σE activity is partially independent of σF, σG activity is not dependent on σE, and σK activity does not require σG. Moreover, σK is not strictly required for heat-resistant spore formation. These findings suggest that the temporal segregation between the early and late sigma factors is reduced, and the cell-cell signaling pathways are less stringent. Nonetheless, the top level of the endosporulation network, with sigma factors acting as key regulators, is conserved between these two organisms.The conservation of the sporulation sigma factors and their sequential activation in C. difficile have implications for understanding the evolution of endosporulation. This study emphasizes the importance of further investigating the sporulation network and its regulatory interactions in various sporeformers, especially considering the emergence of hypervirulent strains and the role of spores in the infection cycle.
The paper discusses a framework for modeling the dose-response of allosteric multisite phosphorylation proteins using a single auxiliary variable, which can closely replicate the steady-state behavior of detailed multisite systems. The reduced framework is useful for modeling and analyzing biochemical systems, as demonstrated through an application analyzing a newly discovered checkpoint signaling pathway in budding yeast. The pathway incorporates a signal proportional to bud growth or size, a mechanism to read the signal, and an all-or-none response triggered only when the signal reaches a threshold, forming a robust hysteretic switch. The paper also discusses the role of multisite phosphorylation in the emergence of bistability and hysteresis in regulatory processes. The modified fraction (MF) modeling approach is introduced as a simple mechanistic approach for modeling multisite allosteric proteins, which can describe ultrasensitive dynamics without introducing numerous variables. The MF framework can also be extended to other types of multisite modification. The paper applies the MF approximation to model a cell size checkpoint in budding yeast, comparing it with a detailed mechanistic model, and carrying out a mathematical analysis of the proposed checkpoint signaling pathway. The model hypothesizes that the interaction pathway can produce a bistable signal responsible for a sudden switch from polar to isotropic growth once the bud has undergone sufficient polar growth, presenting a clear downstream signal when sufficient polar bud growth has occurred. Overall, the paper presents a framework for modeling multisite allosteric proteins and demonstrates its potential through applications in cell signaling and checkpoint regulation.
"Quorum Sensing (QS) in bacteria, such as E. coli, enables multicellularity and selective advantages for communicating populations. QS is based on genetic ""switching"" phenomena, which are complex and context-dependent, and their mechanistic underpinnings have remained elusive. A study combined experimental work and mathematical models to decipher network connectivity and signal transduction in the AI-2 QS system of E. coli. The study revealed the importance of the LsrR regulator and its determinant role in the E. coli QS ""switch,"" normally masked by interfering regulatory loops. The research provides a ""bottom-up"" approach to unravel complex QS network architectures and coordinate emergent behaviors, contributing to the understanding of how biological systems support accurate signal propagation and the interplay among regulatory sub-structures in gene regulation. This knowledge can lead to the directed coordination of emergent behaviors and have important implications for synthetic biology, systems biology, and biotechnology."
In the sub-Saharan region, where both malaria and helminths are prevalent, the impact of these co-infections is not yet fully understood. A study was conducted to investigate the effect of schistosomiasis on the prevalence and incidence of Plasmodium falciparum infection in school-age children living in two rural communities in Gabon. The study found that schistosomiasis in children tends to increase the risk of plasmodium infection, and when infected, schistosomiasis enhances susceptibility to developing malaria in young children but not in older children. Additionally, the study found that soil-transmitted helminths (STH) enhance the risk for P. falciparum infection in schistosomiasis-positive children. These findings suggest that co-infections with helminths and schistosomiasis can increase the risk and severity of malaria infections in children, particularly in areas where these infections are prevalent. Further research is needed to better understand the impact of these co-infections on malaria outcomes in order to inform targeted interventions and control strategies.
In this study, researchers investigated the role of IRF-5-mediated inflammation in regulating CD8+ T cell responses during Leishmania donovani infection. They found that the inflammatory response induced by IRF-5 limits CD8+ T cell expansion and induces HIF-1α in dendritic cells. Ablation of HIF-1α in CD11c+ cells led to a higher frequency of short-lived effector cells (SLEC), enhanced CD8+ T cell expansion, and increased IL-12 expression by splenic DCs. Furthermore, mice with a targeted depletion of HIF-1α in CD11c+ cells had a significantly lower splenic parasite burden, suggesting that induction of HIF-1α may represent an immune evasive mechanism adopted by Leishmania parasites to establish persistent infections. This study highlights the importance of maintaining a balance between inflammatory and anti-inflammatory responses for effective immunity against infectious pathogens while limiting collateral inflammatory damage to the tissue. Excessive immunosuppressive responses can result in the strong inhibition of protective pro-inflammatory responses and lead to susceptibility to infectious pathogens. Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is a good example of dysregulated balance between inflammatory and anti-inflammatory responses, characterized by persistent infection of the spleen and immunodeficiency during the chronic stage. Experimental infection with L. donovani results in pathogen-induced disruption of the splenic microarchitecture, mediated by TNF, which is overexpressed during VL. The researchers demonstrated that the inflammatory response following L. donovani infection is largely mediated by the transcription factor IRF-5, which is responsible for the activation of genes encoding for various key inflammatory cytokines. L. donovani infected Irf5-/- mice do not show the hallmark symptoms of VL due to the lack of inflammatory cell infiltration and generate profoundly defective Th1 responses during chronic disease. The role of IRF-5-mediated inflammation on the development of CD8+ T cell responses during VL has not yet been explored. The researchers observed a 3-4 fold increase in the number and frequency of OT-I CD8+ T cells present in the spleen of IRF-5-deficient mice at d7p . i . ; no difference was detected at d14p . i . This suggests that IRF-5 participates in limiting CD8+ T cell expansion and hampering the development of SLEC. Since inflammation is known to induce HIF-1α, they assessed HIF-1α expression in splenocytes from L. donovani infected mice and found that HIF-1α was upregulated in the spleen of L. donovani infected mice. They further found that HIF-1α upregulation was induced by IRF-5-mediated inflammation and that HIF-1α expression was only upregulated in DCs purified from infected IRF-5-sufficient mice but not in those purified from IRF-5 deficient mice. These results suggest that IRF-5 is involved in the induction of HIF-1α in DCs and that HIF-1α upregulation in DCs reduces their stimulatory capacity for T cell functions in vitro. To investigate the role of HIF-1 α expression in DCs during experimental VL, they generated HIF-1α conditional knock-out mice by crossing Hif1aflox/flox with Cd11c-Cre mice. They found that amastigotes were able to survive inside DCs from Hif1aflox/flox—Cd11c-Cre+ mice and that OT-I CD8+ T cells underwent a greater expansion in Hif1aflox/flox—Cd11c-Cre+ mice compared to their Cre- littermates as indicated by a larger number and higher frequency of cells present in the spleen at d7 p . i . Unlike in IRF-5 deficient and Hif+/- mice, this difference was still observed at d14 p . i ., when OT-I CD8+ T cell numbers were 3--4 fold higher in the conditional knock-out group. These results suggest that HIF-1α expression in CD11c+ cells favours the development of MPEC and limits CD8+ T cell expansion following L. donovani infection. CD45. 1-OT-I CD8+ T cells were adoptively transferred into Hif1aflox/flox—Cd11c-Cre+ mice and their Cre- littermates a day prior to infection with L. donovani amastigotes. CD8+ T cell responses were then monitored at d7 ( peak expansion ) and 14 p . i . ( end of contraction ). Remarkably, OT-I CD8+ T cells underwent a greater expansion in Hif1aflox/flox—Cd11c-Cre+ mice compared to their Cre- littermates as indicated by a larger number and higher frequency of cells present in the spleen at d7 p . i . Unlike in IRF-5 deficient and Hif+/- mice, this difference was still observed at d14 p . i ., when OT-I CD8+ T cell numbers were 3--4 fold higher in the conditional knock-out group. These results suggest that HIF-1α expression in CD11c+ cells favours the development of MPEC and limits CD8+ T cell expansion following L. donovani infection.
This systematic review analyzed 14 studies focused on prognostic factors for American visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in Latin America, examining potential predictors of adverse outcomes and death. Limitations include the lack of validation of prognostic models and the need for further research. Strongest predictors of adverse outcomes were jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hemorrhage, HIV coinfection, diarrhea, severe neutropenia, ages less than 5 and over 40-50, dyspnea, and bacterial infections. Limited studies considered age-specific outcomes and factors like hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and weight loss showed weak associations. Considering the empirical evidence, physicians should carefully monitor VL patients with these risk factors to potentially reduce fatality rates and improve overall disease management.
In Algeria, leishmaniasis, a vector-borne disease caused by Leishmania parasites, is endemic in large areas and affects approximately 12 million people. The country ranks second after Afghanistan for the incidence of cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) and has a high burden of visceral leishmaniasis (VL), which is caused by L. infantum and transmitted by Phlebotomus perniciosus or P. longicuspis. Over a 30-year period, the National Public Health Institute gathered information about cases of CL and VL, and Leishmania isolates were collected from patients, mammalian reservoirs, and phlebotomine sandflies. These resources were used to examine the epidemiological associations and determine the antimony susceptibility of Leishmania isolates. A total of 106 isolates were studied, and the susceptibility of the Leishmania strains to antimony was determined in vitro. The results showed that there was a trend of increasing antimony susceptibility in VL isolates during the 30-year period, but there was an increase in the frequency of S- phenotypes in isolates causing CL during the same period. The emergence of S- phenotypes correlates with the inclusion of L. killicki (syn: L. tropica) isolates that cause CL and have emerged in Algeria during the last decade. These findings provide insights into the spatiotemporal dynamics of Leishmania antimony susceptibility in Algeria and highlight the need for the future implementation of an effective methodology to determine the antimony susceptibility status of Leishmania isolates to detect the emergence of and prevent the dissemination of drug-resistant strains.
Crohn's disease (CD) is a chronic inflammatory condition of diverse etiology, and exposure to foodborne pathogens causing acute gastroenteritis produces a long-term risk of CD well into the post-infectious period. However, the mechanistic basis for this ongoing relationship to disease onset is unknown. A study found that disease activity in the post-infectious period after gastroenteritis is driven by the tissue-associated expansion of the resident AIEC pathobiont, with an attendant increase in immunopathology, barrier defects, and delays in mucosal restitution following pathogen clearance. These features required AIEC resistance to host defense peptides and a fulminant inflammatory response to the enteric pathogen. The results suggest that individuals colonized by AIEC at the time of acute infectious gastroenteritis may be at greater risk for CD onset. Importantly, the data identify AIEC as a tractable disease modifier, a finding that could be exploited in the development of therapeutic interventions following infectious gastroenteritis in at-risk individuals. CD can involve the small and large bowel and is accompanied by changes in the microbial composition and distribution at these sites. AIEC has emerged as having likely pathogenic significance in CD. AIEC can be isolated from seemingly healthy individuals, implying that interactions between AIEC and other microbes or host genes might be needed to elicit their pathogenic character. CD is more common in individuals exposed to acute infectious gastroenteritis caused by Salmonella and other enteric pathogens, sometimes with onset times on the order of years after the infectious episode. The mechanistic basis for this long-term risk association following an acute event lasting ~2 weeks is unresolved, but one possibility is that resident gut microbes could perpetuate inflammatory reactions in the post-infectious period. Acute infectious gastroenteritis increases the risk of CD onset, and gastroenteritis causes inflammation that selectively disrupts the resident intestinal microbiota in favor of some members of the Enterobacteriaceae. Intestinal infections with frank enteric pathogens have been implicated as a probable cause of relapse in inflammatory bowel disease patients.
The passage discusses the role of the LIS gene in flowering plants, specifically in the Arabidopsis species. LIS is a homolog of the yeast splicing factor PRP4, and it is involved in a mechanism that prevents accessory cells from adopting gametic cell fate. In the female gametophyte of Arabidopsis, the lis-1 mutation, which is a loss-of-function mutation, leads to the formation of supernumerary egg cells due to accessory cells adopting gametic cell fate. This is because the lis-1 mutation creates an in-frame stop codon after three WD40 repeats, and the LIS protein is strongly conserved among eukaryotes. LIS expression is detected at moderate levels in all tissues examined, with strongest expression in reproductive tissues. GUS expression driven by the LIS promoter is detected at all stages of female gametophyte development, but shortly after cellularization, expression in the accessory cells is down-regulated, whereas expression in the gametic cells is strongly up-regulated. The proposed mechanism is that gametic cells upon differentiation generate a LIS-dependent signaling molecule that is transmitted to the adjacent accessory cells to inhibit their gametic cell competence, thereby preventing excess gametic cell formation. The lis mutant phenotype is a result of impaired lateral inhibition, i.e., the gametic cells fail to identify themselves to their neighboring cells, resulting in the recruitment of all gametophytic cells as gametic cells. The data suggest that a combinatorial mechanism operates to pattern the female gametophyte, and additional factors are needed to explain the generation of four distinct cell fates. The surprising nature of the LIS protein as a splicing factor suggests the participation of components of the splicing machinery in cell fate decisions and the generation of a lateral inhibition signal.
A study on the role of footwear in preventing Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs) was conducted in a rural Ethiopian community endemic for podoconiosis, a type of elephantiasis triggered by exposure to irritant soils in the tropical highlands. The study found that while shoes can prevent podoconiosis and chronic larva migrans, evidence for the role of shoes in preventing other NTDs such as hookworm, helminthiases, Buruli ulcer, snakebite, and tungiasis is inconsistent or circumstantial. The study identified several barriers to shoe wearing that are amenable to intervention, including limited access to shoes due to financial constraints, unsuitability of shoes for daily activities, and low risk perception. These barriers are relevant to a range of NTDs. While there is growing interest in the use of footwear in the primary prevention of NTDs, research on the impact of behaviors related to footwear and their impact on NTDs is limited. Therefore, understanding the barriers to consistent use of shoes in a rural setting can provide valuable information for those designing future studies and developing shoe-related prevention programs.
The pseudorabies virus (PRV) Us9 protein plays a key role in targeting viral capsids and glycoproteins to axons of sympathetic neurons, and Us9 null mutants are defective in anterograde transmission of infection in vivo. The glycoproteins gB, gC, gD, and gE are associated with lipid raft microdomains on the surface of infected swine kidney cells and monocytes, and are directed into the axon in a Us9-dependent manner. This report determined that Us9 is associated with lipid rafts, and that this association is critical to Us9-mediated sorting of viral structural proteins. Infected non-polarized and polarized PC12 cells were used, and in these cells, Us9 is highly enriched in detergent-resistant membranes (DRMs). Reducing the affinity of Us9 for lipid rafts inhibited anterograde transmission of infection from sympathetic neurons to epithelial cells in vitro. Therefore, association of Us9 with lipid rafts is key for efficient targeting of structural proteins to axons and for directional spread of PRV from pre-synaptic to post-synaptic neurons and cells of the mammalian nervous system. Lipid rafts play a key role in the axonal sorting of membrane proteins during neuronal maturation, and axonal growth and guidance. The increased synthesis of sphingomyelin during neuronal maturation is critical for the formation of protein-lipid complexes, an essential step for the targeting of randomly distributed GM1 ganglioside in immature neurons to the axon of fully mature neurons. Alpha herpesviruses, such as herpes simplex virus and pseudorabies virus, replicate and traffic within polarized neurons, and a well-known observation is that upon reactivation from the latent infection, α-herpesviruses rarely enter the central nervous system despite having what seems to be two rather similar choices: cross one synapse and infect the central nervous system (rare) or traffic back down the axon to the initial peripheral site of infection (very common). The Us9 gene product, a small, tail-anchored type II membrane protein, has been of interest in understanding the mechanisms of anterograde transport of alpha herpesviruses in the mammalian nervous system. PRV Us9 directs viral membrane proteins and capsids to axons of infected neurons, an absolute requirement for anterograde neuron-to-cell and neuron-to-neuron spread of the virus.
Genetically identical cells, including those of yeast and bacteria, can exhibit extensive phenotypic variation even under constant and benign conditions. This phenomenon, known as nongenetic heterogeneity, has important clinical implications as it can affect the growth rate and drug susceptibility of cancer cells and microbial infections. In the case of the budding yeast, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, nongenetic heterogeneity is shown in the form of a positive correlation between growth rate and susceptibility to acute heat stress at the single-cell level. Using a combination of genetic and chemical perturbations along with high-throughput single-cell assays of yeast growth and gene expression, it has been discovered that heterogeneity in intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels, acting through the conserved Ras/cAMP/protein kinase A (PKA) pathway and its target transcription factors, Msn2 and Msn4, underlies this nongenetic heterogeneity. Specifically, lower levels of cAMP correspond to slower growth, and an endogenous reporter of this pathway's activity correlates with growth in individual cells. Furthermore, the paralogs Msn2 and Msn4 differ in their roles in nongenetic heterogeneity in a way that demonstrates slow growth and stress tolerance are not inevitably linked. This finding has implications for the potential development of treatments for infections and cancer, as perturbing nongenetic heterogeneity by mutating genes in this pathway or by culturing wild-type cells with certain chemicals can significantly impact survival of acute heat stress.
Chikungunya virus (CHIKV), an alphavirus in the Togaviridae family, can cause severe febrile disease in humans. In December 2013, the Asian Lineage of CHIKV spread from the Old World to the Americas, causing a rapid epidemic throughout the New World. A study was conducted to understand how CHIKV may have evolved during this outbreak by studying the viral genetic diversity present in infected individuals. Deep-sequencing technologies and bioinformatics pipelines were used to characterize the minority variants and diversity in CHIKV-infected individuals from Guadeloupe and Martinique. The study found changes in the consensus sequence and a diverse range of minority variants present at various levels in the population. After single passages in cell lines, overall diversity was dramatically reduced. A novel 3' untranslated region (UTR) structure was identified, which led to increased replication in insect cells. The study highlights the need for continued viral diversity surveillance over time as this epidemic evolves to understand the evolutionary potential of CHIKV. Arthropod-borne viruses, such as CHIKV, pose an imminent threat to public health and are continuously re-emerging or spreading to uninfected areas. The CHIKV strain that has arrived in the Americas is from the Asian lineage and has rapidly evolved in a short period since it entered this naïve population. A survey of the mutant spectra present in human clinical samples has not yet been performed for CHIKV. This study characterized the minority variants directly from human samples by whole-genome deep sequencing. The data revealed considerable intra-host genetic diversity, with a 3' untranslated genome region (UTR) duplication unique among the circulating CHIKV strains around the world.
The mTOR signaling pathways, which control cell metabolism, growth, proliferation, and survival, are regulated by various factors at multiple cellular organelles and are involved in numerous human diseases. A study has identified UBTOR, a previously unannotated gene, as a functional player in regulating cell growth and mTOR signaling. UBTOR encodes a protein without any known functional domains and is conserved in vertebrates. Reduction of UBTOR function in cultured hippocampal neurons and PC12 cells promotes neurite outgrowth, while UBTOR depletion activates mTOR signaling and promotes cell growth. UBTOR overexpression suppresses colony formation in cancer cell lines. UBTOR inhibits mTOR signaling by stabilizing the mTOR complex component DEPTOR, and ubtor gene disruption results in higher mTOR activity and aggravates HRAS (G12V) induced neoplasia in zebrafish. UBTOR depletion promotes tumor growth and mTOR signaling in a xenograft mouse model. Therefore, UBTOR regulates cell growth and neoplasia via mTOR signaling.
Trypanosoma brucei, a unicellular flagellated parasite responsible for human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) and Nagana in cattle, has a life cycle including an insect stage (procyclic stage) and a mammalian stage. Trypanosomatid parasites, including T. brucei, have a high degree of divergence from well-studied eukaryotes, resulting in a lack of sequence similarity with model organisms for most of their proteins. This has led to the inapplicability of homology-based approaches for the identification of potential functions for over half of all trypanosomatid genes. To overcome this challenge, protein interaction maps are essential for functional annotation of proteins in T. brucei.In this study, the researchers constructed a global co-fractionation network of T. brucei by performing four high-resolution fractionation experiments using two orthogonal biochemical approaches. The fractionation-derived network was combined with other orthogonal resources of protein-protein interaction data to predict the network context of 866 protein groups, including many hypothetical and experimentally unannotated proteins. Clustering of this high-confidence network led to the assignment of 716 protein groups to 128 complexes.This study has several strengths. First, the use of two orthogonal biochemical approaches allows for a high-confidence network of protein interactions. Second, the authors validated the utility of the protein complex map by revealing novel factors involved in the mitochondrial post-transcriptional regulation of T. brucei. Finally, the high-confidence network provides a useful resource for formulating new biological hypotheses and further experimental leads.However, the study also has some limitations. First, the study was performed using the procyclic life stage of T. brucei, which may not fully capture the complexity of protein interactions in other life stages. Second, the study did not include validation of all the identified protein complexes, so further experimental validation is necessary to confirm the interactions.In conclusion, this study presents the largest proteomics-based interaction map of trypanosomatid parasites to date, providing a valuable resource for the identification of protein complexes and functional annotation of proteins in T. brucei. The results of this study are available at [www.TrypsNetDB.org](http://www.TrypsNetDB.org).
Tuberculosis (TB) is a significant global health issue, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), with an estimated 2.3 billion people infected worldwide. Extrapulmonary TB, including lymph node (LN) infection, is common, and the most common site of extrapulmonary Mtb infection in humans. Macaques are commonly used as models for TB research, and thoracic LNs are frequently infected in Mtb-infected macaques. However, the bacterial dynamics and impact of Mtb infection on LN structure and function are not well-studied. A study was conducted on thoracic LNs from Mtb-infected cynomolgus and rhesus macaques, analyzing PET CT scans, bacterial burden, LN structure, and immune function. The study found that FDG avidity correlated with the presence of live bacteria in LNs at necropsy and that LNs had different trajectories of increasing, maintaining, or decreasing PET activity over time. Rhesus macaques were more susceptible to Mtb infection than cynomolgus macaques, and this is in part due to more extensive LN pathology. Notably, compared to lung granulomas, LNs are generally poor at killing Mtb, even with drug treatment. Granulomas that form in LNs lack B cell-rich tertiary lymphoid structures, disrupt LN structure by pushing out T cells and B cells, introduce large numbers of macrophages that can serve as niches for Mtb, and destroy normal vasculature. Overall, LNs are not only sites of antigen presentation and immune activation during infection but also serve as important sites for persistence of significant numbers of Mtb bacilli, and understanding the relationships between LNs, bacterial persistence, and disease progression may yield new insights into disease pathogenesis, improve TB treatment, and limit reactivation of latent TB.
Microsporidia are fungi-related intracellular pathogens that can infect virtually all animals, but are poorly understood. The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans has become a model host for studying microsporidia through the identification of its natural pathogen Nematocida parisii. However, the prevalence and diversity of microsporidia infections in C. elegans and other related nematodes in the wild were unclear. In a study, 47 nematodes with microsporidian infections were isolated and cultured, revealing that N. parisii is the most common microsporidia infecting C. elegans in the wild. Six new species in the Nematocida genus were further described and named, and two subclades that are genetically distinct from Nematocida were identified and named Enteropsectra and Pancytospora, which belong to the main clade of microsporidia that includes human pathogens. These microsporidia are horizontally transmitted and most specifically infect intestinal cells, except for Pancytospora epiphaga that replicates mostly in the epidermis of its Caenorhabditis host. The spores of Enteropsectra show a characteristic apical distribution and exit via budding off of the plasma membrane, unlike Nematocida which exits via exocytosis. Host specificity varies among microsporidia, with some infecting multiple host species and others being more host-specific. The study highlights the diversity and ubiquity of microsporidian infections in nematodes and provides a valuable resource for investigating host-parasite coevolution in tractable nematode hosts.
Chemokine receptors, a subclass of G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), play crucial roles in the human immune system and are involved in cancer metastasis and HIV infection. Homo- and heterodimers or even higher order oligomers of the chemokine receptors CXCR4, CCR5, and CCR2 have been shown to modulate receptor function. Membrane cholesterol also affects chemokine receptor activity, but structural information about homo- and heterodimers formed by chemokine receptors and their interplay with cholesterol is limited. A study used thousands of molecular dynamics simulations to report homo- and heterodimer configurations of CXCR4, CCR5, and CCR2 at atomistic detail. The results showed that observed homodimerization patterns were similar for the closely related CC chemokine receptors, yet they differed significantly between the CC receptors and CXCR4. Despite their high sequence identity, cholesterol modulated the CC homodimer interfaces in a subtype-specific manner. Chemokine receptor heterodimers display distinct dimerization patterns for CXCR4/CCR5 and CXCR4/CCR2. Associations between CXCR4 and CCR5 reveal an increased cholesterol-sensitivity as compared to CXCR4/CCR2 heterodimerization patterns. This work provides a first comprehensive structural overview over the complex interaction network between chemokine receptors and indicates how heterodimerization and the interaction with the membrane environment diversifies the function of closely related GPCRs. GPCRs constitute one of the largest groups of cell surface transmembrane receptors, and chemokine receptors, a subgroup of GPCRs, play essential roles in the inflammatory response and have been reported to play important roles in tumor progression and metastasis and as co-receptors for the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) during cell infection. Chemokine receptors have been indicated to function as homo- or heterodimers or even oligomers of higher order, and the interactions between receptors are mainly formed by their transmembrane helices. Certain membrane components, such as cholesterol or polyunsaturated lipids, have been reported to modulate the function and association of GPCRs. The homodimerization of CXCR4 was shown to prevent TM1 and TM7 from engaging in dimer interactions, while the intercalation of cholesterol between monomers induced a symmetric interface including TM3 and TM4 of both receptors. CCR5 homodimerization was suggested to impair HIV infection, and CCL5, an agonist chemokine of CCR5, was suggested to stabilize receptor dimers. CCR2, closely related to CCR5, was shown to homodimerize and ligand stimulated receptors altered the dimer configuration. Heterodimerization of CXCR4, CCR5, and CCR2 has been observed and could be connected to modulations of ligand binding and receptor function. Negative ligand-binding cooperativity of allosteric nature across chemokine receptor heteromers was reported, suggesting that usually only one ligand binds to a complex of receptors, inducing conformational changes in the associated receptor. Especially the assembly of CXCR4 and CCR5 gained a great deal of attention since both receptors can act as co-receptors for HIV. It was shown that each receptor can associate with the transmembrane glycoprotein cluster determinant 4 (CD4) and that these associates are used by HIV to enter the cell. A mutant of CCR2 delayed the development of AIDS in HIV-infected individuals potentially due to heterodimerizing with CXCR4 or CCR5. Inducing the oligomerization of CCR2 with CCR5 and CXCR4 with a specific monoclonal antibody was reported to block HIV-entry. Based on the impact of GPCR dimerization on receptor function, novel therapies are developed to target protein association, such as the construction of bivalent ligands that are able to bind both receptors in homo- or heterodimeric GPCR complexes. However, the rational design of new drugs targeting GPCR dimers is subject to the availability of receptor complex structures. Structural information regarding GPCR homodimer interfaces is most frequently derived from available crystal structures, but no crystallographic data on GPCR heterodimers is available. In silico methods such as molecular dynamics (MD) simulations have proven useful to provide molecular information about the dimerization of transmembrane proteins. Especially coarse-grained (CG) simulations are a commonly used method to study GPCR assembly, and the interactions between certain lipid types or cholesterol and GPCRs have been found for several receptors. The binding strength of different dimer interfaces can be approximated with CGMD simulations, and from these studies, energetically favored dimer interfaces and possible energy barriers for dimer formations resulting from trapping of lipids at the interfaces could be elucidated.
"Systemic leishmaniasis, also known as Kala-Azar, is a parasitic disease that typically presents with fever, organomegaly, and wasting, and can be fatal if left untreated. While it is generally considered to have a well-defined clinical picture, recent research has identified a wider spectrum of signs and symptoms associated with the disease. In a study of 160 patients with depressed immunity, 19.4% were found to have an ""atypical"" form of systemic leishmaniasis, characterized by the presence of Leishmania parasites in macrophages but with normal or near-normal laboratory profiles. These patients presented with symptoms mimicking non-functional immune systems and were at risk of recurrent secondary infections. This form of the disease is more common than previously thought and can affect adults as well as children. The study highlights the need for a broader understanding of systemic leishmaniasis and the importance of considering this diagnosis in patients with unexplained depressed immunity. Additionally, the study was conducted in Lebanon and focused on patients referred to a specialized immunology laboratory, so further research is needed to determine the prevalence and characteristics of atypical systemic leishmaniasis in other populations."
The human genome contains millions of genetic variations, and identifying the ones that cause diseases or have clinical significance is a significant challenge. Computational approaches have used the perturbation of conserved amino acids as a useful criterion for identifying variants likely to have phenotypic consequences. However, a new study explores the potential of variants that occur at homologous positions within paralogous human proteins as a means of identifying polymorphisms with likely phenotypic consequences. The study found that the locations of variants are correlated in paralogous proteins and if one member of a variant-pair is disease-causing, its partner is likely to be disease-causing as well. Therefore, information about variant-pairs can be used to identify potentially disease-causing variants, extend existing procedures for polymorphism prioritization, and provide a suite of candidates for further diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. This new approach of using paralogous genes can provide a source of additional information for in silico variation characterization, one complementary to Amino Acid Substitution (AAS) approaches such as SIFT and PolyPhen. The study found that sequence variants co-occur at aligned amino acid pairs more frequently than expected by chance, and if one member of a variant-pair is disease-causing, its partner is likely to be disease-causing as well. Thus, knowledge of a sequence variant's paralogous relationships is useful for purposes of in-silico identification of novel disease-causing alleles. The study provides a novel resource for functional genomics and can help in identifying disease-causing variants and their relationships with other variants, diseases, and proteins.
The malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum causes severe disease in humans, leading to over 400,000 deaths annually. A study was conducted to analyze gene expression in parasite isolates from patients with severe and uncomplicated malaria in Papua, Indonesia. RNA sequencing (RNAseq) was used to analyze the transcriptomes of 44 parasite isolates, and it was found that parasites associated with severe malaria had unique transcriptional profiles. These parasites had decreased glycolysis without activation of compensatory pathways, altered chromatin structure, reduced surface expression of PfEMP1, and down-regulated expression of multiple chaperone proteins. Additionally, there were decreased histone methylation and novel associations between disease severity and PfEMP1 transcripts, domains, and smaller sequence segments. These findings suggest how parasites adapt to the host environment in severe malaria and inform efforts to identify vaccine targets for severe malaria.
A promising approach for preventing HIV-1 infection is the long-term delivery of potent, broadly-neutralizing antibodies. This has been demonstrated in rhesus monkeys using AAV vectors to deliver anti-SIV monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) in IgG1 form, achieving persisting levels as high as 270 μg/ml. However, host antibody responses to the delivered antibody were observed in 9 of the 12 monkeys, limiting the concentration of delivered antibody. Six monkeys in the AAV-5L7 IgG1 mAb group showed protective effects against difficult-to-neutralize SIVmac239 challenges, despite the absence of detectable neutralizing activity against the challenge virus. The protective effects included lowering of viral load at peak height and set point, and delay in the time to peak viral load. An effective preventive vaccine against HIV-1 is considered a difficult task due to the virus's immune evasion strategies, but using AAV vectors to deliver antibodies with potent and broadly-neutralizing activity is a promising approach. Challenges include overcoming anti-antibody responses and developing an effective vaccine to completely block the initial infection or provide immune responses that are more effective than those resulting from infection.
The assumption of linear response of protein molecules to thermal noise or structural perturbations, such as ligand binding or detachment, is commonly used in studies of protein dynamics. Conformational motions in proteins are traditionally analyzed in terms of normal modes and experimental data on thermal fluctuations in such macromolecules is also usually interpreted in terms of the excitation of normal modes. However, a study of two important protein motors, myosin V and kinesin KIF1A, using numerical investigations within the coarse-grained elastic network approximation, found that the linearity assumption is deficient for ligand-induced conformational motions and can even be violated for characteristic thermal fluctuations. The deficiency is particularly pronounced in KIF1A where the normal mode description fails completely in describing functional mechanochemical motions. These results suggest that important assumptions of the theory of protein dynamics may need to be reconsidered. The study of protein machines, which may represent enzymes, ion pumps or molecular motors, is a major challenge and understanding of their activity is crucial. Operation of these machines is based on slow conformational motions powered by external energy supply, often with ligands (such as ATP). In molecular motors, binding of ATP and its subsequent hydrolysis induce functional mechanochemical motions, essential for their operation. These motions, which follow after an energetic activation, are conformational relaxation processes. Large-scale conformational changes may take place in proteins as a result of ligand binding and despite the large magnitude of such changes, they are nonetheless often considered in the framework of the linear response theory and the normal mode approximation. However, there is no general justification to assume that relaxation processes in proteins are linear and this assumption has to be verified for particular macromolecules. It is known that relaxation processes in complex dynamical systems may be strongly nonlinear and deviate much from simple exponential relaxation. Conformational relaxation in single protein molecules may also be a complicated process, comprising qualitatively different kinds of mechanochemical motions. While partial unfolding and refolding, associated with ligand binding, are known for some protein machines, usually functional conformational motions in molecular machines and, specifically, in motor proteins are elastic. This means that the pattern of contacts between the residues in a protein is not changed upon ligand binding and preserved during the relaxation process.
The studies discussed here focus on the interaction and regulation between different endocytic pathways, specifically between clathrin-independent endocytosis and caveolar proteins. Caveolae, specialized microdomains enriched with cholesterol, have been identified as endocytic vehicles that can interact with other endocytic pathways. The research reveals that caveolar proteins, such as Cavin-1 and Cavin-3, can negatively regulate the CLIC/GEEC (CLathrin- Independent Carriers/GPI-AP enriched Early endosomal Compartment) pathway, which plays a significant role in cellular uptake and membrane dynamics. This inhibition occurs independently of caveola formation and is mediated by the interaction between caveolar proteins and lipid microdomains. In the absence of cavins and caveolae, caveolins, such as CAV1, are endocytosed via the CLIC/GEEC pathway, which loses its polarization and sorting attributes, impacting membrane dynamics and endocytic polarization in migrating cells and adult muscle tissue. These findings highlight the complex interplay between different endocytic pathways and the crucial role of caveolar proteins in regulating CLIC/GEEC pathway activity.
Two-component signaling systems are crucial for bacteria, Archaea, and plants to sense and respond to environmental stimuli. These systems typically involve a sensory histidine kinase that phosphorylates a REC domain on a conserved aspartate residue. However, some REC domains lack this phosphorylatable aspartate, and their functions and regulation are unclear. A study compiled all deposited REC domains missing their phosphorylatable Asp residue, renaming them ALR domains, and found they are common and enriched for rare effector outputs. Analysis of ALRs from Streptococcus pneumoniae suggests they have reorganized their active pockets to take on a constitutive regulatory role or accommodate input signals other than Asp phosphorylation. This work defines ALRs as an atypical REC subclass and provides insights into shared mechanisms of activation between ALR and REC domains. The REC domain family was found to be missing the conserved phospho-accepting Asp residue in up to 4% of sequences, renaming this subset of REC-type sequences Aspartate-Less Receivers (ALRs). ALRs were found to have unique ED architectures and substitutions within predicted acidic triad positions, indicating they are regulated by input signals other than histidine phosphorylation. ALRs were found in various phyla and were predominantly characterized in pathogens but numerically dominated by environmental bacteria, where greater selective pressures might drive REC divergence to accommodate new input signals.
Oncolytic herpes simplex viruses (oHSVs) have shown efficacy in clinical trials and practice, with most gaining cancer-specificity from deletions or mutations in genes that counteract the host response. However, these deletions often result in attenuated or over-attenuated viruses. Researchers have developed next-generation oHSVs that carry no deletion or mutation, and gain cancer-specificity from specific retargeting to tumor cell receptors, such as HER2. These viruses are fully-virulent in the targeted cancer cells and have shown to have a high safety profile in immunocompetent mice. In a study, both unarmed R-LM113 and IL-12-armed R-115 inhibited the growth of primary HER2-Lewis lung carcinoma-1 (HER2-LLC1) tumors, with R-115 being constantly more efficacious. The viruses were able to induce immunomodulatory cytokines, including IFNγ and T-bet, and increase the presence of certain tumor infiltrating cells. This resulted in a durable response and breakage of tolerance towards both HER2 and the wt tumor cells, indicating a systemic immunotherapeutic vaccine response. These next-generation oHSVs have the potential to be highly safe and effective anticancer agents.
The study investigates the susceptibility of vector-specific CD4 T cells to HIV in response to vaccination with two different viral vectors, Ad5 and ALVAC, tested in the HVTN204 and RV144 trials, respectively. The findings suggest that ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells are substantially less susceptible to both R5 and X4 HIV in vitro compared to Ad5-specific CD4 T cells. This difference is associated with reduced surface expression of HIV entry co-receptors CCR5 and CXCR4 on ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells, which display a strong Th1 phenotype and produce higher levels of IFN-γ and CCL4 (MIP-1β) but little IL-17. Furthermore, while ALVAC preferentially induces CD8 T-cell proliferation, Ad5 vector induces CD4 T-cell proliferation, and depletion of ALVAC-induced CD8 T cells in PBMC leads to a modest increase in HIV infection of vector-specific CD4 T cells, suggesting a role of ALVAC-specific CD8 T cells in protecting ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells from HIV. The study highlights the importance of better evaluating anti-vector responses in HIV vaccination and understanding the HIV susceptibility of vector-specific CD4 T-cell populations induced by different vaccine vectors.
X inactivation, the transcriptional silencing of one X chromosome copy per female somatic cell, is universal among therian mammals but varies in its choice of which X to silence among species. This variability can be attributed to conditions of dominance, linkage, recombination, and sex-differential selection. A population genetic analysis indicates that a single, critical interaction between allelic dominance and sex-differential selection can select for a broad range of X inactivation strategies, including unequal rates of inactivation between maternally and paternally inherited X chromosomes. RXI is favored over complete PXI when alleles deleterious to female fitness are sufficiently recessive. The criteria for RXI evolution are more restrictive when fitness variation is sexually antagonistic. Evolutionary transitions from PXI to RXI generally increase mean relative female fitness at the expense of decreased male fitness. These results provide a theoretical framework for predicting and interpreting the evolution of chromosome-wide expression of X-linked genes and can motivate future studies of allele-specific gene expression variation.
ZAP, a host antiviral protein, inhibits the replication of various RNA and DNA viruses by posttranscriptional RNA regulation, such as mRNA decay and translation inhibition. It has been shown to recruit the RNA processing exosome complex and poly (A) specific ribonuclease to degrade the target RNA from the 3'-end, and interacts with p72 RNA helicase to recruit decapping enzymes DCP1/DCP2 and exoribonuclease XRN1 to degrade the target RNA from the 5'-end. In this study, the authors investigated the antiviral potential of human ZAP against three flaviviruses, Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), dengue virus (DENV), and Zika virus (ZIKV). They found that only JEV was sensitive to ZAP, with ZAP overexpression blocking JEV infection and depletion of endogenous ZAP enhancing JEV replication. ZAP inhibited JEV translation and targeted viral RNA for 3'-5' RNA exosome-mediated degradation. The zinc-finger motifs of ZAP were essential for RNA targeting and anti-JEV activity, and JEV's 3'-UTR, specifically the region with dumbbell structures and high content of CG dinucleotide, was mapped to bind ZAP and confer sensitivity to ZAP. In summary, ZAP may act as an intrinsic antiviral factor through specific RNA binding to fight against JEV infection.
Rift Valley Fever Virus (RVFV) is a highly pathogenic virus that can cause severe disease in both humans and ruminant animals, including hepatitis, hemorrhagic fever, and encephalitis, with a higher mortality rate in animals than in humans. RVFV is endemic in sub-Saharan Africa and has recently spread to the Arabian Peninsula, causing significant health and agricultural concerns due to the potential introduction to naïve populations. There are currently no licensed vaccines or therapeutic options available for RVFV in humans. However, a live-attenuated vaccine strain, MP-12, has shown promise in animal studies, providing protection in ewes and lambs from wild-type virus challenge.In a study using C57BL/6 mice, researchers found that animals infected with the live-attenuated MP-12 strain survived productive viral infection with little evidence of clinical disease and minimal cytokine response in evaluated tissues. In contrast, ZH501 infection was lethal and caused depletion of lymphocytes and platelets and elicited a strong, systemic cytokine response, which correlated with high virus titers and significant tissue pathology. The study found that RVFV pathogenesis in mice is associated with a loss of liver function due to liver necrosis and hepatitis, but the long-term course of disease for those that might survive the initial hepatitis is neurologic in nature. The findings of this study can help guide the development of effective vaccines or therapeutic intervention for RVFV infection in humans. The study was conducted in accordance with animal use protocol approved by the University of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB) and all work was performed in a facility accredited by the American Association for the Accreditation of laboratory Animal Care.
Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is a subtype of breast cancer that is aggressive and has a poor prognosis. Chemotherapy is a common treatment for TNBC, but chemoresistance is a major challenge. A study found that C-C motif chemokine ligand 20 (CCL20) was significantly elevated during taxane-containing chemotherapy in breast cancer patients with nonpathologic complete response. CCL20 promotes the self-renewal and maintenance of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) through protein kinase Cζ (PKCζ) or p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK)-mediated activation of p65 nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB) pathway, increasing the frequency and taxane resistance of BCSCs. The blockade of CCL20 or its downstream pathway might reverse the taxane resistance in breast cancer patients. Therefore, CCL20 can be a novel predictive marker for taxane response. Taxane-induced CCL20 could promote self-renewal of BCSCs through the activation of p65 NF-κB, which was mediated by PKCζ and p38 MAPK activity. The activation of p65 NF-κB further promoted transcription of both ABCB1 and CCL20, which sequentially increased extracellular efflux of taxane and enhanced CCL20 effect via a positive feedback loop, leading to the taxane-resistance of TNBCs and promoting breast cancer progression with worse prognosis. Taxanes are widely recognized as active chemotherapeutic agents in the treatment of metastatic and early-stage breast cancer. Cytokine changes during chemotherapy regulate disease progression, favoring the growth and proliferation of tumor cells. However, the involvement of taxane-induced cytokines in chemoresistant breast cancer has not been well studied. A study found that CCL20 was obviously increased in the sera collected during the chemotherapy compared with that collected before NAC in non-pCR patients. CCL20 was also augmented in sera after chemotherapy compared with that collected before NAC in non-pCR patients. CCL20 staining was significantly increased in the tumor specimens from postchemotherapy, representing chemoresistant tumors. CCL20 level was obviously elevated after taxane treatment in MDA-MB-231 cells. CCL20 was the most universally and significantly up-regulated in common. These results suggest CCL20 might play a vital role in regulating the taxane resistance of breast cancer cells. CCL20, a member of the C-C motif chemokine subfamily, participates in many diseases’ progression and promotes the malignancy in colorectal cancer and lung cancer. However, the role of CCL20 in cancers has not been well elucidated. More importantly, little work has been done on the role of CCL20 in regulating the tumor progression and chemoresistance in breast cancer, especially TNBC, and the regulation mechanisms still remain unknown.
Toxoplasma gondii is a widespread intracellular parasite that can infect various nucleated cells in warm-blooded animals. Its tachyzoites, which are responsible for acute infection, can invade host cells and form a parasitophorous vacuole (PV) within which they replicate. To manipulate the host cell and acquire essential nutrients, Toxoplasma secretes effector proteins from unique organelles called rhoptries and dense granules. These effectors can localize to different parts of the host cell, such as the nanotubular network, PVM, or host cell nucleus. GRA16 and GRA24 are two effectors that localize to the host cell nucleus and affect p53 levels and PP2A-B nuclear translocation, and c-Myc up-regulation, respectively. These effectors are predicted to be intrinsically disordered proteins and are dependent on ASP5 for their export across the PVM. ASP5 cleaves the TEXEL motif in GRA16 and interacts with p38α MAP kinase via a kinase-interacting motif (KIM) in GRA24, leading to the activation of multiple host pathways. However, the process of how these effectors are transported across the PVM is not well understood. In Plasmodium falciparum, effector translocation across the PVM depends on the PTEX complex, which consists of an HSP101 AAA+ ATPase, EXP2, PTEX150, PTEX88, and a thioredoxin domain-containing protein, TRX2. In Toxoplasma, the protein and molecular components required for translocation across the PVM are not well understood. Recently, a novel protein, MYR1, was identified and found to be essential for effector translocation across the PVM and parasite virulence in a mouse model. Two novel membrane proteins, MYR2 and MYR3, were also identified and found to be involved in effector translocation. These proteins form a novel complex with MYR1 at the PVM, and the fusion of intrinsically disordered GRA16 to murine DHFR is sufficient to block its translocation, affecting the translocation of other effectors. This suggests a translocon-based model of effector transport. Overall, these findings reveal new insights into the mechanism of effector transport across the PVM and the molecular components involved in Toxoplasma's manipulation of host cells.
The paper reports the discovery of the binding of human papillomavirus (HPV) and bovine papillomavirus type-1 (BPV-1) E2 proteins to ORC2, a pre-replication complex (pre-RC) factor. However, ORC2 is not present at the viral replicon, and its depletion increases the presence of E1 and E2 at the viral origin. E2 restricts cellular origin recognition by ORC, which would otherwise complete for factors necessary for viral DNA synthesis. This mechanism allows PV E2 to orchestrate the viral genome replication program in a stratifying epithelial environment. ORC2 was not detected near the viral replicon, and ORC2 depletion increased replication of the luciferase-linked HPV-31 ori plasmid driven by co-transfected E1 and E2. ORC2 shRNA had the opposite effect on the HPV reporter compared to the EBV reporter, demonstrating that the increased luciferase levels in the HPV system were not due to a direct effect of ORC2 shRNA on luciferase protein expression but reflective of PV copy number. ORC2 knockdown caused a ten-fold increase in HPV-16 DNA episome number measured by quantitative PCR with primers specific to the HPV-16 LCR. ORC2 silencing had no effect on the cell cycle profile at 48 hours. ORC2 depletion enhanced luciferase levels at 48 hours and increased HPV-31 DNA content significantly higher with ORC2 knockdown compared to the control at 72 hours. ORC2 is not necessary for HPV ori licensing, and E2 association might interfere with ORC2 function. These results suggest a novel mechanism by which PV E2 orchestrates the viral genome replication program in a stratifying epithelial environment.
Brucellosis is a common zoonotic disease that affects poor and marginalized populations, and is often found in Central Asia. In Dushanbe, Tajikistan, a study was conducted to investigate the presence of Brucella DNA in bovine milk. The study found that Brucella DNA was present in 10.3% of 564 cow milk samples, as determined by IS711-based real-time PCR. This is concerning because consumption of unpasteurized dairy products is common in the region. Brucella DNA was detected in the milk of all seropositive cows, but 8.3% of the seronegative cows also showed the presence of Brucella DNA. Sequence analysis of the rpoB gene suggests that one cow was infected with B. abortus and another cow was most likely infected with B. melitensis. These findings highlight the need for further investigation into the possibility of false serological negative individuals in Brucella surveillance, control, and eradication programs. Vaccination of cattle and small ruminants may be necessary to control Brucella infections in the livestock population. However, further research is required to gain a comprehensive understanding of the Brucella spp. circulating among the livestock in this region.In conclusion, the study found that Brucella DNA was commonly detected in bovine milk in the UPU area of Dushanbe, both among Brucella seropositive and seronegative individuals. With a prevalence of 10.3%, the study suggests that the true number of Brucella-infected cattle in the study area may be underestimated by serology screening. False negative serology results and low antibody titers over time may contribute to the discrepancies between serology and qPCR results. Further research is needed to understand the circulating Brucella spp. among the livestock population, and to develop effective control and eradication strategies.
The stability of the genome is crucial for normal cell function and is linked to chromosome and DNA repair mechanisms stability. Many organisms have accessory or supernumerary chromosomes that differ from standard chromosomes. The fungus Zymoseptoria tritici has up to eight accessory chromosomes that are unstable, transcriptionally repressed, and enriched with repetitive elements and heterochromatic histone methylation marks. To understand the role of heterochromatin in genome stability in Z. tritici, researchers deleted the genes responsible for H3K9me3 and H3K27me3 and studied the impact on chromosome and genome stability. The loss of H3K9me3 led to dramatic chromatin reorganization, genome rearrangements, and activation of transposable elements, while the loss of H3K27me3 increased the stability of accessory chromosomes. The study highlights the importance of H3K9me3 in maintaining genome stability by preventing H3K27me3 in constitutive heterochromatin regions and the role of H3K27me3 in reducing the stability of accessory chromosomes.
Rabies is a fatal disease preventable through post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), but life-saving vaccines and biologicals are often inaccessible or unaffordable, particularly for the poorest sectors of society. Increasing accessibility, reducing costs, and preventing delays in delivering PEP should be prioritized. Analysis of different PEP vaccination regimens shows that switching from intramuscular (IM) administration of PEP to equally efficacious intradermal (ID) regimens could result in significant savings in vaccine volume required and costs. Financing mechanisms can help make PEP more affordable and accessible, supporting new and existing rabies control and prevention programs. A universal switch to ID delivery would improve affordability and accessibility of PEP for bite victims, ultimately reducing human rabies deaths and being economical for healthcare providers.
Toxoplasma is an obligate intracellular parasite that replicates in a parasitophorous vacuole (PV) within mammalian cells. It has developed a mechanism to acquire nutrients by attracting host organelles to the PV, including lipid droplets (LD), which are ubiquitous fat storage organelles. Toxoplasma replication is reduced in host cells depleted of LD or impaired in TAG lipolysis or fatty acid catabolism. The number of host LD and the expression of host LD-associated genes increase during infection, and Toxoplasma is capable of accessing and incorporating lipids from host LD into its own membranes and LD. This study highlights the reliance of Toxoplasma on host LD for its intracellular development and the parasite’s capability in scavenging neutral lipids from host LD. In mammalian cells, LD consist of an organic core bounded by a monolayer of phospholipids with structural proteins, lipid biosynthetic enzymes, lipolytic enzymes, and membrane-trafficking proteins. LD are involved in various cellular processes, including energy storage, lipid homeostasis, cell signaling, inflammation, immunity, and RNA metabolism. Toxoplasma induces LD formation in host cells, and Toxoplasma-infected cells show changes in host LD abundance, intracellular distribution, and neutral lipid syntheses. Toxoplasma internalizes host LD into the PV and salvages their lipid content for incorporation into membranes or storage in its own LD. The attraction of host LD to the PV is a general phenotype of Toxoplasma infection in vitro. The progressive displacement of host LD to the PV and the increased expression of HsDGAT2 at the onset of parasite replication suggest that host LD may play a role in supporting the intracellular development of Toxoplasma.
Fasciolosis, a disease caused by liver flukes Fasciola hepatica and Fasciola gigantica, is an emerging zoonotic disease with increased human infections reported. Chemotherapy is the main control measure available, with triclabendazole being the preferred drug. However, resistance to triclabendazole has been reported in several countries, necessitating the search for new chemical entities and target molecules to control fluke infections. A study searched a library of forty flavonoid derivatives for inhibitors of Fasciola hepatica cysteine proteases FhCL3 and FhCL1. Chalcones substituted with phenyl and naphtyl groups emerged as good cathepsin L inhibitors, with one compound, C34, tightly binding to juvenile specific FhCL3 with an IC50 of 5.6 μM. C34 is a slow-reversible inhibitor that interacts with the Cys-His catalytic dyad and key S2 and S3 pocket residues, determining the substrate specificity of this family of cysteine proteases. C34 reduces the larval ability to penetrate the gut wall and decreases NEJ's viability in vitro. This study is the first to screen non-peptidic inhibitors of Fasciola hepatica cathepsins and identifies chalcones as novel inhibitors of the two main Cathepsins secreted by juvenile and adult liver flukes. The findings open new avenues for the development of novel agents to control fluke infection and possibly other helminthic diseases.
The visual system uses separate neural pathways to transmit information about fast and slow changes in light intensity. Bipolar cells (BCs) play a crucial role in this process by transmitting signals from rod and cone photoreceptors through synaptic terminals of varying sizes. Researchers used in vivo imaging to investigate how bipolar cells transmit these signals to the inner retina. They discovered that the volume of the synaptic terminal is an intrinsic property that contributes to different temporal filters. Individual cells transmit through multiple terminals varying in size, with smaller terminals generating faster and larger calcium transients, leading to quicker vesicle release with higher initial gain and more profound adaptation. Modeling global calcium dynamics indicated that variations in the volume of presynaptic compartments contribute directly to these differences in response dynamics, enabling one neuron to transmit different temporal components in the visual signal through synaptic terminals with different adaptational properties. These findings reveal a mechanism through which multiple spatio-temporal filters are built using a limited number of neurons responding to a particular region of the visual field. By reconsidering the neural element through which the visual signal is transmitted to the inner retina, researchers can better understand how heterogeneous transmission of the visual signal reflects intrinsic variations between the various synaptic compartments of a BC.
A novel unsupervised probabilistic method for detecting synapses from multiplex fluorescence microscopy (muxFM) image data has been developed and tested, showing success in detecting synapses and accurately reproducing known features of cortical synapse distributions. This method, which uses a probabilistic model-based synapse detector that accepts molecular-morphological synapse models as user queries and delivers a volumetric map of the probability that each voxel represents part of a synapse, has been validated using human annotation of cAT EM data as ground truth. The algorithm detects synapses from muxFM data alone as effectively as human annotators, and can reproduce known architectural features of cortical synapse distributions. This approach has the potential to lead to relief from arbitrary threshold parameters and improvements in biological understanding of what defines a synapse.
