The proposed method has numerous advantages, including producing outputs in the form of probability maps, reflecting the limited certainty with which synapses can be detected, and the superior utility for both interactive and algorithmic exploration conferred by the query-based architecture resulting from the unsupervised framework. The method is not only unsupervised and more broadly applicable than existing methods, but it also outperforms them in cases where both methods can be used. The algorithm may also be useful for analysis of confocal and super-resolution FM images. This development is an important step towards deeper experimental analysis of the relationships between synaptic structure, molecules, and function, and can help to analyze volume images large enough to contain complete neural arbors, allowing discernment of the relationships between detected synapses and their presynaptic and postsynaptic parent neurons.
Zinc is a vital trace element involved in various cellular proteins' proper function, playing a key role in nucleic acid metabolism, gene expression regulation, signal transduction, cell division, immune and nervous system functions, wound healing, and apoptosis. Zinc homeostasis disruption can lead to human pathologies due to impaired cellular functions. Mammalian zinc transport is carried through two transporter families, ZnT and ZIP. The focus of this study is ZnT2, responsible for vesicular zinc accumulation and zinc secretion into breast milk during lactation. Although a proton gradient-dependent zinc transport has been suggested, it has not been conclusively established. This study aimed to model the mechanism of action of ZnT2 and demonstrate that ZnT2 is indeed a proton-coupled zinc antiporter.ZnT2 was shown to have a critical role in the development and normal function of the mouse mammary gland, as well as in involution. Expanding the mechanistic understanding of ZnT2 function will provide valuable information with important physiological and possible therapeutic implications. The study used computational energy calculations and functional zinc transport assays to show that ZnT2 is a proton motive force-driven, electroneutral vesicular zinc exchanger. ZnT2 functions as an antiporter with a stoichiometry of 2H+/Zn2+ ion, concentrating zinc in acidic vesicles on the expense of proton extrusion to the cytoplasm.Understanding the mechanism of action and the proton-dependent zinc transport of ZnT2 is crucial due to its critical role in zinc homeostasis and the development and normal function of the mouse mammary gland. Expanding the mechanistic understanding of ZnT2 function will provide valuable information with important physiological and possible therapeutic implications.
Replication fork integrity and genome stability are maintained by checkpoint-mediated phosphorylation events, with 14-3-3 proteins playing an undefined role under DNA replication stress. Exonuclease 1 (Exo1) processes stalled replication forks in checkpoint-defective yeast cells and interacts with 14-3-3 proteins in both yeast and mammalian cells. In yeast, 14-3-3-deficient cells fail to induce Mec1-dependent Exo1 hyperphosphorylation, leading to Exo1-dependent ssDNA gaps at stalled forks and persistent checkpoint activation, causing recovery defects. 14-3-3 proteins promote fork progression under limiting nucleotide concentrations. In mammalian cells, EXO1 activity is controlled by post-translational modifications such as ATR-dependent phosphorylation targeting EXO1 to ubiquitin-mediated degradation upon replication fork stalling. EXO1 deletion suppresses the sensitivity of rad53, but not mec1, mutant cells to agents causing reversible or irreversible stalling of replication forks. Eukaryotic 14-3-3 are highly conserved proteins that form flexible homo- and hetero-dimers, modulating the functions of proteins involved in various cellular processes such as apoptosis and cell-cycle. Upon DNA damage and DNA replication stress, 14-3-3 proteins are required for cell cycle restart, suppression of genomic instability, and viability. The exact mechanism of 14-3-3 action remains unknown, and further investigation is required to elucidate the role of 14-3-3 in regulating DNA replication stress response and fork stability.
The role of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDC) in HIV-1 infection and pathogenesis remains unclear, but studies in humanized mice have provided insight into their complex and often opposing roles. In acute HIV-1 infection, pDC are the critical IFN-I producer cells and contribute to suppressing HIV-1 replication. However, during chronic HIV-1 infection, pDC are still major IFN-I producers and help control HIV-1 replication, but their depletion during this phase surprisingly rescues human leukocytes, including CD4 T cells, in lymphoid organs despite higher levels of HIV-1 replication.A humanized mouse model of HIV-1 infection and pathogenesis was used to develop a pDC-specific mAb that specifically and efficiently depletes human pDC in various lymphoid organs. The study found that pDC play two opposing roles during HIV-1 infection: they produce IFN-I to inhibit HIV-1 replication, but also enhance HIV-1 pathogenesis by promoting cell death of human leukocytes, including CD4 and CD8 T cells.The gut-associated lymphoid tissue (GALT), a major site of human T-cell depletion by HIV-1 infection, is not structurally developed in humanized mouse models, making it difficult to examine the effect of pDC depletion in GALT in the current model. However, future studies examining the effect of pDC depletion in SIV-infected monkeys, which recapitulate GALT pathogenesis as in HIV-infected humans, could provide valuable insights.In addition to direct killing of HIV-1 infected CD4 cells, bystander cells, including hematopoietic progenitor cells and uninfected human mature cells, are also depleted, associated with immune hyperactivation during pathogenic HIV-1 infection. Recent reports suggest that pDC may contribute to HIV-1 induced immune activation and subsequent immunopathogenesis. Persistent activation of pDC by HIV-1 infection in lymphoid organs contributes to HIV-1 immunopathogenesis by accelerating the death of all human leukocyte cells.In conclusion, these findings demonstrate that pDC play critical roles in both acute and chronic HIV-1 infection, and understanding their complex functions could lead to the development of novel strategies for treating HIV-1 immune non-responsive patients with persistent immune activation despite effective anti-retrovirus treatment.
Sulforaphane (SFN), a compound found in cruciferous vegetables, has been shown to block HIV infection in macrophages, which play a critical role in HIV infection and pathogenesis. SFN is generated after mechanical damage to the vegetables, and reaches various tissues after consumption, where it maintains biological function. It is a powerful mobilizer of the transcription factor Nrf2, which is held in check by its constitutive degradation. SFN modifies KEAP1 to prevent engagement of Nrf2, allowing it to translocate into the nucleus and initiate transcription from antioxidant response elements. Nrf2 activates several types of genes, predominantly those that counter oxidizing conditions. HIV infection has been shown to be blocked by SFN in myeloid-derived cells including primary macrophages, but not in primary T cells. SFN blocks infection after reverse transcription but before formation of 2-LTR circles. The anti-viral effect induced by SFN treatment is reversible and the SFN dose determines the duration over which the anti-viral state is maintained. These findings suggest that SFN may be a useful therapeutic alternative to support prevention and cure strategies for HIV.
A community-based cross-sectional survey was conducted in rural western Kenya to measure the prevalence of and identify risk factors for geohelminth infections among pregnant women. The study found that 76.2% of the 390 participants were infected with at least one geohelminth: 52.3% with Ascaris lumbricoides, 39.5% with hookworm, and 29.0% with Trichuris trichiura. Infection with at least one geohelminth species was associated with the use of an unprotected water source and the lack of treatment of drinking water. Geohelminth infections were not associated with clinical symptoms or low body mass index, but a hookworm infection with an egg count ≥1000/gram feces was associated with lower hemoglobin. Among gravidae 2 and 3, women with A. lumbricoides were less likely to have malaria parasitemia compared to women without A. lumbricoides. Geohelminth infections are common in this pregnant population, but there were few observed detrimental effects. Routine provision of antihelminth treatment during an antenatal clinic visit is recommended, but an evaluation of the impact on pregnancy, malaria, and birth outcome is useful. Geohelminth infections are a major global health burden, with an estimated 3.8 billion persons infected and an estimated 135,000 deaths attributed to clinical complications annually. Geohelminth infections in pregnancy have been associated with iron deficiency, maternal anemia, and impaired nutritional status, as well as decreased infant birth weight, intra-uterine growth retardation, and adverse birth outcomes. However, effects of geohelminths among pregnant women may differ by area and helminth burden.
Mycolactone is a macrolide produced by the skin pathogen Mycobacterium ulcerans, which causes Buruli ulcer disease. It has cytotoxic, analgesic, and immunomodulatory properties. A recent study showed that mycolactone blocks the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by immune cells by affecting the Sec61-dependent production. This study aimed to investigate the effects of mycolactone on the inflammatory responses of the nervous cell subsets involved in pain perception, transmission, and maintenance, as well as its impact on neuroinflammation associated with chronic pain. The study found that prolonged exposure to mycolactone induced significant cell death at concentrations >10 ng/ml in sensory neurons, Schwann cells, and microglia. However, nanomolar concentrations of mycolactone efficiently suppressed the cell production of pro-inflammatory mediators without affecting their viability within the first 24h of treatment. Mycolactone also prevented the pro-inflammatory polarization of cortical microglia. In vivo, mycolactone decreased significantly the local production of inflammatory cytokines without inducing detectable cytotoxicity in a rat model of neuropathic pain. The study suggests that mycolactone-mediated analgesia may, at least partially, be explained by its anti-inflammatory properties.
Human African trypanosomiasis (HAT), or sleeping sickness, is a vector-borne disease endemic in sub-Saharan Africa and caused by two sub-species of trypanosomes. In West Africa, Guinea has the highest prevalence of HAT, especially in the mangrove areas of coastal Guinea, where the vector, the tsetse fly Glossina palpalis gambiensis, is abundant. HAT caused by T. b. gambiense is classically described as a chronic disease, but asymptomatic carriers and spontaneous cure without treatment have been reported. A recent long-term longitudinal survey in Côte d'Ivoire found people who were initially diagnosed by microscopy but on follow-up examination, up to 15 years later, had no detectable parasitaemia by microscopy. These individuals were classified as latent infections, i.e., able to control blood parasitaemia at very low levels. Many factors could play a role in this variability of response to infection, including genetic polymorphism of the parasite and host genetic factors involved in the control of immunity. Thus, the present study aimed to investigate the role of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in IL4, IL6, IL8, IL10, IFNG, APOL1, TNFA, HPR, HLA-G, HLA-A, HP, and MIF genes on susceptibility/resistance to HAT by means of an association study between HAT cases, seropositive microscopically aparasitaemic subjects with latent infections, and controls.The study was performed as part of a medical survey conducted by the national control program according to the national HAT diagnostic procedures and was approved by the Ministry of Health in Guinea. Blood was collected from 425 individuals living in three active HAT foci in the mangrove areas of coastal Guinea and classified into three phenotypes: HAT cases or active HAT patients, latent infections, and endemic controls. DNA was extracted from buffy coat samples and 80 SNPs were selected for genotyping using two strategies. After quality control and filtering, 28 SNPs were remaining and used for association analysis. Association analysis's were done using pairwise comparison between cases-controls, cases-latent infections, and latent infections-controls.The results showed that the A allele of IL6 rs1818879 and the G allele of APOL1 G1 appear to be associated with a higher risk of developing a latent infection but a lower risk of progressing from latent infection with undetectable parasitaemia to active disease. The APOL1 G2 allele increased the risk of progressing from latent infection to active HAT. The associations with the APOL1 G1 and G2 polymorphisms confirm previous observations, and the alleles seem to provide some degree of protection for individuals with latent infections. IL6 rs1818879 A allele carriers had a lower risk of developing the disease. These findings suggest that the genetic diversity of the hosts plays a role in the clinical diversity of sleeping sickness. The study was performed as part of the larger multi-country TrypanoGEN consortium study and aimed to understand the genetic basis of human susceptibility to trypanosomiasis.
The Singapore Sequencing Indian Project (SSIP) involved whole-genome sequencing of 38 Singapore Indians with a target coverage of 30X, comparing their genetic structure and diversity to other Asian populations and the 1000 Genomes Project (1KGP). SSIP samples exhibited higher intra-population genetic diversity and heterozygosity than other Asian populations, and were genetically close to South Indians. However, eight SSIP samples belonged to European-predominant mitochondrial haplogroups and showed elevated European admixture, indicating complex ancestry. This resource will aid in understanding the genetic architecture of Asian Indians.Meanwhile, Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS) technologies have revolutionized genomics by enabling comprehensive cataloging of genetic variants in a cost-effective way. NGS allows for sequencing of multiple individuals in a population to identify genetic variations, including Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs), insertion-deletions (indels), and structural variants (SVs). The 1000 Genomes Project (1KGP) aims to sequence over 2,500 individuals from 20 populations, providing valuable insights into the population genetics of 14 populations through a multi-individual, low-sequence-depth approach.In South Asia, NGS has been utilized in the Singapore Sequencing Malay Project (SSMP) and the SSIP. The SSMP, which examined the merits of deep sequencing for more comprehensive variant characterization, sequenced 100 Austronesian Malays at a coverage of at least 30X. The Indian subcontinent, home to over 20% of the world's population, has a complex demographic history shaped by migrations and interactions since the first human dispersal out of Africa. Ancient admixture analyses, mitochondrial sequence analyses, and genome-wide genotyping surveys have provided insights into the admixture and ethno-linguistic influences in the Indian subcontinent.The SSIP provides whole-genome sequencing of 38 Singapore Indians, yielding a high-quality resource for genetic studies of Asian Indians. Upon quality control and filtering, a total of 10,305,409 SNPs, 1,269,000 indels, and 56,088 large deletions were discovered, demonstrating novelty and ethnic diversity. Pathway analysis identified significant enrichment in pathways related to olfactory transduction, ATP-bind cassette (ABC) transporters, and Histidine metabolism. Further investigation of the loss-of-function variants and their association with diseases and phenotypes highlights the potential impact of genetic variation on health and disease. Therefore, the SSIP represents a significant contribution to understanding the diversity and genetic architecture of global populations and provides a valuable resource for understanding disease susceptibility and treatment response in Asian Indians.
Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of melioidosis, is a significant health concern in tropical and subtropical regions. The bacteria's intrinsic resistance to various antibiotics, including aminoglycosides and macrolides, complicates treatment. This resistance is primarily due to the AmrAB-OprA efflux pump. However, some strains, such as 708a, 2188a, and 3799a, from Northeast Thailand, exhibit susceptibility to these antibiotics. The study found that the aminoglycoside susceptibility of strains 708a, 2188a, and 3799a is due to the absence or reduced expression of AmrAB-OprA. In strain 708a, this is due to a large chromosome 1 deletion of approximately 131 kb, which includes the amrAB-oprA operon and other genes implicated in virulence and bacterial pathogenesis. Despite missing several putative virulence genes, strain 708a was fully virulent in a murine melioidosis model. Strain 708a, therefore, presents a natural candidate for genetic manipulation experiments using Select Agent compliant antibiotics for selection, validating the use of laboratory-constructed Δ(amrAB-oprA) mutants in such experiments.
In eukaryotic development, the induction of lineage-specific transcription factors drives the differentiation of multipotent progenitor cells while repressing alternative lineages, often mediated by extracellular signaling molecules like cytokines. A study of CD4 T helper (Th) cell differentiation into Th1 versus Th2 states revealed that, contrary to mutually exclusive expression of antagonistic transcription factors, these factors are co-expressed in individual cells at high levels, and cytokines are expressed only in a small subpopulation of cells, with cell-to-cell variation significantly larger than in the fully differentiated state. This early differentiation process of CD4 T cells results in a mixed Th1/Th2 state, instructed by extracellular cytokines, with an interplay between extracellular and intracellular signaling components as a common strategy for mammalian cells to buffer against noisy cytokine expression.
The paqr-2 gene in C. elegans, which encodes a protein with seven transmembrane domains similar to the mammalian adiponectin receptors AdipoR1 and AdipoR2, is essential for adaptation to low temperatures. A mutation in paqr-2 impairs the ability of C. elegans to grow and reproduce at 15°C, and this mutation also results in an abnormal fatty acid composition, an excess of lipid droplets, and is synthetic lethal with loss-of-function mutations in genes that promote fatty acid turnover. By using an unbiased forward genetic approach, a novel regulatory pathway connecting paqr-2, phosphatidylcholine (PC) synthesis, and the regulation of fatty acid desaturation to increase membrane fluidity during cold adaptation was established. Three paqr-2 suppressors are gain-of-function alleles of nhr-49, a nuclear hormone receptor homologous to the mammalian HNF4 and with activities that are sometimes compared to that of PPARα, while two other paqr-2 suppressor mutations are loss-of-function alleles of the genes ech-7 and hacd-1, which encode enzymes involved in fatty acid β-oxidation. The remaining three paqr-2 suppressor mutations are loss-of-function alleles of pcyt-1 and cept-1, which are enzymes important for PC synthesis. These paqr-2 suppressors, as well as the previously identified partial suppressors aak-2 and nhr-80, are all involved in PC synthesis and fatty acid metabolism, and they likely increase unsaturated fatty acids to compensate for the paqr-2 mutation. An analysis of the fatty acid composition of PCs, phosphatidylethanolamines (PEs), and triacylglycerols (TAGs) in synchronized wild-type, paqr-2 mutants, and paqr-2 mutants carrying suppressor mutations showed that paqr-2 mutants have an abnormally high abundance of saturated fatty acids, and that suppression of the paqr-2 phenotypes is associated with an increased abundance of unsaturated fatty acids. Additionally, the nhr-49 (et8) and cept-1 (et10) mutations normalized the overall PE/PC ratio in the paqr-2 mutant, suggesting that the paqr-2 mutant may compensate for an inability to upregulate fatty acid unsaturation by increasing the PE/PC ratio. Modulating the PE/PC ratio has important effects on membrane dynamics since PEs are bilayer-destabilizing phospholipids. Genetic interaction experiments suggest that nhr-49 (et8) and cept-1 (et10) likely act on a common target to suppress the paqr-2 phenotypes. Since nhr-49 is a well-established promoter of fatty acid desaturation, it is tentatively concluded that this is also the essential outcome of the cept-1 (et10) mutation. These findings provide new insights into the regulation of fatty acid metabolism during cold adaptation and tail tip maintenance in C. elegans.
Herpes simplex virus type-1 (HSV-1) is a well-studied virus with a large, double-stranded DNA genome contained within an icosahedral capsid, a pleomorphic proteinaceous layer called the tegument, and a glycoprotein-containing lipid envelope. The portal vertex, located at the twelfth vertex of the icosahedron, is believed to be the site of DNA packaging and release. A study using electron cryo-tomography of HSV-1 virions revealed a unique feature at the portal vertex that extends across the tegument layer and forms a connection between the capsid and the viral membrane. This assembly, called the portal vertex-associated tegument (PVAT), is a set of proteins that are consistently arranged with respect to the portal vertex and are continuous with the heterogeneous surrounding tegument. The detection of the PVAT is difficult due to its presence at only one vertex and its surrounding of inconsistently arranged tegument material. However, using sensitive methods, the PVAT was visualized and aligning each subtomogram based on its density distribution meant that the PVAT density was reinforced in the final reconstruction. The PVAT is likely to play a role in docking the capsid to the nuclear pore complex and signalling the proper conditions for release of the viral DNA, similar to the function of the tail in tailed bacteriophages. The composition of the PVAT cannot be directly determined from the reconstructions, but it is likely to include proteins such as pUL25 and pUL36 which have been shown to have roles in NPC recognition and DNA release.
Parasitic helminths like Schistosoma mansoni can modify human immune responses by skewing and dampening them, which could have implications for HIV-1 transmission and disease progression. A study examined the effects of soluble egg antigen (SEA) from S. mansoni on modulating HIV-1 infection and cytokine/chemokine production in vitro. The study found that SEA, specifically through kappa-5, can bind to DC-SIGN and block DC-SIGN mediated HIV-1 trans-infection, while not interfering with cis-infection. DCs exposed to SEA while maturing under Th2 promoting conditions, upon co-culture with naïve T-cells, induce a T-cell population that is less susceptible to HIV-1 R5 infection, but not to X4 virus infection. This was not observed for DCs exposed to SEA while maturing under Th1 or Th1/Th2 promoting conditions. The T-cell populations induced by SEA exposed DCs demonstrate a reduced capacity to produce IFN-γ and MIP-1β. The infection profile of T-cells infected with HIV-1 R5 was not associated with down-modulation of CCR5 cell surface expression. These results suggest that SEA parasite antigens and specifically rω-1 can modulate HIV-1 infectivity and have the potential to influence disease course in co-infected individuals.
Neuronal stimulation leads to a 30% shrinkage of the extracellular space (ECS) between neurons and surrounding astrocytes in both gray and white matter. This shrinkage phenomenon is closely linked to potassium clearance and water transport processes. Despite its potential implications for understanding basic aspects of potassium clearance and astrocyte function, it remains unexplained. A dynamic model has been developed to account for current experimental data related to this shrinkage phenomenon in wild-type and gene knockout individuals. The model suggests that neuronal release of potassium and uptake of sodium during stimulation, astrocyte uptake of potassium, sodium, and chloride in passive channels, action of the Na/K/ATPase pump, and osmotically driven transport of water through the astrocyte membrane are sufficient for generating ECS shrinkage. However, the Na+/K+/Cl- (NKCC1) and the Na+/HCO3- (NBC) cotransporters appear to be critical determinants for achieving observed quantitative levels of ECS shrinkage. The model provides a framework for guiding future key experiments and paving the way for more comprehensive astroglia-neuron interaction models for normal and pathophysiological situations. Astrocytes, first discovered in the mid 19th century, are star-shaped neuroglial cells that constitute the most abundant type of macroglia in the brain. They were once considered passive bystanders of neural activity, but are now known to be critically involved in modulating excitatory and inhibitory synapses, maintaining extracellular K+, H+, and glutamate levels, supplying energy substrates for neurons, and interacting with the vasculature to form functional compartments controlling communication pathways. Dysfunctional astrocytes have been linked to various central nervous system disorders, including neuropathic pain, epilepsy, Alzheimer's disease, schizophrenia, depression, and other psychiatric disorders. Despite the importance of astrocytes in neural function and pathology, our understanding of their normal behavioral repertoire is limited, particularly regarding the mechanisms underlying ECS shrinkage.
In Arabidopsis thaliana, transposable elements and other repetitive DNA elements are kept in check through transcriptional and post-transcriptional silencing mechanisms, which involve small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) generated by the RNase III enzyme Dicer. These siRNAs provide sequence specificity for effector complexes that mediate RNA cleavage and/or the establishment of repressive chromatin modifications at target loci. Transcriptional silencing of transposable elements is achieved through the RNA-induced initiation of transcriptional gene silencing (RITS) pathway, which is initiated by the recognition of target loci by AGO4-siRNA complexes. This recognition requires sequence identity between siRNAs and the genomic loci, and it is hypothesized to occur through base-pair interactions with DNA or nascent RNA transcripts. Recent studies have suggested that in Arabidopsis, RNA Polymerase V (Pol V) produces non-coding transcripts in otherwise silent chromatin, and its activity is required for the establishment and maintenance of repressive chromatin modifications. These Pol V-produced non-coding transcripts physically interact with AGO4 and recruit siRNA-AGO4 complexes to their targets, and the transcriptional silencing of several loci needs AGO4 slicer activity, suggesting that in plants siRNAs may recognize their targets by base-pair interactions with Pol V transcripts. However, it is still unclear how siRNAs work with Pol V transcripts, AGO4, and other proteins to recruit chromatin modifying enzymes to their target loci in chromatin. SPT5L is a homolog of SPT5 Pol II-associated elongation factor and has been shown to interact with AGO4, RNA, and Pol V complex. It has been hypothesized that SPT5L works downstream of Pol V and recruits AGO4 to Pol V-transcribed loci. IGN5, IGN6, and AtSN1 are Pol V-transcribed loci that require both Pol V and SPT5L for DNA methylation. SPT5L does not work upstream of Pol V in the siRNA-mediated transcriptional gene silencing pathway, and Pol V is needed for SPT5L protein stability. SPT5L and AGO4 are recruited to chromatin in parallel and at least partially independently of each other, and both are needed for DNA methylation and repressive histone modifications at several loci. SPT5L binding to chromatin is not affected by the rdr2 mutation, suggesting that RDR2-dependent siRNA is not required for SPT5L binding to chromatin. SPT5L and AGO4 are both guided by interactions with Pol V complex and/or Pol V transcripts. The parallel and independent recruitment of SPT5L and AGO4 to chromatin suggests that at Pol V-transcribed loci, none of them is sufficient for the establishment and maintenance of silent chromatin modifications. At least at a subset of loci, SPT5L and AGO4 work together to recruit repressive chromatin modifications, including DNA methylation and H3K9me2. The locus-specific function of SPT5L affects not only DNA methylation but also H3K9me2 and H3Ac. However, the pool of AGO4 that is bound to chromatin in an SPT5L-dependent manner is not required for silencing, suggesting that AGO4 and SPT5L are recruited to chromatin in parallel and independently of each other. Our findings establish the order of events leading to siRNA-mediated establishment of transcriptional silencing, including the recognition of silencing targets and the production of two classes of non-coding RNAs: siRNAs and Pol V-transcribed non-coding RNAs. Pol V recruitment to chromatin and transcription is followed by the association of AGO4 and SPT5L with chromatin. SPT5L binds chromatin independently of 24-nt siRNA and is likely a general factor associated with transcribing Pol V and its transcripts.
The RpoS regulon, controlled by the alternative sigma factor RpoS, is crucial for the transmission of Lyme disease spirochetes (Borrelia burgdorferi) by feeding nymphs. RpoS-deficient organisms are unable to traverse the midgut and infect distant sites in mice, although they replicate at normal levels during the nymphal blood meal. The aberrant morphology of RpoS-deficient spirochetes, referred to as round bodies or cysts, can be attributed to reduced levels of Coenzyme A disulfide reductase in vitro. These findings suggest that RpoS plays a significant role in the physiological adaptations required for tick-to-mammal transmission and triggers a default survival mode, round body formation, when spirochetes cannot produce sufficient energy for dissemination within the nymph. This highlights the importance of understanding the spirochete's transcriptome within ticks, which is currently not technically feasible. Therefore, qRT-PCR was used to measure transcript levels for a panel of RpoS-dependent genes, revealing that all eight genes previously shown to be absolutely RpoS-dependent in DMC-cultivated spirochetes were induced during nymphal feeding. Overall, these findings indicate that genes whose expression is upregulated by RpoS are likely to be expressed both during and after transmission by nymphs, while RpoS-dependent repression appears to occur only after spirochetes have fully adapted to the mammalian host.
In Arabidopsis, the precise coordination of stamen and pistil development is crucial for fertile flower formation. The development of stamen is regulated by various genes and hormones, including gibberellin (GA) and jasmonate (JA). Mutations affecting the biosynthesis of GA and JA cause male sterility due to impaired stamen filament elongation and anthesis. GA and JA play a hierarchical role in controlling stamen development, where GA promotes JA biosynthesis to control the expression of MYB21, MYB24, and MYB57. These MYB genes are downregulated in the ga1-3 single mutant and the sterile quadruple mutant ga1-3 gai-t6 rga-t2 rgl1-1 (loss-of-function of GAI, RGA, RGL1 three DELLA genes but RGL2 is normal), but restored to wild type levels in the fertile penta mutant ga1-3 gai-t6 rga-t2 rgl1-1 rgl2-2 (loss-of-function of GAI, RGA, RGL1 and RGL2 four DELLA genes). The absence of the four DELLAs (GAI, RGA, RGL1 and RGL2) cannot suppress the short stamen phenotype conferred by the loss-of-function of MYB21 and MYB24. The application of exogenous JA onto the ga1-3 gai-t6 rga-t2 rgl1-1 rgl2-1 quadruple mutant flower buds could restore the expression of MYB21, MYB24, and MYB57, whereas application of exogenous GA onto opr3 mutant flower buds failed to increase the expression of these three MYBs. GA upregulates JA-biosynthetic genes DAD1 and LOX1 and the JA content in the young flower buds of the GA-deficient quadruple mutant ga1-3 gai-t6 rga-t2 rgl1-1 is much lower than that in the WT and penta mutant. Therefore, it is established that GA upregulates the DAD1 and LOX1 expression to promote JA production to promote the expression of the three MYBs necessary for stamen filament development.
Dietary restriction (DR) has been shown to extend lifespan in various species and slow the onset of age-related diseases. A conserved protein kinase known as the target of rapamycin (TOR) pathway is essential for longevity phenotypes resulting from DR. TOR regulates growth and metabolism in response to nutrients and growth factors. A transcription factor complex known as HIF-1, which plays key roles in oxygen homeostasis, tumor formation, glucose metabolism, cell survival, and inflammatory response, is one of the targets of the TOR pathway in mammalian cells. A study in Caenorhabditis elegans found that HIF-1 deficiency results in extended lifespan, which overlaps with that by inhibition of the RSKS-1/S6 kinase, a key component of the TOR pathway. The hif-1 loss-of-function mutant extends lifespan under rich nutrient conditions but fails to show lifespan extension under DR. A mutation in egl-9, which increases HIF-1 activity, diminishes the lifespan extension under DR, and this deficiency is rescued by tissue-specific expression of egl-9 in specific neurons and muscles. Increased lifespan by hif-1 or DR is dependent on the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress regulator inositol-requiring protein-1 (IRE-1) and is associated with lower levels of ER stress. Therefore, the study demonstrates a tissue-specific role for HIF-1 in the lifespan extension by DR involving the IRE-1 ER stress pathway. DR has been shown to extend lifespan in various species, and identification of genes involved in DR response will provide potential targets for treatments of age-associated diseases and the extension of healthful lifespan in humans.
In studying the chromatin changes and gene expression programs during transitions of progenitor keratinocytes to differentiation and migration, it was found that unique complements of enhancers (regulatory regions distant from target promoters) are formed in each state. These enhancers are classified as typical enhancers (TES) or super-enhancers (SEs), with the latter being longer and associated with higher levels of cooperatively binding transcription factors and H3K27Ac activation marks. SEs are more important for cell type specifications and driving the expression of cell identity genes than TES. In the case of GRHL3, a single transcription factor that promotes both differentiation and migration of keratinocytes, it regulates divergent gene expression programs under different physiological states within the same cell type by switching locations of chromatin binding in the context of enhancer landscapes that are distinct for each state. Specifically, GRHL3 binds to distal regulatory regions during keratinocyte differentiation and to promoters during keratinocyte migration, while repressing the expression of migration inhibitors during migration. SEs are enriched for skin disease sequence variants, and GRHL3 binds preferentially to SEs in differentiating keratinocytes and to promoters in migrating keratinocytes. Many key epidermal differentiation transcription factor genes, including GRHL3, are located within SEs, and these transcription factors in turn bind to and regulate SEs. GRHL3 also represses the formation of progenitor and non-keratinocyte SEs in differentiating keratinocytes. Therefore, chromatin relocates GRHL3 binding and enhancers to regulate both the irreversible commitment of progenitor keratinocytes to differentiation and their reversible transition to migration.
Endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) are remnants of ancient retroviral infections of the host germline, passed down vertically from generation to generation. In sheep, two exogenous (horizontally transmitted) oncogenic retroviruses, Jaagsiekte sheep retrovirus and Enzootic nasal tumor virus, coexist with highly related and biologically active endogenous retroviruses (enJSRVs). Sheep are an interesting model to study retrovirus-host coevolution due to this unique coexistence. A study of 27 enJSRV proviruses revealed that two of them, enJS56A1 and enJSRV-20, acquired a defective Gag polyprotein in two temporally distinct events, resulting in a transdominant phenotype that blocks late replication steps of related exogenous retroviruses. These transdominant proviruses became fixed in the host genome before or around sheep domestication (∼9,000 years ago). This suggests that endogenization and selection of ERVs acting as restriction factors is a mechanism used by the host to fight retroviral infections. Exogenous retroviruses occasionally infect the germ cells of their hosts, resulting in stably integrated endogenous retroviruses that are passed on to subsequent generations. ERVs can interfere with exogenous retroviruses by various mechanisms, such as the expression of envelope (Env) glycoproteins that block viral entry of exogenous retroviruses by receptor competition. Sheep offer a unique opportunity to study the coevolution of ERVs, exogenous retroviruses, and their hosts.
The study evaluates the performance of Schistosoma PCRs in diagnosing schistosomiasis, compared to microscopy and serological assays. The Schistosoma PCRs were performed on 412 samples from patients with suspected schistosomiasis, targeting S. mansoni and S. haematobium. The results showed that PCRs significantly increased the sensitivity of diagnosis for Sh in urine and Sm in stools, and for serum samples, the overall sensitivity was 72.7%, with a specificity of 98.9%. After treatment, serum PCR positivity rates declined slowly, while antibody detection remained positive after 1 year. The study suggests that Schistosoma PCRs could be part of the reference methods combined with WB-based serology, and when serological assays are positive and microscopy is negative, serum PCRs provide species information to guide further clinical exploration. Biomarkers such as DNA and antibodies are of limited relevance for early treatment monitoring, but serum PCR could be useful when performed at least 1 year after treatment to help confirm a cured infection. Schistosomiasis is a snail-borne parasitic disease of great concern worldwide, with a growing number of people potentially infected in non-endemic areas. The development of molecular methods has encouraged research on Schistosoma DNA detection, which appears to be a promising, highly sensitive, and specific tool for diagnosing schistosomiasis.
The use of machine learning for estimating potential energy surfaces has been demonstrated to speed up molecular dynamics simulations for small systems, and this approach has been shown to be feasible for larger, structurally complex molecules, using the natural product Archazolid A as an example. A model was developed to estimate energies of new conformations using Gaussian process regression and predictive variance to assess whether a conformation is in the interpolation region, allowing for a controlled trade-off between prediction accuracy and computational speed-up. The model achieved mean absolute errors of less than 1 kcal/mol for energies of relaxed conformations at the density functional level of theory. This study demonstrates the potential for developing predictive machine learning models for structurally complex, pharmaceutically relevant compounds, enabling considerable speed-ups in simulations of larger molecular structures.Archazolid A is a potent inhibitor of vacuolar-type ATPase and has a complex structure, including a 24-membered macrolactone ring with seven alkenes and eight methyl- and hydroxyl-bearing stereocenters. The relative and absolute stereochemistry and three in-solution model conformations were elucidated using NMR spectroscopic methods. The model was trained using a series of computationally expensive QM calculations, with the underlying assumption that similar chemical systems have similar properties. The model used a simple matrix representation based on nuclear charges and intra-molecular distances for the simulated system.Semi-empirical MD simulations were carried out using the AM1 Hamiltonian, starting with a model of Archazolid A minimized with NMR constraints. Four trajectories of 300 ps length were calculated using an NVT ensemble with a Berendsen heat bath coupling constant of 40 fs and the velocity Verlet integrator. Snapshots were recorded every 100 fs, and the initial 50 ps of each trajectory were discarded to ensure equilibration. A total of 1000 equally distributed conformers from the four trajectories were energy minimized using MOPAC2012 at the AM1 level. The resulting structures were further optimized using DFT-D2 calculations with TURBOMOLE and single point calculations on the BLYP (RI)-D3-COSMO/def2-TZVP level for direct comparison of MD snapshots and experimental data.The study demonstrated that the MD simulations sampled relevant conformations of the central macrocyclic structure, as the generated conformers possessed favorable energies and similar compliance with experimental data as the literature-reported conformations 5a, 5b, and nmr. A total of 2,800 diverse conformers were generated using the MMFF94x FF, which were clustered with respect to geometric measurements of the macrolactone ring. The results showed that about 40% of the FF-based structures were in clusters containing no QM-based conformers and vice versa. Therefore, only DFT-D energies were considered for further study.Gaussian processes, a non-parametric regression method with regularization, were used to train ML models to capture the relationship between the relaxed Archazolid A conformations sampled from the MD simulation and their DFT-D3 energies. The ML models were trained using a simple matrix representation based on nuclear charges and inter-atomic distances. The results showed a root mean squared error of 5.35±0.72 kJ/mol, mean absolute error of 3.51±0.38 kJ/mol, and squared correlation coefficient of R2=0.88±0.03. These results suggest that GP regression, a Bayesian non-parametric ML method, is suited for modeling relationships between molecular structure and QM properties even for structurally complex, pharmaceutically relevant compounds.
"In Central Africa, a ""hotspot"" for emerging infectious diseases, an outbreak of ebolavirus is currently affecting multiple countries and suspected to have caused recent declines in resident great apes. While ebolavirus vaccines have been proposed as an intervention to protect apes, their effectiveness would be improved with diagnostic confirmation of EVD as the cause of die-offs, establishing ebolavirus geographical distribution, identifying immunologically naïve populations, and determining if apes survive virus exposure. A new approach of noninvasive detection of antibodies against EBOV in wild ape feces has been developed, identifying gorillas with antibodies to EBOV at a prevalence rate of 10%, demonstrating that EBOV exposure or infection is not uniformly lethal in this species. This new approach will contribute to protecting apes from future EBOV infections and have a profound impact on public health in local communities by identifying great ape outbreaks and preventing human pathogens of animal origin from reaching a pandemic state."
Type III effectors are virulence factors used by Gram-negative bacterial pathogens to manipulate host cell processes, including innate immunity and gene expression. A novel type III effector XopL from the model plant pathogen Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria exhibits E3 ubiquitin ligase activity, both in vitro and in planta. This activity is associated with the C-terminal region of XopL, which specifically interacts with plant E2 ubiquitin conjugating enzymes and mediates formation of predominantly K11-linked polyubiquitin chains. The crystal structure of the XopL C-terminal domain revealed a single domain with a novel fold, termed XL-box, not present in any previously characterized E3 ligase. The E3 ligase activity is required for XopL-induced plant cell death, while suppression of PAMP responses solely depends on the N-terminal LRR domain. The unique structural fold of the E3 ubiquitin ligase domain within XopL highlights the variation in bacterial pathogen effectors mimicking this eukaryote-specific activity.
The RV254 cohort was used to study T helper- B cell responses in acute HIV infection and the impact of early antiretroviral treatment (ART) on T and B cell function. The function of circulating T follicular helper cells (cTfh) from this cohort was examined, and cTfh and memory B cell populations were phenotyped. Impaired cTfh cell function was observed in individuals treated in stage 3 when compared to stage 1/2. This coincided with lower IL-10 and increased RANTES and TNF-α, suggesting a role for inflammation in altering cTfh and B cell responses. Elevated plasma viral load in stage 3 was found to correlate with decreased cTfh-mediated B cell IgG production, indicating a role for increased viremia in cTfh impairment and dysfunctional humoral response. Phenotypic perturbations were also evident in the mature B cell compartment, most notably a decrease in resting memory B cells in stage 3 compared to stage 1/2, coinciding with higher viremia. These data suggest that early ART for acutely HIV infected individuals could prevent immune dysregulation while preserving cTfh function and B cell memory. This is important as antiretroviral treatment (ART) has been pivotal in reducing the viral burden in persons infected with HIV, but the concurrent decline in the HIV-specific T and B cell memory response poses a great risk, as treatment interruption can lead to a loss in the control of viremia. The need to identify immune parameters that are associated with preservation of the memory response during HIV infection is therefore important to providing clues for therapies going forward.
Schistosomiasis, a tropical parasitic disease affecting approximately 200 million people worldwide, is currently treated with the drug praziquantel (PZQ). However, the drug has several less than ideal features, such as lack of understanding of its mechanism, inability to improve it through chemical derivatization, inability to kill all parasitic life cycle stages, and sub-optimal cure rates in the field. To address these issues, researchers have been looking for new drug targets. One potential target is a schistosome serotonergic G protein coupled receptor (Sm. 5HTR) that has been shown to be involved in the efficacy of PZQ. In a recent study, the researchers profiled the Sm. 5HTR using a miniaturized screening assay compatible with high content screening. The assay uses a split luciferase based biosensor that is sensitive to cellular cAMP levels and resolves the proximal kinetics of GPCR modulation in intact cells. The results showed a divergent pharmacological signature between the parasitic serotonergic receptor and the closest human GPCR homolog (Hs. 5HTR7), supporting the feasibility of optimizing parasitic selective pharmacophores. New ligands and chemical series with potency and selectivity for Sm. 5HTR over Hs. 5HTR7 were identified in vitro and validated for in vivo efficacy against schistosomules and adult worms. The study suggests that Sm. 5HTR is a promising target for the development of next generation anthelmintics.
"Gastrulation, a crucial step in the development of many organisms, involves the formation of the three germ layers - ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm - and their organization into the basic body structure. The separation of these germ layers has been traditionally explained by the Differential Adhesion Hypothesis, which suggests that adhesion differences between cell populations lead to their separation and positioning. However, recent studies have shown that the ectoderm-mesoderm boundary serves not only to keep these germ layers separated but also as a substratum for mesoderm migration and as a site for tissue separation. This mechanism relies on localized responses to signals exchanged at the tissue boundary and an attachment/detachment cycle that allows for cell migration across a cellular substratum.The separation of the ectoderm and mesoderm has been studied extensively in Xenopus, where the boundary between these two germ layers, Brachet's cleft, must permit mesoderm movement yet prevent invasion of the ectoderm. The molecular control of separation behavior is partly known and involves non-canonical Wnt signaling, interaction of Xfz7 with paraxial protocadherin and with the ankyrin repeat domain protein 5, and activation of RhoA and Rho kinase. A candidate for the proximal mechanism that generates the boundary is ephrin/Eph signaling. This signaling pathway involves Eph receptor tyrosine kinases, which are subdivided into EphA and EphB subclasses, and their membrane-linked ephrin ligands. Within subclasses, binding appears promiscuous, and receptor ligation and clustering initiate ""forward signaling,"" while receptor-ligand interaction can also stimulate ""reverse signaling"" downstream of the ephrin ligand.Ephrin/Eph signaling has been implicated in boundary formation, and experiments have shown that it can regulate cell adhesion, migration, and sorting in the early Xenopus embryo. Furthermore, the behavior of ectodermal and mesodermal cells at the boundary has been observed in living tissues, and results indicate that contact-induced detachment between ectodermal and mesodermal cells is at the base of a tissue separation mechanism supportive of cell movement at the interface.Experiments in an in vitro assay have shown that ephrinB-Fc treatment of ectoderm tissues causes tissue separation, indicating that an EphB receptor is present on ectodermal cells and that its stimulation by ephrinB can immediately induce tissue separation. These results suggest that increasing ephrinB levels is sufficient to trigger separation and that the differences in ephrin composition between ectodermal and mesodermal tissues play a role in the formation of the ectoderm-mesoderm boundary. Further studies are needed to fully understand the role of ephrin/Eph signaling in tissue separation and the mechanisms underlying this process."
The number of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) cases has increased significantly over the past four decades, with diagnoses currently based on behavioral observations and psychometric tools due to limited biological knowledge. However, the inclusion of biochemical data in ASD diagnosis is expected to enable earlier and more accurate diagnoses. A study analyzing metabolite concentrations from the folate-dependent one-carbon metabolism and transulfuration pathways in blood samples of 83 participants with ASD and 76 age-matched neurotypical peers demonstrated the potential of this approach. Using Fisher Discriminant Analysis and kernel partial least squares, the study achieved a 96.1% correct classification rate for neurotypical participants and a 97.6% rate for the ASD cohort, outperforming previous methods. These results indicate a strong correlation between the metabolites under consideration and an ASD diagnosis, and highlight the potential of statistical analysis techniques for extracting valuable information from complex biochemical datasets. ASD is a group of early-onset neurological diseases characterized by social communication/interaction difficulties and expression of restricted repetitive behaviors and interests. Twin studies suggest a heritability of 37-55% for ASD, and environmental factors such as maternal/paternal age, toxic chemical exposure, and maternal rubella infection are also emerging as key contributors to ASD liability. Despite the strong genetic association, only 15% of ASD cases have a known genetic source. Abnormalities in folate-dependent one-carbon metabolism (FOCM) and transsulfuration (TS) contribute to the genetic and environmental predisposition to ASD, with several genes in these pathways associated with increased ASD risk. Environmental toxins such as prenatal valproate use, toxic chemicals, heavy metals, and air pollutants have also been linked to ASD predisposition. Identifying biomarkers supporting the diagnosis process is an ongoing area of research, with FOCM/TS dysfunction being a potential contributor to ASD etiology. Advanced modeling and statistical analysis tools can help distinguish ASD from neurotypical participants based on FOCM/TS metabolites and reveal strong correlations between metabolite concentrations and adaptive behavior.
Leishmaniasis, a group of tropical diseases, affects 350 million people in 98 countries, with an estimated 2 million cases annually. Brazil is one of the most severely affected countries. A study used Bayesian geostatistical negative binomial models to analyze reported incidence data of cutaneous and visceral leishmaniasis in Brazil from 2001-2010. The study identified climatic, environmental, and socioeconomic risk factors, with precipitation and socioeconomic proxies being the most important for both types of leishmaniasis. The predicted number of cases in 2010 was 30,189 (SD: 7,676) for cutaneous leishmaniasis and 4,889 (SD: 288) for visceral leishmaniasis. The study's risk maps can help prioritize intervention areas and optimize resource allocation for control and elimination efforts.
Dengue has emerged as the most significant mosquito-borne viral illness worldwide, with an estimated 50 million symptomatic infections occurring annually. While traditionally affecting children, recent trends show an increase in hospitalization of young adults in Southeast Asia. This shift can be attributed to factors such as socioeconomic development, improved vector control, and changes in birth and death rates. Reports suggest that adults experience unusual complications with high mortality, including acute liver failure, encephalopathy, myocarditis, and acute renal failure, more frequently than children.A comparative study conducted in southern Vietnam between 2006 and 2008 analyzed 647 adults and 881 children with confirmed dengue. The study found that children had more frequent and severe signs of vascular leakage and shock, while bleeding manifestations and organ involvement were more common in adults. Adults also experienced significantly more severe thrombocytopenia. Secondary infection increased thrombocytopenia in both age groups, but adults had a smaller effect due to their intrinsically lower platelet counts compared to children. These findings highlight the importance of understanding age-related differences in dengue cases for developing appropriate management guidelines.In conclusion, the epidemiology of dengue is evolving, with a growing number of young adults requiring hospitalization. As the disease dynamics change, it is crucial to consider age-related differences in clinical presentation and disease progression to improve patient care and outcomes.
In contrast to HIV infection in humans and SIV in macaques, SIV infection in its natural host, the sooty mangabey (SM), is non-pathogenic despite robust virus replication. A novel SM CCR5 allele containing a two base pair deletion (Δ2) encoding a truncated molecule that is not expressed on the cell surface and does not support SIV entry in vitro has been identified in SM. This allele was present at a 26% frequency in a large SM colony, along with 3% for a CCR5Δ24 deletion allele. Overall, 8% of animals were homozygous for defective CCR5 alleles and 41% were heterozygous. The prevalence of natural SIVsmm infection was not significantly different in animals lacking functional CCR5 compared to heterozygous and homozygous wild-type animals. Furthermore, animals lacking functional CCR5 had robust plasma viral loads, which were only modestly lower than wild-type animals. SIVsmm primary isolates infected both homozygous mutant and wild-type PBMC in a CCR5-independent manner in vitro. These data indicate that SIVsmm relies on CCR5-independent entry pathways in SM and raises the possibility of novel CCR5-negative target cells that may be more expendable than CCR5+ cells and enable the virus to replicate efficiently without causing disease in the face of extremely restricted CCR5 expression seen in SM and several other natural host species. HIV and SIV entry into target cells is initiated by binding of the viral envelope glycoprotein (Env) to cell surface CD4, followed by structural changes that enable interactions with a seven transmembrane G protein coupled cell surface receptor that then triggers fusion. HIV-1 isolates use CCR5 or CXCR4 or both, and in vitro use other molecules infrequently. The restricted expression of CCR5 mainly on memory CD4+ T cells, but broader expression of CXCR4 on both memory and naïve subsets, is thought in part to underlie the accelerated disease progression seen in individuals in whom CXCR4-using HIV-1 variants emerge late in the course of infection. In contrast, SIV strains use CCR5 almost universally and very rarely use CXCR4. Sooty mangabeys express very low levels of CCR5 on their CD4+ T cells, a mechanism by which replication might be regulated in vivo and restrict transmission and pathogenesis. However, most strains of SIV use a number of other alternative coreceptors in vitro, such as CXCR6, the orphan receptors GPR1 and GPR15, and several others. Despite the efficient use of such alternative entry pathways by SIVmac and SIVsmm isolates in transfected cells, infection and cell targeting in vivo is generally thought to be dependent on CCR5. Notably, the proportion of CD4+ T cells depleted and/or infected at a given time in macaques and mangabeys may exceed the proportion of cells with detectable CCR5 expression, raising the possibility that other pathways in addition to CCR5 might be utilized.
MEF2, a family of transcriptional regulators, can have both pro-oncogenic and tumor suppressive activities depending on interacting partners. In leiomyosarcomas (LMS), MEF2's two-faced trait is relevant for tumor aggressiveness. Class IIa HDACs are overexpressed in 22% of LMS, and high levels of MEF2, HDAC4, and HDAC9 inversely correlate with overall survival. The knockout of HDAC9 suppresses the transformed phenotype of LMS cells. HDAC9 coordinates the demethylation of H3K4me3 at the promoters of MEF2-target genes. Class IIa HDACs do not bind all the regulative elements bound by MEF2, allowing for the coexistence of actively transcribed and strongly repressed MEF2-target genes in the same cell. These findings suggest that class IIa HDACs, particularly HDAC9, can be druggable targets for therapeutic intervention in LMS.
Hydrophobins are important proteins produced by filamentous fungi, with both biological and nanotechnological relevance. They affect the environment to promote fungal growth through their unique properties at interfaces. A study using protein docking, molecular dynamics simulation, and electron cryo-microscopy was conducted to analyze the surface structure of films composed of two class II hydrophobins (HFBI and HFBII) produced by Trichoderma reesei. The results suggest a unit cell composed of six proteins with P6 symmetry computationally and P3 symmetry experimentally, with a unit cell size of 56 Å. The study also discusses the possibility of an alternate ordering with a three protein unit cell and P3 symmetry, which could play a role in increasing the rate of surface coverage by hydrophobin films, indicating a mechanism of significance in both biology and nanotechnology. Hydrophobins have various industrial applications due to their unique interfacial film properties, including foams, protein immobilization, emulsification, and dispersion of insoluble compounds. The exceptional properties of hydrophobin films can be found on various interfaces, including liquid-liquid and gas-liquid interfaces. This summary focuses on the structure, mechanisms, and applications of HFBI and HFBII, two class II hydrophobins from Trichoderma reesei, which have potential industrial applications due to their ability to form amphiphilic 2D crystalline structures at the air-water interface.
This summary discusses a study on Leishmania donovani, the primary cause of visceral leishmaniasis. The study focuses on threonyl tRNA synthetase (ThrRS) of L. donovani, an enzyme required for protein synthesis in bacteria and fungi. Recombinant LdThrRS was expressed in E. coli and purified, and its kinetic parameters were determined. The subcellular localization of LdThrRS was found to be in both the cytosol and mitochondria of the cell. Heterozygous mutants of LdThrRS were generated in Leishmania promastigotes, and their proliferation, virulence, aminoacylation activity, and sensitivity to the ThrRS inhibitor, borrelidin, were studied. A 3D-model of LdThrRS was compared to that of humans and found to be similar. Borrelidin showed a strong affinity for LdThrRS (KD: 0.04 μM) and effectively inhibited the aminoacylation activity of rLdThrRS (IC50: 0.06 μM). Borrelidin inhibited the promastigotes stage of the parasites (IC50: 21 μM). The study suggests that LdThrRS is essential for L. donovani survival and is a potential target for drug discovery efforts.
In the field of virology, understanding how the innate immune response of mammalian cells responds to viral infections is crucial in developing therapeutic strategies. A study on the hepatitis C virus (HCV) has identified a multi-motif PAMP (pathogen-associated molecular pattern) signature of non-self recognition by RIG-I, a crucial protein involved in the innate immune response to RNA virus infection. The HCV PAMP motif drives potent RIG-I signaling to induce the innate immune response to infection. The study also highlights the importance of accurate discrimination of self from non-self by PRRs (pattern recognition receptors) and the role of multiple motifs in a PAMP that marks it as non-self to avoid self-recognition and subsequent autoimmunity. The research provides insights into the antiviral therapeutic potential of targeted RIG-I signaling activation, which could lead to innovative vaccine vectors and antiviral therapeutic strategies for controlling RNA virus infections. Overall, this study significantly contributes to the field of virology and innate immunity, offering a more profound understanding of the complex processes involved in the innate immune response.
The functions of eosinophils extend beyond host defense and allergy to metabolism and tissue regeneration, and have been found to promote growth of parasitic worms. A study investigating the mechanism of this observation focused on Trichinella spiralis larvae in skeletal muscle, finding that eosinophils promote larval growth by an IL-4 dependent mechanism that limits local interferon-driven responses that otherwise alter nutrient metabolism in infected muscle. This interaction allows for a nutrient-rich environment that facilitates larval growth. Parasitism in nematodes emerged in free-living nematodes as a result of multiple, independent evolutionary events and is associated with loss of functions that enable a free-living lifestyle. Understanding these dependencies is important for devising therapeutic and prophylactic approaches to controlling parasitic disease. Eosinophils, a hallmark of the host immune response to parasitic worms, have been shown to have varying influences on worms, from no effect to protecting the host to supporting the parasite. Eosinophils have also been found to have a regulatory influence on the outcome of worm infection through control of energy metabolism. The current study builds on previous findings of eosinophils positively regulating both survival and growth of Trichinella spiralis larvae, with larval survival dependent on eosinophil-derived interleukin (IL)-10 and growth supported by a distinct mechanism independent of IL-10. The study found a requirement for IL-4/signal transducers and activators of transcription 6 ( STAT6 ) signaling in eosinophils for normal larval growth. In the absence of eosinophils, there is a sustained, local, interferon-driven inflammation that promotes a shift in metabolism in infected muscle, altering nutrient availability for the larvae. The findings provide evidence for a host-parasite relationship in which the recruitment of eosinophils promotes a nutrient-rich environment that facilitates larval growth.
Genome-wide replication timing studies had suggested that mammalian chromosomes consist of megabase-scale domains of coordinated origin firing separated by large originless transition regions. However, a quantitative genome-wide analysis of DNA replication kinetics in several human cell types contradicts this view. Replication origins are spaced at 40 kb intervals and fire as small clusters whose synchrony increases during S phase, with a mean replication fork velocity of 0.7 kb/min and a maximum of 2 kb/min. There are no large regions of unidirectional fork progression, and temporal transition regions are replicated by sequential activation of origins at a rate that increases during S phase. Activation of internal origins in a specific temporal transition region is directly demonstrated by DNA combing of the IGH locus in HeLa cells. These findings challenge the deterministic replication timing program model and support a stochastic model for chromosomal replication, where origins fire independently of each other but under the control of long-range chromatin structure. These findings provide a general model for the replication kinetics of mammalian genomes.
The ability to recognize objects regardless of changes in position, lighting, or perspective is crucial for everyday tasks, and the brain performs this task with remarkable ease. However, even small changes in the position of an object can lead to vastly different stimuli on the level of primary sensory signals. Therefore, the brain must identify different stimuli as representations of the same underlying cause, which requires the development of an internal representation that is invariant to irrelevant changes of the stimulus. This is known as the slowness or temporal stability principle. The brain gathers information from the sensory input experienced during interaction with the environment to form invariant representations in a largely unsupervised manner. Slowness learning can be implemented through spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) with a specific learning window and is not just relevant for the learning window alone, but rather the convolution of the learning window with the postsynaptic potential. Slow feature analysis (SFA) and the trace rule can be derived from slowness learning, both of which are compatible with physiological data in shape and timescale. SFA consists of finding the input-output function that generates the most slowly varying output signal, which is required to be an instantaneous function of the input signal. SFA has been used to learn translation, rotation, and other invariances in a model of the visual system and has been shown to reproduce a wide range of features of complex cells in primary visual cortex. However, as a technical algorithm, SFA is biologically implausible, and the eigenvector that corresponds to the smallest eigenvalue of the covariance matrix of the time derivative of a multidimensional signal must be extracted, which seems odd compared to what neurons are normally thought to do. Therefore, the goal is to show how this kind of computation can be realized in a spiking model neuron.
The development of drug resistance in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is a significant challenge in cancer therapy, and it is attributed to intrinsic and acquired resistance. Intrinsic resistance is primarily caused by genetic mutations, while acquired resistance can emerge during treatment due to phenotypic plasticity and drug-induced cell state transitions. A recent study shows that cooperative adaptation to therapy (CAT) is a previously unrecognized behavior in heterogeneous tumors where cancer cells induce co-resistant phenotypes in neighboring cancer cells when exposed to cancer therapy. The study used a CRISPR/Cas9 toolkit to engineer phenotypically diverse NSCLC cells and monitored their three-dimensional growth dynamics under unstimulated or drug pressure conditions. The results showed that the combination of wild-type and mutants in co-cultures allowed for beneficial growth in previously drug-sensitive cells despite drug pressure via induction of cell state transitions. Furthermore, an ex vivo human tumor model predicted that cellular and morphologic heterogeneity correlates to prognostic failure of multiple clinically-approved and off-label drugs in individual NSCLC patient samples. Therefore, profiling for druggable targets alone may be insufficient to assign effective therapy.
The EMINI population cohort, consisting of 17,872 participants in Mbeya Region, Tanzania, was used to conduct a seroprevalence study on Spotted Fever Group (SFG) rickettsiae. A total of 1,228 participants above the age of 5 years were randomly selected and stratified by age, altitude of residence, and ownership of domestic mammals. The study found that the seroprevalence of SFG-seropositivity in the cohort was 67.9% (range among nine sites: 42.8--91.4%). Multivariable analysis revealed an association with age, warmer temperatures, male gender, and low population density. At higher elevations, higher cattle density was associated with higher seroprevalence. SFG rickettsial infection seems to be common in the more rural population of Mbeya Region, with the spread being further limited by temperature and higher elevation. Examination of the contribution of SFG to febrile illnesses seems warranted in a prospective study to estimate the disease burden in the population and determine the causative pathogens. The EMINI study was a population-based survey with longitudinal follow up, which was used to provide a representative sample of the population in the nine study sites. Blood samples were cryopreserved after cells were separated from serum, and serum samples were tested for antibodies against SFG-Rickettsia by indirect immunofluorescence. Uni- and multi-variable Poisson regression models with robust (or Huber-White) variance estimates adjusted for household clustering were used to identify possible risk factors for SFG IgG positivity.
The study reveals the role of the monounsaturated fatty acid oleate in the innate immune response of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. The researchers conducted an RNAi screen for regulators of innate immune defense genes and identified the two stearoyl-coenzyme A desaturases that synthesize oleate in C. elegans. They found that the synthesis of oleate is necessary for the pathogen-mediated induction of immune defense genes. C. elegans deficient in oleate production are hypersusceptible to infection with diverse human pathogens, which can be rescued by the addition of exogenous oleate. However, oleate is not sufficient to drive protective immune activation. These findings suggest an ancient link between nutrient stores, metabolism, and host susceptibility to bacterial infection. The study highlights the health-promoting effects of monounsaturated fatty acids and their role in regulating immune responses.
Riboswitches are regulatory elements that modulate gene expression in response to specific metabolite binding, with recent studies indicating that riboswitch agonists may have antimicrobial properties by binding to the riboswitch domain. Guanine riboswitches regulate the transport and biosynthesis of purine metabolites, which are critical for the nucleotides cellular pool. Upon guanine binding, these riboswitches stabilize a 5′-untranslated mRNA structure that causes transcription attenuation of the downstream open reading frame. A pyrimidine compound (PC1) was identified that binds guanine riboswitches, exhibiting bactericidal activity against a subgroup of bacterial species including nosocomial pathogens. This selective bacterial killing is only achieved when guaA, a gene coding for a GMP synthetase, is under the control of the riboswitch. Antibiotics binding to riboswitches provide novel antimicrobial compounds that can be rationally designed from riboswitch crystal structures. PC1 targets a different metabolic pathway, inhibiting multiple drug-resistant strains, making it a promising antimicrobial agent. This finding is significant as community-acquired bacterial infections have recently started to emerge, with multiple drug resistance being a growing problem due to the excessive use of antibiotics and limited chemical scaffolds for drug design.
A study on how gaze informs the construction of mental space during wayfinding in visual species like primates was conducted by examining the navigation behavior, visual exploration, and hippocampal activity of macaque monkeys as they searched a virtual reality maze for a reward. The findings indicate that counterparts of rodent place cells in primates embody multidimensional, task-situated knowledge pertaining to the target of gaze, thereby supporting self-awareness in the construction of space. Place cells, which are the quintessential signature of hippocampal neural activity in rodents and code the animal’s position in an environment, were found to be sensitive to one or more variables like head direction, point of gaze, or task context in primates. Hippocampal activity was best fit by a fine-grained state space comprising current position, view, and action contexts. These results suggest that the nature of hippocampal coding in primates, including humans, is multidimensional and task-situated, and bridges the gap between studies in rodents and primates in real and virtual environments.
The isthmic organizer (IsO) plays a crucial role in the development of vertebrates by controlling the development of the mid- and hindbrain. The IsO is characterized by a well-defined pattern of gene expression around the mid-hindbrain boundary (MHB) maintained by a regulatory network of transcription and secreted factors. This study uses a Boolean analysis of the characteristic spatial gene expression patterns at the murine MHB to predict key regulatory interactions in this network. The analysis reveals that Fgf8 has a maintaining, rather than inducing, effect on Wnt1 expression. This prediction is confirmed by mouse anterior neural plate/tube explant cultures. The findings allow for the construction of a regulatory network between key transcription and secreted factors at the MHB, which can explain the stable maintenance of the MHB and time-courses of expression patterns under wild-type and various knock-out conditions. The study demonstrates that spatial expression patterns can be used to gain information about the structure of regulatory networks and understand the maintenance of the MHB on a systems level.
The apicomplexan parasite Theileria annulata transforms infected host cells, inducing uncontrolled proliferation and clonal expansion. After sporozoite entry, the parasite develops into the transforming schizont, which remains tethered to host cell microtubules (MTs) and engages the cell's astral and central spindle MTs during mitosis and cytokinesis to ensure its distribution between the two daughter cells. The molecular mechanism by which the schizont recruits and stabilizes host cell MTs is unknown, but a new study has identified a key player in this process. The Theileria parasite surface protein p104, previously identified as a Theileria sporozoite microneme-rhoptry protein, functions as a bona fide EB1-binding protein, interacting with EB1 via a classic ‘SxIP’ motif. This is the first parasite-encoded EB1-binding protein described to date. EB1 is an important regulator of MT dynamics and a central component of the MT plus end protein interaction network. The study found that p104 recruits EB1 in vitro through a consensus SxIP motif located in a highly disordered C-terminal region, and that this interaction is cell cycle regulated. This discovery provides important new insight into the mode of interaction between Theileria and the host cell cytoskeleton, and highlights the potential of p104 as a target for the development of new anti-parasitic therapies.
In budding yeast, broken replication forks caused by replication passing through nicks, ligase insufficiency, or other DNA damage can result in persistent DNA damage and constitutive activation of the DNA damage checkpoint. This DNA damage can be repaired via homologous recombination or break-induced replication (BIR). In cases of mild insufficiency in the replicative ligase Cdc9, a population of cells with persistent DNA damage, activated DNA damage checkpoints, and longer telomeres arise. These longer telomeres are dependent on functional telomerase, the core DNA damage signaling cascade Mec1-Rad9-Rad5
Onchocerciasis, caused by the filarial nematode Onchocerca volvulus, is a major public health concern. Current diagnostic methods for onchocerciasis rely on detecting microfilariae in skin snips or using antibody-based tests, but these methods have limitations such as being invasive, lacking specificity, or not detecting pre-patent infections. A study was conducted to investigate the potential of using luciferase immunoprecipitation systems (LIPS) as a more rapid, specific, and standardized diagnostic assay for Onchocerca volvulus infection. The study tested four recombinantly produced Onchocerca volvulus antigens (Ov-FAR-1, Ov-API-1, Ov-MSA-1 and Ov-CPI-1) on a large cohort of blinded sera from uninfected controls and patients with a proven parasitic infection including Onchocerca volvulus (Ov), Wuchereria bancrofti (Wb), Loa loa (Ll), Strongyloides stercoralis (Ss), and other conditions. The results showed that antibody responses to the four different Ov antigens allowed for unequivocal differentiation between Ov-infected and uninfected control sera with 100% sensitivity and 100% specificity. The study also found that a mixture of the 4 Ov antigens simultaneously in the standard format or a quick 15-minute format, called QLIPS, showed 100% sensitivity and 100% specificity in distinguishing the Ov-infected sera from the uninfected control sera and had the best performance in distinguishing Ov from Wb, Ll, and Ss-infected sera with sensitivity and specificity values of 76%, 84% and 93% respectively. The multi-antigen LIPS assay can be used as a rapid, high throughput, and specific tool to not only to diagnose individual Ov infections but also as a sensitive and potentially point-of-care method for early detection of recrudescent infections in areas under control and for mapping new areas of transmission of Ov infection. This new diagnostic tool could be very useful for controlling and eliminating onchocerciasis.
