A study was conducted in two rural districts of Yen Bai province in northern Vietnam to evaluate the impact of weekly iron-folic acid supplementation and deworming on hematological and parasitological outcomes in women of reproductive age. The study, which included 389 women, found that after 54 months, mean hemoglobin increased from 122 g/L to 131 g/L, and anemia prevalence decreased from 38% to 18%. Iron deficiency and iron deficiency anemia were reduced to 8% and 4%, respectively. The prevalence of hookworm infection decreased from 76% to 11%, and moderate or heavy intensity infection with any soil transmitted helminth was reduced to less than 1%. However, results differed significantly between ethnic groups, with Kinh women having a lower prevalence of anemia and iron deficiency anemia at baseline compared to non-Kinh women. Despite an overall drop in compliance with taking iron-folic acid supplements at 54 months, the identified difference in non-compliance between Kinh and non-Kinh groups was not significant. Overall, the study found that population-based interventions can efficiently and effectively reduce anemia, iron deficiency anemia, and soil transmitted helminth infections in women of reproductive age, maintaining them below the level of public health concern. However, maintaining iron stores over extended periods through regular iron-folic acid supplementation is essential in areas with inadequate dietary intake of heme iron.
Cell-mediated immunity plays a crucial role in controlling viral infections, particularly against herpesviruses that can establish lifelong persistence despite primed immunity. Herpesviruses exploit immune evasion strategies, including reduced viral antigen expression during latency and targeting antigen presentation pathways. A prototypical herpesvirus, Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), encodes a novel immunoevasin, gp150, which inhibits antigen presentation by HLA class I, HLA class II, and CD1d molecules. Gp150's mechanism of T-cell escape does not involve degradation of antigen-presenting molecules and depends on its abundant glycosylation, creating a shield that impedes surface presentation of antigen. This is an unprecedented immune evasion mechanism for herpesviruses. EBV gp150 prolongs the timespan for producing viral offspring at the most vulnerable stage of the viral life cycle. Cell-mediated immunity, mediated by antigen-specific T cells, is essential for eliminating virus-infected cells, reducing viral replication, and stimulating other immune effector functions. CD8+ and CD4+ T cells are activated by peptide Ags presented at the cell surface in the context of HLA class I and class II molecules, while invariant natural killer T (iNKT) cells recognize lipid Ags presented by CD1d, a non-classical, non-polymorphic HLA molecule. In EBV infections, iNKT cells play a role in providing protection against viral infection. EBV downregulates its Ag expression in the latent stage of infection and exploits immune evasion gene products, particularly during its replicative phase, to interfere with immune activation. EBV gp150 interferes with immune recognition of HLA I, II, and CD1d/Ag complexes at the cell surface in a glycan-dependent manner, representing a novel immune evasion mechanism in herpesviruses.
Chlamydia trachomatis, the leading cause of preventable blindness worldwide and the most frequent sexually transmitted bacterial infection in the United States, is an obligate intracellular gram-negative bacterium with a developmental cycle involving extracellular infectious forms called elementary bodies (EB) and intracellular replicative reticulate bodies (RB) within a membrane-bound parasitophorous vacuole called an inclusion. The exact mechanisms of chlamydial attachment and entry into nonphagocytic cells are unclear, but the involvement of actin in the process is conserved across chlamydial species. The translocated actin recruiting phosphoprotein (Tarp) is conserved among pathogenic chlamydial species and has been identified as playing an essential role in chlamydial pathogenesis. Tarp harbors at least three functionally distinct domains: an N-terminal tyrosine-rich repeat domain, a proline-rich domain required for Tarp oligomerization, and an actin binding domain. The proline rich domain and actin binding domain are harbored within the minimum Tarp peptide required for Tarp mediated actin nucleation. Tarp orthologs from Chlamydia pneumonia, C. caviae, C. muridarum and various C. trachomatis serovars all harbor at least one and up to four functional actin binding domains and promote actin nucleation as determined by in vitro polymerization assays. These findings indicate that Tarp mediated actin binding and nucleation is a conserved feature among diverse chlamydial species and this function plays a critical role in bacterial invasion of host cells.
Schistosomiasis japonica is a zoonotic disease endemic in the People's Republic of China, the Philippines, and Indonesia, with over 40 mammalian species acting as reservoirs, including water buffaloes that contribute up to 75% to human transmission in China. A new copro-parasitological method, the formalin-ethyl acetate sedimentation-digestion (FEA-SD) technique, was developed to improve the visualization and quantification of S. japonicum eggs in bovine feces. This technique, which involves filtration, sedimentation, potassium hydroxide digestion, and centrifugation steps prior to microscopy, removes bulk debris and renders it translucent, allowing for improved microscopic visualization and accurate quantification of S. japonicum eggs in bovines and other ruminant reservoir hosts. The FEA-SD technique could be a valuable surveillance tool for animal reservoirs of S. japonicum, particularly in areas with low to high infection intensity or where there is suspected elimination of schistosomiasis japonica. The FEA-SD technique is as efficient as real-time PCR for determining schistosome prevalence in bovines but is less costly to implement. This new method can help improve the control and surveillance of schistosomiasis japonica by providing an accurate and cost-effective tool for identifying and quantifying S. japonicum eggs in bovines and other ruminant reservoir hosts.
In this study, researchers investigated the role of prolyl 3-hydroxylase 1 (P3H1) in recessive Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) by generating knock-in mice with a point mutation in the catalytic site of P3h1 (Lepre1H662A). This substitution abolished P3h1 activity but retained the ability to form a complex with Crtap and thus the collagen chaperone function. The knock-in mice showed absence of prolyl 3-hydroxylation at Pro986 of the α1 (I) and α1 (II) collagen chains but no significant over-modification at other collagen residues. They had normal appearance, no growth defects, and normal cartilage growth plate histology, but showed decreased trabecular bone mass. This new mouse model recapitulated elements of the bone phenotype of OI but not the cartilage and growth phenotypes caused by loss of the prolyl 3-hydroxylation complex. The findings suggest differential tissue consequences due to selective inactivation of P3H1 hydroxylase activity versus complete ablation of the prolyl 3-hydroxylation complex.In addition, the study also summarized previous findings about the role of mutations in genes encoding cartilage associated protein (CRTAP), P3H1, and cyclophilin B (CYPB) in recessive OI. Mutations in these genes can cause recessive forms of OI by altering post-translational collagen modification, trafficking, and signaling. Null mutations in either LEPRE1 or CRTAP can result in recessive forms of Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) with almost identical features, suggesting that P3H1 and CRTAP stabilize each other.Overall, this study provides insights into the function of P3H1 in OI and the potential consequences of selective inactivation of its hydroxylase activity, which could have implications for the development of targeted therapies for this genetic disorder.
The P-element, a DNA transposon, was horizontally transferred from a distant relative into Drosophila melanogaster, causing 'hybrid dysgenesis' and spreading globally. Recently, it has also been found in D. simulans, having been horizontally acquired from D. melanogaster. This invasion occurred rapidly and nearly simultaneously in regions surveyed, with strains containing P-elements becoming common by 2014. Transposable elements (TEs) like the P-element are genetically simple and can be beneficial but are often deleterious, causing DNA damage and mutations. Hybrid dysgenesis, exhibited by D. melanogaster crosses between 'P strains' and 'M strains', is caused by DNA damage from actively transposing P-elements in the germline. This damage is reduced in offspring protected by piRNAs sequestered in the egg cytoplasm, which target the P-element mRNA for degradation. TEs, like the P-element, can be vertically transmitted and horizontally transmitted between species, causing limited damage in the short-term and substantial damage in the long-term.
A recent study has explored the use of rhodamine B, a thiol-reactive fluorescent dye, for marking male Aedes aegypti mosquitoes in the context of sterile insect technique (SIT) and incompatible insect technique (IIT) control strategies. Rhodamine B can be administered to male mosquitoes via sugar-feeding, allowing for the dye to be transferred to females during mating and resulting in body marking. The study found that solutions containing 0.4% and 0.8% rhodamine B were the most effective at marking male body and seminal fluid, and that marking had no effect on male mating competitiveness. The use of rhodamine B marking is also less expensive and time-consuming compared to other methods such as PCR and protein/isotope labelling. This technique has the potential to be a useful evaluation method for male-based SIT/IIT control strategies and as a mark-release-recapture method for male mosquitoes.
Bacterial superantigens are toxic molecules produced by Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes that can cause toxic shock by activating an intense immune response. Superantigens bind directly to MHC-II and TCR molecules, activating up to 20% of T cells and inducing Th1 cytokines such as IL-2, INF-γ, and TNF. Superantigens also require CD28 costimulation to induce cytokine gene expression. A study found that superantigens must bind directly into the dimer interface of CD28 to elicit inflammatory cytokine gene expression and toxicity. Mice were protected from lethal superantigen challenge by short peptide mimetics of the CD28 dimer interface and by peptides selected to compete with the superantigen for its binding site in CD28. Structural analysis showed that when a superantigen binds to the T cell receptor on the T cell and major histocompatibility class II molecule on the antigen-presenting cell, CD28 can be accommodated readily as a third superantigen receptor in the quaternary complex, with the CD28 dimer interface oriented towards the β-strand/hinge/α-helix domain in the superantigen. The study identifies the CD28 homodimer interface as a critical receptor target for superantigens and broadens the scope of pathogen recognition mechanisms.
The use of pluripotent stem cells in the clinic requires an understanding of the mechanisms regulating their cell cycle, proliferation, and potency. Embryonic stem cells (ESCs) have a fast cell cycle with a short G1 phase due to the lack of expression of cell cycle inhibitors, which determines naïve pluripotency and holds back differentiation. The Wnt/β-catenin pathway controls mESC pluripotency via the Wnt-effector Tcf3, but its role in controlling the cell cycle of mESCs is unclear. This pathway, known to be mitogenic in somatic tissues, triggers an anti-proliferative effect in mESCs via Tcf1 activity. Tcf1 is recruited to the promoters of cell cycle genes such as the Ink4/Arf locus, leading to an increase in negative cell cycle regulators such as p15Ink4b, p16Ink4a, and p19Arf upon Wnt pathway activation. These findings show that, in contrast to its mitogenic effect in somatic cells, the Wnt/β-catenin pathway has an anti-proliferative effect in mESCs via Tcf1 activity. This is important because mESCs are believed to be refractory to the action of some CDKi as p16Ink4a, but an increased expression of p21 or p27 can increase the length of mESC G1 and reduce their proliferation. The Ink4/Arf locus, which encodes for p15Ink4b, p16Ink4a and p19Arf, controls the two main cell cycle inhibitors and tumor suppressor pathways, and its expression is upregulated after Wnt pathway activation in mESCs. These findings highlight the potential of Wnt/Tcf1 in regulating mESC proliferation and have implications for the use of mESCs in regenerative medicine.
Dengue fever (DF) is a viral infection caused by the dengue virus (DENV) and can lead to a wide range of clinical manifestations, from asymptomatic to severe and even fatal outcomes. The severity of DF has been associated with high viral load and exacerbated cytokine production. DENV can infect and replicate in human monocytes/macrophages and dendritic cells, which can release soluble mediators that contribute to vascular permeability and plasma leakage. Dendritic cells can be divided into two major subpopulations: myeloid or conventional dendritic cells (cDCs) and plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs). Unlike cDCs, pDCs are not found in homeostatic tissues and are mainly found in circulating blood and in lymphoid tissues. pDCs can produce large amounts of type I interferon (IFN-α) in response to virus exposure.In this study, the authors aimed to characterize pDC activation in dengue patients and their function under DENV-2 stimulation in vitro. They found that pDCs of mild dengue patients exhibit significantly higher frequencies of mTRAIL (membrane TRAIL) compared to severe cases or healthy controls. Plasma levels of IFN-α and soluble TRAIL were also increased in mild compared to severe dengue patients, positively correlating with pDC activation. In vitro exposure to DENV-2 induced mTRAIL expression on pDC, which was relocalized from intracellular compartment to plasma membrane. Chloroquine treatment inhibited DENV-2-induced mTRAIL relocalization and IFN-α production by pDC, suggesting the involvement of endocytosis pathway in DENV-2 infection. Coculture of pDC/DENV-2-infected monocytes revealed a dramatic decrease of antigen detection, indicating that pDC effect on viral load reduction was mainly dependent on IFN-α production. These data suggest that pDC activation and TRAIL-expressing pDCs may have an important role in the outcome of dengue disease.
The immune response to Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection is complex and involves the role of tumor necrosis factor (TNF) in host defense during both active and latent phases of infection. Experimental evidence has shown that TNF-neutralizing drugs increase the risk of tuberculosis (TB), and animal studies support this finding. A computational approach was taken to characterize the role of TNF in protection against the tubercle bacillus in both active and latent infection. The study found that bioavailability of TNF following anti-TNF therapy is the primary factor for causing reactivation of latent infection and that sTNF is essential for control of infection. The study suggests that a TNF-modulating agent could be developed to balance the requirement for reduction of inflammation with the necessity to maintain resistance to infection and microbial diseases. The importance of TNF in control of TB is highlighted by an increased susceptibility of patients to TB reactivation. The incidence of TB in individuals receiving antibody appears to be higher than in those treated with receptor fusion molecule, suggesting that there are differences in the mode of action of these agents. Simulations predict that with an inoculum of 25 mycobacteria, latency is achieved in fewer than 300 days under appropriate immunologic conditions. Latent TB is characterized by low levels of extracellular bacterial load and all intracellular bacteria reside within a small number of chronically infected macrophages. During latency, TNF levels are on the order of 0.12 pg/mL, and neutralizing this concentration of TNF drives the system into active TB, indicating a critical role for even small amounts of TNF in maintaining latency. Predicted ranges for IFN-γ and IL-10 correlate with studies measuring cytokine levels at the infection site. Total macrophage numbers do not change significantly in the first year post-infection, and most of them become infected by one year post-infection. The roles played by different cellular sources of TNF involved in protective immunity remain unclear. The mathematical model can simulate active infection, which is characterized by uncontrolled growth of intracellular and extracellular bacteria throughout the simulation, reaching a total bacterial load of 108 per cm3 of granulomatous tissue approximately at day 300. High bacterial load is coupled to very high levels of IFN-γ and TNF. Total macrophage population increases within the first 200 days, and by one year post-infection most of them are infected. T cell numbers are comparable with macrophage numbers during active TB. Among all TNF-related mechanisms, lymphocyte recruitment and macrophage activation are the most influential toward controlling bacterial levels when compared with TNF-induced apoptosis. The model predicts that enhanced recruitment of lymphocytes is a desirable strategy toward establishing latency. Little or no data are available to indicate the fraction of TNF that is cleaved into sTNF in vivo. We introduce a parameter σ to indicate the fraction of TNF cleaved. The remaining (1−σ)Fα represents tmTNF. Considering the relative transient expression of tmTNF in vitro, we assume that σ is approximately 95% so that the majority of tmTNF is cleaved and released in its bioactive soluble form. We test variations on levels of σ (percent sTNF) and report results in two settings. The system gradually shifts to higher bacterial loads with decreasing amounts of sTNF, and reactivation occurs when almost no sTNF is released. This suggests sTNF is necessary to control active TB and to maintain latency, likely because of its crucial role in lymphocyte and macrophage recruitment, and that tmTNF is not sufficient to maintain latency in humans. We investigate the importance of specific TNF-dependent mechanisms that allow for infection control via sensitivity and uncertainty analyses. We observe how variations in different sets of parameters affect bacterial load. The model predicts that enhanced recruitment of lymphocytes is a desirable strategy toward establishing latency. Macrophage activation plays a more important role in maintaining latency: the correlation between macrophage activation rate and bacterial load is significant only after latency is achieved. TmTNF effects on macrophage and lymphocyte activation are not significant in either achieving or maintaining latency. Among all TNF-related mechanisms, the uncertainty and sensitivity analyses indicate that lymphocyte recruitment and macrophage activation are the most influential toward controlling bacterial levels when compared with TNF-induced apoptosis. This is consistent with experimental evidence that TNF-induced apoptosis accounts for only 5%-10% killing of MIs. Our virtual deletion and depletion experiments are consistent with TNF gene knockouts and TNF neutralization studies, further supporting that TNF is necessary toward both achieving and maintaining latency.
Gene retroposition, which involves the creation of intronless copies of existing genes through reverse transcription of mRNAs and subsequent insertion into the genome, leads to significant genetic variation between individuals. Recent studies have revealed the presence of at least 208 retroduplication variations (RDVs) in individual genomes, mainly resulting from recent retroduplications. In this study, the researchers used data from Phase 1 of the 1000 Genomes Project, RNA-Seq data from the Illumina BodyMap project, and data from lymphoblastoid cell lines provided by the Geuvadis Consortium to investigate variation in the loss of ancestral retrocopies among different human populations and examine retrocopy expression levels. The researchers also developed a new approach to detect novel retrocopies absent from the reference human genome and experimentally confirmed their presence or absence in the genomes of 17 different populations.The study identified 193 RDVs, the majority of which resulted from retrocopy deletion. Most of these RDVs had not been previously reported. The expression, conservation, and low rate of deletion of ten retrocopies suggest some functionality. The researchers also found nine retrogenes that undergo statistically significant differential expression between populations.Retrogenes can be functional and play a role in various biological processes and diseases. For instance, the RHOB gene, a tumor suppressor that belongs to the Rho GTPases family, is a retrocopy involved in cancer development. Additionally, retroposition gives rise to considerable genetic variation between individuals and provides valuable insights into evolutionary processes and population history.Despite the advances in sequencing technology and the increasing number of studies on retrocopies, many questions remains unanswered. Current methods of discovering novel retropositions are limited and do not account for evolutionary events that occurred earlier in the human lineage. Additionally, single nucleotide polymorphisms located in retrogene promoters and regulatory sequences might result in different levels of retrogene expression between individuals and populations, but this has not been thoroughly explored.Overall, this study contributes to the growing body of evidence on the importance of retroposition in shaping genetic variation, evolutionary processes, and disease development. Further research is needed to understand the functional aspects of different kinds of retrogene polymorphisms and their potential implications for human health and disease.
Neurocysticercosis (NCC), an infection of the central nervous system by the larval stage of the parasitic helminth Taenia solium, is a common disease in regions where pigs are raised freely. NCC is a major cause of epileptic seizures in developing countries and can affect the brain parenchyma, cerebellum, brainstem, ventricles, subarachnoid space, and spine. The two main forms of NCC are parenchymal and extraparenchymal disease, with different clinical presentations, pathophysiology, and treatment. A study was conducted to quantify and compare the inflammatory response following cysticidal treatment to cysticerci located in the brain parenchyma, meninges, or both tissues in a naturally infected pig model. The results showed that parenchymal cysticerci provoked a significantly greater level of pericystic inflammation after antiparasitic treatment compared to meningeal and corticomeningeal cysticerci. The suboptimal inflammatory response to cysticidal drugs in meningeal cysticerci may be the reason subarachnoid NCC is generally refractory to treatment compared to parenchymal NCC. The vessels in parenchymal and meningeal tissue differ in their constitutive proteins, susceptibility to changes in permeability of the blood-brain barrier (BBB), expression of cytokines that regulate BBB function, and associated astrocytes. These tissue-specific characteristics could explain the differences in inflammation around the cysticercus in experimental murine models and thus be involved in the severity of the inflammatory reaction elicited when the parasite degenerates.
Yaws, a re-emerging endemic treponemal infection caused by Treponema pallidum ssp . pertenue, is reportedly endemic in Ghana, with azithromycin mass distribution being the cornerstone of the WHO yaws eradication campaign. A cross-sectional survey was conducted in thirty communities in two districts of Ghana where MDA for trachoma had previously been conducted to investigate the possibility of drug-resistant T. pallidum ssp . pertenue or alternative causes of some of the reported cases. Children aged 5-17 years with ulcerative lesions compatible with yaws were enrolled, and samples for treponemal serology and lesion PCR were collected. Of the 90 children enrolled, syphilis serology was negative in all, and PCR for T. pallidum ssp pertenue was negative in all children. However, Haemophilus ducreyi DNA was detected in 9 lesions. The study found no evidence of ongoing transmission of yaws in these communities, and H. ducreyi was associated with a proportion of skin lesions, but the majority of lesions remain unexplained. Integration of diagnostic testing into both pre and post-MDA surveillance systems is required to better inform yaws control programs. The findings emphasize the urgent need for accurate data on the epidemiology of yaws to guide disease eradication efforts and the importance of serological testing in surveillance to better inform national reporting data and yaws control programs.
The Jak-STAT pathway plays a crucial role in the persistence of HIV infection, as it regulates T cell homeostasis, particularly in memory T cells where the virus resides. Cytokines involved in memory T cell homeostasis trigger the Jak-STAT pathway, leading to increased levels of integrated viral DNA. Two FDA-approved Jak inhibitors, tofacitinib and ruxolitinib, have been found to block seeding and maintenance of the HIV reservoir in vitro. These inhibitors reduce the frequency of CD4+ T cells harboring integrated HIV DNA, block viral production from infected cells, and inhibit IL-15-induced viral reactivation from latent stores. This prevents transmission of infectious particles to bystander activated T cells. In vivo, Jak inhibitors impact the magnitude of the HIV reservoir in all memory CD4 T cell subsets. The Jak-STAT pathway is also triggered by type I and II Interferons, which enhance HIV replication. Inhibition of Jak-STAT signaling by ruxolitinib has been shown to significantly impede T cell homeostasis, reduce CD4 T cell numbers, and decrease numbers of T regulatory cells and activated (HLA-DR+) CD4 T cell populations after a few weeks of treatment. Tofacitinib, on the other hand, showed only small changes in CD3+, CD4+, and CD8+ counts and an increase in B cell counts after 24 weeks of treatment. Overall, Jak inhibitors represent a therapeutic modality to prevent key events of T cell activation that regulate HIV persistence and could be integrated into future curative strategies.
Baculoviruses are large DNA viruses that infect arthropods, particularly insects from the orders Lepidoptera, Diptera, and Hymenoptera. They have a long history of use as microbial insecticides to control insect pest populations in forestry and agriculture. Baculovirus infection impacts a host in various ways, affecting different tissues and cell types differently. Insects have innate immune responses to virus infections, including cellular and humoral responses that share the same signalling pathways. These responses involve hemocyte-mediated activities like phagocytosis, nodulation, and encapsulation, as well as the identification of invading microbes by pattern recognition proteins and the synthesis of antimicrobial peptides (AMPs). The production of AMPs in insects is regulated by the Toll, Imd, and JAK-STAT signalling pathways.Recent research has shown that the insect immune protein hemolin is involved in baculovirus infection. In the Lepidopteran host Antheraea pernyi, baculovirus infection induces the expression of hemolin, and silencing of hemolin affects the progress of viral infection. However, this may not be the case for all insects, as another study found no changes in the expression of hemolin after infection with baculovirus in two species of Lepidoptera.Immune-related genes are regulated after baculovirus infection, indicating their involvement in the response to baculovirus. After being ingested by the insect, baculoviruses reach the gut, one of the main physical barriers for the establishment of a systemic infection in the larvae. Immune aspects in insects were initially studied in the hemolymph and fat body, but recent research has also focused on the gut. Gut epithelial tissue has been found to express pattern recognition proteins as well as antimicrobial proteins, indicating that the gut plays an important role in the immune responses of insects. The immune system faces an enormous challenge in gut tissue, as it must continuously confront microbiota present in the gut lumen.Gut microbiota are involved in various physiological functions, including digesting food and protecting against pathogen infections by occupying attachment sites, competing for nutrients, and preventing colonization. Commensal microbiota present in the gut modulate insect immune responses and insect susceptibility to pathogens such as Bacillus thuringeiensis. In vertebrates, gut commensal microbiota play a crucial role in the immune responses to pathogens and shape the gut immune system. The knowledge of genes affected by virus infection may serve to improve baculoviruses as heterologous protein expression vectors and as biocontrol agents.
A team of researchers have isolated and characterized a novel gene, OSD1, in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana that controls entry into the second meiotic division. By combining a mutation in this gene with two other mutations that affect key meiotic processes, the team created a genotype called MiMe, in which meiosis is replaced by mitosis. This allows the plants to produce functional diploid gametes that are genetically identical to their mother. This research is an important step towards understanding and engineering apomixis, asexual reproduction through seeds, which has the potential to revolutionize agriculture by allowing any desired genotype to be perpetuated through successive seed generations. The OSD1 gene is conserved throughout the plant kingdom and its paralogue, UVI4, is necessary for maintaining the mitotic state. The team hypothesizes that OSD1 may fine tune APC activity/cyclin levels at the end of meiosis I to ensure the transition to meiosis II. Further research is needed to introduce apomixis, which consists of apomeiosis, parthenogenesis, and the initiation of endosperm development, into a sexual plant species. However, the strong conservation of the genes involved in the MiMe genotype among plants suggests that apomixis may be engineered in any plant species, including crops.
The prioritization of candidate disease-causing genes is crucial in the post-genomic era and is typically based on protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks. However, current methods use a static picture of human PPIs, which may not accurately represent the specific tissues impacted by diseases. To address this, a study has constructed tissue-specific PPI networks for 60 tissues by integrating tissue-specific gene expression data with PPI information. The results show that tissue-specific PPI networks significantly improve the prioritization of results compared to those obtained using a generic PPI network. This approach also allows for the prediction of novel disease-tissue associations, which can point to sub-clinical tissue effects that may escape early detection. The study of tissue-specific PPI networks is still relatively unexplored, but has the potential to enhance the accuracy of existing network-based gene prioritization algorithms and provide insight into the molecular basis of hereditary diseases.
The article discusses a flexible two-locus model for the spread of insecticide resistance in mosquito species that transmit human diseases such as malaria. The model allows for differential exposure of males and females to high or low concentrations of insecticide, and allows selection pressures and dominance values to differ depending on the concentration of insecticide encountered. The authors demonstrate the model's application by investigating the use of insecticides either sequentially or mixed together to minimize the spread of resistance. The model recovers previously published results and conducts a sensitivity analysis over an extensive parameter space to identify the circumstances that favor mixtures over sequences. The results show that both strategies lasted more than 500 mosquito generations, but in those runs where resistance had spread to high levels by 500 generations, 56% favored sequential use and 44% favored mixtures. The authors emphasize that the paper is about designing and implementing a flexible modelling strategy to investigate the spread of insecticide resistance in vector populations and demonstrate how the model can identify vector control strategies most likely to minimize the spread of insecticide resistance. Insect populations are controlled for various reasons such as pests, nuisance-biting mosquitoes, and to control the spread of vector-borne infectious diseases. The World Health Organization estimates that 17% of all infectious diseases are vector-borne. This manuscript focuses on the control of mosquitoes responsible for transmitting human malaria, which is the target of considerable public health efforts through the deployment of insecticide-treated bed nets and insecticides sprayed onto house walls. However, these efforts have resulted in the evolution of insecticide resistance (IR) in mosquito populations. The article discusses four main strategies that may potentially be used as insecticide deployment strategies, including sequential use, mixtures, rotations, and mosaics. The authors highlight the need for a planned and rational way to deploy new insecticide products in a planned and rational way to minimize selection for resistance while maintaining their impact in disease control.
The sialome of Rhodnius neglectus, a triatomine insect that acts as a vector for Chagas disease, was studied using next generation sequencing and mass spectrometry. A total of 4,230 coding DNA sequences (CDS) were deposited in GenBank, with 73 of them confirmed by proteomic analysis. The sialome of R. neglectus was found to contain serine protease transcripts and families of proteins that are common in hematophagous arthropods, including lipocalins, serine protease inhibitors, and antigen-5. Metalloproteases, disintegrins, and odorant binding protein families were less abundant. The data provides new insights into the complex interplay between hematophagous vectors and their vertebrate hosts and aids in understanding the dynamics of the blood-feeding process and disease transmission. The RNA-seq sequencing generated over 12 million reads, which were mapped to contigs and annotated using various databases. Coding sequences were classified into putative secreted, housekeeping, unknown, transposable element, and viral product classes. The housekeeping class was the largest, followed by the secreted class which included subclasses with previously known gene families present in hematophagous saliva, such as lipocalin, nitrophorin, antigen-5, as well as gene families not commonly reported in triatomine saliva, such as serine protease and disintegrin. Lipocalins were one of the most abundant groups of transcripts, with 16.29% of putatively secreted reads. These proteins are usually found in blood-sucking insect and tick saliva and are associated with binding to small hydrophobic molecules, cell surface receptors, or other proteins.
The post-genomic era has seen a significant increase in high-throughput technologies, with transcriptional profiling by microarrays being one of the most widely used. This technology has been applied to identify genes differentially expressed in response to different environmental conditions, with the assumption that such genes are functionally important under those conditions. However, it remains unclear whether differential expression is predictive of functional importance. To address this question, this study employed Caenorhabditis elegans as a model for the interaction of native soil nematode taxa and soil bacteria. Researchers used transcriptional profiling to identify candidate genes regulated in response to different bacteria isolated in association with grassland nematodes or from grassland soils. They then used mutations to inactivate 21 of the identified genes and demonstrated that most of these genes contribute to lifespan and/or fitness in a given bacterial environment. These findings suggest that changes in food source, such as those that occur in environmental disturbances, can have a large effect on gene expression and have important consequences for fitness. The study also used regression analysis to show that for many genes, the degree of differential gene expression between two bacterial environments predicted the magnitude of the effect of the loss of gene function on life history traits in those environments. Overall, this study highlights the potential of using transcriptional profiling and genetic analysis to understand the genetic mechanisms underlying organismal responses to environmental changes.
A critical event in mammalian embryo development is the formation of an inner cell mass (ICM) surrounded by a trophoectoderm (TE), which is a shell of cells that later form extra-embryonic structures. A study using multi-scale, stochastic modeling investigated the design principles responsible for the robust establishment of these structures. The investigation made three key predictions, all supported by quantitative imaging. First, stochasticity in the expression of critical genes promotes cell plasticity and has a crucial role in accurately organizing the developing mouse blastocyst. Second, asymmetry in the levels of noise variation (expression fluctuation) of Cdx2 and Oct4 provides a means to gain the benefits of noise-mediated plasticity while ameliorating the potentially detrimental effects of stochasticity. Third, by controlling the timing and pace of cell fate specification, the embryo temporally modulates plasticity and creates a time window during which each cell can continually read its environment and adjust its fate. These results suggest that noise has a crucial role in maintaining cellular plasticity and organizing the blastocyst. This is crucial for the development of mammals, where a single cell gives rise to an organism of exquisite complexity. The fertilized egg begins this process by dividing multiple times to form a morula, which then undergoes compaction to create the blastocyst. Each cell of the early cleavage stage embryo is considered to be totipotent and can differentiate to become either the ICM, which mainly gives rise to the future embryo, or the TE, which forms extra-embryonic structures. This lineage divergence is the first differentiation event in mammalian development and is an intensely studied process in mammalian reproductive biology. ICM and TE cell populations are distinguished by both their spatial position within an embryo and gene expression differences. Structurally, the ICM is located in the interior of the blastocyst and the TE forms an outer layer surrounding it. Molecularly, Pou5f1/Oct4, Nanog, and Sox2 transcription factors (TFs) specify ICM cells, while Tead4 and Cdx2 TFs specify the TE. Interplay among these TFs is critical in specifying the ICM and TE cell fates. A preimplantation mouse embryo interprets various types of information and coordinates the cellular response to produce a normal blastocyst. Although lineage biasing of blastomeres might start as early as the 4-cell stage, the embryo is a dynamic entity and each cell at this stage maintains the ability to give rise to both embryonic and extra-embryonic tissues. Removal of a blastomere (s) of the cleavage stage embryo can accommodate the loss of cells and still generate normal embryos. The extraordinary adaptability and robustness of the system beg the question of what mechanism governs the earliest cell lineage decision-making process in mammals. Time-lapse microscopy has been used to study lineage allocation in unmanipulated mouse embryos. Results show that 95% of cells maintained their position after the 32-cell stage, and the identity of the remaining 5% of cells was unknown. Independently, by carefully following the movement of each cell between 8-32-cell stages, it was found that an average of 1.5 cells per embryo move away from the surface of the embryo toward inside during the segregation of ICM and TE cells. These dynamic cell movements suggest that a robust organizational mechanism must exist for both constructing the proper embryonic architecture and correcting organizational mistakes that arise over time from stochastic motion and division of cells.
This work investigates the flexibility of germline gene-encoded antibodies to bind to various antigens, with binding affinity and specificity increasing as antibody genes acquire somatic mutations in antigen-stimulated B cells. The researchers determined the basis for recognition of diverse antigens by antibodies encoded by three VH gene segments and computationally redesigned panels of somatically mutated antibodies to predict antibodies that could engage multiple antigens at once. The Rosetta multi-state design process predicted antibody sequences for the entire heavy chain variable region, including framework, CDR1, and CDR2 mutations. The predicted sequences closely matched the germline gene sequences, revealing residues that enable polyspecificity, or binding of many unrelated antigens with a common sequence, thereby reversing antibody maturation in silico. This approach captures important aspects of antibody/antigen recognition, identifying key positions in the VH gene encoding CDR1, CDR2, and the immunoglobulin framework that contribute to polyspecificity in germline antibodies. Computational design of antibodies capable of binding multiple antigens may allow the rational design of antibodies that retain polyspecificity for diverse epitope binding, facilitating the development of antibody-based therapeutics and diagnostics.
Locusts exhibit two behavioral phases, solitarious and gregarious, with crowded conditions promoting transition to the gregarious phase. A model is constructed to predict the dynamics of hopper band formation at the population level, using a partial integrodifferential equation model incorporating the interplay between phase change and spatial movement at the individual level. Stability analysis reveals conditions for an outbreak, characterized by a large scale transition to the gregarious phase. Numerical simulations provide descriptions of the aggregation's structure and reveal transiently traveling clumps of gregarious insects. This model can help predict and manage locust outbreaks, which can affect vast areas of Northern Africa, the Middle East, Asia, and Australia, causing significant crop damage and economic losses. The study of locust phase change and aggregation behavior can contribute to the development of more effective control strategies for these economically significant pests.
"The fusion of viral membranes is a crucial step in the infection process of many enveloped viruses, and is mediated by viral envelope glycoproteins. Although high-resolution structures of these fusion proteins in their pre- and post-fusion conformations are available, intermediate structures of the fusion pathway are difficult to define due to their transient nature. Flaviviruses, such as tick-borne encephalitis virus, possess a class II viral fusion protein (E) that is converted from a dimer to a trimer with a hairpin-like structure during the fusion process. A study found that exposure of virions to alkaline instead of acidic pH traps the particles in an intermediate conformation where the E dimers dissociate and interact with target membranes via the fusion peptide without proceeding to the merger of the membranes. Further treatment to low pH leads to fusion, suggesting that these monomers correspond to an as-yet-elusive intermediate required to convert the prefusion dimer into the postfusion trimer. This sequence of events provides important new insights for understanding the dynamic process of viral membrane fusion. Membrane fusion processes are tightly regulated by specific control proteins in both viral and cellular fusion systems. Viral fusion proteins are present in a metastable conformation at the surface of mature virions and undergo structural rearrangements to drive the merger of the viral membrane with a membrane of the target cell when exposed to an appropriate trigger. A common property of viral fusion proteins is the presence of a fusion peptide that inserts into the cellular membrane to initiate the fusion process. Distinct structural classes of viral fusion proteins have been identified, displaying radically different architectures and organizations on the virion. Despite the overall different architecture of fusion protein classes, certain similarities in their overall postfusion conformation suggest that the corresponding fusion processes are mechanistically related. A key feature in this context is the formation of a ""hairpin""-like trimeric postfusion structure, bringing into contact the C-terminal membrane anchor with the target-membrane inserted FP."
We are currently experiencing an extinction event comparable to those recorded in the fossil record, with present-day extinction rates significantly higher than background rates and projected to increase further. Vertebrates' biological traits, such as body size, fecundity, and geographic range, influence their vulnerability. However, our understanding of plant extinctions and vulnerabilities is lagging, despite their critical role as the basis of life on Earth. A study focused on the Cape of South Africa, a global biodiversity hotspot, reveals that the taxonomic distribution of extinction risk in plants differs from that of vertebrates, and cannot be explained by simple biological traits. Instead, the most threatened plant species are those that cluster within short branches at the tips of the phylogenetic tree, possibly due to rapid speciation. These findings have significant implications for conservation priorities and challenge the utility of current Red List criteria for plants. Rapid biodiversity loss, driven mainly by habitat loss, fragmentation, and climate change, is the most significant ecological challenge we face. Identifying key traits linked to high extinction risk is crucial for predicting future declines and implementing preemptive conservation measures. However, the particular attributes influencing vulnerability can differ among clades and geographic regions, and current knowledge of plant extinctions is much poorer than for vertebrates. In the Cape, extinction risk is higher for young and fast-evolving plant lineages and cannot be explained by correlations with simple biological traits. Consequently, conservation efforts must focus on reducing species loss rates and carefully consider the most sensible conservation strategies for plants and animals.
Phagocytosis is a crucial process by which cells of the innate immune system eliminate pathogens, and it is vital in preventing Candida albicans infections. Dectin-1 is the major phagocytic receptor involved in anti-fungal immunity, and two new interacting proteins of Dectin-1 in macrophages, Bruton's Tyrosine Kinase (BTK) and Vav1, have been identified. These proteins are recruited to phagocytic cups containing C. albicans yeasts or hyphae but are absent from mature phagosomes. BTK contributes to DAG synthesis at the phagocytic cup and the subsequent recruitment of PKCε. BTK- or Vav1-deficient peritoneal macrophages display a defect in both zymosan and C. albicans phagocytosis. Bone marrow-derived macrophages that lack BTK or Vav1 show reduced uptake of C. albicans, comparable to Dectin1-deficient cells. BTK- or Vav1-deficient mice are more susceptible to systemic C. albicans infection than wild type mice. This work highlights the important role of BTK and Vav1 in immune responses against C. albicans.
Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a vector-borne disease affecting ruminants and humans, caused by RVF virus (RVFV). It has been a significant issue in Madagascar, with major outbreaks in 1990-91 and 2008-09. A recent study aimed to identify environmental factors and areas favorable to RVFV transmission to both cattle and humans, as well as human behaviors that contribute to the spread in the Malagasy context. The study used Multiple Factor Analysis (MFA) and Generalized Linear Mixed Models, analyzing cattle and human serological data collected nationwide.The study identified that cattle and human seroprevalence rates were positively associated with humid environments (p<0.001). Areas with high cattle density were also at risk (p<0.01; OR = 2.6). Additionally, frequent contact with raw milk contributed to explaining human infection (OR = 1.6). The study highlighted the eastern-coast, western, and north-western parts as high-risk areas for RVF transmission in cattle.The findings suggest that both vectorial and direct transmissions are critical to maintaining RVF enzootic transmission. Vectorial transmission probably occurs in both cattle and humans in the suitable eastern-coast, western, and north-western areas for Culex and Anopheles mosquitoes. The relative contribution of vectorial or direct transmissions could be further assessed by mathematic modeling. The association between cattle seroprevalence, humid environments, and high cattle density indicates that cattle are an essential factor in RVFV transmission and might be a useful indicator for RVF risk assessment.
Prions are self-propagating protein conformations that can transmit between non-identical proteins, though this is often inefficient. This inefficiency is attributed to sequence differences in prion proteins, but the underlying mechanisms are unclear. A study using a yeast Rnq1/[PIN+]-based experimental system found that Rnq1 encompasses multiple prion determinants that can independently drive amyloid formation in vitro and transmit the [PIN+] prion state in vivo. Transmission of the prion state between different Rnq1 fragments with different sets of prion determinants established that one common QN-rich region is required and usually sufficient for transmission, but despite identical sequences of the common QNs, such transmissions are impeded by barriers of different strength. This indicates that in complex prion domains, multiple prion determinants act cooperatively to attain the final prion conformation, revealing transmission barriers determined by this cooperative fold.
A novel likelihood-free inference framework using deep learning is introduced to compute the likelihood of complex population genetic models, which is often infeasible. Deep learning is a powerful modern technique in machine learning that uses multilayer neural networks to learn a feature-based function from the input to the output. This method can effectively infer population genetic parameters and learn informative features of data. The authors focus on the challenging problem of jointly inferring natural selection and demography, which is demonstrated on 197 African Drosophila melanogaster genomes from Zambia. The results show many regions of the genome that have experienced hard sweeps and fewer under selection on standing variation or balancing selection. Additionally, soft sweeps and balancing selection occur more frequently closer to the centromere of each chromosome. Furthermore, the authors find that previously estimated bottlenecks for African Drosophila melanogaster are too extreme. Overall, this study shows that deep learning can effectively be employed for population genetic inference and learning informative features of data.
High-risk HPV oncogenes, especially HPV16, play a crucial role in the development of anogenital and oropharyngeal cancers. A persistent expression of high-risk HPV oncogenes, E6 and E7, is necessary for the formation of these cancers. These cells expressing E6 and E7 have been found to be hypersensitive to DNA crosslinking agent cisplatin and have defects in repairing DNA interstrand crosslinks (ICL). The E6 and E7 oncoproteins attenuate the Fanconi anemia (FA) DNA crosslink repair pathway, which is crucial for maintaining genomic stability. Although E6 and E7 activated the FA pathway, they inhibited the completion of the repair by impairing FancD2 colocalization with double-strand breaks (DSB), hindering the recruitment of downstream protein Rad51 to DSB, and causing delayed FancD2 de-ubiquitination. The increased chromatin retention of FancD2 hinders USP1 de-ubiquitinating activity and persistently activates ATR/CHK-1/pS565 FancI signaling. E6-mediated p53 degradation does not hamper the cell cycle specific process of FancD2 modifications but abrogates repair by disrupting FancD2 de-ubiquitination. Further, E6 reduces the expression and foci formation of Palb2, which is a repair protein downstream of FancD2. These findings provide insight into how HPV oncogenes contribute to genomic instability and the response to cisplatin therapies.
The Southern Chiapas focus in Mexico is one of the major onchocerciasis foci in Latin America, with 559 endemic communities having undergone semi-annual mass treatment with ivermectin since 1998. In 2003, the treatment frequency shifted from twice to four times a year in 50 communities and was further extended to 113 communities in 2009. Extensive epidemiological and entomological assessments were conducted in six sentinel and three extra-sentinel communities, all of which had undergone at least two rounds of ivermectin treatment per year. The results showed that none of the 67,924 Simulium ochraceum s.l. flies collected during the dry season of 2011 were found to contain parasite DNA, resulting in an upper bound of the 95% confidence interval (95%-ULCI) of the infective rate in the vectors of 0.06/2,000 flies examined. Moreover, serological assays on 4,230 children aged five years and under (out of a total population of 10,280 in this age group) revealed that only two individuals were exposed to O. volvulus (0.05%; one-sided 95% confidence interval=0.08%). The in-depth epidemiological and entomological findings from the Southern Chiapas focus meet the criteria for interruption of transmission established by the international community.
Listeria monocytogenes is a Gram-positive bacterium that can cause serious invasive disease in humans, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. The bacterium can survive as a saprophyte in soil but can transition into a pathogen following ingestion by mammalian hosts. The transition is coordinated by the central virulence regulatory protein, PrfA, which regulates the expression of gene products associated with bacterial virulence. A study has identified a lipoprotein, PplA, that is secreted in increased amounts following PrfA activation and shares homology with a peptide pheromone-encoding lipoprotein in Enterococcus faecalis. The L. monocytogenes genome encodes for gene products that share homology with E. faecalis proteins required for peptide pheromone processing, import, and transcriptional regulation. The pPplA peptide pheromone contributes to intracellular growth and bacterial virulence. Bacterial cultures of prfA* strains exhibit bacterial settling and/or aggregation, and the pPplA pheromone contributes to this aggregation. The CtaP oligopeptide transport system may be involved in the import of the pPplA pheromone into the bacterial cell to stimulate bacterial aggregation following PrfA activation. The secretion of the PplA lipoprotein is increased following PrfA activation, and mutant strains lacking the PplA lipoprotein, the pheromone and lipoprotein, and the Eep protease show attenuated virulence in a mouse infection model.
Vibrio cholerae, the bacterium that causes cholera, is highly adaptable and can colonize hostile environments, including the human small intestine. To understand how V. cholerae combats reactive oxygen species (ROS) during infection, a study used whole-genome transposon sequencing (Tn-seq) to analyze gene requirements for colonization in mice with and without the antioxidant N-acetyl cysteine (NAC). The study found that mutants of the methyl-directed mismatch repair (MMR) system, such as MutS, had significant colonization advantages in untreated, ROS-rich mice but not in NAC-treated mice. Further analysis suggested that the accumulation of catalase-overproducing mutants and rugose colony variants in NAC- mice was the leading cause of mutS mutant enrichment caused by oxidative stress during infection. The mutation rate of wildtype colonized in NAC- mice was significantly higher than that in NAC+ mice. The study supports a paradigm in which V. cholerae employs a temporal adaptive strategy to battle ROS during infection, resulting in enriched phenotypes. V. cholerae is a versatile bacterium that can survive in both aquatic and host environments. To cope with harsh conditions during the transition to the host gut and during subsequent growth, V. cholerae senses host signals and coordinates both virulence gene activation and repression to evade host defenses and successfully colonize intestines. Late in the infection, V. cholerae optimally modulates its genetic programs for the forthcoming dissemination into the aquatic environment. In the aquatic environment, V. cholerae forms biofilms, which provide protection from environmental stresses, including nutrient limitation, protozoa predation, and bacteriophage infection.One of the major stresses V. cholerae must overcome is exposure to ROS. Reactive compounds, including ROS, are abundant in marine systems, and V. cholerae encounters oxidative stress during the later stages of infection. Catalases, peroxiredoxin, organic hydroperoxide resistance protein, a redox-regulated chaperone, and a DNA-binding protein from starved cells are important for V. cholerae ROS resistance. ROS resistance in V. cholerae is tightly regulated through a variety of mechanisms, including the quorum sensing systems, PhoB/PhoR two-component systems, and the virulence regulator, AphB.Further identifying bacterial stress responses to host-derived ROS is important for understanding V. cholerae pathogenesis. In this study, the researchers used Tn-seq to screen for V. cholerae genes that are involved in ROS resistance during infection. By comparing colonization in control mice to mice treated with antioxidant N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) that reduces the production of ROS in murine intestines, the study found that deletion of mutS, encoding a key component in the DNA methyl-directed mismatch repair (MMR) system, results in a significant colonization advantage compared to wildtype in ROS-rich mice. This finding suggests that the MMR system is important for maintaining the overall stability of the genetic material and that inactivation of the MMR system leads to better adaptation and persistence of V. cholerae in murine models.
Mlh1-Mlh3 is an endonuclease that plays a major role in meiotic crossing over and a minor role in eukaryotic DNA mismatch repair (MMR), with its activity stimulated by Msh2-Msh3 in MMR. An analysis of 60 mlh3 alleles in baker's yeast revealed that five specifically disrupted MMR, while one (mlh3-32) specifically disrupted meiotic crossing over. Both Mlh1-mlh3-32 and Mlh1-mlh3-45 displayed wild-type endonuclease activities in vitro, but Msh2-Msh3 stimulated the endonuclease activity of Mlh1-mlh3-32 but not Mlh1-mlh3-45, suggesting that Mlh1-mlh3-45 is defective in MSH interactions. Whole genome recombination maps were constructed for wild-type and MMR+ crossover-, MMR- crossover+, endonuclease defective and null mlh3 mutants in an S288c/YJM789 hybrid background. All of the mlh3 mutants showed increases in the number of noncrossover events, consistent with recombination intermediates being resolved through alternative recombination pathways. These observations provide a structure-function map for Mlh3 that reveals the importance of protein-protein interactions in regulating Mlh1-Mlh3’s enzymatic activity and illustrate how defective meiotic components can alter the fate of meiotic recombination intermediates, providing new insights for how meiotic recombination pathways are regulated.
The intense use of antibiotics to treat diseases such as tuberculosis, malaria, Staphylococcus aureus, and gonorrhea has led to increasing population levels of drug resistance. This has resulted in a need to switch to new drugs and discontinue older ones, but resistance often persists even after the discontinuation of these drugs. This is usually attributed to low fitness costs of resistance in the absence of the drug. However, a new study shows that the structure of the host population, specifically heterogeneity in the number of contacts, also plays a significant role in the reversion dynamics. Host contact structure affects the distribution of the resistant strain among the infected population during the phase of intense treatment and the competition dynamics after the discontinuation of the drug, leading to a slower reversion rate and a lower probability of reversion to sensitivity at the population level. The impact of heterogeneity in the host structure is greatest in the biologically most plausible parameter range, namely when fitness costs of resistance are small. This suggests that host contact structure should be taken into account when studying the evolution of resistance in the context of treatment.
Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASDs) are complex neurodevelopmental diseases with deficits in social interaction, communication, and restricted, repetitive behaviors. While some highly penetrant gene variants have been identified, there is growing evidence that combinatorial effects from multiple loci contribute to ASDs. A study using Drosophila models found synergistic interactions between pairs of informatically-identified candidate genes whose orthologues are affected by large de novo copy number variants (CNVs) in individuals with ASD, including a patient carrying a 22q11.2 deletion. These CNVs affect genes operating in the same functional pathway/network and simultaneously affect multiple genes whose proteins interact within that functional pathway. Combinatorial effects of these genes’ copy number change likely causally contribute to patients’ autistic phenotypes. The study illustrates mechanisms through which synergistic effects resulting from large structural variation can contribute to human disease, highlighting the importance of understanding gene-gene interactions in ASD.
In the study of experimental cerebral malaria (ECM), a severe neurological syndrome induced by Plasmodium berghei ANKA infection in C57BL/6 mice, it was found that brain-infiltrating CD8+ T cells play a central role in its development. However, the mechanisms through which they mediate their pathogenic activity during malaria infection are not well understood. The study used intravital two-photon microscopy and ex vivo flow cytometric analysis to show that brain-infiltrating T cells accumulate within the perivascular spaces of brains of mice infected with both ECM-inducing (P. berghei ANKA) and non-inducing (P. berghei NK65) infections. However, perivascular T cells displayed an arrested behavior specifically during P. berghei ANKA infection, and formed long-term cognate interactions with CX3CR1-bearing antigen presenting cells within the brains during P. berghei ANKA infection. Pathogenic CD8+ T cells were found to colocalize with rare apoptotic cells expressing CD31, a marker of endothelial cells, within the brain during ECM. However, cellular apoptosis was a rare event and did not result in loss of cerebral vasculature or correspond with the extensive disruption to its integrity observed during ECM. The arrest of T cells in the perivascular compartments of the brain is a unique signature of ECM-inducing malaria infection and implies an important role for this event in the development of the ECM-syndrome.Malaria is a significant global health problem with 207 million cases and 584,000-1,238,000 deaths annually. A high proportion of these deaths are due to cerebral malaria (CM), a neuropathology induced primarily by the species Plasmodium falciparum. Current treatment of cerebral malaria is limited to parasiticidal chemotherapies, and the mortality rate of CM, even after treatment, remains at 10-20%. A greater understanding of the parasitological and immunological events leading to the development of CM would aid the development of improved therapeutic options to treat the condition. Infection of susceptible strains of mice with P. berghei ANKA results in the development of a serious neurological syndrome, termed experimental cerebral malaria (ECM), which recapitulates many of the clinical and pathological features of CM.The study found that CD8+ T cells are crucial in the development of cerebral pathology, and protection from ECM is afforded by their depletion as late as one day prior to the development of neurological signs. The pathogenic parasite-specific CD8+ T cells are primed in the spleen by CD8α+ dendritic cells (DCs) before migrating to the brain through homing dependent upon IFNγ-stimulated CXCL10 production in the CNS. Monocytes play a role in recruitment of the pathogenic CD8+ T cells to the brain during ECM; however, the relative importance of this event in development of cerebral pathology remains undefined. It has previously been shown that parasite-specific CD8+ T cells mediate ECM development through perforin- and granzyme B-dependent mechanisms, yet where the CD8+ T cells localize within the brain to cause ECM has remained unclear. Parasite-specific CD8+ T cells appear to require in situ antigen-dependent stimulation within the brain to program their pathogenic activity necessary for ECM development. To date, however, the identity of the putative antigen cross-presenting cells that interact with pathogenic CD8+ T cells during ECM is unknown.In conclusion, the study suggests that the arrest of T cells in the perivascular compartments of the brain is a unique signature of ECM-inducing malaria infection and implies an important role for this event in the development of the ECM-syndrome. Understanding the mechanisms through which brain-infiltrating CD8+ T cells cause ECM may help in the development of improved therapeutic options to treat cerebral malaria.
Tungiasis, a parasitic disease caused by the sand flea Tunga penetrans, is a significant health issue in Vihiga County, Kenya, particularly among lower-income individuals. A study was conducted to determine the burden of tungiasis in the area, examining 437 participants across 21 villages in three sub-locations. The overall prevalence of tungiasis was found to be 21.5% (95% CI: 17.7--25.3%). Multivariate analysis indicated that low economic status, age (≤14 years), lack of regular use of closed footwear, and common resting place inside the house were associated with the occurrence of tungiasis. These findings suggest the need for cost-effective and accessible control strategies for tungiasis in the region. Tungiasis is a neglected tropical disease, primarily affecting populations living in poverty with poor housing, inadequate sanitation, and close contact with domestic animals. Although not officially recognized by the World Health Organization, tungiasis is a health concern in many tropical and subtropical countries. The burden of tungiasis in Kenya is estimated to be between 19% and 40% in affected communities, with children and the elderly being most vulnerable. Factors contributing to the spread of tungiasis include earthen and dusty floors, non-regular use of closed footwear, common resting places outside the house, and the presence of animals in the compound or living with animals in the same house. Understanding the geographical distribution of tungiasis is crucial for improving control measures, as limited resources often require targeting high transmission areas in sub-Saharan Africa. While progress has been made in mapping neglected diseases, there is still a need to understand the geographical distribution and burden of tungiasis to effectively address this ectoparasitosis.
Auxin and cytokinin, two plant hormones, have antagonistic interactions that play a key role in the development of vascular tissues in plants. These tissues are crucial for long-distance transport, structural support, and the formation of wood. The vascular tissues are composed of xylem and phloem, with the xylem axis consisting of protoxylem and metaxylem cells. Protoxylem specification is an early event in post-embryonic vascular patterning, and it has been suggested that the correct positioning and specification of protoxylem depends on a mutually inhibitory interaction between auxin and cytokinins. However, the relevance and plausibility of an informative spatial pattern in cytokinin levels in this context remains unclear. Cytokinin has been shown to regulate auxin transport, and this regulation plays a central role in protoxylem specification. Auxin transport depends on the activity of molecular transporters, including the PIN class of efflux carriers, which are polarly localized within cells and play a crucial role in determining the overall auxin distribution and flux pattern. Computational modelling has been used to investigate how cytokinin signalling modifies the auxin distribution and flux via the PIN transporters in the Arabidopsis root tip and explore the possible functional consequences. These models have revealed that cytokinin signalling is essential for correct vascular patterning and that auxin accumulation activates AHP6 expression at the protoxylem position, which in turn inhibits cytokinin signalling, resulting in a feedback loop that positions the xylem axis in Arabidopsis. The patterns in cytokinin signalling are a combined consequence of both the spatial distribution in the levels of cytokinin and the strength with which individual cells respond to those levels of cytokinin. Computational modelling has also been used to investigate auxin-cytokinin interactions in a realistic spatial context, which has uncovered a mechanism by which regulated transverse auxin transport increases the robustness of the xylem-axis maximum and impinges on lateral root initiation.
The study of gene expression changes in neural systems and their role in environment-induced behavioral plasticity in animals has revealed that the neuropeptide F (NPF)/nitric oxide (NO) signaling pathway plays a regulatory role in phase-related locomotor plasticity in migratory locusts. A conserved transcription factor, CREB-B, has been identified as a key mediator in this signaling pathway, triggering locomotor activity shift between solitarious and gregarious phases. CREB-B directly activates brain NOS expression by interacting with the NOS promoter region, and its phosphorylation at the serine 110 site dynamically changes in response to population density variation, which is negatively controlled by NPF2. The regulatory effects of NPF2 on CREB-B phosphorylation and NOS transcription are mediated by protein kinase A. These findings highlight a precise signal cascade underlying environment-induced behavioral plasticity.
The maternal-to-zygotic transition (MZT) in metazoans is a critical period in development, during which there is a shift from control of development by maternally contributed mRNAs and proteins to control by the zygotic genome. The MZT is preceded by the transcription of a small number of genes that initiate sex determination, patterning, and other early developmental processes. The zinc-finger protein Zelda (ZLD) plays a key role in the transcriptional activation of these genes. A study using ChIP-Seq to map regions bound by ZLD before, during, and after the MZT in Drosophila found that ZLD is bound to thousands of regions before the MZT, many of which are also bound by transcription factors that regulate patterned gene activation during the MZT. The association between early ZLD binding and MZT activity is so strong that ZLD binding alone can be used to identify active promoters and regulatory sequences with high specificity and selectivity. This strong early association of ZLD with regions not active until the MZT suggests that ZLD is not only required for the earliest wave of transcription but also plays a major role in activating the genome at the MZT. Delayed activation of the zygotic genome during the early phases of embryogenesis is a nearly universal phenomenon in metazoans. The zygotic genome is largely transcriptionally quiescent immediately following egg activation, with development controlled by maternally contributed mRNAs and proteins. At a point known as the MZT, the degradation of maternally provided RNAs is tightly coordinated with widespread initiation of zygotic transcription. In Drosophila melanogaster, the fertilized egg undergoes a series of replication cycles without cytoplasmic divisions to generate a syncytial blastoderm. During cycle 14, the blastoderm nuclei cellularize and general zygotic transcription is initiated. However, a subset of genes required for sex determination, pattern formation and cellularization are transcribed as early as cycle 8. These genes share a common set of related heptameric DNA motifs, CAGGTAG and related “TAGteam” elements, in their regulatory regions. The zinc-finger transcription factor Zelda (ZLD) is the most important factor in regulating early gene expression, and mutations in zld lead to defects in early embryonic mitosis and severe cellularization defects by mitotic cycle 14. A microarray study of ZLD-depleted embryos identified 120 genes whose proper expression during early embryogenesis is dependent on ZLD, but the full range of ZLD targets and its mechanisms of action are not known.
Circadian clocks, present in most living organisms, regulate important physiological processes and behaviors through precise timing of gene expression, protein-protein interactions (PPIs), and post-transcriptional/posttranslational modifications. A yeast-two-hybrid (Y2H) screen revealed 109 novel PPIs among circadian clock proteins, including the interaction of protein phosphatase 1 and CLOCK/BMAL1 resulting in BMAL1 destabilization. A dynamic circadian PPI network was constructed, predicting PPI timing using circadian expression data. Systems analysis of a global dynamic network in liver revealed that interacting proteins are expressed at similar times, restricting regulatory interactions to specific phases. Many important cellular processes, such as signal transduction and cell cycle, are predicted to be dynamically connected by circadian PPIs, contributing to the temporal organization of cellular physiology. Further investigation of these PPIs and their dynamics is essential to understand the regulation of circadian output processes and the control of cellular physiology.
Nematode polyprotein allergens (NPAs) are an unusual class of lipid-binding proteins found in nematodes, synthesized as large tandemly repetitive polyproteins and post-translationally cleaved into multiple copies of small lipid binding proteins. They are crucial for transport and distribution of small hydrophobic compounds in nematodes and may play key roles in nutrient scavenging, immunomodulation, and IgE antibody-based responses in infection. The structure of ABA-1A, the most common repeating unit of the NPA of Ascaris suum, was determined by protein nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and adopts a novel seven-helical fold. NPAs have no counterparts in vertebrates, making them potential targets for drug or immunological intervention. Tandemly repetitive polyproteins (TRPs) are rare in nature, produced as large precursor polypeptides and comprising repeated units of similar or identical amino acid sequence that are post-translationally cleaved into a dozen or so copies of functionally similar proteins. TRPs represent an efficient and economical means of synthesizing large quantities of a functional protein. NPAs are produced in large quantities by parasitic nematodes and have affinity for small lipids, crucial for safe movement within cells and acquisition, protection, and distribution of lipids for parasitic nematodes. Immunological responses to NPAs have been associated with naturally-acquired resistance to infection in humans and are under strict genetic control. These immune responses have shown potential as vaccine candidates.
Ciguatera, a type of fish poisoning that occurs in tropical regions, particularly in developing Pacific Island Countries and Territories (PICTs), has seen a 60% increase in annual incidence between 1998-2008, with a mean annual incidence of 194 cases per 100,000 people, potentially affecting half a million Pacific islanders in the last 35 years. Ciguatera is caused by the consumption of coral reef fish contaminated by ciguatoxin from dinoflagellates and cyanobacteria. The disease is prevalent in tropical and subtropical waters, particularly in PICTs, and is under-diagnosed and under-reported. Ciguatera has been linked to military activities, coral reef damage, and climate change, which exacerbate the extent and range of the disease. Despite extensive research, little is known about the ecology and environmental factors that cause the blooms of ciguatera-causative organisms. Effective management of ciguatera is hampered by the inability to detect ciguatoxin in fish and Gambierdiscus in routine testing, and the reliance on symptom-based diagnosis in humans. Increased degradation of coastal marine environments, coastal development, and land run-off, as well as global climate change, are predicted to increase the incidence of ciguatera cases in the future. Therefore, it is hypothesized that ciguatera incidence is an increasing human health and ecological concern across the PICTs. Continued research, education campaigns, improved toxin detection, and a better understanding of the environmental factors contributing to ciguatera are required to help reduce the adverse impacts of ciguatera.
Chagas disease, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, remains a significant public health issue in Latin America and globally. The main treatment is benznidazole (BNZ), which has side effects and whose effectiveness during the chronic phase is controversial. However, studies suggest that BNZ can improve the immune system's capacity against the parasite and prevent the development of cardiomyopathy during the chronic phase. A study of 38 chronic Chagas disease patients (18 symptomatic and 20 asymptomatic) and 12 healthy donors found that CD4+CD8+ T cells were more frequent in chronic Chagas disease patients, with a higher ratio of CD4+CD8low/CD4+CD8high subpopulations compared to healthy donors. These cells expressed and co-expressed higher levels of inhibitory receptors in proportion to the severity of the pathology. BNZ treatment reduced the frequency of CD4+CD8+ T cells and decreased the ratio of CD4+CD8low/CD4+CD8high subpopulations. The co-expression level of inhibitory receptors was reduced after treatment, accompanied by an improvement in the multifunctional capacity of CD4+CD8+ T cells and an increase in the frequency of T. cruzi antigen-specific CD4+CD8+ T cells expressing IL-2 and TNF-α.
