CD4+CD8+ T cells have an important role in controlling T. cruzi infection, and BNZ treatment can partially reverse the exhaustion process caused by T. cruzi infection in these cells and improve their functional response. Therefore, identifying biomarkers of therapeutic efficacy is crucial for monitoring treated patients and understanding the role of all immune system components involved in T. cruzi infection control. T cells, especially CD4+ and CD8+ T cells, play a crucial role in Chagas disease control. However, further studies are required to understand the functions of other T cell components, such as CD4+CD8+ peripheral T cells, which represent approximately 3% of lymphocytes in human blood. These cells have the potential to be activated and respond to specific antigens, produce cytokines and cytotoxic molecules, and migrate to inflamed tissues. In the context of Chagas disease, CD4+CD8+ T cells respond to T. cruzi antigens, express greater amounts of activation markers and perforin than healthy subjects, and are found in the inflammatory infiltrate of cardiac tissue from a patient who underwent cardiac transplant, suggesting they could play an important role in the control of Chagas disease. However, the study of the population of CD4+CD8+ T cells in chronic Chagas disease has not yet been explored in detail, and understanding their ability to respond to T. cruzi antigens and the mechanism underlying the exhaustion process in these T cells can lead to the identification of new biomarkers that can be used to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of known and new drugs and improve knowledge concerning all components of the immune system that play a key role in the control of T. cruzi infection.
Phosphoinositides are important lipid signals in plant development and stress response, but the specific enzymes and roles in the biosynthetic pathway are not well understood due to multiple isoforms of the genes. A study in Arabidopsis thaliana found that phosphoinositide-specific phospholipase C2 (AtPLC2) is the primary enzyme in phosphoinositide metabolism and is involved in seedling growth and endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress responses. Lipidomic profiling of multiple plc mutants showed that the plc2-1 mutant had increased levels of its substrates phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate and phosphatidylinositol 4, 5-bisphosphate, indicating that the major phosphoinositide metabolic pathway is impaired. AtPLC2 displayed a distinct tissue expression pattern and localized at the plasma membrane in different cell types, where phosphoinositide signaling occurs. Seedlings of the plc2-1 mutant showed growth defects and hypersensitive response to ER stress, suggesting that phosphoinositide-specific phospholipase C activity borne by AtPLC2 is required for seedling growth and ER stress response. This study reveals the primary enzyme in phosphoinositide metabolism, its involvement in seedling growth and an emerging link between phosphoinositide and the ER stress response.
"Reductionism in science typically assumes that causation in the physical world occurs at the micro level, with coarser causal models seen as approximations due to limitations in measurement or computation. However, a study utilizing a measure of intrinsic cause-effect power (integrated information, or Φ) challenges this assumption. The study evaluates simple systems for Φ across different spatial and temporal scales, considering all possible ""black boxes"" - macro elements consisting of micro elements over micro updates. By examining the inputs and outputs of these black boxes and ignoring internal micro elements, the study reveals that macro levels can ""beat"" the micro level in terms of cause-effect power. High-order mechanisms and joint constraints not apparent at the micro level emerge, resulting in a macro system having more mechanisms (higher composition) that are more interconnected (higher integration), leading to a higher Φ value. This challenges the reductionist assumption and provides a framework for identifying stable local maxima during a system's biological function, offering a natural vantage point for scientific inquiries."
A rule-based model of the mitochondrial respiratory chain (RC) was extended to account for electron transport in the whole RC coupled to proton translocation, TCA cycle reactions, and substrate transport to mitochondria. This model was used to fit respiratory electron fluxes and the dynamics of NAD+ reduction in rat brain mitochondria fueled by succinate or pyruvate and malate. The analysis revealed an association of ROS production with levels of specific radicals of individual electron transporters and their combinations in species of complexes I and III, and confirmed the phenomenon of bistability for the whole RC. The conditions for switching to a state with a high content of free radicals in complex III were predicted based on theoretical analysis and confirmed experimentally. These findings provide a new insight into the mechanisms of ROS production in RC and can be useful for advances in transplantology and therapy.
Intracellular transport in eukaryotic cells is facilitated by motor proteins, which convert chemical energy into kinetic energy to enable unidirectional and bidirectional transport of intracellular cargo over long distances. Disruptions in these transport mechanisms, often caused by mutations that alter single motor characteristics, can lead to neurodegenerative diseases. A recent study investigates the effects of mutations on transport properties of cargo carried by multiple wild-type and mutant motors. The results indicate that mutants with altered stall forces might determine the average velocity and run-length even when they are outnumbered by wild type motors in the ensemble. A semi-analytic method is developed to analyze transport of cargo by multiple motors of multiple types, which can be used to model mutations and deduce effects of such alterations on transport. These findings are important for understanding how mutant motors impact intracellular transport and lead to onset of diseases. Specifically, recent studies have implied that alterations in the kinesin-1 motor domain may have a role in impaired axonal transport, and phosphorylation of a mammal kinesin motor domain by kinase c-Jun N-terminal kinase-3 ( JNK3 ) at a conserved serine residue is implicated in Huntington’s disease. A negative charge at this serine residue leads to a lower stall force and decreased velocity under external loads, while leaving ATPase, microtubule-binding affinity, and processivity unchanged. A recent experimental study reported that a negative charge at Ser-175, acquired through mutation or phosphorylation, leads to a lower stall force and decreased velocity under external loads of 1 pN or more, while leaving ATPase, microtubule-binding affinity, and processivity unchanged. A separate contribution of the article is a semi-analytical method for determining the probability distribution of various configurations of a cargo carried by multiple number and types of motor-proteins. However, observing the transport dynamics of multiple motors is experimentally challenging due to the combinatorial complexity introduced by the multitude of scenarios possible when many motors and motor types participate in transport. Therefore, analytical and computational tools are used to study the transport of cargo by multiple motors. The Master Equation based method analytically solves for the probability distributions of all possible scenarios at any time point and enables the calculation of various biologically relevant quantities such as average velocity and run-length, for reasonably sized ensembles and with high accuracy while using lesser computational resources and time as compared to Monte Carlo simulations. This method can be used to study the transport of cargo by multiple motors of two different types where each type of motor protein can be individually characterized by a probabilistic model describing its stepping, detachment and attachment rates. For this article, the technique has been utilized to introduce alterations of various parameters from the nominal ones to model a mutation of the serine residue and compute the effect of such a mutation on cargo carried by a mixture of wild-type and mutant motor-proteins. In summary, a simulation engine was developed to study the transport of cargo by multiple motor proteins with distinct properties that in concert can exhibit emergent transport behaviors.
The study found that behavioral experiments are designed to test specific cognitive functions, but animals may use various individual behavioral strategies to solve tasks. Learning is seen as the selection and adaptation of potential behavioral policies. The research focused on the Cacna1c gene, which is associated with learning deficits and psychiatric disorders. A selective functional ablation of the Cacna1c gene showed that the knockout mice did not impair learning in general. Instead, the majority of Cacna1c knockout mice still managed to increase reward feedback across trials but did so by adapting an outcome-based strategy, while the majority of matched controls adopted the experimentally intended cue-association rule. This reveals a specific role of a single gene in learning and highlights that much more mechanistic insight could be gained by examining response patterns in terms of a larger repertoire of potential behavioral strategies. The results may also have clinical implications for treating psychiatric disorders.In summary, animal learning is a complex process that relies on a variety of behavioral strategies, and learning may not be impaired but instead shifted towards different strategies. The research on the Cacna1c gene and its impact on learning further supports the idea that a single gene can play a specific role in learning and behavior. These findings have the potential to contribute to the development of new treatments for learning disorders and psychiatric conditions.
Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, which transmit diseases like dengue and Zika, are widespread in tropical and subtropical regions. Wolbachia bacteria are being used as a potential method to control these diseases by reducing the mosquitoes' ability to transmit the viruses. Wolbachia are maternally transmitted bacteria that can manipulate their host's reproduction and inhibit the replication of RNA viruses in insects. However, the success of Wolbachia interventions may depend on environmental conditions, particularly temperature. A study found that rearing Ae. aegypti larvae infected with certain Wolbachia strains (wMel and wMelPop-CLA) at fluctuating and extreme temperatures reduced the expression of cytoplasmic incompatibility and the density of Wolbachia, and prevented the transmission of the bacteria to the next generation. The wAlbB strain, however, was able to maintain a high density, exhibit complete cytoplasmic incompatibility, and was transmitted from mother to offspring with a high fidelity under the same temperature cycle. These findings highlight the importance of temperature control in rearing and the potential impact of environmental conditions on the success of Wolbachia interventions.
Adenoviruses are important human pathogens that have been developed as vectors for gene therapies and genetic vaccines. Previous studies have shown that human infections with adenoviruses are self-limiting in immunocompetent hosts, with some evidence of persistence in adenoid tissue. A recent study investigated the natural history of adenovirus infections in various non-human primates and discovered that healthy populations of great apes and macaques shed substantial quantities of infectious adenoviruses in stool. Stool samples from asymptomatic humans showed less frequent shedding, comparable to frequencies reported before. The study also purified and fully sequenced 30 novel adenoviruses from apes and 3 from macaques, and analyzed their sequences together with 22 complete adenovirus genomes available from GenBank. The results showed that ape adenoviruses could be classified into species corresponding to human adenovirus species B, C, and E, and there was evidence for intraspecies recombination between adenoviruses. The high degree of phylogenetic relatedness of adenoviruses across their various primate hosts provided evidence for cross species transmission events to have occurred in the natural history of B and E viruses. The high degree of asymptomatic shedding of live adenovirus in non-human primates and evidence for zoonotic transmissions warrants caution for primate handling and housing. Furthermore, the presence of persistent and/or latent adenovirus infections in the gut should be considered in the design and interpretation of human and non-human primate studies with adenovirus vectors.
The eukaryotic genome is packaged into a nucleus in the form of chromatin, with the nucleosome being the fundamental structural unit. A nucleosome is a protein-DNA complex consisting of 146 or 147 base pairs of DNA wrapped 1.75 times around an octameric histone core. However, for proper gene function, this nucleosomal DNA must be unwrapped at least partially. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations with enhanced sampling methods have been used to investigate the unwrapping of the outer superhelical turn of nucleosomal DNA. The results showed that the free energy change for unwrapping is about 11.5 kcal/mol, which agrees well with values obtained in single molecule experiments. The simulation revealed a variety of conformational states, indicating there are many potential paths to outer superhelical turn unwrapping, but the dominant path is likely asymmetric. The unwrapping occurs in stages, with different base pairs being unwrapped at each stage. These results provide insight into the construction, disruption, and repositioning of nucleosomes during cellular processes. MD simulations and umbrella sampling were used to estimate the free energy cost of unwrapping a total of 44 bps, corresponding to nearly the entire outer DNA, to be about 11.5 kcal/mol. This value is quite reasonable compared with reported values and indicates that the unwrapping of the outer DNA from nucleosomes has a significant energy cost.
ApoD, a lipid binding protein, is crucial for maintaining lysosomal membrane integrity and regulating lysosomal pH homeostasis upon oxidative stress. It is internalized and targeted to lysosomes in a stress-dependent manner, preventing lysosomal membrane permeabilization, and it is necessary for lysosomes to recover from oxidation-induced alkalinization. Lysosomal dysfunction is linked to neurodegenerative diseases, and maintaining lysosomal membrane stability is essential for cell survival. ApoD has been found to optimize autophagy in neurodegeneration-triggered conditions in Drosophila, slowing down the process and making it more efficient, potentially minimizing the negative effects of autophagic stress. These findings suggest that Lipocalins, including ApoD, play a significant role in lysosomal membrane integrity and pH homeostasis, opening therapeutic opportunities for lysosome-related disorders.
Phlebotomus orientalis Parrot, the primary vector of visceral leishmaniasis (VL) caused by Leishmania donovani in East Africa, was studied through two of its colonies from different locations in Ethiopia: Melka Werer (MW), a non-endemic site in the lowlands, and Addis Zemen (AZ), an endemic VL focus in the highlands. While life-cycle parameters varied between the two colonies and RAPD PCR, cytB, and COI mitochondrial genes showed no genetic differences, F1 hybrids developed with higher fecundity. Both colonies demonstrated susceptibility to Ethiopian L. donovani strains, with an average blood-meal volume of 0.7 µl and an infective dose as low as one or two L. donovani promastigotes per sand fly blood-meal. The distribution of P. orientalis seems to favor Acacia - Balanites forests, cracks of black cotton clay soil, and termite hills. Despite attempts, colonization and laboratory maintenance of P. orientalis have proven difficult. These findings suggest that differences in VL prevalence are not due to P. orientalis susceptibility to L. donovani but possibly to human, reservoir host, or environmental factors. Further research is required to establish actual breeding sites and factors influencing colonization success.
The Chinese government considers advanced schistosomiasis, a chronic disease caused by a blood fluke, a top healthcare priority due to its serious health and economic impacts. However, it has not been included in the estimates of schistosomiasis burden in the Global Burden of Disease (GBD) study. To address this, a study was conducted to estimate the disability weight (DW) of advanced schistosomiasis japonica, the most common and severe form of the disease in China. The study used a patient-based quality-of-life evaluation and the European quality of life questionnaire with an additional cognitive dimension, ultrasonography, and laboratory testing to assess disability and morbidity in confirmed cases. The results showed that most patients reported impairments in at least one health dimension, such as pain or discomfort, usual activities, and anxiety or depression. The overall DW was 0.447, and age-specific DWs ranged from 0.378 among individuals aged 30–44 years to 0.510 among the elderly aged ≥60 years. These estimates could provide updated data for a revision of the GBD and for evidence-based decision-making in China's national schistosomiasis control program.
Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) and African Animal Trypanosomiasis (AAT), also known as sleeping sickness and nagana, respectively, are parasitic vector-borne diseases prevalent in sub-Saharan Africa. Transmitted through the tsetse fly, HAT affects humans, while AAT impacts animals, although the two conditions are interconnected. Historically, HAT has been addressed through active surveillance programs in specific countries, resulting in a decline in cases. However, much of rural sub-Saharan Africa lacks HAT-diagnostic capacity and passive surveillance programs, making it challenging to estimate population prevalence outside of active case-finding areas. A retrospective-cross-sectional study in Kenya used national census data from 1999 to estimate population vulnerability and disability in seven tsetse belts, where tsetse vectors for HAT and AAT are present. The study found that incorporating reports on disability from the national census is a promising surveillance tool for enhancing future HAT surveillance programs in sub-Saharan Africa. Future research will assess changes in the spatial relationships between high tsetse infestation and human disability.
Hexamethylene bisacetamide (HMBA) is a compound that reactivates viral production in chronically infected cell lines. It does so through an NF-kB-independent activation of HIV transcription. HMBA induces viral production in a dose-dependent manner in cells from monocytic and lymphocytic lineages. It increases the expression of HEXIM1 and HEXIM2, which, along with 7SK small nuclear RNA (snRNA), inhibit and sequester the positive transcription elongation factor b (P-TEFb) in its transcriptionally inactive complex (large complex [LC]). P-TEFb is responsible for the phosphorylation of the C-terminal domain of RNA polymerase II and negative transcription elongation factors, and is predominantly bound to Brd4 or is in a free heterodimeric form. HMBA disrupts the LC, resulting in cellular differentiation and the recruitment of P-TEFb to the HIV promoter to stimulate viral transcription elongation. This disruption of the LC is transient, and the reassociation of P-TEFb with HEXIM1 is more efficient than the reassociation with HEXIM2. HMBA activates the PI3K/Akt pathway, which leads to the concomitant disruption of the LC and the recruitment of P-TEFb to the HIV promoter. The inhibition of the PI3K/Akt pathway or the expression of a mutant HEXIM1 protein that cannot be phosphorylated by Akt and is resistant to HMBA-mediated disruption of the LC antagonizes the induction of HIV transcription by HMBA. Therefore, HMBA releases P-TEFb to reactivate viral production from latency by activating the PI3K/Akt pathway and disrupting the LC.
Leishmaniasis is a protozoan parasitic disease affecting 12 million people worldwide, with 350 million at risk. It has two major forms: cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) and visceral leishmaniasis (VL). New World Leishmania (Viannia) species cause CL, which can lead to mucosal (ML) or disseminated cutaneous leishmaniasis (DCL). The hyperinflammatory immune response causing this aggressive phenotype is associated with a parasite dsRNA virus (LRV). A study demonstrated LRV's role in elevated parasitemia, destructive inflammation, and disease exacerbation. Improved LRV detection and quantitation methods without sequence prerequisites are crucial. An anti-dsRNA monoclonal antibody, J2, specifically recognizes dsRNA in a sequence-independent manner, increasing diagnostic potential. Refining these methods for field use could aid LRV detection, assessing complication risks, and monitoring disease progression.
"EPEC and EHEC are closely-related pathogens that cause actin pedestal formation on intestinal epithelial cells, but they use different mechanisms to trigger pedestal formation. EPEC uses the tyrosine phosphorylated transmembrane receptor Tir, while EHEC uses the multivalent scaffolding protein EspFU. Both strains form macrocolonies that encompass multiple host cells, and Tir, EspFU, and the host Arp2/3 complex are critical for the expansion of macrocolonies. EspFU accelerates the formation of larger macrocolonies compared to EPEC Tir, as EspFU-mediated actin assembly drives faster bacterial motility to cell junctions. The ability to form macrocolonies enhances epithelial colonization and allows for efficient cell-to-cell transmission. The mechanisms by which pedestals promote colonization and disease remain unclear, but pedestals may play a role in anti-phagocytosis, bacterial motility, and epithelial cell colonization. EPEC and EHEC pedestals serve similar functions with respect to resisting phagocytosis by macrophages and enabling actin-based motility on non-polarized cells. However, on polarized epithelial cells, EHEC pedestals confer a colonization advantage, allowing for the formation of large ""macrocolonies"" that encompass several host cells, providing an EHEC-specific advantage stemming from faster EspFU-driven motility and a previously unrecognized mechanism of cell-to-cell bacterial transfer."
The isolation of extracellular vesicles (EVs) from other excretory-secretory products is crucial for downstream studies and application development in helminth pathogens, including the liver fluke Fasciola hepatica. The most widely used purification method for EVs in helminth pathogens is differential centrifugation (DC), but there is no agreed research community 'gold standard' for EV isolation. This case study compares DC and size exclusion chromatography (SEC) for EV purification from Fasciola hepatica. EVs prepared by SEC were smaller in size and less diverse than those resolved by DC, and demonstrated a higher EV purity to free excretory-secretory protein (ESP) yield ratio. Proteomic analysis further highlighted DC contamination from ESP in DC-prepared EVs, with a greater diversity of protein identifications and unique peptide hits compared to SEC-prepared EVs. Additionally, SEC-purified EVs contained fewer tegumental-based proteins than DC-purified EVs. Therefore, SEC methods should be considered for EV purification prior to downstream studies, as certain DC protocols may include more free ES proteins and tegumental artefacts.
Systems biology uses a cycle of experiment and modeling, including reverse engineering to fit models to data and infer regulatory mechanisms. This is challenging in a complex biological context, and requires rigorous methods to determine if model parameters can be properly identified. The authors use reverse engineering to study post-transcriptional regulation in pattern formation, specifically analyzing the expression of the gap genes Krüppel, knirps, and giant in Drosophila melanogaster. They find that post-transcriptional regulation is not required for patterning in this system, but is necessary for proper control of protein levels. They demonstrate that the uniqueness and specificity of a fitted model can be rigorously determined in the context of spatio-temporal pattern formation, which has implications for the study of development and other complex biological processes. Reverse engineering approaches involve formulating a mathematical model, fitting it to data, and analyzing the output to gain biological insight. However, there are challenges in deciding what kind of data and model are needed for a successful fit, and in analyzing whether a given solution is specific and reliable. Mathematical methods can be used to establish whether a reverse-engineering problem is well-posed and able to produce a unique and consistent solution. These methods include structural (a priori) parameter identifiability analysis, practical (a posteriori) parameter identifiability analysis, and optimal experimental design. However, the application of these methods to gain specific and novel biological insights is limited by the complexity of most real-world biological regulatory systems and the nature of the data used in reverse-engineering studies. The authors present a case study combining model fitting by global optimization strategies with rigorous structural and practical identifiability analysis, applied to the dynamics of spatio-temporal pattern formation in the early embryo of Drosophila melanogaster. They investigate the role of post-transcriptional regulation within the context of the gap gene network involved in segment determination during the blastoderm stage of early fly development. They find that post-transcriptional regulation is required for the accurate control of gap protein levels, with specific predictions about the timing of translational efficiency and protein stability.
Rotavirus is a significant cause of diarrhea in human children, particularly affecting infants younger than six years, while adults remain asymptomatic. The virus exhibits a marked cell tropism for epithelial cells of the small intestine and causes significant destruction of the neonatal epithelium. In a study using an oral mouse infection model, it was found that the innate immune receptor for viral dsRNA, Toll-like receptor (Tlr) 3, was low in the epithelium of suckling mice but strongly increased during the postnatal period, inversely correlating with rotavirus susceptibility, viral shedding, and histological damage. Adult mice deficient in Tlr3 or the adaptor molecule Trif exhibited significantly higher viral shedding and decreased epithelial expression of proinflammatory and antiviral genes as compared to wild-type animals. These findings suggest that upregulation of epithelial TLR3 expression during infancy might contribute to the age-dependent susceptibility to rotavirus infection. This is further supported by the detection of a significant age-dependent increase of TLR3 expression in human small intestinal biopsies.
A study was conducted to investigate the genetic architecture of Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) through whole-exome sequencing of 1,039 subjects diagnosed with ASD and 870 control subjects. The sequencing data came from two centers using different methods to produce sequences and call variants. The initial goal was to ensure the distribution of rare variation was similar for data from different centers, which was achieved by filtering called variants by fraction of missing data, read depth, and balance of alternative to reference reads. Gene-based analyses of association were performed, and it was shown that mega-analysis has better power than meta-analysis. Before analyzing the data for association, the impact of population structure on rare variant analysis was explored. It was found that population structure can confound case-control studies by the clustering of rare variants in ancestry space, but principal component-based analyses were sufficient to control for ancestry and produce test statistics with appropriate distributions. However, after using a variety of gene-based tests and both meta- and mega-analysis, no new risk genes for ASD were found in this sample. The results suggest that standard gene-based tests will require much larger samples of cases and controls before being effective for gene discovery, even for a disorder like ASD.
Mycetoma is a chronic infectious granulomatous disease commonly found in tropical and subtropical climates, caused by bacteria or fungi with Madurella mycetomatis being the most common causative agent worldwide and in Sudan. The fungus forms grains in tissue, with chitin present in the fungal cell wall. The human immune system responds to chitin exposure by producing chitinases, including chitotriosidase and AMCase, to break down chitin. However, polymorphisms in the genes encoding for these chitinases can result in altered chitinase activity. A study in a Sudanese population found that a polymorphism resulting in decreased chitotriosidase activity was associated with increased odds of eumycetoma, while no association was found for polymorphisms in the genes for AMCase. The study suggests that decreased chitotriosidase activity is a risk factor for M. mycetomatis mycetoma.
Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) has served as the prototype for viral latency, characterized by acute or lytic and latent phases. However, recent evidence suggests that lytic genes can be transcribed during latency, challenging the deep quiescence of HSV latency. A study utilized a Cre-marking model to demonstrate that around half of HSV spread leading to latently infected sites occurred beyond the initial acute infection, and presented direct evidence of lytic promoters driving protein expression during latency. Historically, viral transcription during latency was considered restricted to latency-associated transcripts (LATs), but lytic gene transcription in latency has been noted in sporadic reports. Recent single-cell analysis found lytic gene transcripts in more than two-thirds of all latently-infected neurons, with biologically relevant modulation of host antiviral and survival gene transcription. Although direct evidence for translation of lytic transcripts has been harder to find, activated, virus-specific CD8+ T cells in the sensory ganglia of latently infected individuals provide indirect evidence for the translation of at least some lytic proteins, such as glycoprotein B (gB) and ICP6. Cre-reporter mice, coupled with viruses that express Cre recombinase, serve as a highly sensitive model to detect transient and/or low levels of viral protein production. However, no promoter that drives a major target of anti-HSV CD8+ T cells has been tested. In conclusion, these findings suggest that lytic and latent phases are less clearly defined, with significant implications for understanding HSV latency and reactivation.
Neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, frontotemporal dementia, and prion diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. In prion diseases, the misfolded protein is the prion protein, which forms a protease-resistant form (PrPSc) that accumulates in neurons, astroglia, and microglia in the CNS. A study using mouse scrapie strains with different brain regional pathology found that PrPSc from each strain had a different pattern of cell specificity, mainly associated with astroglia or neurons and neuropil. Despite these differences, the pattern of upregulated genes was similar for all three strains, correlating with activation of both astroglia and microglia in early disease. The profile of upregulated genes in scrapie differed markedly from that seen in two acute viral CNS diseases. Overall, these findings suggest that though the specific cellular associations of misfolded proteins may vary in different prion strains, the inflammatory response is a common feature in prion diseases, and targeting this response could be a potential strategy for therapeutic intervention.
A study discusses the importance of the 3D organization of chromosomes in regulating gene expression and cell function, and the challenges in deciphering the mechanistic principles behind chromosome folding. A generic strategy is proposed to develop efficient coarse-grained models for self-avoiding polymers on a lattice, taking into account polymer entanglement length and volumic density. The simulation scheme captures the structural and dynamical properties of the system and tracks the same dynamics at different coarse-graining, offering a significant power-law gain in numerical efficiency. The formalism is used to investigate the time evolution of the 3D organization of chromosome 3R in drosophila during one cell cycle, showing good agreement with experimental data. The study highlights the importance of accounting for topological constraints in chromosome models, as neglecting them may lead to different structural and dynamical properties.
A recent study aimed to improve the understanding of the genetic architecture and causal mechanisms of cell type specificity of eQTLs, which are genetic variants that can affect gene expression in a cell type specific manner. The study performed an eQTL analysis in three parts, first identifying eQTLs from eleven studies on seven cell types, then integrating eQTL data with cis-regulatory element (CRE) data from the ENCODE project, and finally building a set of classifiers to predict the cell type specificity of eQTLs. The study found that the cell type specificity of eQTLs is associated with eQTL SNP overlap with hundreds of cell type specific CRE classes, including enhancer, promoter, and repressive chromatin marks, regions of open chromatin, and many classes of DNA binding proteins. These associations provide insight into the molecular mechanisms generating the cell type specificity of eQTLs and the mode of regulation of corresponding eQTLs. The study also demonstrated the feasibility of predicting the cell type specificity of eQTLs using a random forest classifier with cell specific CRE-SNP overlap as features, and the use of CREs from a trait-associated cell type to annotate GWAS associations in the absence of eQTL data for that cell type. The study concludes that such integrative, predictive modeling of cell specificity will improve the ability to understand the mechanistic basis of human complex phenotypic variation.
Achieving a vaccine for HIV has been elusive, but progress has been made in understanding the role of glycosylation in the design and production of an effective vaccine. Many broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (bN-mAbs) to the HIV-1 envelope protein (Env) gp120 recognize epitopes that consist of both amino acid and glycan residues, with glycans being early intermediates in the N-linked glycosylation pathway. However, suitable cell lines for biopharmaceutical production that limit N-linked glycosylation to mannose-5 (Man5) or earlier intermediates are not readily available, making the production of vaccine immunogens displaying these glycan-dependent epitopes challenging. To address this, a stable suspension-adapted Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cell line was developed using the clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeat (CRISPR)/CRISPR-associated protein 9 (Cas9) gene editing system, which contains a mutation that inactivates the gene encoding Mannosyl (Alpha-1, 3-)-Glycoprotein Beta-1, 2-N-Acetylglucosaminyltransferase (MGAT1). This cell line, MGAT1− CHO, produces monomeric gp120s with improved binding to prototypic glycan-dependent bN-mAbs directed to the V1/V2 domain and the V3 stem while preserving the structure of important glycan-independent epitopes. The MGAT1− CHO cell line's ability to limit glycosylation to early intermediates in the N-linked glycosylation pathway without impairing the doubling time or ability to grow at high cell densities suggests it will be a useful substrate for the biopharmaceutical production of HIV-1 vaccine immunogens.
Parasitic nematodes cause devastating diseases in the tropical areas of developing nations, with lymphatic filariasis being a major disease caused by these nematodes. It is a leading cause of permanent and long-term disability worldwide. A potential target for therapeutic inhibitor discovery is trehalose-6-phosphate phosphatase (T6PP) from Brugia malayi, which is essential for nematode survival. The X-ray crystal structure of T6PP from B. malayi has been determined, revealing a stabilizing N-terminal MIT-like domain and a catalytic C-terminal C2B-type HAD phosphatase fold. Five residues important for binding and catalysis have been identified through structure-guided mutagenesis and kinetic analyses using a designed competitive inhibitor, trehalose 6-sulfate. The proposed model of the T6PP-trehalose 6-phosphate complex suggests that high-affinity inhibitors will be bi-dentate, taking advantage of substrate-like binding to the phosphoryl-binding pocket while simultaneously utilizing non-native binding to the trehalose pocket. The conservation of key residues in T6PP enzymes suggests that development of broad-range anthelmintic and antibacterial therapeutics employing this platform may be possible.
The study presents a novel computational framework that simulates vascular blood flow and interstitial fluid transport in tumors, using whole, realistic tumors extracted ex vivo. The model couples Poiseuille and Darcy descriptions of vascular and interstitial flow, respectively, and incorporates spatially heterogeneous blood vessel lumen and interstitial permeabilities to generate accurate predictions of tumor fluid dynamics. The platform enables highly-controlled experiments to be performed, providing insight into how tumor vascular heterogeneity contributes to tumor fluid transport. Sensitivity analysis is performed to understand the key biological mechanisms which determine tumor fluid transport. The model shows that reducing tumor interstitial fluid pressure is not essential to increase interstitial perfusion and that therapies should seek to develop an interstitial fluid pressure gradient. The study also hypothesizes that stabilising vessel diameters and permeabilities are not key responses following vascular normalization and that therapy may alter interstitial hydraulic conductivity. The study suggests that normalizing the interstitial microenvironment may provide a more effective means to increase interstitial perfusion within tumors. Overall, the study highlights the importance of incorporating realistic vasculatures in computational models to better understand and predict tumor fluid dynamics and therapy response.
HIV spreads efficiently in vitro through both cell-free and cell-cell transmission modes, but the relative importance of cell-cell transmission in natural infection and its vulnerability to neutralizing antibodies is not fully understood. This study aimed to analyze neutralizing antibody activity during cell-cell transmission using specifically tailored experimental strategies. The results demonstrated that the activity of neutralizing monoclonal antibodies and entry inhibitors during cell-cell transmission varies depending on their mode of action. Specifically, gp41-directed agents remain active, while CD4 binding site (CD4bs) directed inhibitors, including the potent neutralizing mAb VRC01, dramatically lose potency during cell-cell transmission. This implies that CD4bs mAbs act preferentially through blocking free virus transmission, while still allowing HIV to spread through cell-cell contacts, providing a plausible explanation for how HIV maintains infectivity and rapidly escapes potent and broadly active CD4bs directed antibody responses in vivo. Additionally, this study highlights the complexity of studying HIV transmission modes and the need for further research to fully understand the impact of neutralizing antibodies on cell-cell transmission. This knowledge is crucial for the design of an effective HIV vaccine and entry inhibitor.
The text discusses the effects of visual attention on neural responses and proposes a model to explain these effects. Attention can modulate the responses of visual neurons in various ways, including response-gain, contrast-gain, biased competition, and feature-similarity gain. Attention can also shift and resize receptive fields in topological and feature space. The model proposed in the text suggests that these effects can be explained by a top-down attentional modulation that targets higher levels of the visual system, such as V4 or MT, rather than input areas like V1. The model requires the existence of modulatory feedback connections between areas and short-range lateral inhibition within each area. The feedback connections redistribute the top-down modulation to lower areas, which in turn alters the inputs of other higher-area cells, producing the observed effects of attention on neural responses. The model can reproduce the observed attentional effects on response rates and receptive field structure without modifying model parameters. The model also makes the novel prediction that attentional effects on response curves should shift from response gain to contrast gain as the spatial focus of attention drifts away from the studied cell.
The posterior signaling center (PSC) in Drosophila larvae, a group of specialized cells, controls hemocyte homeostasis in the lymph gland, similar to the niche in vertebrates. The PSC maintains JAK/STAT signaling in hematopoietic progenitors (prohemocytes) to preserve their multipotent character, enabling differentiation into lamellocytes upon wasp parasitism. A short type I cytokine-related receptor, CG14225/Latran, is required to switch off JAK/STAT signaling in prohemocytes for lamellocyte differentiation. Latran forms heteromers with Domeless and antagonizes its activity, leading to a decrease in cytokine mRNA levels and complete inhibition of residual JAK/STAT signaling upon wasp parasitism. This specific function of Drosophila Latran highlights the potential role of nonsignalling receptors in controlling specific aspects of vertebrate cellular immunity.
Genetic recombination is a key process in the evolution of various virus species, particularly among begomoviruses in the single-stranded DNA virus family Geminiviridae. The patterns of recombination in these viruses are influenced by both basal recombination rates across genomes and the viability of different recombinant genomes. Basal recombination rates are affected by local sequence similarity between recombining genomes, nucleic acid secondary structures, and genomic sensitivity to nuclease attack or breakage. The viability of recombinant genomes is determined by the degree to which their co-evolved protein-protein and protein-nucleotide and nucleotide-nucleotide interactions are disrupted by recombination. An experiment investigating patterns of recombination over 120-day long infections of tomato plants with the begomoviruses Tomato yellow leaf curl virus and Tomato leaf curl Comoros virus found that local degrees of sequence similarity, but not genomic secondary structure, strongly influence where recombination breakpoints occur. Over-all patterns of recombination are influenced by selection against individual recombinants displaying disrupted intra-genomic interactions. The study also found that recombination patterns can be used to identify the exact sequence tracts involved in these interactions and to infer the interaction networks within the virus genomes. These findings highlight the importance of understanding the role of recombination in virus evolution and the potential implications for the emergence of novel pathogens.
Nucleosomes, the fundamental units of chromatin in eukaryotes, have been suggested to influence the evolution of eukaryotic genomes, affecting both the rate of DNA mutation and the maintenance or exclusion of nucleosomes in specific locations. Although commonly believed to be unique to eukaryotes, histone proteins have also been discovered in some archaeal genomes, although archaeal nucleosomes differ from their eukaryotic counterparts in several ways, such as forming tetramers rather than octamers and lacking N- and C-terminal tails. Despite these differences, a study has found that the association between nucleosome footprints and sequence evolution is conserved between humans and the model archaeon Haloferax volcanii. This finding has led researchers to examine whether selection or mutation can explain concordant substitution patterns in the two kingdoms. They found that neither the mutation nor the selection model is sufficient to explain the observed association between nucleosomes and sequence divergence. Instead, they demonstrate that nucleosome-associated substitution patterns are more consistent with a third model where sequence divergence results in frequent repositioning of nucleosomes during evolution. This finding highlights the importance of considering the direction of causality between genetic and epigenetic change. Both in vitro and in vivo, nucleosomes are non-randomly positioned with regard to the underlying sequence, forming preferentially on stretches of DNA that are more amenable to being wrapped around the histone core. Consequently, changes at the sequence level during evolution can bring about changes in nucleosome positioning and occupancy, which can locally alter epigenetic states. Epigenetic states can also influence evolution at the sequence level by affecting the efficacy of DNA repair, altering rates of initial lesion formation, and mediating access to promoter elements or transcription factor binding sites, which can disrupt proper access to these functionally important sites if mutations alter nucleosome position.
The native state conformational diversity of proteins plays a crucial role in modulating their function, with different ligands causing shifts in the conformational equilibrium through binding to highest-affinity conformers. The intramolecular vibrational dynamics associated with each conformation enable these conformational transitions, which may be connected to evolutionary conserved traits. A novel procedure has been developed to identify key positions that sustain this conformational diversity associated with ligand binding, using a refined dataset of 188 paired protein structures in their bound and unbound forms. Normal modes most involved in the conformational change are selected and used to analyze the effect of simulated point mutations on preserving the conformational diversity of the protein. Mutations that alter the normal mode subspaces associated with ligand-binding the most are found to be evolutionarily conserved, mostly buried aliphatic residues localized in regular structural regions of the protein like β-sheets and α-helices. Molecular dynamics simulations and normal mode analysis are critical tools for understanding the role of protein dynamics and conformational changes in biological function. Despite the complexity of protein energy functions, normal modes provide a decoupled harmonic description of protein vibrations, making it possible to identify individual equilibrium vibrational motions that participate in ligand-binding. The proposed procedure for defining and comparing normal mode subspaces associated with ligand-binding could enable better understanding of protein-ligand interactions and aid in the development of more effective therapeutic strategies.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) is a pathogen that can survive in diverse host environments due to its metabolic flexibility in utilizing various carbon sources. Fructose bisphosphate aldolase (FBA) is an essential enzyme for Mtb's glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, and it differs from human FBA in its reaction mechanism, making it a potential drug target. To investigate the role of FBA in Mtb's acute and chronic infections and its in vitro essentiality, a study generated Mtb strains with regulated FBA expression using a tunable dual-control genetic switch. The study found that FBA is essential for Mtb's growth during acute and persistence during chronic mouse infections. However, its essentiality is carbon source-dependent, and Mtb can grow without FBA if two carbon sources enter metabolism above and below the FBA-catalyzed step. Complete inactivation of FBA by deletion of fba causes a failure to replicate with a single carbon source, while growth with two carbon sources is not affected. The presence of single carbon sources results in killing of the fba deletion strain, with varying kinetics depending on the specific carbon source. FBA-depleted Mtb fails to replicate in resting bone marrow-derived mouse macrophages and is cleared from mouse lungs by day 10 post-infection. Metabolism of single carbon sources by Δfba significantly alters intracellular metabolite concentrations, with a defect in glucose metabolism due to the absence of FBA activity. Growth of Δfba requires the presence of two carbon sources entering metabolism above and below the FBA-catalyzed reaction, and FBA facilitates the efficient catabolism of butyrate by driving glycolysis. Mtb is more sensitive to FBA depletion when grown with glucose as a sole carbon source than when metabolizing butyrate. This study's findings enhance our understanding of Mtb carbon metabolism and are relevant to tuberculosis drug development.
Two-cysteine peroxiredoxins are ubiquitous peroxidases that play various functions in cells, and they are particularly relevant in Leishmania and related trypanosomatids, which lack catalase and selenium-glutathione peroxidases. A specific enzyme of this family, the mitochondrial 2-Cys peroxiredoxin (mTXNPx), was investigated for its functional relevance along the Leishmania infantum life cycle. mTXNPx null mutants (mtxnpx−) were found to be unable to thrive in a murine model of infection, but this was not due to lack of peroxidase activity. Instead, the enzyme may function as a molecular chaperone, as suggested by its ability to suppress the thermal aggregation of citrate synthase in vitro and by the increased sensitivity of mtxnpx− to a temperature shift from 25°C to 37°C. These findings challenge the paradigm that all trypanosomatid 2-Cys peroxiredoxins are peroxide-eliminating devices and demonstrate that these 2-Cys peroxiredoxins can be determinant for pathogenicity independently of their peroxidase activity.
The Histoplasma urine antigen (HUAg) test, specifically the IMMY ALPHA Histoplasma EIA, is a valuable tool for diagnosing progressive disseminated histoplasmosis (PDH) in HIV patients, especially in regions outside the United States where fungal cultures may not be readily available. In a multicenter, prospective study including two secondary and eight tertiary-care facilities in Mexico, the sensitivity of the ALPHA-HUAg was 67.1% (95% CI, 56-76.8%) and the specificity was 97.5% (95% CI, 94.3%-99.1%). However, the study found that the ALPHA-HUAg was inferior to the MVista-HUAg, which is the centralized test used in the United States. The study also found that a co-existing opportunistic infection was diagnosed in 10.5% of the PDH-proven patients, mostly disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex infection. Therefore, while the IMMY-HUAg may be useful for starting early antifungal treatment, a culture-based approach is necessary since co-infections are frequent and a negative IMMY-HUAg result does not rule out PDH. Histoplasmosis is a mycosis endemic to many parts of Latin America, including Mexico, and its clinical presentation varies depending on the host's immune status. In HIV-infected patients in advanced stages of the disease, it usually presents as PDH, which is fatal unless timely diagnosed and treated. The standard of reference for PDH diagnosis is the isolation of Histoplasma capsulatum from a non-respiratory sample or the visualization of yeast-like structures in the histopathologic examination. However, cultures may require up to six weeks of incubation and handling of H. capsulatum isolates requires advanced biosafety facilities, which are scarce in Latin America. Therefore, some have advocated that histoplasmosis is underreported in Latin America and since it is a neglected disease. In the United States, histoplasmosis is also endemic, and its PDH presentation is commonly diagnosed by the detection of Histoplasma urine antigen (HUAg). This test, introduced in the late 80's, was performed until recently by a single central laboratory. However, in 2007, a new HUAg detection kit was released and approved for clinical use, which is commercially available for on-site use. This test, the IMMY ALPHA Histoplasma EIA, has been considered inferior to the centralized test, but multicenter comparisons of these tests against fungal cultures and histopathology are lacking. For regions outside the United States, an on-site HUAg test is preferred for logistics, costs, and turn-around time of results. Therefore, this study aimed to prospectively and independently evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of ALPHA-HUAg for the PDH diagnosis among HIV-infected patients in Mexico.
"Worldwide, approximately 1.8 million children die from diarrhea annually, with millions more suffering multiple episodes of nonfatal diarrhea. In up to 40% of cases, no etiologic agent can be identified. The advent of metagenomic sequencing has enabled the characterization of microbial populations, allowing for the detection of novel viruses in stool during episodes of acute diarrhea. A study used a ""micro-mass sequencing"" approach, which involves minimal starting sample quantity, minimal sample purification, and limited sequencing, to characterize the eukaryotic viral communities present in diarrhea specimens from 12 children. This methodology detected known enteric viruses as well as multiple sequences from putatively novel viruses with only limited sequence similarity to viruses in GenBank. The study also identified sequences from at least 9 putatively novel viruses, including two novel picobirnaviruses, a novel norovirus, and a novel astrovirus. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that many of the sequences were divergent from known sequences on the order that approximated a distinct subtype or genotype. The detection of these novel or unexpected viruses enables investigations to assess whether these agents play a causal role in human diarrhea."
The Dominican Republic has experienced significant outbreaks of dengue and Zika viruses, transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito, causing widespread morbidity and mortality. A study was conducted using data from 2015-2016 to analyze the transmission dynamics, demographics, and reproductive number (R0) of these outbreaks. The study found that dengue cases were higher in males (54.5%) than females (45.5%), while Zika cases were more prevalent in females (73.8%) than males (26.2%). The R0 for Zika was 1.80 (95% CI 1.78, 1.82), with a higher R0 for females (1.84, 95% CI 1.82, 1.87) than males (1.72, 95% CI 1.69, 1.75). The study also found that Zika cases were more widely distributed among the population compared to dengue, which was mostly reported in those under 20 years old. Existing dengue immunity had little impact on Zika attack rates at the population level, and the accuracy of epidemiological metrics may be affected by sex-specific over-reporting. Community awareness campaigns and screening are recommended for women of reproductive age during Zika outbreaks. Further research is needed to understand clinical Zika outcomes among dengue seropositive individuals. The study's findings can inform public health interventions and control strategies for Aedes-borne arboviruses in the Dominican Republic and similar settings.
In Arabidopsis thaliana, PARP2 rather than PARP1 plays a major role in DNA damage and immune responses, and PARG1 rather than PARG2 is the primary enzyme that counteracts poly (ADP-ribosyl) ation. PARP1 and PARP2 are involved in DNA damage repair and programmed cell death in animals, and in Arabidopsis, they have similar functions in microhomology mediated back-up non-homologous end joining and respond to ionizing radiation, dehydration, and excess cadmium. PARP inhibition in Arabidopsis enhances growth by promoting leaf cell number and makes plants more tolerant to a broad range of abiotic stresses. Arabidopsis PARP proteins make limited contributions to telomere regulation and maintenance, but telomere dysfunction triggers PARP activation. Poly (ADP-ribosyl) ation is reversible and covalently attached poly (ADP-ribose) can be cleaved from acceptor proteins by PARG. Mammalian genomes encode a single PARG gene and mutation of PARG caused enhanced sensitivity to genotoxic stress and embryonic lethality in mice and Drosophila. Unlike animal models, the Arabidopsis genome encodes two PARG genes, PARG1 and PARG2, with 52% amino acid identity. PARG1 and PARG2, as well as an inactive pseudogene At2g31860, are all located adjacent to each other on Arabidopsis chromosome 2. PARG1 was originally identified to play a role in circadian oscillation in Arabidopsis, and the Arabidopsis PARG2 gene is robustly induced by pathogen-associated molecular patterns and numerous different pathogens, but disruption of PARG1, not PARG2, altered various plant defense responses. Arabidopsis PARG1 has also been implicated in drought, osmotic and oxidative stress responses. Despite the above work, the mechanisms by which PARPs and PARGs regulate diverse cellular processes in plants remain largely unknown.
The Pam/Highwire/RPM-1 (PHR) proteins, including the C. elegans ortholog RPM-1, are intracellular signaling hubs that regulate synapse formation and axon termination. RPM-1 acts as a ubiquitin ligase to inhibit the DLK-1 and MLK-1 MAP kinase pathways. A new MAP kinase pathway has been identified, consisting of MIG-15 (MAP4K), NSY-1 (MAP3K), JKK-1 (MAP2K), and JNK-1, which suppress synapse formation defects but not axon termination defects in rpm-1 mutants. This pathway functions cell autonomously in mechanosensory neurons and localizes to presynaptic terminals. Transgenic overexpression of kinases in the MIG-15/JNK-1 pathway impairs synapse formation in wild-type animals. Loss of MIG-15/JNK-1 signaling suppresses habituation defects in rpm-1 mutants, indicating the MIG-15/JNK-1 pathway restricts glutamatergic synapse formation and short-term learning. Previous studies have shown that PHR proteins inhibit MAPK signaling by ubiquitinating MAP3Ks, and JNK signaling needs to be restricted for proper synapse formation. JNK signaling impacts the formation of neuron-neuron, central synapses in vivo, and altered JNK signaling has been linked to synaptic dysfunction in Alzheimer’s disease.
The nematodes C. elegans and C. briggsae share a sex-determination system where the master transcription factor TRA-1 controls sexual development. TRA-1 is a bipotential transcription factor, functioning as both an activator and a repressor, and its activity is regulated by interactions with other proteins and its own cleavage. The study of TRA-1 and its regulation is essential as it controls the sperm/oocyte decision and has been conserved in nematodes. A subset of transcription factors like Gli2 and Oct1 are bipotential, and recent studies have shown that TRA-1 might also be bipotential. The C. briggsae TRR-1 gene, a homolog of mammalian TRRAP, is required for spermatogenesis and works with TRA-1 as a co-activator to promote the expression of genes like fog-3. The relative importance of TRR-1 and TRA-1 has changed dramatically during recent evolution, with C. briggsae trr-1 null mutants preventing hermaphrodite spermatogenesis, and C. elegans fem null mutants preventing spermatogenesis. The relationship between the two halves of a bipotential switch can shift rapidly during evolution, producing the same phenotype by alternative, complementary mechanisms. This study highlights the importance of comparative evolutionary studies in understanding conserved aspects of gene regulation.
Researchers have developed new measures, ΦE and ΦAR, to quantify the extent of information generated by a system as it transitions between states, overcoming limitations of previous measures that were defined only for discrete Markov systems. These new measures can be applied to time-series data and are demonstrated to be effective through simulations. The findings have implications for understanding consciousness and other neurocognitive processes, but also pose challenges for theories that ascribe physical meaning to the measured quantities. The researchers also highlight the importance of measuring dynamical complexity in networks of interconnected elements, such as neural systems, and the potential for dynamical complexity to account for fundamental aspects of consciousness. The study of integrated information, a measure of the amount of information that is integrated by a system, is also discussed, with new versions of this measure being both theoretically well-grounded and practically applicable given time-series data. These new measures have the potential to shed light on many complex systems, both biological and non-biological, and to formulate testable hypotheses and synthetic models relating information integration to cognitive and neural operations.
In recent years, there has been a widespread transmission of Rhodesian human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) in Uganda, raising concerns about a potential overlap with the Gambian form of the disease. A recent study used logistic regression methods to explore the relationship between the prevalence of Rhodesian HAT and several social, environmental, and climatic variables in two of the most recently affected districts of Uganda. The study found that the disease had spread into the study area due to the movement of infected, untreated livestock. This research was extended to account for spatial autocorrelation, incorporate uncertainty in input data and model parameters and undertake predictive mapping for risk of high HAT prevalence in future.The study used a spatial analysis in which a generalized linear geostatistical model was used in a Bayesian framework to account explicitly for spatial autocorrelation and incorporate uncertainty in input data and model parameters. The results strongly support the theory that Rhodesian HAT was imported to the study area via the movement of untreated, infected livestock from endemic areas. The analysis also confirmed the confounding effect of health care accessibility on the spatial distribution of Rhodesian HAT and the linkages between the disease's distribution and minimum land surface temperature. Predictive mapping indicates an increased risk of high HAT prevalence in the future in areas surrounding livestock markets, demonstrating the importance of livestock trading for continuing disease spread.Rhodesian HAT and Gambian HAT are caused by different parasites, and the most effective control options, diagnostic procedures, and treatment regimes differ for the two forms of the disease. Currently, treatment is implemented based on knowledge of the areas affected by each type of HAT, and a definitive diagnostic differentiation between the two parasite subtypes is difficult and requires expensive, complex methods. Consequently, spatial concurrence of the two forms of HAT would compromise diagnostic and treatment protocols, resulting in a higher proportion of treatment failures and placing increased pressure on an already stretched health system.A comprehensive understanding of the social, environmental, and climatic aspects involved in the spatial distribution and spread of Rhodesian HAT is vital to enable the targeting of disease control activities. The interaction of factors influencing the long-distance spread of Rhodesian HAT, such as livestock trading networks, with the environmental and climatic factors controlling the spatial distribution of the disease in affected areas, is not well understood. Such knowledge could provide significant evidence for targeted control measures to prevent the further spread and establishment of the disease.
The consensus that complexity begets stability in ecosystems has been challenged, leading to the discovery that the existence of a feasible equilibrium, assumed in local stability criteria, is not guaranteed in species-rich systems. This is true even when weak interactions are present in ecologically-inspired systems. The dynamical behavior of ecologically inspired architectures is richer than that of unstructured systems. A fundamental question in ecology is understanding the factors and conditions that ensure ecological systems persist, a requisite for the sustained provisioning of vital ecosystem services. Early ideas suggested that complex natural systems are more likely to be stable, but later it was shown that large random systems may be expected to be stable up to a certain connectance threshold, contradicting the earlier ideas. More recent work has established stability criteria for systems where species interact specifically via competition, mutualism, or predation. The general conclusion is that, in species-rich communities, interactions should be moderate to ensure the stability of the equilibrium. Simulations show that such ecologically-inspired structured graphs are less stable than unstructured ones. All these approaches are local-stability analyses, assuming the equilibrium is feasible. However, a true Jacobian, evaluated at the equilibrium, was replaced by a random matrix in previous works. The feasibility of the equilibria was not tested in May's work, and it was found that stability increased with the number of species in feasible systems. Equilibrium-abundances must be strictly positive for a stable equilibrium to be meaningful. A recent study has explored the question of feasibility, showing that keeping the fraction well-defined when the number of species increases requires that the absolute mean interaction strength is small enough. In this work, we present an extensive study of the fundamental question of equilibrium feasibility and investigate how complexity influences feasibility probability. We find that, in situations compatible with previous works, the existence of a feasible equilibrium is not guaranteed, and with weak interactions, non-trivial feasible equilibria are found only in ecologically-inspired systems in a way that is ecologically sensible.
Coxiella burnetii, the bacterium that causes Q fever, is a widespread intracellular pathogen with a near-global distribution, although there are significant gaps in the understanding of its prevalence, spatial distribution, and risk factors in Africa. A recent systematic review highlighted these gaps, focusing on parts of Western and Nyanza Provinces in Western Kenya. A cross-sectional survey was conducted to assess the One Health epidemiology of Q fever in cattle and humans in the region. Serum samples from 2049 humans and 955 cattle were analyzed for C. burnetii antibodies, and questionnaires covering demographic, socio-economic, and husbandry information were administered. These data were linked to environmental datasets based on geographical locations.The overall seroprevalence of C. burnetii was 2.5% in humans and 10.5% in cattle. However, there was no evidence of correlation between cattle and human seroprevalence within households or when incorporating spatial proximity to other households. Multilevel modeling indicated the importance of several factors for exposure to the organism. Cattle obtained from markets (as opposed to those bred in their homestead) and those residing in areas with lower precipitation levels had the highest seroprevalence. For humans, the youngest age group had the highest odds of seropositivity, and there were variations between ethnic groups. Frequent livestock contact, specifically grazing and dealing with abortion material, was also a risk factor.These results illustrate endemicity of C. burnetii in western Kenya, although prevalence is relatively low. Environmental factors may play a role in cattle exposure patterns, while human exposure patterns are likely to be driven more strongly by livestock contacts. The implication of livestock markets in cattle exposure risks suggests these may be a suitable target for interventions.
Schistosomiasis, a tropical disease caused by parasitic flatworms, affects millions of people worldwide. The genome sequences of the three major schistosome species have been determined, necessitating the development of functional genomic approaches to understand the role and importance of these genes. Transgenesis is an established approach for functional genomics, which can lead to gain-or-loss-of-functions, facilitate vector-based RNA interference, and represent a powerful forward genetics tool for insertional mutagenesis screens. However, routinely introducing transgenes into schistosomes is challenging due to the lack of reliable germ cell localization. A potential solution is to transduce the egg, a critical developmental stage in the schistosome life cycle. To monitor transgene integration into schistosome germ cells, vasa, an ATP-dependent DEAD-box RNA helicase, was identified as a germ cell marker. Three vasa-like genes, Smvlg1, Smvlg2, and Smvlg3, were identified in S. mansoni, showing high identity to Vasa proteins from other flukes. These genes exhibited germ cell-specific expression in the posterior ovary, where oocytes mature. These findings suggest that reporter transgenes driven by a vasa promoter might be useful for monitoring transgene integration into schistosome germ cells. Overall, these results contribute to the development of functional genomic approaches for studying schistosome genes, which could lead to the identification of novel targets for anti-schistosomal interventions.
Heart valve disease is a major global health issue, and understanding the mechanisms of cardiac valve development and homeostasis is essential. Hippo signaling is crucial for organ development and tissue homeostasis, but its role in valve formation and maintenance is unclear. A study found that VGLL4, a transcription cofactor, is mainly expressed in valve interstitial cells at the post-EMT stage and is required for normal valve development by antagonizing YAP activity. Tissue-specific knockout of VGLL4 in different cell lineages revealed that only endothelial loss of VGLL4 led to valve malformation. Manipulation of Hippo components could be a potential therapy for preventing the progression of congenital valve disease. The Hippo pathway regulates cell proliferation, differentiation, stem cell fate determination, and organ size in multiple organs and tissues. VGLL4, a member of the Vestigial-like family, is a transcription cofactor that competes with YAP for TEADs binding, resulting in the inhibition of YAP-induced overgrowth and tumor genesis. VGLL4 is the only member of the VGLL family expressed in the heart, and its role in heart valve development and homeostasis has remained unknown. A VGLL4 reporter mouse line was constructed to investigate the VGLL4 expression pattern and found that the expression of VGLL4 increased dramatically in endothelial and interstitial cells in the valve region at the post-EMT stage and was maintained till the adult stage. Endothelial specific and neural crest specific Cre mice were used to knock out VGLL4 in different cell lineages that contribute to valve interstitial cells. The results showed that only endothelial loss of VGLL4 led to valve malformation, and semi-knockout of YAP rescued the phenotype of arterial valves in VGLL4 deleted heart, indicating that VGLL4 was required for normal valve development by antagonizing YAP activity. Therefore, VGLL4 plays a key role in valve development and maintenance.
A debate exists in the scientific community regarding the prevalence and identifiability of soft selective sweeps in natural population data. Some studies argue that soft sweeps are pervasive across organisms, while others claim they are rare. This discrepancy can be attributed to opposing results from different studies and the relevance and identifiability of these models in natural populations. Recent research has highlighted issues with the underlying methodologies of these studies, including high false-positive rates and the oversight of well-fit demographic histories combined with rare hard sweeps. These findings emphasize the importance of proper demographic null models, best practices, and the need for a more nuanced understanding of the role of positive selection in shaping genetic variation. Despite the enthusiasm for invoking soft sweeps, it remains unclear whether they are a common occurrence or a rare exception. Therefore, it is crucial to critically evaluate new methodologies and claims regarding the prevalence and identifiability of soft selective sweeps.
Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are the primary vectors for dengue fever, causing 50-100 million infections in humans per year. Female mosquitoes transmit the disease through blood-feeding, and their host-seeking behavior is inhibited for three days following a blood meal by a hemolymph-borne humoral factor. Head Peptide-I is a candidate peptide mediating this suppression, showing sequence similarity to short Neuropeptide-F peptides that signal through Neuropeptide Y-Like Receptors (NPYLRs). Eight NPYLRs were identified in the Ae. aegypti genome and screened in a cell-based calcium imaging assay for sensitivity against a panel of peptides. NPYLR1 responded to Head Peptide-I as well as sNPFs, and two NPYLR1 homologues were also sensitive to Head Peptide-I in the genome of the Lyme disease vector, Ixodes scapularis. However, npylr1 mutants displayed normal behavior in locomotion, egg laying, sugar feeding, blood feeding, host seeking, and inhibition of host seeking after a blood meal, indicating that other receptors, additional peptides, or both regulate this important behavior. These findings suggest that the inhibition of host-seeking behavior in mosquitoes is a complex process involving multiple signaling pathways. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms underlying this behavior and to develop effective strategies for combating the spread of mosquito-borne diseases.
Schistosomiasis is a parasitic disease that is prevalent in Nigeria and globally, with Nigeria having the highest number of cases in the world. The disease is caused by Schistosoma parasites and is transmitted through contact with freshwater containing cercariae, the parasite's larval stage. The transmission and distribution of schistosomiasis are influenced by environmental factors such as temperature, rainfall, elevation, slope, land use/land cover, and proximity to water bodies. A study was conducted in Akure North Local Government Area (LGA) of Ondo State, Nigeria, to identify areas with suitable conditions for schistosomiasis transmission using remote sensing and spatial analysis.The study focused on temperature, drainage, elevation, rainfall, slope, and land use/land cover as the factors controlling schistosomiasis incidence in the study area. The researchers used multicriteria evaluation (MCE) and Saaty’s analytical hierarchy process (AHP) to obtain the mapping weight or importance of each individual schistosomiasis risk factor. The results showed that a larger portion of the area (82%) fell under the high and very high-risk category, and the predictions made by the model correlated strongly with observations from field studies.Schistosomiasis is a significant public health problem in Nigeria, with S. haematobium being the predominant species. The parasite's life cycle involves a freshwater snail host, and the distribution and abundance of these snails drive the links between transmission and environment/climate. Therefore, temperature, rainfall, proximity to water bodies, and other environmental factors may be possible factors for risk area determination. Remote sensing and geographic information system (GIS) can be used to study the transmission dynamics of the disease and promote prevention and control towards sustainenace of a healthy environment.In conclusion, schistosomiasis is a widespread and neglected tropical disease in Nigeria, with environmental factors playing a significant role in its transmission and distribution. Remote sensing and GIS can be useful tools in identifying and predicting the transmission of schistosomiasis and monitoring disease risk in newly established rural and agricultural communities.
Pneumococcal meningitis, a common bacterial infection of the brain, is associated with significant long-term disabilities and is largely dependent on the presence of the cholesterol-dependent cytolysin pneumolysin (PLY) for its neuropathogenic potential. PLY is critical for the clinical course of experimental pneumococcal meningitis and is persistent in the cerebrospinal fluid, correlating with a poorer prognosis in human patients. A study of human frontal neocortical brain samples obtained from autopsy cases following death from S. pneumoniae meningitis and from control cases found that S. pneumoniae meningitis induced a reduction in synaptic density that was independent of cell death, specifically in the superficial neocortical layers I-II. Further experiments using the PLY-producing S. pneumoniae strain D39 and PLY-deficient mutants confirmed that PLY deficiency strongly diminished synaptic loss in mouse pneumococcal meningitis without an increase in cell death. Exposure of acute mouse brain slices to PLY at disease-relevant, non-lytic concentrations caused permanent dendritic swelling, dendritic spine elimination, and synaptic loss, due to increased glutamate levels within the mouse brain slices. This glutamate-dependent synaptic damage is mediated by PLY initiating glutamate release from astrocytes. These findings demonstrate for the first time the occurrence of synaptic pathology in pneumococcal meningitis and outline a significant synapto- and dendritotoxic role for PLY in the disease through its ability to initiate glutamate release from astrocytes.
Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are associated with major human cancers, and there is interest in developing vaccines and microbicides to prevent HPV infections. The infectious life cycle of HPVs is closely linked to the differentiation state of the stratified epithelium it infects, with progeny virus only made in the terminally differentiating suprabasal compartment. It has been hypothesized that this specificity may be due to the expression of entry receptors, but this could not fully explain the differentiation restriction of HPV infection. A study using chemical biology approaches found that cell cycle progression through mitosis is critical for HPV infection. G1-synchronized human keratinocytes as hosts and early viral gene expression as a readout for infection showed that the recipient cell must enter M phase for HPV infection to take place. This finding provides one reason why HPVs initially establish infections in the basal compartment of stratified epithelia, as only this compartment of the epithelium contains cells progressing through the cell cycle. By defining a major condition for cell susceptibility to HPV infection, these results have potentially important implications for HPV control.
