This suggests that maternal S. mansoni and its treatment during pregnancy may affect immunoregulatory responsiveness in childhood schistosomiasis. In communities where schistosomiasis is endemic, an age-dependent build-up of immune response and resistance to S. mansoni infection is observed, and in-utero sensitisation to schistosome antigens might influence early childhood responses and resistance to infection. Additionally, children who are exposed in-utero, but do not become sensitised, may have acquired tolerance to schistosome antigens, which might render them more susceptible to infection. In-utero sensitisation to schistosome antigens might also influence schistosomiasis morbidity, as early or in-utero sensitisation can modulate the immune response and subsequent pathology associated with S. mansoni infection. A balanced type one/type two immune response is needed to limit morbidity in schistosomiasis, and responses established in-utero could influence this balance. The study followed offspring of women in a randomized, double-blind placebo-controlled trial of praziquantel versus matching placebo and albendazole versus matching placebo during pregnancy. The women provided stool samples that were examined for intestinal helminths including S. mansoni infection. Children were followed up annually and stool and blood samples were collected at each visit. For the current study, the researchers focused on offspring of the study women at age five years. The stool samples were examined for helminth infections including S. mansoni by the Kato Katz method for all children, and blood samples were processed for immune responses, plasma was separated and stored at −80°C, and peripheral blood mononuclear cells were isolated and stored in liquid nitrogen. Whole blood culture for responses to schistosome antigens, and anti-schistosome antibody assays, were performed in a subgroup of 436 children. The levels of endotoxin in the antigen preparations were negligible and unlikely to influence cytokine responses in whole blood culture. Cytokine levels in unstimulated cultures were generally low and cytokine concentrations in unstimulated wells were subtracted from the measured concentrations in antigen-stimulated wells. Plasma levels of IgG1, IgG4 and IgE to SWA and SEA were measured in duplicate by ELISA with a high through-put semi-automated system. The study found that children of women treated with praziquantel during pregnancy had higher IL-10 responses to SWA than those who did not, suggesting that maternal S. mansoni and its treatment during pregnancy may affect immunoregulatory responsiveness in childhood schistosomiasis.
Following an infectious challenge, macrophages are key players in clearance of pathogens, mainly through receptor-mediated phagocytosis. However, certain conditions such as mycobacterial infections can evade this process, leading to survival within macrophages. As an alternative to receptor-mediated phagocytosis, macrophages can internalize material via macropinocytosis, which allows the internalization of large amounts of cargo independent of any receptor usage. A study described inflammatory stimuli as a switch for the macrophage endocytic pathway from receptor-mediated phagocytosis to macropinocytosis. This switch occurs through protein kinase C-mediated phosphorylation of the macrophage protein coronin 1, which relocates from the cell cortex to cytoplasmic puncta and activates phosphoinositol-3-kinase activity, essential for macropinocytic uptake. Furthermore, the authors demonstrated that activated coronin 1 was sufficient to induce PI3-kinase activation and macropinocytosis even in the absence of inflammatory stimuli, suggesting a novel mechanism to regulate the internalization and degradation of infectious material during inflammation. Overall, this study sheds light on the importance of macropinocytosis in inflammation-induced clearance of pathogens, a process that could be targeted in therapeutic interventions for infectious diseases.
In West Nile, Uganda, there are renewed efforts to eliminate neglected tropical diseases, including sleeping sickness, through more cost-effective tsetse control methods. A study was conducted in Arua District to assess community knowledge, perceptions, and acceptance of tsetse baits in villages with and without previous exposure to tsetse control programs. The study found that community perceptions of deployed baits varied significantly between neighboring villages, depending on their duration of experience with tsetse control programs. In villages new to such interventions, negative perceptions, fear, and anxiety related to witchcraft and ghosts were reported. Conversely, in villages with previous exposure, community members had positive attitudes and understood the benefits of tsetse control interventions. To ensure the success of community-based interventions against tsetse, early engagement and carefully designed sensitization campaigns are crucial, especially in communities new to these interventions.Tsetse control plays a significant role in the global effort to eliminate sleeping sickness by 2020. With the advancement in tsetse control technology, making it more cost-effective, easier to deploy, and maintain, large-scale HAT control operations become increasingly attractive. However, community participation is essential for the success of such programs. Lack of sustained government funding, collaboration between provider and beneficiary, and adequate sensitization of communities can hinder the implementation of large-scale vector control operations. Factors like community acceptance of traps, involvement in construction, deployment, and maintenance are vital for the success of tsetse control programs. Negative attitudes and associations with indigenous beliefs might lead to resistance, theft, and vandalism of traps, ultimately causing operational failure.In summary, understanding community perceptions and participation is crucial for the success of large-scale tsetse control programs aimed at eliminating neglected tropical diseases like sleeping sickness. Addressing concerns, involving communities in the process, and designing sensitization campaigns tailored to specific communities can significantly improve the acceptance and success of such interventions.
Recombination is a fundamental biological process with significant evolutionary implications, as it increases the effectiveness of selection in natural populations. However, quantifying its impact has been challenging due to a lack of detailed characterization of recombination rate variation across genomes and within species. This study reports the first high-resolution description of genomic and population variation in recombination for Drosophila melanogaster, differentiating between the two outcomes of meiotic recombination: crossing over (CO) and gene conversion (GC). Researchers characterized the products of 5,860 female meioses by genotyping a total of 139 million informative SNPs and mapped 106,964 recombination events at a resolution down to 2 kilobases. This analysis allowed for the generation of whole-genome CO and GC maps as well as a detailed description of variation in recombination among individuals of this species.The study identified extreme variation and punctuated patterns in CO rates along chromosomes, with hot and coldspots, and extensive intra-specific variation in CO landscapes associated with hotspots at low frequency in the sample. GC rates were more uniformly distributed across the genome than CO rates and detectable in regions with reduced or absent CO. Recombination events were found to be associated with numerous sequence motifs and primarily occurred within transcript regions, suggesting that chromatin accessibility favors double-strand breaks. This detailed characterization of recombination rate variation and its multi-layered variation across genomes and among individuals will improve estimates of recombination rates and inform a new generation of population genetic models of the interaction between selection and linkage.
IDN2, a component of the RNA-directed DNA methylation (RdDM) machinery in Arabidopsis thaliana, interacts with two paralogs IDP1 and IDP2. The XH domain of IDN2 is required for this interaction and is critical for IDN2 function in RdDM and transcriptional gene silencing. IDP1 and IDP2 are incapable of binding double-stranded RNA, suggesting they have distinct roles in the IDN2-IDP1/IDP2 complex. This complex likely facilitates the recruitment of double-stranded RNA-containing effector complexes to specific chromatin regions at a downstream step of the RdDM pathway. IDN2 is capable of interacting with its paralogs IDP1 and IDP2 in vivo and forms a 400-KDa protein complex. IDN2 is most similar to At3g12550 and At4g01780, while IDP1 (AT1G15910) and IDP2 (AT4g00380) are highly similar to each other and exist in another clade of the family. However, IDP1 and IDP2 but not At3g12550 or At4g01780 were co-purified by affinity purification of IDN2. IDP1 is required for siRNA accumulation, de novo DNA methylation, and transcriptional gene silencing, whereas IDP2 has partially overlapping roles with IDP1.
Neutrophils are crucial in the body's defense against various pathogens, including Leishmania braziliensis. They are the first line of defense and are rapidly recruited to the site of Leishmania inoculation. Depletion of inflammatory cells during Leishmania braziliensis infection increases the parasite load, while co-inoculation of neutrophils with L. braziliensis has the opposite effect. In vitro, exposure of neutrophils to L. braziliensis modulates the expression of surface molecules, induces the oxidative burst, and releases inflammatory mediators. This response is mainly observed in infected and not bystander cells. In vivo inoculation of serum-opsonized L. braziliensis promastigotes in mice induces neutrophil accumulation, peaking at 24 hours. These findings suggest that L. braziliensis induces neutrophil recruitment and activates them, which may impact parasite elimination, particularly at the early stages of infection. Neutrophils are essential components of the early inflammatory response and play distinct roles during Leishmania infection depending on the combination of mouse strain and parasite species. They can contribute to parasite killing or enhance disease in resistant or susceptible mice. Following phagocytosis, some Leishmania spp can be found within non-lytic compartments, exploiting neutrophils as to gain access to macrophages where infection is established. In vivo, neutrophils readily arrive at the site of L. major and L. infantum-chagasi inoculation within minutes and capture L. major parasites at the site of sand fly bite. The absence of neutrophils is unfavorable to infection. Therefore, understanding the interaction between neutrophils and L. braziliensis is crucial in developing effective strategies for the treatment and prevention of Leishmaniasis.
Bovine tuberculosis (bTB) is a significant problem for farmers, with costs associated with testing and restrictions on animal movements. Current diagnostic tests for bTB, such as the tuberculin skin test, cannot differentiate between infected and vaccinated animals, which has been a barrier to the use of vaccination as part of control programs. However, new diagnostic tests called DIVA (Differentiate Infected from Vaccinated Animals) have the potential to allow for the use of vaccination in existing eradication programs.Using within-herd transmission models estimated from historical data from Great Britain, researchers explored the feasibility of supplemental use of vaccination within existing bTB eradication programs. The economic impact of bTB for farmers is largely due to the costs associated with testing and restrictions on animal movements. Farmers' willingness to adopt vaccination will require vaccination to not only reduce the burden of infection but also the risk of restrictions being imposed. The research found that, under the intensive sequence of testing in GB, it is the specificity of the DIVA test, rather than the sensitivity, that is the greatest barrier to seeing a herd level benefit of vaccination. The potential negative effects of vaccination could be mitigated through relaxation of testing, but this could potentially increase the hidden burden of infection within Officially TB Free herds.The study estimates that a DIVA specificity of at least 99.85% and sensitivity of >40% is required to see a protective benefit of vaccination with no increase in the risk of missed infection. Data from experimentally infected animals suggest that this target specificity could be achieved in vaccinates using a cocktail of three DIVA antigens while maintaining a sensitivity of 73.3% (95%CI: 61.9, 82.9%) relative to post-mortem detection. Human vaccine Mycobacterium bovis bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccination has been shown to induce significant levels of protection in cattle. However, vaccination is not currently used as part of a national bTB control program due to the interference of BCG with the specificity of the tuberculin skin test. A new generation of diagnostic DIVA tests that can differentiate vaccinated from infected animals has the potential to allow for the use of BCG within current control programs.In summary, the use of vaccination in conjunction with new DIVA diagnostic tests has the potential to improve the control of bTB in cattle, but the specificity of the DIVA test is a key factor in realizing the benefits of vaccination. Further research is needed to optimize the use of these new tools in bTB control programs.
Trichuris trichiura, a human whipworm, infects around 500 million people globally, leading to physical growth and educational performance issues, particularly in children. Current drug treatment options are limited and lack efficacy against the worm, making the development of new treatments crucial. Using Trichuris muris as a model for T. trichiura, researchers screened a library of 480 novel drug-like small molecules and identified a class of dihydrobenz[e][1,4]oxazepin-2(3H)-one compounds with anthelmintic activity against T. muris. Further screening and resynthesis of the most potent molecules led to the identification of 20 active dihydrobenzoxazepinones, a class of molecule not previously implicated in nematode control. These compounds immobilize adult T. muris with EC50 values around 25–50μM, comparable to the existing anthelmintic levamisole. The best compounds from this chemotype show low cytotoxicity against murine gut epithelial cells, demonstrating selectivity for the parasite. Developing a novel oral pharmaceutical treatment for a neglected disease like trichuriasis and deploying it via mass drug administration is challenging. However, the dihydrobenzoxazepinones also reduce the ability of embryonated T. muris eggs to establish infection in the mouse host in vivo, supporting an alternative strategy of developing a therapeutic that acts in the environment, perhaps via a spray, to interrupt the parasite lifecycle. These results highlight the potential of dihydrobenzoxazepinones as a new class of anthelmintic, active against both egg and adult stages of Trichuris parasites, with encouraging selectivity for the parasite and potential for further optimization to improve potency and pharmacokinetic properties for developing a clinical agent.
"The idea of ""date"" and ""party"" hubs in protein-protein interaction networks has been influential in the study of network connectivity, with date hubs displaying low co-expression with partners and party hubs showing high co-expression. However, it has been shown that the importance of date hubs to network connectivity can be attributed to a small subset of them, and these hubs do not display particularly low expression correlation. The distribution of hubs is not always bimodal, as previously thought, and topological properties of hubs do not correlate with co-expression. Despite this, interaction centrality has been found to correlate with the functional similarity of interacting proteins. Protein interaction networks do not capture the fact that actual interactions depend on physiological conditions, and the use of mRNA expression data can help incorporate this information. The date/party hub distinction has been debated and the hypothesis has been prominent in the literature, but the validity of the distinction remains unclear. It is suggested that thinking in terms of a date/party dichotomy for hubs in protein interaction networks is not meaningful, and it might be more useful to conceive of roles for protein-protein interactions rather than for individual proteins. Further research is needed to understand the organization of the interactome."
The development of methodologies for reconstructing transmission trees in infectious disease outbreaks from densely sampled whole genome sequence data has been ongoing in recent years. However, a key limitation of these approaches is the requirement for genetic diversity to arise on epidemiological timescales, meaning that the position of infected individuals in a transmission tree can only be resolved by genetic data if mutations have occurred between the sampled pathogen genomes. The authors of this study introduce the concept of ‘transmission divergence’ to quantify and compare the useful genetic diversity expected from genetic data in different pathogen outbreaks. Transmission divergence is defined as the number of mutations separating whole genome sequences sampled from transmission pairs. The study simulates outbreak scenarios and sequence evolution for ten major outbreak-causing pathogens using two models of sequence evolution to describe transmission divergence. They find that while the mean transmission divergence varies significantly between the pathogens considered, it is generally very low, with many outbreaks characterized by large numbers of genetically identical transmission pairs. The authors demonstrate that genetic sequence data of rapidly evolving pathogens such as RNA viruses can provide valuable information on individual transmission events, while sequence data of pathogens with lower mean transmission divergence provide little to no information about individual transmission events. The study highlights the informational limitations of genetic sequence data in certain outbreak scenarios and the need to expand the toolkit of outbreak reconstruction tools to integrate other types of epidemiological data.
X chromosome inactivation (XCI) silences most genes on one X chromosome in female mammals, but some genes escape XCI. A study analyzed allele-specific expression and chromatin structure of X-linked genes in mouse tissues and cells with skewed XCI and distinguishable alleles. The study found that few genes (3-7%) escape XCI in any of the mouse tissues examined, while an in vitro system showed a higher density of escape genes (21%). Allele-specific RNA polymerase II occupancy and DNase I hypersensitivity at the promoter of genes on the Xi correlated well with levels of escape, consistent with an open chromatin structure at escape genes. The study also found that allele-specific CTCF binding on the Xi clustered at escape genes and was denser in brain compared to the Patski cell line, possibly contributing to a more compartmentalized structure of the Xi and fewer escape genes in brain compared to the cell line. Overall, the study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms that regulate XCI and the identification of escape genes in vivo.
Plasmodium vivax, a significant human malaria species, causes hundreds of millions of illnesses each year, leading to severe morbility and mortality, particularly in children. The emergence and spread of multidrug-resistant vivax malaria are a growing concern, associated with fatal disease. Cysteine proteases of malaria parasites play vital roles in various physiological processes necessary for the parasite's survival. Two cysteine proteases, vivapain (VX) -2 and VX-3, have been identified in P. vivax, but comprehensive studies are hindered by the inability to culture P. vivax. This study describes the biochemical properties of a novel cysteine protease of P. vivax, vivapain-4 (VX-4), exhibiting unusual pH-dependent substrate specificity. Molecular modeling and mutation analysis revealed that Glu180 is involved in the pH-dependent substrate specificity of VX-4. The protease effectively hydrolyzed hemoglobin at acidic pH, actin at neutral pH, and plasmepsin 4 at neutral and acidic pHs, supporting its role in the maintenance of metabolic homeostasis and architectural remodeling of the parasite during growth and development. Further investigation of P. vivax cysteine proteases is essential to understand their biological roles and to characterize targets for antimalarial drugs.
A novel genome-scale model of metabolism and macromolecular synthesis (ME-model) for the model acetogen Clostridium ljungdahlii has been reconstructed, representing the first ME-model for a Gram-positive bacterium. This model includes all major central metabolic, amino acid, nucleotide, lipid, major cofactors, and vitamin synthesis pathways as well as pathways for RNA and protein synthesis necessary for catalyzing these reactions. The ME-model significantly broadens the scope and predictability of microbial systems biology, and enables prediction of fermentation profiles, including overflow metabolism products, gene expression, and usage of cofactors and metals. The model accurately predicted secretion of acetate, ethanol, and glycerol during changing carbon and metal availability, and revealed how protein allocation and media composition influence metabolic pathways and energy conservation in this model acetogen. The model was able to predict both batch and nutrient-limited growth conditions, and identified unique growth rate and yield functions for growth with CO, CO2+H2, or fructose. The ME-model was able to recapitulate overflow metabolism by accounting for redox balancing and concurrent proteome limitations, and was able to predict substrate-specific growth rates with high accuracy. The ME-model predicted previously unknown secretion of glycerol following acetate and ethanol production during growth on xylose or glucose. In silico maximum growth rates for individual substrates can be obtained through the ME-model, which predicted slower growth on glucose than for fructose, in contrast to the M-model. Overall, the iJL965-ME model provides a robust, genome-wide approach to define how transition metals affect an organism’s functional network, particularly for acetogens where metals are crucial for the Wood-Ljungdahl pathway.
Current genome-wide association studies (GWAS) are using large cohorts of primary cell lines to study a disease of interest and assign biological relevance to genetic signals. This approach is demonstrated using a panel of human osteoblasts (HObs) to perform a transcriptomic survey, similar to previous studies in lymphoblastoid cell lines (LCLs). The distinct nature of HObs and LCLs is reflected by the grouping of cell type-specific genes within biologically and functionally relevant pathways unique to each tissue type. A cis-association analysis identified genetic variations of transcript isoforms, with differential expression controlled by cis-regulatory genetic variants in both a tissue-specific and tissue-independent fashion. Examination of the top SNPs from a GWAS of bone mineral density revealed overlap with probeset associations observed in this study, with a novel transcript isoform variant identified for the top hit corresponding to the FAM118A gene. This study suggests that multiple transcript isoforms are often present in both tissues, with genetic control affecting the relative expression of one isoform to another. This approach is useful for detecting the proportion of genetic variation common to different cell types and for the identification of cell-specific isoform variants that may be functionally relevant.
Saccharomyces eubayanus, a non-S. cerevisiae parent of S. pastorianus lager-brewing hybrid, cannot utilize the maltotriose, a major carbohydrate in brewer’s wort. However, S. eubayanus strain CBS 12357T has four SeMALT genes that enable uptake of the alpha-di-glucoside maltose. A study aimed to examine the evolvability of maltotriose utilization in S. eubayanus CBS 123
The variants of human influenza virus have caused and continue to cause significant morbidity and mortality. Current approaches to assess the impact of influenza on human death rely mostly on intensive and unbiased influenza surveillance, but this presents a substantial challenge. A study proposes a novel host-virus interaction model and establishes a positive correlation between the excess mortalities caused by viral strains of distinct antigenicity and their antigenic distances to their previous strains for each (sub) type of seasonal influenza viruses. Based on this relationship, the study further develops a method to rapidly assess the mortality burden of influenza A (H1N1) virus by accurately predicting the antigenic distance between A (H1N1) strains. Rapid estimation of influenza mortality burden for new seasonal strains should help formulate a cost-effective response for influenza control and prevention. Seasonal influenza viruses have been and will continue to be a significant threat to public health. There are three types of seasonal influenza – A, B and C. Among them, influenza H1N1 and H3N2 of type A and type B are currently circulating frequently in the human population. During evolution, many variants of influenza virus with distinct antigenic properties have emerged either by mutation or reassortment of the gene encoding the viral coat protein hemagglutinin (HA). These antigenic variants have caused morbidity and mortality with varying magnitude. If the mortality burden of a newly emerged virus can be estimated accurately and in time, this knowledge will be extremely valuable not only for public preparedness for an impending epidemic/pandemic but also for the health authorities to develop cost-effective control and intervention strategies.
The Asian soybean rust fungus, Phakopsora pachyrhizi, is a significant threat to soybean production, causing severe disease epidemics. The genomes of rust fungi encode many small, secreted cysteine-rich proteins (SSCRP) that are thought to function within the host, but their roles are unknown. This study characterizes PpEC23, a SSCRP of P. pachyrhizi, and shows that it suppresses plant immunity and interacts with a soybean transcription factor, GmSPL12l. Plants with silenced GmSPL12l have constitutively active immunity, identifying it as a negative regulator of soybean defenses. These findings suggest that PpEC23 is able to suppress soybean immune responses and physically interact with a soybean transcription factor that negatively regulates the immune system, providing insights into the mechanisms by which rust pathogens manipulate host immune systems.
Chlamydia trachomatis, an obligate intracellular bacterium, invades host cells and replicates inside a membrane-bound vacuole called inclusion. The bacterium induces a long-lasting activation of the PI3 kinase (PI3K) signaling pathway, which is required for its efficient replication. The EphrinA2 receptor (EphA2) is identified as a chlamydial adherence and invasion receptor that induces PI3K activation, promoting chlamydial replication. Interfering with the binding of C. trachomatis to EphA2, downregulation of EphA2 expression, or inhibition of EphA2 activity significantly reduces C. trachomatis infection. C. trachomatis interacts with and activates EphA2 on the cell surface, resulting in Ctr and receptor internalization. During chlamydial replication, EphA2 remains active, accumulating around the inclusion and interacting with the p85 regulatory subunit of PI3K to support the activation of the PI3K/Akt signaling pathway necessary for normal chlamydial development. Overexpression of full-length EphA2, but not the mutant form lacking the intracellular cytoplasmic domain, enhances PI3K activation and Ctr infection. Despite the depletion of EphA2 from the cell surface, Ctr infection induces upregulation of EphA2 through the activation of the ERK pathway, which keeps the infected cell in an apoptosis-resistant state. These findings suggest that EphA2 is exploited by C. trachomatis as an entry and intracellular signaling receptor to facilitate chlamydial replication, representing a new mechanism by which Chlamydia subverts the host cell and induces apoptosis resistance.
"Neurons have active dendrites to enhance their dynamic range due to the enormous number of afferent synapses and large variability of input rates. The presence of extensive dendritic trees and active ion channels allows for non-linear summation and dendritic spikes, leading to ""dendritic computation."" This ability to perform computations and enhance dynamic range is not fully accounted for by passive cable theory or biophysical neuron models with few compartments. The collective behavior of interacting branchlets within a dendritic tree provides a theoretical background for understanding the cooperative behavior of these excitable media. This behavior includes the creation and annihilation of non-linear pulses, leading to a highly non-linear input-output transfer function and a very large dynamic range. This dynamic range is largely dependent on dimensionality, network topology, symmetries, parameter randomness, noise, and boundary conditions, rather than the detailed modeling of the basic compartmental unit."
The use of time-series transcriptomics data to infer regulatory interactions and create quantitative models of gene regulation has been extensively studied in various fields such as drug discovery, cancer research, and biotechnology. However, these methods are based on assumptions regarding biological processes that may not always be valid. These assumptions include the use of mRNA abundance as a proxy for protein concentrations, and the assumption that changes in gene expression are solely due to transcription factors and specific regulators, neglecting global physiological effects. A study was conducted using models and experiments in vivo to investigate the importance of these assumptions and develop possible corrections. The study used time-series data of the FliA-FlgM module of the E. coli motility network to measure gene activity and estimate protein concentrations and global physiological effects. The findings suggest that correcting for the bias of the assumptions improves the quality of the models. The study shows that incorporating these corrections greatly improves inference results in the FliA-FlgM module, demonstrating the importance of global physiological effects and the active regulation of FliA and FlgM half-lives in the dynamics of FliA-dependent promoters. Overall, the study's approach is applicable to various problems in network inference when using time-series transcriptome data.
A study on the rodent species Oligoryzomys fulvescens (O. fulvescens) was conducted in the community of Agua Buena, Tonosí County, Panama, between April 2006 and December 2009. The study aimed to characterize the landscape distribution and spatio-temporal dynamics of O. fulvescens, an important mammalian reservoir in Central America. The research used a mark-recapture longitudinal study and spatial statistical analyses to examine the spatial association patterns among local populations of O. fulvescens. The study found that the local spatial abundance of O. fulvescens was spatially aggregated over relatively short distances and showed a shift in hot spots that changed over multiple years. The distribution and abundance of the O. fulvescens populations fluctuated widely both among the seasons and across years. The repeated absence of O. fulvescens at trapping sites during the transitional months of the season followed by its re-establishment suggests that the population is being maintained by repeated recolonization from somewhere off the study site. The research highlights the challenges in monitoring or predicting zoonotic disease outbreaks at the level of reservoir populations, which are subject to fluctuations over time and have geographically restricted populations. The study provides an important characterization of the challenges in understanding the environmental factors and seasonal cues that may be crucial to habitat shifts by zoonotic hosts.
"The inability to distinguish mutations that determine an organism's phenotype from ""hitchhiker"" mutations is a significant challenge in genome research, with important implications for medical and biotechnological applications. For human influenza viruses, recognizing changes in the antigenic phenotype and a strain's ability to evade pre-existing host immunity is crucial for producing efficient vaccines. A new method for inferring ""antigenic trees"" for the major viral surface protein hemagglutinin has been developed, which assigns antigenic weights to all tree branches and allows for the resolution of the antigenic impact of associated amino acid changes. This technique predicted antigenic distances with comparable accuracy to antigenic cartography and identified both known and novel sites and amino acid changes with antigenic impact in the evolution of influenza A (H3N2) viruses from 1968 to 2003. Influenza viruses cause approximately 500,000 deaths annually and are a significant threat to human health. The antigenic impact of individual amino acid exchanges is not yet fully understood, and computational methods for determining this impact do not exist, requiring time- and cost-intensive experimental characterization of mutant viruses. The method described in this study allows for a more fine-grained resolution of the antigenic impact of individual changes without the need for experimental characterization. This technique has significant implications for understanding the evolution and antigenic impact of mutations in influenza and other pathogens."
A high-throughput RNAi silencing screen identified a cluster of mitotic genes required for human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV16) infection, revealing a new mechanism for import of the viral DNA into the nucleus. In interphase cells, viruses are endocytosed and routed to the perinuclear area, but the viral DNA (vDNA) fails to be imported into the nucleus. During mitosis, the vDNA and L2 associate with host cell chromatin on the metaphase plate, suggesting that HPV16 requires nuclear envelope breakdown for access of the vDNA to the nucleoplasm. This study highlights the value of genes found by RNAi screens for understanding viral infections and provides a resource for future virus-host cell interaction studies.
Black Sigatoka, caused by the fungus Pseudocercospora fijiensis, is the most destructive foliar disease of bananas worldwide, requiring frequent fungicide applications that increase costs and lead to fungicide-resistant strains. The P. fijiensis genome, sequenced in two strains, is the largest among Dothideomycetes due to LTR retrotransposons, with genetic differentiation and high diversity in field populations. A homologue of the Cladosporium fulvum Avr4 effector was identified, potentially aiding in fungicide treatment and breeding programs. The disease's impacts are significant, with enormous environmental costs and potential crop losses, particularly affecting the global banana trade and smallholder farmers who rely on bananas as a staple food. The P. fijiensis genome sequence offers insights into Dothideomycete genome structures and the potential for improved disease management.
A novel method to infer lineage-specific transcription factor binding sites (TFBS) and trace their evolutionary origin was developed and applied to analyze the evolution of binding sites for six transcription factors (GATA1, SOX2, CTCF, MYC, MAX, ETS1) in the human lineage after the human-mouse common ancestor. The method utilizes a birth-death model to estimate the birth and death rates of TFBS, and infers the ancestral states of a given motif without relying on base-by-base alignment details in cross-species sequence alignments. The results show that a substantial fraction of binding sites (∼58-79% for each factor) in humans have origins since the divergence with mouse, and over 15% of all binding sites are unique to hominids. These lineage-specific regulatory elements are often enriched near genes associated with specific pathways and harbor more common SNPs than older binding sites in the human genome. This method helps understand the role of regulatory element evolution in shaping variation in gene regulation across species, and paves the way for further studies on the functional consequences of these lineage-specific regulatory elements.
The zebrafish is a valuable model for studying the process of circadian clock entrainment as its tissues directly respond to light, leading to local clock entrainment and gene expression, including clock genes. A Light Responsive Module (LRM) within the per2 promoter of the zebrafish period2 (per2) gene, which is proximal to the transcription start site, is both necessary and sufficient for light-driven gene expression and clock regulation. The LRM is strongly conserved in other vertebrate per2 genes and contains E- and D-box elements that are critical for its function. The E-box directs circadian clock regulation, while the D-box confers light-driven expression. The zebrafish homolog of the thyrotroph embryonic factor binds efficiently to the LRM D-box and transactivates expression, with tef mRNA levels being light inducible. Knock-down of tef expression attenuates light-driven transcription from the per2 promoter in vivo. These findings suggest a model where a light-dependent crosstalk between E- and D-box binding factors is a central determinant of per2 expression, extending the understanding of the mechanism of clock entrainment by light and the regulation of clock gene expression by light in vertebrates.
Malaria is caused by Plasmodium parasites, which need to migrate at various stages of their complex life cycle. The sporozoite stage, which infects the liver, has the most impressive motility. It moves through the skin and other tissues using a gliding motion driven by actin filaments and myosin underneath the plasma membrane. Actin filaments are regulated by actin-binding proteins, including coronin, which is the only bona-fide actin filament-binding protein in Plasmodium. Coronin is conserved in Plasmodium species and has one or two WD40 repeat-containing β-propellers that mediate actin filament-binding. It can also bind membranes and interact with other proteins. In P. berghei, coronin localizes to the sporozoite periphery in a calcium-dependent but actin-independent manner and contributes to parasite motility through actin filament-binding. It is required for efficient transmission of the parasite from mosquitoes to mice. Coronin (−) parasites and parasites expressing mutated coronin show defects in salivary gland invasion and migration. Coronin might be involved in a switch in signaling pathways linking calcium- and cAMP-mediated signaling during migration and invasion.
Leishmania mexicana is a significant burden to global health, with few treatment options available. Amphotericin B (AmB) is an important drug for treating leishmaniasis, but resistance is a concern. Four novel AmB-resistant L. mexicana lines were studied, all with altered sterol biosynthesis and hypersensitivity to pentamidine. Whole genome sequencing revealed resistance-associated mutation of the sterol biosynthesis gene sterol C5-desaturase in one line, while three out of four lines had loss of expression of sterol C24-methyltransferase (SMT), responsible for drug resistance and altered sterol biosynthesis. This loss of SMT expression was due to structural variations at the locus, possibly promoted by local regions of sequence homology and retrotransposon elements. This repeat sequence-mediated instability is concerning, as it provides an important example of how copy number instability in Leishmania genomes contributes to resistance to an antileishmanial drug of growing importance, with no evidence of associated fitness costs.
In this study, researchers aimed to understand the interaction between attention and prediction in the human brain, and how they modulate information processing. The researchers had participants perform a visual task while recording their neural activity using electroencephalography (EEG). Participants were asked to attend or ignore a periodic stream of gratings, the orientations of which could be predictable, surprising, or unpredictable. The study applied forward encoding models to the EEG data to investigate the effects of attention on two distinct types of information: feature and mismatch information.The findings suggest that surprising stimuli evoke neural responses related to the difference between predicted and observed stimulus features (mismatch information), and attention facilitated the encoding of this type of information in the brain. Moreover, attention increased the selectivity for mismatch information in the neural response to surprising stimuli. These results support the theory that attention optimizes precision expectations during hierarchical inference by increasing the gain of prediction errors.The study also aimed to compare the 'mismatch information model' and the 'feature information model' in explaining the neural coding of surprising stimuli in the human brain and the influence of selective attention on each of these two neural codes. The results support the 'mismatch information model,' indicating that attention increases the selectivity for mismatch information in the neural response to surprising stimuli relative to unsurprising stimuli. It also suggests that top-down prediction signals cancel out bottom-up sensory signals that match the predicted content, leaving only the remaining prediction error to propagate forward and update a model of the sensory environment.In sum, this study employed forward encoding models on EEG data to understand the interaction between attention and prediction in information processing in the human brain. The findings support the theory that attention optimizes precision expectations during hierarchical inference and that attention increases the selectivity for mismatch information in the neural response to surprising stimuli. The study provides new insights into the role of attention and prediction in information processing in the human brain.
Trypanosoma brucei, an important parasite in sub-Saharan Africa, has three sub-species with different geographical distributions, hosts, and diseases. T. b. brucei cannot infect humans because it is sensitive to trypanosome lytic factors (TLF) in human serum. However, T. b. gambiense and T. b. rhodesiense can infect humans as they are resistant to lysis by human serum. T. b. gambiense, the West African trypanosome, is responsible for over 90% of African sleeping sickness cases. A critical aspect of African trypanosome biology is that the adaptive immune response of vertebrates is ineffective due to the parasite's ability to evade the immune response by changing the variable surface glycoprotein (VSG) antigens on its cell surface. Primates, including humans, rely on innate immunity to prevent infection in the form of TLFs in serum. There are two distinct forms of TLF particles, TLF-1 and TLF-2, in human serum. TLF-1 is a member of the HDL family, while TLF-2 is a related high molecular weight serum protein complex. HPR and APOL1 are two primate-specific proteins found in TLF, necessary for optimal lysis, and have complementary roles. HPR facilitates uptake of TLF-1 via the HpHbR receptor, while APOL1 has lytic activity against trypanosomes, disrupting their lysosome membrane and causing osmotic lysis. The two human-infective trypanosome sub-species have evolved counter-measures to overcome the innate defense factors. T. b. gambiense and T. b. rhodesiense have distinct mechanisms of human serum resistance. T. b. gambiense has two distinct groups that differ in genotype and phenotype. Group 1 T. b. gambiense has a stable human serum resistance trait that may, in part, be due to a reduced uptake of TLF-1, possibly due to reduced expression of the HpHbR receptor. Group 2 T. b. gambiense exhibits a variable human serum resistance phenotype superficially similar to T. b. rhodesiense. Research has shown that isogenic resistant and sensitive group 2 T. b. gambiense parasites expressed the HpHbR gene at similar levels and internalized TLF-1 similarly to T. b. brucei. However, unlike group 1 T. b. gambiense, group 2 parasites are resistant to the main lytic component APOL1, and the expression does not appear to correlate with a change in expression site or expression of HpHbR, suggesting differences in the mechanism of human serum resistance between T. b. gambiense groups 1 and 2.
HIV-1 latency, the main obstacle to eradicating HIV-1 from infected patients, is established in a reservoir of resting memory CD4+ T cells that escapes host immune responses and antiretroviral therapy. Transcriptional shutdown and multistep formation of restrictive chromatin at long terminal repeats (LTR) lead to the latent state of HIV-1 provirus. CpG methylation of retroviral promoter sequences is another transcriptional silencing mechanism that contributes to difficulties in accessing transcription factors to target DNA. However, the role of proviral DNA methylation in HIV-1 latency is not clear. In an in vitro model of reactivable latency and in a latent reservoir of HIV-1-infected patients, CpG methylation of the HIV-1 5′ LTR is an additional epigenetic restriction mechanism that controls resistance of latent HIV-1 to reactivation signals and determines the stability of HIV-1 latency. Transcriptional reactivation is accompanied by changes in local chromatin structure and the recruitment of chromatin remodeling factors. Tight but incomplete control of HIV-1 latency by CpG methylation might have important implications for strategies aimed at eradicating HIV-1 infection.
The Drosophila Genetic Reference Panel (DGRP) is a population resource consisting of 192 sequenced wild-derived inbred Drosophila melanogaster lines, which is useful for understanding genome function due to the availability of powerful genetic tools and resources. A nucleotide-resolution catalog of variants, including SNPs, insertions, deletions, complex substitutions, and structural variants in 39 DGRP lines, was generated using an integrative approach for variant discovery. This allowed for the identification of over 3.6 million unique sequence variants across all 39 DGRP lines, including 2.8 million SNPs, 0.6 million indels, and 0.2 million complex sequence variants. The majority of these variants are a substantial source of genomic variation in Drosophila, with a SNP every 43 bp and an indel or complex variant every 144 bp. The accuracy of the variant catalogue is of similar quality as variant data produced for other organisms using high-throughput sequencing. This high-resolution variant data was then used to investigate the impact of naturally occurring genetic variation on adult gene expression, revealing novel insights into the regulatory architecture of gene expression variation in Drosophila.
The article discusses the use of rectified surface EMG signals as an estimator of neural drive to muscles, and how amplitude cancellation can distort this correlation. An ideal rectified EMG signal (EMGnc) without amplitude cancellation is shown to be a better estimator of the neural drive than the actual rectified EMG signal. The correlation between the neural drive and EMGnc is strong, but this correlation decreases linearly with amplitude cancellation. A stronger neural drive implies a stronger correlation between the rectified EMG and the neural drive, but amplitude cancellation distorts this correlation, particularly for low-frequency components of the neural drive. The study concludes that valid use of the rectified EMG as an estimator of the neural drive requires low contraction levels and/or strong common synaptic input to the motor neurons. The pool of motor neurons innervating a muscle receives a large relative proportion of common synaptic input, which is transmitted to the motor neuron output generating the neural drive to the muscle. The neural drive to muscles can be measured directly from motor unit recordings or indirectly inferred from surface EMG signals. However, the amplitude of the EMG signal can be influenced by the waveforms of the motor unit action potentials, and rectification of the EMG signal is typically recommended to reduce the influence of these waveforms. Amplitude cancellation can reduce the EMG amplitude and limit the possibility of accurately inferring individual frequency components of the neural drive to muscle from the rectified EMG.
Auxin, a phytohormone involved in various plant processes, is necessary for aluminum (Al) stress-induced root growth inhibition, but the molecular mechanism is largely unknown. The YUCCA (YUC) genes, which encode flavin monooxygenase-like proteins, regulate local auxin biosynthesis in the root apex transition zone (TZ) in response to Al stress. Al stress up-regulates YUC3/5/7/8/9 in the root-apex TZ, leading to auxin accumulation and root-growth inhibition. This process depends on ethylene signaling, as increasing or disrupting ethylene signaling enhances or reduces YUC up-regulation, respectively. Ethylene-insensitive3 (EIN3) and PHYTOCHROME INTERACTING FACTOR4 (PIF4) function as transcriptional activators for YUC5/8/9 in this process. PIF4 promotes Al-inhibited primary root growth by regulating local YUCs and auxin signal in the root-apex TZ. The Al-induced expression of PIF4 in root TZ acts downstream of ethylene signaling. YUCs play a role in the auxin response in the root-apex TZ during Al stress. Al stress up-regulates YUCs, driving up auxin accumulation in the root-apex TZ and inhibiting root growth. The Al stress-regulated up-regulation of YUCs is modulated by an ethylene-dependent process. EIN3 and EIL1 may play an important role in the Al-regulated local up-regulation of YUCs, as Al stress induces a clear local up-regulation of EIN3p:GFP and EIL1p:GFP in the root-apex TZ. EIN3 can physically bind to the YUC9 promoter, and EIN3 overexpression can increase YUC9 promoter activity. PIF4 is involved in Al-inhibited primary root growth by regulating YUC5, YUC8, and YUC9 expression. YUCs are locally induced in the root-apex TZ in the presence of Al stress, and PIF4 regulates Al stress-induced local up-regulation of YUCs in root-apex TZ. The Al-induced local expression of PIF4 is regulated by ethylene signaling. The up-regulation of PIF4 in the root-apex TZ under Al stress is regulated by ethylene signaling, as Al stress-induced up-regulation of PIF4p:GFP in the root-apex TZ is intensified by the ACC co-treatment, but repressed by the AVG co-treatment.
Natural killer (NK) cells in primates are regulated in part by interactions between two highly polymorphic molecules, killer-cell immunoglobulin-like receptors (KIRs) on NK cells and major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I ligands on target cells. A common MHC class I molecule in the rhesus macaque, Mamu-A1*002, binds to the inhibitory receptor Mamu-KIR3DL05, and this interaction is stabilized by certain simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) peptides. These SIV peptides, when bound by Mamu-A1*002, suppress the cytolytic activity of primary Mamu-KIR3DL05+ NK cells. Changes in C-terminal positions of the peptide can convert inhibitory peptides into disinhibitory peptides, and vice versa. Viral peptides can differentially affect NK cell responses by modulating MHC class I interactions with inhibitory KIRs, providing a mechanism by which immunodeficiency viruses may evade NK cell responses. NK cells play an important role in innate defense against viral pathogens, differentiating virus-infected cells from healthy cells through the integration of complex signals from activating and inhibitory receptors. Polymorphic differences in KIR and HLA class I genes can influence the course of HIV-1 infection, as well as the outcome of infection with other viral pathogens. Immunodeficiency viruses, such as HIV-1 and SIV, may acquire changes in epitopes that increase the binding of MHC class I ligands to inhibitory KIRs to impair NK cell killing of virus-infected cells.
Bacterial pathogens, including nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae (NTHI), must sense, respond, and adapt to various microenvironmental stressors to survive and cause chronic infections. A study examining NTHI-induced otitis media (OM) found that strains adapted to survive nutrient deprivation may be more adept at colonization and chronic infection. In a preclinical model of NTHI-induced OM, transient nutrient limitation resulted in microevolution of NTHI, with a mutation in the icc gene leading to decreased 3' , 5'-cyclic adenosine monophosphate phosphodiesterase activity. This mutation resulted in decreased recovery of middle ear fluid, indicative of disease resolution, but bacterial burdens in the middle ear remained similar to the parental strain. Additionally, the icc mutant formed significantly more intracellular bacterial communities (IBCs) than the parental strain. These findings suggest that NTHI microevolution during nutritional limitation may contribute to both chronic and recurrent disease associated with OM. Bacteria, including NTHI, can adapt to stresses such as nutrient limitation through transcriptional, epigenetic, and genetic mechanisms. Identification of genes subject to microevolution provides insight into new therapeutic targets to quell infection.
Iron plays a critical role in host-pathogen interactions, being a crucial nutrient for both microbial pathogens and their mammalian hosts. Macrophages are essential for immune function and also contribute to iron homeostasis maintenance by obtaining heme iron from phagocytosed senescent or damaged erythrocytes and utilizing transferrin-bound iron or non-transferrin-bound iron via specific transporters. The natural resistance macrophage protein 1 can pump iron from late endosomes and phagolysosomes into the cytoplasm, while the lipocalin 2 receptor allows macrophages to acquire both iron-laden and iron-free complexes of siderophores and lipocalin 2. Excess intracellular iron is stored in ferritin, or exported by the transmembrane protein ferroportin, whose expression is increased by heme and iron. The expression of ferroportin is controlled systemically by hepcidin, an acute-phase peptide secreted by hepatocytes and macrophages, leading to intracellular iron accumulation and hypoferremia when bound to ferroportin. Limiting iron availability from invading pathogens represents a key pathway in host defense, and successful pathogens must employ mechanisms to evade nutritional immunity to cause disease.Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of melioidosis, is a gram-negative bacterium found in tropical and subtropical areas, with its major endemic regions in Southeast Asia and northern Australia. The bacterium can enter, survive, and replicate within mammalian host cells by using a type three secretion system. Previous work has pointed toward a link between high iron levels and the occurrence of B. pseudomallei in soil or water samples. Iron supplementation in soil can affect the growth of B. pseudomallei, increase biofilm formation, and change the pathogen's morphology, which may be advantageous for its persistence in the environment and transmission to humans. B. pseudomallei produces a hydroxamate-type siderophore, malleobactin, able to capture iron from host proteins transferrin and lactoferrin, and several genes encoding iron acquisition systems, including for the siderophore pyochelin and the uptake of heme or plasma membrane iron transporters.Recent studies revealed that conditions with enhanced iron stores, such as thalassemia or idiopathic pulmonary hemosiderosis, are risk factors for melioidosis. However, the contribution of the HO-1 metabolite iron during B. pseudomallei infection is not well understood. Therefore, a study was conducted to define the changes of macrophage iron homeostasis upon infection and to elucidate the importance of such modifications for host susceptibility or resistance to infection. The study found that B. pseudomallei has developed strategies to circumvent iron restriction mechanisms of the host and that alterations in iron homeostasis can influence the course of murine melioidosis.
"The authors propose a novel technique called ""functional mode analysis"" to identify collective motions directly related to a specific protein function. This technique requires an ensemble of protein structures and a ""functional quantity"" that quantifies the functional state of the protein. The functional quantity could be a geometric, electrostatic, or chemical observable, or any other variable relevant to the protein's function. The technique detects the collective motion that is maximally correlated to the functional quantity and estimates the motion that is most likely to induce a substantial change in the functional quantity. The paper applies this approach to several biomolecules, including a polyalanine-helix, T4 lysozyme, Trp-cage, and leucine-binding protein.Protein function is often the result of collective atomic motions. Identifying these motions and relating them to the protein's function is essential for understanding its functional mechanisms. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and experimental methods like nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), X-ray crystallography, and single-molecule fluorescence or electron-transfer measurements have been used to elucidate collective motions in proteins. However, established methods such as principal component analysis (PCA) and normal mode analysis (NMA) may not necessarily yield collective motions directly related to protein function.The proposed functional mode analysis (FMA) technique seeks to address this challenge by elucidating collective motions directly related to a specific protein function. FMA requires a set of protein structures and a ""functional quantity"" expressed as a single number for each input structure. The functional quantity can be a geometric, electrostatic, or chemical observable relevant to the protein's function. FMA seeks the collective protein motion that is maximally related to the functional quantity, aiming to explain variations in the functional quantity in terms of collective motions.The paper provides four examples of FMA applied to a polyalanine helix, T4 lysozyme, Trp-cage, and leucine-binding protein. The examples demonstrate FMA's ability to detect functionally relevant collective motions. The proposed method could help better understand the complex interplay between protein motion and function, ultimately contributing to a more profound understanding of protein function and behavior."
Nuclear genes of certain eukaryotes, particularly euglenids and marine diplonemids, contain unique, nonconventional introns that differ from typical spliceosomal introns found in other eukaryotic genomes. These nonconventional introns have no conserved borders, and they form a stable secondary structure bringing together both exon/intron junctions. The removal of nonconventional introns occurs rapidly but later than spliceosomal introns. An analysis of the tubA and gapC genes in Euglena gracilis, which contain both types of introns, revealed that conventional introns are removed before nonconventional introns. Additionally, the order of intron removal is not always consistent with their arrangement in the gene or transcript. The splicing of adjacent introns generally follows a 'first-come-first-served' model, but several factors, such as intron length, exon length, and the composition of intronic and exonic splicing enhancers and silencers, can influence the directing of intron removal. Non-collinear removal of introns from pre-mRNA is observed in transcripts undergoing alternative splicing, wherein constitutive introns are mainly co-transcriptionally removed, whereas alternative introns are removed post-transcriptionally.
Coxsackievirus B (CVB) is a common enterovirus that typically causes a self-limited febrile illness in infants but can occasionally lead to severe infection and manifest as acute myocarditis. The chronic consequences of mild CVB infection are unknown, but there is an epidemiologic association between early subclinical infections and late heart failure. A mouse model of juvenile CVB3 infection demonstrated that subclinical doses of CVB3 caused no evident symptoms in mice, but following physiological or pharmacologically-induced cardiac stress, juvenile-infected adult mice underwent cardiac hypertrophy and dilation, indicating progression to heart failure. Evaluation of the vasculature in the hearts of adult mice subjected to cardiac stress showed a compensatory increase in CD31+ blood vessel formation, although this effect was suppressed in juvenile-infected mice. Furthermore, CVB3 efficiently infected juvenile c-kit+ cells, and cardiac progenitor cell numbers were reduced in the hearts of juvenile-infected adult mice. These results suggest that the exhausted cardiac progenitor cell pool following juvenile CVB3 infection may impair the heart's ability to increase capillary density to adapt to increased load.CV are human pathogens that typically cause a self-limited infection with mild symptoms, but can also cause severe inflammatory diseases including myocarditis and dilated cardiomyopathy. Although the manifestation of a cardiac disease phenotype is rare, it has been documented that subclinical CV infection can cause subtle but lasting injury, although it is unclear whether such enduring damage is immune-mediated or due to virus-mediated cytopathic effects. Previous studies suggest that CVB3 may exhibit unique tropism for undifferentiated cells such as neural and hematopoietic progenitor cells, thereby altering cell lineage commitment or diminishing their restorative capacity.Based on these observations, researchers investigated the effect of CVB3 on CPCs in the developing heart. They established a mouse model of juvenile CVB3 infection and observed that not only did CVB3 productively infect CPCs but infection caused a sustained reduction in the CPC pool into adulthood. These results suggest that a mild CVB3 infection may predispose the heart to pathologic remodeling later in adult life, leading to dilated cardiomyopathy. Immunostaining confirmed that in infected mice, viral protein expression colocalized with c-kit and Sca-1, indicating infection of CPCs in the juvenile heart. Viral protein expression was not observed in the surrounding myocardium, suggesting that CPCs were preferentially targeted for infection in the juvenile heart.Overall, these findings suggest that juvenile CVB3 infection may cause long-term consequences for heart development and function through the infection and depletion of cardiac progenitor cells, leading to an increased susceptibility to stress-induced cardiac hypertrophy, left ventricular dilation, and fibrosis, which are early stages of dilated cardiomyopathy.
The bacterial pathogen Burkholderia pseudomallei, which causes melioidosis, regulates IL-1β and IL-18 production through NOD-like receptors NLRP3 and NLRC4, and pyroptosis. A recent study has investigated the downstream signalling pathways of these receptors and the role of B. pseudomallei factors in inflammasome activation. The study found that caspase-1 processing and pyroptosis is dependent on NLRC4, but not on NLRP3 in the early phase of macrophage infection. During the early phase, an activation pathway involving caspases-9, -7 and PARP downstream of NLRC4 and caspase-1 was identified. In contrast, at later time points, caspase-1 activation and cell death was NLRC4-independent. Infection with B. pseudomallei resulted in an early, dose-dependent cell death in wild-type macrophages but a delayed cell death in caspase-1/11 KO macrophages. The B. pseudomallei flagellin FliC, T3SS3 effector protein BopE and the inner rod protein BsaK were found to play a role in caspase-1 activation, pyroptosis induction, and IL-1β secretion, and their function in primary macrophages and murine melioidosis was also characterized. This information is crucial in understanding the pathogenesis of B. pseudomallei and the host immune response towards it.
The KINβγ protein, a subunit of the SNF1-related protein kinase 1 complex, plays crucial roles in the regulation of plant development and is localized in the cytoplasm and nucleus of the vegetative cells of pollen grains in Arabidopsis. In pollen, the kinβγ mutant is unable to germinate on the stigma, but germinates normally in vitro. This is due to the compromised hydration of the mutant pollen on the stigma, which can be promoted by adding water to the stigma, indicating that the compromised hydration of the mutant pollen leads to its defective germination. The mutant pollen exhibits destroyed mitochondria and peroxisome structures, reduced numbers, and decreased levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS). The addition of H2O2 in vitro partially compensates for the reduced water absorption of the mutant pollen, and reducing ROS levels in pollen by overexpressing Arabidopsis CATALASE 3 results in compromised hydration of pollen on the stigma. These results suggest that Arabidopsis KINβγ is critical for the regulation of ROS levels by mediating the biogenesis of mitochondria and peroxisomes in pollen, which is required for pollen-stigma interactions during pollination.
RNase III is an enzyme that plays a crucial role in double-stranded RNA processing in both bacterial and eukaryotic systems. It is involved in various cellular functions such as ribosomal RNA maturation, bacterial gene silencing, and the regulation of small RNAs. However, the function of RNase III in Bacillus subtilis is unique, as it is essential for the survival of the organism, unlike in other bacteria. This essential role of RNase III in B. subtilis is due to the protection it provides against the expression of toxin genes borne by two prophages, Skin and SPβ, through antisense RNA.Specifically, RNase III is responsible for the degradation of two type I toxin-encoding mRNAs, txpA from Skin and yonT from SPβ, and its absence leads to an increase in the steady-state levels of these toxin mRNAs. Inactivation of RNase III results in the overexpression of these toxin mRNAs, leading to cell toxicity. Moreover, the antitoxin for the txpA toxin is the RatA RNA, which has a 3′ end that overlaps with the toxin mRNA, and overexpression of RatA leads to the degradation of the txpA toxin RNA.These findings suggest that RNase III has a specific function in B. subtilis that cannot be removed, unlike in other bacteria where the rnc gene can be deleted. This specific function is related to its role in toxin mRNA turnover, particularly in the degradation of type I toxin-encoding mRNAs. The Skin prophage is more detrimental than the SPβ prophage in strains lacking RNase III, suggesting that the presence of Skin is the most detrimental in an RNase III mutant strain.In summary, RNase III plays a critical role in double-stranded RNA processing and has various cellular functions in both bacterial and eukaryotic systems. However, its function in B. subtilis is unique and essential for the survival of the organism. It plays a specific role in toxin mRNA turnover, specifically in the degradation of type I toxin-encoding mRNAs, and its absence leads to cell toxicity due to the overexpression of these toxin mRNAs.
The filarial nematode Brugia malayi, which causes the disease lymphatic filariasis, can modify the biology of its host, but the mechanisms by which this occurs are unclear. One theory is that parasite-derived extracellular vesicles (EVs) release bioactive proteins and small RNA species, allowing for the secretion of parasite effector molecules and their potential trafficking to host tissues. Research has shown that EVs are released by all life stages of B. malayi, including microfilariae, L3, L4, adult males, and adult females, and these EVs are internalized by murine macrophages with no preference for life stage, indicating a uniform mechanism for effector molecule trafficking. Proteomic profiling of adult male and female EVs has revealed quantitative and qualitative differences in the adult EV proteome, helping to define the biogenesis of Brugia EVs and revealing sexual dimorphic characteristics in immunomodulatory cargo. Ivermectin, a drug used to treat lymphatic filariasis, has been found to rapidly inhibit EV release by all Brugia life stages, highlighting a potential mechanism of action for this drug and suggesting new screening platforms for anti-filarial drug development. This research has important implications for our understanding of the interactions between parasitic nematodes and their hosts and for the development of new treatments for lymphatic filariasis.
In the Solomon Islands, a Pacific island nation, a study was conducted to determine the prevalence of scabies and impetigo in ten rural villages in the Western Province. Of the 1908 participants, 19.2% had scabies and 26.7% had active impetigo, with the highest prevalence in children aged 1-4 years. Scabies infestation was significantly associated with active impetigo, with 41.1% of active impetigo cases also having scabies. Multiple studies have shown increased scabies prevalence associated with poverty and overcrowding. The World Health Organization has recognized scabies as a neglected tropical disease, and controlling scabies could potentially reduce the burden of impetigo and its complications. Mass drug administration of topical scabicides and oral ivermectin has shown promising results in reducing scabies and impetigo prevalence. Further investigation into the effect of single-dose azithromycin against staphylococcal and streptococcal skin disease is warranted.
The study of the relationship between T-cells and hippocampal neurogenesis has been motivated by the observation that rates of adult hippocampal neurogenesis differ between inbred strains of mice, indicating that quantitative trait loci (QTL) contribute to this variation. A genetic approach was adopted to address the question of whether QTLs influencing neurogenesis could be found that influenced other phenotypes, which might cast light on the function of neurogenesis. The study used heterogeneous stock (HS) mice, which are descended from eight inbred progenitor strains and maintained for over 50 generations, and mapped QTLs to an average region of 3 Mb. The HS is unique for its high resolution and the number of QTLs that have been mapped, as well as for the diversity of traits analyzed. The phenotypes include those previously suggested to be related to neurogenesis: novelty suppressed feeding, measures of anxiety taken in an elevated plus maze and open field, and contextual fear conditioning. The study assessed cellular proliferation in the subgranular zone of the dentate gyrus by counting the absolute number of KI67-positive cells in 719 HS animals and found a correlation with four behavioral measures assessed in the same HS animals, as well as a correlation with changes in the relative proportions of CD4+ and CD8+ cells among blood CD3+ lymphocytes. Higher levels of hippoc influencing cellular proliferation in the hippocampus and variation in the distribution of T cell lineages suggests that one phenotype influences the other. Mapping QTLs contributing to variation in cellular proliferation in the hippocampus and comparing their location to QTLs previously mapped for %CD8+ among CD3+ T cells found QTLs with the same location for both phenotypes on five chromosomes. To test whether variation in T cell lineages and cellular proliferation in the hippocampus have a common genetic origin, the study included %CD8+ in CD3+ as a covariate in a linear model for KI67 and mapped the residuals. The results indicate that common genetic loci contribute to variation in the two phenotypes. Comparison between QTLs influencing behavioral measures putatively related to hippocampal neurogenesis and KI67 showed little overlap in location. The genetic data are consistent with a model in which adult neurogenesis influences T cells and also with one in which T cells influence neurogenesis. The study tested the first model by ablating adult neurogenesis and then looking for changes in T cells and found no significant difference in T cell subsets after ablation of neurogenesis. The second hypothesis, an effect of T cell function on neurogenesis, was examined by studying a series of mouse mutants with alterations in T cell differentiation. The results implicate cells expressing the αβT cell receptor and excluding B and γδT lymphocytes, and suggest that the presence of CD4+ cells mediates the effect of lymphocytes on neurogenesis.
Chagas disease, caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, is a major health problem in Latin America and an emerging infectious disease in the US. A previously conducted computational/bioinformatics study identified antigens in the T. cruzi sequence database with vaccine candidate characteristics. A subsequent study investigated the protective efficacy of a multi-component DNA-prime/protein-boost vaccine (TcVac2) consisting of these candidates and cytokine (IL-12 and GM-CSF) expression plasmids in a murine model. The results showed that TcVac2 induced a strong antigen-specific antibody response and a substantial CD8+ T cell response associated with type 1 cytokines, resulting in control of acute parasite burden. During the chronic phase, the antibody response persisted, and tissue parasitism, inflammation, and fibrosis in the heart and skeletal muscle of TcVac2-vaccinated chronic mice were undetectable by histological techniques. In contrast, mice injected with vector or cytokines only responded to T. cruzi by elicitation of a mixed (type 1/type 2) antibody, T cell and cytokine response, and exhibited persistent parasite burden and immunopathology in the myocardium. Therefore, TcVac2-induced activation of type 1 antibody and lymphocyte responses provided resistance to acute T. cruzi infection and prevented the evolution of chronic immunopathology associated with parasite persistence in chagasic hearts.
Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have been successful in identifying disease susceptibility loci for common and complex diseases. However, the ability to quantify individual disease risk based on genotype data for personalized prevention and treatment remains an open question. Previous studies have primarily failed due to the use of only a limited number of confirmed susceptibility loci. A new study suggests that sophisticated machine-learning approaches with a large ensemble of markers may improve disease risk assessment performance. The study used a Support Vector Machine (SVM) algorithm and applied it to a GWAS dataset generated on the Affymetrix genotyping platform for type 1 diabetes (T1D). The SVM model was optimized using hundreds of markers and tested on two independent datasets. The results showed an area under the ROC curve (AUC) of approximately 0.84 in both datasets. The study suggests that improved disease risk assessment can be achieved by using algorithms that take into account interactions between a large ensemble of markers. Genotype-based disease risk assessment may be feasible for diseases where a notable proportion of the risk has already been captured by SNP arrays. Genome-wide association studies have enabled human geneticists to examine a wide range of complex phenotypes and have allowed the confirmation and replication of previously unsuspected susceptibility loci for various diseases such as T2D, T1D, CD, height, and dyslipidemia. However, these variants still explain only a small proportion of individual differences in disease predisposition or phenotypic diversity. The remaining genetic variance still represents a challenge for the foreseeable future. Besides identifying genes influencing disease susceptibility or phenotypic variation, another often suggested utility of GWAS is that these discoveries will facilitate implementation of personalized medicine. However, for common and complex diseases, the application of personalized medicine may not be as straightforward. Previous studies have shown limited predictive value, and the performance of these studies is far below what would be considered clinically feasible or practical. Therefore, the failure of previous studies to predict individual disease risk is not unexpected due to the omission of the vast majority of genuine susceptibility loci that are yet to be validated from GWAS. The study suggests that using an entire list of markers reaching a pre-defined statistical threshold for association with a disease and utilizing machine-learning techniques such as SVM can optimize prediction modeling and take advantage of potential interactions between markers to achieve the optimal binary predictive power.
Memory CD8+ T cells are a crucial component of the immune system, providing protective immunity against re-infection by viruses and other intracellular pathogens. They exhibit a variety of functional characteristics, such as the production of cytokines and cytolytic activity, and are able to infiltrate and/or be retained in non-lymphoid tissues. Memory CD8+ T cells can be classified as circulating or tissue-resident (TRM). TRM CD8+ T cells are often located at environmental barriers and are responsible for immediate protection against re-infections prior to the trafficking of additional circulating memory CD8+ T cells into the site of infection. The tissue microenvironment plays a critical role in regulating the differentiation of TRM CD8+ T cells, with local inflammation promoting the acquisition of the TRM phenotype. CD69 and CD103 are commonly used to identify TRM CD8+ T cells in the skin, and TGF-β signaling may be an important retention signal for TRM differentiation in the skin. The ultimate fate of activated CD8+ T cells is highly dependent on the integration of conflicting signals that either promote or inhibit non-lymphoid tissue recruitment and retention. In a study, it was found that circulating memory CD8+ T cells rapidly traffic into the skin following vaccinia virus (VacV) infection independent of their ability to survey peripheral lymph nodes and provide significant protective immunity. In contrast to naïve CD8+ T cells, most circulating TCM CD8+ T cells do not express CD103 in the skin microenvironment during the resolution of viral infection and only a subset ultimately become functional CD69+/CD103- TRM. Following entry into VacV-infected skin, circulating memory CD8+ T cells expressed granzyme B and required cytolytic function to provide protection against VacV infection. Altogether, this study demonstrates that TCM CD8+ T cells rapidly infiltrate non-lymphoid tissues in response to local inflammatory cues, accelerate viral clearance, and become secondary CD69+ TRM that form following the resolution of viral skin infection, an important consideration for tissue-specific vaccine development.
