Acute systemic infection with LCMV-Armstrong causes antigen-specific TRM CD8+ T cells to be seeded in a variety of non-lymphoid tissues, but it does not generate TRM CD8+ T cells in the skin. However, infection of the skin with VacV generates both circulating memory CD8+ T cells as well as TRM in the previously infected skin. Following TCR engagement, TRM CD8+ T cells rapidly produce IFNγ that initiates a local inflammatory response and also promotes a general “anti-viral” state in the tissue microenvironment. Circulating memory CD8+ T cells rapidly enter non-lymphoid tissues and also provide significant protective immunity against viral skin infection.
Myosin VI, a minus-end-directed motor, plays a vital role in the enrichment of proteins on the surface of axons, while myosin motors contribute to the enrichment of both axonal and dendritic proteins at the plasma membranes of the appropriate polar compartments. After synthesis in the secretory pathway, axonal and dendritic transmembrane proteins follow distinct transport pathways to the plasma membrane. Axonal and dendritic proteins are transported by kinesin motors, but targeting of dendritic proteins cannot be explained by the intrinsic properties of dendritic kinesins. Recent work indicates that vesicles are targeted to dendrites through the actions of plus-end-directed myosin motors, suggesting that a minus-end-directed motor might participate in the localization of axonal proteins. Myosin VI, which moves towards the pointed (or minus) end of actin filament, is a good candidate for this role due to its involvement in endocytosis and association with clathrin-coated vesicles and proteins that mediate endocytosis. A version of Channelrhodopsin 2 that was engineered to bind to Myosin VI is concentrated at the surface of the axon of cortical neurons in mice in vivo, suggesting its potential as a useful tool for probing circuit structure and function.
Daphnia magna, a freshwater crustacean, determines its sex through environmental cues, which triggers alternative genetic signals and regulates male or female sex-determining genes. Two categories of sex-determining systems are genetic and environmental, with the former being more prevalent in animals. Environmental sex determination (ESD) is found in various taxa, including rotifers, nematodes, crustaceans, insects, fishes, and reptiles. ESD has arisen repeatedly during evolution, implying its adaptive significance. Genes involved in ESD share similar genetic components with genetic sex determination (GSD), and both may have the same origin. The water flea Daphnia magna uses ESD, with juvenile hormone being a key molecule for understanding this process. A Doublesex (Dsx) gene, initially identified in D. melanogaster, plays a critical role in sex determination cascades in GSD by targeting genes that confer sexually dimorphic traits. Dsx has two conserved domains: a Dsx/Mab-3 domain at the N-terminus and an oligomerization domain at the C-terminus. Genes encoding DM-domain have been discovered in various species, including vertebrates. However, other genetic sex-determining genes are widely diverse among species. In D. magna, two Dsx genes were found, with DapmaDsx1 playing an essential role in directing the major sexually dimorphic development of D. magna. The function of Dsx is significantly conserved between Daphnia and genetic sex-determining insect species, which are thought to be the sister group of branchiopod crustaceans. However, the factors that regulate Dsx gene expression are independently co-opted in each lineage. This functional demonstration that Dsx controls sexual dimorphism in an environmental sex-determining organism supports the hypothesis that genetic and environmental sex determination are similar at their most fundamental level.
A trivalent vaccine containing HSV-2 glycoproteins C, D, and E (gC2, gD2, gE2) along with CpG and alum has been found to be highly effective in preventing genital herpes in rhesus macaques and guinea pigs. The vaccine works by inducing plasma and mucosa neutralizing antibodies, antibodies that block gC2 and gE2 immune evasion activities, and stimulating CD4 T cell responses. In guinea pigs, the trivalent vaccine was 97% efficacious in preventing genital lesions and significantly reduced HSV-2 DNA shedding and shedding of replication competent virus compared to gD2 alone. The trivalent vaccine has the potential to prevent genital herpes in humans and reduce the incidence of neonatal herpes and the risk of HIV acquisition and transmission. Currently, no vaccine for genital herpes is available and the prevalence of genital herpes is high, particularly in sub-Saharan African countries. A vaccine for genital herpes is urgently needed to prevent the pain and suffering associated with the disease and to reduce the transmission and acquisition of HIV.
The development of next generation sequencing has enabled genome-wide profiling of protein-DNA interactions by ChIP-seq, but interactions in highly repetitive regions of genomes have been difficult to map due to short read lengths mapping to multiple locations. Standard analytical methods discard these multi-mapping reads, leading to a loss of valuable data. Perm-seq, a prior-enhanced read allocation method for ChIP-seq experiments, has been developed to accurately allocate multi-mapping reads in highly repetitive regions of the genome. Perm-seq significantly improves multi-read allocation accuracy over methods that do not utilize additional data types and can be supervised with a variety of data sources, including histone ChIP-seq. The application of Perm-seq to 64 ENCODE ChIP-seq datasets from GM12878 and K562 cells identified many novel protein-DNA interactions in segmental duplication regions. Although these interactions are evolutionarily less conserved, they share the overall sequence characteristics of the protein-DNA interactions in non-repetitive regions. Current state-of-the-art approaches for allocating multi-mapping reads rely on utilizing read counts of the local neighborhoods of the mapping positions, but these approaches have critical limitations when the local neighborhood read counts of the mapping positions are highly similar. Perm-seq utilizes data from DNase I hypersensitive sites sequencing (DNase-seq) experiments to inform read allocation in ChIP-seq and has significant power for discriminating between the mapping locations of multi-reads with similar local ChIP-seq read counts. A probabilistic model utilizing DNase-seq derived priors maps reads originating from highly repetitive regions with high accuracy, and the Perm-seq framework is versatile enough to enable incorporation of multiple sources of data such as histone ChIP-seq for read allocation. The reanalysis of a large collection of ENCODE ChIP-seq datasets with Perm-seq identifies many novel protein-DNA interaction targets in highly repetitive regions of the genome, especially in segmental duplications, and these novel targets share similar chromatin signatures with repetitive and non-repetitive modes of protein-DNA interactions. H2a . z ChIP-seq data performs as well as DNase-seq data for supervising allocation of multi-reads in highly repetitive regions.
Schistosomiasis, a parasitic worm infection affecting over 218 million people worldwide, has been associated with increased risk of HIV-1 acquisition and impaired immune control of HIV-1 in infected individuals. A nested case-control study within a large population-based survey of HIV-1 transmission in Tanzania revealed that women with schistosome infections had a higher odds of HIV-1 acquisition than those without (adjusted OR = 2.8 [1.2--6.6], p = 0.019). Schistosome-infected men did not have increased odds of HIV-1 acquisition. Additionally, HIV-1 seroconverters with schistosome infection had significantly higher median whole blood HIV-1 RNA levels (4.4 [3.9--4.6] log10 copies/mL) compared to those without schistosomiasis (3.7 [3.2--4.3], p = 0.017). This study suggests that pre-existing schistosome infection increases odds of HIV-1 acquisition in women and raises HIV-1 viral load at the time of HIV-1 seroconversion. Further validation studies are needed to confirm these findings.
Ribosomal DNA (rDNA) is a highly variable region in the human genome with respect to copy number and is vital for cellular function. However, the factors governing its copy number, stability, and sequence in the mammalian genome are largely unknown due to challenges in mapping and analysis. A study using computational and droplet digital PCR approaches measured rDNA copy number in normal and cancer states in human and mouse genomes and found that copy number and sequence can change in cancer genomes. Human cancer genomes show a loss of copies, accompanied by global copy number co-variation, and cancer genomes with lower copies have mutational evidence of mTOR hyperactivity. This loss of copies is a recurrent feature in cancers associated with mTOR activation and rDNA copy number may be a simple and useful indicator of whether a cancer will be sensitive to DNA damaging treatments. Furthermore, recent technological developments enable accurate and high throughput measurements of the copy number of the rDNA, which can be estimated from whole-genome sequence and droplet digital PCR. The plethora of cancer genome sequencing projects allows comparison between the copy number in the tumor genome versus the normal genome from a single individual and has shown that rDNA copy number is reduced in cancer genomes with mTOR activation.
A study was conducted to understand the bacterial population dynamics in a whole-animal infection model, specifically focusing on Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium infections in mice. The researchers used an integrated approach that relied on tracing tagged subpopulations of otherwise identical bacteria through infected animals and their organs. Eight wild-type isogenic tagged strains (WITS) were generated, each carrying a different 40-bp DNA signature tag in the same noncoding region of the chromosome. Using inoculations consisting of mixtures of low numbers of each tagged strain, the dynamics of each subpopulation were monitored at different body sites throughout the course of a systemic infection. The researchers addressed three specific questions about the dynamics of infection: how an acute bacterial infection replicates and grows in infected organs, whether the spread of infection within and between organs results from homogeneous bacterial growth or from expansion of subpopulations, and how components of the immune response affect spatiotemporal bacterial population dynamics. By using depletion of tagged diversity as a proxy for bacterial death and spatiotemporal heterogeneity as a proxy for bacterial transfer between organs as a function of time postinoculation, the researchers were able to develop mathematical models to dissect the determinants of net growth at different infection stages and map local (intraorgan) versus systemic spread of each bacterial subpopulation. The findings of this study illustrate that to understand the basic idiosyncrasies of infection requires a disaggregation of the global disease dynamics and awareness of the separate infection dynamics of subpopulations within the same host.
The inverse optics problem of local binocular 3D motion perception has yet to be fully solved by existing processing schemes such as interocular velocity difference, changing disparity over time, and joint encoding of motion and disparity. A more flexible framework for solving this problem is proposed, using local velocity constraints in combination with binocular disparity and other depth cues. This approach suggests that motion and disparity input is processed in parallel and integrated late in the visual processing hierarchy. Three main processing models have emerged in the literature for 3D motion perception: Interocular velocity difference (IOVD), changing disparity over time (CDOT), and joint encoding of motion and disparity (JEMD). However, psychophysical results have been inconclusive and the nature of 3D motion processing remains an unresolved issue. The aperture problem, which features prominently in 2D motion perception, has been neglected in the study of 3D motion perception. Large and persistent perceptual bias has been found for dot stimuli with unambiguous motion direction, suggesting processing strategies that are different from the three main processing models. It seems promising to investigate local motion stimuli with ambiguous motion direction such as a line or contour moving inside a circular aperture, because they relate to local encoding and may reveal principles of 3D motion processing. The aim of this paper is to evaluate existing models of 3D motion perception and to gain a better understanding of binocular 3D motion perception.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a Gram-negative pathogen, causes acute and chronic infections, and is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality among cystic fibrosis (CF) patients. It forms biofilms, composed primarily of secreted extracellular polysaccharides, making it more resistant to antibiotics and host defense mechanisms. Alginate is an exopolysaccharide synthesized in the cytoplasm and modified in the periplasm through O-acetylation and epimerization during chronic lung infections in CF patients. Modification of polysaccharides through the addition or removal of acetate is an essential biological process for survival and virulence in many bacterial species. The O-acetylation of alginate in P. aeruginosa is an important modification as acetylated alginate is less susceptible to recognition and clearance by the host immune system than its non-O-acetylated counterpart. AlgJ and AlgX are required for alginate acetylation, both annotated as O-acetyltransferases. However, recent studies suggest that they have separate and distinct roles in O-acetylation, with AlgX as the terminal acetyltransferase. The anionic, O-acetylated exopolysaccharide alginate, secreted by P. aeruginosa, is a major constituent of a protective biofilm matrix during chronic lung infections in CF patients. Four proteins, AlgIJF and AlgX, have been implicated in alginate O-acetylation. AlgJ, a SGNH hydrolase-like protein, exhibits a distinct electrostatic surface potential and acetylesterase activity in vitro. However, it exhibits weak or no detectable polymer binding in vitro, in contrast to AlgX, which binds polymannuronic acid specifically in a length-dependent manner. AlgX can utilize a surrogate acetyl-donor to catalyze the O-acetylation of polymannuronic acid. These results suggest that AlgX is the terminal acetyltransferase in alginate acetylation, while AlgJ has a different role. This refined model provides a rationale for the variability in the number of proteins required for polysaccharide O-acetylation in different bacterial species and their distinct roles in the process.
Candida albicans, a commensal human fungal pathogen, causes a range of infections from superficial mucosal surfaces to severe systemic bloodstream infections, with a mortality rate of approximately 30%. Current antifungal agents have limitations due to drug resistance or toxicity. The fungal cell wall is a potential drug target due to its role in pathogenicity, presenting virulence factors, antigenic cell wall proteins and polysaccharides, and serving as the intermediate for fungal-host interactions. One approach to improve anti-fungal strategies is to enhance the detection of fungal cell wall antigens by host immune cells. Dectin-1, a C-type signaling lectin receptor in innate immune cells, recognizes β (1, 3) -glucan, an essential component of fungal cell walls. C. albicans masks β (1, 3) -glucan from Dectin-1 detection via the outer layer of mannosylated proteins. However, unmasking of β (1, 3) -glucan can be induced through treatments with drugs such as echinocandins or by certain genetic mutations that disrupt cell wall integrity. The PS synthase enzyme (Cho1) controls cell wall β (1, 3) -glucan exposure. The homozygous CHO1 mutant, cho1Δ/Δ, exhibits greater β (1, 3) -glucan exposure compared to wild-type. The Cek1 MAPK cascade, composed of a conserved module of three kinases, controls β (1, 3) -glucan masking in C. albicans. CEK1 null mutants display unmasking of β (1, 3) -glucan and hyper-sensitivity to agents that disturb the cell wall such as Congo red. Activation of the Cek1 MAPK pathway causes unmasking of β (1, 3) -glucan and increases pro-inflammatory responses from macrophages, which is distinct from that seen at bud scars. In the cho1Δ/Δ mutant, there is upregulation of the activity of both Cek1 and Mkc1 MAPKs, and a higher concentration of active Cdc42 than wild-type. Cells overexpressing CDC42G12V, a hyperactive allele of CDC42, exhibited decreased proliferation and increased β (1, 3) -glucan exposure. The Cek1 pathway can cause β (1, 3) -glucan exposure when hyper-activated, and this may help explain the increased β (1, 3) -glucan exposure seen in the cho1Δ/Δ mutant. However, the Mkc1 pathway is also upregulated in cho1Δ/Δ, and both pathways play a role in β (1, 3) -glucan exposure.
A genome-wide association study and analysis of known genetic risk loci for Alzheimer's disease (AD) dementia were performed using neuropathologic data from 4,914 brain autopsies. The neuropathologic data were used to define clinico-pathologic AD dementia or controls, assess core neuropathologic features of AD, and evaluate commonly co-morbid neuropathologic changes. Genome-wide significance was observed for clinico-pathologic AD dementia, neuritic plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, and Lewy body disease with a number of variants in and around the apolipoprotein E gene. GalNAc transferase 7, ATP-Binding Cassette, Sub-Family G, Member 1, and an intergenic region on chromosome 9 were associated with neuritic plaque score, and Potassium Large Conductance Calcium-Activated Channel, Subfamily M, Beta Member 2 was strongly associated with hippocampal sclerosis of the elderly. Twelve of the 21 non-APOE genetic risk loci for clinically-defined AD dementia were confirmed in the clinico-pathologic sample. Correlation of effect sizes for risk of AD dementia with effect size for neurofibrillary tangles or neuritic plaques showed positive correlation, while those for risk of vascular brain injury showed a moderate negative correlation. The other co-morbid neuropathologic features showed only nominal association with the known AD loci. This study discovered new genetic associations with specific neuropathologic features and aligned known genetic risk for AD dementia with specific neuropathologic changes in the largest brain autopsy study of AD and related dementias.
"Urea is a denaturant commonly used in studying protein folding/unfolding, but its ultimate reasons for its denaturing properties remain elusive. The dominant paradigm suggests that urea interacts with exposed protein residues more strongly than water, but the nature of this preferential interaction is unclear. Some claim it is electrostatic and related to direct hydrogen bonds, while others suggest it is due to preferential dispersion. There is also discussion regarding whether the major destabilizing effect of urea is related to interaction with the backbone or side chains, and if so, which side chains: polar and charged or apolar. A recent study combined multi-replica molecular dynamics simulations and direct NMR measures of ubiquitin to characterize the ""urea unfolded ensemble"" of this model protein. The results suggest that urea stabilizes flexible over-extended conformations of the protein, which are unlikely to be sampled in the ""unfolded"" state of aqueous proteins. However, this study did not provide information on the kinetic role of urea in the unfolding process. To analyze this point, a study of the effect of urea in the first stages of thermochemical unfolding is needed. This study performed microsecond-long atomistic simulations using 30 proteins covering all major protein folds and several of the most popular force-fields to investigate the first stages of urea-driven protein unfolding. The results revealed robust trends that illustrate the effect of urea during the early stages of protein unfolding, providing a complete picture of the role of urea in destabilizing folded states of proteins and on the molecular mechanisms by means of which urea contributes to accelerating protein unfolding."
A systematic literature review was conducted to study the epidemiology of dengue disease in Colombia between 2000 and 2012. The review identified 30 relevant studies out of 225 citations, which showed a stable number of dengue fever cases and major outbreaks in 2001-2003 and 2
Tegumentary leishmaniasis (TL) is a skin and mucosal tissue disease caused by Leishmania parasites, which can co-exist with other pathogens in human populations, impacting TL's clinical outcome. This review focused on the frequency of TL coinfections in human populations, interactions between Leishmania and other pathogens in animal models and human subjects, and implications for clinical practice. The search resulted in 73 records, including 21 experimental studies and 52 human studies. Co-infection frequencies vary, with approximately 41% of TL patients in Argentina carrying Trypanosoma cruzi and 15%-88% of TL patients in Brazil carrying helminths. Interactions between pathogens may involve innate immunity and regulatory networks affecting acquired immune responses. Diagnostic problems, reduced effectiveness of antileishmanial treatment, and cumulative adverse effects of drug combinations can occur in TL coinfections. More research is needed to understand how coinfections interfere with TL pathogenesis and clinical management.
The Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) is a gene-dense region affecting MHC expression and T cell selection, but the specific genes responsible have not been identified. This study aimed to assess the impact of natural genetic variation on MHC expression and CD4:CD8 lineage commitment using two genetic models in rats. The first model, Heterogeneous Stock rats, identified 10 Quantitative Trait Loci (QTLs) across the genome, with QTLs for individual traits colocalizing in the MHC region. A large panel of MHC-recombinant congenic strains refined the QTLs to two 0.25 Mb intervals in the MHC-I and II regions, with an interaction between these intervals affecting MHC class I expression and negative selection/lineage commitment of CD8 single-positive thymocytes. The interaction was mapped to the transporter associated with antigen processing 2 (Tap2) in the MHC-II region and the classical MHC class I gene (s) in the MHC-I region. Variants of Tap2 have been previously shown to influence the antigenicity of MHC class I molecules by altering the MHC class I ligandome, and this study shows a restricted peptide repertoire on MHC class I molecules leads to reduced negative selection of CD8SP cells. Overall, this study shows how a recombination between natural alleles of genes in the MHC influences lineage commitment of T cells, providing new insights into the relationship between MHC genes and T cell selection and maintenance.
Chagas disease, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, is a potentially life-threatening illness that can lead to cardiac disorders, digestive issues, and death if left untreated. While it is mostly endemic in 21 Latin American countries, it has been spreading to non-endemic countries, including Europe, due to population mobility and migration from endemic countries. Spain, in particular, has seen a significant increase in Chagas cases due to its high immigration rates from Latin America. From 1997 to 2011, Spain recorded 1729 hospitalizations related to Chagas disease, with a hospitalization rate of 242.8 per 100,000 population in 2011. Being male, aged 45 and 64 years, and having a median hospitalization cost above 3,065 euros were associated with hospitalizations with organ complications. However, Spain currently lacks a nationwide systematic approach towards early detection of T. cruzi, particularly among fertile aged women and relatives from endemic Latin American countries. This increases the risk of underdiagnosing asymptomatic infections and exacerbating health inequalities among immigrants. Therefore, a nationwide systematic approach, including a national surveillance system and screening programs, is necessary to gain extended disease knowledge and evaluate control actions in Spain.
"BlocBuster is a systems-level approach that efficiently constructs genome-wide, allele-specific networks to accurately segregate homogenous combinations of genetic factors and test their associations with given phenotypes. It employs a custom correlation measure for single nucleotide polymorphisms that returns a multi-faceted collection of values that captures genetic heterogeneity. The method was applied to analyze psoriasis and discovered a combinatorial pattern with an odds ratio of 3.64 and a Bonferroni-corrected p-value of 5.01x10−16. This pattern was replicated in independent data, demonstrating its robustness. Psoriasis is a complex disease characterized by hyperproliferation and aberrant differentiation of the epidermis, coupled with marked cutaneous inflammation. Its heritability is estimated at 80%, and it has been linked to the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) region on chromosome 6. However, less than 20% of genetic heritability can be accounted for by previous discoveries, and many of these loci have not been replicated using independent data, suggesting the existence of genetic heterogeneity in the pathogenesis of this disease. BlocBuster has the potential to discover combinatorial genetic associations within heterogeneous genome-wide data, thereby transcending the limiting ""small effects"" produced by individual markers examined in isolation."
A large-scale study was conducted to analyze chromosomal copy number variations (CNVs) in patients with congenital brain malformations, including agenesis of the corpus callosum (ACC), cerebellar hypoplasia (CBLH), and polymicrogyria (PMG), and compare them to controls. The results showed that ACC patients had a higher prevalence of large gene-rich CNVs than CBLH and PMG. Specifically, ACC patients had significantly more rare CNVs over 1 Mb and over 20 genes compared to controls. In contrast, CBLH and PMG patients did not show a significant enrichment of rare CNVs. Exome sequencing revealed a recessive maternally inherited nonsense mutation in the non-deleted allele of NDE1 in an ACC patient with microcephaly and a paternally inherited deletion of 16p13.11 that included NDE1. Six novel CNVs were identified, each in a single patient, that are likely deleterious. This study provides a systematic assessment of CNVs in congenital brain malformations and reveals a much higher prevalence of large gene-rich CNVs in ACC than in CBLH and PMG.
The freshwater planarian, Schmidtea mediterranea, has a high capacity for regeneration, making it an ideal model to study stereotyped proliferative and transcriptional responses to injury. The Hippo signaling cascade effector, yorkie (yki), plays a key role in restricting early injury responses during planarian regeneration. In yki (RNAi) regenerating animals, wound responses are hyper-activated, leading to increased stem cell proliferation and a prolonged transcriptional wound response program. This results in the de-repression of novel wound-induced genes and an expansion of epidermal and muscle cell populations. Additionally, yki (RNAi) animals have alterations in the sensing of injury size, leading to failures in brain, gut, and midline remodeling and scaling during morphallaxis. These findings suggest that yki functions as a critical regulator of multiple aspects of the injury response, including proliferation, apoptosis, injury-induced transcription, and patterning during planarian regeneration.
Exosomes, membrane-encapsulated vesicles that transfer genetic materials between cells, play significant roles in viral infections. In EV71-infected cells, exosomes containing replication-competent EV71 RNA and miR-146a facilitate viral transmission independent of virus-specific receptors. Exosomal viral RNA can be transferred to and replicate in new target cells, while exosomal miR-146a suppresses type I interferon response in the target cell, facilitating viral replication. EV71 infection upregulates exosome secretion, with a 2.4-fold increase in THP-1 and 2.2-fold increase in HT-29 cells. IFN-stimulated gene factors, such as BST-2/tetherin, regulate EV71-induced upregulation of exosome secretion. In vivo studies show that exosomal viral RNA exhibits differential tissue accumulation compared to free virus particles. Exosomes can protect their contents from immune recognition, playing crucial roles in the viral life cycle. Exosomal RNAs, including miRNAs, are implicated in many exosome-mediated biological functions, with a diverse collection of exosomal RNA species, among which miRNAs are the most abundant. Exosomal miRNAs can be taken up by distal tissues or cells, allowing viruses to modulate immune defense of the neighboring cells and facilitate the spread of the virus.
PINK1, a serine/threonine kinase required for mitochondrial homeostasis, is a gene product associated with early-onset Parkinson's disease (PD). Parkin, another early-onset PD gene product, is thought to function downstream of the PINK1 signaling pathway. A mitochondrial protein, PGAM5, has been identified as a PINK1-binding protein that modulates the PINK1 pathway. Loss of PGAM5 suppresses muscle degeneration, motor defects, and shorter lifespan caused by PINK1 inactivation in Drosophila, but does not affect phenotypes in parkin mutant flies. Ectopic expression of PGAM5 exacerbates PINK1 and parkin phenotypes, suggesting that PGAM5 negatively regulates the PINK1 pathway and acts between PINK1 and Parkin or independently of Parkin downstream of PINK1. PGAM5 is a mitochondrial protein localized at the outer mitochondrial membrane and lacks phosphoglycerate mutase activity. In Drosophila, the PGAM5 gene has two orthologs, dPGAM5 and dPGAM5-2, with dPGAM5 being more similar to hPGAM5. A dPGAM5 null allele, PGAM51, results in longer lifespan, while transgenic expression of dPGAM5 or dPGAM5-2 leads to shorter longevity. Inactivation of the dPGAM5 gene does not cause mitochondrial degeneration but alters mitochondrial morphology, leading to fragmented mitochondria with cristae well-preserved. DPGAM5 is likely to promote the mitochondrial fission process in Drosophila.
Buruli ulcer (BU) is a chronic skin disease caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans, which produces the cytotoxic macrolide exotoxin mycolactone. The immune response to M. ulcerans infection is not yet fully understood, but it is believed that interferon-γ (IFNγ) plays a crucial role in host defense during the early stages of infection. In an experimental BU mouse model, IFNγ knockout mice displayed faster progression of the infection compared to wild-type mice, including faster tissue necrosis and oedema formation, and a significantly higher bacterial burden after five weeks of infection. This indicates that mice lacking IFNγ have a reduced capacity to kill intracellular bacilli during the early intra-macrophage growth phase of M. ulcerans. These findings suggest that concepts for vaccine development against tuberculosis may also be valid for BU, and that IFNγ-dependent activation of the bactericidal activity of macrophages helps to contain the infection during its intracellular early stages. Overall, the outcome of an infection with M. ulcerans may depend strongly on cellular immune defense mechanisms, and IFNγ is likely to play an important role both as an element of innate immunity in the early phase of host-pathogen interaction and in the development of protective adaptive cellular immune responses.
A recent study investigates the increase in reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in mitochondria, particularly during hypoxia and reoxygenation, which is associated with major diseases such as heart disease, age-related degenerative conditions, and ischemic syndrome in reperfusion. The study aims to understand the causes of elevated ROS production during anoxia/reoxygenation and develop novel strategies addressing primary events of this clinical phenomenon. The authors propose a new methodology for modeling the mechanism of ROS generation, taking into account all possible redox states formed in the process of electron transport, even for respiratory complex III, by constructing a system of hundreds of differential equations.The study finds that respiratory complex III can persist in two different steady states at the same microenvironmental conditions, characterized by low and high ROS producing modes. Various perturbations, such as temporal anoxia, can induce the transition of the respiratory chain from one steady state to another. Specifically, during temporal anoxia, the respiratory chain switches to a high ROS producing state, which persists after the return to normal oxygen supply, resulting in oxidative stress and cell damage.The researchers validate this prediction experimentally, demonstrating that the methodology could be widely used in systems biology studies. These findings suggest that the recognition of the bistability of complex III operation may enable novel therapeutic strategies for oxidative stress. More importantly, understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying elevated ROS production during anoxia/reoxygenation could help develop targeted therapies for various diseases associated with ROS production.
The early embryo of Drosophila melanogaster has been established as a powerful model system for studying the role of genes in pattern formation, with the gap gene network being the first zygotic regulatory tier involved in specifying the position of body segments. This study uses a systems-level approach to investigate the regulatory effect of the terminal gap gene huckebein (hkb) on gap gene expression. Quantitative expression data for the Hkb protein is presented and used to include hkb in gap gene circuit models, which are mathematical models of gene networks used to extract regulatory information from spatial expression data. These models are shown to be consistent with earlier results, and are able to reproduce mutants of terminal gap genes, capturing the expression dynamics of all posterior gap genes and some variational properties of the system. This is a significant step towards a better, quantitative understanding of the developmental and evolutionary dynamics of the gap gene network. Traditional genetic and molecular approaches have limitations, such as difficulty in studying expression features not specifically affected by a particular mutation, ambiguity in determining whether an interaction is direct or not, and uncertainty in establishing whether known regulatory interactions are sufficient to account for patterning in the wild-type system. This study demonstrates a complementary approach for investigating the patterning function of a particular gene in its wild-type context in a rigorous and quantitative manner. Gap genes, such as hunchback (hb), Krüppel (Kr), giant (gt), and knirps (kni), are involved in the regulation of pair-rule and segment-polarity genes, establishing a segmental pre-pattern of gene expression by gastrulation time. Gap gene expression is regulated by spatial gradients of maternal co-ordinate proteins Bicoid (Bcd), Hb, and Caudal (Cad), and maintained and refined through gap-gap cross-regulation and regulation by the terminal maternal system acting through the terminal gap genes tailless (tll) and huckebein (hkb). This study focuses on hkb and its role in gap gene regulation.
Brucellosis is a significant zoonotic disease that affects animals and humans worldwide, causing major economic losses and health issues. Current therapies for brucellosis are ineffective, and no immunotherapy or biomarker to monitor therapy efficacy is available. The disease is caused by Brucella abortus, which can be transmitted to humans through direct contact with infected animals or consumption of contaminated dairy products. Vaccines such as S19 and RB51 have been used to control bovine brucellosis; however, they have limitations, such as antibody interference in serological diagnosis and Rifampicin resistance in RB51.Phage lysates, which are bacteriophages that specifically infect and lyse bacteria, have been explored as an alternative immunotherapeutic agent for brucellosis. Phage lysates have been shown to induce effective immunization and exhibit a protective effect stronger than vaccines produced by heat or chemical inactivation of bacteria. In this study, phage lysates of S19 and RB51 were used to immunize adult cattle affected by brucellosis. The results showed that a single subcutaneous dose of a cocktail lysate (both RL and SL) eliminated live virulent Brucella from brucellosis-affected cattle with plasma level of Brucella-specific 223 bp amplicon undetectable by RT-PCR and blood negative for live Brucella by culture in 3 months post-immunization. This is the first report on minimally invasive monitoring of the efficacy of antibacterial therapy employing plasma RNA specific for live bacteria as a biomarker.In conclusion, phage lysates have shown promising results as an alternative immunotherapeutic agent for brucellosis in cattle. The use of phage lysates as a cocktail of S19 and RB51 has shown to be effective in eliminating live virulent Brucella in brucellosis-affected cattle. Additionally, the use of plasma RNA specific for live bacteria as a biomarker has shown to be a useful tool in monitoring the efficacy of antibacterial therapy in a non-destructive and minimally invasive manner. Further studies are needed to confirm these findings and evaluate the safety and efficacy of phage lysates in larger populations.
In this passage, the authors discuss the role of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) in the DNA damage response and cell cycle progression in eukaryotic cells. CDKs are important for regulating the cell cycle, but their specific functions in the DNA damage response are not well understood. In mammals, Cdk2 is active throughout S and G2 phases, but is dispensable for survival due to compensation by other CDKs. However, the authors found that replacing wild-type Cdk2 with a mutant version sensitized to inhibition by bulky adenine analogs revealed a non-redundant requirement for Cdk2 activity in the DNA damage response. Specifically, transient, selective inhibition of analog-sensitive (AS) Cdk2 after exposure to ionizing radiation (IR) enhances cell-killing. In vitro experiments using an ATP analog preferentially used by AS kinases showed that Cdk2as phosphorylated the Nijmegen Breakage Syndrome gene product Nbs1, a component of the Mre11-Rad50-Nbs1 complex required for normal DNA damage repair and checkpoint signaling. In vivo, selective inhibition of Cdk2 delayed and diminished Nbs1-Ser432 phosphorylation during S phase, and mutation of Ser432 to Ala or Asp increased IR-sensitivity. Therefore, the authors identified a specific target of Cdk2 within the DNA repair machinery and uncovered a non-redundant requirement for Cdk2 activity in response to DNA damage. These findings highlight the importance of CDKs in the DNA damage response and provide a potential target for therapeutic intervention in diseases characterized by genomic instability.
Genome-wide association (GWA) studies have identified many genetic loci associated with various traits and diseases, but determining the functional variants and their mechanisms is a challenge. Many GWA signals are located outside exons, suggesting they may lie within regulatory regions. This summary discusses a study that applied the FAIRE method in megakaryocytic and erythroblastoid cell lines to map active regulatory elements at known loci associated with hematological quantitative traits, coronary artery disease, and myocardial infarction. The study found distinct patterns of open chromatin between the two cell types and identified an open chromatin region at chromosome 7q22.3 in megakaryocytes but not erythroblasts, which harbors the common non-coding sequence variant rs342293 associated with platelet volume and function. Resequencing provided evidence that rs342293 is the only putative causative variant in this region. The C- and G-alleles differentially bind the transcription factor EVI1, affecting PIK3CG gene expression in platelets and macrophages. A protein-protein interaction network indicated that PIK3CG is associated with pathways with an established role in platelet membrane biogenesis and thrombus formation. Therefore, rs342293 is the functional common variant at this locus, providing a molecular mechanism by which a non-coding GWA index SNP modulates platelet phenotype.
The mechanisms of action of most pharmacological blockers of voltage-gated ion channels are well understood, but this knowledge is rarely considered when interpreting experimental data. It is often assumed that the effects of blockade are equivalent, regardless of the mechanism of the blocker involved. However, using computer simulations, it has been demonstrated that this assumption may not always be correct. In this study, the blockade of a persistent sodium current (INaP) in respiratory neurons was simulated via two distinct pharmacological mechanisms: pore obstruction mediated by tetrodotoxin and altered inactivation dynamics mediated by riluzole. The reported effects of experimental application of tetrodotoxin and riluzole in respiratory circuits are diverse and seemingly contradictory, leading to considerable debate within the field. The results of the simulations match a wide array of experimental data spanning from the level of isolated pre-BötC neurons to the level of the intact respiratory network and also generate a series of experimentally testable predictions. The study provides a mechanistic explanation for seemingly contradictory experimental results from in vitro studies of INaP block, shows that the effects of INaP block in in vitro preparations are not necessarily equivalent to those in more intact preparations, demonstrates and explains why riluzole application may fail to effectively block INaP in the intact respiratory network, and derives the prediction that effective block of INaP by low concentration tetrodotoxin will stop respiratory rhythm generation in the intact respiratory network. These simulations support a critical role for INaP in respiratory rhythmogenesis in vivo and illustrate the importance of considering mechanism when interpreting and simulating data relating to pharmacological blockade.
MicroRNAs (miRNAs) play crucial roles in tumor metastasis, including in gastric cancer (GC). This piece of writing discusses the regulation and function of miR-218 in GC metastasis. The expression of miR-218 is reduced in metastatic GC, along with the expression of one of its host genes, Slit3. Robo1, one of the Slit receptors, is negatively regulated by miR-218, creating a negative feedback loop. Decreased miR-218 levels eliminate Robo1 repression, activating the Slit-Robo1 pathway and promoting tumor metastasis. The restoration of miR-218 suppresses Robo1 expression and inhibits tumor cell invasion and metastasis in vitro and in vivo. Overall, these findings suggest that targeting miR-218 may provide a strategy for blocking tumor metastasis. Despite advances in diagnostic and therapeutic approaches for GC, the prognosis for advanced GC with extensive invasion and metastasis remains poor. The metastatic cascade includes various steps such as detachment, migration, local invasion, angiogenesis, intravasation, survival in the circulatory system, extravasation, and regrowth in different organs. In the metastatic cascade, invasion of GC into the surrounding tissue is a crucial early step. However, the mechanisms of invasion have not been fully elucidated. A large number of miRNAs have been implicated in cancer metastasis, including miR-218 in GC. Emerging evidence has revealed that miRNAs play key roles in various biological processes, including cell differentiation, proliferation, apoptosis, stress resistance, fat metabolism, tumorigenesis, and metastasis. A better understanding of the changes in miRNA expression during GC invasion may lead to a better understanding of GC development, as well as possible improvements in the diagnosis and treatment of advanced GC.
A study on atherosclerosis-prone mice with human-like hypercholesterolemia found that lowering plasma lipoproteins slowed the initial progression of atherosclerotic lesions, then rapidly expanded, and eventually plateaued after advanced lesions formed. Genetic lowering of plasma cholesterol at a critical point in lesion progression prevented the formation of advanced plaques and activated a network of 37 cholesterol-responsive genes mediating this effect. These genes regulate cholesterol-ester accumulation, and a subset of eight genes, including CD36 and PPARA, were found to belong to a regulatory gene network influencing foam-cell formation. Inhibiting PVRL2 and HSDL2 showed promising results in preventing foam-cell formation, suggesting their potential for therapies to prevent advanced plaque formation. The findings emphasize the need for further research into cholesterol-responsive atherosclerosis genes and regulators of foam-cell formation as potential targets for atherosclerosis therapy.
A new high-throughput assay was developed to identify genes affecting the biogenesis of the Gram-negative bacterial envelope, using Escherichia coli as a model. The screen, based on β-galactosidase (LacZ) activity, allowed for the identification of 102 genes of unknown function likely impacting envelope biogenesis. One of these, ElyC (YcbC), was found to play a critical role in the metabolism of the essential lipid carrier used for the biogenesis of cell wall and other bacterial surface polysaccharides. The screening assay should be adaptable to other organisms to study the biogenesis of different envelope architectures. This research highlights the importance of understanding envelope assembly in developing new therapies against Gram-negative bacteria, whose envelope's complexity and multilayered structure presents challenges for antimicrobial drug penetration and resistance. The rise of new resistance mechanisms among these organisms further necessitates the discovery of new vulnerabilities in the Gram-negative envelope for antibacterial drug targeting.
A new approach to studying dynamical processes in biology using an integrated view of multivariable dynamics has been developed. The approach uses a semi-supervised learning framework to fuse heterogeneous datasets, as demonstrated using a dataset from studies of pattern formation in Drosophila. The result is a continuous trajectory that reveals the joint dynamics of gene expression, subcellular protein localization, protein phosphorylation, and tissue morphogenesis. This method can be used with other imaging modalities and is a starting point for further data analytics and modeling of biological dynamics. This is important because the need to synthesize data from different observations into coherent multivariable trajectories is a challenge in various fields, and systematic approaches for accomplishing this task have yet to be established. The fusion of heterogeneous datasets from imaging of live and fixed tissues is a non-trivial task, and the problem can be addressed by casting the task of data fusion as a matrix completion problem. This allows for the completion of an image of a fixed embryo or a frame from a live imaging movie by filling in the missing components by estimates informed by the rest of the data. This approach assumes that the multivariable dynamics of the patterning process are both low-dimensional and smooth with respect to the underlying parameters, an assumption that is supported by studies with mathematical models of specific biological systems and by computational analysis of datasets from imaging studies of development. The accuracy of the estimated multivariable dynamics can be assessed using a K-fold validation strategy on the labeled samples. The proposed approach successfully recovers multivariable dynamics from heterogeneous datasets that combine continuous views for part of the state variables and snapshots that report several states without direct temporal information.
Snake venom metalloproteinases (SVMPs) are important components of snake venoms, particularly in the Viperidae family. They have undergone complex molecular evolution, resulting in a diverse range of SVMPs with various biological activities. These enzymes are classified into three main classes (PI, PII, and PIII) based on their domain constitution. PI SVMPs contain only the metalloproteinase domain, PII SVMPs have an additional disintegrin domain, and PIII SVMPs have a disintegrin-like and a cysteine-rich domain. The non-metalloproteinase domains in PII and PIII SVMPs contain exosites that determine binding to specific targets in the extracellular matrix or plasma membrane of cells. Immunohistochemical observations revealed distinct patterns of distribution of PI and PIII SVMPs in the tissue. PII and PIII SVMPs show a close association with the microvasculature, while PI SVMP has a more widespread distribution in the tissue. In terms of function, SVMPs can induce damage to the microvasculature and generate hemorrhage. A study compared PI, PII, and PIII SVMPs in terms of tissue localization, their ability to hydrolyze basement membrane components in vivo, and by proteomics analysis of exudates collected in tissue injected with these enzymes. The results showed that PII and PIII enzymes co-localized with type IV collagen in capillaries, arterioles, and post-capillary venules to a higher extent than PI SVMP. The three SVMPs showed a similar pattern of degradation of type IV collagen, supporting the concept that hydrolysis of this component is critical for the destabilization of microvessel structure leading to hemorrhage. Proteomic analysis of wound exudate revealed similarities and differences between the action of the three SVMPs. Higher extent of proteolysis was observed for the PI enzyme regarding several extracellular matrix components and fibrinogen, whereas exudates from mice injected with PII and PIII SVMPs had higher amounts of some intracellular proteins. In conclusion, SVMPs have a complex evolutionary history, leading to a diverse range of enzymes with various biological activities. They are classified into three main classes based on their domain constitution, and the non-metalloproteinase domains in PII and PIII SVMPs contain exosites that determine binding to specific targets in the extracellular matrix or plasma membrane of cells. Immunohistochemical observations revealed distinct patterns of distribution of PI and PIII SVMPs in the tissue, and PII and PIII SVMPs show a close association with the microvasculature, while PI SVMP has a more widespread distribution in the tissue. The three SVMPs showed a similar pattern of degradation of type IV collagen, supporting the concept that hydrolysis of this component is critical for the destabilization of microvessel structure leading to hemorrhage. The proteomic analysis revealed similarities and differences between the action of the three SVMPs, providing novel clues for understanding the mechanisms by which SVMPs induce damage to the microvasculature and generate hemorrhage.
The homeotic genes in Drosophila melanogaster are aligned on the chromosome in the order of the body segments they affect, with posterior genes repressing anterior ones. This is particularly evident in the case of the abdominal-A (abd-A) and Abdominal-B (Abd-B) genes. Animals lacking Abd-B show ectopic expression of abd-A in the epidermis of the eighth abdominal segment, but not in the central nervous system (CNS), due to repression by a 92 kb noncoding RNA (iab-8 RNA). This RNA produces a microRNA to repress abd-A, but also has a second, redundant repression mechanism acting in cis, likely through transcriptional interference with the abd-A promoter. This iab-8 ncRNA is part of a 90 kb long transcription unit with a likely start site within the iab-8 regulatory region. In the CNS, the iab-8 RNA represses abd-A expression through both the miR-iab-8 microRNA and transcriptional interference. Any genotype lacking both the iab-8 RNA and miR-iab-8 miRNA shows strong ABD-A misexpression in the CNS of PS13. The iab-8 RNA can only repress the copy of abd-A on the chromosome from which it is transcribed, and this repression is termed transcriptional interference.
"Focal seizures, which are instances of disruptive brain activity arising from localized abnormalities, are a major focus in epilepsy management. The identification of the precise origin of a given patient's focal seizures is crucial for effective clinical management. While various clinical evidence can point to the nature and site of the origin, data recorded by electroencephalography (EEG) or the invasive alternative of electrocorticography (ECoG) are particularly critical. Previous clinical studies suggest that focal seizures could have different onset mechanisms. Relatedly, there is a clear heterogeneity in clinical outcomes: only a subset of patients responds to medications, or surgical removal of the presumed epileptic focus. In terms of the appearance and morphology of focal seizure activity, generally two types of common onset patterns are reported: The low amplitude fast (LAF) activity, characterized by oscillations in the beta to gamma range of initially low amplitude that slowly increases as the seizure progresses; and the high amplitude slow (HAS) activity, which is generally described as a slower oscillation below the alpha range with a high amplitude at onset. Depending on the study and subtype of epilepsy, finer distinctions in the onset pattern have been characterized, and different quantitative measures have been used to categorize the onset patterns. Importantly, the LAF pattern is associated with a good surgical outcome when removed, while the HAS pattern may be associated with a worse surgural outcome.A recent computational study used a previously established model of neocortical tissue to investigate the possible mechanisms underlying the different focal seizure onset patterns. The researchers validated the model using clinical recordings of focal seizures and reproduced the two onset patterns in their most defining properties in the model. They found that the two patterns are associated with different mechanisms at the spatial scale of a single ECoG electrode. The LAF onset is initiated by independent patches of localized activity, which slowly invade the surrounding tissue and coalesce over time. In contrast, the HAS onset is a global, systemic transition to a coexisting seizure state triggered by a local event. Such a global transition is enabled by an increase in the excitability of the ""healthy"" surrounding tissue, which by itself does not generate seizures but can support seizure activity when incited. The model also demonstrates how changes in tissue excitability could be elucidated using active stimulation, suggesting that the excitability of the tissue surrounding the seizure core may play a determining role in the seizure onset pattern as well as in the surgical outcome."
Flowering plants, also known as angiosperms, have a unique reproductive system that evolved around 180-140 million years ago to adapt to various ecological environments. These plants have a haploid male gametophyte that is reduced to a three-cellular pollen grain and pollen tube, which can be transported over long distances and grow inside female reproductive tissues. The sperm cells of flowering plants are non-motile and are transported to the female gametes via the pollen tube. Upon arrival at the female gametes, two sperm cells are discharged into the receptive synergid cell to execute double fertilization.Recent studies have identified the first molecular players involved in inter-gametophyte signaling to attract pollen tubes and to arrest their growth. However, the physiological mechanisms leading to pollen tube burst and thus sperm discharge remained elusive. A study published in the journal Science identified polymorphic defensin-like cysteine-rich proteins ZmES1-4 from maize that are exclusively expressed in the cells of the female gametophyte. These proteins accumulate in vesicles at the secretory zone of mature synergid cells and are released during the fertilization process. ZmES4 induces pollen tube burst in a species-preferential manner. Pollen tube plasma membrane depolarization, which occurs immediately after ZmES4 application, as well as channel blocker experiments, suggest a role of K+-influx in the pollen tube rupture mechanism. The intrinsic rectifying K+ channel KZM1 was discovered as a direct target of ZmES4. Following ZmES4 application, KZM1 opens at physiological membrane potentials and closes after wash-out. Vesicles containing ZmES4 are released from the synergid cells upon male-female gametophyte signaling. Subsequent interaction between ZmES4 and KZM1 results in channel opening and K+ influx, leading to water uptake and culminating in osmotic tube burst. The species-preferential activity of polymorphic ZmES4 indicates that the mechanism described represents a pre-zygotic hybridization barrier and may be a component of reproductive isolation in plants.
Oncolytic viruses that specifically target and kill tumor cells are a promising approach in cancer therapy. A significant challenge is effectively targeting disseminated tumors in the body. A study led by De Giovanni et al. retargeted the herpes simplex virus (HSV) to the HER-2 oncoprotein, which is overexpressed in ovarian and breast cancers. The modified HSV, R-LM249, exclusively infects and kills tumor cells expressing high levels of human HER-2, leaving healthy cells unharmed.The researchers tested the efficacy of systemically injected R-LM249 against disseminated tumors in mouse models that mimic tumor spread to the peritoneum in women. The results showed that intraperitoneal administration of R-LM249 strongly inhibited carcinomatosis, resulting in 60% of mice free from peritoneal diffusion and a 95% reduction in the total weight of neoplastic nodules. Intraperitoneal metastases of HER-2+ breast cells were also reduced. Furthermore, brain metastases were also reduced upon i.p. administration of R-LM249.Overall, the study demonstrated that the HER-2-redirected oncolytic HSV effectively reduced the growth of ovarian and breast carcinoma disseminated to the peritoneal cavity. This novel therapy has the potential to improve the treatment of disseminated tumors in women with ovarian and breast cancers. Further research is needed to confirm these findings in clinical trials and to assess the long-term safety and efficacy of this approach.
Centrosome duplication occurs once per cell cycle and is crucial for bipolar spindle formation and genome maintenance. This process is regulated by cyclin-dependent kinases (Cdks), and a study has identified Sfi1, a conserved centrosome component, as the first Cdk substrate required to restrict centrosome duplication to once per cell cycle. Reducing Cdk1 phosphorylation by changing Sfi1 phosphorylation sites to nonphosphorylatable residues leads to defects in separating duplicated spindle pole bodies (SPBs) and premature SPB reduplication during mitosis. These cells also display defects in bipolar spindle assembly, chromosome segregation, and growth. Additionally, the protein phosphatase Cdc14 has the opposite role of activating licensing, likely via dephosphorylation of Sfi1. Cdk1 phosphorylation of Sfi1 promotes SPB separation for spindle formation and prevents premature SPB duplication.
The study conducted by Sato and colleagues investigates the role of the HIV-1 accessory protein Vpr during HIV-1 infection in vivo. The researchers used a human hematopoietic stem cell-transplanted humanized mouse model infected with wild-type and vpr-deficient HIV-1. The findings suggest that Vpr plays a crucial role in accelerating CCR5-tropic HIV-1 propagation during acute infection by utilizing CCR5+ proliferating CD4+ T cells including Tregs.Vpr is known to induce G2 cell cycle arrest and apoptosis and previous in vitro studies have reported that vpr-deficient HIV-1 is less replicative. However, the significance and the precise role of Vpr in vivo remain unclear. The study aimed to characterize the profile of human CD4+ T cell subsets, including Tns, Tms, and Tregs, in human peripheral blood mononuclear cells isolated from HIV-1-negative healthy donors and in the spleen of humanized mice. The results showed that Tregs are more actively cycling in vivo than the other T cell subsets and have a higher expression level of CCR5, the HIV-1 coreceptor, making them more vulnerable to exploitation by Vpr during acute HIV-1 infection.Furthermore, the study found that HIV-1 infection decreases Tregs in humanized mice, resulting in immune activation. Additionally, Vpr enhances virus dissemination and induces Treg depletion leading to immune activation in humanized mice. The distribution of HIV-1-infected cells during acute infection showed that Tregs were more positive for p24, the HIV-1 antigen, than Tm and Tn in both WT HIV-1-infected and HIV-1Δvpr-infected mice, and the percentage of p24+ Tregs in WT HIV-1-infected mice was significantly higher than that in HIV-1Δvpr-infected mice. These findings suggest that Tregs were highly susceptible to HIV-1 infection, produced large amounts of the virus with Vpr responsible for augmenting this production.In conclusion, the study demonstrates the crucial role of Vpr in accelerating CCR5-tropic HIV-1 propagation during acute infection by utilizing CCR5+ proliferating CD4+ T cells including Tregs in vivo. The findings suggest that Vpr-mediated Treg depletion leads to immune activation, thereby augmenting viral propagation in vivo.
Vivax malaria, caused by the Plasmodium vivax parasite, is the second most prevalent form of human malaria, affecting around 390 million people annually. Although it was eliminated in South Korea in the 1970s, it re-emerged in 1993. To understand and control the transmission of P. vivax in South Korea, it is important to analyze the genetic structure of the parasite population. In this study, microsatellite DNA markers of P. vivax from 163 South Korean isolates collected from 1994 to 2008 were analyzed. The analysis of linkage disequilibrium, genetic differentiation, and population structure showed a gradual decrease in linkage disequilibrium levels, while the levels of genetic differentiation between successive years and analysis of the population structure based on the Bayesian approach suggested that a drastic genetic change occurred in the South Korean population during 2002 and 2003. The results suggest the continual introduction of P. vivax into South Korea through other parasite population sources, potentially from North Korea. Molecular epidemiology using microsatellite DNA of the P. vivax population is effective for assessing the population structure and temporal dynamics of parasite transmission, which can assist in the elimination of vivax malaria in endemic areas.
The enhancement of transcription by a splicing-competent intron is a conserved feature in eukaryotes, but the molecular mechanism behind this phenomenon is not fully understood. A study using strand-specific transcription run-on (TRO) analysis found that the transcription of mRNA is favored over upstream anti-sense transcripts (uaRNA) initiating from the promoter in the presence of an intron. Mutation of either the 5′ or 3′ splice site resulted in the reversal of promoter directionality, indicating that the entire splicing-competent intron regulates transcription directionality. ChIP analysis revealed the recruitment of termination factors near the promoter region in the presence of an intron, and this recruitment was adversely affected by the removal of the intron or mutation of splice sites. The study also found that gene looping is crucial for the recruitment of termination factors in the promoter-proximal region of an intron-containing gene, and this looping is dependent on the presence of a splicing-competent intron. The authors propose that the intron-dependent gene looping places terminator-bound factors in the vicinity of the promoter region for termination of the promoter-initiated upstream antisense transcription, thereby conferring promoter directionality. Introns have been enigmatic in their precise physiological role in biological systems, but one of their evolutionarily conserved functions in eukaryotes is in the regulation of mRNA output of a gene. The promoter-proximal introns often stimulate transcription of genes that harbor them in a phenomenon called ‘intron-mediated enhancement of transcription’ (IME). Despite the ubiquity of IME, the molecular mechanism underlying the phenomenon remains elusive. Intron-containing genes contribute nearly 28% of mRNA produced in yeast cells, and the intron-mediated enhancement of transcription involves gene looping, which is the physical interaction of the promoter and terminator regions of a gene in a transcription-dependent manner.
A single nucleotide substitution in intron 3 of the IGF2 gene in pigs leads to a 3-fold up-regulation of IGF2 in skeletal muscle, resulting in major effects on muscle growth, heart size, and fat deposition. The repressor for this gene, ZBED6, was found to be a previously unknown protein specifically in placental mammals and derived from an exapted DNA transposon. ZBED6 affects Igf2 expression, cell proliferation, wound healing, and myotube formation. The protein has a high conservation level in placental mammals and broad tissue distribution with many target genes that have essential biological functions. Strong selection for lean growth in domestic pigs during the last 60 years has resulted in increased muscle growth and reduced fat deposition, with a quantitative trait locus (QTL) mapping to the IGF2 gene. The favorable IGF2 allele has undergone a massive selective sweep and is close to fixation in pig populations used for meat production. The IGF2 mutation up-regulates expression of an IGF2 antisense noncoding transcript with hitherto unknown function. The repressor, ZBED6, binds to its target site only when it is unmethylated, and ZBED6 takes part in the regulation of genes associated with basal functions in placental mammals.
"The RNA editing process, which alters hereditary information by introducing differences between RNA and its corresponding DNA sequence, has been significantly understood through Next Generation Sequencing technology. However, several issues regarding the strategies to accurately delineate the editome, the mechanism by which its profile is maintained, and its evolutionary and functional relevance remain unresolved. This article presents an accurate and quantitative profile of the RNA editome for rhesus macaque, a close relative of human, by combining genome and transcriptome sequencing of multiple tissues from the same animal. The study identified 31,250 editing sites, of which 99.8% are A-to-G transitions, and verified 96.6% of editing sites in coding regions and 97.5% of randomly selected sites in non-coding regions. The findings suggest that RNA editing is a widespread functional regulation in primate evolution and provides an informative framework for further understanding RNA editing in human. The study complements the ""continuous probing"" model, which postulates tinkering-based origination of a small proportion of functional editing sites. The macaque editome highlights RNA editing as a crucial regulatory step shaped by purifying selection, providing an essential evolutionary context to understand RNA-editing regulation in human."
A series of studies have explored the optimal population decoding of sensory responses in two-alternative visual discrimination tasks. These tasks involve integrating noisy neural responses into a more reliable representation of the likelihood that certain stimuli evoked the observed responses. An ideal observer should be able to evaluate likelihood with high precision and only consider the likelihood of the two relevant stimuli involved in the discrimination task. However, a new perceptual bias has been reported, suggesting that observers read out the likelihood representation with low precision during grating spatial frequency discrimination tasks. This bias indicates that observers evaluate likelihoods of a broad range of irrelevant frequencies and discard prior knowledge of stimulus alternatives.Perceptual decisions in visual tasks rely on information encoded in neural responses in primary visual cortex (V1). However, this information may not be readily available to higher levels of the visual system because it is distributed across entire populations of neurons. Each neuron's reliability is limited by intrinsic response variability, and its relevance strongly depends on the perceptual task at hand. To form accurate perceptual judgements, the brain needs to pool sensory responses efficiently, decoding the population response into a reliable decision variable. Studies have shown that the visual system uses a flexible precision pooling scheme or a crude, unselective pooling scheme, depending on the reliability and relevance of sensory responses to the task at hand. However, it remains unclear why results differ across studies, indicating that neural decision making is not fully understood.Formally, optimal decoding requires evaluating neural responses probabilistically by computing the log likelihood function, which captures the likelihood that specific stimuli gave rise to the observed population response. Subsequently, the likelihood function must be read out and linked to a decision variable. In two-alternative discrimination tasks, an optimal decoder calculates a ratio of likelihoods by reading out the likelihood function at two specific locations that correspond to the two possible stimulus alternatives. However, it remains unclear to what extent the likelihood ratio can be computed with arbitrary high precision. A failure to sample the likelihood representation with high precision may account for the suboptimal unselective pooling reported previously.A new perceptual bias has been estimated to understand the width of the likelihood read-out functions involved in two-alternative pattern detection and discrimination tasks. The study found that filtered noise backgrounds dramatically alter the perception of grating spatial frequency. Embedding a grating in low-pass filtered noise causes the perceived spatial frequency of the grating to decrease, while high-pass filtered noise increases perceived grating spatial frequency. A population code model is proposed, consisting of a physiologically inspired V1 encoding front-end followed by a decoding stage. By simultaneously modeling grating detectability and discriminability, the study was able to estimate both the amount of sensory information encoded in the V1 population response and the extent to which this information is used to maximize performance. The findings suggest that observers failed to sample the likelihood function at the appropriate locations with arbitrary high precision, indicating that precision pooling was not adopted in the tasks.
PiRNAs in C. elegans are small non-coding RNAs that play a crucial role in defending the genome against foreign genetic elements. Each piRNA represents a tiny, autonomous transcriptional unit, derived from a 21 nucleotide sequence and an upstream motif with limited genomic context. This motif is necessary for independent expression of a germline-enriched, Piwi-dependent piRNA. A single nucleotide position within this motif directs differential germline enrichment, with over 70% of C. elegans piRNAs being preferentially expressed in male or female germlines. These piRNAs are expressed autonomously, with more than 15,000 unique piRNA sequences encoded in the genome. This number is similar to the number of mRNA coding genes in the C. elegans genome, indicating the significance of piRNAs in this organism.
Brucella species, which cause the disease brucellosis in animals and humans, replicate within host cells in specialized endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-derived vacuoles. However, the mechanisms by which the bacteria acquire ER-derived membrane and establish a replication niche are not well understood. In a study by Zhang et al., the authors investigated the role of the unfolded protein response (UPR) and host factor Yip1A in Brucella abortus replication. The UPR is a cellular stress response that helps restore ER homeostasis, and it is composed of three pathways: IRE1, PERK, and ATF6. Zhang et al. found that B. abortus preferentially activates the IRE1 pathway, leading to the upregulation of COPII vesicle components Sar1, Sec23, and Sec24D. These components are involved in the formation of COPII vesicles at ER exit sites (ERES), where functional ERES and COPII vesicles are required for B. abortus replication. Through immunoprecipitation and Western blotting, the authors identified Yip1A, a 257 amino acid multi-pass membrane protein, as a host factor that interacts with pIRE1 in a UPR-dependent manner. Yip1A localizes to ERES, binds to Sec23 and Sec24, and is involved in COPII vesicle budding. Knockdown of Yip1A diminished the increase in pIRE1 and reduced the splicing of XBP1 mRNA and the amount of spliced-XBP1 protein during Tm treatment. Additionally, Yip1A-knockdown cells showed little upregulation of downstream targets Sar1, Sec23, and Sec24D during B. abortus infection. The localization of IRE1 was not affected by Yip1A-knockdown, but the deficiency in IRE1 phosphorylation caused by Yip1A-knockdown may be attributed to the inability of IRE1 to form oligomers. Overall, the study suggests that Yip1A is a pivotal host factor for B. abortus to establish its ER-derived safe replication niche by regulating the activation of IRE1 via high-order assembly of IRE1 molecules under the UPR condition.
Tombusviruses, including tomato bushy stunt virus (TBSV) and carnation Italian ringspot virus (CIRV), rely on the subversion of host factors and the retargeting of cellular pathways to support their replication. The researchers discovered that TBSV and CIRV recruit the cellular Vps34 phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) into the large viral replication compartment, and the kinase function of Vps34 is critical for TBSV replication, suggesting that PI (3) P phosphoinositide is utilized by TBSV for building the replication compartment. Overexpression of PI (3) P phosphatase in yeast or plants inhibited TBSV replication on the peroxisomal membranes and CIRV replication on the mitochondrial membranes. The direct interaction between the p33 replication protein and Vps34p is needed for the biogenesis of the replication compartments. The researchers concluded that Vps34 and PI (3) P are needed for providing the optimal microenvironment for the replication of the peroxisomal TBSV and the mitochondrial CIRV. Vps34 and PI (3) P play multiple roles in human diseases, such as numerous forms of cancer, heart problems, neurodegeneration, and hepatitis C virus (HCV) replication. Many DNA and RNA viruses are influenced by the PI3K signaling pathway, and subversion of Vps34 PI3K and PI (3) P could be widespread among viruses. The accumulation of PI (3) P helps the recruitment of its numerous protein effectors, and many intracellular microbes and parasites exploit the cellular PI (3) P to establish infections. The SopB effector of the Salmonella bacterium recruits Vps34 to the bacteria-containing vacuole, leading to enrichment of PI (3) P and maturation of the bacteria-containing vacuole. Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Phytophtora, and Plasmodium parasites also exploit PI (3) P to regulate endosomal functions. In summary, Vps34 and PI (3) P play central roles in microbe-host intracellular interactions and are hijacked by tombusviruses to create a favorable environment for their replication.
This study conducted in Iquitos, Peru, between 2011 and 2015, aimed to compare different methods of transmitting dengue virus (DENV) from humans to mosquitoes for a field-based epidemiological study. The study involved 58 participants who were 5 years and older with 5 or fewer days of fever. The three feeding methods compared were direct feeding, indirect feeding with EDTA-treated blood, and indirect feeding with no additive. The study found that infection rates were significantly lower for mosquitoes that fed indirectly on blood with no additive compared to direct and indirect-EDTA feeding. However, dissemination rates were similar across all feeding methods. The study also found no differences in DENV infection or dissemination rates in mosquitoes fed directly on participants with different dengue illness severity. The study demonstrates the feasibility of using direct and indirect feeding methods for field-based studies on vector competence. The study highlights the importance of developing appropriate methods to quantify virus transmission between humans and mosquitoes for mosquito-borne viruses such as DENV, chikungunya, and Zika, which have significant public health impact.
The model organism Caenorhabditis elegans was used to investigate the causes of variability in sensitivity to anti-neoplastic drugs that target topoisomerase II. It was found that wild strains of C. elegans vary in their sensitivity to these drugs, with a methionine-to-glutamine substitution in topoisomerase II (TOP-2) being responsible for this variation. This residue is conserved from yeast to humans and influences cytotoxicity of topoisomerase II poisons in human cell lines. This finding explains why hTOPIIα and hTOPIIβ are differentially affected by various poisons and demonstrates the utility of C. elegans in understanding the genetics of drug responses. Antineoplastic regimens used to treat cancer are often associated with poor prognoses and severe side effects. Ideally, antineoplastic regimens can be tailored to an individual patient based on various genetic markers to maximize therapeutic effectiveness and minimize unwanted side effects. However, the predictive power of identified genetic variants can be inconsistent due to biases in the sampled population and other limitations of clinical genome-wide association studies. The study of model organisms, such as C. elegans, can help identify variants that predict patient outcomes to antineoplastic compounds. In this study, C. elegans was used to identify a major-effect QTL for etoposide resistance on chromosome II at 11.83 Mb, which explained 27% of the phenotypic variance among the recombinant lines. This QTL was confirmed using homozygous reciprocal near-isogenic lines and was found to contain 90 genes, 68 of which contain variation between the parental strains. Of these genes, the top-2 gene, which encodes a topoisomerase II enzyme that is homologous to the two human isoforms of topoisomerase II, was prioritized because topoisomerase II enzymes are the cellular targets for etoposide.
