Genetic variation present in the top-2 gene was found to contribute to differential etoposide sensitivity, with the Bristol top-2 allele underlies etoposide resistance. This study highlights the power of using C. elegans natural genetic variation to identify mechanisms of drug susceptibility in human cells that could inform human health decisions based on genetic information.
"A study was conducted to understand the genetics of lifespan determination in mammals, specifically focusing on rodents, as most research has been done on short-lived animals and it is unclear if these insights can be transferred to long-lived mammals like humans. The study found that some African mole-rats have life expectancies multiple times higher than similar-sized and phylogenetically closely related rodents. To gain new insights, genomic and transcriptomic data from 17 rodent species were obtained and scanned for positively selected genes (PSGs) associated with the evolution of enhanced longevity. The set of 250 identified PSGs showed an expression pattern in the liver of long-lived naked mole-rats and short-lived rats that fits the antagonistic pleiotropy theory of aging. The PSGs were found to be enriched for genes known to be related to aging, including ""cellular respiration,"" ""metal ion homeostasis,"" and functional terms associated with processes regulated by the mTOR pathway: translation, autophagy, and inflammation. Remarkably, among PSGs are RHEB, a regulator of mTOR, and IGF1, both central components of aging-relevant pathways, as well as genes yet unknown to be aging-associated but representing convincing functional candidates. The study concludes that the results provide a meaningful resource for follow-up studies to mechanistically link identified genes and amino acids under positive selection to aging and lifespan determination."
A new Aedes albopictus transinfection, ARwP-M, was generated by introducing wMel Wolbachia in the ARwP line which had been established previously by replacing wAlbA and wAlbB Wolbachia with the wPip strain. This new transinfection showed a 100% rate of maternal inheritance of wMel and wPip Wolbachia. Survival, female fecundity, and egg fertility did not differ between the three Ae. albopictus lines (ARwP-M, ARwP, and SANG). ARwP-M males induced a level of sterility significantly higher than that expected for an equal mating competitiveness when competing with SANG males for SANG females. The overall Wolbachia density in ARwP-M females was about 15 fold higher than in ARwP, mostly due to the wMel infection. This feature corresponded to a strongly reduced vector competence for chikungunya and dengue viruses with respect to ARwP females. Results regarding Zika virus did not highlight significant differences between ARwP-M and ARwP. However, none of the tested ARwP-M females was capable at transmitting ZIKV. These findings are expected to promote the exploitation of Wolbachia to suppress the wild-type Ae. albopictus populations. These strategies have the potential to significantly affect mosquito populations, leading to a diminished risk that they may support diseases. Despite control measures applied worldwide over decades, arthropod-borne diseases continue to pose a constant threat to human and domestic animal health. Human-induced changes in the environment, climate change, passive transportation and acquisition of resistance to insecticides by the vectors are contributing to a dramatic re-emergence of harmful viruses such as dengue (DENV) and yellow fever (YFV) transmitted by mosquitoes.
The text discusses the use of protein structures and their interactions to understand the behavior of proteins in a cellular context. Proteins often interact with other molecules to form complexes or transmit signals. High-resolution 3D structures of these interactions, collected in the Protein Data Bank, can reveal important information about the forces holding the proteins together and the potential disruptibility of the interface. The text describes two main classes of protein-protein interfaces: domain-domain interfaces, which are large and stable, and interfaces between a globular domain and a peptide stretch, which are smaller and often transient, making them ideal for signalling networks. The text also discusses the use of computational tools to predict and understand these domain-motif interactions (DMIs), including the use of sequence-based motif discovery algorithms and tools that search 3D structures for sites that may bind a given motif. The text highlights the importance of high-resolution 3D structures in understanding the function and fast-evolving profiles of DMIs, and the potential of these interactions as drug targets.
Environmental enteropathy (EE) is a disorder associated with growth failure, micronutrient malabsorption, and impaired responses to oral vaccines in disadvantaged populations, particularly children. A study of 49 adults with EE in Lusaka, Zambia used confocal laser endomicroscopy (CLE), histology, immunohistochemistry, and mRNA sequencing of small intestinal biopsies to define cellular mechanisms of impaired barrier function and explore protective mechanisms. The study found virtually ubiquitous small intestinal damage in CLE images, with epithelial defects predominantly at villi tips corresponding to leakage seen in vivo. Circulating LPS was correlated with cell shedding events and inversely with GLP-2, a protective peptide. Zinc uptake was attenuated in 64% of individuals, reduced by HIV, and positively correlated with GLP-2. Transcriptomic analysis identified 23 differentially expressed genes in severe enteropathy, including protective peptides and proteins. The study suggests that confocal endomicroscopy, claudin 4 immunostaining, and histology can identify epithelial defects, sites of bacterial translocation, and the role of GLP-2 and other protective peptides in mucosal protection in EE. Further elucidation of these pathways is of considerable importance for developing strategies to prevent and treat EE.
Superinfection Exclusion (SIE) is a phenomenon where a pre-existing virus, referred to as the primary invader, prevents secondary infections by the same or closely related viruses, known as superinfectors, at the cellular and/or organismal levels. This phenomenon has been observed in many human and animal pathogenic viruses, including HIV, HCV, WNV, and VSV, as well as large double-stranded DNA viruses like herpesviruses and poxviruses. SIE has also been documented in plant viruses, such as citrus tristeza virus and tobacco mosaic virus, and is thought to be mechanistically related to the cross protection phenomenon observed in virus-infected plants. SIE is primarily a virus-driven phenomenon, with one or a few virus-encoded proteins playing a critical role and little involvement of host cell components. In the case of turnip crinkle virus (TCV), SIE is exclusively determined by p28, one of the two replication proteins encoded by this virus. P28 expressed from a TCV replicon exerts strong SIE to a different TCV replicon, and this repressive activity can be recapitulated by transiently expressing p28. P28 forms multimeric intracellular inclusions that inactivate p28 translated from superinfectors, thereby denying superinfectors the chance to replicate. This novel, simple mechanism of SIE could prove to be applicable to many other viruses and predicts a novel target for antiviral therapy.
In a study to test the duration of protection provided by the Trypanosoma cruzi trans-sialidase (TS) gene using different delivery methods, it was found that while TS DNA vaccines induced robust TS-specific IFN-γ responses and protected mice against lethal challenge in the short term, long-term protection was not reported. The goal of the study was to investigate whether the co-administration of a plasmid encoding IL-15 (pIL-15) could improve the duration of protection achieved through genetic vaccination with pTS alone. Mice immunized with pTS alone developed robust TS-specific IFN-γ responses and survived a lethal challenge given within the first 3 months following immunization. However, mice vaccinated with both pTS and pIL-15 challenged 6 months post-vaccination were significantly more protected against lethal T. cruzi challenges than mice vaccinated with pTS alone (P<0.05). Improved protection correlated with significantly higher numbers of TS-specific IFN-γ producing total and CD8+ T cells detected 6 months post immunization. The addition of pIL-15 during genetic vaccination greatly improved long-term T cell survival, memory T cell expansion, and long-term protection against the important human parasite, T. cruzi. This is significant because over 11 million individuals are infected worldwide with T. cruzi, and current chemotherapies have limited effectiveness in chronic infection and are often poorly tolerated. A safe and effective vaccine is needed to curb the spread of Chagas disease and reduce its burden on public health.
The protein kinase TbPLK in the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma brucei plays crucial roles in basal body segregation, flagellum attachment, and cytokinesis. The level of TbPLK protein is tightly controlled through a Cullin-RING ubiquitin ligase composed of Cullin4, the DNA damage-binding protein 1 homolog TbDDB1, and a WD40-repeat protein WDR1. WDR1 interacts with the PEST motif in TbPLK via its C-terminal domain and binds to TbDDB1 via its N-terminal WD40 motif, promoting TbPLK degradation in the basal body and the bilobe after the G1/S cell cycle transition. This mechanism ensures proper bilobe duplication, basal body separation, and flagellum-cell body adhesion. TbPLK contains two potential degradation motifs, putative D-boxes and a putative PEST motif, and its degradation depends on both these motifs. APC/C is involved in TbPLK degradation, but it is not the sole and major ubiquitin ligase responsible for TbPLK degradation. WDR1, a TbPLK-interacting protein, localizes to the basal body and the bilobe region during S phase and interacts with TbPLK via its C-terminal domain. WDR1 forms a complex with TbCUL4 but not other Cullins, suggesting that WDR1 specifically forms a Cullin-RING ubiquitin ligase complex with TbCUL4, TbDDB1, and TbPLK, named CRL4WDR1, which mediates TbPLK degradation. Knockdown of WDR1 results in a severe growth defect and disrupted flagellum-cell body adhesion, suggesting that WDR1 is essential for cell proliferation and proper flagellum attachment in the procyclic form.
The DExD/H box RNA helicases, such as RIG-I-like receptors (RLR), are important components of the innate immune system. Here, a study reveals the significant role of the heterosomal isoforms of the DEAD box RNA helicase DDX3 in the immune system. Mice lacking DDX3X during hematopoiesis showed altered leukocyte composition in bone marrow and spleen, and a significant inability to combat Listeria monocytogenes infection. The alterations in innate immune responses resulted from decreased effector cell availability and function and a sex-dependent impairment of cytokine synthesis. DDX3X is a regulator of IFN-I transcription in cells infected with viruses or with Listeria monocytogenes. DDX3X is implicated in cellular processes such as apoptosis, cell cycle regulation, and tumorigenesis. Deletion of DDX3X in all embryonic tissues causes the death of male embryos at an early postimplantation stage. DDX3X and DDX3Y share around 90% homology, with DDX3Y protein expression originally thought to be confined to the male germline. However, more recent proteomic databases list DDX3Y in cells of the immune system, including T-cells, B-cells, and NK-cells, suggesting that DDX3 and DDX3Y are functionally redundant. The heterosomal origin of the DDX3 isoforms suggests they may contribute to sex-related differences in immunity to microbes, the ability to resolve inflammation and the propensity to develop autoinflammatory syndromes. DDX3X may promote replication of viruses like HIV or HCV, but it also stimulates the production of antiviral IFN-I. Antimicrobial pathways leading to IFN-I synthesis converge at two related S/T kinases, TBK1 and IKKε. DDX3X interacts with TBK1 and serves as its substrate and interacts with IKKε, the other non-canonical IKK kinase responsible for phosphorylation and activation of the interferon regulatory factors (IRF) 3 and 7 that control Ifnb gene transcription. In addition to its function downstream of TBK1/IKKε, DDX3X reportedly associates with the adaptor protein MAVS which localizes upstream of TBK1 and IKKε and supports signal transduction by the two DExH helicases RIG-I and MDA-5. In this context, DDX3X was shown to sense viral RNA and to supplement the function of RIG-I and MDA-5 in the early phase of infection. Strengthening its importance for antiviral immunity, a recent report lists DDX3X among genes conferring intrinsic antiviral immunity to stem cells.
A biophysical model of receptor potential generation in male moth olfactory receptor neurons is presented, focusing on post-effector processes involving second messengers, ionic channels, and Ca2+ extrusion mechanisms. The model captures the main features of the dose-response curves and reproduces the second messenger kinetics. It suggests that two types of depolarizing ionic channels play different roles at low and high pheromone concentrations. ORNs are essential for odor molecule recognition, and modeling has contributed significantly to understanding their transduction cascade. The model presented here focuses on post-effector processes in male moth pheromone ORNs, taking advantage of modeling studies in both moths and vertebrates. It aims to fit experimental dose-response curves and address the functional roles of various currents and mechanisms behind the characteristics of concentration-response curves. A global qualitative model of pheromone transduction is developed based on experimental results, assumptions, and known facts. Computer simulations, sensitivity analysis, and feedback control assessments are carried out to determine parameter values, fit experimental curves, and understand the system's behavior. The results suggest the coexistence of two signaling pathways in both pheromonal and non-pheromonal ORNs, one ionotropic and the other metabotropic, both gating a cationic channel. The ionotropic signal is rapid and transient, while the metabotropic signal is sensitive and prolonged, with different intensities and timings. The ionotropic pathway has lower energetic cost and could explain the high speed of response in ORNs and moths.
The study investigates the interaction between chromatin status and p53RE context in the transactivation response of p53, a tumor suppressor protein that responds to DNA damage and cellular stress signals. The researchers used a well-characterized lymphoblastoid cell-culture exposure model system and ENCODE data to analyze genome-wide changes in p53 binding, H3K4me3, gene expression, and DNase I hypersensitivity (DNase-seq) induced by the DNA-damaging, chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin (DXR) in human lymphoblastoid cell lines (LCL). The results showed inverse correlations between p53 occupancy and both chromatin accessibility and evolutionary conservation. The study also revealed that p53RE sequence content is highly correlated with genomic occupancy and that chromatin state context strongly modulates the relationship between p53 occupancy level and changes in gene expression. The interaction between these features appears to have been shaped by evolutionary selective pressure, likely driven by transposable elements. The findings suggest the importance of considering the interactions of sequence content and epigenetic factors in interpreting p53-mediated stress responses.
Synthetic biology aims to design and reengineer biological systems, with efforts mainly focused on transcriptional circuits due to limited understanding of signaling circuits' systems dynamics and experimental challenges. However, bacterial two-component signaling systems offer a rich diversity of sensory systems that can be reengineered through synthetic biology. A study focused on a specific motif in two-component signaling, where a single histidine kinase (HK) phosphotransfers reversibly to two separate output response regulator (RR) proteins, found that this motif not only allows rapid signal termination but also implements a sigmoidal signal-response relationship. Mathematical conditions on system parameters were identified, necessary for sigmoidal signal-response relationships, and key parameters that control threshold levels and sensitivity of the signal-response curve were defined. In vitro reconstitution of the one HK-two RR motif found in the Sinorhizobium meliloti chemotaxis pathway confirmed these findings. The study concludes that the one HK-two RR motif allows bacteria and yeast to implement tunable switch-like signal processing and provides an ideal basis for developing threshold devices for synthetic biology applications. This research contributes to understanding the signal-response relationship in two-component systems and facilitates the design of synthetic threshold devices using two-component signaling proteins.
In both bacteria and humans, individual cells within isogenic populations can show significant variation in stress tolerance, but the nature of this heterogeneity is unclear. To investigate this, a study used single-cell RNA sequencing to quantify transcript heterogeneity in single Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells treated with and without salt stress. The study aimed to explore population variation and identify cellular covariates that influence the stress-responsive transcriptome. By leveraging the extensive knowledge of yeast transcriptional regulation, the study uncovered significant regulatory variation in individual yeast cells, both before and after stress. A subset of cells appears to decouple expression of ribosomal protein genes from the environmental stress response, in a manner partly correlated with the cell cycle but unrelated to the yeast ultradian metabolic cycle. Overall, the study suggests that cells maintain a cellular filter against decoupled bursts of transcription factor activation but mount a stress response upon coordinated regulation, even in a subset of unstressed cells. The variation in stress tolerance can be traced to heterogeneous expression of defense genes, and in some cases, such variation is intrinsic to the gene promoter, producing stochastic transcriptional bursts. Extrinsic variation in the cellular system, such as activation of the broader upstream signaling response or transition through other physiological states, likely plays an important role. Several studies have shown that variation in stress tolerance can be linked to the Environmental Stress Response (ESR), a common transcriptomic response triggered by diverse stresses, which includes induced expression of defense genes and repression of genes encoding ribosomal proteins and factors involved in ribosome biogenesis. Activation of the ESR after mild stress can impart increased tolerance to subsequent stress, while increased expression of the iESR genes is coupled to reduced expression of RP and RiBi genes in the repressed-Environmental Stress Response gene set. Cell-to-cell variation in Msn2 activation could explain the heterogeneity in stress tolerance in an actively growing culture.
African trypanosomiasis, also known as sleeping sickness, is a parasitic disease caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma brucei and transmitted through the tsetse fly. The parasite can infect various organs and tissues, including the male reproductive system. A recent study found that in mice, T. brucei accumulates in the male reproductive system, specifically in the stroma of the epididymis, epididymal adipose tissue, and fibrous tunics of the testis. However, the parasites are not located in immune-privileged sites and are exposed to a strong immune response. This finding suggests the potential use of fine needle aspiration cytology as a complementary diagnostic tool for Animal African Trypanosomiasis.Human African Trypanosomiasis is a neglected tropical disease that affects both humans and animals, causing significant pathology and limiting livestock production in sub-Saharan Africa. The disease has two sub-species, T. b. gambiense and T. b. rhodesiense, with T. b. gambiense being the most prevalent and responsible for approximately 97% of the cases. Animal African Trypanosomiasis (AAT), also known as nagana, is primarily caused by T. congolense and T. vivax, while T. b. evansi and T. brucei subspecies play a minor role. AAT is transmitted cyclically by tsetse flies, while T. b. evansi is transmitted mechanically by hematophagous biting flies and T. equiperdum is sexually transmitted.A study in mice infected with T. b. brucei showed that parasites circulate in blood, lymph, and are present in interstitial space of several organs and tissues, including adipose tissue, skin, and testis. The presence of replicating T. b. brucei parasites in the male reproductive organs has also been described in other animals such as rats, guinea pigs, and rabbits. A recent study proposed that the accumulation of T. b. brucei in the male reproductive organs could protect parasites from the immune system and drugs.The male reproductive system has specialized tissue barriers, such as blood-testis and blood-epididymis barriers, that maintain sperm inaccessible to the immune system. A disruption of these barriers generates a foreign body reaction/granuloma and commonly leads to infertility. Reproductive organs are often affected in trypanosomiasis in both male and female animals. In male animals infected with T. b. brucei, testis show multiple lesions, including scrotal dermatitis, orchitis, and periorchitis, resulting in poor quality semen.In conclusion, T. brucei accumulates in the male reproductive organs of mice, including the testis and epididymis, in niches that are not protected by the blood-testis, nor blood-epididymis barriers, leading to severe inflammation and disruption of both barriers. The detection of parasites in the male reproductive organs opens the possibility of using fine needle aspiration cytology as a complementary diagnostic tool for Animal African Trypanosomiasis. Reproductive health is affected in both humans and animals infected with T. b. gambiense or T. b. rhodesiense, leading to impotence, gynecomastia, infertility, or sterility in men and irregular estrous cycle, infertility, or sterility in women. Reproductive health disorders can also affect fetal development in pregnant women and animals infected with trypanosomiasis.
Chemosensation is critical for the survival of most organisms, including Drosophila melanogaster, and is mediated by large families of chemoreceptor proteins. The expression of chemoreceptor genes must be tuned appropriately to changes in the chemical environment. A study was conducted to understand the regulation of chemoreceptor genes in D. melanogaster, focusing on genes that are clustered in the genome. The study found that these genes undergo independent transcriptional regulation at different developmental stages and between sexes. Expression of distinct subgroups of chemoreceptor genes is sensitive to reproductive state and social interactions. Exposure of flies to odor of the opposite sex results in altered transcript abundance of chemoreceptor genes, and genes are distinct from those that show transcriptional plasticity when flies are allowed physical contact with same or opposite sex members. The chemosensory subgenome is structured as a mosaic of small modules of highly correlated transcripts, enabling fine tuning of the expression of the chemoreceptor repertoire in response to ecologically relevant environmental and physiological conditions. These findings have implications for the understanding of the evolution and function of chemosensory systems in animals.
"Human trisomies, which result from abnormal meiotic recombination and nondisjunction during maternal meiosis I or II, can be better understood by studying the meiotic recombination process in human females. Immunofluorescence methodology can be used to analyze crossover-associated proteins, such as MLH1, in human fetal oocytes to identify abnormal crossover configurations and characterize genome-wide levels of recombination in the human female. Studies have shown that the number of MLH1 foci is lower than predicted, but their localization pattern conforms to that expected for a crossover-associated protein. Observations also provide evidence for the presence of ""vulnerable"" crossover configurations in the fetal oocyte, which can lead to nondisjunctional events in the adult oocyte. Meiotic errors, particularly in the first meiotic division, are a significant cause of chromosome abnormalities in humans, with most abnormalities originating in the oocyte. Disturbances in meiotic recombination have been linked to various human trisomies, with most trisomies associated with reductions in recombination and alterations in the location of crossover events. It is hypothesized that there is a two-step process linking aberrant meiotic recombination and meiotic nondisjunction, with achiasmate homologous chromosomes or homologous chromosomes with sub-optimally located exchanges being a large proportion, if not a majority, of human trisomies. Despite advancing maternal age being the most important risk factor for meiotic nondisjunction, these meiotic recombination abnormalities occur in the fetal ovary."
The article discusses the impact of pre-exposure to arthropod saliva on the transmission and control of vector-borne diseases. When a mammal is bitten by a blood-feeding arthropod, it is injected with vasodilatory and immunomodulatory compounds in the arthropod’s saliva that facilitate feeding. The mammalian host mounts a variety of immune responses, and local immune responses to an arthropod bite include inflammation, production of anti-salivary protein antibody, and recruitment of immune cells to the skin. Prior exposure to mosquito saliva has been shown to reduce Plasmodium burden in the liver- and blood-stage, while no pre-sensitisation effect was found for the infectivity of sporozoites. In West Nile virus, empirical evidence for the role of pre-exposure to mosquito saliva is mixed. The immunological mechanisms behind any protective effects remain unclear.The article then discusses the potential impact of pre-exposure to arthropod saliva on the effectiveness of vector control strategies. Classic epidemiological models tend to ignore the effects of immune pre-sensitisation, predicting that heightened adult vector mortality can effectively control a vector-borne disease by reducing vector abundance. However, these theoretical predictions have not always held up in practice, with insecticide spraying interventions failing to reduce the number of infections in some host populations. The article argues that the interplay between vector saliva and host immunity can produce a variety of epidemiological outcomes, depending on the effect of pre-sensitisation on the duration of infection.The authors developed mathematical models to determine the potential for pre-exposure to vector saliva to affect between-host infection dynamics and modulate the consequences of interventions that target vectors. The models showed that the interplay between vector saliva and host immunity can produce a variety of epidemiological outcomes, depending on the effect of pre-sensitisation on the duration of infection.In conclusion, pre-exposure to arthropod saliva can have a significant impact on the transmission and control of vector-borne diseases. While prior exposure to mosquito saliva has been shown to reduce Plasmodium burden in the liver- and blood-stage, the immunological mechanisms behind any protective effects remain unclear. Classic epidemiological models tend to ignore the effects of immune pre-sensitisation, and further research is needed to determine the potential for pre-exposure to vector saliva to affect between-host infection dynamics and modulate the consequences of interventions that target vectors.
Leishmaniasis is a disease affecting 12 million people in 88 countries, with 2 million new cases each year. In Brazil, Leishmania amazonensis is a significant agent, causing different clinical forms of the disease. A study compared the proteomes of amastigotes isolated from BALB/c and BALB/c nude mice to understand the effect of the host immune response on Leishmania proteins. The athymic nude mice, with a T-cell deficiency, may resemble patients with diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis, anergic to Leishmania's antigens. The results showed that specific isoforms of virulence factors, such as OPB and tryparedoxin peroxidase, were increased in parasites from nude mice, suggesting that T cells probably restrain their posttranslational modifications in BALB/c mice. Identifying potential virulence factors and ways of regulating their expression could lead to a better understanding of the disease and potential targets for treatment.
AID, an enzyme that initiates antibody gene mutation to increase diversity, is tightly regulated and predominantly found in the cytoplasm. However, it requires access to the nucleus to function. AID stability and abundance are affected by posttranslational modifications and interactions with other proteins that modulate cytoplasmic retention and nuclear import. AID is cell cycle-regulated, with nuclear degradation occurring more slowly in G1 phase than in S or G2-M phase. Mutations that affect regulatory phosphorylation or catalytic activity can alter AID stability and abundance. By fusing AID to tags derived from cell cycle regulators CDT1 and Geminin, it was shown that nuclear AID accelerates somatic hypermutation and class switch recombination in G1 phase, but compromises viability in S-G2/M phase. These findings suggest that cell cycle regulation of AID activity may be useful for engineering genes by iterative mutagenesis and selection, and that cell cycle tags may be generally applicable to studying DNA repair, recombination, RNA biogenesis, and genome engineering.
The metabolism of plant polysaccharides by microbes is crucial to environmental carbon cycling, human nutrition, and industrial processes utilizing cellulosic bioconversion. This study demonstrates a method to analyze the catabolism of plant polysaccharides by microbes, combining carbohydrate-active enzyme (CAZyme) assays, RNA sequencing (RNA-seq), and anaerobic growth screening. The bacterium Clostridium phytofermentans, which has 171 CAZyme-encoding genes, was used as the model organism to study the fermentation of various plant biomass components. The research found that C. phytofermentans ferments glucans, mannans, xylans, galactans, pectins, and arabinans with varying efficiencies, and that the bacterium responds to different polysaccharides by up-regulating specific groups of CAZymes, transporters, and enzymes to metabolize the constituent sugars. Additionally, the study identified synergies between enzymes acting on the same substrate with different catalytic mechanisms, advancing our understanding of how microbes degrade and metabolize plant biomass.
The studies from 1974 to 2005 in Sierra Leone showed onchocerciasis endemicity in 12 of 14 health districts, and baseline studies from 2005-2008 showed lymphatic filariasis (LF) endemicity in all 14 health districts. From 2008-2010, three integrated annual mass drug administrations (MDAs) were conducted in the 12 co-endemic districts with good geographic, programmatic, and drug coverage. A midterm assessment in 2011 determined the impact of these MDAs on LF in these districts. The mf prevalence and intensity in the 12 districts were determined using the thick blood film method and compared with baseline data from 2007-2008. Overall, mf prevalence fell from 2.6% to 0.3%, a decrease of 88.5%. Prevalence was 0.0% in four districts: Bo, Moyamba, Kenema and Kono, and seven districts had reductions in mf prevalence of between 70.0% and 95.0%. Only Bombali still had an mf prevalence ≥1.0% (1.58%). Overall, arithmetic mean mf density reduced by 65.0% among mf-positive individuals, and 95.8% for the entire population. These results show that mf prevalence decreased to <1.0% in all but one of the 12 districts after three MDAs, and overall mf density reduced by 65.0% among mf-positive individuals, and 95.8% for the entire population. LF and onchocerciasis are two of the major neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) targeted for elimination using the World Health Organization (WHO) recommended strategy of preventive chemotherapy and transmission control (PCT). The elimination strategy is through annual MDAs with albendazole and ivermectin/diethylcarbamazine. LF elimination is implemented through the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GPELF) which has expanded MDA coverage from three million people treated in 12 countries in 2000 to more than 450 million in 53 countries in 2010. In Sierra Leone, both diseases are widely distributed across the country and co-endemic in 12 of the 14 health districts. Surveys conducted in Sierra Leone after 2002 showed that vector biting rates and community microfilaria load had reverted to pre-treatment levels in many communities. Since 2003 annual MDAs have been conducted for onchocerciasis control using the CDTI strategy. The CDTI strategy, which promotes community participation as the key aspect of ivermectin distribution to improve access to ivermectin and ensure community ownership of the process, has been observed to significantly reduce parasite prevalence and intensity in many communities of Sierra Leone since control operations resumed in 2003. Reports from health facilities had always indicated high endemicity of LF in all districts. Pre-baseline prevalence of LF was very high in south-eastern Sierra Leone. Surveys in the early 1990s showed an average mf prevalence of 34.8% in three villages in the Moyamba district. After national mapping of LF in 2005 and baseline data collection on microfilaria (mf) prevalence and density in 2007-2008, CDTI was expanded to include albendazole distribution to control LF in six co-endemic districts in 2007. With support from the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) NTD Control Program, the NOCP was transformed into the National Neglected Tropical Diseases Control Programme (NTDCP) in 2008 to upscale treatment for LF from 6 districts to all 14 endemic districts and integrate other NTDs such as schistosomiasis and soil transmitted helminthiasis into the control effort.
High-throughput sequencing techniques, such as 16S rRNA gene profiling, are used to explore complex natural microbial communities, like those from the ocean or the human gut. A critical step in analyzing this data is identifying dependencies between community members, which is typically done through correlation analysis. However, correlation analysis can produce unreliable results with compositional data, where observed data is presented as relative fractions of genes or species rather than absolute abundances. This issue is highlighted in a study using simulated and real data from the Human Microbiome Project, which found that many correlations among taxa can be artificial, and true correlations may even appear with opposite sign. Community diversity was identified as the key factor that modulates the severity of these compositional effects. To address this issue, the study developed a new approach called SparCC, which can estimate correlation values from compositional data, and was used to infer a rich ecological network connecting hundreds of interacting species across 18 sites on the human body. The study found that the standard approach yields 3 spurious species-species interactions for each true interaction and misses 60% of the true interactions in the human microbiome data. Compositional effects are shown to be a significant challenge in the analysis of genomic survey data, and methods like SparCC provide a solution for estimating correlations in compositional data.
Lysozyme, an antimicrobial factor found in high concentrations in mucosal surface fluids, has two antibacterial activities: a muramidase activity that hydrolyzes the peptidoglycan of bacterial cell walls and a non-muramidase activity attributed to its function as a cationic antimicrobial peptide. In Streptococcus pneumoniae, two enzymes, PgdA and Adr, have been implicated in its resistance to lysozyme in vitro by modifying different sites on the peptidoglycan. The muramidase activity of lysozyme is critical for its antimicrobial effect and both peptidoglycan modifications are required for full resistance by pneumococci. During colonization of the upper respiratory tract, wild-type pneumococci out-compete the double mutant in lysozyme M-sufficient mice, but not in lysozyme M-deficient mice, indicating the importance of resistance to the muramidase activity of lysozyme during mucosal colonization. The combined peptidoglycan modifications reduce overall fitness, but this is outweighed by the benefits of resistance to the peptidoglycan degrading activity of lysozyme. Organisms that reside on mucosal surfaces where lysozyme is particularly abundant must have the ability to evade its antibacterial effects. However, the contribution of cell wall modifications, which affect lysozyme resistance, to bacterial survival on mucosal surfaces has not been examined.
Dengue is a significant global health issue, with Brazil being responsible for approximately 80% of dengue cases in the Americas. A study was conducted to investigate the usefulness of NS1 capture tests as an alternative tool to detect DENV in tissue specimens from previously confirmed dengue fatal cases in Brazil. The study used 74 tissue samples from 23 fatal cases and evaluated three tests for NS1 antigen capture: first generation Dengue Early ELISA, Platelia NS1, and the rapid test NS1 Ag Strip. The NS1 Ag Strip was found to be the most sensitive at detecting DENV in tissue samples, achieving 78.3% sensitivity compared to 22.9% for Dengue Early ELISA and 45.9% for Platelia NS1. These findings suggest that NS1 capture assays, such as the NS1 Ag Strip, are a valuable approach to postmortem dengue confirmation and may be used as a clinical/pathological diagnostic tool. However, further studies are needed to establish the specificity of this approach before NS1 antigen testing can be relied upon for the diagnosis of fatal dengue cases.
The study analyzes the molecular alterations in Multiple Myeloma (MM) between African American (AA) and Caucasian American (CA) patients, using whole exome sequencing, RNA-sequencing, and clinical data from 718 MM patients from the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation CoMMpass study Interim Analysis 9. The study found significant differences in mutation frequency between AA and CA cases in several genes, including BCL7A, BRWD3, AUTS2, TP53, and IRF4. These genes are involved in translocations in B-cell malignancies. The study suggests that interrogating diverse tumor cohorts can help understand tumor genomics across populations and provide rationale for addressing disparities in incidence and outcomes observed among AA or otherwise African descent patients. The study also highlights the importance of considering both self-reported race and genetic ancestry in future MM studies to better understand the biological determinants of MM.
The exome of cancer cells often has a large number of passenger mutations, which don't affect the cell's reproductive rate but provide information about the cancer's evolutionary history and can become targets for immunotherapy or confer resistance to treatment. A population of cancer cells can be described by its stochastic expansion, which can be analyzed both forward and backward in time to calculate fixation probabilities, frequencies of successive passenger mutations, and the number of cancer cells present when a certain mutation arose. Passenger mutations can be used to infer the parameters of the tumorigenic process in neutral evolution. During clonal expansion, new mutations can reach fixation in the population with a probability that increases with the mutation rate and the death-birth ratio. The expected number of subclonal mutations present at a frequency larger than α is highly dependent on the ratio δ. Formula (5) can be fitted to cancer sequencing data to determine how well the branching process model of neutral evolution describes the observed mutation frequencies and to extract the most likely parameters of the process. The frequencies of the first and most abundant passenger mutations are influenced by the death-birth ratio of the cancer cells and determine the shape of the cancer's phylogenetic tree.
The expansion of polyglutamine (polyQ) in exon1 of the huntingtin protein is linked to Huntington's disease. When the number of glutamines exceeds a threshold of approximately 36-40 repeats, XN1 can readily form amyloid aggregates. The misfolding of a XN1 monomer plays an important role in the length-dependent aggregation, and the flanking sequences surrounding the polyQ region can play a critical role in determining the structural rearrangement and aggregation mechanism of XN1. Molecular dynamics simulations on monomeric XN1 with full flanking regions, a variant missing the polyproline regions, and an isolated polyQ peptide (Qn) were performed. The results showed that polyQ peptides have a positive correlation between their probability to form a β-rich misfolded state and their expansion length. The flanking regions of XN1 affect its probability to form a β-rich state compared to the isolated polyQ. Particularly, the polyproline regions form polyproline type II helices and decrease the probability of the polyQ region to form a β-rich state. Additionally, by lengthening polyQ, the first N-terminal 17 residues are more likely to adopt a β-sheet conformation rather than an α-helix conformation. Therefore, the molecular dynamics study provides a structural insight of XN1 misfolding and elucidates the possible role of the flanking sequences in XN1 aggregation.
CRISPR/Cas systems are a crucial defense mechanism in archaea and bacteria against foreign nucleic acids, including phages and conjugative plasmids. Consisting of repeat sequences and spacer sequences derived from foreign DNA, CRISPR arrays, along with cas genes, provide acquired resistance to viruses and conjugative plasmids. The Human Microbiome Project (HMP) has provided an opportunity to explore the distribution and diversity of CRISPRs in human-associated microbial communities. By using a targeted assembly strategy, researchers were able to reconstruct CRISPR arrays in HMP datasets and identified 150 known CRISPRs and discovered 86 novel CRISPRs. The distributions of these CRISPRs, both known and novel, were found to be largely body-site specific, with some CRISPRs predominantly found in stool, oral, or vaginal samples. The role of CRISPR/Cas systems in microbiomes is essential for understanding the ecology and evolution of microbiomes. The ability of CRISPRs to prevent plasmid spread is also medically relevant, as it may hinder the exchange of antibiotic resistance genes and the acquisition of resistance by pathogens. The study of CRISPRs in human microbial communities will continue to provide valuable insights into the tracing of rare species, virus exposure, and the evolution of microbiomes.
The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, a well-established model organism for studying development and behavior, may exhibit circadian rhythms. Despite the presence of rhythms in C. elegans, their robustness and dependence on external cues are unclear. Here, genome-wide expression profiling was used to identify light- and temperature-entrained oscillating transcripts in C. elegans. These transcripts exhibited rhythmic expression with temperature-compensated 24-h periods and were sustained under constant conditions, suggesting circadian regulation. Light and temperature cycles strongly drove gene expression and appeared to entrain largely nonoverlapping gene sets. Mutations in a cyclic nucleotide-gated channel required for sensory transduction abolished both light- and temperature-entrained gene expression, implying that environmental cues act cell nonautonomously to entrain circadian rhythms. These findings demonstrate circadian-regulated transcriptional rhythms in C. elegans and suggest that further analyses in this organism will provide new information about the evolution and function of this biological clock.
The Saccharomyces cerevisiae RAD3 gene is the homolog of human XPD, encoding a DNA helicase of the TFIIH complex involved in both nucleotide excision repair (NER) and transcription. Some mutant alleles of RAD3, such as rad3-101 and rad3-102, have partial defects in DNA repair and a strong hyper-recombination (hyper-Rec) phenotype. The hyper-Rec phenotype of rad3 strains is caused by persistent single-stranded DNA gaps converted to recombinogenic double-strand breaks (DSBs) by replication. Both rad3-101 and rad3-102 elevate the frequency of reciprocal crossovers about 100-fold, with three-quarters of these crossovers reflecting DSBs formed at the same positions in both sister chromatids (double sister-chromatid breaks, DSCBs) and the remainder reflecting DSBs formed in single chromatids (single chromatid breaks, SCBs). The ratio of DSCBs to SCBs is similar to that observed for spontaneous recombination events in wild-type cells. A comparison of these data with previous analyses of spontaneous mitotic recombination events suggests that a sub-set of spontaneous events in wild-type cells may be initiated by incomplete NER reactions, and that DSCBs, which cannot be repaired by sister-chromatid recombination, are a major source of mitotic recombination between homologous chromosomes.
The gastric pathogen Helicobacter pylori uses simple sequence repeats (SSRs) as contingency loci to adapt to its host environment through a slipped strand mispairing mechanism, generating heterogeneous populations. In H. pylori, an intergenically located T-tract, through slipped strand mispairing, operates with a rheostat-like function to fine-tune the activity of the sabA promoter, driving expression of the sialic acid binding adhesin SabA. The length of the T-tract generates multiphasic output from the sabA promoter, altering H. pylori binding to sialyl-Lewis x receptors on gastric mucosa. Fragment length analysis of post-infection isolated clones shows that the T-tract length is a highly variable feature in H. pylori, reflecting the host-pathogen interplay. The T-tract length affects the local DNA structure and RNA polymerase binding, acting as a rheostat to modulate cognate promoter output. This mechanism provides an alternative mechanism for transcriptional regulation in bacteria like H. pylori, which have a limited repertoire of classical trans-acting regulatory factors.
High-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) must evade innate immune surveillance to establish persistent infections and amplify viral genomes upon differentiation. Members of the JAK-STAT family, including STAT-1 and STAT-5, regulate the innate immune response. HPV E7 activates STAT-5 phosphorylation without altering total protein levels, and inhibition of STAT-5 phosphorylation by the drug pimozide abolishes viral genome amplification and late gene expression in differentiating keratinocytes. The STAT-5β isoform is mainly responsible for this activity, mediated through the ATM DNA damage response, and downstream target PPARγ contributes to the effects on members of the ATM pathway. These findings identify an important new regulatory mechanism by which the innate immune regulator STAT-5 promotes HPV viral replication. HPVs are the causative agents of cervical and other anogenital cancers, with high-risk genital HPVs such as HPV16, 18, 31, and 35 infecting the squamous epithelia of the genital tract. The HPV life cycle is closely associated with epithelial differentiation, and to establish persistent infection, HPVs must escape host innate and adaptive immune responses. High-risk HPV genomes encode early and late genes, with E6 and E7 playing important roles in regulation of the productive life cycle and in the development of anogenital cancers. HPV E6 and E7 have been implicated as important regulators of immune evasion. The ATM DNA damage pathway is necessary for HPV genome amplification in differentiating cells but has no effect on the stable maintenance of episomes in undifferentiated cells. Activation of the ATM DNA damage pathway has been shown to be necessary for HPV genome amplification in differentiating cells, but how they regulate HPV genome amplification and what signals are responsible for their activation remains unclear. HPVs must evade surveillance by both innate and adaptive immune responses, and the JAK/STAT pathway is one of the primary pathways regulating the innate immune response. The JAK/STAT pathway is activated by external growth signals mediated through cytokines, growth factors, and interferons, leading to translocation of STAT proteins to the nucleus and increased expression of downstream genes. Previous studies have shown that HPV gene products suppress transcription of STAT-1, but not STAT-2 or STAT-3, and that this repression is necessary for stable maintenance of viral episomes and differentiation-dependent genome amplification. We investigated if HPV proteins similarly suppress other members of the JAK-STAT pathway and found that HPV gene products activate STAT-5 phosphorylation without altering total protein levels. This activation was observed in the absence of any added cytokines or growth factors, suggesting that constitutive activation of STAT-5 by HPV proteins could play a role in the HPV life cycle. The levels of phospho-STAT-5 are significantly increased in HPV positive cells, and inhibition of STAT-5 phosphorylation by the drug pimozide suppresses HPV differentiation-dependent genome amplification and late gene expression. These findings indicate that STAT-5 plays an important role for both HPV genome amplification and for late gene expression.
Salmonella enterica serotype Typhi, the causative agent of typhoid fever, can establish a chronic carriage state in the biliary tract of infected individuals, resulting in persistent reservoirs of infection within a community. The interaction between the host and pathogen in this carriage state is not well understood, and there is no reliable diagnostic assay to identify asymptomatic S. Typhi carriage. A study used in vivo-induced antigen technology (IVIAT) to identify potential biomarkers unique to carriers and identified 13 immunoreactive antigens, including YncE, an uncharacterized protein with an ATP-binding motif. Further evaluation of YncE and other antigens could lead to improved diagnostic assays to identify asymptomatic S. Typhi carriers, which is critical for the long-term control of enteric fever. S. Typhi and S. Paratyphi A, human-restricted pathogens, cause enteric fever, affecting millions and leading to 200,000 deaths annually. Chronic carriers, who may act as reservoirs and introduce infection to susceptible individuals and new communities, are estimated to complicate 1-3% of acute infections. Currently, there is no reliable diagnostic assay to identify asymptomatic S. Typhi and S. Paratyphi A carriage. The development and persistence of the carrier state may facilitate the development of improved diagnostic assays and therapeutic approaches for S. Typhi carriage.
A new epigenetic phenomenon of trans-reactivation has been discovered, where non-functional alleles of the white gene, unable to produce a coding transcript, can reactivate in trans the expression of a wild type copy of the same gene silenced by heterochromatin. This phenomenon is heritable, relies on the presence of homologous RNAs, and is affected by mutations in genes involved in post-transcriptional gene silencing. The researchers propose a new level of gene expression control mediated by homologous RNA molecules in the context of heterochromatic genes. This discovery builds on the understanding of eukaryotic genomes' complexity, where at least 90% of the analyzed eukaryote genome is transcribed in different cell types, generating an enormous number of non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs). These RNAs are essential to finely control gene expression and genomic plasticity and are part of epigenetic regulatory networks with striking evolutionary conservation. Dynamic changes in chromatin function are frequently transacted by nuclear RNA signaling pathways, involving RNAs that 'rewrite' the transcriptional state of an allele, in processes that apparently escape classic Mendel's laws of genetic inheritance. These unusual epigenetic phenomena involve the activity of ncRNAs that 'rewrite' the transcriptional state of an allele, in processes that apparently escape classic Mendel's laws of genetic inheritance.
Hematophagous mosquitos and ticks avoid host hemostatic system through the expression of enzyme inhibitors that target proteolytic reactions of the coagulation and complement cascades. Boophilin, a 2-Kunitz multi-functional inhibitor found in ticks' midgut, inhibits thrombin, elastase, and kallikrein. It has been expressed in HEK293 cells and purified to homogeneity, and it behaves as a classical non-competitive inhibitor of thrombin with respect to small chromogenic substrates. Boophilin inhibits platelet aggregation, fibrin formation, and clot-bound thrombin in vitro, and it also prevents FIX activation and inhibits kallikrein activity and the reciprocal activation. Additionally, Boophilin abrogates cathepsin G- and plasmin-induced platelet aggregation and partially affects elastase-mediated cleavage of TFPI. In vivo, Boophilin inhibits carotid artery occlusion and promotes bleeding. Through inhibition of several enzymes involved in proteolytic cascades and cell activation, Boophilin plays a major role in keeping the midgut microenvironment at low hemostatic and inflammatory tonus, which allows ticks to successfully digest a blood meal which is critical for metabolism and egg development. Boophilin is the first tick midgut FXIa anticoagulant also found to inhibit thrombosis. Protease inhibitors have been identified in the midgut of blood-sucking animals, including Ornithodorus moubatta, Haemaphysalis longicornis, Triatoma brasiliensis, Dipetalogaster maxima, and Rhodnius prolixus, as well as in Triatoma infestans and Rhipicephalus hemaphysaloides. These inhibitors display unique specificity and high-affinity binding for coagulation factors or components of the complement cascade and affect immune cells, endothelial cells, and platelet functions.
The mucosa of the intestinal tract is a finely tuned system where tissue structure strongly influences and is influenced by its function as both an absorptive surface and a defensive barrier. Inflammation is a key factor in the pathogenesis of many gastrointestinal diseases and is controlled by morphogenic pathways. The Spatially Explicit General-purpose Model of Enteric Tissue (SEGMEnT) is a computational model developed to dynamically represent existing knowledge of the behavior of enteric epithelial tissue as influenced by inflammation. SEGMEnT provides insight into clinically relevant cellular-molecular mechanisms, such as the protective role of enterocyte sloughing in enteric ischemia-reperfusion and chronic low level inflammation as a driver for colonic metaplasia. SEGMEnT can serve as an integrating platform for the study of inflammation in gastrointestinal disease.The structure-function relationship of the gut mucosa is crucial in the diagnosis of intestinal disease and is maintained by morphogenesis pathways subject to control modules that balance complex interplays of functional objectives. Inflammatory pathways are among the most clinically significant, playing an important role in a host of intestinal diseases. SEGMEnT is an agent-based computational model that simulates the cellular and molecular interactions that maintain and modify the enteric mucosal architecture, providing a platform for instantiating conceptual models representing baseline, healthy systems, and exploring different disease trajectories. SEGMEnT models the spatial dynamics of the crypt-villus tissue architecture, incorporating the effect of inflammation on those morphogenic processes.SEGMEnT has been used to investigate potentially pathogenic conditions such as local tissue injury resulting in a wound, the response to enteric ischemia-reperfusion, and chronic conditions that result in a persistent alteration of the homeostatic set-point of the crypt-villus architecture. SEGMEnT is a dynamic knowledge representation of a minimally sufficient set of components, mechanisms, and interactions for the maintenance of enteric mucosal architecture and the effect of inflammation, with the eventual goal of serving as a community resource. Integral to the use of computational models is their ability to replicate baseline, healthy behavior, and SEGMEnT is able to produce the appropriate cell distributions and spatial morphogen gradients leading to homeostasis.
The traditional vector control approaches, such as source reduction and insecticide spraying, have limited effect on reducing Aedes aegypti population, the primary vector for dengue, chikungunya, Zika, and yellow fever viruses. A promising tool to mitigate arbovirus transmission is the endosymbiont Wolbachia, which has been deployed worldwide to reduce the spread of these diseases. The wMelBr strain of Wolbachia has a high maternal transmission rate and cytoplasmic incompatibility, making it a suitable candidate for population replacement. However, the invasion of Wolbachia into natural populations is influenced by various factors, including insecticide resistance. In a study conducted in Tubiacanga, Rio de Janeiro, the wMelBr strain was released for 20 consecutive weeks, but the frequency of Wolbachia-positive Ae. aegypti mosquitoes plateaued around 40% and dropped as releases stopped. Investigation revealed that the overuse of insecticides by householders and the release of pyrethroid-resistant genotypes in the lab colony jeopardized the Wolbachia invasion. To overcome this, a new strain (wMelRio) was produced by backcrossing wMelBr females with males from the field to introduce mostly pyrethroid resistance alleles. This new strain increased mosquito survival but produced relevant negative effects on Ae. aegypti fecundity traits, reducing egg clutch size and egg hatch. Despite the cost on fitness, wMelRio successfully established where wMelBr failed, highlighting the importance of matching the local population genetics, especially insecticide resistance background, to achieve invasion. Local householders' support was consistently high, reaching 90% backing on the second release (wMelRio strain). The drought summer and harsh temperature recorded did not affect the expression of maternal transmission of wMel on a Brazilian background. Therefore, Wolbachia deployment should match the insecticide resistance profile of the wild population to achieve invasion. Considering pyrethroid-resistance is a widely distributed phenotype in natural Ae. aegypti populations, future Wolbachia deployments must pay special attention to maintaining insecticide resistance in lab colonies for releases.
In a study on poxviruses, researchers analyzed the role of the B1 protein kinase in inactivating the cellular antiviral factor BAF and orchestrating other pathways. They used experimental evolution of a B1 deletion virus to identify novel pathways involving B1. After several passages, they observed a robust increase in viral titer of the adapted virus. They found that mutations correlating with a loss of function of the vaccinia B12 pseudokinase provided a striking fitness enhancement to this virus. They also discovered that B12 possesses a potent inhibitory activity that can be masked by the presence of the B1 kinase. Further investigation revealed that B12 primarily localizes to the nucleus and may function in part by enhancing antiviral activity of BAF. The study presents novel evidence of a paralogous kinase-pseudokinase pair that can exhibit a unique epistatic relationship in a virus, serving to enhance B1 conservation during poxvirus evolution and to orchestrate nuclear events during infection. This research contributes to the understanding of how protein kinases are regulated and what evolutionary mechanisms may have driven their conservation in all kingdoms of life as well as viruses.
The article discusses the behavior of amphiphilic peptides, which have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic components, and their propensity to form alpha-helices in hydrophobic/hydrophilic interfaces (HHI). The authors use molecular dynamics simulations to study the folding and aggregation behavior of two synthetic peptides, LKKLLKLLKKLLKL (LK) and EAALAEALAEALAE (EALA), and how they respond to different environmental conditions. The study finds that both peptides display a high degree of conformational flexibility in solution, and their behavior is influenced by factors such as pH, salts, and the presence of interfaces. The authors also highlight the importance of studying the behavior of these peptides at low concentrations, as they may be the toxic species responsible for neurodegenerative diseases.In the context of amyloid-fibril forming peptides, the amphiphilic character of these proteins plays a crucial role in their aggregation and membrane activity. These peptides can interact with biomembrane surfaces, and in some cases, can penetrate and rupture membranes. This aspect links them to cell-penetrating peptides (CPPs), which are used for the targeted delivery of therapeutics. The folding and aggregation equilibria of these systems are complex and sensitive to external factors. In particular, folding patterns are diverse, and transitions between states are coupled to changes in peptide/protein concentration, the presence of initial aggregates, and the presence of membranes, interfaces, or surfaces.The authors use classical atomistic molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the environment-dependent folding equilibrium of the two model peptide systems. They find that both systems display a highly dynamic conformational behavior, with a sizeable amount of intrinsic disorder in solution and an ability to form alpha-helices under certain conditions. These synthetic peptides share the key features of their conformational behavior with natural systems such as alpha-synuclein. The study concludes that the chosen model peptides are good systems to analyze the contribution of different interactions and driving forces to the coupled equilibria of folding, aggregation, and partitioning at hydrophobic/hydrophilic interfaces, and to characterize typical microscopic intermediates and pathways. The study highlights the importance of understanding the behavior of these amphiphilic peptides in HHI, as they play a crucial role in biomedically important processes, such as amyloid-fibril formation, which is responsible for many human disorders, including severe neurodegenerative diseases.
Human herpesvirus 6A (HHV-6A) and 6B (HHV-6B) are ubiquitous betaherpesviruses that infect humans in the first years of life and establish latency in various cell types. Both viruses can integrate their genomes into telomeres of host chromosomes in latently infected cells. The molecular mechanism of viral integration is not well understood, but the viruses harbor arrays of telomeric repeats (TMR) that are identical to human telomere sequences at the ends of their genomes. A study was conducted to determine if the TMR are involved in virus integration. The study found that deletion of both pTMR and impTMR in the HHV-6A genome did not affect the replication of the virus, but integration was severely impaired in the absence of the TMR and the virus genome was lost rapidly. The pTMR play the major role in HHV-6A integration, while the impTMR only make a minor contribution. The data shows that the HHV-6A TMR are dispensable for virus replication, but are crucial for integration and maintenance of the virus genome in latently infected cells. HHV-6A and HHV-6B primarily infect during early childhood, with HHV-6B being the most common causative agent of the febrile illness roseola infantum and HHV-6A being associated with lymphoproliferative disorders. Both viruses establish latency and can integrate into the telomere region of host chromosomes in latently infected cells. Inherited chromosomally integrated HHV-6 (iciHHV-6) is present in about 1% of the human population, and can reactivate from latently infected cells, causing various diseases. The underlying molecular mechanism of HHV-6 integration remains unknown.
Poxviruses have a unique method of producing infectious particles, unlike most enveloped viruses. Instead of budding through cellular compartments to acquire their lipid membrane, poxviruses generate immature particles from crescent-shaped precursors. A study of the vaccinia virus, a member of the Poxviridae family, has revealed the 2.6 Å crystal structure of D13, a key structural component of the outer scaffold of viral crescents. D13 forms trimers with a double-barrel organization, consisting of two jellyrolls and a head domain. The head domain is unrelated to any previously known folds and is inserted in the J2DE loop. The trimeric assembly of D13 is stabilized by interactions between J1 and J2, and an N-terminal arm that forms an amphipathic helix. Structural comparison reveals close similarity between D13 and capsid proteins of several large DNA viruses, including the major capsid protein VP54 of PBCV-1, a virus of the Phycodnaviridae family that infects unicellular green algae. This finding supports the notion that the two jellyrolls result from a duplication event that predates the divergence of the clades currently observed for all NCLDV members. Overall, the first committed step of poxvirus morphogenesis utilizes an ancestral lipid-remodeling strategy common to icosahedral DNA viruses infecting all kingdoms of life. D13 is the target of rifampicin, which reversibly blocks morphogenesis before the immature virion stage and results in the relocation of D13 into cytoplasmic inclusion bodies. Despite the eradication of smallpox by vaccination, poxviruses remain a concern for human health.
The study observes the role of model organisms in understanding the auxin biosynthesis in plants and its applicability to distant relatives. The researchers focus on Arabidopsis and Brachypodium, two plant species with different root development mechanisms. In Arabidopsis, auxin biosynthesis via IPA is essential for root development, while in Brachypodium, ethylene inhibits the rate-limiting step of auxin biosynthesis in an IPA-dependent manner to confer auxin levels that are sub-optimal for root cell elongation. The study reveals a delicate homeostasis of local auxin and ethylene activity to control cell elongation in Brachypodium roots, suggesting alternative wiring of auxin-ethylene crosstalk as compared to Arabidopsis. This research highlights the importance of understanding the molecular genetic control of root growth and branching in crops to increase root system plasticity with respect to biotic and abiotic stresses.
The rate at which genes diverge in expression in species of the budding yeast is correlated with the organization of their promoter nucleosomes. Genes lacking a nucleosome-free region (OPN) vary widely between the species, while the expression of those containing NFR (DPN) remains largely conserved. To examine if early evolutionary dynamics contributes to this difference in divergence, researchers artificially selected for high expression of GFP–fused proteins. Surprisingly, selection was equally successful for OPN and DPN genes, but they adapted by distinct mechanisms. DPN-selected strains duplicated large genomic regions, while OPN-selected strains favored trans mutations not involving duplications. When selection was removed, DPN genes reverted rapidly to wild-type expression levels, consistent with their lower diversity between species. These results suggest that promoter organization constrains the early evolutionary dynamics and biases the path of long-term evolution. This demonstrates the link between the plasticity of biological traits on multiple time scales and the role of gene expression in generating phenotypic diversity, which is linked to the organization of promoter nucleosomes in yeast. The two classes of genes, OPN and DPN, differ in the way they respond to identical selection forces. Artificial selection for high expression of GFP-fused proteins resulted in duplication of large genomic regions for DPN genes and trans mutations not involving duplications for OPN genes. The findings suggest that promoter organization impacts on the early evolutionary dynamics and biases the path of long-term evolution.
The human T-lymphotropic virus type 1 (HTLV-1) is the causative agent of adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATL), a malignancy of CD4+ T cells. The HTLV-1 transactivator/oncoprotein, Tax, is thought to play a key role in ATL development. Tax is a potent activator of HTLV-1 transcription and NF-κB, and can activate the anaphase promoting complex/cyclosome (APC/C), leading to premature poly-ubiquitination and degradation of mitotic regulators including cyclin B and Skp2. This results in p21-/27-mediated cellular senescence, which constitutes a checkpoint against IKK/NF-κB hyper-activation. This senescence can be attenuated by mutations in Tax that reduce IKK/NF-κB activation and prevented by blocking NF-κB using a degradation-resistant mutant of I-κBα. The HTLV-1 anti-sense protein, HBZ, can mitigate Tax-induced senescence by inhibiting NF-κB, allowing HTLV-1-infected cells to proliferate and persist. In HTLV-1-transformed T cells, the loss of p27 expression and cytoplasmic localization of p21 has been observed, indicating inactivation of the senescence checkpoint and facilitating constitutive NF-κB activation and leukemia development.
The frontal lobes are responsible for decision-making and executive control, but current models of frontal executive function do not fully explain human decision-making in naturalistic situations. A new computational model proposes that the human frontal function monitors up to three or four concurrent behavioral strategies and infers online their ability to predict action outcomes. When one strategy appears more reliable than unreliable, it is chosen to guide the selection and learning of actions that maximize rewards. Otherwise, a new behavioral strategy is formed and probed. This model supports a view of human frontal function that integrates reasoning, learning, and creative abilities in the service of decision-making and adaptive behavior. The ability to adapt to uncertain, changing, and open-ended environments is a hallmark of human intelligence, and this model helps to clarify how the frontal executive function controls an expanding repertoire of behavioral strategies and manages an expanding collection of behavioral strategies for driving action.
The field of medical systems biology aims to improve understanding of molecular mechanisms that drive disease progression and translate this knowledge into therapies. A new modeling approach, ADAPT, analyzes the long-term effects of a pharmacological intervention by introducing a concept of time-dependent evolution of model parameters to study the dynamics of molecular adaptations. This approach has been employed to identify metabolic adaptations induced upon pharmacological activation of the liver X receptor (LXR), a potential drug target to treat or prevent atherosclerosis. The ADAPT modeling and computational analysis of LXR activation provided insights into the cascade of adaptations, specifically the counter-intuitive reduction in hepatic capacity to clear cholesterol upon prolonged treatment. This prediction was confirmed experimentally. The ADAPT approach can also be used to design new target interventions to prevent unwanted side effects. The approach is useful for studying biological systems from which the network topology is relatively well known, making it applicable to the study of metabolic pathways in relation to progressive diseases such as Type 2 Diabetes and cardiovascular disease.
The spinocerebellar and spino-reticulocerebellar systems are critical for coordinating multi-segmented limbs and bodies by providing useful recombinations of sensory and motor signals to the cerebellum. These inputs are necessary for the cerebellum to establish piecewise-linear approximations of non-linear functions. The granule cells (GrCs) in the cerebellar cortex, which receive input from mossy fibers (MFs), have a distinct feature of a marked difference between the resting membrane potential and the threshold potential for spike firing. The molecular layer interneurons, innervated by the parallel fibers and inhibiting the Purkinje cells (PCs), allow the weights between PFs and PCs to become negative. The PCs, which constitute the only output from the cerebellar cortex, are able to modulate their spontaneous firing frequency, creating a continuous output signal. The GrCs are designed to be tonically inhibited, mostly due to alpha-6-containing GABA (A) receptors, and even when the alpha-6 subunit is knocked-out, GrCs seem to compensate for this loss by increasing the expression of potassium conductances. The traditional fast inhibitory response is gradually lost as the tonic component of the GrC inhibition develops. GrC responding with burst responses to skin stimulation show little sign of Golgi cell inhibition, but Golgi cells can still contribute to cerebellar processing by regulating the difference between the resting membrane potential and spike firing threshold of the GrCs by modulating the level of tonic inhibition. At least for the cerebellar regions involved in limb control, MFs carrying functionally equivalent inputs preferably target the same set of GrCs. The GrC layer contains a highly redundant representation of MF inputs, which is needed to average out the noise and recode the incoming MF signals. The role of the Golgi cell to GrC tonic inhibition, potentially supplemented by other sources of GABA input, is to allow the GrC responses within a redundant population to become sufficiently varied. A population of redundant GrCs, which sample functionally equivalent MF input and differ with respect to the separation between the resting and the spike firing threshold, can be used to combine the inputs from these GrCs into a piecewise-linear (PL) approximation of an arbitrary smooth function, with the number of GrCs directly related to the approximation error.
The application of genomics and Next Generation sequencing has led to the identification of a new class of cellular functional molecules, small RNAs, with microRNAs (miRNAs) being demonstrated to have a determinative influence on various cellular processes. Host/vector/pathogen encoded miRNAs have been found to impact eventual pathogenesis, with vector encoded miRNAs being investigated for their role in disease transmission and pathogen development. A study was conducted to evaluate the role of host miRNAs upon CHIKV infection in Aedes albopictus. The study identified 88 and 79 known miRNAs in uninfected and CHIKV infected Ae. albopictus Singh's cell line respectively, as well as nine novel miRNAs. Comparison of the two libraries revealed differential expression of 77 common miRNAs between them. CHIKV infection specifically altered the miRNA profile of a specific set of eight miRNAs. This investigation provides an insight about cellular modification by miRNAs during CHIKV infection and the results provide leads for identifying potential candidates for vector based antiviral strategies.Vector borne diseases like malaria, dengue, chikungunya are a major burden to the economy of countries in the tropical and sub-tropical regions. Currently, no vaccines are available for any of the above mentioned infections and vector control with intense public awareness is the only effective measure for disease control. Understanding vector-pathogen dynamics is important for effective control strategies, with RNA interference being the most important phenomena used by insects as the first line of defense against microbial invaders. Infection of mosquitoes by virus results in generation of different kind of small RNA populations of viral origin, as well as modulation of host miRNAs.The study focused on identifying mosquito host miRNAs that may be impacted during chikungunya infection. Deep sequencing of small RNA population in Aedes albopictus Singh's cell line upon chikungunya virus infection was performed, and several Aedes known and novel miRNAs were identified and profiled. In a separate study, microRNAs in Anopheles stephensi mosquitoes were identified and profiled upon Plasmodium infection. During the course of analysis, it was recognized that there were miRNAs common between Aedes and Anopheles; however, there was discrete regulation of some of the common miRNAs upon infection by CHIKV and Plasmodium.In conclusion, the study described Ae. Albopictus miRNAs and their regulation upon CHIKV infection, as well as the repertoire of common and distinct host miRNAs regulated during Plasmodium and CHIKV infections in their respective hosts. Understanding the role of these miRNAs may be playing during pathogen infection in mosquitoes will aid in the development of effective control strategies for vector-borne diseases.
Cystic echinococcosis (CE) is a significant parasitic infection in humans and livestock, causing considerable medical and economic problems in many developing countries, including Iran. However, the full socioeconomic impact of CE is not well understood in most endemic countries. A study was conducted to determine the monetary burden of CE in Iran using epidemiological and economic data. The study found that the mean number of surgical CE cases per year for 2000-2009 was 1,295, with an estimated 635,232 (95% CI 149,466-1,120,998) asymptomatic individuals living in the country. The overall annual cost of CE in Iran was estimated at US$232.3 million (95% CI US$103.1-397.8 million), including both direct and indirect costs. The cost associated with human CE was estimated at US$93.39 million (95% CI US$6.1-222.7 million), and the annual cost associated with CE in livestock was estimated at US$132 million (95% CI US$61.8-246.5 million). The cost per surgical human case was estimated at US$1,539. CE has a considerable economic impact on Iran, with the cost of the disease approximated at 0.03% of the country's gross domestic product. Establishment of a CE surveillance system and implementation of a control program are necessary to reduce the economic burden of CE on the country. Cost-benefit analysis of different control programs is recommended, incorporating present knowledge of the economic losses due to CE in Iran.
Mouse polyomavirus (MPyV) is a DNA virus that infects mouse cells, causes lytic infection, and transforms rat cells in culture. It has a circular double-stranded DNA genome and a life cycle divided into early and late phases.
