During the early phase, both early-strand and late-strand transcripts are expressed, but early-strand transcripts are preferentially accumulated and spliced into mRNAs for Large, middle, and small tumor antigens. These early gene products induce host cell S phase entry and virus utilizes host factors for viral DNA replication. At late times in infection, late-strand RNAs accumulate rapidly and are alternatively spliced to generate mRNAs for the viral capsid proteins VP1, VP2, and VP3. MPyV Large T antigen plays multiple roles during infection, including altering host protein pathways to promote virus production, blocking the interferon antiviral response, recruiting host DNA replication factors to the viral origin, acting as a helicase for viral DNA replication, and modulating late gene transcription. MPyV middle T antigen is a highly oncogenic protein necessary for viral transformation of cells in culture and functions as a scaffold to activate signal transduction pathways. MPyV small t antigen functions primarily by binding protein phosphatase 2A.Deep sequencing was used to follow MPyV infection of mouse NIH3T6 cells at various times after infection and analyze both the viral and cellular transcriptomes. The study illustrated the transcriptional profile of the early-to-late switch with both early-strand and late-strand RNAs being transcribed at all time points. RNA editing of viral transcripts was demonstrated at late times in infection. By late times in infection, 359 host genes were seen to be significantly upregulated and 857 were downregulated. Gene ontology analysis indicated that transcripts involved in translation, metabolism, RNA processing, DNA methylation, and protein turnover were upregulated while transcripts involved in extracellular adhesion, cytoskeleton, zinc finger binding, SH3 domain, and GTPase activation were downregulated. Additionally, the levels of a number of long noncoding RNAs were altered, including the long noncoding RNA MALAT1, which is involved in splicing speckles and used as a marker in many late-stage cancers, was noticeably downregulated. These results provide new insights into the MPyV life cycle and its effects on host cell growth and metabolism.
"The number of participants in marathons has significantly increased over the past four decades, with a considerable percentage of them experiencing severe carbohydrate depletion, known as ""hitting the wall,"" and thousands dropping out before finishing. Traditional analyses have suggested that human glycogen reserves are insufficient to fuel a marathon, making ""hitting the wall"" inevitable, or have implied that maximal glycogen loading is required to complete a marathon without experiencing this issue. However, a new computational study demonstrates that the energetic constraints on endurance runners are more subtle, depending on muscle mass distribution, liver and muscle glycogen densities, and running speed. By estimating the distance at which runners will exhaust their glycogen stores as a function of running intensity, this analysis provides a basis for guidelines to ensure the safety and optimize the performance of endurance runners.In addition to these static considerations, there are also dynamic factors that influence energy management in marathon running, which some athletes and advisors might overlook. Endurance runners primarily focus on two questions: the amount of carbohydrate required for a given distance and how to avoid depleting carbohydrate reserves before completing the race. By synthesizing human physiologic data collected over several decades, the present work derives a modeling framework for providing personalized answers to these questions, taking into account aerobic capacity, relative exertion, and glycogen reservoir size under typical and maximally loaded conditions.The study further reveals that functional dependencies of the distance required to run glycogen stores to depletion, the fastest pace at which a given distance can be run without exhausting glycogen stores, and a quantitative approach to establishing an effective midrace fueling strategy. By accounting for individual physiologic variation and population distribution of aerobic capacities, the model provides a principled basis for marathon qualifying standards such as those used in the Boston Marathon. Considering both the static and dynamic factors, the study offers a comprehensive approach to understanding energy management in marathon running and ensuring optimal performance."
Toxoplasma gondii is a globally widespread intracellular parasite that can infect a variety of warm-blooded animals, and is the second leading cause of foodborne illness in terms of cost and quality-adjusted life years lost in the US. While most infections result in asymptomatic lifelong infection in immunocompetent individuals, immunocompromised individuals and congenital infections can lead to severe disease or even death. The severity of disease is influenced by both host genetic background and the genotype of the infecting strain. In Europe and North America, the majority of strains belong to one of three clonal lineages (Type I, II, or III), but in South America, a greater variety of strains are found. These strains differ in phenotypes such as virulence, persistence, and oral infectivity, and it is hypothesized that the genotype of the parasite strain plays a major role in the outcome of toxoplasmosis in patients. A study was conducted to determine if non-canonical Toxoplasma strains have unique interactions with the host cell by infecting murine macrophages with 29 different Toxoplasma strains and using RNA-sequencing to determine host and parasite transcriptomes. The study found large differences between strains in the expression level of known parasite effectors, large chromosomal structural variation in some strains, and novel strain-specifically regulated host pathways, including the regulation of the type I interferon response by some atypical strains. These findings suggest that the genotype of the parasite strain plays a significant role in the outcome of toxoplasmosis and provide insight into the host response to a large variety of Toxoplasma strains.
Recombination in enteroviruses is an important evolutionary mechanism that allows for the acquisition of extensive novel sequences and has been key to the emergence of neuropathogenic poliovirus variants. However, the recombination process is still not well understood. A study used a reverse genetic approach to investigate heterologous recombination and found that chimeric intertypic polioviruses with duplicated sequences at the recombination junction could be isolated, and these imprecise junctions yielded progeny with increased fitness after serial passage. Mutations or inhibitors that altered polymerase fidelity or the coalescence of replication complexes markedly altered the yield of recombinants. The study proposed that extant recombinants result from a biphasic process in which an initial recombination event is followed by a process of resolution, deleting extraneous sequences and optimizing viral fitness. This process has implications for the wider understanding of 'evolution by duplication' in positive-strand RNA viruses. Genetic variation in RNA viruses has important consequences for viral pathogenesis, host tropism, and evolution, and can result from misincorporation of nucleotides, recombination/reassortment, or the absence of proofreading by viral RNA-dependent RNA-polymerases. The human enteroviruses (HEV) are particularly well studied as they contain important pathogens responsible for various diseases. The HEV genome can be considered as modular, with recombination between the functional entities that drive translation and replication. Recombination within the P1 region is rarely observed, while different serotypes exhibit distinct temporal and geographic kinetics in the appearance of predominant recombinant forms. The majority of characterized HEV recombinants are intraspecies, but interspecies recombination may have occurred in ancestral enteroviruses. Despite the importance of recombination as an evolutionary process in enteroviruses, the molecular mechanism involved has received little attention. The favored replicative mechanism involves template-switching of the viral RdRp during negative strand RNA synthesis, but an alternative process involving the replication-independent joining of RNA molecules has also been described. Studies of the viable recombinant progeny from cells co-infected with enteroviruses are confounded by the relatively low frequency of recombinants and the high levels of parental viruses generally produced. To overcome these limitations, an in vitro reverse genetic system was developed to enable the recovery of recombinants alone from dually transfected cells in culture. This system provides important insights into the molecular mechanism of recombination in positive strand RNA viruses and suggests a means by which 'evolution by duplication' may occur.
In the treatment of metabolic diseases, beiging of white adipose tissue (WAT) is a promising target through norepinephrine (NE) mediated signaling pathways. While NE clearance mechanisms have been reported via SLC6A2 on sympathetic neurons or proinflammatory macrophages in ATs, the low catecholamine clearance capacity of SLC6A2 may limit its cleaning efficiency. A study has found that mouse organic cation transporter 3 (Oct3; Slc22a3) is highly expressed in WAT and displays the greatest uptake rate of NE as a selective non-neural route of NE clearance in white adipocytes. Adipocytes express high levels of NE degradation enzymes Maoa, Maob, and Comt, providing the molecular basis on NE clearance by adipocytes together with its reuptake transporter Oct3. After NE administration, ablation of Oct3 induces higher body temperature, thermogenesis, and lipolysis compared with littermate controls. After prolonged cold challenge, inguinal WAT (ingWAT) in adipose-specific Oct3-deficient mice shows much stronger browning characteristics and significantly elevated expression of thermogenic and mitochondrial biogenesis genes than in littermate controls, and this response involves enhanced β-AR/PKA/CREB pathway activation. Glycolytic genes are reprogrammed to significantly higher levels to compensate for the loss of ATP production in Oct3 KO adipocytes, indicating the fundamental role of glucose metabolism during beiging. Inhibition of β-AR largely abolishes the higher lipolytic and thermogenic activities in Oct3-deficient ingWAT, indicating the NE overload in the vicinity of adipocytes in Oct3 KO adipocytes. Additionally, reduced functional alleles in human OCT3 are also identified to be associated with increased basal metabolic rate. Overall, this study demonstrates that Oct3 governs β-AR activity as a NE recycling transporter in white adipocytes, offering potential therapeutic applications for metabolic disorders.
"HP1 proteins, which are crucial for heterochromatin-mediated silencing and chromosome structure in various eukaryotes, contain two primary domains: the chromo-domain (CD) and the chromoshadow-domain (CSD). The CD binds histone H3 tails methylated on lysine 9, while the CSD is responsible for dimerization and interaction with many molecular partners. HP1 proteins have been found on both active and inactive genes, suggesting they are not simply ""chromatin condensers"" but rather regulators of enzymatic activities involved in transcription initiation or elongation. A study found that HP1 proteins can bind histone H3 independently of the well-characterized association of the CD with methylated K9. Specifically, the CSD interacts with a region of histone H3 located at the border of the globular domain. This region is also contacted by the catalytic subunits of the human SWI/SNF complex, and in vitro efficient SWI/SNF remodeling requires this contact and is inhibited in the presence of HP1 proteins. The antagonism between SWI/SNF and HP1 proteins is also observed in vivo on a series of interferon-regulated genes. SWI/SNF activity favors loading of HP1 proteins to chromatin both in vivo and in vitro."
The significance of non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) has increased considerably in the last decade, particularly with the discovery of endogenously encoded microRNAs (miRNAs). RNA structure plays a crucial role in its functionality, and the self-containment property of RNA refers to its tendency to maintain the same optimal secondary structure regardless of its surrounding nucleotide context. The study found that miRNAs exhibit high self-containment, indicating structural invariance during biogenesis, and are notably self-contained even when embedded in a larger sequence. This robustness during biogenesis is a hallmark of the broader phenomenon of modular composability, where biopolymers are generated through the combinatorial composition of structural motifs. The study concludes that high self-containment is an intrinsic property of certain RNA sequences, indicating structural robustness and potential for a modular building block in larger structures.
In the study of plant disease resistance to necrotrophic fungal pathogens, researchers have identified four transcription factors (TFs) in Arabidopsis that limit pathogen spread and are necessary for resistance to Botrytis cinerea and Plectosphaerella cucumerina. Mutants defective in these TFs displayed increased disease susceptibility and a common transcriptional signature of 77 up-regulated genes. These genes encode peptides with a secretion signal, named PROVIR (for provirulence) factors, which are important for disease susceptibility of the host to fungal necrotrophs. The TFs and PROVIRs identified in this work represent novel genetic determinants for plant disease susceptibility to necrotrophic fungal pathogens.Plants are constantly exposed to microbial pathogens, but only a few are capable of colonizing a specific host, suggesting the existence of efficient recognition mechanisms to activate plant defenses. Two types of microbial pathogens can be distinguished based on their lifestyles: necrotrophic and biotrophic pathogens. Both types of pathogens elicit distinct host immune responses, and the timing and efficiency in activating various basal defense mechanisms is thought to underlie differences in host susceptibility to necrotrophic pathogens.The study of PAMP-triggered necrotrophic immunity is largely derived from Botrytis cinerea, one of the most important fungal plant pathogens. The fungal cell wall component chitin and its constituent oligosaccharides are fungal PAMPs that activate defense responses. Polygalacturonase (PG) is another fungal component essential for virulence and is detected by the plant as a PAMP, activating host defense responses. OGs of a certain length can function as DAMPs that activate plant immunity.Resistance and susceptibility to necrotrophs is a genetically complex process involving the coordinated action of a wide range of hormones and secondary metabolites. Coordinated and timely regulation of genes in immune response pathways is central to effective plant defense. Transcription factors that affect immune responses towards necrotrophic fungal pathogens have been described, and many are involved in camalexin biosynthesis, JA-related genes, and cell wall composition.In summary, the study of plant disease resistance to necrotrophic fungal pathogens has identified four TFs in Arabidopsis that limit pathogen spread and are necessary for resistance to Botrytis cinerea and Plectosphaerella cucumerina. The TFs and PROVIRs identified in this work represent novel genetic determinants for plant disease susceptibility to necrotrophic fungal pathogens. The timing and efficiency in activating various basal defense mechanisms is thought to underlie differences in host susceptibility to necrotrophic pathogens.
In the endometrium, a receptive state is required for successful embryo implantation, and poor uterine receptivity can result in recurrent pregnancy loss or failures in in vitro fertilization cycles. A study has discovered that the transcription factor Forkhead Box O1 (FOXO1) is a vital regulator of endometrial receptivity in vivo. Foxo1 ablation in mice using the progesterone receptor Cre (PgrCre) mouse model resulted in infertility due to altered epithelial cell polarity and apoptosis, preventing the embryo from penetrating the luminal epithelium. Additionally, during the window of receptivity (WOR), FOXO1 regulates gene expression for transcripts involved in cell invasion, molecular transport, apoptosis, β-catenin signaling pathway, and PGR signaling. FOXO1 and PGR signaling are interrelated, and their reciprocal expression is critical for embryo implantation. FOXO1 is localized in the nucleus of the luminal and glandular epithelium of the endometrium during the WOR in humans and mice and in the cytoplasm of the murine decidua as pregnancy processes. FOXO1 is involved in regulating cell cycle, apoptosis, and metabolic flux, and its expression is required for decidualization in human endometrial stromal cells in tissue culture settings. The conditional ablation of Foxo1 in the mouse uterus results in infertility due to disrupted implantation of the blastocyst, and several important pathways involved in the fetal-maternal crosstalk are regulated by FOXO1, including those that allow the removal of the epithelial barrier for trophoblastic invasion.
A study was conducted to map the spatial variation of dengue cases in Bangladesh, a country where dengue is endemic and cases are under-reported. The researchers developed a negative binomial generalized linear mixed effect model that accounted for zero-inflation, spatial, and temporal random effects. The model was fitted to district-level monthly reported dengue cases over the period 2000 to 2009. The study found that temperature and its interaction with diurnal temperature range, as well as rainfall, were significantly associated with dengue incidence. The model estimated that 92% of annual dengue cases occurred between August and September. Despite this, less than half of the affected districts reported cases as observed from the surveillance data. The majority of cases were identified in the capital Dhaka, which is located in the middle of the country. The study highlights the importance of considering under-reporting and incorporating climatic and demographic factors in disease mapping. The resulting maps can help in efficiently distributing vector control interventions to areas of highest need at the appropriate time.
"When mammals, including rats and mice, are introduced into a novel environment, they establish preferred places within it. Rats have a distinct home base, characterized by the highest frequency of visits, longest cumulative dwell time, and low outbound trajectory speed with high inbound speed. Mice, on the other hand, have a lower occurrence of home base establishment during forced exploration of a relatively featureless environment. However, when exposed to a large open field arena, mice, especially those injected with saline, establish preferred places called ""knots,"" where they perform ""knot-scribbling,"" tracing a tortuous path full of twists, turns, and bends. These knots are typically not associated with physical objects or nesting material, but are enhanced by stress and arousal. The establishment of knots could function as a way to obtain an overview of the entire environment, allowing re-calibration of the mouse's locale map and compass directions. Intact mice establish knots during exploratory behavior, regardless of saline injection, indicating that knots are natural ethological building blocks of mouse exploration."
Invasive fungal infections (IFIs) cause a significant number of deaths worldwide, with Candida albicans, Cryptococcus neoformans, and Aspergillus fumigatus being the major human fungal pathogens. The development of new antifungal drugs is challenging due to the high evolutionary conservation between fungi and man, resulting in a limited number of druggable nodes. A study identified NGx04, an ergoline compound, with selectivity over mammalian cells and activity against C. neoformans. High-resolution chemogenomics revealed that the lipid transfer protein Sec14p is the target of NGx04, with compound-resistant mutations defining compound-target interactions in the substrate binding pocket of the protein. Sec14p is essential for the pathogenicity of fungi such as C. neoformans, making it an attractive antifungal target. NGx04 inhibits the growth of C. neoformans, and NGx04-related compounds have fungicidal activity against a fluconazole resistant C. neoformans strain. These findings suggest that NGx04 inhibits fungal Sec14p and supports its potential as a novel antifungal starting point.
Schistosomiasis, a debilitating disease that disproportionately affects those living in poverty, is often neglected despite affecting hundreds of millions of people worldwide. The disease is caused by a digenetic trematode of the genus Schistosoma, with S. haematobium, S. japonicum, and S. mansoni being the primary species affecting humans. Current treatment and control of schistosomiasis depend on a single drug, praziquantel, which exclusively targets adult worms and has minor activity against young developing stages. This reliance on a single drug has led to concerns about the emergence of drug-resistant parasites.A study reports the antischistosomal properties of mefloquine, an antimalarial drug, in mice infected with adult Schistosoma mansoni or S. japonicum. A single dose of mefloquine (200 or 400 mg/kg) administered orally resulted in high or complete total and female worm burden reductions (72.3%-100%). Furthermore, high worm burden reductions were observed for young developing stages of S. mansoni and S. japonicum harbored in the mouse. Both mefloquine erythro-enantiomers resulted in high and comparable total and female worm burden reductions when given to mice with either a sub-patent or patent S. mansoni infection.The findings suggest the potential of mefloquine as a novel antischistosomal drug based on an aminoalcohol functionality. Further studies are underway to elucidate the possible mechanism of action and to study the effect of mefloquine on S. haematobium and other trematodes. The study highlights the potential impact of mefloquine, which is widely and effectively used for the treatment of malaria, on schistosomiasis in areas where both malaria and schistosomiasis co-exist. The study emphasizes the importance of developing new antischistosomal drugs due to the paucity of a concerted effort to develop novel antischistosomal drugs and the high failure rates of compounds during preclinical and clinical testing.
A study was conducted in Cameroon to map the distribution of podoconiosis, a neglected tropical disease that causes swelling of the lower legs, and contribute to the global atlas of podoconiosis. The study used a multi-stage sampling design with stratification of the country by environmental risk of podoconiosis and surveyed 10,178 individuals from 4,603 households in 76 villages. The results showed that the overall prevalence of podoconiosis was 0.5% (95% CI; 0.4--0.7), with at least one case found in every region of Cameroon except Adamawa. The majority of clusters surveyed, 58%, reported no cases of podoconiosis, but there appeared to be micro-epidemiological heterogeneity in the prevalence of podoconiosis with four clusters located in the Northwest region showing relatively higher prevalence. The study demonstrated low prevalence but almost nationwide distribution of podoconiosis in Cameroon, indicating a need for a health system response to the burden of podoconiosis through case surveillance and morbidity management services. This is the first national population-based survey of podoconiosis in Cameroon, and the data collected will be useful for developing an efficient and cost-effective podoconiosis control and elimination program in the country.
Stem cell aging is associated with reduced stem cell occupancy in the niche, and this phenomenon is observed in various organisms, including mammals, Drosophila, and C. elegans. A study on Drosophila female germline stem cells (GSCs) found that Notch signaling plays a role in controlling GSC-niche adhesion in response to aging. Specifically, Notch signaling is increased with age in GSCs, leading to their removal from the niche. This is due to decreased adhesiveness of GSCs with higher levels of Notch signaling, which allows GSCs with lower levels of Notch signaling to out-compete them for niche occupancy. Notch activation is mediated by Fringe, a glycosyltransferase that modulates the binding of Notch to its ligands, and is regulated by insulin signaling in response to diet. The study found that while insulin/IGF signaling is required for GSC proliferation and maintenance, Notch signaling is involved in the diminished ability of GSCs to occupy the niche during aging. In young ovaries, Notch signaling in GSCs is low, allowing them to persist in the niche. However, as ovaries age, Notch signaling in GSCs is elevated, resulting in the loss of GSCs from the niche. Notch signaling in niche cells, which is required for niche integrity, is decreased with age, contributing to age-induced GSC loss. Therefore, both intrinsic and extrinsic Notch signaling control the niche residency of GSCs during aging.
The UL97 protein of human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a kinase that phosphorylates cellular proteins, including the retinoblastoma (Rb) tumor suppressor and lamin A/C. This kinase has been shown to have authentic cyclin-dependent kinase (Cdk)-like activity. Other human herpesviruses also encode kinases with similar sequences and positions, known as conserved herpesvirus protein kinases (CHPKs). These CHPKs are found in all three herpesvirus families: alpha, beta, and gamma. To determine if the Cdk-like activities of UL97 were shared by all CHPKs, a study expressed and tested individual epitope-tagged alleles of each protein in human cells and yeast. The results showed that the ability to phosphorylate Rb and lamin A, and to disrupt the nuclear lamina, was shared by all CHPKs from the beta and gamma-herpesvirus families, but not by their alpha-herpesvirus homologs. Similarly, all but one of the beta and gamma CHPKs displayed bona fide Cdk activity in yeast, while the alpha proteins did not. These virally-encoded Cdk-like kinases (v-Cdks) are likely to serve both overlapping and non-overlapping functions during viral infections, and some are targets of approved or developmental antiviral drugs. The CHPKs play important roles in viral replication and are involved in tegument disassembly, modulation of gene expression, stimulation of viral DNA replication, and facilitating capsid nuclear egress in part through disruption of the nuclear lamina. The UL97 kinase of HCMV was found to directly phosphorylate the Rb tumor suppressor protein both in vivo and in vitro, on residues that are normally targeted by cellular Cdk proteins, and to rescue the G1-to-S cell cycle defect of yeast cells lacking Cdk function, indicating that the kinase has Cdk activity. This makes UL97 the first identified v-Cdk. Further study showed that the CHPKs encoded by the beta and gamma-herpesviruses are all capable of inducing Rb phosphorylation in vivo on residues that inactivate the cell cycle inhibitory and tumor suppressor function of this protein, and disrupt the nuclear lamina. Importantly, all the beta- and gamma-herpesvirus CHPKs, with the exception of the HHV-8 (KSHV) ORF36 protein, displayed authentic Cdk function in the yeast complementation assay. The alpha-herpesvirus CHPKs were unable to phosphorylate Rb or lamin A, efficiently disrupt the nuclear lamina, or act as Cdks in S. cerevisiae. When all eight kinases were assayed for additional non-Cdk functions, it was found that despite the evolutionary conservation of these proteins, functional conservation was poor. Altogether, the study identifies a subset of the CHPKs as v-Cdks, but also indicates that the positional homology and amino acid similarity of these protein kinases does not always translate into common substrates or similar biological activities for these proteins.
The bacteria Burkholderia pseudomallei, which causes melioidosis, is a Tier 1 Select Agent and is a Gram-negative bacillus present in the environment in many tropical countries. An international working party, Detection of Environmental Burkholderia pseudomallei Working Party (DEBWorP), was formed during the VIth World Melioidosis Congress in 2010 to review the literature on the detection of environmental B. pseudomallei, update the risk map for melioidosis, and propose international consensus guidelines for soil sampling. The working party found that global coverage of B. pseudomallei in the environment was patchy, with a lack of studies in many areas where melioidosis is suspected to occur. The sampling strategies and bacterial identification methods used were highly variable and not all were robust. The proposed consensus guidelines provide the basis for the development of an accurate and comprehensive global map of environmental B. pseudomallei. Melioidosis is a community-acquired infectious disease caused by the environmental Gram-negative bacillus B. pseudomallei. It is acquired through contact with B. pseudomallei in the environment, and defining the global distribution of environmental B. pseudomallei is important for the development of a risk map for melioidosis. Environmental sampling can be used to identify areas where people are at risk even before cases are recognized. However, the studies lacked standardization in almost all aspects of study design and conduct. The proposed consensus guidelines aim to reduce the probability of false-negative results and provide affordable and ‘low-tech’ methodology that is applicable in both developed and developing countries.
The mechanism of membrane fusion by class II viral fusion proteins involves large-scale domain rearrangements of the envelope glycoprotein and a transition from dimers to trimers. Peptides derived from the stem of dengue-virus E bind stem-less E trimer, modeling a conformational intermediate, and inhibit viral fusion. These peptides specifically block viral infection with potency proportional to their affinity for the conformational intermediate. The stem peptides inhibit infectivity even when free peptide is removed from a preincubated inoculum before infecting cells, suggesting that peptides bind virions before attachment and are carried with virions into endosomes. Binding depends on particle dynamics, as there is no inhibition of infectivity if preincubation and separation are at 4°C rather than 37°C. The stem peptides bind sE in its rearranged, trimeric conformation, but not the sE dimer, and inhibition of infectivity is reversible. The results suggest that non-specific membrane interactions may dominate the initial association of peptide and virion and that this sequestration may concentrate the peptide in the viral membrane for rapid association during the short lifetime of the E-protein fusion intermediate. The stem peptides gain access to sites on the viral membrane that are occluded in the equilibrium structure, and dynamics of the virion surface permit access to transiently exposed sites on E, on the membrane, or on both. The peptide-virion interactions are specific, as biotinyl-DV2419-447 binds virions efficiently at pH 8, and the yield of retained virions decreases at 4°C. Membrane binding of stem peptides decreases lipid mobility and hence decreases the likelihood of excimer formation.
Cholera is a significant global health concern, with an estimated 4 million cases and 95,000 deaths annually. Recent outbreaks in places like Haiti and Yemen demonstrate the need for effective strategies to control and eliminate the disease. A promising approach involves using stool specimens preserved on filter paper for molecular analysis of Vibrio cholerae, the bacterium that causes cholera. This method is particularly useful in resource-limited settings, as it allows for the rapid, low-cost, and safe preservation of specimens for sequencing. Whole genome sequencing (WGS) of these specimens can provide valuable molecular epidemiological sequence information and confirm the presence or absence of genes of epidemiological interest. WGS can also identify co-infections with other diarrheal pathogens, which may impact the severity of disease. In a study of cholera outbreaks in Cameroon, dried filter paper spotted with APW-enriched specimens and culture isolates was found to be a viable method for preserving genomic material for characterization of the outbreak. This method allowed for DNA extraction and PCR amplification, even after storage at room temperature for up to 2 years. WGS of these specimens confirmed the presence of V. cholerae and provided valuable molecular epidemiological sequence information. Overall, the use of dried filter paper for stool specimen preservation, along with WGS, has the potential to significantly improve our understanding of cholera outbreaks and inform public health responses.
An intense investigation has discovered a complex protein network controlling epithelial polarity, with cytoplasmic Dynein as a key regulator. A genetic screen for epithelial defects in Drosophila follicle cells found that Dynein, through the cytoplasmic scaffolding protein Stardust, localizes the transmembrane protein Crumbs, particularly during early stages of epithelial development. Dynein-dependent apical targeting of specific sdt mRNA isoforms enriches Sdt protein in the apical cytoplasm. A unique mechanism was introduced where alternative splicing of a coding exon controls mRNA localization during development. This discovery highlights the importance of mRNA localization in the regulation of apico-basal organization and adds a new class of gene products, mRNAs, to the existing paradigm for apico-basal polarity regulation.
Leishmania, a unicellular digenetic parasite known for its clonal reproduction mode, has been suggested to have a non-obligate sexual cycle in its extracellular stage within the sand fly vector. This proposition comes from genetic analysis of populations and co-infections in sand flies, indicating the possibility of intraclonal genetic exchange. A study found that transgenic L. infantum lines expressing drug resistance markers linked to green and red fluorescent reporters were able to successfully exchange both types of markers within the sand fly midgut of the natural vector Phlebotomus perniciosus when individuals from these species were fed with a mixture of parental clones. The hybrid progeny appeared to be triploid based on DNA content analysis. The hybrid clone analyzed was stable throughout the complete parasite life cycle. Infections by the hybrid clone in BALB/c mice caused a reduction in parasite loads in both spleen and liver, and provided weight values similar to those obtained with uninfected mice. Spleen arginase activity was also significantly reduced relative to parental strains. These findings suggest that Leishmania has the ability to recognize the same genotype and mate, and that the yellow hybrid progeny is stable throughout the whole parasite life cycle but with a slower virulence, which correlates well with the lower arginase activity detected both in vitro and in vivo infections.
Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in Ethiopia, caused by Leishmania donovani, is a major health problem, with parasites clustering in distinctive genotypes depending on the geographic region and transmitted by different vectors. A recent study analyzed 63 L. donovani strains from VL and HIV-VL co-infected patients in north and south Ethiopia, using PCR targeting ITS1, cpb, and HASPB (k26) regions. Results showed that the k26-PCR amplicon size varied depending on the patient's geographic origin, with most strains from northwestern Ethiopia producing a 290 bp product and almost all strains (4/40) from HIV-VL co-infected patients giving a 410 bp amplicon. In contrast, most strains (20/23) from southwestern Ethiopia produced a 450 bp amplicon with smaller products (290 or 360 bp) only observed for three strains. High-resolution melt (HRM) analysis distinguished the different PCR products, and sequence analysis showed that the k26 repeat region in L. donovani is comprised of polymorphic 13 and 14 amino acid motifs. The number and order of the repeats in L. donovani vary between geographic regions, and this should be taken into account when designing diagnostic assays and vaccines based on this antigen. VL, transmitted by L. donovani, is primarily found in Sudan, South Sudan, and Ethiopia, accounting for 30,000-57,000 cases each year, resulting in 20-40,000 deaths annually.
The HIV-1 genome, which causes AIDS, is highly diverse due to error-prone reverse transcriptase, high viral turnover, and diversifying selection from the immune response. This diversity is partitioned into phylogenetic clusters called subtypes, and recombination between subtypes can generate inter-subtype recombinants. When these recombinants are transmitted between individuals, they are termed Circulating Recombinant Forms (CRFs) and can contribute significantly to the pandemic. A study hypothesized that only a subset of recombination breakpoints, the points where the parental strands switch, convey any selective advantage. The null hypothesis is that most recombination breakpoints are selectively neutral. A probabilistic model was generated to test this hypothesis, taking into account the local sequence identity between the co-packaged RNA genomes and producing an expected null distribution of breakpoints across two parental sequences. The results indicate that the majority of recombination breakpoints detected in the HIV-1 pandemic provide limited selective advantage, with the exception of specific genomic regions in which recombination events have a higher probability of being important to viral evolution. Recombination breakpoints are less likely to occur within five nucleotides of a mismatch between the aligned parental strains, and the probability of a breakpoint occurring is reduced within a window of size five nucleotides anchored to the 5′ end of each mismatch. The model accurately predicts the breakpoint distribution in experimental data and can identify regions where there is a significant over- or under-representation of breakpoints.
Computational modeling is crucial in modern neuroscience research, with statistical methods used to address two interdependent problems: estimating individual variation in parameters over a population of subjects for a given computational model, and comparing and estimating individual variation in expressed models. Previous research has addressed these problems separately, but a new hierarchical Bayesian inference (HBI) framework combines them, providing advantages for parameter estimation and model comparison. The HBI framework estimates parameters with smaller errors, is robust against outliers, and unbiased in model comparison. The HBI enables researchers to make inferences on group-level parameters through a fully Bayesian approach, and its advantages are demonstrated through synthetic and empirical datasets, outperforming previous methods. Computational modeling studies typically aim to compare model evidence across competing models and estimate free parameters for each individual and their group-level distributions. The HPE procedure employs a hierarchical approach to define priors based on group statistics, while HBI adds another level of hierarchy for each subject's model, allowing for joint inference of model identities and parameters. This results in a fully Bayesian framework that quantifies uncertainty and provides a rigorous statistical test for making inferences about population-level model parameters.
The study reveals that individual rhombomeres, specifically r4, and their associated Hox codes play a crucial role in the assembly of distinct functionally segregated sub-circuits in the developing auditory brainstem. The r4 contributes to functionally linked sensory and motor components, including the ventral nucleus of the lateral lemniscus, posterior ventral cochlear nuclei (VCN), and motor olivocochlear neurons. The assembly of r4-derived auditory components is involved in sound perception and depends on regulatory interactions between Hoxb1 and Hoxb2. Mutant mice with Hoxb1 and Hoxb2 mutations lose the transmission of low-level auditory stimuli, leading to hearing impairments. Hoxa2 regulates the Rig1 axon guidance receptor and controls contralateral projections from the anterior VCN to the medial nucleus of the trapezoid body, a circuit involved in sound localization. Therefore, r4 and its associated Hox codes control the assembly of distinct functionally segregated sub-circuits in the developing auditory brainstem, playing a crucial role in sound perception and localization.
The marine bacterium Saccharophagus degradans strain 2-4
Japanese Encephalitis Virus (JEV) is a significant cause of viral neurological infections in children across Asia, with genotype dominance shifting from genotype III (GIII) to genotype I (GI) in recent years. Culex mosquitoes play a critical role in maintaining the enzootic transmission cycle of JEV, and a study was conducted to determine if mosquitoes played a potential role in JEV genotype shift. Female Cx. pipiens mosquitoes were exposed orally to either GI or GIII JEV strains, and midgut, whole mosquitoes, secondary organs, and salivary glands were collected at 7 and 14 days post-infection (dpi) for analysis. The study found that Cx. pipiens mosquitoes were competent vectors for both GI and GIII JEV infection, with similar infection rates and growth kinetics. However, GI-infected mosquitoes had a slightly higher positive rate in salivary glands at 14 dpi compared to GIII-infected mosquitoes, indicating a higher transmission potential. Overall, the study suggests that Cx. pipiens mosquitoes may not play a critical role in JEV genotype shift, but further studies are needed to confirm this conclusion. JEV is a significant public health concern in Asia, and understanding the role of mosquitoes in JEV genotype shift is essential for developing effective control strategies.
Dengue infection, a rapidly spreading mosquito-borne viral disease, poses a significant health threat in tropical and subtropical countries, including Malaysia, which has experienced large outbreaks in recent years. This summary focuses on a retrospective review of dengue deaths in Malaysia between 2013 and 2014. A total of 322 dengue deaths were reviewed, with a mean age of 40.7±19.3 years, and 72.5% of them being adults. The most common warning signs were lethargy or restlessness, persistent vomiting, and laboratory markers indicating hemoconcentration. However, 22.4% did not exhibit any warning signs. Only 34% were suspected of having dengue at their initial presentation.Severe plasma leakage, multi-organ involvement, and dengue shock syndrome (DSS) were common in fatal cases, with DSS being the leading cause of death, regardless of age groups. More adults developed severe plasma leakage, and elderly patients had more heart involvement. The atypical presentation and rapid progression of severe dengue highlight the need for early recognition and aggressive intervention to prevent deaths. This study emphasizes the importance of increased awareness, monitoring, and healthcare interventions to reduce dengue-related mortality.
The authors previously discovered that global manipulation of insulin signaling, a nutrient-sensing pathway that affects reproductive potential, changes the composition and attractiveness of female pheromones in fruit flies. Here, they investigate the tissue specificity of insulin signaling effects on attractiveness by examining tissues involved in Drosophila reproduction and attractiveness phenotypes.Modulation of insulin signaling in oenocytes, which produce attractiveness cues, does not affect attractiveness, suggesting that other tissues may be involved. Elimination of functional ovaries reverses the effects of global insulin signaling on female attractiveness, and insulin signaling manipulation in ovarian tissues, specifically in late follicle cells surrounding vitellogenic oocytes, recapitulates the effects of global manipulations. Manipulations of insulin signaling targeted to the fat body produce opposite effects on attractiveness compared to global manipulations. These findings suggest that female attractiveness results from an interplay of insulin-dependent attractiveness cues from oenocytes and the fat body, integrated with reproductive effort in late-stage follicle cells. This system has implications for understanding the mechanism and reliability of Drosophila mate assessment.
The Ebola virus disease (EVD) epidemic in West Africa from 2013-2015 spread heterogeneously across Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone, with significant variation in transmission at the district level. A statistical modeling approach was used to estimate the basic reproduction number (R0) for each district and country using weekly incident case numbers, with growth rates estimated during the early exponential phase of the outbreak. At the district level, R0 ranged from 0.36 in Dubréka, Guinea to 3.37 in Margibi, Liberia, and at the national level, R0 was estimated to be 0.97 for Guinea, 1.26 for Liberia, and 1.66 for Sierra Leone. Socio-demographic variables related to urbanization, such as high population density and high wealth index, were positively associated with R0, suggesting that the consequences of fast urban growth in West Africa may have contributed to the increased spread of EVD. Overall, the estimation of national transmission offers little information about subnational dynamics, and the availability of district-level data provides a unique opportunity to investigate local disease transmission during the 2013-2015 epidemic.
The factors that determine a protein's rate of evolution are a subject of debate, with unclear relative roles of intrinsic present-day protein properties versus historical factors such as protein age. A study of human and mouse protein orthologs with mapped PDB structures found that structural properties and evolutionary rates are correlated within age groups, including relationships between solvent accessibility, designability, and evolutionary rates. However, age also plays a crucial role, as younger proteins tend to evolve faster than older proteins, even though they are less designable. These findings suggest that multiple factors, both intrinsic and historical, can interact to determine rates of protein evolution. Previous studies have identified various determinants of protein evolutionary rate, such as protein dispensability, expression level, number of protein-protein interactions, sequence length, role in the interaction network, and structural properties. However, it is difficult to identify causal factors due to correlations between these determinants. A principal component regression analysis found that a single component, including codon adaptation index, protein abundance, and gene expression level, accounted for nearly half of the observed variability in protein rate variation, but expression-related factors are measured with less noise than other possible factors. A protein's three-dimensional structure plays a key role in determining its evolutionary rate, with the core of a protein mostly formed by buried residues that often play a crucial role in the stability of the folded structure. Exposed residues tend to evolve faster than buried ones, and the relationship between solvent exposure and evolutionary rate is linear and strong. However, a protein's structural characteristics, such as the number of intra-protein residue interactions, can also affect its evolutionary rate. Additionally, the age of a protein, which depends on its evolutionary history, is correlated with its evolutionary rate, suggesting that a protein's evolution could be shaped in part by its evolutionary origin. Overall, the factors that determine a protein's rate of evolution remain poorly characterized, and the relative roles of intrinsic and historical factors of present-day proteins versus protein age remain unclear.
Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) is crucial for regulating gene expression during development, embryonic stem cell (ESC) differentiation, and cancer by trimethylating lysine 27 of histone H3 (H3K27me3). This study identifies Polycomb-like 3 (Pcl3) as a component of PRC2 that promotes ESC self-renewal. Pcl3 interacts with core PRC2 components and its knockdown decreases H3K27me3 levels, indicating its role in promoting PRC2 function. Pcl3 localizes at a subset of PRC2 targets, including genes and microRNAs associated with differentiation and development, and its Tudor domain is essential for this function. Pcl3 and its paralog Pcl2 exist in different PRC2 complexes but bind many of the same PRC2 targets. Thus, Pcl3 is a critical component of PRC2 for ESC self-renewal, histone methylation, and recruitment of PRC2 to a subset of its genomic sites. The study also highlights the importance of Pcl3 in maintaining ESC self-renewal and regulating PRC2 binding at diverse target genes.
The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans changes its chemosensory behavior depending on its feeding state, and this is achieved through the dynamic regulation of chemoreceptor gene expression. A study focused on the chemoreceptor gene srh-234, which is specifically expressed in ADL sensory neurons, found that its expression levels are highly dependent on feeding state conditions. In fed animals, srh-234 is strongly expressed in ADL neurons, but when starved, the expression is rapidly downregulated. The feeding state-dependent regulation of srh-234 occurs at the level of transcription, with a predicted MEF2 factor binding site and an E-box motif identified in the minimal promoter of srh-234. The E-box motif is necessary for srh-234 expression in ADL neurons, while the MEF2 site is required to repress, but not promote, srh-234 expression during starved conditions.The study also identified multiple bHLH genes as regulators of srh-234 expression levels. Mutations in hlh-2, hlh-3, mxl-3, and hlh-4 reduced srh-234 expression in fed conditions, while hlh-30 mutants suppressed the starvation-induced downregulation of srh-234. The bHLH transcription factors HLH-2, HLH-3, and HLH-4 are transiently expressed in and act in ADL neurons to regulate srh-234 expression. The expression levels of srh-234 in ADL is remotely regulated by MXL-3 and HLH-30 acting in the intestine via non-cell-autonomous regulation of srh-234 expression mediated by DAF-2/DAF-16 insulin signaling in ADL. These findings suggest that MEF2 and bHLH transcriptional factors link feeding state conditions via insulin signaling to the regulation of chemoreceptor genes in chemosensory neurons. The identification of the MEF2 and E-box motifs and their roles in srh-234 expression provides insight into the cis- and trans-regulatory logic for chemoreceptor gene expression and highlights the importance of studying feeding state-dependent gene regulation in C. elegans.
Buruli ulcer (BU) is a destructive skin condition caused by the environmental bacterium Mycobacterium ulcerans. The transmission of M. ulcerans is not fully understood, but several studies suggest that biting insects, particularly mosquitoes, may be involved. In this study, the authors investigated the correlation between the detection of M. ulcerans in mosquitoes and the risk of BU in humans in an endemic area of southeastern Australia. Adult mosquitoes were trapped in seven towns on the Bellarine Peninsula in Victoria, Australia, from December 2004 to December 2009 and screened for M. ulcerans by real-time PCR. The number of laboratory-confirmed cases of BU in permanent residents of these towns diagnosed during the same period was tallied to determine the average cumulative incidence of BU in each location. The authors found a strong dose-response relationship between the detection of M. ulcerans in mosquitoes and the risk of human disease (r, 0.99; 95% CI, 0.92--0.99; p<0.001). This study adds to the evidence that mosquitoes are involved in the transmission of M. ulcerans in southeastern Australia, which has implications for the development of intervention strategies to control and prevent BU.
The rat demyelination (dmy) mutation is a unique model for studying myelin maintenance, as it results in severe myelin breakdown in the CNS after postnatal completion of myelination. A G-to-A transition, 177 bp downstream of exon 3 of the Mrs2 gene, generates a novel splice acceptor site and functionally inactivates the mutant allele. This gene encodes an essential component of the major Mg2+ influx system in mitochondria and is involved in mitochondrial homeostasis. The dmy/dmy rats have major mitochondrial deficits, and MRS2-GFP recombinant BAC transgenic rats show that MRS2 is dominantly expressed in neurons and localized in the inner membrane of mitochondria. Therefore, it can be concluded that dmy/dmy rats suffer from a mitochondrial disease and have a different mechanism for myelin maintenance than its initial production. Mg2+ homeostasis in CNS mitochondria is essential for the maintenance of myelin. Myelin is essential for correct neural function, and any event causing an imbalance in myelination or remyelination has a high chance of inducing dys- or demyelination of the central or peripheral nervous system. The knowledge of the myelination process has benefited from studies on human patients with defects of myelination and myelin turnover, as well as from research on animal models. However, there is still a small number of genes directly or indirectly involved in the myelination process that have been identified and functionally annotated. Therefore, any new mutation occurring spontaneously or after mutagenesis, such as the dmy mutation, is of potential interest for unraveling the molecular mechanisms involved in myelin assembly.
Microarray gene expression signatures have the potential to be powerful tools for patient stratification, diagnosis of disease, prognosis of survival, assessment of risk group, and selection of treatment. However, before they can impact clinical practice, they need to be communicated to other healthcare centers with data for external evaluation and ultimately to practitioners for use in clinical routine. This requires unambiguous documentation of the signature. Currently, documentation standards do not allow for an unambiguous application to study-external patients, hindering independent evaluation and delaying their use in clinical practice. A study of eight clinical microarray studies found that discrepancy between study-internal and study-external diagnoses can be as frequent as 30% (worst case) and 18% (median). By using the proposed documentation by value strategy, which documents quantitative preprocessing information, the median discrepancy was reduced to 1%. The study shows that the process of evaluating microarray gene expression diagnostic signatures and bringing them to clinical practice can be substantially improved and made more reliable by better documentation of the signatures.
Curli amyloid fibrils, secreted by Enterobacteriaceae, play a crucial role in host cell adhesion, biofilm formation, and promoting bacterial resistance to environmental stressors. Two studies reveal structural similarities between curli and human pathological amyloids by presenting crystal structures of amyloid-forming segments from the major curli subunit, CsgA. These steric zipper fibrils are composed of tightly mated β-sheets, suggesting a link between curli and human pathological amyloids. D-enantiomeric peptides, originally developed for Alzheimer’s disease-associated amyloid-β, inhibited CsgA fibrillation and reduced biofilm formation in Salmonella typhimurium. Furthermore, CsgA fibrils cross-seeded fibrillation of amyloid-β, supporting their structural resemblance and potential cross-species amyloid interactions. These findings provide structural insights into amyloidogenic regions important for curli formation, suggest a novel strategy for disrupting amyloid-structured biofilms, and hypothesize on the formation of self-propagating prion-like species originating from a microbial source that could influence neurodegenerative diseases.
The Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) is a significant public health threat in most of Asia, including the Philippines, with high case fatality rates and significant neurologic sequelae in survivors. The epidemiology of JE in the Philippines is not well-defined, with limited surveillance and laboratory confirmation. A systematic literature review and analysis of surveillance data from 2011-2014 revealed endemicity and extensive geographic range of JE in the Philippines. The review identified 29 published reports and presentations on JE in the Philippines, including 5 serologic surveys, 18 reports of clinical cases, and 8 animal studies. JEV was the causative agent in 7-18% of cases of clinical meningitis and encephalitis combined and 16-40% of clinical encephalitis cases. JE predominantly affected children under 15 years of age and resulted in 6-7% case fatality. Surveillance data from 2011-2014 identified 73 (15%) laboratory-confirmed JE cases out of 497 cases tested. Continued and improved surveillance with laboratory confirmation is needed to quantify the burden of JE, guide prioritization of high-risk areas, and measure the impact of preventive measures, including immunization against this important public health threat.
The evolutionary origins of genetic robustness, or the invariance of phenotypes in the face of perturbations, are still a topic of debate. Some researchers believe that it arises due to requirements imposed by varying environmental conditions, while others argue that it is due to intrinsic factors such as metabolic requirements or an adaptive selection in favor of genes that allow a species to endure genetic perturbations. A recent study used a large-scale computational approach to chart the level of robustness of metabolic networks in hundreds of bacterial species across many simulated growth environments. The study found that variations among species in their level of robustness reflect ecological adaptations, with at least 20% of the non-essential reactions being due to environmental-dependent factors and associated with the species' lifestyle. Additionally, the study found that environmental-independent factors, such as intrinsic metabolic capacities, also play a role in metabolic robustness. However, environmental robustness, or the ability to buffer against external changes, cannot fully explain the dispensability of genes. The study identifies reactions that are uniquely susceptible to perturbations in human pathogens, potentially serving as novel drug-targets. Overall, the study highlights the intertwined nature of genetic and environmental robustness in metabolic networks and the importance of studying the underlying mechanisms in order to understand the evolution of genetic robustness.
"The study ""Immune Modulation and Childhood Immunisation (IMoChI)"" was conducted to investigate the effects of Schistosoma mansoni infection on responses to measles catch-up immunization and of praziquantel treatment on this outcome in a randomized trial in Entebbe, Uganda. The study enrolled children aged 3-5 years, with and without S. mansoni infection. The study found that at one week post-immunization, S. mansoni-infected children had lower levels of anti-measles IgG and a lower percentage with protective antibody levels compared to uninfected children. Among S. mansoni-infected children, those treated with praziquantel had higher anti-measles IgG levels one week post-immunization compared to those not yet treated. At 24 weeks post-immunization, IgG levels did not differ between the trial groups, but tended to be lower among previously-infected children who were still S mansoni stool-positive than among those who became stool-negative. The study suggests that S. mansoni infection among pre-school children is associated with a reduced antibody response to catch-up measles immunization and that praziquantel treatment improves the response. The study highlights the potential impact of S. mansoni infection on vaccine efficacy in endemic populations."
The evolution of bacterial populations has been better understood through large-scale sequencing of population samples, revealing that DNA sequences from multiple genes and broad sample coverage are needed for an unbiased view of genetic structure and ancestry patterns. However, traditional statistical methods for evolutionary inference like phylogenetic analysis face difficulties under extensive sampling scenarios, particularly when recombination is expected. To address this, statistical tools for detecting and representing recombination between populations and a model-based description of a population's molecular variability and affinity towards other populations have been introduced. These tools are available in the BAPS 5.2 software. Recombination plays a major role in shaping bacterial populations' genetic structure, with varying probabilities for certain populations to undergo recombination. Preferential recombination should lead to greater admixture between populations, detectable through DNA sequence data. Despite challenges, statistical analysis of molecular variation and reproductive isolation in natural populations is essential for understanding patterns of virulence and antibiotic resistance. Bayesian statistical approaches based on explicit admixture models have gained popularity for studying bacterial populations. The BAPS models in the software identify molecular evidence linking a group of strains together based on nucleotide frequencies, with the aim of estimating the strength of gene flow via a stochastic characterization of admixture rates between identified populations.
Cortical rhythms, particularly beta rhythms in the 20 Hz range, have been found to play crucial roles in cognitive abilities and attention. Studies using a computational model of sensory cortical areas suggest that top-down beta rhythms, generated in higher cognitive areas and delivered to earlier sensory areas, can support attentional gain modulation by activating ascending synaptic projections from L5 to L4 and L2/3 in superficial layers. Slow-inhibitory interneurons are shown to resonate to the 20 Hz input and modulate the activity in superficial layers in an attention-related manner. These findings suggest a potential mechanism by which cholinergic drive can support selective attention. The model also supports the hypothesis that primary sensory L5 cells, resonating to top-down beta frequency inputs, can modulate responses of superficial neurons in sensory cortices predominantly through SI interneurons. These results provide new insights into the functional roles of beta rhythms and their underlying mechanisms in attentional gain control.
The article discusses the value of stochastic transmission dynamic models for studying the emergence of new pathogens and the challenge of developing methods for parameter estimation and prediction. The authors propose a calibration and prediction framework for stochastic compartmental transmission models of epidemics, called Multiple Shooting for Stochastic systems (MSS). MSS uses a linear noise approximation to describe the size of the fluctuations and updates the belief about the true epidemic state using each new surveillance observation. The authors evaluate MSS using simulated outbreaks of a novel viral pathogen and compare its performance to three state-of-the-art benchmark methods. They find that MSS outperforms the benchmark methods in the majority of epidemic scenarios tested. The authors conclude that MSS may improve on current approaches for calibration and prediction using stochastic models of epidemics. The sporadic emergence of new human pathogens highlights the importance of monitoring pathogen spread in human populations and the need for tools to make inference about the true state of the epidemic and the values of fundamental epidemic parameters using observations that can only imperfectly represent the true epidemic state. The authors propose MSS as a promising method for this purpose.
The study investigates the factors that influence visual perception, focusing on the role of past stimuli and perceptual decisions. An experiment was conducted to compare the ability of sensory stimuli and perceptual decisions to predict future errors in an orientation adjustment task. The results showed that previous responses, after correcting for orientation-dependent biases, were a more efficient predictor of serial dependence than the relative orientation of consecutive stimuli. This suggests that attractive biases in visual perception may result from the history of perceptual decisions. A second experiment presented stimuli at the fovea and varied the relative orientation of consecutive stimuli to ensure a fair comparison between models. The results replicated the first experiment, confirming that previous perceptual decisions are a better predictor of serial dependence than previous stimuli. The study concludes that perceptual decisions and behavioral responses are critical for serial dependence in orientation discrimination.
The Clock-Cycle (CLK-CYC) heterodimer is a key circadian transcription complex in Drosophila, with CYC having a DNA-binding domain and CLK having a transcriptional activation domain. However, most of CLK-CYC's transcriptional activity comes from CLK's glutamine-rich region. A CYC-viral protein 16 (VP16) fusion protein was created to study the role of transcription in core circadian timekeeping. The addition of VP16 to CYC significantly enhances the transcriptional activity of CLK-CYC, leading to increased levels of CLK-CYC direct target gene mRNAs and a short period, indicating that circadian transcription contributes to core circadian function. This suggests that the timing of transcriptional activation, not just the activation itself, is critical for the behavioral effects observed in CYC-VP16-expressing flies. These findings highlight the importance of transcription in circadian rhythms and their regulation in Drosophila.
The horizontally acquired pmrD gene in Salmonella enterica activates the ancestral PmrA/PmrB two-component system, promoting transcription of PmrA-dependent genes and conferring resistance to polymyxin B. In Escherichia coli, the pmrD gene cannot activate the PmrA/PmrB system, and this has been attributed to the highly divergent E. coli PmrD protein. However, it has been shown that the E. coli PmrD protein can activate the PmrA/PmrB system in Salmonella, suggesting that these two species differ in an additional component controlling PmrA-P levels. Further investigation revealed that the E. coli PmrB displays higher phosphatase activity towards PmrA-P than the Salmonella PmrB, and this difference is due to a specific PmrB subdomain. Replacement of the E. coli pmrB gene with the Salmonella homolog was sufficient to render E. coli resistant to polymyxin B under PmrD-inducing conditions. These findings suggest that quantitative differences in the biochemical activities of orthologous ancestral proteins can dictate the ability of a horizontally acquired gene product to confer species-specific traits and that horizontally acquired genes can potentiate selection at ancestral loci. The pmrD gene was likely horizontally acquired and its expression is controlled by the PhoP/PhoQ two-component system in both Salmonella and Escherichia. However, the PmrD protein functions in Salmonella but not in Escherichia, and this has been attributed to differences in the phosphatase activity of the PmrB protein towards PmrA-P between the two species. This demonstrates that an ancestral protein can control the ability of a horizontally acquired gene product to confer new traits and that quantitative differences in the biochemical activities of ancestral proteins can dictate the ability of a horizontally acquired gene to confer a selective advantage upon a recipient organism.
A novel statistical approach has been developed to identify differentially expressed genes at the early stages of cell differentiation, demonstrated through the differentiation of murine embryonic stem cells (mES) into embryoid bodies (EB). The Differentiation-Test is based on the observation that the variance of measured expression of a gene in a mixed cell population increases as compared to its variance before differentiation, due to differences in the percentage of parental and descendent cells across biological replicates. The Differentiation-Test was applied to a dataset of mES cells differentiated into EBs, and the top 200 differentially expressed genes of 4-day and 8-day EBs were identified. These gene lists showed significant overlap with a benchmark gene list obtained through fluorescence activated cell sorting, indicating the accuracy of the Differentiation-Test. The test was able to detect differentially expressed genes in a very early stage of the differentiation process, providing consistent results to those obtained from a laborious experimental procedure of cell sorting. The Differentiation-Test can identify novel self-renewal regulators, as demonstrated through the study of two transcription regulators detected by the Differentiation-Test, Smarcad1 and Pias2. Smarcad1 was found to be an important sequence-specific transcription regulator for maintaining the pluripotency of ES cells. This research highlights the potential of statistical methods in identifying differentially expressed genes during cell differentiation and their regulatory roles, providing a valuable tool for understanding the mechanisms of differentiation.
Gene functional analysis is important in next-generation sequencing studies to understand the function of many genes and their classification to pathways, which are often unknown. Functional associations between genes are inferred from large-scale omics data, such as protein-protein interactions and gene co-expression networks. However, these data can be affected by confounding bias, leading to false positive findings. This issue is addressed in a study that presents an integrative method for discerning molecular pathways relevant to complex disease by examining functional associations between human genes from diverse data types and assessing them with a novel phenotype-based method. The study finds that controlling for confounding bias, such as coding-sequence length in the case of de novo gene variants, is crucial in identifying functional associations among genes mutated in the same disease. The method presented in the study is found to be superior in identifying functional associations among genes mutated in the same disease even after accounting for significant sequencing study bias, demonstrating its suitability for functionally clustering variant genes underlying polygenic disorders.
In January 2014, the Mexican government implemented an 8% tax on nonessential foods with energy density ≥275 kcal/100g and a peso-per-liter tax on sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) to prevent continued increases in obesity and diabetes. This study, using data from The Nielsen Company’s Mexico Consumer Panel Services, analyzed the volume of purchases of taxed and untaxed foods from January 2012 to December 2014. The results showed that the mean volume of purchases of taxed foods in 2014 changed by -25g (95% CI = -46, -11) per capita per month, or a 5.1% change beyond what would have been expected based on pre-tax (2012-2013) trends, with no corresponding change in purchases of untaxed foods. Low SES households purchased on average 10.2% less taxed foods than expected, medium SES households purchased 5.8% less taxed foods, whereas high SES households’ purchases did not change. The main limitations of the findings include the inability to infer causality, the sample being only representative of urban areas, having only 2 years of data prior to the tax, and not capturing all foods purchased by the household. Household purchases of nonessential energy-dense foods declined in the first year after the implementation of Mexico’s SSB and nonessential foods taxes.
The article discusses the role of power laws in brain functions and their potential underlying mechanisms. A model of collision-sensitive neurons, specifically the Lobula Giant Movement Detector Neuron (LGMD), is presented, which assumes noisy information channels with response thresholds. The model obtains an approximative power law as a result of pooling these channels, and it successfully predicts many response characteristics of the LGMD. The results depend critically on noise in the inhibitory pathway but are robust against noise in the excitatory pathway.The article also explores the role of noise in the nervous system, which is usually considered unwanted but can be used to solve computational problems. For example, a suitable amount of noise can help push otherwise undetectable signals across the response threshold of a neuron, a phenomenon known as stochastic resonance. Noise can also smooth the threshold behavior of a neuron and transform contrast-invariant, orientation-tuned input to cortical simple cells into contrast-invariant spike tuning.Furthermore, the article proposes that threshold smoothing may occur at the single neuron level, where noisy and thresholded (pre-synaptic) inputs are integrated by the dendritic tree of a neuron. This property is used in a computational model aimed at explaining many characteristics of the LGMD neuron.In summary, power laws describe brain functions at various levels, and they may be generated by similar underlying mechanisms. Noise, which is prevalent and unavoidable in the nervous system, can be used to solve computational problems and play a crucial role in transforming signals in the visual system. The LGMD neuron, which responds best to objects approaching one of the locust's compound eyes on a direct collision course, can be modeled using a biophysically plausible model with noisy information channels and response thresholds, which obtains an approximative power law as a result of pooling these channels. The results depend critically on noise in the inhibitory pathway but are robust against noise in the excitatory pathway.
Cameroon's National Buruli Ulcer Control Program (NBUCP) began in 2002, with the goal of reducing suffering and morbidity associated with the disease. The program has seen significant achievements, such as a decrease in case detection rates from 3.89 to 1.45 per 100,000 inhabitants between 2001 and 2014, and an increase in the number of endemic health districts from two to 64. The program also established five diagnostic and treatment centers, with two more planned. However, there are still challenges, namely insufficient resources and funding. The program relies heavily on partner resources, but these are becoming increasingly scarce, resulting in cuts to activities and decreased performance indicators. The Cameroon government provides limited funding for recurrent costs, but it is not enough to cover the gap. The NBUCP aims to detect cases early, particularly non-ulcerative forms and category 1 lesions, and to treat all active cases according to standard guidelines. However, there is a lack of diagnostic and management skills for BU among health personnel, as BU is not taught in all medical faculties and training schools. Research is also needed to answer outstanding questions about BU, such as the mode of transmission and the relationship between BU and HIV/AIDS. While progress has been made, resource mobilization is needed to expand and scale up program activities.
The paper investigates the impact of outcome valence on confidence while learning stimulus-outcome associations through trial-and-error. The experiments reveal that participants were more confident in their choices when learning to seek gains compared to avoiding losses, despite equal difficulty and performance in both contexts. This bias is driven by the context-value, a dynamically updated estimate of the average expected-value of choice options. The biasing effect of context-value on confidence has functional consequences, such as differing flexibility in learning strategies in volatile environments depending on outcome valence. Despite similar behavior, profound asymmetries may exist between learning to avoid losses and seeking gains. These findings demonstrate the importance of understanding confidence and its biases in reinforcement learning.
Alphaviruses, enveloped positive-strand RNA viruses with a 5' capped and 3' polyadenylated genome of approximately 11.5 kb, can cause serious disease in humans and domestic animals. Alphavirus RNA replication takes place in membrane invaginations that protrude from the inner surface of the host cell plasma membrane and from the outer surface of endosomes and lysosomes. The replication complexes contain as essential components the virus-encoded nonstructural proteins nsP1-nsP4, which arise through cleavage from a polyprotein precursor P1234. The functions of nsP3 have remained more obscure, although mutations in it affect various steps of RNA synthesis. The N-terminus of nsP3 contains a structurally conserved protein domain termed the macro domain, which is capable of binding ADP-ribose derivatives and RNA, and also hydrolyzing ADP-ribose-1''-phosphate. The C-terminus of alphavirus nsP3 contains a 'tail' region, which varies in length between ~150--250 amino acid residues in different alphavirus and is devoid of predicted secondary structure. The tail region has been implicated in the virulence of alphaviruses. Some regions of the tail are also heavily phosphorylated on serine and threonine residues, and in Semliki Forest virus (SFV), deletion of the phosphorylated region gave rise to a virus that replicated well in cell culture but was apathogenic in mice. In this study, a carboxyterminal proline-rich sequence motif shared by many alphaviral nsP3 proteins was found to serve as a preferred target site for the Src-homology 3 (SH3) domains of amphiphysin-1 and -2. Upon alphavirus infection, the intracellular distribution of amphiphysin was dramatically altered and colocalized with nsP3. Mutations in nsP3 disrupting the amphiphysin SH3 binding motif as well as RNAi-mediated silencing of amphiphysin-2 expression resulted in impaired viral RNA replication in HeLa cells infected with SINV or SFV. Infection of Balb/c mice with SFV carrying an SH3 binding-defective nsP3 was associated with significantly decreased mortality. These data establish SH3 domain-mediated binding of nsP3 with amphiphysin as an important host cell interaction promoting alphavirus replication.
Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic granulomatous infection of the skin caused by melanized fungi, particularly members of the order Chaetothyriales. A study was conducted to assess population diversity among 123 clinical strains of the disease in Brazil using sequencing of the rDNA internal transcribed spacer region and partial cell division cycle and β-tubulin genes.
