The study found that the strains were limited to three clusters divided over the single family Herpotrichiellaceae known to comprise agents of the disease. The Fonsecaea cluster contained the most important agents, with F. pedrosoi being prevalent at 80% of the total set of strains, followed by F. monophora, F. nubica, and a single isolate of F. pugnacius. Additional agents were located among members of the genus Rhinocladiella and Cyphellophora, with frequencies of 3% and 1%, respectively. The infection is assumed to occur through accidental inoculation of the fungus via contaminated plant debris, and is one of the most frequent implantation mycoses found among rural populations. Clinically, the disease is characterized by pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia with epidermal microabscesses and dermal granulomata. The disease has a slow evolution, but may result in disfigurement of affected body sites. The initial lesion is noted as a small pink papule at the site of inoculation which gradually enlarges, developing into large papillomatous and verrucous warts.
Listeria monocytogenes, a bacterium that causes the foodborne disease listeriosis, is capable of manipulating the host's cells to its advantage during infection. Upon infection, L. monocytogenes induces DNA breaks and activates the DNA Damage Response (DDR) pathway, but the bacterium is able to dampen the activation of the DNA-damage signaling pathway through the bacterial factor Listeriolysin O (LLO). LLO induces the degradation of Mre11, a major sensor of DNA damage, through a mechanism independent of proteasome degradation. This dampening of the DDR is important for infection as inhibition of proteins implicated in this pathway increases bacterial infection. Additionally, L. monocytogenes induces an increase in γH2AX levels during infection both in tissue-cultured cells and in mice. The LLO toxin prevents H2AX phosphorylation, which is a crucial step in the DDR, and is a potent inhibitor of the DDR. The LLO toxin dampens the DDR downstream of DNA breaks and reduces the level of γH2AX and the number of 53BP1 foci during infection. Peritoneal infections of mice with either the wild type or Δhly mutant L. monocytogenes confirmed these in vitro observations, showing that LLO prevents phosphorylation of H2AX. Furthermore, LLO dampens the DDR induced by known cytotoxic agents such as etoposide or irradiation. The bacteria's ability to dampen the DDR is important for its virulence and survival within the host.
The human Herpes Simplex Viruses, HSV-1 and HSV-2, are common pathogens that cause various diseases, with HSV-1 primarily causing cold sores and HSV-2 being a major factor in sexually transmitted infections. Both viruses infect epithelial cells and establish latency in sensory neurons. While much is known about HSV replication, the molecular machinery responsible for its regulation remains elusive. A study was conducted to identify factors affecting HSV infection by screening an epigenetic compound library and discovered that BRD4, a member of the bromodomain and extraterminal family, plays a critical role in HSV infection. BRD4 is an epigenetic reader that recruits transcriptional regulatory complexes to acetylated chromatin and participates in host gene regulation. The study found that bromodomain inhibition enhances HSV infection by promoting transcription factor association with HSV gene promoters. Specifically, treatment with JQ1, a BD1 inhibitor, acts through BRD4 protein, and suppressing BRD4 expression or inhibiting CDK9 activity impedes HSV infection. The study demonstrates that BRD4 is a modulator for JQ1 action on HSV infection and has an essential role in HSV infection.
Noma, or cancrum oris, is a devastating gangrenous oral infection that primarily affects malnourished children in developing countries, causing severe facial disfigurement. The exact cause of noma is still unknown, but it is thought to be triggered by a complex mix of microbial infection, poor oral hygiene, and weakened immune system. A recent study aimed to understand the microbial ecology of noma by sequencing 16S rRNA gene amplicons from sixty samples of gingival fluid from healthy children and those suffering from noma or Acute Necrotizing Gingivitis (ANG). The study found that samples taken from lesions in diseased mouths were enriched with Spirochaetes and depleted for Proteobacteria, regardless of whether the samples were taken from noma or ANG lesions. However, samples from noma mouths did not have a higher abundance of Fusobacterium, casting doubt on its role as a causative agent of noma. The study also identified several Operational Taxonomic Units (OTUs) in the Orders Erysipelotrichales, Clostridiales, Bacteroidales, and Spirochaetales as indicators of noma, suggesting that one or more microbes within these Orders is associated with the development of noma lesions. Overall, the study highlights the importance of understanding the microbial communities associated with noma and the need for further research into the role of these microbes in the development of this devastating disease.
Quorum sensing is a communication system used by bacteria to coordinate adaptation properties, cell fate, or commitment to sporulation. The infectious cycle of Bacillus thuringiensis in the insect host is a powerful model to investigate the role of quorum sensing in natural conditions. It is tuned by communication systems regulators belonging to the RNPP family and directly regulated by re-internalized signaling peptides. One such RNPP regulator, NprR, acts in the presence of its cognate signaling peptide NprX as a transcription factor, regulating a set of genes involved in the survival of these bacteria in the insect cadaver. However, in the absence of NprX and independently of its transcriptional activator function, NprR negatively controls sporulation. NprR inhibits expression of Spo0A-regulated genes by preventing the KinA-dependent phosphorylation of the phosphotransferase Spo0F, thus delaying initiation of the sporulation process. This NprR function displays striking similarities with the Rap proteins, which also belong to the RNPP family, but are devoid of DNA-binding domain and indirectly control gene expression via protein-protein interactions in Bacilli. Conservation of the Rap residues directly interacting with Spo0F further suggests a common inhibition of the sporulation phosphorelay. The crystal structure of apo NprR confirms that NprR displays a highly flexible Rap-like structure. A molecular regulatory mechanism is proposed where key residues of the bifunctional regulator NprR are directly and alternatively involved in its two functions. NprX binding switches NprR from a dimeric inhibitor of sporulation to a tetrameric transcriptional activator involved in the necrotrophic lifestyle of B. thuringiensis. NprR thus tightly coordinates sporulation and necrotrophism, ensuring survival and dissemination of the bacteria during host infection.
Achieving effective treatment for HIV, which cannot currently be cured, involves combination treatment with multiple anti-retroviral drugs due to different viral genotypes for each individual patient. Computational models have been developed to predict an optimal treatment regimen for an individual patient, with current models based solely on sequence data derived from viral genotyping and not considering chemical similarity of drugs. A study applied proteochemometric (PCM) models, combining chemical and protein target properties in a single bioactivity model, and found they performed better in resistance classification and prediction of Log Fold Change compared to previously published sequence data. PCM models were able to accurately predict the phenotypic resistance based on genotypic data even for novel mutants and mixtures, with an applicability domain informing the user about the reliability of predictions. This is crucial as mutations in the viral genome occur frequently, with even single point mutations having the potential to cause insensitivity of HIV to treatment with all members from an entire drug class. Occurrence of these resistance-conferring mutations can be contained or minimized by the nature of HAART therapy due to the combination of multiple drugs classes, but the occurrence of high impact mutations can cause treatment failure in HAART for certain specific drug regimens. Therefore, it is crucial that the drug regimen is tailored to the specific viral genotype, with knowledge of the effect of individual mutations on the efficacy of different drugs required for a tailored drug regimen. Computational methods, such as PCM models, have been shown to perform equal to phenotypic assays and significantly better in patients experiencing drug failure.
"Eukaryotic chemotaxis, the movement of cells towards a source of attractants, is a biologically important and theoretically interesting process that has been widely studied. The traditional understanding of this mechanism is that attractants cause actin polymerization leading to pseudopod formation and cell movement. However, a new proposed mechanism suggests that pseudopods are made by a self-generated cycle, with chemoattractants modulating the cycle rather than directly causing actin polymerization. A computational model based on this pseudopod-based mechanism has been found to reproduce a wide range of existing data about cell movement and chemotaxis, predicting both bias of pseudopod position in low chemoattractant gradients and lateral pseudopod initiation in high gradients. These findings suggest that an intrinsic pseudopod cycle lies at the heart of cell motility, implying that the mechanism behind chemotaxis relies on modification of intrinsic pseudopod behavior, more than generation of new pseudopods or actin polymerization by chemoattractants. Previous models have considered chemotaxis to be driven by a ""compass"" mechanism, where there is a localized signal representing the direction of the chemoattractant gradient, causing new pseudopods to be made towards attractant sources. However, it has been found that simple generation of new pseudopods cannot explain observed cell steering and that, unless gradients are very steep, new pseudopods are usually more strongly controlled by internal dynamics than by chemoattractants. A ""pseudopod-centred"" mechanism has been proposed as an alternative, where each cell's direction is entirely represented by the pseudopods themselves. Directional migration is accomplished by biasing the cycle of pseudopod generation and retraction, rather than simply at the level of new pseudopod initiation."
Fleas can transmit Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague, through two mechanisms: early-phase transmission (EPT) and biofilm-dependent transmission (BDT). EPT occurs when fleas transmit Y. pestis immediately after taking an infectious blood meal, while BDT occurs when Y. pestis accumulates in the flea's proventriculus and is transmitted to the host through regurgitation. A study examining the mechanism of EPT and the effect of host blood on it found that fleas fed bacteremic rat or guinea pig blood were more likely to reflux a portion of the infected blood meal into the esophagus within 24 hours of feeding, a phenomenon called post-infection esophageal reflux (PIER). This correlated with increased numbers of Y. pestis CFU transmitted by Oropsylla montana. When fleas fed on bacteremic rat blood, they were more likely to become partially blocked and transmit Y. pestis within a time frame typically attributed to EPT. The study suggests that the relative insolubility of the hemoglobin of rats and Sciurids and the slower digestion of their blood promotes regurgitative transmission, which may be one reason why these rodents are particularly prominent in plague ecology.
"The study of neural population codes has traditionally focused on the detrimental effects of positive correlations on coding performance. However, this study shows that positive correlations can significantly enhance coding performance by suppressing the probability of discrimination error and increasing the number of stimuli encoded. These effects do not require unrealistic correlation values and can occur in populations with a few tens of neurons. The benefits of positive correlations are further amplified by heterogeneity commonly seen in population activity. A pattern of correlation can lead to a ""lock-in"" of response probabilities, eliminating variability in the subspace relevant for stimulus discrimination. These findings are particularly relevant for understanding the neural basis of perception, as they demonstrate that correlations in neural activity can support high-fidelity coding and rapid perception. The study also highlights the potential benefits of positive correlations for neural population codes and suggests new experimental tests for identifying the proposed pattern of correlation."
A conjugate vaccine for cholera, prepared via squaric acid chemistry from the O-specific polysaccharide (OSP) of Vibrio cholerae O1 Inaba strain PIC018 and a recombinant heavy chain fragment of tetanus toxin (OSP:rTTHc), was assessed for immune responses in mice. The vaccine induced prominent anti-OSP and anti-TT serum IgG responses, as well as vibriocidal antibody and memory B cell responses following intramuscular or intradermal vaccination. Intestinal lamina proprial IgA responses targeting OSP occurred following intradermal vaccination. The vaccine was found to be protective in a mouse survival cholera challenge model. The development of an effective cholera conjugate vaccine that induces high level and long-term immune responses against OSP would be beneficial, especially in young children who respond poorly to polysaccharide antigens. Cholera is a severe, dehydrating diarrheal disease caused by toxigenic strains of Vibrio cholerae, with approximately 3-5 million cases and 100,000-130,000 deaths globally each year. Vaccination against cholera can assist in control measures until safe water and adequate sanitation become a reality for those most at risk for cholera.
The Immunochromatographic card test (ICT) is a tool used to map the distribution of Wuchereria bancrofti, the parasite causing lymphatic filariasis (LF), a vector-borne disease affecting millions worldwide. The study investigates the cross-reactivity of ICT when mapping LF in areas with contrasting endemicity levels of loiasis and mansonellosis in Cameroon. A cross-sectional study was conducted in 42 villages across three regions of the Cameroon rainforest domain, and blood samples were collected from 2190 individuals for the detection of circulating filarial antigen (CFA) by ICT and assessment of Mf using a thick blood smear. The study found that ICT positivity was strongly associated with high L. loa prevalence and intensity (Mf/ml of blood) at the individual level. These results suggest that the main confounding factor for positive ICT test card results are high levels of L. loa. The findings may indicate that W. bancrofti is much less prevalent in the Central African region where L. loa is highly endemic than previously assumed and accurate re-mapping of the region would be very useful for shrinking of the map of LF distribution.
"Positive-strand RNA viruses, a large group that includes human pathogens such as SARS-coronavirus (SARS-CoV), replicate in the cytoplasm of infected host cells, with their replication complexes associated with modified host cell membranes. These membrane structures include distinct spherular membrane invaginations and elaborate webs of packed membranes and vesicles. A unique reticulovesicular network of modified endoplasmic reticulum, consisting of convoluted membranes, numerous interconnected double-membrane vesicles (DMVs), and ""vesicle packets"" apparently arising from DMV merger, has been implicated in SARS-CoV RNA synthesis. The convoluted membranes were most abundantly immunolabeled for viral replicase subunits, while double-stranded RNA, presumably revealing the site of viral RNA synthesis, mainly localized to the DMV interior. The formation and function of these membrane-associated replication complexes, or ""viral factories,"" are not yet fully understood, but they are thought to facilitate the concentration of viral macromolecules, provide a membrane-based structural framework for RNA synthesis, coordinate different steps in the viral life cycle, and delay the induction of host defense mechanisms. Understanding the structure-function relationships that govern the membrane-associated replication of positive-strand RNA viruses will enhance our general understanding of their molecular biology and may have important implications for the development of novel antiviral control strategies."
The article presents a study on the role of suberin in the roots of Arabidopsis thaliana in controlling water and mineral ion uptake and transport to the leaves. The study used the enhanced suberin1 (esb1) mutant, which has increased root suberin, to establish a connection between suberin and both water movement through the plant and solute accumulation in the shoot. The results showed that esb1 mutants had reduced daytime transpiration rates and increased water-use efficiency during their vegetative growth period. Additionally, the changes in suberin and water transport were associated with decreases in the accumulation of Ca, Mn, and Zn and increases in the accumulation of Na, S, K, As, Se, and Mo in the shoot. These findings provide direct genetic evidence that suberin in the roots plays a critical role in controlling both water and mineral ion uptake and transport to the leaves. The changes observed in the elemental accumulation in leaves are also interpreted as evidence that a significant component of the radial root transport of Ca, Mn, and Zn occurs in the apoplast. Overall, the study highlights the importance of suberin in regulating water and solute transport in plants, and the potential for suberin-modified plants to be used in improving water-use efficiency and mineral nutrition in crops.
The single photon response (SPR) in vertebrate phototransduction is regulated by the dynamics of R* during its lifetime, including the random number of phosphorylations, catalytic activity, and random sojourn time at each phosphorylation level. Despite this randomness, the SPR is highly reproducible, but the mechanisms that confer such low variability are not completely understood. A Continuous Time Markov Chain (CTMC) model based on the biochemistry of rhodopsin activation and deactivation, interfaced with a spatio-temporal model of phototransduction, was used to investigate the kinetics of rhodopsin deactivation. The results showed that only the randomness of the sojourn times in each of the phosphorylated states contributes to the Coefficient of Variation (CV) of the response, whereas the randomness of the number of R\* turnoff steps has a negligible effect. This indicates that R\* shutoff is responsible for the variability of the photoresponse, while the diffusion of the second messengers acts as a variability suppressor. The activation/deactivation module of the cascade is not experimentally separable from the transduction module, but a mathematical model is used to analyze the randomness of each phosphorylation state of R\*. The dynamics of R\* deactivation regulates the production of cGMP and therefore the current response. Following isomerization, a molecule undergoes a random number of phosphorylations by rhodopsin kinase (RK) and finally is inactivated by arrestin (Arr) binding. Activated rhodopsin keeps activating its cognate G-protein (G) transducin while its catalytic activity declines with increasing level of phosphorylation. The active G-protein (G\*) associates with the effector protein phosphodiesterase (E) forming an active G-GPE complex, which by hydrolyzing cGMP reduces its concentration, thereby generating a current response on the outer shell of the ROS. The SPR exhibits a low variability in the sense that the amplitude and shape of the electrical responses, corresponding to a set of activation-deactivation events, are similar. The Coefficient of Variation (CV) of the SPR area for mouse is about 0.35. However, the mechanisms that confer high reproducibility of the SPR are not completely understood, and several studies attribute the high reproducibility of the SPR mainly to the mechanisms regulating rhodopsin deactivation. Rhodopsin inactivation can occur by several mechanisms, including Arr binding and thermal decay to opsin, but the former occurs on a much longer time scale. Shutoff of R\* by Arr binding can follow an infinite number of paths, depending on the random number of phosphorylated states, and the random sojourn times in those states.
A new mathematical framework has been developed to uncouple a stochastic reaction network from its dynamic environment, allowing for the analysis of a system's behavior within a fluctuating extrinsic environment. This framework is crucial for understanding the behavior of low-copy molecule biochemical systems, which require mathematical models that account for intrinsic stochasticity. Recent studies have shown that intrinsic noise alone cannot account for the substantial phenotypic variability among isogenic cells and that extrinsic noise, or fluctuations in the intracellular environment, represent an additional source of variability. The new framework allows for the marginalization of fluctuating extrinsic components, such as chemical species, into a decoupled model with its own process-and master equations. The approach has been shown to be significant through several case studies. The development of this framework will aid in turning stochastic modeling and simulation techniques more large-scale and more faithful to in vivo conditions, where significant environmental fluctuations are present. It can also be used in the model-based design of novel circuit motifs in synthetic biology and the analysis of how environmental stochasticity is propagated along coupled reaction networks.
A novel closed-loop BMI training architecture, adaptive optimal feedback-controlled (OFC) point process filter (PPF), has been developed to enable BMI control at the time-scale of spike events and allow for dynamic adaptation of decoder parameters with every spike event. The architecture incorporates an infinite-horizon optimal feedback-control model of the brain’s behavior in closed-loop BMI control and a point process model of spikes. The OFC model infers the user’s motor intention during CLDA, and is used to design an autonomous and dynamic assisted training technique. The point process model allows for neural processing, control and decoder adaptation with every spike event and at a faster time-scale than current decoders. Closed-loop experiments in a non-human primate showed that the OFC intention estimation improved BMI performance compared with current intention estimation techniques, OFC assisted training allowed the subject to consistently achieve proficient control, spike-event-based adaptation resulted in faster and more consistent performance convergence compared with batch-based methods, and was robust to parameter initialization. The architecture extended control to tasks beyond those used for CLDA training. These results have significant implications towards the development of clinically-viable neuroprosthetics.
The study investigates the impact of stimulus structure on redundancy in the retina by measuring simultaneous responses from populations of retinal ganglion cells presented with natural and artificial stimuli that varied in correlation structure. The results showed that responding to spatio-temporally structured stimuli such as natural movies, pairs of ganglion cells were modestly more correlated than in response to white noise checkerboards, but they were much less correlated than predicted by a non-adapting functional model of retinal response. The study found that stimuli with purely spatial correlations, pairs of ganglion cells showed increased correlations consistent with a static, non-adapting receptive field and nonlinearity. The study's findings suggest that the retina dynamically adjusts its coding strategy to represent new stimulus classes efficiently, and temporal processing plays a key role in maintaining the level of output correlations. The study also found that a fixed linear filter is largely sufficient to explain the effect of spatial correlations, whereas higher-order processing is necessary to suppress the impact of temporal stimulus correlations on output correlation. The study's data and stimuli are publicly available online for further research.
Genetic interactions, which occur when a combination of mutations results in a surprising phenotype, are important for predicting function, dissecting protein complexes into functional pathways, and exploring the mechanistic underpinnings of common human diseases. Although synthetic sickness and lethality are the most studied types of genetic interactions in yeast, only a small proportion of gene pairs have been tested for genetic interactions due to the large number of possible combinations. To expand the set of known synthetic lethal (SL) interactions, a new integrative multi-network approach has been developed. This approach, which significantly improves upon existing approaches, defines a large number of features for characterizing the relationships between pairs of genes from various data sources and uses these features to develop a non-parametric multi-classifier system for predicting SL interactions. This allows for the simultaneous use of multiple classification procedures and leads to an improved performance when compared to the current state of the art method. This approach has been used to derive the first yeast transcription factor genetic interaction network and to predict SL interactions between all non-essential gene pairs in yeast. This integrative approach is expected to be more effective and robust in uncovering new genetic interactions in yeast and higher organisms.
The BRCA Challenge, initiated within the Global Alliance for Genomics and Health, is a long-term data-sharing project that aims to aggregate BRCA1 and BRCA2 data to support collaborative research activities. Its goal is to generate an informed and current understanding of the impact of genetic variation on cancer risk across these iconic cancer predisposition genes. The project has integrated reported variants in BRCA1 and BRCA2 available from public databases into a single site, www.brcaexchange.org, to provide the community with a reliable and easily accessible record of variants interpreted for a high-penetrance phenotype. The BRCA Exchange has aggregated over 20,000 variants, of which approximately 7,250 have expert classifications. The data set is based on shared information from existing clinical databases, such as Breast Cancer Information Core (BIC), ClinVar, and the Leiden Open Variation Database (LOVD), as well as population databases, all linked to a single point of access. The BRCA Challenge has brought together the existing international Evidence-based Network for the Interpretation of Germline Mutant Alleles (ENIGMA) consortium expert panel, along with expert clinicians, diagnosticians, researchers, and database providers, to advance the understanding of BRCA1 and BRCA2 variation. The BRCA Challenge's ongoing work includes encouraging data sharing from national centers with access to BRCA1 and BRCA2 diagnostic data, developing methods for extraction of genetic variation at the level of individual laboratory reports, and engaging with participant communities to enable a more comprehensive understanding of the clinical significance of genetic variation in BRCA1 and BRCA2. The BRCA Challenge is an essential initiative that aims to facilitate the sharing of BRCA1 and BRCA2 data to advance our understanding of the impact of genetic variation on cancer risk and to provide valuable insights for clinical decision-making.
Malaria, caused by the parasite Plasmodium, is a significant global health threat, leading to about one million human deaths annually. Plasmodium has a complex life cycle in both humans and mosquitoes, requiring rapid adaptation to various environments. Maintaining redox balance is crucial for Plasmodium's survival, as it is constantly exposed to reactive oxygen species. A recent study systematically analyzed the subcellular localization of major antioxidant and redox regulatory proteins in Plasmodium falciparum, creating the first complete map of redox compartmentation. Notably, two plasmodial peroxiredoxins and a putative glyoxalase system were targeted to the apicoplast, a non-photosynthetic plastid. Alternative-translation-initiation (ATI) is used for differential targeting of two major antioxidant redox-enzymes, glutathione reductase and thioredoxin reductase, possibly opening new avenues for therapeutic intervention. Malaria parasites are vulnerable to disruptions in redox equilibrium during their erythrocytic life stages, making these findings particularly relevant for drug development.
PUMA, a member of the BH3-only protein family, is an intrinsically disordered protein that binds to its cellular partner Mcl-1 through its BH3 motif, which folds upon binding into an α helix. A structure-based coarse-grained model with an explicit Debye—Hückel charge model was used to study the importance of electrostatic interactions in the early and later stages of this model coupled folding and binding process. The model was calibrated with experimental data on helical content and affinity and shown to be consistent with previously published experimental data on binding rate changes with respect to ionic strength. The results suggest that intramolecular electrostatic interactions only marginally influence the unbound states of PUMA, while intermolecular electrostatic interactions, particularly non-native electrostatic interactions, are involved in the formation of the initial encounter complex. The simulation strategy provides residue level detail for the mechanism of this modeled coupled folding and binding process, including the role of non-native electrostatic contacts in the formation of the encounter complex. The study highlights the potential importance of such electrostatic interactions for describing the binding reactions of IDPs and could be used to provide predictions for the results of mutational studies.
Polycomb Group (PcG) proteins are conserved chromatin factors that maintain the silencing of key developmental genes outside of their expression domains. They localize in structures called Polycomb (PC) bodies within the cell nucleus and bind to specific PcG response elements (PREs) in the genome. Genome-wide analyses have shown that PREs form local and long-range spatial networks and PC bodies mainly correspond to 3D structural counterparts of the linear genomic domains identified in genome-wide studies. Immunostaining, immuno-FISH, and live imaging of GFP fusion proteins have been used to analyze the formation and mobility of PC bodies during fly embryogenesis. These studies have shown that PC bodies and chromatin domains containing H2Av-GFP undergo long-range motions that may correspond to the movement of whole chromosome territories and each PC body and chromatin domain has its own fast and highly constrained motion. PC bodies move within volumes slightly larger than those of condensed chromatin domains and both types of domains move within volumes much smaller than chromosome territories, restricting their possibility of interaction with other nuclear structures. The fast motion of PC bodies and chromatin domains observed during early embryogenesis decreases in late developmental stages, indicating a possible contribution of chromatin dynamics in the maintenance of stable gene silencing. The binding of regulatory factors to chromatin and specific post-translational histone modifications are crucial for the biological mechanisms that allow one genome to translate into the many epigenomes that characterize different cell types. In Drosophila, PcG proteins are recruited to chromatin through PRE sequences which can be located several tens of kilobases away from their target genes. PREs recruit the PRC2 complex, which trimethylates lysine 27 of histone H3 (H3K27me3), a mark that is recognized by PcG proteins of the PRC1 complex, such as PC and PH, to bring about gene silencing. H3K27me3 and its associated silencing mediated by Polycomb group (PcG) proteins play a crucial role by repressing key developmental regulators in embryonic stem cells.
MtDNA mutations are implicated in the aging process, but there is no universally accepted method for their accurate quantification. Ultra-deep sequencing was used to study genome-wide mtDNA mutation load in the liver of normally- and prematurely-aging mice. MtDNA point mutation loads were 10-times-higher in mtDNA mutator mice, who also had increased levels of a truncated linear mtDNA molecule and decreased sequence coverage in the deleted region. However, circular mtDNA molecules with large deletions occurred at extremely low frequencies in mtDNA mutator mice, indicating they do not drive the premature aging phenotype. Most somatic mtDNA mutations in mice occur as replication errors during development and do not result from damage accumulation in adult life. A decline of mitochondrial function has been observed in a variety of aging mammalian tissues, but the relative contribution of each of the different types of mtDNA mutations to the aging process remains unknown.
The anaerobic bacterium Fusobacterium nucleatum utilizes glutamate decarboxylation to create a transmembrane sodium ion gradient, which is directly coupled to ATP synthesis via an F1Fo-ATP synthase containing a novel sodium recognition motif. This is shared by other human pathogens. The rotary element of the enzyme, the c-ring, has been shown through molecular modeling, free-energy simulations, and X-ray crystallography to specifically recognize sodium ions. The c-ring features two carboxylates for ion binding, which allows for a proton to be concurrently bound to all sites, although sodium ions alone drive the rotary mechanism. This new mode of ion coupling in ATP synthases provides a basis for drug-design efforts against this opportunistic pathogen. The ATP synthase is a crucial enzyme for ATP synthesis in biological cells, and this study elucidates the specific mechanism of sodium ion coupling in the ATP synthase of F. nucleatum.
In the initiation of adaptive cellular immunity, the recognition of foreign peptides bound to major histocompatibility complex (pMHC) molecules on antigen presenting cells (APCs) by αβ T cell receptor (TCR) is crucial. High-affinity binding and/or long-lived interactions between TCRs and pMHC in vitro have been shown to correlate with high-potency T cell activation. However, less is known about the influence of TCR/pMHC interaction parameters on T cell responses in vivo. A study was conducted to understand this by tracking CD4+ T cell activation, effector, and memory responses to immunization with peptides exhibiting a range of TCR/pMHC half-lives and in vitro T cell activation potencies. The study found that optimal in vivo T cell responses occur to ligands with intermediate TCR/pMHC half-lives. The diminished in vivo responses observed to the ligand exhibiting the longest TCR/pMHC half-life were associated with attenuation of intracellular signaling, expansion, and function over a broad range of time points. These results reveal a level of control over T cell activation in vivo not recapitulated in in vitro assays and highlight the importance of considering in vivo efficacy of TCR ligands as part of vaccine design.
Nectria haematococca, also known by its asexual name Fusarium solani, is a member of the Fusarium solani species complex, a group of over 50 phylogenetic species capable of colonizing various environments, including forests, scrub communities, savannahs, prairies, swamps, littoral zones, coastal zones, deserts, and even highly radioactive inner parts of damaged nuclear reactors. N. haematococca MPVI, one of the members of this complex, has a diverse range of habitats due to its genetic plasticity and metabolic diversity, with genes on supernumerary chromosomes contributing to its adaptability. These supernumerary chromosomes have more repeat sequences, are enriched in unique and duplicated genes, and have a lower G+C content compared to other chromosomes. The genome of N. haematococca MPVI has 17 chromosomes and a physical size of 54.43 Mb, the largest reported for ascomycetes. Its genome encodes 15,707 genes, with many of these genes not present in other fungi or present as multiple copies, possibly resulting from gene duplication events or horizontal gene transfer. These additional genes may account for individual isolates having different environmental niches and contribute to the species' diverse range of habitats.
The egress of newly assembled herpesvirus particles from infected cells is a dynamic process involving the host secretory pathway and viral components. A live-cell fluorescence microscopy method was developed to visualize the final transport and exocytosis of pseudorabies virus (PRV) particles in non-polarized epithelial cells using total internal reflection fluorescence (TIRF) microscopy. This method revealed that individual virus particles travel to the plasma membrane inside small acidified secretory vesicles, which undergo fast, directional transport directly to the site of exocytosis near patches of LL5β, part of a complex that anchors microtubules to the plasma membrane. Rab GTPases, key regulators of the plasma membrane-directed secretory pathway, are present on the virus secretory vesicle. After exocytosis, particles remain tightly confined on the outer cell surface. These findings provide new insights into the mechanisms of alpha herpesvirus egress and contribute to our understanding of the interactions between viruses and host cells.
A study was conducted to examine the impact of Enterobius exposure on the composition of gut microflora and its interactions with the host immune responses in a prospective cohort of 109 primary school-aged children. The children were divided into pinworm-negative and pinworm-positive groups, and stool samples were collected from the pinworm-infected individuals before and after administration of mebendazole. The results showed that pinworm infection and mebendazole deworming were associated with a decreased relative abundance of Fusobacteria and an increased proportion of Actinobacteria at the phylum level. At the genus level, the relative abundance of the probiotic Bifidobacterium increased after enterobiasis and mebendazole treatment. The intestinal SIgA level was found to be lower in the pinworm-infected group, and was increased in half of the individuals after mebendazole deworming treatment. The study suggests that childhood exposure to pinworm plus mebendazole is associated with increased bacterial diversity, an increased abundance of Actinobacteria including the probiotic Bifidobacterium, and a decreased proportion of Fusobacteria. The gut SIgA level was lower in the pinworm-infected group, and was increased in half of the individuals after mebendazole deworming treatment. The immunomodulatory roles of helminth have been well studied, and it has been suggested that helminth infections may increase intestinal bacterial diversity and alter the composition of microbiota. Recent studies have shown that gut microbiota is suspected as causing T helper type 1 (Th1) responses in Trichuris muris infections in mice, and Schistosoma mansoni has been suggested to cause Th1-mediated inflammation and granuloma formation via alteration of microbiota. Therefore, the net immunomodulatory effect of pinworm on an individual may be dependent on its interaction with that individual’s intestinal microbiota.
The genetic basis of complex traits, such as root length in Arabidopsis thaliana, is often studied using the assumption that most genetic variance is additive. However, a study examining the genetics of A. thaliana root length found that the genomic narrow-sense heritability for this trait was statistically zero, indicating that the genetic variation is not due to additive effects but rather epistatic interactions. Four interacting pairs of loci were revealed, involving seven chromosomal loci, but these were not detected using standard additive-model-based genome-wide association approaches. The use of statistical epistasis analyses was indispensable for confirming known and identifying new candidate genes for root length in this population of wild-collected A. thaliana accessions. This study highlights the importance of considering non-additive variation and using statistical epistasis approaches to fully understand the genetic architecture of complex traits. The current quantitative genetics paradigm is based on the assumption of additive gene action, but there is increasing evidence that non-additive effects are crucial to many, if not most, biological systems. Despite this, the focus on additive variation alone can leave a considerable amount of genetic variance unexplored. Statistical epistasis has been shown to be pervasive in both humans and model organisms, but epistatic contributions to complex traits have primarily been identified using candidate gene approaches and QTL mapping. Genome-wide association (GWA) analyses have emerged as an effective method for mapping loci underlying phenotypic variation, but GWA analyses to detect epistatic interactions are still under-utilized. GWA analyses to detect epistatic interactions are important for identifying novel loci, enhancing sensitivity in statistical analyses, selecting the most promising analytical approaches and experimental designs, and providing insights into the genetic and biological mechanisms that can lead to non-additive genetic variance and genotype-phenotype relationships. Public resources have been developed for studying genotype-phenotype associations with GWA analyses in model organisms such as A. thaliana and Drosophila melanogaster. However, there are challenges in using epistatic interactions in natural populations, including the cost and time to collect large datasets, the lack of power due to noisy phenotypes, and the difficulties in performing necessary follow-up studies to replicate the epistatic associations.
In this study, researchers analyzed over 30,000 human mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) sequences to examine the relationship between inherited mtDNA mutations and genetic background. They found that the clinical presentation of certain pathogenic mtDNA mutations is associated with a specific background mtDNA haplogroup, and that mutations tend to be more frequent on younger sequences and in genomes with two or more disease-causing mutations. The researchers also found that mutations were more common on specific haplogroup backgrounds, either due to a founder effect or recurrent mutation events within the same phylogenetic cluster. These findings suggest that the mtDNA background plays a role in recurrent mutation events that have been purified through natural selection in older populations, which could explain the low frequency of mtDNA disease reported in specific ethnic groups. Overall, this research highlights the importance of considering the genetic background when studying mtDNA mutations and their associated diseases.
In collective cell migration, cells move in a coordinated manner for various biological functions such as immune system development, early embryo development, and cancer invasion. Cell-cell interactions can create new dynamics not seen in individual crawling cells, such as fingering instabilities, emergent chemotaxis, and leader cells. Contact inhibition of locomotion (CIL) is a well-studied cell-cell interaction where a cell changes direction after contact with another cell. This phenomenon plays a crucial role in the coordination of collective migration in various systems. To analyze CIL in vitro, collision assays are used, where the velocity of pairs of cells before and after collision is measured. However, these assays can have low efficiency due to rare cell-cell collisions. Recent studies have developed 1D collision assays, where cell motion is restricted to an adhesive micropatterned stripe, increasing efficiency and ensuring a reproducible collision geometry. These assays can help study outcomes of cell-cell collisions and identify critical molecular mediators of CIL. In this context, a computational model was developed to evaluate the chemical and mechanical factors that control the interactions of motile, eukaryotic cells exhibiting CIL on narrow micropatterned stripes. The model, based on a phase field technique, simulates a large number of cell-cell collisions on narrow micropatterned stripes to probe which properties in the cell-cell interactions are responsible for the different outcomes observed in experiments. The model considers cell polarity, interface tension, and bending modulus, as well as cell-cell adhesion and volume exclusion. Chemical concentrations within the cell are modeled with reaction-diffusion equations, while for Rho GTPase Rac dynamics, a minimal model is used to describe the dynamics of a polarity protein. CIL is incorporated through the assumption that cell-cell contact leads to local generation or activation of a Rac inhibitor. The simulations can reproduce all experimental observed cell-cell collision cases (reversal, sticking, walk past, and chaining) by varying only four parameters: adhesion strength σ, critical overlap Ocrit, and the CR and FR strengths kCR and kFR. The relative importance of these parameters and their impact on the collision outcomes are further explored through parameter sweeps, with a focus on the width of the adhesive stripe, d, which can be easily varied in experiments. The modeling results predict that varying d strongly affects the walk-past transition, revealing that decreasing the stripe width can strongly decrease the walk-past rate, and this transition is sharp. Overall, the computational model provides insights into the mechanical and chemical factors that control cell-cell interactions during collisions, which can help understand and manipulate collective cell migration in various systems.
The dissociation mechanism of thioredoxin (Trx) mixed disulfide complexes has been a topic of debate for over twenty years. A specific point of contention is the activation of the nucleophilic cysteine as a thiolate during the dissociation of the complex. A study using the complex between Trx and its endogenous substrate, arsenate reductase (ArsC), as a model found that conformational changes around the intermediate disulfide bring Cys32Trx in contact with Cys29Trx, activating it for nucleophilic attack. Cys32Trx was found to be more reactive than Cys82ArsC and directs its nucleophilic attack on the more susceptible Cys29Trx and not on Cys89ArsC. This information provides new insights into a universal thiol/disulfide exchange reaction mechanism that results in reduced substrate and oxidized Trx. Thioredoxin is a powerful and universal protein disulfide bond oxido-reductase with a very low redox potential. It has a conserved active-site loop containing two redox-active cysteine residues. These cysteines have a low pKa, which enables thioredoxin to act as a nucleophile, attacking disulfides in proteins. Arsenate reductases (ArsC) are endogenous substrates of Trx and are involved in arsenic detoxification. ArsC catalyzes the reduction of arsenate to arsenite and involves a phosphatase-like nucleophilic displacement reaction in the active site with a distinct intra-molecular disulfide-bond cascade. After a single catalytic arsenate reduction event, oxidized ArsC exposes a disulfide between Cys82 and Cys89 on a looped-out redox helix. Thioredoxin converts oxidized ArsC back to its initial reduced state through a series of reactions involving mixed disulfide intermediates. The exact mechanism behind the regioselectivity of these reactions is not fully understood and is the subject of ongoing research.
A study was conducted to examine the uncertainty and updating of tastes in temporal discounting, the extent to which a person prefers a temporally proximal reward over a distal one. The study used the 'Delegated Interpersonal Discounting (DID)' task, which involves three phases: in phase 1, subjects made a series of temporal discounting decisions; in phase 2, they learned to make choices expressed by another simulated participant; and in phase 3, they made more choices for themselves and the other. The study found that participants' choices were better accounted for by a random-taste model than by a response-noise model and that their apparent taste shifts were well described by a Bayesian model taking into account taste uncertainty and the relevance of social information. The findings have neuroscientific, clinical, and developmental significance, as they suggest that people can learn about their tastes by considering evidence such as the preferences of relevant others and updating their beliefs accordingly.
"In budding yeast, filamentous growth is a complex differentiation response that occurs under specific environmental conditions and is regulated by multiple pathways, including the RAS, RIM101, OPI1, and RTG pathways. A novel screening approach, secretion profiling, was used to identify new regulators of filamentous growth by measuring the release of the extracellular domain of Msb2p, the signaling mucin that functions at the head of the filamentous growth (FG) MAPK pathway. The results showed that many of the pathways that regulate filamentous growth are also required for FG pathway activation, sensitizing the FG pathway to multiple stimuli and synchronizing it to the global signaling network. Several of the regulators were required for MSB2 expression, identifying the MSB2 promoter as a target ""hub"" where multiple signals converge. The histone deacetylase (HDAC) Rpd3p positively regulates FG pathway activity and filamentous growth by further regulating accessibility to the MSB2 promoter. These findings provide the first glimpse of a global regulatory hierarchy among the pathways that control filamentous growth, and systems-level integration of signaling circuitry is likely to coordinate other regulatory networks that control complex behaviors. In metazoan development, a network of interactions between evolutionarily conserved pathways like Notch and EGFR coordinates every facet of cell growth and differentiation, and miscommunication between pathways is an underlying cause of diseases such as cancer."
A study was conducted to understand the role of changes in gene expression in the evolution of divergent morphologies using a model system of five filamentous fungi in the Sordariomycetes. The fungi were cultured in a common garden environment, and genome-wide gene expression was profiled at five developmental stages. Ancestral gene expression phenotypes were reconstructed, and genes with the largest evolved increases in gene expression across development were identified. Knockouts and phenotypic analysis of two divergent species demonstrated altered fruiting body development in the species that had evolved increased expression. This evolutionary approach proved to be more efficient than other gene deletion studies in identifying relevant genes. Combining gene expression measurements with knockout phenotypes facilitated the refinement of Bayesian networks of genes underlying fruiting body development.Changes in gene regulation have been argued to play a greater role than changes in protein function in the evolution of complex phenotypes. Many examples of interspecies variation in the phenotype of gene expression have been identified, many of which can be linked to the evolution of higher, more complex phenotypes. Estimation of gene expression phenotypes in ancestral lineages provides a means of identifying putative changes in gene expression that may be key to morphological and adaptive innovation. Identification of the changes in the genetic network architecture underlying altered ancestral expression and regulation could open up the “black box” linking genotype to phenotype through development, revealing relevant gene network modularity and identifying the origins of diversity.Genomic techniques for measuring gene expression offer the opportunity to comprehensively evaluate the relationship of gene expression to morphology. Fungi represent a great model for addressing this challenge as they are typically heterotrophic generalists, genome sequences of a large number of fungal species are now available, genes are well annotated, and experimental validation can be performed on many fungi via functional approaches.The fruiting bodies of fungi offer a degree of multicellular developmental complexity, including tissue differentiation, that represent a good model for more complex multicellular eukaryotes. The genetics of sexual development in the ascomycetous filamentous fungi has been studied extensively using saprotrophic model organisms such as Neurospora crassa, Aspergillus nidulans, and Sordaria spp. and in the plant pathogen Fusarium graminearum. Neurospora and Fusarium species belong to the orders Sordariales and Hypocreales, respectively, of the Sordariomycetes and produce complex, flask-shaped fruiting bodies called perithecia.The fruiting bodies harbor the meiospores (ascospores) within cellular sacs called asci, which function as cellular cannons to forcibly discharge spores into the air. Asci are formed from ascogenous hyphae, products of mating in self-incompatible species or self-fertilization in self-compatible species. Thus, fruiting bodies have a role in sexual recombination but also provide an effective means to local and long-distance dispersal.The ecology of Neurospora and Fusarium spp. provides an opportunity to relate developmental evolution to their ecology. Perithecia of Neurospora spp. and Fusarium spp. have retained shared common features such as the ascus structure. While transcriptional and morphological divergence among N. crassa, N. tetrasperma, and N. discreta and between F. graminearum and F. verticillioides have been previously examined, the two genera have not been compared.The genera differ significantly in morphology. Fusarium spp. feature a noticeable stroma: a mass of often darkly pigmented pseudoparenchyma tissue from which the perithecia emerge. In contrast, the perithecia of Neurospora lack a stroma. In addition, the ontogeny of the paraphyses differs between the two genera. Neurospora species develop an extended ostiole, or ‘beak’, while Fusarium species do not.The evolution of new phenotypes requires alteration of the developmental process, which in turn requires alteration of interactions within and among gene modules. Reverse genetics can be guided by genomic assays, such as gene expression profiling, and provide contextual clues to gene interactions and modules that are relevant to phenotypes and their evolution.In this study, comprehensive profiling of gene expression across developmental stages has been conducted in three species of Neurospora and two species of Fusarium. Gene expression levels were measured during perithecium development in Neurospora spp. and Fusarium spp. Of the 4668 single copy orthologs, one or more reads were identified for 4490 orthologs for all five species across all sample points for all stages.Fundamental cellular processes exhibited common patterns among sister species. For instance, mitochondrial ribosomal gene expression was upregulated during initial stages of perithecial development, and expression of nuclear ribosomal genes peaked during formation of the asci.Hypothesizing that genes whose expression increased substantially in one lineage during divergence of Fusarium and Neurospora are important to the evolution of morphological differences between these genera, genes were ranked in each lineage by differences in expression between the most recent common ancestor of the two Fusarium species and the MRCA of the three Neurospora species, providing a candidate gene knockout prioritization list.Knockouts of genes that recently underwent an increase in expression were hypothesized to exhibit phenotypes during sexual development, in particular at the stages of morphological divergence where the increase occurs. Therefore, the stage of each knockout phenotype obtained was defined as the first stage in which a definitive aberrant phenotype was observed.In F. graminearum, knockouts of genes that recently underwent an increase in expression exhibited phenotypes during sexual development, in particular at the stages of morphological divergence where the increase occurs.In conclusion, the study provides evidence for the role of changes in gene expression in the evolution of divergent morphologies using a model system of five filamentous fungi in the Sordariomycetes. The findings demonstrate the utility of combining gene expression measurements with knockout phenotypes to refine the understanding of the genetic networks underlying fruiting body development. Understanding the genetic basis of morphological evolution is a fundamental question in biology, and the findings of this study contribute to our understanding of the genetic underpinnings of phenotypic diversity.
Schistosomiasis is a tropical disease for which current control efforts rely heavily on the drug praziquantel. However, the large genomes of schistosomes and the limitations of in vitro culture systems pose challenges for genetic manipulation and germ line transgenesis. A recent study investigated the utility of square wave electroporation to deliver transgenes and other macromolecules into eggs of Schistosoma mansoni. The study found that electroporation was more effective than soaking alone for transduction of schistosome eggs by messenger RNA encoding luciferase and by pseudotyped retrovirus virions. Transgenes were successfully introduced into the schistosome egg, with electroporation resulting in 2-3 times as many copies of provirus in larval schistosomes compared to soaking alone. These findings highlight the potential of targeting the schistosome egg for germ line transgenesis. Despite the abundance of schistosome genome sequence data, functional analysis of potential target genes is not yet possible. The development of reliable methods for reverse genetics in schistosomes is a key goal for future research. The entire developmental cycle of human schistosomes cannot be maintained in vitro, but laboratory maintenance of the developmental cycles of all three human schistosomes can be accomplished using rodents as the mammalian host and the intermediate host snails. Schistosome eggs can be obtained from livers of experimentally infected rodents, and miracidia obtained from these eggs are infectious for the intermediate host. In vitro culture of eggs is possible for at least one week. The study explored the introduction of transgenes and other macromolecules into eggs of S. mansoni by square wave electroporation and found that electroporation was more efficient than soaking alone. This research underscores the potential of targeting the schistosome egg for germ line transgenesis.
The Perturbation-based Markovian Transmission (PMT) model is a novel approach for studying the dynamic responses of large macromolecular assemblies in cells, which are important for biological processes. The PMT model monitors the responses of all residues simultaneously across many decades of time until equilibrium is reached, using a Krylov subspace projection method. This approach can yield rich information about the system, including the identification of pivot residues that are important for macromolecular movement, messenger residues that are key to signal mediation, and anchor residues that are important for binding interactions. The PMT model has an accuracy of 71-84% in predicting the functionally important residues in the GroEL-GroES chaperone system. The PMT model is a useful tool for studying the dynamic properties of large macromolecular assemblies, including virus capsid and ribosomal complex, and can be applied to other systems.
Fungal galectin, CGL2 from Coprinopsis cinerea, inhibits development, reproduction, and causes death in Caenorhabditis elegans. This toxicity depends on the interaction between CGL2 and a fucose-containing glycoconjugate, specifically a Galβ1, 4Fucα1, 6 modification of C. elegans N-glycan cores. A novel putative glycosyltransferase required for the biosynthesis of this glycoepitope was identified. CGL2 toxicity is dependent on its ability to bind carbohydrates, and the phenotype of CGL2-mediated nematotoxicity is similar to the intoxication of C. elegans induced by feeding with E. coli cells expressing the nematicidal pore-forming crystal toxin Cry5B from Bacillus thuringiensis. The ligand of C. cinerea galectins in C. elegans is different from the Cry5B-ligand but its biosynthesis also relies on fucose biosynthesis. A forward genetic screen for mutations conferring CGL2-resistance in a pmk-1 ( km25 ) mutant genetic background was performed to identify the target glycoconjugate of CGL2 in C. elegans, yielding Mos1-insertions in five different genes: bre-1, ger-1, gly-13, fut-8 and M03F8 . 4. The identified Mos1-insertions are located in 5′-untranslated regions, at an exon-intron junction, and in exons. bre-1 and ger-1 code for the GDP-mannose-4,6-dehydratase and GDP-4-keto-6-deoxymannose-3,5-epimerase-4-reductase, respectively, catalyzing the two enzymatic steps in the conversion from GDP-mannose to GDP-fucose. fut-8 encodes the only fucosyltransferase capable of transferring fucose in α1, 6-configuration from GDP-fucose to the asparagine-linked GlcNAc in C. elegans N-glycan cores. Gly-13 codes for the major GlcNAc-transferase I (GnTI) in C. elegans, which transfers GlcNAc in β1, 2-configuration to the α1, 3-linked mannose of pentamannosidic N-glycan. The modification of N-glycans by GnTI is the prerequisite for many of the subsequent modifications of N-glycans including the action of core α1, 6-fucosyltransferase. In C. elegans, GnTI is not required for the core modification by another fucosyltransferase, encoded by the fut-1 gene, which forms the so-called HRP epitope consisting of fucose α1, 3-linked to the core asparagine-linked GlcNAc.
The existence of long-lived reservoirs of latently infected CD4+ T cells is the major barrier to curing HIV. These reservoirs, which are established soon after infection and are long-lived, can lead to delayed evolutionary dynamics within a single host, with longer delays associated with larger relative reservoir sizes and/or homeostatic proliferation of cells within the reservoir. This delay can fundamentally change the dynamics of the virus at the epidemiological scale, allowing for the evolution of intermediate viral loads consistent with maximizing transmission. This effect can be further enhanced if viruses similar to those that initiate infection are preferentially transmitted. These results depend strongly on within-host characteristics such as the relative reservoir size, with the evolution of intermediate viral loads observed only when the within-host dynamics are sufficiently delayed. Therefore, the latent reservoir has important and hitherto under-appreciated roles in both within- and between-host viral evolution.
The paper explores the interaction between viruses and the host's T cell response, with a focus on coxsackievirus B3 (CVB3). The study uses transgenic CD4+ and CD8+ T cells as sensors to evaluate CVB3's antigen presentation in vitro and in vivo. The results show that CVB3 inhibits antigen presentation via the MHC class I pathway, thereby evading CD8+ T cell immunity. However, MHC class II presentation remains unencumbered, leading to phenotypically normal in vivo CD4+ T cell responses. These memory CD4+ T cells expand dramatically following challenge infection and differentiate into secondary effector cells capable of secreting multiple cytokines. The study has implications for the efficiency of antigen cross-presentation during CVB3 infection and the in vivo efficiency of cross-priming. Most viruses are readily detected by host T cells and induce strong T cell responses, but CVB3's ability to evade T cell responses is not complete, and its impact on the host's T cell responses is far from complete. CVB3 is a significant human pathogen that causes severe acute and chronic diseases, particularly in infants, young children, and immunocompromised individuals. It is the most common cause of infectious myocarditis, pancreatitis, and aseptic meningitis. The study's ultimate goal is to map T cell epitopes in the virus and enhance the ability to detect and analyze CVB-specific T cell responses.
Leprosy is a chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, affecting the skin and peripheral nerves. Type 1 reactions (T1Rs) are a major cause of nerve function impairment (NFI) in patients with leprosy, affecting up to 30% of susceptible individuals. They may occur during multi-drug therapy or after completion and are characterized by acute inflammation in skin lesions or nerves or both. T1Rs are treated with oral corticosteroids, but there are few data to support the optimal dose and duration of treatment. A study was conducted to investigate the efficacy of three days of high-dose (1 g) intravenous methylprednisolone at the start of prednisolone therapy in leprosy Type 1 reactions and nerve function impairment. Forty-two individuals were randomized to receive methylprednisolone followed by oral prednisolone or oral prednisolone alone. The study found that individuals treated with methylprednisolone were less likely than those treated with prednisolone alone to experience deterioration in sensory function between day 29 and day 113 of the study. The study also demonstrated that 50% of individuals with Type 1 reactions and/or nerve function impairment required additional prednisolone despite treatment with 16 weeks of corticosteroids. These findings suggest that more prolonged courses of corticosteroid may be necessary to treat Type 1 reactions and that further investigation is needed to identify risk factors for the recurrence of Type 1 reaction and nerve function impairment during and after corticosteroid treatment.
In chronic HIV infection, Treg from HIV infected patients (Treg/HIV+) have a defect in modulating both the differentiation and the expression of PD-1/PD-L1 molecules on HIV-specific CD8 T cells, which may contribute to the exhaustion of HIV-specific T cell responses. Treg/HIV+ showed a reduced ability to inhibit polyclonal autologous CD8+ T cell function and HIV-Gag-specific CD8+ T cells, but inhibited IFN-γ expression of autologous CD8+ T cells stimulated with recall CMV/EBV/Flu antigens. Treg/HIV+ had a lower capacity to suppress HIV-specific CD8+ T cells compared to Treg from HIV-negative controls. These defects in Treg function in HIV infection, along with decreased responsiveness of effector clones and high levels of PD-1/PD-L1 expression, may contribute to the ultimate failure to contain generalized HIV-1–associated immune activation. The impairment in Treg function is specific to HIV-infected individuals and may play a role in HIV pathogenesis.
The lymphatic filarial parasites can survive in the human body for years, thanks to the immunomodulatory strategies they adopt, one of which is the release of glutathione-S-transferases (GSTs) that counteract the oxidative free radicals produced by the host. This study aimed to evaluate the potential of parasite GSTs as vaccine candidates against lymphatic filariasis. The GST gene was cloned from the third stage larval (L3) cDNA libraries of Wuchereria bancrofti and recombinant GST (WbGST) was expressed and purified. Serum samples from individuals living in an endemic area were analyzed, and it was found that sera from endemic normal individuals (EN) carry significant levels of anti-WbGST IgG antibodies compared to subjects who are microfilaraemic (Mf) or show symptoms of clinical pathology (CP). Vaccine potential of rWbGST was evaluated in a jird model, and it was found that approximately 61% protection could be achieved against a B. malayi challenge infection in jirds immunized with rWbGST. Therefore, rWbGST is a potential vaccine candidate against lymphatic filariasis. Lymphatic filariasis is a mosquito-borne infection caused by Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, or Brugia timori that affects 120 million people in 73 countries, and another 1.1 billion people are at risk. Despite the availability of excellent anti-filarial drugs, several rounds of mass treatment are necessary to reduce the levels of infection below those necessary to sustain transmission. Therefore, additional preventive measures such as vector control and vaccine development are crucial to control the infection in endemic regions. A protective role for immunization with GSTs from several helminth parasites has been established, and the schistosome 28 GST has been successfully developed into a vaccine against S. mansoni and S. bovis. The mechanisms underlying the protection conferred following immunization with S. mansoni 28 GST appear to be due to an inactivation of the GST enzymatic activity. Thus, neutralizing the activity of GST may be a strategy to induce protection against certain parasitic infections. Immunization of mice with Fasciola gigantica GST26 could confer from 77–84% protection against challenge infection in mice. Therefore, GST appears to be a critical protein for the survival of the parasite in the host. Based on homology sequences, Nathan et al. constructed the 3D structure of W. bancrofti GST (WbGST) and predicted sites for docking of GST inhibitors as a new approach to develop drugs against W. bancrofti. These studies suggest that WbGST may be a promising target for vaccine development. Therefore, in this study, the vaccine potential of filarial GST was evaluated.
CRISPR-Cas9 technologies have revolutionized genome editing in experimental organisms and hold immense therapeutic potential. However, concerns about off-target effects remain a challenge. Recent studies have used whole-genome sequencing (WGS) of gene-edited embryos or animals to search for de novo mutations (DNMs) as potential off-target changes. However, these studies used strain-matched but not pedigree-matched controls, making it difficult to distinguish generational or colony-related differences from true DNMs. A new study used a trio design and whole-genome sequenced 8 parents and 19 embryos, where 10 of the embryos were mutagenized with well-characterized gRNAs targeting the Tyrosinase (Tyr) locus. The study's findings, published in the journal Nature Communications, suggest that if CRISPR mutagenesis were causing SNV or indel off-target mutations in treated embryos, the number of these mutations is not statistically distinguishable from the background rate of DNMs occurring due to other processes. The results support further efforts to develop CRISPR-Cas9 as a therapeutic tool. The study was performed at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute Research Support Facility under Home Office licensed authority, adhering to the UK Home Office regulations under the Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986.
The stomatal pores present on plant leaf epidermis regulate CO2 uptake for photosynthesis and water loss by transpiration, affecting photosynthesis, water use efficiency, and agricultural crop yields. Blue light, one of the environmental signals that regulates stomatal aperture, is perceived by cryptochromes and phototropins, which activate signal transduction cascades leading to stomatal opening response. Two new players, Hypersensitive to Red and Blue 1 (HRB1) and Protein Phosphatase 7 (PP7), have been identified in the control of stomatal aperture. Both HRB1 and PP7 are expressed in guard cells and interact through the N-terminal ZZ-type zinc finger motif of HRB1 and the catalytic domain of PP7. Blue light increases HRB1 phosphorylation and complex size, but in the pp7 mutant, HRB1 is predominantly phosphorylated, and the size shift is impaired. These findings suggest that HRB1 phosphorylation by PP7 under blue light is essential for proper conformation or the assembly of a functional HRB1 protein complex, providing strategies for plants to enjoy the advantages of both constitutive and ABA-induced protection under water-limiting conditions.

"A recent study used a simple model of hippocampal activity and computational tools from algebraic topology to investigate the formation of a topological connectivity map from neuronal spiking patterns. The researchers varied three parameters in computer simulations of rat trajectories in three topologically and geometrically distinct test environments: firing rate, place field size, and number of neurons. They found that the patterns of neuronal co-firing can convey topological information about the environment in a biologically realistic length of time. The simulations revealed a ""learning region"" that highlights the interplay between the parameters in combining to produce hippocampal states that are more or less adept at map formation. The researchers propose that this learning region provides a coherent theoretical lens through which to view conditions that impair spatial learning by altering place cell firing rates or spatial specificity. The study suggests that the hippocampus creates a topological connectivity map derived from place cell co-firing patterns, and that the information contained in the spike trains is qualitative in nature and can be studied using topological techniques. The researchers hypothesize that although the hippocampal connectivity map could contain additional space encoding mechanisms for geometric information, experiments have demonstrated that smooth geometric variations of the environment produce continuous stretches of the place field layouts that preserve the relative timing between spikes, so that the temporal pattern of spiking remains largely invariant with respect to geometric transformation."
The current model of HCV production involves the assembly of virions on lipid droplets, envelopment at the ER, and egress via the secretory pathway. However, the cellular requirements and molecular mechanisms of HCV secretion are not fully understood. An RNAi analysis of host factors for infectious HCV secretion, combined with live cell imaging of HCV core trafficking, was conducted to gain a detailed understanding of HCV egress. RNAi studies identified multiple components of the secretory pathway, including ER-Golgi trafficking, lipid and protein kinases that regulate budding from the TGN, VAMP1 vesicles and adaptor proteins, and the recycling endosome. Live cell imaging revealed that HCV core traffics to the cell periphery along microtubules and exits the cell via the secretory pathway. Sub-populations of HCV core co-traffic with components of the recycling endosome, and silencing of the recycling endosome component Rab11a results in the accumulation of HCV core at the Golgi. The majority of dynamic core traffics in association with apolipoprotein E (ApoE) and VAMP1 vesicles. This study identifies many new host cofactors of HCV egress, while presenting dynamic studies of HCV core trafficking in infected cells. HCV is a positive-strand RNA virus that contains a single-stranded genome of approximately 9600bp. The genome is translated into a polyprotein, which is processed by viral and host proteases into 3 structural proteins (core and the glycoproteins E1 and E2) and 7 non-structural proteins (p7, NS2, NS3, NS4A, NS4B, NS5A, NS5B). The NS proteins are involved in viral RNA replication and host cell interactions, as well as HCV assembly. NS2 is a central regulator in capsid assembly and acts as a scaffold to coordinate interactions between the structural and non-structural proteins leading to viral RNA encapsidation. Capsid envelopment occurs at the ER in close juxtaposition to lipid droplets (LDs), and HCV particles are infectious upon envelopment and appear to be secreted from the cell in association with distinct lipid and apolipoprotein associations. The egress of HCV through the secretory pathway is less clear, but it is distinct from the flaviviruses in that HCV particles are infectious upon envelopment and appear to be secreted from the cell in association with distinct lipid and apolipoprotein associations. HCV particles circulating in the blood of infected patients are rich in triglycerides, ApoB, and ApoE, and cell culture-derived virus also has a broad range of buoyant densities, with the lower density fractions containing virus highly infectious virus. Purified HCV virions have diverse morphologies ranging from 30-125 nm and a lipid composition resembling very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL). The VLDL synthesis pathway has been implicated in infectious HCV secretion. Small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) or inhibitors that target components of VLDL synthesis, including microsomal triglyceride transfer protein, ApoB, and ApoE inhibit infectious HCV secretion. This study is a continuation of two previous RNAi studies in which membrane trafficking pathways were interrogated for their roles in HCV entry and replication. A unique siRNA library was used to identify siRNAs that inhibited infectious extracellular HCV accumulation in a primary screen and then re-tested in secondary assays to identify the stage of the life cycle that they influenced. Genes involved in entry had a secondary phenotype in inhibiting HCVpp infection and genes involved in HCV replication had a defect in subgenomic replicon replication. The primary screen was performed by electroporating four individual siRNAs per gene into Huh-7.5 cells and then allowing silencing for 48 or 72 hours before infection with HCV. Viral supernatants were collected at two days
In this study, the role of imprinted genes in tumorigenesis was examined using mice with heterozygous mutations in the Neurofibromatosis I tumor suppressor gene (NF1) to model radiotherapy-associated second malignant neoplasms. Expression analysis of tumor cell lines established from these mouse models identified Grb10 expression as widely absent. Grb10 is an imprinted gene, and polymorphism analysis of cell lines and primary tumors demonstrated that the expressed allele is commonly lost in diverse Nf1 mutant tumors. Functional studies revealed that Grb10 restoration in Nf1 mutant tumors decreases proliferation, decreases soft agar colony formation, and downregulates Ras signaling. Additionally, Grb10 loss independently promotes Ras pathway hyperactivation, which promotes hyperproliferation, an early feature of tumor development. These findings suggest a novel role for an imprinted gene in tumorigenesis and demonstrate that mutations in imprinted genes should be considered with regard to parental origin.
A study was conducted to investigate human autonomic nervous system (ANS) responses to conditioned stimuli during Pavlovian fear conditioning, a type of associative learning. The study used a statistical framework for psychophysiological modeling to obtain precise, trial-by-trial, single-subject estimates of ANS responses, specifically skin conductance responses (SCR) and pupil size responses (PSR).
