Three experiments were conducted, and a probabilistic learning model best explained ANS responses for both SCR and PSR. The SCR tracked a mixture of expected outcome and uncertainty, while PSR tracked expected outcome alone. The study provides evidence that the formation and maintenance of Pavlovian threat predictions in humans may rely on probabilistic inference and includes estimation of uncertainty. These findings could inform theories of neural implementation of aversive learning.
The septation initiation network (SIN) and the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway are two essential signaling pathways in the filamentous fungus Aspergillus nidulans, involved in cell growth, reproduction, and response to environmental stress. The SIN pathway, composed of a SepH kinase cascade, plays a crucial role in septation and conidiation, while the MAPK pathway depends on a successive signaling cascade phosphorylation to sense and respond to stress and environmental factors. A recent study identified a SepH suppressor, PomA, in A. nidulans, which acts as a negative regulator of septation and conidiation. The pomA mutant can cure defects of sepH1 in septation and conidiation, and overexpression of pomA significantly suppresses septation. Under normal cultural conditions, SepH positively regulates the phosphorylation of MAPK-HogA, while PomA reversely affects this process. In the absence of PbsB, PomA and SepH are unable to affect the phosphorylation level of HogA. Under osmotic stress conditions, induced phosphorylated HogA is capable of bypassing the requirement of SepH, but not the whole SIN requirement. These findings suggest that crosstalk exists between the SIN and MAPK pathways, and PomA and SepH indirectly regulate HogA phosphorylation through affecting HogA-P upstream kinases. Overall, this study provides insights into the regulatory mechanisms of the SIN and MAPK pathways in fungal cells and the crosstalk between these two pathways.
Tegumentary Leishmaniasis (TL) is widely distributed in 98 countries, with approximately 1.5 million people affected annually and Brazil being one of the six countries with the highest incidence. TL is endemic in all regions of Brazil, with the highest incidence in the northern region, including the Amazon rainforest, where seven species of Leishmania have been identified. TL clinical manifestations range from cutaneous to mucosal and diffuse leishmaniasis. While the pathogenesis of TL is not fully understood, recent studies suggest that the presence of Leishmania RNA virus 1 (LRV1) in Leishmania (Leishmania) braziliensis and Leishmania (Viannia) guyanensis is associated with the severity of mucosal leishmaniasis (ML). A study of 156 patients with various forms of TL in Rondonia, Brazil, found that 77.6% were infected with L. braziliensis, 11.5% with L. guyanensis, and 1.8% with L. lainsoni. LRV1 was detected in L. braziliensis, L. guyanensis, L. amazonensis, and L. lainsoni. A case-control study of 147 patients with cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) and ML found that the relative risk of patients with positive LRV1 mucosal lesions (39.30%) was 2.93 times higher than those with negative LRV1 mucosal lesions (12.30%). However, other factors, such as the genetic characteristics of the host and parasite virulence, may also contribute to the emergence of mucosal lesions. Studies with clinical follow-up are needed to confirm the involvement of the virus in the pathogenesis of the disease and the possible role of LRV in the metabolism of the parasite.
Streptococcus pneumoniae infections can lead to bacterial pneumonia, sepsis, and meningitis, with high morbidity and mortality rates. Type I interferon (IFN-I) plays a role in host defense against pneumococci by preventing bacteria from transmigrating from the lung to the blood. Mice that lack the IFN-I receptor or are treated with a neutralizing antibody against the IFN-I receptor develop bacteremia following intranasal pneumococcal infection, while mice treated with IFNβ or IFN-I-inducing synthetic double-stranded RNA show reduced bacteremia. IFN-I upregulates tight junction proteins and downregulates the pneumococcal uptake receptor, PAF receptor, reducing pneumococcal cell invasion and transmigration across epithelial and endothelial layers. Pneumococci can migrate from the nasopharynx to the lungs, and IFN-I regulates both receptor-mediated transcytosis and pericellular migration of pneumococci across epithelial barriers. The IFN-I family consists of multiple IFNα and a single IFNβ protein, which promote an anti-inflammatory response during infection. IFN-I production depends on pneumococcal uptake and the presence of pneumolysin in macrophages and intracellular bacterial DNA and NOD2 in lung epithelial cells. Intranasal administration of IFNβ protects mice against systemic disease following intranasal infection with pneumococci.
A study demonstrates the capability of neural networks with a single plastic layer utilizing reward modulated spike time dependent plasticity (STDP) in learning simple foraging tasks. The research further explores the use of a network of spiking neurons with multiple plastic layers for advanced pattern discrimination and continuous learning. The network utilizes both reward modulated and non-reward modulated STDP, and implements multiple mechanisms for homeostatic regulation of synaptic efficacy, including heterosynaptic plasticity, gain control, output balancing, activity normalization of rewarded STDP, and hard limits on synaptic strength. The study finds that the addition of a hidden layer of neurons employing non-rewarded STDP creates neurons that respond to specific combinations of inputs, performing basic classification of the input patterns. When combined with a following layer of neurons implementing rewarded STDP, the network is able to learn discrimination between rewarding patterns and those designated as punishing, even in the absence of labeled training data. The network is able to learn and respond to an ever changing environment. Biologically inspired neural networks can perform sophisticated information processing similar to the human and animal brains. Most learning models employ Hebbian type learning principles, but the most promising model of learning at the synaptic level is spike time dependent plasticity (STDP), where the synapse increases or decreases in strength based on the firing of presynaptic and post synaptic cells. Heavily studied is the visual sensory pathway, but the stages at which visual learning occurs and the plasticity mechanisms operating at different processing steps are still a matter of controversy. Most learning models have been successful without considering cellular level mechanisms, but a deeper understanding of how learning at the cellular level gives rise to learning at the level of animal behavior is still needed. The study provides important insights into the properties of a spiking neuronal network with STDP that is sufficient to solve a complex foraging task involving pattern classification and decision making.
During pregnancy, the ETS transcription factor ELF5 establishes the milk-secreting alveolar cell lineage in the mammary gland by driving a cell fate decision in mammary luminal progenitor cells. In breast cancer, ELF5 plays a crucial role in determining tumor subtype and has been implicated in the development of insensitivity to anti-estrogen therapy. In a mouse model of luminal breast cancer, increased ELF5 levels drove metastasis by co-opting the innate immune system, specifically by recruiting myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) and promoting vasculogenesis and angiogenesis. These findings suggest that ELF5 may be a defining factor in the acquisition of the lethal phenotype in luminal A breast cancer, which is a heterogeneous disease with subtypes that predict differential clinical outcomes based on shared patterns of gene expression and mutation.The cell of origin, including the basal ER- and luminal ER+ breast cancer subtypes, plays a crucial role in determining the phenotypic dichotomy between ER+ and ER- cancers. The ETS transcription factor ELF5 is a key determinant of cell fate decisions made by mammary progenitor cells and is influenced by hormonal control and paracrine signals. In luminal breast cancer cells, a mutual negative-regulatory loop occurs between ER and ELF5, while ER- basal breast cancers are characterized by high ELF5 levels and stem-cell–like claudin-low subgroups do not express ELF5. Knockdown of ELF5 levels in luminal breast cancer cells has a small effect on proliferation, but a much greater effect is seen in ER- basal cell lines. Importantly, ELF5 levels rise in luminal breast cancer cells that acquire antiestrogen resistance, and resistant cells become dependent on ELF5 for their proliferation, providing an escape pathway from inhibition of proliferation by antiestrogen therapy and facilitating disease progression.ELF5 influences phenotypic plasticity, which regulates the acquisition of invasive and motile characteristics to cancer cells. The innate immune system plays a crucial role in the interaction between the tumor and the host immune system. Myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) are a group of immature neutrophils that have been identified as mediators of vasculogenesis and metastasis. In the MMTV-PyMT mouse mammary model of breast cancer, increased TGF beta signaling caused MDSC recruitment to primary tumors, which delayed the development of lung metastases when depleted and increased the number of lung metastases when tumor cells were co-inoculated with MDSCs.In a mouse model of mammary-specific ELF5 expression in the context of luminal mammary cancer, induced ELF5 expression produced tumors that were detected earlier but took longer to reach the ethical endpoint. Forced Elf5 expression reduced cancer cell proliferation, motility, invasion, and mesenchymal characteristics, corresponding with reduced primary tumor growth in the MMTV-PyMT mouse mammary cancer model. However, induction of ELF5 caused widespread tumor hemorrhage, resulting in higher vascular density with finer and more branched vessels, elevated CD31 endothelial cell content, and increased blood vessel permeability. The ability of Elf5 to induce an angiogenic response in the PyMT tumors was analyzed using an independent experimental system, which revealed an aberrant leaky vasculature. Induction of ELF5 greatly increased the amount of PyMT-mRNA present in blood, suggesting increased numbers of circulating tumor cells. Elf5's metastasis-promoting effect was comparable to that produced by pregnancy in this model. In vivo, these effects are coupled with the immune system, indicating the importance of the immune system in the ELF5-driven response.
Recent experiments reveal that chromatin looping interactions are not local but can involve multiple loops, playing a role in determining the level of cell-to-cell variability in gene expression. A mechanistic model is proposed to address how changes in connection patterns, distance between regulatory elements, and communication forms of interacting DNA loops affect variability in expression level systematically. The model shows that nested loops enhance mRNA expression and reduce expression noise, while alternating loops reduce mean expression but increase noise compared to side-by-side loops. The facilitated-tracking mechanism performs better than the direct looping mechanism in enhancing or reducing expression and reducing or enlarging noise, depending on connection patterns, but this control or tuning is distance-dependent, particularly for moderate loop lengths. Experiments suggest that living organisms or cells use the facilitated-tracking mechanism to deal with information about their environments. The rates of chromatin looping, affected by the distances between regulatory elements, also play crucial roles in gene expression.
Metabolic engineering often relies on RNA technology to customize metabolism and maximize production. Pure riboregulators enable dynamic gene repression without the need for coexpressed proteins, unlike Hfq binding small RNAs and CRISPR technology. However, there is a lack of clear design principles for developing de novo repressing riboregulators. To address this, translation inhibiting RNAs were developed from scratch, exploring features related to thermodynamics and structure. After defining 12 structural and thermodynamic features and removing correlations, 18 riboregulators were selected, constructed, and co-expressed with two target untranslated regions. The pure riboregulators showed repression down to 6% of original protein expression levels, and a partial least squares regression model was constructed to link the properties of translation inhibiting RNA riboregulators to gene repression. Overall, this approach allows more reliable forward engineering of effective pure riboregulators, expanding the RNA toolbox for gene expression modulation. Over the last decade, synthetic biology and systems biology have led to advances in metabolic engineering, enabling economically competitive production processes for bulk and fine chemicals from renewable resources. Tuning cellular metabolism is necessary to redirect the metabolic flux towards the product of interest. Traditionally, this has been done through gene deletions, but maximizing various production pathways requires tools able to specifically reduce gene expression. Various metabolic engineering efforts have used CRISPRi technology to successfully repress specific genes, ameliorating the desired product formation. Alternative approaches to control gene expression on the translational level employ small RNAs to repress protein production by blocking translational initiation, enabling metabolic flux redirection at will. However, these approaches rely on coexpressed proteins, which might cause increased metabolic burden, long-term genetic instability, and unexpected behavior. Gene expression modulation systems that solely rely on RNA are preferred, as they require less cellular resources and harness large potential for the construction of fast-responding RNA circuitry. Pure riboregulators, which do not require proteins, offer these advantages and have been successfully used to precisely downregulate specific genes, redirect metabolite fluxes towards the phenotype of interest, and construct RNA circuitry. Despite these benefits, practical applications of pure riboregulators result from thorough, laborious, inefficient, and impractical screening of multiple designs comprising hundreds of nucleotides. Therefore, a framework for the de novo design of pure riboregulators was proposed, which repress gene expression by blocking translation initiation. This predictive framework enables forward engineering in a broader context and the construction of genetic circuitry using solely RNA.
The researchers in this study investigated the nature of transient associations among neurons that are believed to underlie memory and behavior. They recorded ongoing local field potential (LFP) activity at multiple sites within the cortex of awake monkeys and organotypic cultures of cortex. They found that when the composite activity of a local neuronal group exceeds a threshold, its activity pattern, as reflected in the LFP, occurs without distortion at other cortex sites via fast synaptic transmission. These large-amplitude LFPs, which they call coherence potentials, extend up to hundreds of milliseconds and mark periods of loss-less spread of temporal and amplitude information much like action potentials at the single-cell level. However, coherence potentials have an additional degree of freedom in the diversity of their waveforms, which provides a high-dimensional parameter for encoding information and allows identification of particular associations. Such nonlinear behavior is analogous to the spread of ideas and behaviors in social networks. The researchers suggest that this phenomenon of all or none, loss-less propagation of activity at high amplitudes arises by virtue of synaptic transmission and is akin to a 'tipping point' in the cortical network dynamics.
A study was conducted to identify factors involved in the correlation between nuclear size and cell size, a phenomenon that has been observed in various cell types, including unicellular yeasts and multicellular animals and plants. The study utilized fission yeast gene deletion mutants and identified 25 essential factors that alter nuclear size. The analysis implicated RNA processing and LINC complexes in nuclear size control, revealing lower and more extreme higher nuclear size phenotypes. The study also identified global cellular processes and specific structural nuclear components important for nuclear size control. Historical evidence of a constant ratio between nuclear and cell size has been reported in various cell types, and this study provides further insight into the mechanisms that control nuclear size and its correlation with cell size.
Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is an effective treatment for neurological disorders such as Parkinson’s disease and essential tremor (ET), involving the application of a train of pulses with constant frequency via electrodes implanted into the brain. New closed-loop approaches aim to deliver stimulation according to ongoing symptoms or brain activity, potentially improving efficiency, efficacy, and reducing side effects. The success of closed-loop DBS depends on devising a stimulation strategy that minimizes oscillations in neural activity associated with motor disorders. A mathematical model describing how the brain oscillations should change when stimulation is applied at a particular state of the system is a useful stepping stone towards this goal. This paper focuses on using coupled oscillators to represent neurons in areas generating pathological oscillations and analyzes how a patient should respond to stimulation when neural oscillations have a given phase and amplitude, assuming certain conditions are met. The authors predict that the best stimulation strategy should be phase-specific and more effective when applied when the amplitude of brain oscillations is lower. They compare this prediction with data obtained from ET patients and propose a new hybrid strategy that combines two closed-loop strategies found in the literature, namely phase-locked and adaptive DBS.
Schistosomiasis, caused by the parasite Schistosoma mansoni, is a widespread disease affecting over 230 million people worldwide. The parasite's life cycle involves freshwater snails, particularly those of the genus Biomphalaria, which act as intermediate hosts. The development of new monitoring assays for large-scale screening of snails from transmission sites is crucial for snail control interventions related to schistosomiasis elimination. A LAMP (Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification) assay was developed and evaluated for the detection of S. mansoni in experimentally infected snails. The LAMP assay, named Biompha-LAMP, is specific, sensitive, rapid, and cost-effective, making it suitable for large-scale field surveys for schistosomes control campaigns in endemic areas. The assay could be used to detect S. mansoni DNA in individual snails and pooled samples, providing a potential alternative for molecular xenomonitoring in field-applicable conditions. Animal procedures for the study complied with Spanish and European Union regulations, and experiments were conducted at an accredited Animal Experimentation Facility of the University of Salamanca. The study aimed to detect S. mansoni in Biomphalaria glabrata snails under different situations of infection, such as early prepatent period, light or low-grade infections, and in snails pooled samples. A simple, rapid, and economic method for DNA extraction from snails' tissues was successfully used. The LAMP assay presented here could be potentially useful for large-scale screening in searching infected snails with S. mansoni in field-applicable conditions.
Dengue is a major public health problem affecting over half of the world's population, particularly in Asia where it accounts for 70% of the estimated 390 million annual infections. In Sri Lanka, dengue is considered hyperendemic with all four serotypes in circulation for over 30 years. Historically, dengue was a less serious public health threat, but an abrupt increase in the number of severe cases occurred in 1989 and 2000 due to the emergence of new genotypes of the dengue virus. Dengue became a notifiable disease in 1996 and a National Dengue Control Program was set up in 1998. Despite these efforts, the number of reported cases increased 10-fold since the early 2000s, with large epidemics affecting the entire population of the island.In 2012, the Colombo district, the most heavily urbanized district in Sri Lanka, reported 10,017 hospitalized dengue cases. The public sector costs of dengue control activities and hospitalizations in Colombo district during the epidemic year of 2012 were estimated to be US$3.45 million (US$1.50 per capita). Personnel costs accounted for the largest shares of the total costs of dengue control activities (79%) and hospitalizations (46%). The per capita cost of dengue control activities was US$0.42, while the average costs per hospitalization ranged between US$216-609 for pediatric cases and US$196-866 for adult cases. This analysis is the first attempt to assess the economic burden of dengue response in the public health sector in Sri Lanka. Dengue poses a major economic burden on the public health sector in Sri Lanka.
The relative contributions of Paleolithic hunter-gatherers and Neolithic farmers from the Near East to modern European populations have been a topic of intense debate. The commonest European Y-chromosomal lineage, R1b1b2 (R-M269), is carried by 110 million European men and increases in frequency from east to west. Previous studies suggested a Paleolithic origin for this lineage, but a new study shows that its geographical distribution of microsatellite diversity is best explained by spread from a single source in the Near East via Anatolia during the Neolithic. This indicates that most European Y chromosomes originate in the Neolithic expansion, and highlights a unique role for males in the transition from hunter-gatherer to farming societies. The distribution of genetic diversity among modern European populations has been the subject of debate, with anatomically modern humans colonizing Europe from the Near East 40,000 years ago and adopting agriculture in the Near East 10,000 years ago. The spread of agriculture was accompanied by the development of sedentary populations and demographic expansion, and debated to be due to the movement and expansion of Near-Eastern farmers or to the transmission of cultural innovation to existing populations. A frequency cline of the R1b1b2 lineage follows a cline from 12% in Eastern Turkey to 85% in Ireland, and is currently carried by some 110 million European men. The geographical distribution of diversity within the haplogroup is best explained by its spread from a single source from the Near East via Anatolia during the Neolithic, indicating that the great majority of the Y chromosomes of Europeans have their origins in the Neolithic expansion. This reinterpretation makes Europe a prime example of how technological and cultural change is linked with the expansion of a Y-chromosomal lineage, and the contrast of this pattern with that shown by maternally inherited mitochondrial DNA suggests a unique role for males in the transition.
Recent studies on motor learning have examined the role of movement variability, which is the variation in performance across repetitions or continuous performance of the same task. This can be observed in various aspects of movement, such as errors in reaching or throwing, variance in force production, body sway during quiet standing and walking, the spread of movement trajectories, and variable coordination between effectors. While it is clear that motor variability is central to motor control and coordination, its role in motor learning is less understood. Some studies suggest that reduction of variability is a fundamental characteristic of learning, while others argue that initial variability can be beneficial for learning. However, it remains unclear whether initial variability generally facilitates motor learning, as motor learning is highly diverse and can be affected by multiple sources of noise and uncertainty. A recent study found that learners' initial variability is positively correlated with their rate of improvement, but this facilitatory effect of motor variability has not been consistently reported and its universality is questioned. Further research is needed to understand the relative importance of the factors involved in motor learning and to determine the conditions under which motor variability is beneficial or detrimental for learning.
NF-κB is a crucial transcription factor that plays a vital role in cellular immune and inflamory response, survival, and proliferation by regulating the transcription of various genes involved in these processes. RelA, a prominent NF-κB family member, interacts with transcriptional co-activators like CBP and p300 to activate transcription. The RelA:CBP/p3
The time-course gene set analysis (TcGSA) is a method for analyzing genomic data, specifically for longitudinal data, which is an extension of traditional gene set analysis methods used in cross-sectional studies. TcGSA is a hypothesis-driven method that relies on random effects modeling with maximum likelihood estimates, allowing it to use all available repeated measurements while dealing with unbalanced data due to missing at random values. It identifies predefined gene sets with significant expression variations over time, taking into account potential heterogeneity of expression within gene sets. This method has been shown to be more powerful than other approaches for analyzing time-course expression patterns of gene sets, as demonstrated through its application to two real-life datasets and a simulation study. TcGSA is able to detect significant changes in gene expression over time within gene sets, even when standard univariate individual gene analysis and standard Gene Set Enrichment Analysis fail to do so. Overall, TcGSA is a valuable tool for the analysis of longitudinal genomic data.
The spatial epidemiology and geographical distribution of Plasmodium vivax, a neglected parasite causing malaria, is far less understood than that of P. falciparum, complicating control and elimination efforts. To address this, the first systematic effort was made to map the global endemicity of P. vivax, updating an earlier estimate of its transmission limits and using a spatiotemporal Bayesian model with 9,970 geopositioned P. vivax parasite rate surveys from 1985 to 2010. The study aimed to contribute to evidence-based planning for P. vivax control and elimination by generating a comprehensive, detailed depiction of spatially varying endemicity.The results showed that the global area at risk of P. vivax transmission was 22% in the Americas, 3.5% in Africa (mostly in Madagascar and the Horn of Africa), 82% in Central Asia (home to 82% of global PAR or population at risk), and 9% in South East Asia. The endemicity was predicted within a narrow range throughout the endemic world, with point estimates rarely exceeding 7% PvPR1–99. Despite the Americas contributing to 22% of the global area at risk, high endemic areas were sparsely populated and the region accounted for only 6% of the 2.5 billion people at risk (PAR) globally. Africa's stable transmission was constrained to Madagascar and parts of the Horn, contributing 3.5% of global PAR. Central Asia had 82% of global PAR, with important high endemic areas coinciding with dense populations, particularly in India and Myanmar. South East Asia contained areas of the highest endemicity in Indonesia and Papua New Guinea and contributed 9% of global PAR.This study demonstrated that detailed, geographically varying risk assessments can significantly contribute to a paradigm shift towards geographically stratified and evidence-based planning for P. vivax control and elimination. The international agenda for malaria control financing, research, and implementation has increasingly focused on regional elimination, and this ambition should extend to all human malarias, including P. vivax. However, recent years have seen minimal research attention and funding for P. vivax compared to P. falciparum. This neglect has led to the acknowledgment that control approaches for P. falciparum cannot be transferred successfully to P. vivax, as the latter frequently remains entrenched long after P. falciparum has been eliminated and can cause severe disease and death.Important factors contributing to the complexities in defining and mapping P. vivax endemicity include its dormant hypnozoite liver stage, lower parasitemia density, and the influence of the Duffy negativity phenotype. These factors require unique methodological considerations in mapping P. vivax endemicity, distinct from those established for P. falciparum. The study's efforts to accommodate these differences in developing a global distribution of endemic vivax malaria are a significant advancement in understanding and addressing this neglected parasite's spatial epidemiology and geographical distribution.
Staphylococcus aureus is a major cause of skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs), resulting in millions of outpatient visits and hundreds of thousands of hospitalizations in the US annually. The treatment of these infections has become difficult due to the emergence of antibiotic resistance. Vaccines offer a potential solution, but a universal anti-S. aureus vaccine is unlikely due to the wide spectrum of pathologies caused by the bacterium. Instead, a vaccine targeting specific clinical manifestations may be pursued. A vaccine specifically targeted against SSTIs would be of great benefit. If prophylactic vaccines or other forms of immunotherapy are to be developed as an alternative to antibiotics, a greater understanding of the specific role of individual virulence factors during infection at this site is needed to identify important targets for future therapy. S. aureus expresses up to 25 different cell wall-anchored (CWA) proteins, which are primarily involved in adhesion and invasion of host cells and tissues, biofilm formation, and immune evasion. Sortase A-deficient mutants, which lack the majority of cell surface bound CWA proteins, have reduced virulence in a murine kidney abscess model and a skin abscess model, indicating that CWA proteins are important during SSTIs. However, there is a paucity of information regarding the role of individual surface proteins during SSTIs. This study aimed to elucidate the role of Clumping factor B (ClfB) during S. aureus SSTIs and assess its potential as a candidate vaccine antigen specifically targeting SSTIs. The study found that ClfB affects both the rate of abscess formation and the overall size of the abscess formed, ultimately leading to greater bacterial burden in the skin. Additionally, recombinant loricrin loop L2v-GST was used to block the interaction between ClfB and its native ligands, resulting in reduced abscess lesion area and bacterial burden in the skin. A model vaccine containing ClfB was formulated with the Toll-like receptor 9 (TLR9) agonist CpG as an adjuvant. Immunization with ClfB in combination with CpG drove a significant increase in ClfB-specific IFNγ, IL-17, and IL-22 CD4+ T cells by inguinal lymph node cells compared to CpG-immunized mice. Vaccination with ClfB in combination with CpG also induced significantly elevated ClfB-specific serum IgG titers in mice compared to the control group. These results identify ClfB as an important vaccine antigen that can drive effective humoral and cellular immune responses, ultimately leading to protection against S. aureus SSTI. These findings suggest that ClfB represents a good candidate antigen for inclusion in next-generation vaccines targeting S. aureus SSTI.
The Joint United Nations Program on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS) has set a goal to end AIDS by 2030, with an interim target of reducing new HIV infections to 500,000 by 2020. To achieve this, pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is one of the proposed strategies, and Truvada (emtricitabine-tenofovir) is currently the only approved medication for this purpose. However, Truvada is expensive and requires daily adherence to a regimen, which can be a barrier for some individuals. Therefore, next-generation PrEP regimens, including long-acting formulations, are being investigated.To prioritize and help design PrEP regimens, tools are needed that integrate pharmacological, viral, and host factors determining prophylactic efficacy. Researchers have developed a stochastic simulation approach to predict prophylactic efficacy, as an example for dolutegravir (DTG). By combining the population pharmacokinetics of DTG with the stochastic framework, they predicted that plasma concentrations of 145.18 and 722.23nM prevent 50- and 90% sexual transmissions respectively. They then predicted the reduction in HIV infection when DTG was used in PrEP, PrEP “on demand,” and post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) before and after virus exposure.Their simulations indicated that oral 50mg DTG is non-inferior to Truvada and can prevent 99-100% of infections when used in PrEP, and 85% of infections when 50% of dosing events are missed. PrEP “on demand” prevented 79-84% of infections, and PEP >80% when initiated within 6 hours after virus exposure and continued for as long as possible. The predicted 90% preventive concentrations can guide release kinetics of currently developed DTG nano-formulations.In conclusion, while HIV-1 remains a significant public health challenge, preventing its transmission is crucial. The 90-90-90 target aims to reduce new HIV infections to 500,000 by 2020, and PrEP is one of the strategies to achieve this goal. While Truvada is currently the only approved medication for PrEP, next-generation PrEP regimens, such as DTG, are being investigated. A stochastic simulation approach has been developed to predict prophylactic efficacy and help design PrEP regimens by integrating pharmacological, viral, and host factors. The simulations suggest that DTG is non-inferior to Truvada and can prevent 99-100% of infections when used in PrEP, and 85% of infections when 50% of dosing events are missed. Further research is needed to confirm these findings and continue the development of effective PrEP regimens.
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is a major human pathogen that causes severe liver diseases. It induces autophagy in host cells to enhance its replication, but the mechanism by which HCV regulates the autophagic pathway is unclear. This report shows that HCV infection induces the expression of Rubicon and UVRAG, which inhibit and stimulate the maturation of autophagosomes, respectively. The induction of Rubicon is prompt, while the induction of UVRAG is delayed, leading to the accumulation of autophagosomes in the early time points of viral infection. The HCV subgenomic RNA replicon, which expresses only nonstructural proteins, can also induce the expression of Rubicon and the accumulation of autophagosomes. Further analysis indicates that the HCV NS4B protein is sufficient to induce Rubicon and autophagosomes. Therefore, HCV temporally regulates the autophagic flux to enhance its replication by differentially inducing the expression of Rubicon and UVRAG.
Ccnyl1 is a newly-identified member of the cyclin family, highly similar in protein sequences to Cyclin Y (Ccny), but its function is poorly characterized. It is most abundantly expressed in the testis of mice, about seven times higher than the level of Ccny. Male Ccnyl1-/- mice were infertile, while both male and female Ccny-/- mice displayed normal fertility, indicating that Ccnyl1, but not Ccny, is essential for male fertility. Spermatozoa obtained from Ccnyl1-/- mice displayed significantly impaired motility, thin annulus region, and/or bent head. The protein, but not the mRNA, level of cyclin-dependent kinase 16 (CDK16) was decreased in the testis of Ccnyl1-/- mice. Further study demonstrated that CCNYL1 interacted with CDK16, increasing the stability and kinase activity of these two proteins, and altering the phosphorylation levels of CDK16. These results reveal a previously unrecognized role of CCNYL1 in regulating spermatogenesis through the interaction and modulation of CDK16.
EHEC strains cause diarrhea and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) due to toxin-mediated microvascular endothelial injury. EHEC hemolysin (EHEC-Hly), a member of the RTX family, is an important EHEC virulence factor. The toxin exists as free EHEC-Hly and as EHEC-Hly associated with outer membrane vesicles (OMVs) released by EHEC during growth. Free EHEC-Hly lyses human endothelium, while OMV-associated EHEC-Hly triggers apoptosis of human brain microvascular endothelial cells and Caco-2 cells (intestinal epithelial cells) by targeting mitochondria. OMV-associated EHEC-Hly is internalized by HBMEC and Caco-2 cells via dynamin-dependent endocytosis and trafficked into endo-lysosomal compartments. Upon endosome acidification, EHEC-Hly escapes from the lysosomes and targets mitochondria, decreasing mitochondrial transmembrane potential and inducing apoptosis via the intrinsic caspase-9-dependent pathway. This novel mechanism of EHEC-Hly involvement in the pathogenesis of EHEC diseases indicates a new mechanism for bacterial toxin entry into host cells to target mitochondria.
The elongation phase of transcription, where RNA polymerase II (RNAPII) transcribes genes in eukaryotes, is a critical point of regulation for many genes. While transcription initiation has been extensively studied, many of the mechanisms governing elongation are not yet fully understood. Transcription is accompanied by post-translational modification of nucleosomal histones in a highly conserved pattern. A central role in this interplay is played by mono-ubiquitylation of histone H2B (H2Bub1), which is catalyzed by the ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme Rad6 and the E3 ubiquitin ligase Bre1 in budding yeast. H2Bub1 is required for co-transcriptional generation of H3K4me by the methyltransferase Set1 in yeast and contributes to global H3K4me levels in metazoans. In vitro, H2Bub1 directly stimulates the activity of Set1 towards a reconstituted chromatin substrate. H2Bub1 also acts independently of histone methylation, playing a role in normal cell growth, morphology, and elongation by RNAPII at select target genes in fission yeast. Co-transcriptional histone modifications are regulated by a conserved subset of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) associated with the transcription machinery, including Cdk7 and Cdk9. In metazoans, Cdk9 activity overcomes promoter-proximal pausing imposed by unphosphorylated DSIF and a negative elongation factor, playing a role in regulating histone modification. P-TEFb binds the bromodomain protein Brd4 and phosphorylates multiple proteins important for elongation in mammals. Levels of H2Bub1, H3K4me, and H3K36me decrease after depletion of Cdk9 by RNAi or treatment with flavopiridol, an inhibitor of Cdk9 and related kinases. Bur1, the essential ortholog of Cdk9 in budding yeast, is required for co-transcriptional H3K36me and consequent action of the Rpd3S histone deacetylase complex to prevent transcription initiation within coding regions. Budding yeast contains another, non-essential CDK, Ctk1, which is the major Rpb1-Ser2 kinase in vivo and is required for H3K36me. CDKs are themselves regulated by histone modification. For example, phosphorylation of histone H3 favors recruitment of P-TEFb, while certain histone marks work in opposition to specific CDKs during elongation. In fission yeast, the P-TEFb ortholog is the essential Cdk9/Pch1 complex, which phosphorylates the Rpb1 CTD at both Ser5 and Ser2. Inhibition of Cdk9 in vivo reduces the apparent stoichiometry of Rpb1 phosphorylation but does not cause selective loss of either Ser5 or Ser2 signals. Cdk9 also phosphorylates the CTD of fission yeast Spt5, which contains an exclusive, albeit nonessential, target of Cdk9 in vivo. Genetic epistasis suggests that Cdk9 and Set1 govern separate, partially redundant pathways downstream of H2Bub1. The htb1-K119R cells, which lack H2Bub1, display altered RNAPII distribution within gene coding regions. The phosphorylation by Cdk9 stimulates H2Bub1 and vice versa, and proper balance between the two is ensured via a positive feedback loop. Loss of H2Bub1 disrupts that balance and leads to deranged gene expression and aberrant cell morphologies, revealing a novel function of a conserved, co-transcriptional histone modification.
Yellow fever virus (YFV) remains a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in South America and Africa, with an estimated 200,000 cases and 30,000 deaths per year. Although a highly effective vaccine is available, the failure to implement sustained vaccination programs due to poverty, civil war, and inaccessibility of rural areas has led to an alarming resurgence of virus circulation in West Africa over the last 20 years. YFV is a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus with a genome of approximately 11 kb, and is a member of the genus Flavivirus. Previous evolutionary studies suggest that YFV originated in Africa, but the timing and mechanism of its introduction to the Americas is less clear. A phylogenetic analysis of the largest YFV data set compiled to date, representing the prM/E gene region from 133 viral isolates sampled from 22 countries over a period of 76 years, was performed to determine the evolutionary history of this important reemerging pathogen. The analysis revealed that the currently circulating strains of YFV arose in Africa within the last 1,500 years and emerged in the Americas following the slave trade approximately 300-400 years ago. These viruses then spread westwards across the continent and persist there to this day in the jungles of South America. This study illustrates how gene sequence data can be used to test hypotheses of viral dispersal and demographics, and documents the role of human migration in the spread of infectious disease.
A study was conducted to analyze the pathogenesis of Streptococcus pneumoniae, a leading bacterial pathogen, in an infant mouse model, with and without influenza A (IAV) co-infection. The study aimed to identify vulnerable points in the multiple steps of pneumococcal pathogenesis by analyzing population bottlenecks in the model. The findings revealed that in the setting of IAV co-infection, the organism must pass through single-cell bottlenecks during bloodstream invasion from the nasopharynx within the host and in transmission between hosts. These bottlenecks were not associated with genetic adaptation by the pathogen. The bottleneck in transmission occurred between bacterial exit from one host and establishment in another, explaining why the number of shed organisms in secretions is critical to overcoming it. These observations demonstrate how viral infection and the TLR-dependent innate immune responses it stimulates and that are required to control it drive bacterial contagion. The pneumococcus has a predominantly commensal lifestyle and is a leading cause of disease, with high rates of carriage and complications such as otitis media, pneumonia, and sepsis. Pneumococcal infection has been partially controlled through immunization, with the most well-established effect of vaccine-induced immunity in adults being protection of the individual from pneumococcal bacteremia. More recently, widespread immunization of children has led to lower rates of transmission within the community and protection of unvaccinated populations (herd immunity). The study aimed to identify the steps during infection where pneumococci must pass through a population bottleneck, which would be attractive 'weak points' for intervention strategies since there would be relatively few organisms to target.
The article discusses a study conducted to identify and validate recombinant salivary proteins of Phlebotomus orientalis, an important vector of Leishmania donovani, as potential markers of exposure to sand fly bites in human populations from disease-endemic areas in Eastern Africa. The study aimed to screen human sera from Sudan and Ethiopia for anti-P. orientalis antibodies using recombinant salivary proteins. After producing recombinant proteins in bacterial and mammalian expression systems, the researchers identified two proteins, mAG5 and mYEL1, as the most promising antigens for detecting anti-P. orientalis antibodies. These two proteins showed a high correlation coefficient and good specificity compared to whole sand fly salivary gland homogenate. The utilization of equal amounts of these two proteins significantly increased the capability to detect anti-P. orientalis antibody responses. The study highlights the potential of using recombinant salivary proteins as markers of exposure to sand fly bites and the importance of further studies in developing a reliable and efficient serological test for P. orientalis exposure.
IncC conjugative plasmids and Salmonella genomic island 1 (SGI1) are frequently associated with multidrug resistance in clinical isolates of pathogenic Enterobacteriaceae. SGI1 is specifically mobilized in trans by IncA and IncC plasmids following its excision from the chromosome, an event triggered by the transcriptional activator complex AcaCD encoded by these helper plasmids. While SGI1 is not self-transmissible, it carries three genes (traNS, traHS, and traGS) coding for distant homologs of mating pore subunits TraNC, TraHC, and TraGC, respectively, encoded by A/C plasmids. AcaCD increases the expression of traNS and traHGS, and these genes are essential for IncC plasmid transfer. TraNS, TraHS, and TraGS are functional proteins that can replace TraNC, TraHC, and TraGC in the mating pore encoded by IncC plasmids. Remodeling of the IncC-encoded mating pore by SGI1 is essential to enhance the transfer rate of SGI1 over the helper plasmid and allows DNA transfer between cells bearing IncC helper plasmids. Conjugation is a major mechanism of horizontal gene transfer in bacteria, allowing the exchange of large numbers of genes per transfer event across taxonomical barriers. It is mediated by a complex nano-machine called the type IV secretion system (T4SS) and is often associated with the transfer of genetic elements encoding antibiotic resistance, virulence determinants, and other advantageous traits for the bacterial host. IncC plasmids are often found in clinical isolates of major pathogenic bacteria and can transfer and replicate efficiently in a broad range of Enterobacteriaceae and Vibrio cholerae. They are closely related to IncA plasmids and share a common scaffold of genes necessary for their replication, stability, conjugative transfer, and regulation. Expression of the conjugative transfer genes of IncC plasmids is controlled by repressors Acr1 and Acr2, which control the transcription of an operon containing acaC and acaD that code for the two subunits of the master activator AcaCD. In IncC plasmids, AcaCD specifically binds to and activates 18 promoters that drive the expression of multiple genes and operons, most of which are of unknown function. A third of these promoters drive the expression of tra genes coding for F-type T4SS assembly, mating pair stabilization, and the relaxase and type IV coupling protein necessary for conjugative transfer. AcaCD also activates the expression of genes carried by unrelated mobilizable genomic islands (MGIs), thereby triggering their excision from the chromosome and their IncC-dependent dissemination into new bacterial hosts. SGI1 and its multiple variants are frequently found in S. enterica and Proteus mirabilis clinical isolates and all share a common 26-kb core region disrupted by a complex class 1 integron conferring multidrug resistance. SGI1 is thought to hijack the conjugative apparatus encoded by IncA and IncC plasmids to transfer to a new host cell by a mechanism that remains unknown as no origin of transfer (or oriT) or mobilization protein such as a relaxase has been identified in SGI1 to date. However, SGI1 has been reported to be mobilized at a much higher rate than MGIVmi1 and MGIVchHai6 (~3 logs higher) when mobilized by the same IncC plasmid, even outperforming the helper plasmid by 10 fold.
The Saccharomyces cerevisiae polo-like kinase Cdc5 promotes adaptation to the DNA damage checkpoint, which occurs when cells with persistent or irreparable DNA damage escape the cell-cycle arrest imposed by the DNA damage checkpoint. The study found that Cdc5 acts to attenuate the DNA damage checkpoint through loss of Rad5
The brain's extracellular space (ECS) contains ion concentration changes that are crucial to understanding various pathological conditions such as seizures, stroke, and spreading depression. Experimentally tracking ion concentrations and electric potential simultaneously in relevant brain regions is currently unfeasible, but computational models based on biophysical principles are a solution. Previous models were limited in exploring electrodiffusive effects on large spatiotemporal scales due to high computing power requirements. This issue is addressed by a new 3-D Kirchhoff-Nernst-Planck (KNP) framework tailored for large scales and demonstrated through a morphologically detailed pyramidal cell simulation. The KNP-framework bypasses charge-relaxation processes on nanometer and nanosecond scales and is efficient for running simulations on millimeter and second scales on a standard desktop computer. This study highlights the potential of the 3-D KNP framework for understanding pathological conditions with substantial concentration variations in the ECS.
The proposed budget cut in the CDC's vector-borne diseases program, which could amount to $26.7 million, could have significant consequences for the country's ability to prevent and manage mosquito-borne diseases such as dengue and West Nile virus. A study evaluating the impact of delayed control responses to dengue epidemics found that halting mosquito surveillance could increase the management costs of epidemics by up to an order of magnitude compared to a strategy with sustained surveillance and early case detection. The study used a mathematical model to generate hypothetical scenarios of delayed response to a dengue introduction in the City of Cairns, Queensland, Australia, and estimated the cumulative costs of each response scenario. The results showed that even without considering the cost in human lives and well-being, the total costs of preparedness through surveillance are far lower than the ones needed to respond to the introduction of vector-borne pathogens.The proposed budget cut could virtually paralyze surveillance and research activities directed at diseases already circulating in the US, such as dengue and West Nile virus, and jeopardize the capability of the existing health infrastructure for early detection of other exotic mosquito-transmitted pathogens such as Rift Valley fever, Japanese encephalitis, and chikungunya virus. Surveillance is the first line of defense against infectious diseases, and cuts to the CDC's vector-borne diseases program could have severe consequences for the country's ability to prevent and manage mosquito-borne diseases.The analysis clearly shows that the total costs of preparedness through surveillance are far lower than the ones needed to respond to the introduction of vector-borne pathogens, even without consideration of the cost in human lives and well-being. The proposed budget cut could have significant consequences for the country's ability to prevent and manage mosquito-borne diseases. Therefore, the proposed budget cut should be re-assessed, and improved and sustainable systems for vector-borne disease surveillance are needed. The findings provide a science-based justification for the importance of the CDC's vector-borne diseases program.
Dengue is a significant and mostly unrecognized cause of fever in rural western Nicaragua, with 63.5% of febrile patients testing positive for dengue antibodies. The study found that 5.1% of patients had acute dengue, with only 8.1% of confirmed cases suspected clinically. The study also found that dengue seroprevalence increased with age, reaching over 90% in people over the age of 20. The population in the study is at risk for the Zika epidemic that has reached Central America, as Zika is transmitted by the same vector and has been associated with severe congenital infections. The study suggests that dengue is an important and largely unrecognized cause of fever in rural western Nicaragua, and the population is at risk for Zika due to the same vector transmission. The study's limitations include the use of a convenience sample and the reliance on self-reported data. However, the study's strengths include prospective data collection and rigorous testing for dengue infection. Overall, the study highlights the importance of considering dengue in the diagnosis of febrile illness in rural western Nicaragua and the need for ongoing surveillance for Zika in the region.
Plant-parasitic nematodes cause significant losses to crops annually, with an estimated yield loss of 12% internationally and up to 30% in some crops like banana. Nematodes reproduce either parthenogenically or sexually, and the economically significant sedentary endoparasitic nematodes include root-knot nematodes (Meloidogyne spp.) and cyst nematodes (Globodera spp. and Heterodera spp.). These nematodes induce the formation of feeding sites in the roots of host plants, which serve as their sole source of nutrients. Plants have defense mechanisms against nematodes, including the perception of pathogen/microbe-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs or MAMPs) via surface-localised pattern recognition receptors (PRRs), leading to the activation of PAMP-triggered immunity (PTI). However, nematodes can down-regulate or overcome these plant defense responses. In a study, it was shown that Arabidopsis elicits PTI-like responses upon nematode detection, as evidenced by the induction of genes previously shown to be induced during PTI. Additionally, NemaWater (water containing nematode-secreted molecules) from root-knot nematodes Meloidogyne incognita triggers a strong and consistent ROS burst in Arabidopsis roots. Furthermore, NemaWater contains potential elicitor/s that is/are recognized by an immune receptor in plants leading to the activation of PTI-like responses. Pre-treatment with NemaWater reduces the growth of virulent P. syringae and the number of nematodes in Arabidopsis plants, indicating the presence of putative elicitor(s) in NemaWater. These elicitors are likely to be of proteinaceous nature, as treatment of NemaWater with Proteinase K reduces its ability to induce ROS burst. BAK1, a co-receptor for LRR-RLKs and LRR-RLPs, acts as a co-receptor for nematode-derived elicitors. Mutants of bak1-5 and bak1-5 bkk1-1 are more susceptible to nematodes, indicating the importance of BAK1 in defense responses. A nematode-induced LRR-RLK, NILR1, was identified as a potential PRR involved in nematode perception and the induction of PTI responses. The nilr1 mutant showed a consistent increase in the number of female nematodes as compared with Col-0. Overall, the study highlights the potential of manipulating NILR1 and NemaWater for nematode control in crop plants in the future.
Miltefosine, an anti-cancer drug, has been successfully repositioned for the treatment of Leishmania infections and shows promising effects against Schistosoma spp, targeting all life cycle stages of the parasite. A study examined the effect of miltefosine on Schistosoma mansoni adult worms and its exposure of worm surface antigens in vitro. In an indirect immunofluorescence assay, rabbit anti-S. mansoni adult worm homogenate and anti-S. mansoni infection antisera gave strong immunofluorescence of the S. mansoni adult worm surface after treatment with miltefosine. Rabbit antibodies that recognized surface antigens exposed on miltefosine-treated worms were recovered and used in a western immunoblotting assay to identify antigenic targets in a homogenate extract of adult worms. Four proteins reacting with the antibodies in immunoblots were purified and proteomic analysis indicated they were the S. mansoni proteins: fructose-1, 6 bisphosphate aldolase, Sm22.6, alkaline phosphatase and malate dehydrogenase. These antibodies were also found to bind to the surface of 3-hour schistosomula and induce immune agglutination of the parasites, suggesting they may have a role in immune protection. This study reveals a novel mode of action of miltefosine as an anti-schistosome agent and the potential of these antigens as intervention targets. Despite extensive control efforts, schistosomiasis is still prevalent in many countries and concerns are growing over development of resistance to the only drug available for treatment, praziquantel. The suboptimal efficacy of PZQ against immature stages of the infection is another concern. Thus, the search for an alternative therapeutic control or a combination strategy that is effective against multiple stages of the schistosome life cycle has become necessary. One approach is to identify and develop alternative uses for existing, approved drugs that have had their pharmacokinetics, toxicity, and pre-clinical data evaluated - an approach known as ‘Drug-Repositioning’. Miltefosine is a promising example of this approach, with effectiveness against Schistosoma mansoni and Schistosoma haematobium in vitro and against different developmental stages of S. mansoni in vivo. The drug exhibited an advantage over PZQ by clearing the infection at the invasive, immature and adult parasite stages.
The host-pathogen struggle for iron in the infection process is crucial as iron is essential for many biological processes in most life forms, but its low solubility and bioavailability require bacteria to evolve multiple systems to acquire iron from various sources such as heme, hemoglobin, and ferritin. While the molecular basis of iron acquisition from heme and hemoglobin has been extensively studied, little is known about iron acquisition from host ferritin, a 24-mer nanocage protein that stores thousands of iron atoms. However, recent studies have shown that the intracellular bacterium Neisseria meningitidis and the surface protein Als3 of Candida albicans can utilize ferritin for iron acquisition. In the human opportunistic pathogen Bacillus cereus, a surface protein named IlsA binds heme, hemoglobin, and ferritin in vitro and is involved in virulence. IlsA acts as a ferritin receptor, causing ferritin aggregation on the bacterial surface, and binds several types of ferritins through direct interaction with the shell subunits. Disruption of the siderophore bacillibactin production drastically reduces the ability of B. cereus to utilize ferritin for growth, resulting in attenuated bacterial virulence in insects. Therefore, a new model of iron acquisition in B. cereus involves the binding of IlsA to host ferritin followed by siderophore-assisted iron uptake, highlighting a possible interplay between a surface protein and a siderophore, and providing new insights into host adaptation of B. cereus and general bacterial pathogenesis.
The protein phosphorylation cycle in the cyanobacterium S. elongatus, consisting of KaiA, KaiB, and KaiC proteins, is a crucial part of its circadian clock. KaiC forms a homohexamer with two domains, CI and CII, which can bind and hydrolyze ATP but only CII can be phosphorylated at two residues. A new thermodynamically consistent, statistical-mechanical model has been presented, explaining how the clock is driven. The model suggests that ATP hydrolysis in the CI domain provides the thermodynamic driving force for the clock, switching KaiC between an active conformational state and an inactive one. Phosphorylation of the CII domain provides the timer for the hydrolysis in the CI domain. KaiA acts as a nucleotide exchange factor, stimulating phosphorylation of KaiC, and the differential affinity of KaiA for the different KaiC phosphoforms generates the characteristic temporal order of KaiC phosphorylation. The release of ADP from CI slows down as the phosphorylation level in the CII domain rises, making the inactive conformational state of KaiC more stable and leading to KaiC dephosphorylation. The model can describe a wealth of experimental data.
Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a significant public health concern, causing about 600,000 deaths annually and affecting 350 million people chronically worldwide. HBV is a DNA virus but replicates through an RNA intermediate, the pregenomic RNA (pgRNA), which can be sensed by the RIG-I and activates MAVS to mediate interferon (IFN) λ synthesis. However, HBV has developed mechanisms to suppress IFN-αβ synthesis. A study has shown that HBV-induced parkin, a protein associated with Parkinson’s disease, recruits the linear ubiquitin assembly complex (LUBAC) to mitochondria and abrogates IFN-β synthesis. Parkin interacts with MAVS, accumulates unanchored linear polyubiquitin chains on MAVS via LUBAC, disrupts the MAVS signalosome, and attenuates IRF3 activation. This study highlights the novel role of parkin in antiviral signaling and provides avenues of investigations on the role of mitochondrial dynamics in innate immunity. Mitochondria serve as a platform for innate immune signaling, and MAVS, a mitochondrial membrane protein, is the central adaptor molecule on which signals from various pattern recognition receptors that specifically recognize viral nucleic acids converge. HBV suppresses IFN-β synthesis both in vivo and in vitro cultured cells infection. The HBx, a regulatory protein encoded by HBV, targets MAVS-IRF3 signaling and inhibits IFN-β production. In HBV infection, the HBV expression rendered the cells less responsive to polyI:C (pI:C) as evidenced by reduced interferon-stimulated responsive element (ISRE) activity. However, Parkin silencing in these cells restored MAVS/IRF3 signaling, suggesting that HBV usurps Parkin’s function to abrogate antiviral signaling. HBx expression is required for the inhibition of ISRE activity. Parkin silencing in Huh7 cells transfected with wild-type HBV genome restored ISRE activity upon pI:C stimulation. Similarly, HBx expressing Huh7 cells showed reduced ISRE activity, however silencing Parkin expression was sufficient to restore ISRE activity in these cells. Altogether, these findings confirmed that the ability of HBV/HBx to regulate antiviral signaling is mediated by Parkin via enhanced mitochondrial recruitment. The Parkin and HBx interact with MAVS and likely be a part of the MAVS signalosome. HBV expression potentiates Parkin association with MAVS that could be instrumental in suppressing MAVS downstream signaling. Therefore, HBV expression abrogates MAVS-IRF3 signaling by mechanism independent of mitophagy. Parkin can enhance ubiquitin chains on MAVS but does not target MAVS for proteasomal degradation. In HBV expressing cells, the linear (or M-1 ) and K-63 linked chains attached to MAVS were predominantly unanchored in nature and accumulation of M-1 and K-63 linked ubiquitin chains on MAVS is Parkin-dependent. Parkin, being unable to catalyze the linear ubiquitination, can modulate linear ubiquitin chains on MVAS via LUBAC. The LUBAC remains a critical factor for inhibition of antiviral response. In HBV expressing cells, the Parkin mediated modulation of MAVS signaling is actually mediated via LUBAC activity. The Parkin interacts with LUBAC, and the enhanced interaction between Parkin and LUBAC in HBV replicating cells could modulate the stability of LUBAC subunits. In the HBV off condition, most of the HOIP signals were cytosolic, however, in the hepatocytes expressing HBV, there was an enhanced overlap of HOIP and MAVS signal which raised the possibility that upon HBV replication, LUBAC subunits are recruited to the mitochondria. Finally, the cells expressing HBV with silenced level of Parkin did not show any LUBAC accumulation on the mitochondria.
The protein I2, encoded by the pfiT gene of Pseudomonas fluorescens, is a T-cell superantigen associated with Crohn's disease, a type of inflammatory bowel disease. I2/pfiT is a member of the TetR-family of DNA-binding transcription regulators and belongs to a new family of T cell superantigens. It directly interacts with HLA-DR and competes with other superantigens for binding to HLA-DR, indicating that their binding sites overlap. I2/pfiT has been found to stimulate the proliferation of human lymphocytes and bind to mammalian cells in a class II MHC-specific manner. The structural analyses revealed that I2/pfiT and its homolog PA2885 bind to human class II MHC HLA-DR, and to a lesser extent HLA-DP or HLA-DQ, and share an overlapping binding site on HLA-DR1 with other superantigens. The I2 sequence was selectively detected in active CD lesional colonic tissue and serum antibody studies revealed that IgA seroreactivity to a recombinant I2 protein was CD specific. The I2 protein induces proliferation and IL-10 responses by normal CD4+ T cells and its response is dependent on MHC class II-mediated recognition, a feature typical of SAgs. The I2 response was specific for the murine TCR-Vβ5 subpopulation and pfiT exhibited T-cell SAg bioactivity. PA2885, the apparent Pseudomonas aeruginosa homolog of pfiT, also stimulated murine CD4+ T cell proliferation. Therefore, it is speculated that the I2 protein pfiT is a novel T-cell SAg and colonization by the I2 and pfiT-expressing microorganism, P. fluorescens, in IBD susceptible hosts, could provide a superantigenic stimulus pertinent to the pathogenesis of Crohn's disease.
Nanog is a critical regulator of embryonic stem cell (ESC) pluripotency. Recent findings reveal that Nanog exhibits a disperse distribution within stem cell populations due to allelic control of Nanog gene expression and gene expression noise. A multiscale stochastic population balance equation (PBE) framework was developed to investigate how allelic control of Nanog expression influences stem cell population heterogeneity. This framework considers allelic control, gene expression noise, and random partitioning at cell division. The results indicate that allelic control and gene expression noise generate a bimodal distribution of Nanog, while initially uniform populations of stem cells give rise to the same Nanog heterogeneity within ten cell cycles. Allelic regulation facilitates the maintenance of fractions of self-renewing cells with sufficient Nanog content, preventing aberrant loss of pluripotency. The model findings highlight the role of allelic control of Nanog expression as a prime determinant of stem cell population heterogeneity and warrant further investigation in the contexts of stem cell specification and cell reprogramming. This research has important implications for our understanding of the mechanisms governing Nanog heterogeneity and its impact on stem cell fate decisions, and highlights the need for reexamining current rationales proposed for the variability of Nanog in stem cell ensembles.
The cost and benefit of protein expression are balanced through evolution. The expression of unutilized protein, which has no benefits in the current environment, incurs quantifiable fitness costs on cellular growth rates. However, the magnitude and variability of unutilized protein expression in natural settings are unknown due to the challenge in determining environment-specific proteome utilization. A recent study combined absolute and global proteomics data with a genome-scale model of Escherichia coli to compute the environment-specific cost and utility of the proteome on a per gene basis. The results showed that nearly half of the proteome mass is unused in certain environments, and accounting for the cost of this unused protein expression explains over 95% of the variance in growth rates of Escherichia coli across 16 distinct environments. Furthermore, reduction in unused protein expression is a common mechanism to increase cellular growth rates in adaptive evolution experiments. The unused protein encodes several nutrient- and stress-preparedness functions, which may convey fitness benefits in varying environments. Thus, unused protein expression is the source of large and pervasive fitness costs that may provide the benefit of hedging against environmental change. Overall, the costs and benefits of protein synthesis on organismal fitness shape the evolution and regulation of proteome expression.
Recent large-scale genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified multiple genetic variants associated with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2D), many of which are in proteins not previously suspected to be involved in T2D pathogenesis. However, most GWAS have focused on populations of European descent, and GWAS conducted in other populations offer a unique opportunity to study the genetic architecture of T2D. A study was conducted to perform genome-wide association scans for T2D in Chinese, Malays, and Asian Indians, with the goal of identifying novel variants implicated in T2D and assessing the transferability and relevance of previous findings from European populations in the three major ethnic populations of Asia, comprising half of the world's population. The study found that of the SNPs associated with T2D in previous GWAS, only variants at CDKAL1 and HHEX/IDE/KIF11 showed the strongest association with T2D in the meta-analysis including all three ethnic groups. However, consistent direction of effect was observed for many of the other SNPs in the study and in those carried out in European populations. The findings highlight the value of surveying across diverse racial/ethnic groups towards the fine-mapping efforts for the casual variants and also of the search for variants, which may be population-specific. The study underscores the need for further research to fully understand the genetic architecture of T2D in diverse populations.
The nuclear division in the budding yeast Cryptococcus neoformans, a basidiomycete fungus, differs from that of ascomycete budding yeasts like Saccharomyces cerevisiae. In C. neoformans, the nuclear envelope transiently ruptures during mitosis, allowing the evolutionarily conserved Aurora B kinase Ipl1 to localize to the nucleus and ensure high-fidelity chromosome segregation. Ipl1 is required for the timely breakdown of the nuclear envelope, and its spatio-temporal regulation influences Bim1 or/and dynein activity along with microtubule stability to ensure timely onset of nuclear division. Ipl1 ensures the integrity and timely disassembly of the mitotic spindle and phosphorylates She1 and Bim1, influencing dynein activity along the cMTs and spindle movement. C. neoformans divides by budding, and its microtubule organizing centers (MTOCs), microtubule fibers, microtubule-associated proteins (MAPs), and molecular motors regulate microtubule dynamics and the mitotic spindle's functioning. The cytoplasmic microtubules (cMTs) ensure proper spindle positioning and nuclear migration. The Aurora B kinase Ipl1 primarily senses the tension at the kinetochore, stabilizing bi-oriented kinetochore-MT attachments and destabilizing incorrect kinetochore-MT attachments. In C. neoformans, Ipl1 is essential for viability and plays a crucial role in maintaining ploidy during mitosis.
A study published in the journal Nature Genetics in 2017 investigated a case of an aggressive medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) that harbored a somatic RET p. Cys634Arg mutation, a known MTC driver. The researchers also found a germ-line RET substitution (p. Cys630=), which had been considered clinically irrelevant due to its synonymous nature. However, further investigation revealed that the synonymous mutation was in cis with the somatic RET p. Cys634Arg driver mutation and was sufficient to explain the increased RET mRNA level. The presence of the synonymous substitution created new exonic splicing enhancer motifs that enhanced SRp55 recruitment to the mutant allele, leading to more efficient maturation of its pre-mRNA and an increased abundance of mature mRNA encoding a constitutively active RET receptor. These findings provide evidence for a novel mechanism by which synonymous mutations can contribute to cancer progression. This study highlights the importance of considering synonymous mutations in cancer research, as they can have functional relevance and play driver roles in human cancer.
"Metagenomic sequencing of patient samples has the potential to be a highly effective method for diagnosing human infections, as it can capture and analyze all DNA or RNA from pathogenic organisms in a sample. However, the accuracy of this method depends on the quality and availability of genomes for comparison. While thousands of genomes are now available and this number is growing, the presence of contamination in published genomes poses a risk for falsely identifying the wrong pathogen. To address this issue, a new bioinformatics system has been developed to eliminate contamination and low-complexity genomic sequences in the draft genomes of eukaryotic pathogens. This has resulted in a database of ""clean"" eukaryotic pathogen genomes, which has been shown to provide better sensitivity and a significant reduction in false positives when used for diagnosis.Next-generation sequencing (NGS) has emerged as a valuable tool for human pathogen discovery and diagnosis. It provides a fast, specific, and relatively unbiased method of capturing the full spectrum of macro- and microorganisms in any sample. NGS has been shown to be particularly useful in cases where traditional histological, immunological, or molecular techniques are limited or yield incorrect or incomplete diagnoses. For example, NGS has been used to identify bacterial infections in fecal specimens, confirm cultured bacterial infections in urine samples, identify polymicrobial bacterial infections by directly sequencing urine samples, and diagnose bacterial infections in cerebrospinal fluid.Despite the growing number of sequenced pathogens, the dependence on reference databases for diagnosis still presents challenges. This is due to the fact that no database contains the full spectrum of all potential human pathogens and existing reference databases have been found to contain contamination. Additionally, microbial genome projects have predominantly focused on bacteria and viruses, with genome entries in databases such as GenBank and RefSeq reflecting this focus. This means that eukaryotic pathogens, which are critically important for the diagnosis of human infections, are underrepresented in genomic databases.EuPathDB is a database representing more than 250 eukaryotic microorganisms, including both known pathogens and other closely related non-infectious eukaryotic species. However, because no eukaryotic pathogen has yet been completely sequenced, this resource comprises primarily draft genomes at varying degrees of completeness. Despite this, EuPathDB is more comprehensive than the RefSeq database, containing more than 150 genomes that are absent from the RefSeq protozoa and fungi databases.Contamination and incompleteness in reference databases can cause bioinformatics analysis of sequencing reads to yield both false positive and false negative results, decreasing the overall reliability of NGS in pathogen diagnostics. To address this issue, a new method for eliminating genomic contamination has been developed, yielding a cleaned and filtered eukaryotic pathogen database for use in bioinformatics pipelines, including those intended for NGS diagnostics, with decreased false positive and false negative rates."
Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) is a major health problem in Uganda, caused by the unicellular protozoan parasite Trypanosoma brucei, which has three subspecies: T. b. brucei (Tbb), T. b. gambiense (Tbg), and T. b. rhodesiense (Tbr). Tbr and Tbg cause the acute and chronic forms of HAT, respectively. Tbr is restricted to certain regions of East Africa, while Tbg is more widespread in West and Central Africa. Both Tbr and Tbb can co-occur in the same non-human hosts as well as in the tsetse vector. However, recombination is known to happen only in the salivary glands of the tsetse. Tbr is not a reproductively isolated taxon but regarded as a host-range variant of Tbb. A single gene encoding the Serum Resistance Associated (SRA) protein allows Tbr to survive in humans. This gene possesses two main alleles across the Tbr distribution and could potentially be spread naturally by genetic exchange between Tbr and Tbb. Uganda is currently the only country in sub-Saharan Africa known to harbor all three subspecies of T. brucei. The locations of districts affected by HAT are shown in Fig . 1. During most of the 20th century, Tbr was limited to south-east Uganda in the old foci of Busoga (BS) and Bugiri (BG), and in areas bordering Tanzania and Kenya, such as Busia (BU). By the late 1980’s HAT appeared in Tororo (TR) and by 1998, HAT cases began to spread north and west being recorded in the Soroti (SR) district. From 2004 to date, all the districts in central Uganda-Kaberamaido (KA), Dokolo (DK), Lira (LR), Apac (AP), Kole (KO) —have reported HAT cases. The affected areas increased in size from 13, 820 to 34, 843 km2, doubling the human population at risk. Tbr and Tbg are now less than 120km apart. The epidemics in the new foci have been attributed to import of cattle carrying Tbr from disease endemic areas in the south. Analyses of microsatellite and mitochondrial haplotype data show that the populations of G. f. fuscipes north and south of Lake Kyoga are genetically distinct and have identified long distance dispersal events. Population genetics studies have been carried out on T. brucei isolates across Africa, including HAT foci in Uganda and western Kenya. Analysis of Tbr isolates from the old foci in southeastern Uganda (BS, BG, BU) by isoenzyme, RFLP, and microsatellite analyses show that they are relatively heterogeneous. Genotype has been correlated with clinical presentation in patients and virulence in experimental mice. Microsatellite analysis (7 loci) of Tbr populations from Tororo/Soroti and Malawi showed that levels of genetic diversity were much higher in the Malawi focus, with evidence of recent genetic exchange between isolates. The lack of genetic exchange and clonal, epidemic population structure of Tororo/Soroti Tbr agrees with the conclusions of previous population genetics studies. Thus, the local population structure of Tbr seems to depend on the relative amounts of clonal versus sexual reproduction, driven by transmission dynamics specific to the local conditions. A comprehensive study of genetic variation in Ugandan T. brucei was conducted using a set of 17 highly variable microsatellite loci to investigate the patterns of genetic variation among 269 Tbb and Tbr isolates from Uganda and the neighbouring region of western Kenya in order to understand the extent of genetic exchange both within and between Tbb and Tbr and to investigate the origin and spread of HAT in Uganda.
