The natural reservoir of ebolaviruses is still elusive, but recent data suggests that three species of arboreal fruit bats may be carriers of Zaire ebolavirus and a cave-dwelling fruit bat has been implicated as a natural host for marburgvirus. Filovirus outbreaks are sporadic, and the last new species of ebolavirus was discovered 14 years ago in Cote d'Ivoire. The antigen-capture, IgM, IgG, and newly designed real-time PCR assays were quickly transferred to the Uganda Virus Research Institute to facilitate rapid identification and isolation of Ebola cases for efficient control of the outbreak. The entire genome sequence of this virus was completed using a classic primer walking sequencing approach and revealed that the newly discovered virus differed from the four existing ebolavirus species with approximately 32% nucleotide difference from even the closest relative, Côte d'Ivoire ebolavirus. This high level of genetic diversity translates to considerable amino acid differences in the encoded virus proteins, including the important determinant of virus tropism and pathogenicity, the virus surface glycoprotein, and immunosuppressive VP35 protein. Retrospective analysis of case description, epidemiologic, and laboratory data from the Bundibugyo outbreak is ongoing. This investigation highlights the power of molecular detection and characterization tools to quickly identify new pathogens while providing a cautionary note regarding sole dependence on molecular techniques such as real-time PCR assays for detection of novel agents in biodefense or emerging disease surveillance programs.
The progression rates of Alzheimer's Disease (AD) vary significantly among patients, with some transiting the stages of the disease over a period of months, while others take decades. This variability poses a challenge in assessing the efficiency of treatment strategies. The Global Deterioration Scale (GDS) and Functional Assessment Staging procedure (FAST) are commonly used instruments to stage the course of AD, with each GDS/FAST stage having a published mean duration. However, the variance in stage durations is unknown. A statistical analysis of a cohort of 648 AD patients revealed that the standard deviations for stage durations are comparable with their mean values, indicating large variations in AD progression among patients. Such heterogeneity is consistent with the existence of several sub-groups of AD patients with different patterns of decline. Despite the usefulness of quantifying the average course of AD in terms of stage durations, it is essential to quantify the variance of GDS/FAST stage durations to judge the significance of any improvements observed in treatment strategies.
The study presents a model of adult neurogenesis in the hippocampus, focusing on its role in encoding and decoding memory patterns in a changing environment. The model is extended to include spatially driven input firing patterns in the form of grid cells in the entorhinal cortex. The network is trained to adapt to changing input statistics in a sequence of spatial environments using three distinct adaptation strategies: conventional synaptic plasticity, neuronal turnover, and additive neurogenesis. The simulations confirm that additive neurogenesis is the superior adaptation strategy, allowing the network to maintain high retrieval accuracy in new environments while preserving representations of earlier environments. Additionally, a more biologically plausible neurogenesis rule that incorporates cell death and enhanced plasticity of new granule cells has an overall performance significantly better than any one of the three individual strategies operating alone. This adaptation rule can be tailored to maximize the performance of the network when operating as either a short- or long-term memory store. The time course of adult neurogenesis over the lifetime of an animal raised under different hypothetical rearing conditions is also examined, with several distinct features that form a theoretical prediction that could be tested experimentally. Furthermore, the study shows that place cells can emerge and refine in a realistic manner in the model as a direct result of the sparsification performed by the dentate gyrus layer. Overall, the study demonstrates the potential of computational models in understanding the functional relevance of adult-born neurons and the importance of neurogenesis in the hippocampus.
African trypanosomes, the causes of human sleeping sickness and Nagana cattle disease, have a digenetic life cycle, multiplying as infective bloodstream (BS) forms in the blood and body fluids of their mammalian hosts and as procyclic insect form in the midgut of the tsetse fly vector. BS trypanosomes have one of the highest endocytic rates ever measured, with all vesicular trafficking of macromolecules taking place at the flagellar pocket. The lysosome is the final repository of cargo taken up from the host serum for nutritional and immune evasion purposes. BS trypanosomes lack catalase and selenocysteine-containing glutathione peroxidases, and hydroperoxide detoxification is achieved by 2-Cys-peroxiredoxins and non-selenium glutathione peroxidase (Px)-type enzymes. RNA interference studies have revealed that both types of peroxidases are essential, but proliferation of the Px-depleted BS parasites can be fully restored by supplementing the culture medium with the vitamin E analogue Trolox. In this study, the authors focus on the role of Px III and the cytosolic Px I-II in the viability of BS T. brucei. They find that the px III knockout results in parasites that display only a minor and transient growth retardation in vitro, while parasites lacking the cytosolic peroxidases (px I--II−/− cells) die within less than two hours after transfer into Trolox-free medium. Further investigation reveals that, in the absence of Trolox, BS px I--II−/− T. brucei undergo lysosomal disintegration, followed by damage of the mitochondrion and likely other cellular membranes, and total cell lysis. This process is closely linked to the endocytic uptake of iron ions.
PMEL is a well-conserved amyloidogenic protein expressed in pigment cells, forming intralumenal fibrils in melanosomes where eumelanins deposit. Allelic variants in several species are associated with reduced eumelanin levels in epidermal tissues, although it's unclear if they're gain-of-function or loss-of-function. A mouse line with the Pmel gene inactivated (Pmel−/−) shows viable, fertile mice with no obvious developmental defects. Melanosomes in Pmel−/− melanocytes are spherical compared to the oblong shape in wild-type animals. Despite a mild effect on coat color, there's a substantial reduction in eumelanin content in hair. PMEL is essential for maintaining efficient epidermal pigmentation. Vertebrates produce two types of pigment - red/yellow pheomelanins and black/brown eumelanins - with PMEL primarily involved in eumelanins synthesis. In mouse, PMEL expression starts in the retinal pigment epithelium and neural crest-derived melanoblasts, suggesting a function in the early stages of melanosome biogenesis. PMEL mutations in various species are associated with hypopigmentation, such as the silver allele in mice causing diluted black/brown eumelanins but no effect on pheomelanin, resulting in hair graying over time. PMEL fibrils have amyloid characteristics and may serve as a model for functional/non-pathological amyloid formation.
This study systematically reviewed and conducted a meta-analysis of the effectiveness of environmental methods for dengue vector control. The review followed PRISMA guidelines and searched PubMed, EMBASE, LILACS, the Cochrane Library, and Google Scholar. The CONSORT 2010 checklist was used for quality assessment. The meta-analysis calculated the difference-in-differences (DID) and difference-of-endlines (DOE) for the Breteau index (BI) and pupae per person index (PPI) for container covers with and without insecticides, waste management and clean-up campaigns, and elimination of breeding sites. Nineteen studies were included in the systematic review, and 16 studies were included in the meta-analysis.The study found that each of the investigated environmental methods showed some effectiveness in reducing larval and pupal densities of Aedes sp. mosquitoes. However, there is a need for more comparable high-quality studies to strengthen this evidence. The meta-analysis showed that container covers without insecticides and waste management with direct garbage collection achieved the strongest reductions for the BI, whereas container covers with insecticides and elimination of breeding places showed the strongest effects for the PPI.The study concludes that environmental interventions can be effective in controlling the immature stages of Aedes sp. mosquitoes, but the link between the reductions of vector populations and risk of transmission is not clear. Further research is needed to strengthen the evidence and clarify the link between vector populations and transmission risk.
"A new approach for therapeutic development is the identification of small molecules that inhibit protein synthesis by stalling the ribosome, specifically targeting PCSK9, a major regulator of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol. These compounds have shown promising results in preclinical models, reducing LDL cholesterol and affecting the translation of only a few off-target proteins. However, the impact of these compounds on cell physiology and ribosome quality control pathways is unknown. A genome-wide CRISPRi screen was conducted using a selective PCSK9 translational inhibitor, PF-06378503 (PF8503), to identify proteins and pathways that modulate cell growth. The two most potent genetic modifiers of cell fitness in the presence of PF8503 are the ubiquitin binding protein ASCC2 and helicase ASCC3, which bind to the ribosome and protect cells from toxic effects of high concentrations of the compound. Translation quality control proteins Pelota and HBS1L sensitize cells to PF8503 treatment. These results provide new insights into the selectivity of compounds that stall human translation and will aid the development of next-generation selective translation stalling compounds to treat disease. Proteins are the main druggable therapeutic targets for the treatment of human diseases, but many proteins remain ""undruggable"" due to the difficulty in identifying small molecule or biological inhibitors of their function. An alternative approach is to prevent the synthesis of target proteins in the first place by targeting the step of translation. However, targeting translation in a highly specific way remains an unsolved problem. Genomic screens, such as CRISPR interference (CRISPRi) screens, serve as powerful and unbiased tools to identify genetic modifiers of the action of small molecule inhibitors, reveal the pathways likely to be general cellular responses to the stress induced by translation inhibition, and suggest the cell dependencies most likely to be impacted by this class of inhibitors."
The regulation of messenger RNA (mRNA) stability plays a crucial role in controlling gene expression, ensuring transcript fidelity, and enabling cells to respond to environmental cues. However, unregulated enhancement of mRNA turnover can dampen cellular responses to signals. Herpesviruses, including Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV), induce widespread destruction of cellular mRNAs to block host gene expression and evade immune detection. KSHV promotes this phenotype via the activity of its viral SOX protein, which stimulates cellular transcriptome turnover through a unique mechanism involving aberrant polyadenylation. Transcripts in SOX-expressing cells exhibit extended poly (A) polymerase II-generated poly (A) tails and polyadenylation-linked mRNA turnover. SOX-induced polyadenylation changes correlate with its RNA turnover function, and inhibition of poly (A) tail formation blocks SOX activity. Both nuclear and cytoplasmic poly (A) binding proteins are critical cellular cofactors for SOX function, with the latter undergoing striking nuclear relocalization by SOX. SOX-induced mRNA turnover therefore represents both a novel mechanism of host shutoff and a new model system to probe the regulation of poly (A) tail-stimulated mRNA turnover in mammalian cells. KSHV is the etiologic agent of several neoplasms, including Kaposi's sarcoma (KS), and the most common neoplasm associated with untreated HIV infection. KSHV undergoes both latency and lytic replication, and lytic KSHV infection destroys the host transcriptome by promoting global mRNA degradation via unknown mechanisms. The SOX protein mediates this host shutoff and has homologs across the entire herpesvirus family, but its mechanism of mRNA turnover remains unknown due to its lack of intrinsic ribonuclease activity. Instead, SOX likely functions by modulating one or more cellular RNA turnover pathways. Control of message stability represents a powerful means of regulating gene expression both on an individual and a global scale, and nearly all eukaryotic mRNAs are protected from exonucleolytic attack by a 5′ cap structure and a 3′ poly (A) tail. Cleavage and polyadenylation are cotranscriptional events, and polyadenylation generally serves to stabilize mRNAs, whereas in bacteria and some organelles, it facilitates RNA turnover. However, it is now becoming clear that polyadenylation can be a facilitator of eukaryotic mRNA degradation as well. In particular, yeast possess a nuclear polyadenylation complex that marks aberrantly processed RNAs for quality control-mediated turnover via the addition of short poly (A) tails. Analogous pathways may function in higher eukaryotes, as polyadenylated precursors to RNA turnover have also been detected in mammalian cells. Here, it is revealed that KSHV SOX-induced host shutoff is intimately linked to mRNA polyadenylation. SOX promotes aberrant polyadenylation of cellular transcripts in a manner dependent on its RNA turnover activity. Transcript degradation requires both nuclear and cytoplasmic poly (A) binding proteins, the latter of which undergoes striking nuclear relocalization in a host shutoff-dependent manner. In the absence of cellular 3′ end processing and polyadenylation, SOX can no longer target mRNAs for destruction, although addition of a templated poly (A) tail reinstates SOX-induced turnover. These findings suggest SOX is directing a novel polyadenylation-dependent mechanism of host shutoff and demonstrate a link between polyadenylation and mRNA destruction in higher eukaryotes.
The type III interferon (IFN)λ receptor, IL-28R, is highly expressed in the respiratory tract and is crucial for defense against some viral pathogens. However, its role in innate immunity against bacterial pathogens is unclear. In a study, S. aureus and P. aeruginosa infections in mice caused significant production of IFNλ in the lungs. IL-28R null mice showed increased clearance of these bacteria from the lungs, reduced lung pathology, and lower pro-inflammatory cytokine levels. In vitro studies revealed that IFNλ downregulates microRNA miR-21, leading to sustained PDCD4 expression, which promotes inflammatory signaling. Mice lacking the IFNλ receptor or PDCD4 had improved clearance of both airway pathogens and less pathology, suggesting IFNλ promotes inflammation by inhibiting miR-21 regulation of PDCD4 during bacterial pneumonia. These findings suggest a potential therapeutic approach for treating bacterial pneumonia by modulating IFNλ or inhibiting IL-1R.
A retrospective study over 23 years on 781 cases of advanced stage-2 sleeping sickness admitted at the National Reference Center for Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) in the Democratic Republic of Congo analyzed mortality trends and risk factors. Death was the outcome variable, with age, gender, disease duration, body fluid parasites, cytorachy, protidorachy, clinical status, and treatment regimen as predictors. The study found that clinical status on admission, high protidorachy, presence of parasites in the CSF, and high cytorachy were significantly associated with death. The algorithm for initial clinical status assessment can serve as a basis for standardized tools in the clinical management and information exchange in epidemiological reports of HAT.
A new imaging arena and tracking algorithm were developed to study the social behavior of large groups of Drosophila melanogaster flies. This allowed for the reliable tracking of a large number of flies and the creation of an algorithm to quantify changes in the social network in response to prior social isolation. It was observed that isolation significantly and swiftly enhanced individual and local social network parameters. The genome-wide molecular correlates of these behavioral changes were then explored, and it was found that while behavior changed throughout the six days of isolation, gene expression alterations occurred largely on day one and were mostly in metabolic genes. These changes were verified through the increase of lipid content in isolated flies. Therefore, this new pipeline can be used to unravel the behavioral, molecular, and physiological impact of isolation on social network dynamics in Drosophila. Social interactions are a key feature of many species, and isolation is known to affect the onset and progress of diseases in humans. Socially interacting species are influenced by isolation, and changes in social conditions may influence gene expression patterns. Drosophila melanogaster is a powerful genetic and neuroscience model for studying social behavior, but appropriate experimental setups, reliable tracking, behavioral classification, and detailed social network analysis are needed. The pipeline developed in this study includes an efficient and relatively low-cost acquisition setup, an improved tracking algorithm for up to 16 male flies, a machine learning method for classification of social interactions, and a novel algorithm for computing an average social network to analyze social structure. This pipeline was used to study behavioral changes due to isolation and correlate these with changes in genome-wide gene expression, resulting in the discovery of strong and specific effects of isolation on social network dynamics, metabolic gene expression, and animal physiology.
The study conducted in rural Bangladesh aimed to evaluate the impact of a smartphone adaptation of the World Health Organization (WHO) diarrheal disease management guidelines on the adherence to clinical guidelines for the treatment of diarrheal diseases. The 'Rehydration Calculator' was developed based on end-user feedback and evaluated during the fall 2015 cholera season at two hospitals. The study consisted of a 6-week pre-intervention and 6-week intervention period with a 10-day post-discharge follow-up. The primary outcome was adherence to guidelines for prescriptions of intravenous (IV) fluids, antibiotics, and zinc. A total of 841 patients were enrolled, and the intervention resulted in a decrease in the proportion of prescriptions for IV fluids and an increase in the proportion of prescriptions for the recommended antibiotic azithromycin. However, limitations, including an absence of a concurrent control group and no independent dehydration assessment during the pre-intervention, were noted. Despite these limitations, the study demonstrated the potential of a smartphone-based tool to improve guideline adherence, providing a foundation for a randomized controlled trial to expand on these findings. The study also highlighted the challenges faced by medical facilities in resource-limited settings, where logistical, educational, and temporal constraints can impact the quality of clinical care provided, particularly during outbreaks or seasonal swells of diarrheal diseases. The 'Rehydration Calculator' was developed to address some of these challenges by adapting the WHO diarrhea management guidelines onto a smartphone platform, with functionality including weight-for-age estimation, dehydration assessment, and treatment recommendations.
The dynamics of host-parasite interactions are crucial in determining the impact of climate change on disease, as both host and parasite traits can be strongly affected by temperature. However, the effects of environmental change on disease dynamics are difficult to predict due to the distinct temperature dependencies of host and parasite traits. A study using experimental data from Daphnia magna and a microsporidian parasite fitted a mechanistic model of within-host parasite population dynamics, using parameters specified by relationships arising from the metabolic theory of ecology. The model effectively predicts host survival, parasite growth, and the cost of infection across temperature while using less than half the parameters compared to modeling temperatures discretely. This approach of linking simple metabolic models with a mechanistic host-parasite framework can be used to predict temperature responses of parasite population dynamics at the within-host level. The metabolic theory of ecology (MTE) posits that the thermal dependencies of biological processes across levels of biological organization can be deduced from the thermal dependency of the basic metabolic rate of individual organisms. MTE further suggests that the Van't Hoff-Arrhenius model can predict an organism’s metabolic rate and related processes based on temperature. These models can inform classical models of host-parasite dynamics to estimate the net effect of temperature changes on disease prevalence and severity. The simplicity and generality of this framework provide a valuable approach for predicting the outcomes and consequences of infections for hosts and parasites in light of climate change.
GABAergic interneurons, which are outnumbered by excitatory cells in the brain, play a crucial role in maintaining normal brain activity. These interneurons come in various types that differ in their anatomical, physiological, and biophysical properties, leading to the hypothesis that individual types perform specific computations in neuronal microcircuits. Distinct connectivity motifs exist among these interneuron types, such as Parvalbumin-expressing (PV) interneurons preferably inhibiting the perisomatic regions and basal dendrites of excitatory pyramidal cells (PCs), Somatostatin-expressing (SOM) neurons mainly targeting the apical dendrites of PCs, and Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP) interneurons mainly connecting to the dendrite-targeting SOM neurons, providing a disinhibitory circuit for the distal dendrite of PCs. A SOM-PV motif plays a key role in the redistribution of somatic and dendritic inhibition, while a SOM-VIP motif may control the PV/SOM-mediated redistribution of somatic and dendritic inhibition. This SOM-VIP motif, when optimized, can enable a switch between two distinct processing modes in which top-down inputs arriving at the apical dendrites of PCs are either integrated or obliterated via VIP cell modulation. Mutual inhibition between SOM and VIP neurons, along with spike-frequency adaptation, short-term facilitation, and the absence of recurrent connections among both VIP and SOM neurons, underpins the amplification abilities of the microcircuit, allowing for signal amplification, frequency selection, and switching behavior.
Microbiota have a significant impact on various aspects of host phenotype, including disease, and can be linked to specific phenotypes through microbiome-wide association studies (MWAS) that compare microbial abundances between two groups of samples. However, abundance differences may also reflect indirect effects due to microbial interactions. The authors of this study used techniques from statistical physics to develop a method to remove indirect associations and applied it to the largest dataset on pediatric inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The method corrected the inflation of p-values in standard association tests and showed that only a small subset of associations is directly linked to the disease. Direct associations had a much higher accuracy in separating cases from controls and pointed to immunomodulation, butyrate production, and the brain-gut axis as important factors in IBD. The study demonstrates that considering microbial interactions is crucial in MWAS to distinguish taxa directly linked to disease from those affected only through their interactions with other species.
Wolbachia, a common bacterial symbiont in insects, has been studied for its potential to restrict the transmission of mosquito-borne pathogens such as dengue virus (DENV), Chikungunya virus (CHIKV), West Nile virus (WNV), yellow fever virus (YFV), and Plasmodium. The majority of research has focused on DENV replication and has shown that Wolbachia effectively reduces DENV replication and transmission when introduced as a stable infection in the naturally uninfected host Aedes aegypti. However, several disease transmitting mosquito species remain recalcitrant to Wolbachia transinfection, and natural Wolbachia infection models have been examined to provide insight into Wolbachia-host-pathogen interactions. A study by Baton et al. found that wFlu infection in its natural host Ae. fluviatilis enhanced oocyst infection with the avian malaria parasite P. gallinaceum. Zele et al. also showed that in the natural mosquito-Wolbachia-Plasmodium combination, Wolbachia increased the susceptibility of Culex pipiens mosquitoes to P. relictum. A study by Mousson et al. found that Ae. albopictus naturally superinfected with the two Wolbachia strains wAlbA and wAlbB infection limited the transmission, but not replication of DENV. These studies suggest that the degree of pathogen modulation from different host-Wolbachia combinations can differ considerably depending on the mode of infection, the host, and the pathogen. Therefore, it is important not to base predictions of pathogen modulation in a particular host-Wolbachia strain combination on results obtained from divergent infection modes and host species. In this study, the effect of wAlbB on replication and transmission of DENV and WNV (Kunjin strain) in Ae. aegypti infected through both transient somatic infection and stable transinfection was compared. The results showed significantly lower Wolbachia infection densities in transiently infected Ae. aegypti when compared to the stable infected line. Both Wolbachia infection models displayed similar effects, blocking replication and transmission of both DENV and WNV (Kunjin strain). These results conclusively show that neither DENV nor WNV (Kunjin strain) infection is enhanced in Ae. aegypti either transiently or stably infected with wAlbB.
Cilia are microtubule-based organelles that play a crucial role in various cellular functions, including signal transduction. In vertebrates, the Inversin compartment (InvC) is a portion of the cilia shaft adjacent to the transition zone (TZ), and its mechanisms of establishment and maintenance are unknown. The roundworm C. elegans has a ciliated nervous system, with cilia shafts divided into two regions: a proximal microtubule doublet-based region attached to the TZ and a distal microtubule singlet-based region. It has been suggested that C. elegans cilia possess an InvC, similar to mammalian primary cilia. This study explores the biogenesis, structure, and composition of the C. elegans ciliary doublet region and InvC, finding that the InvC is conserved and distinct from the doublet region. Genes associated with these regions modulate the sizes of the NPHP-2 InvC and ARL-13 doublet region and the glutamylation modification of tubulin, a post-translational modification. The study concludes that components in these two regions interact to regulate ciliogenesis via cilia placement, ciliary microtubule ultrastructure, and protein localization.
The study investigates the role of the polarity protein Scribble in the development and regeneration of myelin by oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system (CNS). Scribble is expressed throughout oligodendroglial development, up-regulated in mature oligodendrocytes, and localized to both developing and mature CNS myelin sheaths. Knockdown of Scribble in cultured oligodendroglia results in disrupted morphology and myelination initiation, while its conditional elimination in mice disrupts myelin initiation during development and following focal demyelination, and suppresses the ERK/MAP kinase pathway. These findings highlight the essential role of Scribble and other intracellular polarity regulators in myelination and remyelination, and provide new insights into the mechanisms of remyelination failure in demyelinating diseases such as multiple sclerosis.
Streptolysin S (SLS) is a bacteriocin-like haemolytic and cytotoxic virulence factor produced by Group A Streptococcus (GAS), the causative agent of various diseases such as pharyngitis, impetigo, necrotizing fasciitis, and streptococcal toxic shock syndrome. Recently, it has been discovered that other notorious Gram-positive pathogenic bacteria, including Listeria monocytogenes, Clostridium botulinum, and Staphylococcus aureus, also produce related peptides. The L. monocytogenes cluster is particularly interesting as it is found exclusively among a subset of lineage I strains, which are responsible for most outbreaks of listeriosis. The expression of these genes results in the production of a haemolytic and cytotoxic factor, Listeriolysin S, which contributes to the virulence of the pathogen. This discovery suggests that the genetic basis for the enhanced virulence of a proportion of lineage I L. monocytogenes has been revealed, and the distribution of these genes may explain the reason for the enhanced virulence of certain strains of this pathogen. Bacteriocins, including Class I lantibiotics, have been of particular interest due to their unusual post-translational modifications, which are required for their activity. Most modified bacteriocins have been investigated for their potential applications in medicine or food, but two exceptional examples of bacteriocin-like modified peptides that are cytotoxic and contribute to the virulence of bacterial pathogens are the lantibiotic Cytolysin (Enterococcus faecalis) and Streptolysin S (Group A Streptococcus). Streptolysin S production is significant as it contributes to the cytotoxicity, inflammatory activation, and polymorphonuclear neutrophil (PMN) resistance of GAS, thereby playing a role in necrosis and systemic spread. In-silico analysis has demonstrated that gene clusters potentially encoding Sls-like factors are also present in some of the most notorious Gram-positive pathogens, including Listeria monocytogenes, Staphylococcus aureus, and Clostridium botulinum. A specific focus on the L. monocytogenes cluster has revealed that it encodes an inducible cytotoxic and haemolytic peptide, Listeriolysin S, which plays a role in the survival of the pathogen in PMNs and contributes to its virulence in the mouse model. Notably, the Listeriolysin S-associated cluster is strain variable, being present in a subset of isolates from lineage I, the evolutionary lineage associated with most epidemics associated with this often fatal pathogen.
Mycetoma is a chronic, progressive granulomatous inflammatory disease caused by fungi or bacteria, characterized by the formation of macroscopic structures called grains surrounded by a significant inflammatory reaction. A study at the Mycetoma Research Centre in Sudan examined the expression of interleukin-17 (IL-17) and matrix metalloprotease-9 (MMP-9) in mycetoma lesions and its correlation with disease severity. The study found that IL-17 was mainly expressed in Zones I and II, while MMP-9 was detected mainly in Zones II and III, with higher expression in Actinomadura pelletierii and Streptomyces somaliensis biopsies compared to Madurella mycetomatis biopsies. The study also found a direct correlation between MMP-9 and IL-17 levels and the disease duration. These findings suggest that the expression levels of IL-17 and MMP-9 in mycetoma granuloma formation may be correlated with the severity of the disease, independent of the causative agent. Further studies are needed to investigate the precise function of IL-17 and MMP-9 in the formation of the mycetoma granuloma and their interaction with other cytokines and chemokines within mycetoma lesions.
"The Ewing's Sarcoma oncoprotein family (EFS) includes IDPs that exhibit many features of ""fuzziness,"" a phenomenon characterized by IDP polyvalency, sequence-insensitivity, and a dynamic ensemble of disordered bound-state conformations. The transcriptional activation domain of the EFS oncoprotein family (EAD) is one such IDP, with multiple EAD aromatic side chains driving molecular recognition. A hypothesized polycation-π model suggests that EAD-target binding involves polycation-π contacts between a disordered EAD and basic residues on the target. Experimental effects of EAD sequence variations, including aromatic number, aromatic density, and charge perturbations, support this cation-π model, which is further validated by a coarse-grained EAD chain model and a corresponding analytical model. EAD-target binding is thus driven by a balance between EAD conformational entropy and favorable EAD-target cation-π contacts. This highly versatile mode of molecular recognition offers a general conceptual framework for promiscuous target recognition by polyvalent IDPs."
Borrelia burgdorferi, the bacterium that causes Lyme disease, has two putative ATP-dependent Lon proteases, Lon-1 and Lon-2. Lon-1 is upregulated in response to blood, while Lon-2 is not. Both are expressed during culture in BSK-H medium. The presence of two lon gene homologs is rare in eubacteria, but appears to be unique to the genus Borrelia. Lon-1 and Lon-2 are closely related to each other but are distinct from the canonical Lons of E. coli and B. subtilis. Phylogenetic analysis of the NH2-terminal domains of Lon-1 and Lon-2 shows that they are especially dissimilar, suggesting that they may recognize different substrates. Lon-2 clusters separately from all other bacteria, indicating a close relationship exclusive to the genus Borrelia. B. burgdorferi Lon-1 was studied for its potential role in remodeling spirochete outer surface lipoproteins during the transition from the tick to the mammal and as a potential virulence factor. However, recombinant Lon-1 (rLon-1) did not show ATP-dependent proteolytic activity and was not able to degrade FITC-casein in the presence of ATP. The ATPase activity of rLon-1S714A confirmed that the ATPase and the proteolytic domains function independently, and that introduction of a mutation into the proteolytic domain does not affect the ability of Lon-1 to hydrolyze ATP. Further study of B. burgdorferi Lon function is needed to understand its role in the bacteria, but it is clear that Lon-1 and Lon-2 have distinct functional roles and that Lon-2 functions in a manner consistent with canonical Lon while Lon-1 has a unique role in host adaptation during the transition from tick to mammal.
Fc gamma receptor (FcγR)-mediated antibody functions play a crucial role in preventing HIV infection, and one such function, antibody-dependent phagocytosis (ADP), is thought to be involved in controlling other viral infections. However, the role of ADP in HIV infection is unclear. Researchers measured the ability of HIV-specific polyclonal and monoclonal antibodies to mediate the internalization of HIV-1 virions and HIV-1-decorated cells by phagocytes. They found minimal or no ADP of virions with any of the antibodies, but after coating virions with gp41 or gp41-derived peptides, gp41-specific mAbs efficiently mediated phagocytosis. A minimum of a few hundred gp41 molecules were needed for successful phagocytosis, similar to the number of envelope spikes on viruses that are readily phagocytosed. Phagocytosis or trogocytosis could play a role in clearing HIV-infected cells and cells on the verge of infection. In vivo studies have shown that FcγR-mediated antibody functions play an important role in preventing lentivirus infections, but there is no direct evidence to support the role of any particular FcγR-mediated function in protection. Antibody-dependent phagocytosis (ADP) occurs when antibody-opsonized virions or cells bearing viral antigens are internalized via FcγRs into phagocytic cells. A related phenomenon known as trogocytosis occurs when membrane components from one cell are transferred to another, a process that can be mediated by antibody in an FcγR-dependent manner. Phagocytosis plays a key role in antibody-mediated protection against some viral pathogens, but internalization of antibody-opsonized dengue virus through FcγRs enhances infection of phagocytes and is thought to be a mechanism underlying severe dengue virus infections in humans. Several studies have begun to explore the potential role of phagocytosis in HIV infection, but the role of phagocytosis in preventing or enhancing infection remains unknown.
Human hookworm infection is a highly endemic disease in many low- and middle-income countries, affecting approximately 500 million people and causing 2,126,280 DALYs (Disability-Adjusted Life Years) in 2016. However, the global economic and health impact of hookworm is not well understood, and its economic burden exceeds published estimates for several diseases that receive more attention, such as rotavirus. The disease primarily affects children and adults and leads to iron-deficiency anemia, malnutrition, and chronic health problems. Despite mass drug administration programs, the disease burden remains high due to a lack of significant impact on hookworm-related anemia.To estimate the economic and health burden of hookworm infection, a computational simulation model was developed using a Monte Carlo method in Microsoft Excel and Crystal Ball add-in. The model determined the productivity losses and DALYs for hookworm infection by country, WHO region, and globally from the societal perspective. The model considered age-specific hookworm prevalence, intensity level of each hookworm infection, health outcomes, and productivity losses. The model estimated the probability of low, moderate, and heavy intensity infection and converted each case into health outcomes, resulting in productivity losses and DALYs.The model found that hookworm infection resulted in a total of 2,126,280 DALYs using 2004 disability weight estimates and 4,087,803 DALYs using 2010 disability weight estimates, excluding cognitive impairment outcomes. Total productivity losses varied, ranging from $7.5 billion to $138.9 billion annually using gross national income per capita as a proxy for annual wages and $2.5 billion to $43.9 billion using minimum wage as a proxy for annual wages.In conclusion, hookworm infection has a significant economic and health burden, exceeding published estimates for several diseases that receive more attention. Despite control programs, hookworm's disease burden remains high, and a better understanding of its economic and health burden is necessary for decision-makers to determine how much time, energy, and resources to invest in hookworm control. The computational simulation model developed in this study provides a comprehensive estimate of the economic and health burden of hookworm infection and can inform decision-making for hookworm control.
Hypoxic injury to the developing human brain is a major cause of neurodevelopmental impairments in premature infants, but the mechanisms by which hypoxia disrupts connectivity in the central nervous system (CNS) are not well understood. Recent work in the invertebrate Caenorhabditis elegans has shown that hypoxia causes discrete axon pathfinding errors, and a similar effect has been found in the forebrain neurons of zebrafish (Danio rerio) after developmental hypoxic injury. These pathfinding errors result from activation of the hypoxia-inducible transcription factor (hif1) pathway and are mimicked by chemical inducers of the hif1 pathway or by expression of constitutively active hif1α. Blocking transcriptional activation by hif1α helps prevent the guidance defects. The receptor ephA4a is expressed in a pattern complementary to the misrouting axons, and ephrinB2a, a target of hif1 pathway activation, mediates the pathfinding errors via a reverse-signaling mechanism. Magnesium sulfate, which is known to improve neurodevelopmental outcomes in preterm births, protects against pathfinding errors by preventing upregulation of ephrinB2a. These results suggest that evolutionarily conserved genetic pathways regulate connectivity changes in the CNS in response to hypoxia and support a potential neuroprotective role for magnesium.
This study focused on evaluating pulmonary lesions in an experimental model of paracoccidioidomycosis (PCM) in mice using high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) and histopathological analysis. Male BALB/c mice were infected with Paracoccidioides brasiliensis conidia and scanned using HRCT every four weeks to determine pulmonary lesions, quantify lung density, and reconstruct and quantify lung air structure. Lungs were also analyzed by histopathology and histomorphometry. The study found that HRCT is a useful tool for the evaluation and quantification of pulmonary damage in experimental mouse PCM. The experimental design decreases the need to sacrifice a large number of animals and serves to monitor treatment efficacy. The study also demonstrated that the infection causes granulomatous inflammation of the pulmonary parenchyma leading to fibrosis and severe restriction of respiratory function. The model allowed for the evaluation of histopathological and immunological pulmonary tissue responses occurring during the active and residual stages of the process. The study suggests that recognition and monitoring of CT patterns associated with this model of disease could improve understanding of the anatomo-spatial distribution of lesions and their time course in the same animal. Additionally, imaging could also be used to evaluate in vivo therapeutic responses.
A novel marker for latent L. donovani infection, an interferon-gamma release assay (IFN-γRA), was proposed and tested to detect the cell-mediated immune response in VL. The study used a commercial kit, QuantiFERON, and evaluated five different leishmania-specific antigens from L. donovani. The study found that a whole-blood SLA-based QuantiFERON assay can be used to measure the cell-mediated immune response in L. donovani infection. The assay based on SLA had a sensitivity of 80% and specificity of 100%. The study also found that the positive IFN-γ response to stimulation with leishmania antigen in patients with active VL was contradictory to the conventional finding of a non-proliferative antigen-specific response of peripheral blood mononuclear cells and needs further research. VL is a chronic systemic disease that is fatal if left untreated, and it is highly endemic in countries such as India, Nepal, Bangladesh, Sudan, and Brazil. The study highlights the importance of identifying and documenting trends in incident L. donovani infections for the VL elimination initiative. Currently, serological methods and leishmanin skin testing are used to document incident infection, but their value as markers of infection is not firmly established. The study suggests that markers of the cellular immune response, such as T cell proliferation and IFN-γ released by activated T cells, hold promise for detecting latent Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. A similar assay based on leishmania antigen might also be valuable for leishmaniasis. A recent study explored the use of a modified QuantiFERON assay to detect the cell-mediated immune response against L. infantum. The study developed a novel IFN-γRA based on the QuantiFERON test system and evaluated its potential to detect L. donovani infection.
Gastrointestinal infections caused by enteric yersiniae can lead to persistent complications such as relapsing enteritis and severe autoimmune disorders. The bacteria must cope with hostile surroundings to establish a persistent infection, which is enhanced by the CNFY toxin that induces inflammatory responses and extensive tissue destruction. Suppression of CNFY function increases interferon-gamma-mediated responses and facilitates the establishment of a commensal-type lifestyle. Yersinia pseudotuberculosis infections in humans usually result in self-limiting gastrointestinal disorders but can occasionally lead to autoimmune disorders. The bacteria can persist in the intestinal mucosa and lymphoid tissue for several years, causing chronic ileitis, relapsing enteritis, and the development of reactive arthritis. A murine infection model for persistent Y. pseudotuberculosis infection revealed that sublethal infection results in prolonged asymptomatic colonization of the cecum and shedding of Yersinia with the feces in a fraction of mice. A cnfY mutant showed early reprogramming from virulent to persistent mode, which triggers a host response that allows a commensal-type life-style, promoting the establishment of asymptomatic, persistent infection. In summary, the CNFY toxin plays a crucial role in the persistence and pathogenicity of Y. pseudotuberculosis infections, and its suppression can increase interferon-gamma-mediated responses and facilitate the establishment of a commensal-type lifestyle, promoting the establishment of asymptomatic, persistent infection.
A novel pathogenicity gene, DES1, was identified in Magnaporthe oryzae, which is a significant rice pathogen causing blast disease. This gene plays a crucial role in counter-defenses against host basal resistance during colonization and further reproduction in host plants. The DES1 gene encodes a serine-rich protein with unknown biochemical properties and is conserved in filamentous Ascomycetes. The loss of DES1 in the fungus leads to the failure of host colonization and induces strong plant defense responses. The Δdes1 mutant displayed reduced infectious hyphal extension, resulting in decreased pathogenicity. The DES1 mutant also exhibited hypersensitivity to oxidative stress and a significant reduction in the activity and transcription level of extracellular enzymes, including peroxidases and laccases. In the interaction with a susceptible rice cultivar, rice cells inoculated with the Δdes1 mutant exhibited strong defense responses, including brown granules in primary infected cells, the accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), the generation of autofluorescent materials, and PR gene induction in neighboring tissues. Furthermore, the suppression of ROS generation significantly reduced defense responses in plant tissues challenged with the Δdes1 mutant, allowing the mutant to recover its normal infectious growth. Overall, DES1 functions as a novel pathogenicity gene that regulates the activity of fungal proteins, compromising ROS-mediated plant defense.
Schistosomiasis, a parasitic infection common in the tropics and subtropics, is transmitted through freshwater snails and its prevalence is influenced by environmental factors. In Ghana, the distribution of Schistosoma haematobium and Schistosoma mansoni is not even, with S. haematobium being more prevalent. Model-based geostatistics (MBG) is used to predict prevalence and determine intervention strategies. However, a study in Ghana found that using MBG to determine the appropriate treatment regimen for S. haematobium infection in schools would result in 28% of children being undertreated and 12% receiving treatment without need. The predictive map for Ghana is not adequate for guiding the national program and modelling must be a tool complementary to empiric assessments. Continual empiric testing and model refining is necessary for the practical usefulness of predictive risk mapping.
In the reproductive process, sperm must navigate through the female reproductive tract to locate and fertilize oocytes. While much is known about sperm motility in aquatic species, the mechanisms guiding sperm to oocytes in internally fertilizing animals are less clear. Caenorhabditis elegans is a useful model for studying sperm behavior and fertilization due to its transparant epidermis, allowing visualization of sperm distribution and motility. Oocytes synthesize F-series prostaglandins (PGs) from polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) provided in yolk lipoprotein complexes. These PGs function collectively and largely redundantly to promote sperm guidance. The synthesis of CePGF2, an analog of PGF2α, is dependent on 20-carbon PUFA synthesis and transport to oocytes. In mammals, mammalian cyclooxygenase-dependent pathways convert PUFAs into PGH intermediates, but C. elegans utilizes distinct biochemical mechanisms. A conserved cytochrome P450 enzyme, whose human homolog is implicated in Bietti's Crystalline Dystrophy, negatively regulates prostaglandin synthesis. Overall, these results suggest a model where multiple cyclooxygenase-independent prostaglandins function together to promote sperm motility important for fertilization, and this pathway may be conserved. These findings have implications for understanding the complex processes surrounding sperm guidance and fertilization, and may provide insight into potential targets for reproductive health and fertility treatments.
The immunogenicity of biotherapeutics can pose a significant barrier to their widespread clinical application, leading to the need for improved deimmunization technologies. A recent study describes algorithms that optimize proteins for reduced T cell epitope content while maintaining high-level function, revealing that there is no single global optimum for protein deimmunization. Instead, mutagenic epitope deletion yields a spectrum of designs with tradeoffs between immunogenic potential and molecular function. The Pareto frontier, or the set of undominated variants for which no other single design exhibits better performance in both criteria, has been designed, constructed, and evaluated experimentally for a therapeutic enzyme. Various measures of protein performance were found to map a functional sequence space that correlated well with computational predictions, representing the first systematic and rigorous assessment of the functional penalty that must be paid for pursuing progressively more deimmunized biotherapeutic candidates. These algorithms may prove useful in augmenting, accelerating, and de-risking experimental deimmunization efforts.
In eukaryotes, sexual reproduction typically involves meiosis, which relies on a reciprocal exchange of DNA between homologous chromosomes, known as crossover (CO). The frequency and distribution of COs are regulated by intrinsic and extrinsic factors, with more known about the molecular mechanisms governing the former. A study on Arabidopsis thaliana discovered that elevated temperature induces meiotic hyper-recombination, and the extra COs are derived from the major Type I interference-sensitive pathway. These findings suggest that environmental cues modulate plant meiotic recombination and offer practical applications. Meiosis creates haploid gametes from diploid progenitor cells through a specialized form of cell division, characterized by DNA exchange between homologous chromosomes. CO formation is critical for stabilizing homologous chromosome pairing and ensuring proper chromosome segregation during meiosis. In Arabidopsis, approximately 200 DSBs are formed in each meiocyte, but only about 10 are repaired to form COs, while the remaining DSBs are repaired as non-crossovers. Perturbations in DSB frequency do not concomitantly alter CO frequency, indicating that CO frequency is under homeostatic control. However, CO number and position can be modulated by external factors such as nutrient availability, exposure to environmental toxins, stress, and temperature.
The paper describes a novel computational approach to help bench researchers analyze the vast and rapidly evolving terrain of molecular biomedicine data. The approach involves a knowledge-based system that combines reading, reasoning, and reporting methods. Reading methods extract information from external resources, either structured or unstructured, and track knowledge provenance. Reasoning methods enrich the knowledge that results from reading by noting relationships between genes, such as two genes annotated to the same ontology term or database entry, and calculating a combined reliability score. Reporting methods visualize the combined network of relationships in a tool that facilitates the knowledge-based analysis of experimental data. The implementation of this approach, called the Hanalyzer, was demonstrated on a large-scale gene expression array dataset relevant to craniofacial development. The tool was critical in the creation of hypotheses regarding the roles of four genes never previously characterized as involved in craniofacial development, which were validated by further experimental work. Human knowledge in biomedical research is expanding at an exponential pace, with over 10 million publications indexed by the National Library of Medicine and structured knowledge in the form of molecular biology relevant databases also growing at an impressive rate. However, even with the U.S. National Institutes of Health investing over $52 million to support ontology development and use, it is still unable to keep up with the volume of relevant publications, making it difficult for biomedical researchers to keep up with biomedical knowledge. The Hanalyzer system constrains knowledge to be compatible with the Web Ontology Language and represents relationships as binary or n-ary, depending on the number of individuals or values linked. The system uses the practice recommended in the W3C working group note Defining N-ary Relations on the Semantic Web to represent more than one other individual or value. The system begins from a target list of genes of interest from a particular experiment, and extracts relationships describing protein-protein and protein-DNA interactions from databases and the literature. The system combines relationships from different databases and assay types, and assigns reliability scores to each assay type. The system also extracts protein transport events, protein-protein interaction assertions, and what proteins are expressed in which cell types from the literature using the OpenDMAP system. Overall, the system helps bench researchers navigate the vast and rapidly evolving terrain of molecular biomedicine data and facilitates the knowledge-based analysis of experimental data.
Fasciola hepatica, a helminth parasite, releases extracellular vesicles (EVs) which can modulate host immunity. These EVs have surface proteins and oligosaccharides that interact with host cell surfaces. In a study, two EV sub-populations, 15k and 120k, were found to have different origins - 15k from gastrodermal epithelial cells and 120k from the protonephridial (excretory) system. Proteomic analysis revealed 380 surface proteins, including virulence factors, membrane transport proteins, and molecules involved in EV biogenesis/trafficking. Glycan analysis showed that while both EV populations had high mannose sugars, their lectin profiles differed from each other and from the parasite surface tegument. PNGase F, but not exo- and endo-glycosidases, remodeled the surface oligosaccharides and blocked EV uptake by host macrophages. Pre-treatment with host antibodies or purified antibodies against specific EV surface proteins enhanced EV uptake by macrophages. This study shows the diversity of EV biogenesis and trafficking pathways in F. hepatica and the molecular interaction between parasite EVs and host cells, providing insights into the development of therapeutic blocking agents.
A study has identified the transcription factor CDF2 as a regulator of microRNA (miRNA) biogenesis in plants. CDF2 interacts with DCL1, a key protein in miRNA processing, and affects the accumulation of a population of miRNAs. CDF2 binds directly to the promoters of certain miRNAs and acts as a transcription activator or repressor. It preferentially binds to the pri-miRNAs it regulates and affects DCL1-mediated processing of these pri-miRNAs. Genetically, CDF2 works in the same pathway as miR156 or miR172 to control flowering. The study highlights the importance of proper miRNA levels in controlling plant development and the role of CDF2 in maintaining these levels by regulating miRNA transcription and processing.
Folliculogenesis, the process of ova production for reproductive life, requires bidirectional communication between oocytes and granulosa cells through a physical connection that conveys signals and metabolites. A study has discovered that oocyte geranylgeranyl diphosphate (GGPP), a metabolic intermediate in protein geranylgeranylation, is required to establish this communication. GGPP and geranylgeranyl diphosphate synthase (Ggpps) levels in oocytes increase during early follicular development. Depletion of GGPP impairs granulosa cell proliferation, primary-secondary follicle transition, and female fertility. GGPP depletion inhibits Rho GTPase geranylgeranylation and its GTPase activity, causing the accumulation of cell junction proteins in the oocyte cytoplasm and failure to maintain the physical connection between oocyte and granulosa cells. Additionally, GGPP ablation blocks Rab27a geranylgeranylation, which may account for impaired secretion of oocyte materials such as Gdf9. Immunohistochemistry assays demonstrated that Ggpps is primarily expressed in the cytoplasm of the oocyte at all follicular developmental stages. Oocyte-specific Ggpps knockout mice show a novel function of GGPP-mediated protein geranylgeranylation in the oocyte during the primary-secondary follicle transition. Oocyte GGPP is required for Rho GTPase-regulated physical connection between oocyte and granulosa cells and Rab GTPase-directed secretion of oocyte materials such as Gdf9 and thereby has a profound impact on both the oocyte-granulosa cell communication and ovarian primary-secondary follicle transition.
"The RNA polymerase II (Pol II) is a crucial eukaryotic enzyme that synthesizes messenger RNA using a DNA template. Despite extensive studies, it remains uncertain whether the ""secondary channel"" is the only route for NTPs (nucleoside triphosphates) to reach the enzyme's active site, or if the ""main channel"" could be an alternative. Existing crystallographic structures of Pol II have been helpful in understanding the structural basis of transcription, but the conformation of the unpaired non-template DNA part of the full transcription bubble (TB) is still unknown. To gain a complete understanding of the Pol II transcription process, determining the structural information of the full TB is essential because the diffusion routes of NTP substrate through the main channel might overlap with the TB region. In a study, a structural model of Pol II with a complete TB was built using multiple sources of existing structural data and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations together with structural analysis. The study found that the secondary channel is the major route for NTP entry during Pol II transcription, as it has twice the percentage of MD conformations containing enough space for NTP loading compared to the main channel. Additionally, the diffusion of NTP through the main channel is disfavored due to electrostatic repulsion between the NTP and the highly negatively charged backbones of nucleotides in the non-template DNA strand. Overall, the study provides valuable insights into the NTP loading routes and the role of the TB conformation in the transcription process."
Dengue, a mosquito-borne viral disease, is a significant public health problem in many countries, including Thailand and Cambodia. Although dengue is a reportable disease in these countries, the actual disease burden is underrecognized due to underreporting of cases. A study was conducted using dengue incidence data from laboratory-confirmed outpatient and inpatient cases in prospective cohort studies in Thailand and Cambodia to estimate the magnitude of dengue underrecognition and establish accurate disease burden estimates. The study found that during 2003-2007, there was an 8.7-fold underrecognition of total symptomatic dengue cases and a 2.6-fold underrecognition of inpatient dengue cases in Thailand. In Cambodia, there was a 9.1-fold underestimation of total symptomatic dengue cases and a 1.4-fold underestimation of inpatient dengue cases during 2003-2007. These findings demonstrate that the true burden of dengue is significantly higher than what is reported through national surveillance data, emphasizing the need for improved surveillance and reporting systems to better understand and manage the disease.
In this study, researchers aimed to understand the role of Natural Killer (NK) cells in promoting protective immune responses to viral infections. While it is known that NK cells can control viral replication, their role in orchestrating global antiviral defense is unclear. The researchers used mouse cytomegalovirus (MCMV) as a model system to examine the consequences of NK cell dysfunction on antiviral CD8 T cell responses. They found that NK cells accelerate CD8 T cell responses against a viral infection in vivo by limiting IFN-α/β production to levels not immunosuppressive to the host. This is achieved through the early control of cytomegalovirus, which dramatically reduces the activation of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) for cytokine production, preserves the conventional dendritic cell (cDC) compartment, and accelerates antiviral CD8 T cell responses. These results suggest that NK cells play a critical role in balancing the intensity of other innate immune responses, dampening early immunopathology, and promoting optimal initiation of antiviral CD8 T cell responses. This extends NK cell's role beyond their direct antiviral effects and highlights the importance of intricate relationships between NK cells and other innate leukocytes in the development of antiviral immune responses.
In eukaryotes, rRNA genes are arranged in head-to-tail tandem arrays with not all copies being transcribed under normal growth conditions. In Arabidopsis thaliana, four major rRNA gene variants have been identified, with one being induced and another, the most highly represented variant, reactivated in Atnuc-L1 mutants. These changes in rRNA gene expression are due to a novel mechanism controlled by the nucleolin protein, which plays a major role in controlling active and repressed rRNA gene variants in Arabidopsis. This mechanism involves IGS transcription and symmetric DNA methylation. Further analysis of the rRNA gene variants in A. thaliana revealed at least three major variants, VAR1, VAR2, and VAR3, with VAR1 being silent in wild-type plants but derepressed in A. thaliana plants lacking the AtNUC-L1 protein. VAR1 is differentially expressed in WT plants, being detected essentially in seeds imbibed for 48 hours, though a very weak band is amplified in roots and flowers. In 2-day germinating seedlings expressing the rRNA VAR1 gene, the rRNA chromatin is immature with several FISH signals observed using a 25S probe, but these are smaller compared with those observed in 15-day old plants. These results suggest that rRNA variants are developmentally regulated in A. thaliana plants and chromatin state plays a major role in controlling the expression of rRNA VAR1. Additionally, pre-rRNA cleaved at the primary cleavage site in the 5′ETS region accumulates in Atnuc-L1-1 mutant plants, and northern blot analysis revealed accumulation of 45S pre-rRNA and processing in the 3′ETS region in Atnuc-L1-1 plants. An RNase protection assay confirmed that the mapped cleavage sites are located upstream from four repeat sequence elements named R1 to R4.
In this study, the role of histone deacetylation in regulating human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) gene expression was examined. The researchers used a method for rapid immunoisolation of an epitope-tagged protein coupled with mass spectrometry to identify candidate HDAC1-interacting proteins in the context of infection. They confirmed the interaction of pUL38 and pUL29/28 with HDAC1 using reciprocal immunoprecipitations. The researchers found that multiple components of the NuRD complex, including RBBP4 and CHD4, are needed for efficient HCMV replication. They also showed that pUL29/28 modifies the NuRD complex to stimulate the accumulation of immediate-early RNAs. The HCMV lytic replication cycle involves dynamic changes in histone modifications, and HDACs have been identified within multi-protein complexes such as NuRD. Disruption of the NuRD complex has a profound impact on cellular differentiation and proliferation and is associated with metastatic cancer. In HCMV, the virus-coded IE2 protein interacts with HDAC1 and 2 and auto-regulates viral gene expression. Inhibition of HDACs during CMV infection hyperactivates immediate-early gene expression, overcomes the repressive effects of hDaxx at the MIEP, and substantially rescues the growth of an IE1-deficient virus. HCMV-coded IE1 protein binds HDAC3 and promotes viral replication by antagonizing histone deacetylation. Proteins from several other herpesviruses bind to and modulate HDACs, and modulation of deacetylases occurs during human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. The researchers identified constituents of the NuRD complex as interacting partners of a tagged HCMV UL38-coded protein at 24 hpi, indicating a possible interaction between the viral protein and the NuRD complex. They then performed a global search for putative HDAC1-interacting proteins in the context of infection and validated several of the interactions, including the formation of complexes between components of the NuRD complex with the HCMV-coded proteins, pUL38 and pUL29/28. pUL38 is an early protein that controls cellular stress responses, and pUL29/28 is necessary for efficient viral replication. The interaction between pUL38 and HDAC requires pUL29/28, and blocking expression of NuRD components inhibits replication of a wild-type virus. The researchers demonstrate that full activation of the HCMV MIEP requires pUL29/28 but not pUL38. They propose that HCMV co-opts NuRD function at least in part to enhance expression of its immediate-early genes.
Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is the leading cause of pneumonia in infants, resulting in 57,000 hospitalizations annually in the United States. Although high titers of neutralizing antibodies appear to ameliorate the disease process in infants less than 9 months of age, individuals remain susceptible to RSV upper respiratory tract reinfection life-long. RSV isolates can be classified into two antigenically distinct groups (A and B) with genetic differences occurring primarily in the attachment glycoprotein G (47%) and to a lesser degree in the fusion protein F (9%). This study aimed to analyze the antibody repertoire following primary RSV infection and trace its evolution through adolescence and adulthood.Whole genome-fragment phage display libraries (GFPDL) expressing linear and conformational epitopes in the RSV fusion protein (F) and attachment protein (G) were used for unbiased epitope profiling of infant sera prior to and following RSV infection. F-GFPDL analyses demonstrated modest changes in the anti-F epitope repertoires post-RSV infection, while G-GFPDL analyses revealed a 100-fold increase in number of bound phages. The G-reactive epitopes spanned the N- and C-terminus of the G ectodomain, along with increased reactivity to the central conserved domain (CCD). Panels of F and G antigenic sites were synthesized to evaluate sera from young children (<2 yr), adolescents (14–18 yr), and adults (30--45 yr) in SPR real-time kinetics assays. A steady increase in RSV-F epitope repertoires from young children to adults was observed using peptides and F proteins. Importantly, several novel epitopes were identified in pre-fusion F and an immunodominant epitope in the F-p27. In all age groups, antibody binding to pre-fusion F was 2--3 folds higher than to post-fusion form. For RSV-G, antibody responses were high following early RSV infection in children, but declined significantly in adults, using either G proteins or peptides. This study identified unlinked evolution of anti-F and anti G responses and supportive evidence for immune pressure driven evolution of RSV-G. These findings could help development of effective countermeasures including vaccines.
Filarial nematodes, which include those causing lymphatic filariasis and river blindness, affect millions of people in tropical and subtropical regions, with the existing drugs used in mass drug administration being ineffective against adult filariae. Emodepside, a veterinary anthelmintic, has been found to have macrofilaricidal effects and is being considered for the treatment of onchocerciasis. It has been shown to inhibit motility in nematodes by activating voltage-gated potassium channels, specifically the SLO-1 K channels. Emodepside has a higher potency in males than in females, as demonstrated in Brugia malayi and Onchocerca volvulus. The slo-1 gene, which encodes SLO-1 channels, has several isoforms, and alternative splicing in the RCK1 binding pocket affects emodepside potency. This suggests that the sex of the filarial target is an important therapeutic variable to consider when evaluating a dose-regimen for treatments during clinical trials. Emodepside is currently in the process of being developed as the first registered oral macrofilaricide treatment for onchocerciasis, with DNDi planning to run a Phase II “proof-of-concept” clinical trial in sub-Saharan Africa.
The Global Program to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (LF) relies on rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) to determine where annual mass drug administration for LF is required and when it can be stopped. These tests detect a Wuchereria bancrofti glycoprotein in the blood of infected individuals via a carbohydrate moiety recognized by the monoclonal antibodies AD12 and DH6. However, recent research has identified loiasis cross-reactivity as a serious obstacle to LF elimination in loiasis-endemic areas. This cross-reactivity is due to the presence of multiple L. loa proteins in LF RDT-positive loiasis sera, including both secreted and somatic proteins. These reactive L. loa antigens appear to be only transiently present in the blood of a subset of persons with loiasis. The key differences between the circulating antigens of W. bancrofti and L. loa can be used to differentiate positive results generated by both species and may lead to improved diagnostic tests for LF and loiasis. This research involved the testing of adult human sera and was conducted to identify filarial antigens in the blood of persons infected with L. loa that could cause false-positive LF RDT results. The information obtained from this study may lead to the development of improved diagnostic tests for both infections.
Primary cilia are specialized sensory and developmental signalling organelles present on most eukaryotic cells. Defects in these organelles cause inherited human disorders known as ciliopathies, such as retinitis pigmentosa and Bardet-Biedl syndrome (BBS). The formation, maintenance, and function of cilia depend on intracellular transport systems like intraflagellar transport (IFT), driven by kinesin-2 and IFT-dynein motors, and regulated by the BBS cargo-adaptor protein complex or BBSome. To identify new cilium-associated genes, researchers used the nematode C. elegans, where ciliogenesis occurs within a short timespan during late embryogenesis. Using whole-organism RNA-Seq libraries, they discovered a signature expression profile enriched for transcripts of known ciliary proteins. From a list of 185 candidate ciliary genes, they uncovered orthologues of human MAP9, YAP, CCDC149, and RAB28 as conserved cilium-associated components. Further analyses of C. elegans RAB-28, which is associated with autosomal-recessive cone-rod dystrophy, revealed that this small GTPase is exclusively expressed in ciliated neurons, where it dynamically associates with IFT trains. These findings present a new approach for identifying ciliary proteins and unveil RAB28 as an IFT-associated cargo with BBSome-dependent cell autonomous and non-autonomous functions at the ciliary base.
The brain represents the outside world using neural responses, but it cannot directly access external stimuli and must decode them using only neural responses. The study of stimulus reconstruction usually involves characterizing the space of relevant stimuli, constructing functions relating stimuli to neuronal responses, and using these functions to decode new stimuli. However, the brain does not have access to independent stimulus measurements and must use neuronal spiking activity to represent the external world. In the context of hippocampal place cells, which reflect spatial information in rodents, a new question arises: how can the output of these place cells be used by downstream structures to reconstruct position and the underlying space, without access to corresponding place fields? This study shows that a great deal of information about a physical environment can be obtained using only very coarse features of population spiking activity. By defining a 'cell group' as a collection of cells that collectively fire significantly above baseline within a broad (~250 ms) temporal window, the simple knowledge of which groups of hippocampal place cells fire together is enough to extract global topological features of the environment and reconstruct an accurate geometric representation of physical space within which the animal's position can be faithfully tracked. This is made possible by using standard tools from algebraic topology and graph theory, without requiring place fields, precise spike timing, or any prior independent measurements of position. Therefore, even without access to direct relationships between neural responses and external stimuli, the brain can compare neural responses to each other and reveal structure of the outside world using relationships between stimuli.
Viral fulminant hepatitis (FH) is a severe and potentially fatal disease caused by excessive inflammation in the liver in response to a viral infection. A study using a mouse model of FH, induced by murine hepatitis virus strain-3 (MHV-3), found that the virus induces severe disease and high mortality in wild-type mice, but not in mice deficient in the IL-1 receptor (IL-1R1-/-) or in mice treated with an IL-1 receptor antagonist (IL-1Ra). The virus-infected IL-1R1-/- mice and IL-1Ra-treated mice had reduced virus replication, disease progression, and mortality. The study found that IL-1R1 deficiency impairs the virus-induced FGL2 production in macrophages and CD45+Gr-1high neutrophil infiltration in the liver. The activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome, which is responsible for the cleavage and activation of pro-IL-1β, is required for the in vivo bioactivation of proIL-1β during MHV-3 infection. Mice deficient in NLRP3 or Caspase-1, two essential components of the inflammasome complex, have reduced IL-1β induction and ameliorated hepatitis. The study suggests that the ROS/NLRP3/IL-1β axis is a critical signaling pathway that is overactivated and directly causes severe liver disease during viral infection. These findings provide insights into the development of efficient treatments for human viral FH and other severe inflammatory diseases.
Hookworm infections, caused by Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus, are major global health issues, leading to significant morbidity in terms of anemia and iron deficiency, particularly in children living in tropical regions. Despite their importance, the assessment of hookworm species-specific prevalence and infection load is rarely done due to limitations of current diagnostic methods. A study in Malawi used multiplex real-time PCR to determine the prevalence, infection load, and association of A. duodenale and N. americanus with severe anemia and iron deficiency in pre-school children. The study found that both species were present in the study population, with A. duodenale being more prevalent (26.1%) than N. americanus (4.9%). Moderate and high load A. duodenale infections were positively associated with severe anemia and iron deficiency. The study demonstrated the need for quantitative and species-specific screening of hookworm infections using multiplex real-time PCR as a powerful diagnostic tool to combat anemia and iron deficiency in children living in resource-poor settings.
In meiosis, the successful completion of meiosis requires the induction and repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) through homologous recombination (HR) or non-homologous end joining (NHEJ). However, only HR can generate the interhomolog crossovers (COs) needed for meiotic chromosome segregation. In Caenorhabditis elegans gametogenesis, COM-1, the homolog of CtIP/Sae2/Ctp1, is crucial for the repair of meiotic DSBs via HR and the formation of COs. COM-1-deficient germ cells repair meiotic DSBs via the error-prone pathway NHEJ, resulting in a lack of COs, extensive chromosomal aggregation, and near-complete embryonic lethality. COM-1 promotes meiotic recombination by counteracting the NHEJ complex Ku, and it acts parallel to the nuclease EXO-1 to promote interhomolog HR at the early pachytene stage of meiotic prophase. In the absence of both COM-1 and Ku, animals are viable and proficient in CO formation. These results reveal the potentially lethal properties of NHEJ during meiosis and identify a critical role for COM-1 in NHEJ inhibition and CO assurance in germ cells.
Melioidosis is a significant public health threat in Southeast Asia and Northern Australia, caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei, a Gram-negative, non-spore forming, aerobic, and motile bacillus. The disease has a high mortality rate, and both B. pseudomallei and its close relative, B. mallei, are classified as category B bioterrorism agents. In Thailand, B. pseudomallei is widely distributed in water and wet soils, and human infections occur through dermal inoculation, inhalation, and ingestion. Melioidosis clinical presentation includes pneumonia, sepsis, and chronic abscesses in internal organs, and it can be treated if diagnosed early and correctly. However, current bacteriological methods for detection are too slow to guide early treatment. Therefore, there is a need for a sensitive, specific, and rapid test for diagnosis of melioidosis.A study using a caprine melioidosis model of aerosol infection has the potential to characterize the humoral immune response and identify immunogenic proteins for new diagnostics and vaccine candidates. Outbred goats may more accurately mimic human infection, in contrast to the inbred mouse models used to date. In this study, B. pseudomallei infection was delivered as an intratracheal aerosol, and antigenic protein profiling was generated from the infecting strain MSHR511. Humoral immune responses were analyzed by ELISA and western blot, and the antigenic proteins were identified by mass spectrometry. The results showed a much greater humoral response with IgG antibodies, in both breadth and quantity, compared to IgM antibodies.
