Substitution of arginine residues at positions 24, 30, and 136 within a putative RNA-binding pocket in A3G results in reduced virus inhibition, virion packaging, and oligomerization. Overall, these findings suggest that RNA serves as a key regulator of A3G oligomerization, virion packaging, and antiviral function.
The study of the bric-a-brac (bab) locus in D. melanogaster has identified three regions with multiple polymorphisms significantly associated with natural variation in female abdominal pigmentation. These regions include a 15 kb region in the first intron of bab1, an 8 kb region between the bab1 and bab2 coding regions, and a 9.5 kb region near the transcription start site of bab2. Sequence variation surrounding the core cis-regulatory element (CRE) responsible for sex-specific expression in the epidermis of the last three abdominal segments is strongly associated with pigmentation variation, indicating a larger mutational target for functionally relevant mutations than previously thought. A predicted and experimentally verified Polycomb response element (PRE) in the intergenic region between bab1 and bab2, which regulates transcriptional activity over multiple cell generations, also contains significantly associated polymorphisms. The bab2 promoter and transcription start site, traditionally thought of as passive players in transcription, are found to be active in transcriptional regulation and contain significantly associated polymorphisms. These results suggest that not only are promoter regions involved in transcriptional regulation, but that sequence variation in these regions can have a significant impact on gene expression and phenotype. Additionally, the study finds that haplotypes formed by these associated polymorphisms have a large effect on pigmentation, with each region accounting for 20% to 50% of the pigmentation variation. Overall, the study highlights the complexity of QTL alleles and the importance of considering multiple molecular mechanisms and functional elements when studying the genetic architecture of quantitative traits.
Streptococcus pneumoniae, or pneumococcus, is a significant human pathogen that primarily resides in the human nasopharynx and causes both invasive and mucosal diseases. The bacterium's genome has significant diversity due to frequent genetic exchange with the surrounding microbial community. This genetic diversity leads to changes in the capsule locus, allowing for host-immune evasion, and the acquisition of antibiotic resistance genes. Pneumococcus utilizes various strategies, including a quorum sensing system and a competence system, to persist in the face of clearance mediated by the host and microbiome. The competence system, controlled by the extracellular accumulation of the competence stimulating peptide pheromone (CSP), activates a regulatory cascade resulting in the upregulation of a number of early competence genes, including an alternative sigma factor. This regulatory cascade culminates in the activation of over 180 genes involved in DNA uptake and genetic recombination. Many genes that encode the antagonistic fratricide effectors are upregulated during competence and target non-competent cells in the population for lysis, releasing genetic material for DNA exchange. Previous work suggested a regulatory connection between the competence regulon and the blp locus, responsible for pneumocin production. This study demonstrates that CSP can trigger the activation of the blp locus in rich media, resulting in increased transformation efficiency in dual culture biofilms through bacteriocin expression. This finding further highlights the adaptability of this pathogen and its ability to enhance DNA exchange and uptake during competence.
The poliovirus IRES-mediated translation requires the functions of certain canonical and non-canonical factors for the recruitment of ribosomes to the viral RNA. The interaction of cellular proteins PCBP2 and SRp20 in extracts from poliovirus-infected cells has been shown to function synergistically in viral translation. This study further defines the mechanism of ribosome recruitment for the initiation of poliovirus IRES-dependent translation, focusing on the role of the interaction between cellular proteins PCBP2 and SRp20. The results demonstrate that SRp20 dramatically re-localizes from the nucleus to the cytoplasm of poliovirus-infected neuroblastoma cells during the course of infection and partially co-localizes with PCBP2 in the cytoplasm of infected cells. In extracts from poliovirus-infected cells, SRp20 is associated with PCBP2 bound to poliovirus RNA, indicating that this interaction occurs on the viral RNA. A mutated version of SRp20 lacking the RNA recognition motif (SRp20ΔRRM) was found to be localized similar to the full-length SRp20, and also partially co-localizes with PCBP2 during poliovirus infection. Expression of this mutated version of SRp20 results in a ∼100 fold decrease in virus yield for poliovirus, possibly via a dominant negative effect. These results support a model in which SRp20 interacts with PCBP2 bound to the viral RNA, and this interaction functions to recruit ribosomes to the viral RNA in a direct or indirect manner, with the participation of additional protein-protein or protein-RNA interactions.
A study was conducted to understand the genetic pathways regulating neural crest (NC) development and to dissect the roles of discrete protein domains in this process. An N-ethyl-N-nitrosourea (ENU) mutagenesis screen was used on a mouse model sensitized for NC defects, Sox10LacZ/+. Four heritable loci, called modifier of Sox10 expression pattern 1-4 (msp1-4), were identified and mapped, which showed altered NC patterning. msp1, a new allele of the receptor tyrosine kinase Erbb3, was further characterized and found to carry a single amino acid substitution in the extracellular region of the protein. The ENU-induced mutation was sufficient to impair ERBB3 signaling, leading to impaired NC development and embryonic lethality. This study highlights the importance of the mutated residue for ERBB3 receptor function and activation, and underscores the utility of using an ENU mutagenesis to identify genetic pathways regulating NC development and to dissect the roles of discrete protein domains. NC is a transient population of multipotent stem cells that arises during vertebrate development and gives rise to numerous cell types, including neurons and glia of the peripheral and enteric nervous systems and the melanocytes of the skin and hair. Defects in genes and genetic pathways regulating NC development result in a wide spectrum of developmental disorders, collectively called neurocristopathies. Sox10, a member of the Sox family of transcription factors, is associated with neurocristopathies such as Waardenburg syndrome type II, Waardenburg syndrome type IV, and PCWH syndrome. Mutations in SOX10 have been linked to these syndromes, which are characterized by abnormal pigmentation, hearing loss, and loss of enteric ganglia.
This study investigates risk factors for Schistosoma mansoni infection in a rural Ugandan fishing community as part of a longitudinal reinfection study. The study focuses on the influence of age, sex, and ethnic background on susceptibility to reinfection after anti-helminth drug treatment, while controlling for cercarial exposure and other environmental and behavioral heterogeneities. The findings suggest that ethnic- and sex-related variations in S. mansoni reinfection were due to variations in cercarial exposure, while age-related differences in reinfection were linked to the balance of IgE and IgG4 to the tegumental antigen SmTAL1, which itself was significantly related to resistance to reinfection. The study highlights the benefit of taking a multidisciplinary approach in complex field settings to understand the ecology of a population and make more robust conclusions. Despite control efforts, the estimated worldwide prevalence of schistosomiasis has not changed over the past 50 years, with more than 200 million people currently thought to be infected with Schistosoma spp. Patterns of reinfection in communities that have received curative chemotherapy are never uniform, with some individuals appearing more susceptible to reinfection and others appearing comparably resistant. Studies have observed that water contacts generally decline with age, and gender-related differences in schistosomiasis infection have been attributed to socio-cultural or behavioral factors, but there is evidence that they may also be related to differences in susceptibility to infection. Ethnic differences in infection have been described in many communities and have been mainly ascribed to differences in water contact behavior, but genetic differences may also play a role. Reinfection studies have identified genes associated with relative susceptibility or immunity to infection. This study demonstrates the importance of considering exposure patterns whilst undertaking population-based studies on risk factors for infection and the biology of disease.
A study was conducted to estimate the worm burden of Clonorchis sinensis in humans by counting eggs per gram of feces (EPGs) and comparing it to the actual number of worms collected from 60 residents in an endemic area in Korea. The results showed a positive correlation between EPGs and the number of worms (r=0.681, P<0.001). The worm recovery rates were 9.7% in cases of EPGs 1-1,000 and 73.7% in those of EPGs over 1,000. No worms were detected from egg-negative subjects. The study also estimated that at least 110 worms are infected in a human body with EPGs around 3,000, and egg productivity of a worm per day is around 4,000. Clonorchiasis is a disease caused by infection of C. sinensis and results from ingestion of its metacercariae by consumption of raw or undercooked freshwater fish. The disease is widespread in East Asia, particularly in China and Korea, and can lead to several pathological changes in the bile duct including cholangiocarcinoma and other complications. Despite these risks, most patients with clonorchiasis complain no or mild non-specific symptoms, making accurate diagnosis and subsequent cure in early stage of infection essential. However, the sensitivity of the worm collection method is too low to apply for diagnosis of clonorchiasis, and it is impossible to figure exact number of infected worms from humans due to limitations in worm collection and EPG counting. Thus, numbers of C. sinensis in the present study were minimum confirmed figures from the infected individuals.
Drug resistance is a significant problem in various fields of medicine, including cancer and infectious diseases, leading to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. Combinatorial therapies, which involve using multiple drugs targeting different components of disease networks, have shown promise in treating antimicrobial drug-resistant infections. However, identifying adjunctive targets for these therapies is a major impediment, as most targets have been selected based on previous biological knowledge of drug mode of action and/or mechanisms of resistance, severely constraining the number of proteins that can be targeted.In this study, the researchers performed an unbiased genome-wide screen to identify previously unknown proteins that could be targeted for adjunctive therapy in the context of antimicrobial resistance. They focused on Candida glabrata, a human fungal pathogen with increasing incidence and fluconazole resistance due to gain-of-function mutations in the PDR1 gene. The researchers identified 18 synthetically lethal mutants in Saccharomyces cerevisiae expressing a Candida glabrata PDR1+ gain-of-function allele, one of which was the histone acetyltransferase Gcn5. Deletion or drug-mediated inhibition of Gcn5 caused a lethal phenotype in C. glabrata cells expressing PDR1+ alleles and inhibited the emergence of fluconazole-resistant C. glabrata isolates in evolution experiments.This study provides proof of concept that synthetically lethal genetic screens can identify novel candidate proteins that when therapeutically targeted could allow effective treatment of drug-resistant infections. The researchers demonstrated that unbiased genome-wide screens could reveal previously unknown proteins that could be targeted for adjunctive therapy, expanding the potential number of targets for druggable candidates and paving the way for the development of novel therapeutics to combat antimicrobial resistance.
The study of poliovirus (PV) multiplication reveals the presence of membranes containing phosphatidylinositol-4-phosphate (PI4P), which appear as vesicular clusters in cross-section. The role of PI4P and membrane remodeling prior to or concurrent with genome replication is not well understood. The study employs two PV mutants, EG and GG, with aberrant proteolytic processing of the P3 precursor, delaying genome replication and impairing virus assembly. The research indicates that PV induces temporally distinct membranous structures for genome replication (tubules) and virus assembly (vesicular clusters), with the pace of formation, spatiotemporal dynamics, and efficiency of the replication-to-assembly-organelle conversion potentially determined by the rate of P3 polyprotein processing and the capacity for P3 processing to yield 3AB and/or 3CD proteins. Positive-strand RNA viruses, like PV, pose a significant threat to public health due to their simplicity and evolvability. Establishment of PV infection likely requires multiple genomes entering the cell, possibly through mechanisms like leaving cells in vesicles or attaching to bacterial surface polysaccharides. PV infection wreaks havoc on intracellular membranes, causing dissolution of the Golgi apparatus and forming membranes of unique benefit to the virus. PV-induced membranes often appear as clusters of vesicles, which have been shown to contain viral RNA and proteins. These vesicular clusters arise from tubules induced by viral or viral-hijacked proteins. Early studies of PV-infected cells using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) documented these changes, while more recent studies using electron tomography suggest that PV-induced membranes arise from tubules. The study also discusses the role of PI4P in PV-induced membranes, which relocalizes from the Golgi to a site between the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi, and then to the perinuclear region of the cell, localizing with ER markers and viral RNA and proteins.
Chagas disease, prevalent in Latin America and caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, affects millions of people worldwide. Current treatments have limitations, including severe side effects and drug resistance, indicating a need for new therapies. Cruzain, a promising drug target, is a cysteine protease enzyme essential for T. cruzi's survival within host cells. This study employed a multi-step cascade strategy using integrated ligand- and target-based virtual screening methods to identify potential cruzain inhibitors from the ZINC database. Twelve non-covalent binding cruzain inhibitors with affinity values in the low micromolar range were found, and their binding mode was confirmed through X-ray crystallographic studies. These inhibitors were also tested against cathepsin L, showing similar affinity values, suggesting their potential for investigating the effect on cell proliferation. Through structure-activity relationship studies, two compounds with trypanocidal activity were identified, with Nequimed42 having a tenfold lower IC50 value than benznidazole, the positive control. A smaller derivative of Nequimed42, Nequimed176, was found to be a novel non-peptidic, non-covalent cruzain inhibitor, making it a candidate for optimization as a trypanocidal agent. Overall, this study highlights the potential of using virtual screening and ligand-based approaches to discover new cruzain inhibitors for Chagas disease treatment.
The yellow fever (YF) virus, a member of the Flaviviridae family, is responsible for causing YF, an infection that results in significant morbidity and mortality in tropical areas worldwide. The only available protection against YF is the attenuated YF virus vaccine, 17D/17DD, which produces both long-lasting neutralizing antibodies and strong T-cell responses. However, this vaccine can have severe side effects that are sometimes fatal. This study investigates the use of non-viral DNA-based antigen formulations to provide an alternative YF vaccine. The two DNA formulations encode the full-length envelope protein (p/YFE) or the full-length envelope protein fused to the lysosomal-associated membrane protein signal (pL/YFE) to divert antigen processing/presentation through the major histocompatibility complex II precursor compartments. These DNA constructs were tested in H2b and H2d backgrounds, corresponding to the C57Bl/6 and BALB/c mice strains. The results showed that both DNA formulations induced strong T-cell responses and high titers of anti-YF neutralizing antibodies. The pL/YFE formulation performed best and conferred 100% protection against YF virus in intracerebrally challenged mice. Therefore, the pL/YFE DNA is a promising vaccine candidate and should be considered for further development.
Vibrio cholerae, the bacterium responsible for cholera, is naturally found in the marine environment where it forms biofilms on chitin, the second most abundant biopolymer on the planet. Chitin is abundant in the shells of microscopic crustaceans and Vibrio species play an important role in recycling chitin in the aquatic environment. The pathway for degradation and utilization of this carbon and nitrogen source is conserved among the Vibrionaceae. The expression of genes required for chitin degradation, uptake, and utilization are regulated by the orphan sensor kinase ChiS. A recent study found that SlmA, a nucleoid occlusion protein and a member of the TetR family of proteins, is a regulator of chitin utilization by V. cholerae. SlmA binds directly to the chb operon promoter and this interaction is required for transcriptional activation of this locus and for chitobiose utilization. SlmA's DNA-binding function, but not its nucleoid occlusion function, is critical for transcriptional activation. This study identifies a novel role for SlmA as a transcriptional regulator in V. cholerae in addition to its established role as a cell division licensing factor.
The authors present a nonlinear programming (NLP) framework for the scalable solution of parameter estimation problems in dynamic modeling of biological systems. Such problems are computationally challenging due to highly nonlinear and stiff differential equations, multiple experimental data sets, and many parameters. The framework utilizes advanced modeling and solution tools that are computationally efficient, robust, and user-friendly. It uses a time discretization approach that avoids repetitive simulations, enables fully algebraic model implementations and derivative computation, and utilizes computationally efficient nonlinear interior point solvers that exploit sparse and structured linear algebra techniques. The proposed framework is demonstrated to solve a synthetic human gut microbiome community model with 156 parameters, 144 differential equations, and 1,704 experimental data points in less than 3 minutes, whereas an off-the-shelf simulation-based solution framework requires over 7 hours. Additionally, the proposed framework can solve problems with up to 2,352 parameters, 2,304 differential equations, and 20,352 data points in less than 15 minutes. The framework is flexible, easy-to-use, and can handle sophisticated estimation techniques for quantifying parameter uncertainty, diagnosing observability/uniqueness issues, performing model selection, and handling outliers. Dynamic modeling is essential for understanding biological systems such as microbial communities, gene regulatory networks, and metabolic pathways. Computational challenges in these problems arise from the dimensionality, nonlinearity, stiffness, incomplete observation, and large number of parameters and data sets. The authors have previously reviewed methods for solving estimation problems with differential equations, including maximum likelihood estimation, simulation-based approaches, and derivative-based and derivative-free search schemes. However, these methods have limitations in terms of computational cost, accuracy, and scalability. The proposed NLP framework addresses these limitations and has been demonstrated to handle large-scale parameter estimation problems for biological models. The framework provides an overview of parameter estimation and uncertainty quantification that leverages state-of-the-art optimization methods and can handle complex features such as unknown initial conditions and non-additive objective functions. The paper includes a detailed explanation of the estimation formulation, NLP solvers, and randomized maximum a posteriori (rMAP) methods for outlier mitigation.
The nCounter, a high throughput digital gene expression system, was used to analyze gene expression changes in multiple tissues of Swiss Webster (SW) mice infected with West Nile virus (WNV) over a nine-day course. The gene expression changes of 179 inflammation-related genes were examined in the spleen, lung, liver, kidney, and brain of the mice. The results showed that Cxcl10 and Il12b were differentially expressed in all tissues tested except kidney. Data stratification of WNV(+) and WNV(-) tissues allowed differentiation of the systemic inflammatory gene response from tissue-specific responses arising from WNV infection. Specific gene and protein expression kinetics were found for Ccl2, Ccl3, Ccl4 and Ccl5 and correlated with the presence of infectious virus. The utility of the nCounter platform for rapid identification of gene expression changes in SW mice associated with WNV infection was demonstrated. WNV is a neurotropic flavivirus endemic to parts of the Americas, Africa, Europe, the Middle East, and Asia, with humans and animals being potential hosts. While most WNV infections are asymptomatic, a small percentage can develop into severe neurological diseases such as meningitis or encephalitis. There are currently no approved antiviral therapies or vaccines for human use. The number of WNV infections in the US has totaled 37,088 cases, including 16,114 neuroinvasive cases and 1,549 fatalities, since its introduction in 1999. Outbred Swiss mice, such as the SW mice used in this study, have been utilized to demonstrate differences in neuroinvasiveness and neurovirulence between naturally occurring and engineered WNV strains, to study molecular determinants of neuroinvasiveness in related lineage 1 WNV strains, and for evaluation of candidate vaccines and therapeutics.
In 2014, an outbreak of human rabies occurred in Maputo and Matola cities, Mozambique, resulting in 14 reported cases and an unreported number of unconfirmed cases. A shortage of reliable data on the burden and risk factors of human rabies in Mozambique has led to underinvestment in control measures. This study aimed to investigate the epidemiological profile of animal bites and clinical and epidemiological features of human rabies cases during the outbreak. The study found that the majority of bite victims were children under 15 years old, and most bites occurred in suburban areas where residents have poor access to medical care. Of the 14 human rabies cases, all involved dog bites, and no victims received full post-exposure vaccination. The study found that 819 cases of animal bites were registered during the investigation period, with most bites occurring in people living in suburban areas. Only 30.1% of animal bite victims received post-exposure vaccination. Demographic variables and other known risk factors were compared between cases of animal bites and cases of human rabies to determine predictive variables associated with a higher risk of developing rabies after an animal bite. The study found that age under 15 years, a bite by a stray dog, deep wound, bite in the head, bite by an unvaccinated dog, failure to wash the bite site with soap and water, and no post-exposure prophylaxis were all associated with the development of rabies. The study's findings highlight the need for aggressive interventions, including regular canine mass vaccination campaigns, improvement of the provision of vaccines to humans and animals, accompanied by regular campaigns to remove stray dogs, and massive education in communities and primary schools. Weak control measures, including low coverage rates of dog immunization, poor control of stray and unowned dogs, inadequate management of bites, and poor availability of and adherence to post-exposure prophylaxis, are major factors driving rabies outbreaks in Maputo and Matola cities.
A large Utah family with a history of febrile seizures (FS) was found to have a potential mutation in the SCN9A gene, which encodes the voltage-gated sodium channel Nav1.7. This mutation, p.N641Y, was located in the large cytoplasmic loop between transmembrane domains I and II and was not present in 586 ethnically matched population control chromosomes. To establish a functional role for this mutation in seizure susceptibility, researchers introduced the orthologous mutation into the murine Scn9a ortholog using targeted homologous recombination. Homozygous Scn9aN641Y/N641Y mice exhibited significantly reduced thresholds to electrically induced clonic and tonic-clonic seizures, and increased corneal kindling acquisition rates. These data support the SCN9A p.N641Y mutation as disease-causing in this family. Further analysis of 92 unrelated FS patients identified additional highly conserved Nav1.7 missense variants in 5% of the patients. After one of these children with FS later developed Dravet syndrome, a heterozygous frameshift mutation in the SCN1A gene was identified. Subsequent analysis of 109 Dravet syndrome patients yielded nine Nav1.7 missense variants (8% of the patients). Six of these Dravet syndrome patients with SCN9A missense variants also harbored either missense or splice site SCN1A mutations and three had no SCN1A mutations. This study provides evidence for a role of SCN9A in human epilepsies, both as a cause of FS and as a partner with SCN1A mutations. FS are the most common seizure disorder of early childhood and occur in up to 75% of children with Dravet syndrome. Children who experience FS have a 2-9% chance of developing afebrile seizures later in life. FS are associated with an increased risk of developing other types of epilepsy, some of which can be resistant to currently available anticonvulsant therapy. This study highlights the importance of further research into the role of SCN9A in human epilepsies.
The study of tissue growth and deformation in biology is crucial to understanding how complex tissue shapes arise, with preferential growth along particular orientations being a key factor. The orientation of this growth can be specified through stresses (axiality-based system) or molecular signalling (polarity-based system). A new polarity-based system, Growing Polarised Tissue (GPT) framework, has been developed and applied to a Snapdragon flower, showing that orientations and rates of growth can be specified through a regulatory network. The resulting growth depends on how specified growth patterns interact within mechanically connected tissue, leading to the emergence of features such as curvature. The GPT-framework can be used to understand how genes influence specified growth, which is key to understanding how resultant growth arises. Elements of the stress-based and polarity-based axiality systems have been modelled, and a software implementation of the polarity-based axiality approach, GPT-framework, has been developed. This framework can be used to model tissue growth, with the potential to specify orientation independently of stresses, leading to the generation of complex tissue shapes.
In the early stages of HIV infection, multiple CD8+ T cell responses are elicited, exerting strong selective pressures on different parts of the virus's genome. These pressures result in the selection of mutations that enable the virus to evade recognition, thereby benefiting its survival. The study found that the later these escape mutations emerge, the more slowly they reach fixation. This pattern of escape rate decrease (ERD) can be attributed to distinct mechanisms, including interference among different escape strains in large populations with high beneficial mutation rates. This interference can delay the fixation times of beneficial mutations, leading to a decrease in escape rates. The study found that interference between several equally selectively advantageous mutations can generate the observed ERD pattern and that the number of loci and recombination rates substantially affect ERD. Additionally, the study found that the observed ERD pattern in HIV-infected individuals is consistent with both independent, interference-free mutations and interference effects. Overall, the findings suggest that interference effects should be considered when analyzing HIV escape mutations and that accounting for the stochastic nature of competition between mutations demands novel estimation methodologies based on the analysis of HIV strains, rather than mutation frequencies.
The survival rate for non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients is poor, particularly for those in advanced stages, and can be as low as 1%. The successful choice of preoperative chemotherapy for patients with resectable disease is critical to eliminate micrometastasis and improve operability. An in silico experimentation approach has been developed to suggest the optimal treatment protocol for each patient based on their own multiscale data. A determinant for reliable predictions is the a priori estimation of the drugs’ cytotoxic efficacy on cancer cells for a given treatment. A mechanistic model of cancer response to treatment is applied to estimate the cell killing efficacy of various cisplatin-based doublet regimens. The model incorporates the cancer related mechanism of uncontrolled proliferation, population heterogeneity, hypoxia and treatment resistance. The methodology is based on the provision of tumor volumetric data at two time points, before and after or during treatment. A thorough sensitivity analysis has established the volume growth rate and the growth fraction at diagnosis as key features for more accurate estimates. The methodology is applied on the retrospective data of thirteen patients with NSCLC who received cisplatin in combination with gemcitabine, vinorelbine or docetaxel in the neoadjuvant context. The model is capable of simulating different proliferation patterns based on the assumed conditions of tumor microenvironment and incorporates patient-specific data such as imaging-based, histological, molecular and treatment data. The present work provides a quantitative framework for the estimation of the in-vivo cell-killing ability of various chemotherapies and correlation studies of such estimates with the molecular profile of patients could serve as a basis for reliable personalized predictions.
High levels of antibiotic tolerance in bacterial biofilms, characterized by reversible and transient resistance to antibiotics, is a significant concern in healthcare due to the increased tolerance of biofilm-associated bacteria to multiple antibiotics on medical implants. The molecular mechanisms responsible for this antibiotic tolerance are not well understood, but recent studies suggest that the physiological heterogeneity of biofilms and specialized subpopulations within biofilms contribute to this tolerance. A study using Escherichia coli as a model organism identified amino acid auxotroph mutants that exhibited significantly greater tolerance to the fluoroquinolone ofloxacin in biofilm states than in planktonic states. The biofilm-associated tolerance to ofloxacin was found to be fully dependent on a functional SOS response upon starvation for amino acids and carbon sources, and partially dependent on the stringent response upon leucine starvation. Importantly, the biofilm-specific ofloxacin increased tolerance did not involve any of the SOS-induced toxin–antitoxin systems previously associated with formation of highly tolerant persisters. These findings suggest that the SOS stress response induced in heterogeneous and nutrient-deprived biofilm microenvironments is a molecular mechanism leading to biofilm-specific high tolerance to the fluoroquinolone ofloxacin. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms behind antibiotic tolerance in bacterial biofilms and to develop effective strategies for preventing and treating biofilm-associated infections.
Plasmodium falciparum malaria, a mosquito-borne disease, is responsible for high morbidity and mortality worldwide. The pathogenesis and death associated with this disease are due to parasite-infected erythrocytes. The invasion of erythrocytes by P. falciparum merozoites requires specific interactions between host receptors and parasite ligands localized in apical organelles called micronemes. A study identified cAMP as a key regulator that triggers the timely secretion of microneme proteins, enabling receptor-engagement and invasion. Exposure of merozoites to a low potassium environment, typical of blood plasma, activates a bicarbonate-sensitive cytoplasmic adenylyl cyclase to raise cytosolic cAMP levels and activate protein kinase A, which regulates microneme secretion. Additionally, cAMP activates the Epac pathway, triggering a rise in cytosolic Ca2+ leading to microneme release. The study of these signaling pathways provides novel targets to inhibit blood stage parasite growth and prevent malaria.
The soil-transmitted nematode Strongyloides stercoralis is a commonly overlooked helminth among the neglected tropical diseases (NTDs), occurring worldwide except for the far north and south. Its prevalence is often imprecisely estimated due to a lack of information and the limited sensitivity of diagnostic methods. S. stercoralis can reproduce within a human host, leading to long-lasting infections, and can cause systemic infection in immunosuppressed individuals, resulting in hyperinfection syndrome and disseminated strongyloidiasis, which can be fatal. Uncomplicated intestinal strongyloidiasis may present as gastro-intestinal symptoms, while many infections remain asymptomatic, which can lead to underdiagnosis.A literature review of studies from 1989-2011 revealed a lack of information on S. stercoralis in numerous African, Asian, and South-American resource-poor countries. A Bayesian meta-analysis showed an association between HIV-infection, alcoholism, and S. stercoralis infection. High infection prevalence rates were found in the general population in certain countries and geographical regions. The meta-analysis indicated that S. stercoralis infection is prominent in several risk groups. However, adequate information is still lacking from many countries. The current information emphasizes the need for further assessments in socio-economic and ecological settings and the importance of integrating S. stercoralis control into global helminth control.In summary, the nematode S. stercoralis is a widely distributed but often overlooked helminth associated with neglected tropical diseases. Its prevalence is difficult to estimate due to insufficient information and the limitations of diagnostic methods. The worm can cause long-lasting infections and systemic infections in immunosuppressed individuals, making it a significant public health concern. Despite the limited data, the available information indicates that S. stercoralis infection is widespread in various risk groups and regions. Addressing this issue requires further research and incorporating control strategies into global helminth control programs.
This study explores the role of stochastic noise in circadian oscillations and its relevance to circadian therapeutics. Circadian rhythms, which are daily changes in gene expression and physiology, are critical for metabolic health. While cell-to-cell coupling synchronizes rhythms in the brain's suprachiasmatic nucleus, peripheral tissues have weak or no coupling. Cellular-level rhythms are generated by a large network of gene regulatory elements, and the robustness of these oscillations is linked to metabolic health. Bioluminescence-based cellular circadian reporters offer a direct view of the gene regulatory network and are amenable to high-throughput screens. At the single-cell level, transcription is affected by both intrinsic (molecular counts) and extrinsic (cell size, environment) noise, resulting in stochastic bioluminescence traces. While stochastic noise has been suspected to play a significant role in circadian rhythms, measuring it requires careful preparation, recording, and image processing of individual cells. This study demonstrates a method to reliably infer changes in stochastic noise from the changes to the damping rate of population-level bioluminescence recordings of cultured circadian reporters. The method was validated using single-cell fibroblast data, a small-molecule modulator, a mathematical model, and siRNA knockdown data. The authors conclude that circadian rhythms have likely evolved to an optimal point of high amplitude and low stochastic noise and that their method allows the effect of candidate drugs on stochastic noise to be quantified in a high-throughput manner, which is crucial for the development of circadian therapeutics.
The increasing issue of antibiotic resistance in pathogenic bacteria has necessitated the development of novel drug-target selection and development approaches. One promising target is the essential bacterial cytoskeletal protein FtsZ, which plays a crucial role in bacterial cell division. The allosteric inhibitor PC190723 has demonstrated in vitro activity on Staphylococcus aureus FtsZ and in vivo antimicrobial activities. However, the mechanism of drug action and its effect on FtsZ in other bacterial species are unclear. A recent study used PocketFEATURE, a statistical method that scores the similarity between pairs of small-molecule binding sites based on 3D structure information about the local microenvironment, and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations to examine the structural environment of the PC190723 binding pocket. The study found that species and nucleotide-binding state have significant impacts on the structural properties of the binding site, with substantially disparate microenvironments for bacterial species not from the Staphylococcus genus. MD simulations of an FtsZ dimer also indicated that polymerization may enhance PC190723 binding. Thus, the drug-binding pocket can vary significantly across species, genetic perturbations, and in different polymerization states, yielding important information for the further development of FtsZ inhibitors. PC190723 and its derivatives are promising drug candidates as they have demonstrated inhibitory effects on FtsZ in various Gram-positive bacteria, including Staphylococcus aureus. Importantly, PC190723 exhibited antimicrobial properties in vivo in mouse models, suggesting that this small molecule selectively targets bacterial cell division without affecting tubulin, the eukaryotic FtsZ homolog. Lens epithelium-derived growth factor (LEDGF) is a cellular binding partner of lentiviral integrase (IN) proteins, required for efficient viral replication and specific for lentiviral INs. A crystal structure of the N-terminal and catalytic core domains of HIV-2 IN in complex with the IN binding domain (IBD) of LEDGF shows primarily charge-charge interactions between the NTD of IN and the IBD. These new structural details enable the engineering of a mutant of HIV-1 IN that primarily functions only when presented with a complementary LEDGF mutant. Retroviral INs, including HIV-1 and HIV-2, share a conserved three domain organization and are involved in the integration of reverse transcribed viral cDNA into the host cell genome. The integration process is catalyzed by IN and involves 3′-processing in the cytoplasm of the host cell and strand transfer in the nucleus, where the viral cDNA nicks and joins to opposing strands of the cellular DNA. The enzyme active site of IN is composed of three invariant acidic residues that coordinate a pair of Mg2+ cations during catalysis. The NTD of IN forms a three-helical bundle and folds around a zinc atom, while the CTD features an SH3-like fold and is likely involved in DNA binding. The CCD of IN spans the most conserved region of IN and bears close structural homology to prokaryotic transposases. The active form of retroviral IN is a tetramer, but the structure of a full-length retroviral IN remains elusive. Lentiviral DNA integration critically depends on LEDGF, which tightly associates with chromatin and has been implicated in regulation of cellular gene expression, epigenetic chromatin modifications, and apoptosis. LEDGF tethers lentiviral IN to host chromatin in the nucleus and plays a critical role in directing PICs to active genes during integration.
A study investigating the evolution of cancer stem cells (CSCs) and their impact on tumor progression was conducted using a cellular automaton model. The model tracks the temporal evolution of the malignant subpopulation of CSCs, which are exclusively able to initiate and sustain tumors. The study explores orthogonal cell traits, including cell migration, spontaneous cell death, symmetric cancer stem cell division, and telomere length. The results suggest that cell proliferation potential is the strongest modulator of tumor growth, with an early increase in proliferation potential yielding larger populations of non-stem cancer cells that compete with CSCs and inhibit CSC division. A reduction in proliferation potential, however, decreases intratumoral competition and enables accelerated CSC pool expansion and further evolution. Additionally, the study found that evolutionary phenotypic heterogeneity leads to unpredictable spatiotemporal distribution of cells with varying aggressiveness, and that the fraction of cancer stem cells in collected biopsy samples can vary by as much as two orders of magnitude. Overall, the study highlights the importance of CSCs in tumor progression and the need for further investigation into the evolution of these cells and their impact on tumor growth.
"The emergence of zoonotic diseases in humans, such as the Spanish flu of 1918 and the SARS outbreak of 2003, poses significant risks to global public health. While previous research has studied the evolution and transmission of these diseases within a homogeneous human host population, factors such as human contact patterns and other forms of host heterogeneity may also shape the risk and speed of emergence events. This study focuses on the heterogeneity in the spatial structure of the human host population, specifically in the context of adapting pathogens.The authors use a model of evolution and emergence in which a zoonotic pathogen infects humans and initially has very poor transmissibility. As the pathogen adapts and becomes more transmissible, it can cause epidemics in human populations. The model considers two routes of adaptation with opposite and distinct characteristics. In the ""punctuated"" scenario, the pathogen acquires genetic changes that increase its ability to pass to other humans, while in the ""gradual"" scenario, the pathogen gradually becomes more transmissible over time.The authors use this model to study the impact of the mutation rate and the average reproductive number of the intermediate strain on the probability of emergence per introduction of the pathogen in a single, infinite population. They find that the probability of emergence grows non-linearly with both the mutation rate and the reproductive number of the intermediate strain. They also find that the model is robust to different types of human movement and that the probability of emergence is largely determined by the biology of the novel pathogen.The authors conclude by discussing the implications of these findings for public health. They suggest that, for plausible parameter ranges, the effects of spatial heterogeneity are likely to be dominated by the evolutionary biology of host adaptation. They also emphasize the need for further research to understand the impact of human mobility patterns on the emergence and spread of zoonotic diseases."
Wild birds, particularly those from the orders Anseriformes and Charadriiformes, have been implicated in the emergence of human and livestock influenza. The role of these birds in spreading influenza viruses has been a concern due to the confounding factors in disease control and surveillance efforts. The patterns of viral spread and the subsequent risk posed by wild bird viruses remain unpredictable, largely due to the lack of knowledge of viral movements between different host populations. In a study, researchers analyzed genomic data from 287 newly sequenced avian influenza A virus samples isolated over a 34-year period of continuous systematic surveillance of North American migratory birds. They used a Bayesian statistical framework to test hypotheses of viral migration, population structure, and patterns of genetic reassortment. The results showed that despite the high prevalence of Charadriiformes infected in Delaware Bay, this host population does not significantly contribute to the North American AIV diversity sampled in Anseriformes. The influenza viruses sampled from Anseriformes in Alberta, on the other hand, are representative of the AIV diversity circulating in North American Anseriformes. The study also found that although AIV may be restricted to specific migratory flyways over short time frames, the long-term persistence of AIV was independent of bird flyways with migration between populations throughout North America. These findings are vital in developing appropriately informed predictive models critical for pandemic preparedness and livestock protection.
A novel monoclonal antibody, MAb S139/1, was generated and found to have broad reactivity to multiple subtypes of influenza A viruses, including H1, H2, H3, H5, H9, and H13. MAb S139/1 showed neutralization and hemagglutination-inhibition activities against specific strains of H1, H2, H3, and H13 subtypes. Mutant viruses that escaped neutralization by MAb S139/1 had amino acid substitutions at positions 156, 158, and 193, which are located on the globular head of the HA and form a novel conformational epitope adjacent to the receptor-binding domain of HA. MAb S139/1 binds to a common antigenic site shared among a variety of HA subtypes and neutralizes viral infectivity in vitro and in vivo by affecting viral attachment to cells. This study supports the notion that cross-reactive antibodies play some roles in heterosubtypic immunity against influenza A virus infection and highlights the potential therapeutic utility of cross-reactive antibodies against influenza. Neutralizing antibodies play a critical role in protection from influenza virus infection, with most neutralizing antibodies recognizing the HA, the major surface glycoprotein of influenza viruses. The HA of influenza A viruses has been classified into sixteen antigenically distinct subtypes, with considerable amino acid variability in the globular head region among HA subtypes, whereas the structure of the stem region is relatively conserved. However, it is generally believed that the neutralizing antibodies are not broadly cross-reactive among HA subtypes. This study describes the discovery of a cross-neutralizing monoclonal antibody, MAb S139/1, that reacts with a variety of HA subtypes and inhibits virus binding to sialic acid receptors. The findings suggest the potential of antibodies in heterosubtypic immunity against influenza A virus infection.
A three-year cohort study of 259 Australian Aboriginals aimed to assess the effect of treatment with ivermectin on the prevalence of S. stercoralis infection and the validity of a lower ELISA cut-off in diagnosis. The study found that treatment with ivermectin was highly effective, resulting in a significant fall in the prevalence of infection. The results suggested that using a lower ELISA threshold for treatment was valid in this setting. However, a small group of subjects had persistently positive ELISA serology despite repeated treatment. Overall, control of S. stercoralis infection in this cohort appears to be feasible using pharmacological treatment alone. This is significant as S. stercoralis infection is a common and potentially serious public health issue, particularly in underprivileged communities in developed countries. However, there is no consensus on the best measures for controlling the infection, with some advocating for environmental management, while others emphasize the efficacy and safety of pharmacological treatment. This study adds to the evidence supporting the use of ivermectin for treating S. stercoralis infection and the potential for using a lower ELISA threshold for diagnosis in certain settings. Further research is needed to determine the optimal measures for control of strongyloides infection in different situations.
Prion diseases are a group of transmissible neurodegenerative diseases affecting animals, including humans, and are caused by a misfolded isoform of the prion protein, PrPSc. Prion strains are associated with specific conformations of PrPSc and can interfere with each other, influencing prion strain dynamics and emergence. However, it is unclear if two long-incubation period strains can interfere with each other. A study investigating this found that co-infection of animals with combinations of long-incubation period strains did not result in evidence of strain interference. This lack of interference was not due to a failure to infect common populations of neurons. The study also found that long incubation-period strains contained relatively higher levels of remaining PrPC in PMCA reactions, and the abundance of PrPC is not limiting in vivo or in vitro, allowing prion strains with relatively low prion conversion efficiency to amplify independently. This changes the paradigm of prion strain interactions and has implications for interspecies transmission and emergence of prion strains from a mixture.
Intrinsically disordered proteins/regions (IDPs/IDRs) are prevalent in allosteric regulation, and it was previously thought that intrinsic disorder is favorable for maximizing allosteric coupling. However, a comprehensive ensemble model is proposed to compare the roles of both order-order transition and disorder-order transition in allostery. The model shows that the MWC pathway (order-order transition) has a higher probability than the EAM pathway (disorder-order transition) in allostery, indicating a complicated role of IDPs/IDRs in regulatory proteins. An analytic formula for the maximal allosteric coupling response is also obtained, which shows that too stable or too unstable state is unfavorable to endow allostery, and is thus helpful for rational design of allosteric drugs. This new view of allostery based on the general landscape theory of protein structure highlights the role of ligand binding in stabilizing specific states and shifting the conformational ensemble. The EAM model, which used an ensemble view to explain the allostery of IDPs, provides insight in explaining why IDPs/IDRs are so prevalent in allosteric regulation. However, the pristine EAM model considers only the order-disorder (R-I) transition, but lacks the order-order (R-T) transition as that in the MWC model for the allostery of ordered proteins. Therefore, a comprehensive ensemble model considering both order-disorder and order-order transitions is proposed, which allows for a quantitative evaluation of the role of IDPs/IDRs in allosteric regulation.
Prostate cancer is a major cause of male death in the Western world, but the genetic alterations that drive its initiation and progression are not well understood. One protein that has been implicated in prostate cancer is β-Catenin, which is essential for many developmental processes and has been linked to tumorigenesis in various tissues. However, the role of β-Catenin in human prostate cancer is unclear, with some studies showing increased expression and nuclear localization in late-stage cancer and others showing a loss of nuclear expression in advanced tumors. To further investigate the role of β-Catenin in the prostate, researchers used in vivo genetic studies in the embryo and adult. They found that prostate epithelial β-Catenin is required for embryonic prostate growth and branching, but is dispensable in the normal adult organ. During development, β-Catenin controls the number of progenitors in the epithelial buds and regulates a discrete network of genes, including c-Myc and Nkx3.1. In a model of castration-resistant prostate cancer, deletion of β-Catenin had no effect on disease progression. However, overexpression of β-Catenin in the embryo led to the formation of squamous epithelia, and in the context of Pten loss, it drove progression to invasive carcinoma with squamous metaplasia. These studies suggest that β-Catenin is essential for prostate development and has the potential to drive squamous fate differentiation and invasive prostate cancer.Prostate cancer is the most common male cancer in the developed world and is often driven by the tumor suppressor gene PTEN, the gene rearrangement TMPRSS2-ERG, and the oncogene C-MYC. To better understand the genetic and molecular interactions between these signalling pathways, researchers have investigated genes during embryonic development of the prostate. This approach has identified several genes that are important during both prostate development and tumorigenesis, including Sox9, Hoxb13, and Nkx3.1.The prostate develops from the endodermally derived urogenital sinus in response to androgens that signal through the androgen receptor. This process requires complex epithelial-mesenchymal interactions and involves signalling pathways such as androgens, FGF, and SHH. The buds then elongate, branch, canalize, and undergo cytodifferentiation to become secretory after birth. The adult prostate epithelium is composed of p63-expressing basal cells, AR-positive luminal cells, and rare neuroendocrine cells.The cytoplasmic protein β-Catenin (encoded by the CTNNB1 gene) is crucial in many steps of embryogenesis and is involved in a number of cancers. In the absence of WNT ligand, a destruction complex promotes the phosphorylation and subsequent degradation of β-Catenin via the ubiquitin pathway. However, when WNT ligand binds to the Frizzled/LRP receptor complex, the destruction complex is destabilized, leading to an accumulation of β-Catenin that translocates to the nucleus and activates target genes.In human prostate cancer, CTNNB1 mutations are rare, but β-Catenin expression and localization change during disease progression. In prostate cancer cell lines, β-Catenin enhances androgen-stimulated AR transcriptional activation and increases sensitivity to low levels of androgens and to non-androgen ligands. Nuclear localization of β-Catenin may also result in increased complexes between AR and β-Catenin in prostate cancer cells, changing target gene activation.Mouse models have demonstrated that activating β-Catenin leads to prostate neoplasia and squamous transdifferentiation. Likewise, mouse prostates expressing a stabilized form of β-Catenin in combination with either the SV40 large T-antigen or with a mutated K-ras form invasive carcinoma. PTEN is frequently altered in prostate cancer, with mutations and/or deletions found in 30% of primary cancers and 63% of metastatic prostate tumors. PTEN loss promotes phosphorylation of Akt through PI3K, which in turn phosphorylates multiple targets including GSK3β. Activation of this pathway results in an increase in cell proliferation, cell survival, and protein synthesis. Evidence suggests that β-Catenin can interact with the PI3K/Akt pathway following PTEN loss, through the inactivation of GSK3β and stabilization of β-Catenin.In conclusion, prostate cancer is a complex disease driven by various genetic and molecular interactions. The tumor suppressor gene PTEN and the oncogene β-Catenin play crucial roles in prostate development and tumorigenesis. Understanding the interactions between these pathways may provide novel targets for the treatment of prostate cancer.
A study was conducted to assess factors affecting informed consent in a genetic research study of podoconiosis, a type of elephantiasis, in rural Ethiopia. The study found that the use of everyday language, addressing participants' expectations, and the techniques of presenting information had significant impact on participants' understanding of the research. Researchers recommended that information sheets and consent forms used in developed countries may not be appropriate for developing countries due to differences in cultural settings, literacy levels, and decision-making norms. Guidelines recommend preceding individual consent with community level consultation and approval, using verbal consent and innovative forms of documenting the individual informed consent process, and providing information about the study at an appropriate level of comprehension. The study found that participants supported the concept of informed consent and valued the respect and politeness shown to them by researchers. However, the information provided must be focused around patients' perspectives and expectations, and other approaches of tailoring the communication style to the local context are essential. The findings from the rapid assessment were used to inform the consent process for the genetic research, including preparing sensitization meetings and conducting community discussions and consultations.
The immune system ensures body integrity through the continuous production of diverse T lymphocytes in the thymus, involving processes of proliferation, differentiation, selection, death, and migration to peripheral tissues where proliferation also occurs upon antigen recognition. A study analyzed the dynamics of proliferation of T lymphocytes across differentiation in the thymus and spleen of mice using single-cell multicolour flow cytometry and a generic mathematical model of state transition. The results revealed that T cell proliferation is highly heterogeneous, with a specific signature that depends on genetic origins, is specific to cell differentiation stages in thymus and spleen, and is altered with age. The model allows inferring proliferation rates and estimating cell cycle durations in sub-populations. The cell division is a common characteristic of biological systems, with variability of rates of proliferation and interphase duration. In the immune system, cell proliferation is essential for the high turnover of diversified lymphocytes that ensures dynamic cognitive function and maintenance of body integrity. The production of T cells occurs through processes of proliferation, differentiation, migration, selection, and death in the thymus to finally export less than 6% of cells to peripheral tissues as naïve T cells. T cells circulate through the whole organism and interact with environmental and body antigens to proliferate and differentiate into effector/memory T cells upon antigenic recognition. Quantification and interpretation of lymphocyte dynamics remain a challenge in systems immunology. Studies on T cell dynamics at various ages have questioned the mechanisms of thymic involution, followed by immuno-senescence and inflammation with aging, and physiological accumulation of effector/memory peripheral T cell clones, particularly of CD8 phenotype, in both aged humans and mice. Although the number of T cells decreases with aging, promiscuous CD4 T cells accumulate. Thymic hypoplasia or thymectomy in young individuals also affects the repertoire of peripheral T cells and immunocompetence. Thus, thymic production is primordial so as to maintain a homeostatic and dynamic equilibrium in terms of cell populations and repertoires, thereby allowing an effective and adaptive immune surveillance.
A study has been conducted to analyze the effects of a specific mitochondrial tRNA mutation in mouse cells. The mutation, an m. 3739G>A transition in the mitochondrial mt-Ti gene, recapitulates the molecular hallmarks of a disease-causing mutation described in humans. This mutation, similar to the human one, promotes a high frequency of abnormal folding of the tRNAIle that cannot be charged with isoleucine. The cells harboring the mutant mtDNA show a higher ROS production that leads to a compensatory response by enhancing mitochondrial biogenesis. This study highlights the different nature of mutations affecting protein-coding genes vs. tRNA genes and demonstrates the positive implication of ROS-mediated mitochondrial biogenesis in the expression of mitochondrial tRNA pathological mutations found in human patients. The mechanism may generate an epistatic-like effect by exerting a partial suppression of deleterious mutations in mitochondrial tRNAs, allowing the survival and reproduction of some individuals despite harboring a deleterious allele, thereby facilitating the appearance of a true compensatory mutation.
In mammals, dosage compensation is achieved through X-chromosome inactivation and up-regulation of X-linked genes in both sexes. To determine if X expression is adjusted in response to ploidy, a study examined X-linked and autosomal gene expression in human triploid cells. The results showed that the X:autosome expression ratio is lower (0.81-0.84) in triploid cells with one active X and higher (1.32-1.4) in triploid cells with two active X's, indicating that X-linked gene expression in triploid cells does not strictly respond to an autosomal factor. An epigenetic mechanism may be responsible for adjusting X-linked gene expression in triploid cells with a single active X. The study also found that a small subset of X-linked genes (~7%) had expression levels proportional to the number of autosomal sets, and that X-linked and/or autosomal gene expression can respond to abnormal genotypes. Overall, the study suggests that X-linked gene expression is up-regulated approximately two-fold in triploid cultures with two active X chromosomes like in diploid cultures, but in triploid cultures with a single active X, X expression is further adjusted further upward, although not tripled. Therefore, global X-linked gene expression does not strictly respond to an autosomal counting factor in triploid cells.
The dN/dS ratio is a widely used measure of natural selection's impact on protein-coding sequences, comparing the rate of substitutions at silent sites (dS), assumed neutral, to the rate of substitutions at non-silent sites (dN), possibly experiencing selection. A dN/dS ratio greater than one implies natural selection promotes changes in the protein sequence, while a ratio less than one implies natural selection suppresses protein changes. This intuitive interpretation is supported by theoretical work. However, the dN/dS ratio was originally developed for the analysis of genetic sequences from divergent species, and its relationship with the underlying selection pressure assumes sequences are sampled from independent, divergent species. Despite this, the dN/dS ratio test is frequently applied to data that may represent samples from a single population, particularly in microbes. In such cases, the differences between sequences do not represent fixation events along independent lineages, but rather polymorphisms segregating in a single population. A study analyzed the population genetics of dN/dS and found that the relationship between selection and dN/dS is qualitatively different for samples drawn from a single population compared to samples from divergent lineages. As a result, standard tests for selection based on dN/dS are extremely sensitive to violation of the assumption of divergent lineages. The expected dN/dS ratio within a population is relatively insensitive to selection pressure, and strong positive selection is expected to produce dN/dS<1 among population samples. Therefore, when applied to intra-specific samples, the standard interpretation of dN/dS is unjustified and may lead to surprising conclusions.
Natural selection can indirectly affect linked neutral divergence between both closely and distantly related species, contrary to previous beliefs. This was demonstrated by studying the correlation between neutral divergence and functional content, as well as between neutral divergence and recombination rate in various species. These correlations persist after accounting for confounding factors such as hypermutable CpG sites, GC content, and biased gene conversion. Coalescent models indicate that even when the contribution of ancestral polymorphism to divergence is small, background selection in the ancestral population can still explain a large proportion of the variance in divergence across the genome. This suggests that natural selection plays a significant role in shaping patterns of genetic variation, including inter-species differences, and has implications for understanding the evolution of genomes and interpreting patterns of genetic variation.
Phosphorylation is a key regulatory mechanism for protein stability and activity in circadian clocks across various species. It determines the speed and strength of molecular oscillations by acting on transcriptional activators and their repressors, forming negative feedback loops. In Drosophila, the CK2 kinase phosphorylates and destabilizes the PERIOD (PER) and TIMELESS (TIM) proteins, which inhibit CLOCK (CLK) transcriptional activity. A recent study found that CK2 also targets the CLK activator directly. Downregulating the activity of the catalytic α subunit of CK2 induces CLK degradation, even in the absence of PER and TIM. This indicates that CK2 inhibits CLK degradation while reducing its activity. Since the CK1 kinase promotes CLK degradation, it suggests that CLK stability and transcriptional activity result from counteracting effects of CK1 and CK2. The cyclic regulation of CLK, as opposed to the constitutive expression of CYC, makes the CLK protein the key rhythmic component of the circadian activator in Drosophila. CLK DNA-binding and transcriptional activity show a robust oscillation with an evening peak that is associated with the rapid increase of per and tim mRNA levels. The release of CLK from DNA goes hand in hand with its hyperphosphorylation, which depends on both PER and DBT. Kinase activity of DBT does not seem to be required for hyperphosphorylation, and it is proposed that DBT acts as an interface for the recruitment of other kinases into a complex with CLK. CLK transcriptional activity in cultured cells is affected by calcium/calmodulin-dependent kinase II and mitogen-activated protein kinase. Ubiquitylation is also involved in the regulation of CLK and BMAL1, the CYC ortholog in mammals. In Drosophila, USP8 was recently reported to decrease CLK activity by deubiquitylation. The CK2 kinase has a key function in the clockwork of various organisms. In Neurospora, CK1 and CK2 phosphorylate both the White Collar Complex (WCC) transcriptional activator as well as its inhibitor FREQUENCY (FRQ) to control their activity, subcellular localization, and stability. In mammals, CK2 and CK1 destabilize PER2, although phosphorylation at specific CK2 target sites stabilizes the protein. The CK2 holoenzyme is formed by a tetrameric complex consisting of two catalytic (α) and two interacting regulatory (β) subunits. The β subunits stabilize the α subunits that possess constitutive kinase activity. Phosphorylation of most substrates is enhanced by CK2β, while some substrates are more efficiently phosphorylated by free CK2α in the absence of CK2β. In Drosophila, CK2α and CK2β affect PER and TIM abundance and subcellular localization, which correlates with a direct phosphorylation of both proteins by the CK2 holoenzyme in vitro. The dominant-negative CK2αTik mutation strongly increases TIM stability even in the absence of PER, supporting TIM as the main target of CK2. The CK2αTik protein overexpression induces hyperphosphorylation of TIM that could be explained by enhanced phosphorylation or reduced dephosphorylation of TIM by other kinases and phosphatases. Since the identity of the kinases involved in the control of CLK phosphorylation remains unclear, a study aimed to determine whether CK2 plays a role in the phosphorylation and regulation of CLK. The results indicate that inhibition of CK2α activity strongly increases CLK degradation, whereas CK2β does not affect CLK stability. The CK2 holoenzyme is recruited onto PER, TIM, and CLK mainly during late night, inducing CLK hyperphosphorylation in vivo and CK2 phosphorylates CLK in vitro. Specific CLK activity is increased in dominant-negative CK2αTik-expressing flies indicating repression of CLK by CK2α. The unstable but strongly active CLK acquired by CK2α inhibition joins the club of other circadian transcription factors with similar properties such as the WCC complex in Neurospora.
Chagas' disease, caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, is a significant health issue in Latin America and has become a global concern due to migration. The disease is transmitted through blood-sucking insects from the Reduviidae family. T. cruzi undergoes morphological changes within the insect, including adhering to the midgut and rectal cuticle, dividing, and transforming into metacyclic trypomastigotes before being excreted. Cruzipain, a cysteine peptidase, is a vital virulence factor involved in several steps of T. cruzi's interaction with mammalian cells. Its role in metacyclogenesis and host cell invasion has been demonstrated, and it can cleave all human IgG subclasses. A drug targeting cruzipain, K777, has shown promising results in promoting parasitological cure in mice. Cruzipain is found in all developmental forms and strains of T. cruzi, with varying levels of expression. An endogenous cruzipain inhibitor, chagasin, regulates its activity. Transfectants overexpressing chagasin have reduced cysteine peptidase activity, differentiation capacity, and infectivity. This study investigates the role of cruzipain in the interaction of T. cruzi with the invertebrate host by analyzing the effects of anti-cruzipain antibodies and cysteine peptidase inhibitors on parasite adhesion to the R. prolixus posterior midgut. Results indicate that cruzipain plays a significant role in this interaction, and further research is needed to understand its specific mechanisms.
Cytoplasmic dynein is a microtubule-dependent motor protein involved in various cellular processes, such as centrosome separation, metaphase chromosome congression, anaphase spindle elongation, and chromosome segregation during mitosis, as well as vesicle transport and organelle positioning during interphase. However, the mechanisms that target and regulate dynein are largely unknown. In a study to identify these mechanisms, a genome-wide RNAi screen was conducted in Caenorhabditis elegans, which identified 20 genes that specifically suppress conditionally lethal C. elegans cytoplasmic dynein heavy chain mutants. These genes, when reduced in function, are not essential but contribute to dynein function during mitosis. Additionally, some of these genes encode proteins that overlap with those reported by others for the dynein heavy chain in subcellular sites. The study also identified 29 additional genes that, when reduced in function, suppress conditional mutations not only in dynein but also in loci required for unrelated essential processes. Overall, this study highlights the importance of nonessential genes in regulating and mediating essential cellular processes' functions, such as mitosis, through cytoplasmic dynein.
In Paramecium tetraurelia, a unicellular eukaryote, somatic differentiation involves programmed genome rearrangements (PGR) during which physiological DNA double-strand breaks (DSB) are repaired to maintain genome integrity. Two types of nuclei exist in the cytoplasm: the somatic macronucleus (MAC) and the germline micronucleus (MIC). The MAC is essential for gene expression and is destroyed at each sexual cycle, while the MIC undergoes meiosis and transmits the germline genome to the new MIC and MAC of the next generation. In Paramecium, PGR in the new developing MAC includes the elimination of two types of germline-specific DNA and the precise excision of thousands of short, non-coding Internal Eliminated Sequences (IES). The excision of an estimated one-third of Paramecium IESs is controlled maternally through a sequence homology-dependent mechanism, and a domesticated piggyBac transposase, PiggyMac (Pgm), is essential for introducing the DNA cleavages that initiate the reaction. The C-NHEJ pathway, specifically the Ligase IV-Xrcc4 complex, mediates the final ligation step during IES excision and is essential for PGR. Two KU70 and three KU80 genes were identified in the somatic genome of P. tetraurelia, and RNA interference revealed that development-specific KU genes are essential for PGR. The Ku70a/Ku80c heterodimer is essential for the recovery of a functional somatic nucleus, and PiggyMac-dependent DNA cleavage is abolished at IES boundaries in cells depleted for Ku80c, resulting in IES retention in the somatic genome. PiggyMac and Ku70a/Ku80c co-purify as a complex when overproduced in a heterologous system, indicating that Ku has been integrated in the Paramecium DNA cleavage factory, enabling tight coupling between DSB introduction and repair during PGR.
Prion diseases, or transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs), are fatal neurodegenerative diseases that affect both humans and animals. They are caused by the conversion of the normal prion protein (PrPC) to the infectious form (PrPSc), resulting in the accumulation of PrPRes, extensive vacuolation, and microgliosis and astrocytosis. Neuronal dysfunction and synaptic loss have been observed in animal models of prion disease prior to the onset of clinical symptoms. A study using laser capture microdissection to isolate hippocampal CA1 neurons found that gene expression within these neurons is dynamic and characterized by distinct phases of activity. A major cluster of genes is altered during pre-clinical disease, followed by a direct reversal during clinical disease, and this cluster contains a signature highly reminiscent of synaptic NMDA receptor signaling and the activation of neuroprotective pathways. Additionally, genes involved in neuronal projection and dendrite development were altered throughout the disease, culminating in a general decline of gene expression for synaptic proteins. Deregulated miRNAs follow concomitant patterns of expression. These findings suggest that prion replication results in the persistent stimulation of a programmed response that is mediated, at least in part, by synaptic NMDA receptor activity that initially promotes cell survival and neurite remodeling. Manipulation of these early neuroprotective pathways may redress the balance between degeneration and survival, providing a potential inroad for treatment. All animal procedures were approved by the Canadian Science Centre for Human and Animal Health - Animal Care Committee or the University of British Columbia Animal Care Committee. Mice were inoculated intraperitoneally with the Rocky Mountain Laboratory (RML) strain of scrapie and brains were collected at 6 time points post infection (DPI). Brains were processed accordingly for microdissection or pathological analysis. Microdissected CA1 neurons were used to identify numerous genes and miRNAs with altered expression levels in the microdissected CA1 neurons from infected mice. Transcript expression followed a temporally distinct pattern and a bi-phasic molecular response was identified, with a neuronal protective mechanism up-regulated during early prion disease that was subsequently diminished at late stages of infection.
The authors developed an in silico Petri net model to simulate hepatic granuloma development throughout experimental visceral leishmaniasis (EVL) in mice caused by the protozoan parasite Leishmania donovani. The model recapitulated the progression of EVL and many of the changes in cellular composition seen within granulomas over time. Through in silico experiments, the model revealed a previously unappreciated level of inter-granuloma diversity regarding the development of anti-leishmanial activity and suggested that IL-10 produced by infected Kupffer cells at the core of the granuloma plays a dominant local regulatory role.EVL is the most severe form of leishmaniasis and is usually fatal without treatment. Cellular immune mechanisms play an essential role in controlling subclinical infection. T cell-derived cytokines maintain the balance of immunity during subclinical disease, and granulomatous inflammation serves as a histopathologic correlate of protective immunity. The granuloma is a complex structure involving various leukocytes, including monocytes, T cells, B cells, NK cells, NKT cells, dendritic cells, and, in some cases, neutrophils. In EVL, granuloma formation depends on multiple cytokines, and the elimination of intracellular Leishmania is governed by the balance of cytokines that can activate or deactivate local macrophage anti-leishmanial activity.IL-10 is one of the cytokines with an inhibitory effect on macrophage leishmanicidal activity, and serum IL-10 represents a biomarker of disease severity. IL-10 may operate through direct or indirect pathways, such as inhibiting Nos2 expression in macrophages or regulating effector T cell differentiation and/or activation. Various cell populations, such as macrophages, DCs, CD4+ T cells, and Th1 cells, can produce IL-10. An experimental challenge is determining which of these cellular sources of IL-10 is functionally most potent in the local tissue microenvironment, which cells respond to the IL-10 signals, and how this dynamic balance of immune effector and regulatory function evolves throughout the course of infection. The authors employed an in silico Petri net model to gain a greater insight into the potential importance of macrophage deactivation in regulating the outcome of EVL.The Petri net model faithfully reproduces many of the characteristics of EVL in mice, including the importance of macrophage deactivation mediated through IL-10. The results indicate that local leishmanicidal activity is most strongly influenced through the action of IL-10 produced by infected Kupffer cells themselves rather than by infiltrating leukocytes. These results provide new insight into how effector mechanisms may be regulated within the granuloma and a new tool to interpret how pharmacologic interventions may operate.
"The paper analyzes the computational capabilities of gene transcriptional regulatory machinery, viewing it as a computational device with transcription factor concentrations as inputs and expression level as the output.
