Despite increased understanding of OCRL1's cellular functions, the underlying basis for the renal tubulopathy is unknown. The study found that OCRL1 deficiency in zebrafish causes a defect in endocytosis in the pronephric tubule, a model for the mammalian renal tubule. This defect coincides with a reduction in levels of the scavenger receptor megalin and its accumulation in endocytic compartments, indicating reduced recycling within the endocytic pathway. These results suggest that OCRL1 is required for endocytic trafficking in vivo, and endocytic defects are responsible for the renal tubulopathy in Lowe syndrome and Dent-2 disease. The study also reveals PIP5K as a potential therapeutic target for these disorders. Overall, the findings provide new insights into the pathogenesis of Lowe syndrome and Dent-2 disease and highlight the importance of endocytic trafficking in renal function.
In a study conducted in the Kilombero river valley of Tanzania, inter-epidemic transmission of Rift Valley Fever (RVF) was investigated in livestock populations. A cross-sectional sero-survey was conducted in randomly selected cattle, sheep, and goats from May to August 2011, approximately four years after the 2006/07 RVF outbreak in Tanzania. The study found an overall seroprevalence of 11.3% and a linear increase in prevalence in the post-epidemic annual cohorts, indicating a constant exposure and presence of active foci of recent transmission preceding the survey. Nine inhibition-ELISA positive samples were also positive for RVFV IgM antibodies, indicating a recent infection. Animals living >15 km from the flood plain were more likely to have antibodies than those living <5 km. These findings suggest post-epidemic and recent transmission of RVFV in livestock populations in the Kilombero river valley, and the need for continued monitoring and control measures during inter-epidemic periods. RVF is a mosquito-borne viral zoonosis that affects both livestock and wild ruminants, and can cause mild to severe illness in humans. It is primarily an occupational hazard affecting people in close contact with infected animals, but can also be transmitted through infectious mosquito bites and consumption of unpasteurized animal products.
Trypanosoma cruzi, the etiologic agent of Chagas disease, is an obligate intracellular pathogen that depends on surface proteins to invade its hosts and conserves a contractile vacuole complex (CVC) for osmoregulation. Here, a study used genetic and biochemical approaches to delineate the contribution of the CVC to the traffic of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins to the plasma membrane and promote host invasion. Results showed that TcRab11, a GTPase that localizes in recycling endosomes in most cells, localizes to the CVC of Dictyostelium discoideum and T. cruzi. In T. cruzi epimastigotes, the polyamine transporter TcPOT1.1, which localizes to CVC-like structures, has been reported to appear in the plasma membrane when the culture medium is deficient in polyamines. The CVC of T. cruzi is an acidic calcium store and has roles in calcium ion sequestration and excretion pathways and in the transfer of some proteins to the plasma membrane. In T. cruzi, TcTS genes are distributed in several families, and TcTS is crucial for the life cycle of the parasite, allowing the acquisition of sialyl residues from the host glycoconjugates. GPI-anchored proteins, including TcTS and TcTSSA II, are transported from the ER to the plasma membrane through the Golgi apparatus. However, in T. cruzi trypomastigotes, TcTS, TcTSSA II, and other mucins are transported to the plasma membrane through the CVC, which also possesses lipid-raft like structures. Expression of dominant-interfering TcRab11 mutants altered the morphology, osmoregulation, traffic of TcTS to the plasma membrane, and parasite infectivity. These results suggest the presence of a novel unconventional mechanism of GPI-anchored protein transport to the cell surface of eukaryotic cells.
This phase III clinical trial compared the immunogenicity and safety of a purified chick-embryo cell rabies vaccine (PCECV) administered according to a shortened post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) 4-site/1-week intradermal regimen, compared to the currently recommended 2-site/Thai Red Cross (TRC) regimen. The study enrolled healthy individuals aged ≥1 year, randomized into 4 groups to receive intradermal PCECV according to one of the 2 regimens, with or without human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG) administration at first visit for adults. The primary objective was to assess non-inferiority of the immune response of the 4-site/1-week ID PEP regimen to that of the currently recommended 2-site/TRC ID regimen of PCECV, with or without HRIG administration. At D49, non-inferiority was concluded as the difference in percentage of participants with adequate RVNA concentrations between the 4-site/1-week and the 2-site/TRC groups was -1 (95%CI: -2.4--0.0). The 2 regimens had similar safety profiles. The data suggest that the 4-site/1-week regimen might be an alternative to current recommendations, with potential benefits in terms of improved cost-efficiency and compliance to vaccination. Rabies is a viral disease caused by viruses belonging to the Lyssavirus genus of the Rhabdoviridae family, and is preventable through PEP including vaccination. Current recommendations indicate concomitant administration of rabies immunoglobulins for WHO category III rabies exposures. Intradermal (ID) vaccination regimens have proven to be more cost-effective than intramuscular (IM) ones and are therefore used preferentially. The recommended WHO ID regimen for PEP takes approximately 1 month and requires 4 clinic visits. However, prevention of rabies remains inadequate in developing regions where access to medical care is not optimal. Reducing the number of required visits would reduce costs while increasing compliance to the full PEP course. A newly proposed PEP regimen allows completion of the ID immunization within 1 week and has shown encouraging results in clinical trials. This study aimed to demonstrate the non-inferiority of the immune response following vaccination with PCECV according to the new 4-site/1-week ID regimen compared to the updated conventional 2-site/TRC ID regimen with or without concomitant administration of human RIG (HRIG).
The human brain's ability to adapt to rapidly changing, goal-relevant situations is attributed to its capacity to detect and focus on significant goal-related events in a flexible manner. A crucial role in this process is played by the salience network (SN), which includes the anterior insula and the dorsal anterior cingulate cortex. The SN is responsible for the rapid detection of goal-relevant events and facilitates access to appropriate cognitive resources. In this study, the subsecond resolution of large multisession fMRI datasets from the Human Connectome Project was utilized to investigate the dynamic spatiotemporal organization of the SN using novel graph-theoretical techniques. The study found that the SN exhibits distinctive and robust large-scale brain dynamics characteristics. These include the highest levels of flexibility in time-varying connectivity with other brain networks, the most spatially varied dynamic functional interactions, consistent high levels of network centrality over time, and unique time-varying connectivity profiles that predict individual differences in cognitive flexibility. Moreover, these results were replicated in a second retest dataset, emphasizing their robustness. Overall, this study highlights the SN's unique functional architecture, which facilitates interactions with multiple functional systems, and supports a wide range of cognitive processes in the human brain.
Simian Vacuolating Virus 40 (SV40), a nonenveloped virus, goes through a life cycle with several consecutive and tightly regulated steps, including binding, internalization, penetration, replication, assembly, and release. The release step is crucial for the viral life cycle and involves the exit of viral progeny from the cell for infection dissemination. While enveloped virions are released from the cell by budding or membrane fission, nonenveloped viral release typically requires cell lysis after the viral multiplication cycle. SV40 is a polyomavirus that has been extensively studied and serves as a paradigmatic virus to help expand knowledge of the undefined stages of the nonenveloped viral life cycle, including viral release. A new SV40 gene product, VP4, has been identified and found to be expressed at late times during the viral life cycle, coinciding with the time of viral-mediated cell lysis. VP4 is a 125 amino acid protein with a central hydrophobic domain and has been proposed to play a role in viral release. Studies have shown that VP4 efficiently binds red blood cell (RBC) membranes and supports membrane perforation. VP4 also disrupts liposomes mimicking the composition of mammalian plasma and nuclear membranes. The hydrophobic domain of VP4 is essential for membrane binding and disruption, and it displays a preference for membranes comprised of lipids that replicate the composition of the plasma membranes over that of nuclear membranes. These results support a central role for VP4 acting as a viroporin in the perforation of cellular membranes to trigger SV40 viral release, making it an attractive target for therapeutic intervention.
The dengue virus (DENV) is a significant public health concern, affecting millions of people worldwide. Despite the severity of the disease, there is no specific antiviral treatment or vaccine available. The immune response to DENV is not fully understood, and a better understanding of it is crucial for vaccine development. A DNA vaccine, pcTPANS1, containing the signal peptide sequence from the human tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA) fused to the DENV2 NS1 gene, has been shown to protect mice against dengue. The mechanism of protection involves a combination of cellular and humoral responses. The vaccine induces considerable levels of anti-NS1 antibodies and activates CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. The CD4+ cells play a critical role in the protection against dengue, and the transfer of CD4+ T cells combined with anti-NS1 antiserum obtained from vaccinated mice confers protection in mice infected with DENV2. The results suggest that the protective immune response induced by the expression of NS1 antigen mediated by the pcTPANS1 requires a cooperation between CD4+ T cells and the humoral immunity. The development of an effective anti-dengue vaccine is critical for public health, and the understanding of the immunological mechanisms by which a protective immunity against dengue is generated is essential for the development of a vaccine.
In Gram-positive bacteria, cell-to-cell communication, also known as quorum-sensing, is regulated by oligopeptidic pheromones which activate QS systems when they reach a threshold extracellular concentration. These pheromones are matured by species-specific proteases and either detected in the medium by the extracellular receptor domain of histidine kinases of two-component systems or reinternalized through oligopeptide permeases for direct interaction with intracellular receptors. The RNPP superfamily of cytoplasmic QS regulators, characterized by a tetratricopeptide-repeat (TPR)-type peptide-binding domain, regulates important physiological processes such as sporulation, virulence, and conjugation in bacilli or enterococci. ComR regulators, a subgroup of the RNPP family, regulate competence for natural DNA transformation in streptococci. ComR is directly activated by the binding of its associated pheromone XIP, the mature form of the comX/sigX-inducing-peptide ComS. The crystal structure analysis of ComR from Streptococcus thermophilus combined with a mutational analysis and in vivo assays has elucidated the structure-function relationship of the transcription factor ComR. XIP-binding induces release of the sequestered HTH domain and ComR dimerization to allow DNA binding. Importantly, this activation mechanism is conserved and specific to ComR orthologues, demonstrating that ComR is not an Rgg protein as initially proposed, but instead constitutes a new member of the RNPP family. Inhibiting competence development constitutes an interesting target in drug discovery as competence activation in streptococci also results in the co-expression of genes involved in virulence-associated functions and predation mechanisms, which are essential for their fitness during infection. Studies have been undertaken to target the well-characterized two-component signaling system ComDE, but targeting the ComRS system has not been explored yet. In this manuscript, the structure-function analysis of the ComRS system from S. thermophilus provides the structural basis required for rational design of inhibitors, and reveals an idiosyncratic regulatory mechanism based on the sequestration of the DNA-binding domain.
The pentameric ligand-gated ion channel ELIC, a prokaryotic homolog of eukaryotic pLGICs, has been functionally characterized through electrophysiology and X-ray crystallography. The study identified a class of primary amines as ligands that open the channel by a strongly cooperative process. The open state is comparably stable, but channels desensitize with slow kinetics. X-ray structures reveal electron density in the consensus binding site, suggesting a conserved activation mechanism. ELIC forms cation-selective channels with large single-channel conductance and selectivity properties that resemble other cation-selective members of the family. The ligands, including the neurotransmitter GABA, bind to a conserved site and evoke currents that slowly desensitize over time. This study highlights ELIC's potential as an attractive model system to study general mechanisms of ion conduction and gating in pLGICs.
Asthma, a prevalent chronic lung disease, is linked to atopic dermatitis (AD) and frequently affects individuals with a history of eczema. However, the mechanism behind the progression from AD to asthma is unclear. A study in mice with skin-barrier defects found that thymic stromal lymphopoietin (TSLP) overexpressed by skin keratinocytes is the systemic driver of bronchial hyper-responsiveness, leading to an asthmatic phenotype. This was demonstrated through the use of an AD-like model, RBP-j–deficient animals, which sustained high systemic levels of TSLP and developed severe allergic lung inflammation after antigen-induced allergic challenge. Elimination of TSLP signaling in these animals blocked the atopic march, indicating that high serum TSLP levels are required to sensitize the lung to allergic inflammation. These findings suggest that in addition to early treatment of primary skin-barrier defects, selective inhibition of systemic TSLP may be key to blocking the development of asthma in AD patients.
An approach that integrates multiple omics datasets with bioinformatics tools has been developed, allowing for a detailed annotation of several microbial genomic features. This methodology was used to characterize the genome of Thermotoga maritima, a phylogenetically deep-branching, hyperthermophilic bacterium. Experimental data, including whole-genome resequencing, transcription start site (TSS) determination, transcriptome profiling, and proteome profiling, were analyzed in combination with bioinformatics tools to improve gene annotation, elucidate transcription units (TUs), identify putative non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs), and determine promoters and ribosome binding sites. This analysis revealed many distinctive properties of the T. maritima genome organization relative to other bacteria, including a high number of genes per TU, a paucity of putative ncRNAs, few TUs with multiple TSSs, increased sequence conservation of promoters and ribosome binding sites, and a bimodal length distribution of 5'UTRs. These distinctive properties are hypothesized to be a reflection of this organism's hyperthermophilic lifestyle and could yield novel insights into the evolutionary trajectory of microbial life on earth. The generation of genome-scale data is becoming more routine, but the subsequent analysis of omics data remains a significant challenge. The approach described here enables an experimentally anchored annotation of several bacterial genomic features, providing a valuable resource to the research community and facilitating quantitative and comparative analysis of annotated features across microbial species.
This study investigates the influence of contextual inputs on visual object recognition, specifically on the perception of a target bar in various contexts. The experiments involve presenting observers with a briefly displayed stimulus of a target bar with varying contrast levels against different contexts, and asking them to judge whether the target bar is present. The results show that observers are more likely to perceive a target when the context has a weaker contrast, and this perception is influenced by the observers' prior belief and internal model of likely input contrasts caused by a target bar. The study also suggests that cortical areas beyond the primary visual cortex are responsible for this visual inference. The findings demonstrate that context significantly influences the perception of the target bar, and this influence is mediated through a Bayesian inference and decision process. The results highlight the importance of context in visual perception, and provide insights into the neural mechanisms underlying visual inference and decision-making.
Cooperation for the production of costly common goods is observed in nature, but is vulnerable to exploitation by defectors. This can lead to population collapse and the destruction of cooperation. However, small population size, which is more common during population collapse, can favor cooperation. This is because small population size increases variability in cooperator frequency across different locations, allowing cooperators to outgrow defectors globally despite defectors outgrowing cooperators in each location. Defectors can also create conditions that rescue cooperation by causing defector-induced population collapse, creating empty locations that favor cooperator migrants, and selecting for mutations adaptive to resource limitation caused by defectors. These mechanisms suggest that defectors can play a role in the persistence of cooperation in a structured population. Previous research has uncovered various mechanisms that promote cooperation, such as recognition of cooperators, spatially-structured environments, limited migration, and kin selection. However, migration to sites with additional resources is necessary for cooperation to survive. A group of spatially-separated populations connected through migration, known as a metapopulation, must have cooperator frequency vary greatly among different populations for cooperation to persist. Small population size, which can be achieved through ecologically-relevant ways such as migration of a small number of individuals to a vacant space or exposure to harsh environments, can promote cooperation. This idea has received theoretical and experimental support in both animals and microbes. The presence of defectors can create small population sizes and increase total biomass in a population, as well as maintain selective pressure for partner recognition. A study found that defectors create conditions that rescue cooperation by causing defector-induced population collapse, creating empty locations that favor cooperator migrants, and selecting for mutations adaptive to resource limitation caused by defectors. These mechanisms promote cooperation by generating large variation in cooperator frequency across a metapopulation. Therefore, defectors provide a built-in mechanism that can rescue cooperation by creating small population sizes.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a Gram-negative bacterium that can cause both acute and chronic infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, burn victims, and patients requiring mechanical ventilation. Chronic pulmonary infections with P. aeruginosa severely impact the quality of life and life expectancy of cystic fibrosis (CF) patients. The mucosal barrier presents a significant challenge for P. aeruginosa colonization and bacterial-mediated damage, with infections occurring primarily in patients with altered epithelial cell barriers. A study examining P. aeruginosa's interaction with a polarized epithelium found that the bacterium adheres almost exclusively at sites of multi-cellular junctions, specifically at sites of apoptotic cell extrusion. P. aeruginosa is then internalized through efferocytosis, a process involving the engulfment and disposal of apoptotic cells by surrounding epithelial cells. The bacterium inhabits an efferocytic phagosome that acquires lysosomal features and is eventually killed. This elimination of P. aeruginosa through efferocytosis may be part of the host defense mechanism. These findings could be particularly relevant for the study of CF, which is characterized by an exacerbated number of apoptotic cells and ineffective efferocytosis. Overall, the interaction between P. aeruginosa and the epithelial barrier involves the bacterium's adhesion to apoptotic cells or apoptotic bodies, internalization by surrounding epithelial cells through efferocytosis, and intracellular elimination.
The Drosophila embryonic gonad is formed from two cell types, Primordial Germ Cells (PGCs) and Somatic Gonadal Precursor cells (SGPs). PGCs form at the posterior of the blastoderm stage embryo and migrate to reach the SGPs by traversing the midgut wall and moving through the mesoderm. This process is guided by repulsive cues and attractive signals from the SGPs. The hedgehog (hh) pathway gene shifted (shf) is expressed in the gonadal mesoderm and is required for PGC migration. The hmgcr-dependent isoprenoid biosynthetic pathway plays a pivotal role in generating the PGC attractant in both SGPs and other tissues. Ectopic expression of hmgcr promotes the release/transmission of the Hh ligand from cells into and through the underlying mesodermal cell layer, where Hh can contact migrating PGCs. Potentiation of Hh by hmgcr appears to depend upon cholesterol modification. The hh signaling pathway is crucial in patterning in multicellular eukaryotes and has been implicated in cell migration, axonal guidance, and polarized cellular extensions. Long distance hh signaling is mediated by an unusual multistep pathway in which Hh-Np is transmitted from the basolateral membranes of sending cells to the apical surface, where it can contact migrating PGCs. This process depends on several proteins, including HMGCoA reductase (hmgcr), which contains a transmembrane sterol-sensing domain. In hmgcr mutants, Hh-Np is not properly released from sending cells and instead accumulates in punctate aggregates along the basolateral membranes. Geranylgeranyl-pyrophosphate, a key regulatory target in both isoprenoid and sterol biosynthetic pathways, is used in protein geranylation, including the geranylation of G protein γ subunit 1 (Gγ1), which helps mediate the intracellular trafficking of membrane vesicles and cargo. In hmgcr and qm mutants, geranylgeranyl-pyrophosphate is not properly synthesized, impeding the release of Hh-Np from hh expressing cells. Many of the factors implicated in the basolateral release and subsequent transmission of Hh-Np in polarized epithelium also function in the signaling pathway that directs migration of primordial germ cells (PGCs) to the SGPs during mid-embryogenesis. The Shf protein is enriched in the basolateral ECM and facilitates the long distance transmission of Hh-Np after it has been released from the basolateral membranes of signaling cells. In shf mutants, basolateral accumulation and subsequent spreading of Hh-Np in the wing disc is disrupted, resulting in a reduction in the expression of hh targets in the anterior compartment of the wing. The defects in hh signaling in the wings of shf mutants can be suppressed by overexpression of hmgcr. Shf has no role in Wnt signaling, but functions in the hh pathway to promote hh signaling during embryogenesis. Ectopic shf can upregulate the hh→wingless (wg)→engrailed (en) autoregulatory loop and potentiate hh signaling in the embryo. Shf is expressed in the mesoderm during mid-embryogenesis, when PGCs are migrating, and shf mutants have migration phenotypes, with a subset of PGCs lingering behind on the outside surface of the midgut. Shf is needed for proper PGC migration, and ectopic shf can disrupt the migration of PGCs towards the SGPs.
The development of an effective HIV vaccine remains a significant challenge, and a greater understanding of the mechanisms underlying protection or immune control over HIV replication is essential for future vaccine design strategies. A study examining HIV-specific CD8+ T-cells in long-term nonprogressors (LTNP), patients with durable control over HIV replication, revealed that increased cytotoxic capacity of these cells is associated with efficient elimination of HIV-infected CD4+ T-cell targets. Recipients of a replication incompetent adenovirus serotype 5 (Ad5) HIV-1 recombinant vaccine showed readily detectable HIV-specific CD8+ T-cell recall cytotoxic responses, although the magnitude of these responses was significantly less than that of LTNP and overlapped with that of progressors. However, vaccine recipients carrying the protective HLA class I alleles B*27, B*57 or B*58, which have been associated with immune control over HIV replication in chronic infection, showed significantly higher cytotoxic responses. This suggests that these protective HLA class I alleles might lead to better outcomes in both chronic infection and following immunization due to more efficient priming of HIV-specific CD8+ T-cell cytotoxic responses. Understanding the fundamental basis of immunologic control of HIV is crucial for the development of efficacious HIV vaccines and immunotherapies. Studies of rare patients with natural immune control over HIV, such as LTNP, have provided important clues, suggesting that HIV-specific CD8+ T-cell responses are responsible for mediating immune control. Strong and consistent associations between nonprogressive infection and particular HLA class I alleles, such as B*57, have been observed, and these genetic associations are paralleled by functional data demonstrating an overwhelming immunodominance of HLA B57-restricted, HIV-specific CD8+ T-cells in LTNP.
The ability to undertake jointly intentional behavior, or collaborate, is a key trait of human behavior and has been crucial in the development of modern human cognition. This trait allows individuals to coordinate actions and make decisions that benefit both parties, and it is present in various aspects of human life, from choosing wallpaper colors with a partner to playing on a sports team. While the benefits of collaboration are clear, the evolutionary origins of this trait are not well understood. A study models the evolution of jointly intentional action and shows that it can emerge under certain conditions. The model uses a multi-level selection framework and considers the evolution of collaboration within and between bands of individuals (deme), who are engaged in a process of cultural accumulation. The model includes two types of individuals: N type individuals, who lack the ability to share intentions and behave individualistically, and SI type individuals, who have the ability to share intentions and can coordinate their choices in tandem with their neighbors. The main results of the paper show that the collaborative sharing of intentions can either speed up or slow down the adoption of new norms on a social network, depending on the benefits from adopting new technologies or norms. When these benefits are low, widespread sharing of intentions within a deme slows the adoption of new technologies, leading to a technological disadvantage and selection against collaboration. However, when the benefits from adopting new technologies or norms are high, widespread sharing of intentions within a deme speeds the adoption of new technologies, leading to a technological advantage and the evolution of collaboration. This is consistent with the idea that composite tool manufacture and grammatical language, which facilitate jointly intentional behavior, evolved around the same time (~300 ka). Overall, the study provides a plausible mechanism for the evolution of jointly intentional action and the role of collaboration in human cognition.
Male fertility requires continuous production of high-quality, motile spermatozoa. Alterations in these metrics cause oligoasthenoteratozoospermia, the leading cause of human sub/infertility. Post-mitotic spermatogenesis, including meiotic stages and spermiogenesis, is transcriptionally inert, indicating the potential importance of the post-transcriptional microRNA (miRNA) gene-silencing pathway. The expression of miRNA generating enzyme Dicer within spermatogenesis peaks in meiosis with critical functions in spermatogenesis. Specific miRNAs, including miR-34b/c, are highly expressed in post-mitotic male germ cells and are associated with male fertility. Reduction in these miRNAs, including miR-34b/c, has been causally associated with reduced fertility in humans. Deletion of both miR-34b/c and miR-449 loci resulted in oligoasthenoteratozoospermia in mice, impairing both meiosis and the final stages of spermatozoa maturation. These findings identify the miR-34 family as the first functionally important miRNAs for spermatogenesis whose deregulation is causal to oligoasthenoteratozoospermia and infertility.
Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 (EcN) is a probiotic strain that has been used for over a century to fight bacterial gastrointestinal infections. EcN is known for its ability to impede intestinal colonization by Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium and to exhibit an antibacterial activity against enterohemorrhagic E. coli strains. EcN is an excellent colonizer of the human gut and exhibits beneficial effects in various intestinal dysfunctions such as acute diarrhea in infants and toddlers, chronic constipation, and abdominal pain in patients with irritable bowel syndrome. It has been widely used in the treatment of inflammatory bowel diseases and has proven to be as effective as the gold standard mesalazine for the maintenance of remission in ulcerative colitis in children and adults. EcN probiotic activity is believed to be based on multiple peculiar properties and fitness determinants, including antibacterial activities against other bacteria.EcN reduces S. Typhimurium intestinal colonization by competing for iron through an extensive list of siderophores and multiple siderophore receptors and iron transport systems. In addition to this competition for a limiting nutrient, EcN exhibits a direct antibacterial activity linked to the production of two microcins (Mcc), H47 (MccH47) and M (MccM). Mcc are secreted low-molecular weight peptides that are synthesized by ribosomes and posttranslationally modified, and which display a potent bactericidal activity against phylogenetically-related bacteria. MccH47 and MccM are called “siderophore-Mcc” because they are modified posttranslationally by the linkage of a catechol siderophore. The C-terminus of the Mcc peptide is covalently bound with a linearized and glycosylated derivative of enterobactin. This siderophore moiety is recognized by the catecholate-siderophore receptors of the target bacterium, allowing the siderophore-Mcc to enter and kill the sensitive bacterium by a “Trojan Horse” stratagem.However, EcN is closely related to pathogenic E. coli strains such as the uropathogenic strain CFT073 and carries the pks island encoding a NRPS-PKS assembly line that synthesizes the genotoxin colibactin. Colibactin is produced as a prodrug moiety that is exported in the periplasm by the efflux pump ClbM and then hydrolyzed by the periplasmic membrane-bound ClbP protein with a peptidase activity, which releases the active colibactin. Colibactin is not only a bona fide virulence factor but also a putative procarcinogenic compound.Recent studies have shown that EcN probiotic properties are related to the presence of the pathogenicity island, and that certain enzymes of the pks/clb island enable the synthesis of analgesic lipopeptides. Therefore, it is crucial to specifically decouple the genotoxic activity from the antagonistic activity to optimize EcN. Researchers have successfully decoupled the antibacterial activity from the genotoxic activity by specifically abrogating the genotoxic activity of colibactin. This opens the way to optimize EcN, but further research is needed to fully understand the interplay between colibactin, salmochelin, and siderophore-Mcc biosynthetic pathways and their role in the evolution of E. coli from phylogroup B2. This co-evolution observed in EcN illustrates the fine margin between pathogenicity and probiotic activity, and the need to address both the effectiveness and safety of probiotics.
Cryptococcus neoformans, a leading cause of fatal fungal meningitis worldwide, has an anti-phagocytic polysaccharide capsule containing xylose, a sugar absent in model yeasts. Uxt1 and Uxt2 are xylose donor transporters with distinct localization, expression patterns, and kinetic parameters, and are essential for xylose incorporation into capsule and protein, and for virulence. In C. neoformans, glycans are critical for normal development, growth, and viability, with extensive glycoconjugate repertoire acting as a virulence factor. Glycans play structural and regulatory roles in fungal survival and pathogenesis. Glycosylation is synthesized in the secretory pathway, relying on nucleotide sugar donors synthesized in the cytosol. Nucleotide sugar transporters (NSTs) facilitate this process, and NST dysfunction affects cryptococcal viability and pathogenicity. Cells lacking Uxt1 and Uxt2 lack xylose in all analyzed glycoconjugates, exhibiting growth defects and metabolic abnormalities, and are required for virulence in a mouse model of disease but not for fungal viability in the context of infection.
A global database for neglected tropical diseases (NTDs), including schistosomiasis, soil-transmitted helminthiasis, and leishmaniasis, is being developed to support spatial disease risk modeling, target control interventions, disease monitoring, and surveillance. The database, which is open-access and spatially explicit, contains over 12,000 georeferenced schistosomiasis survey locations in Africa, and is constantly updated with new publications, reports, and field data. The database was initially created to support the CONTRAST project, which aims to enhance understanding of schistosomiasis transmission in sub-Saharan Africa. The database was populated through a systematic review of peer-reviewed journals, grey literature, and personal communication, and includes data on survey location, date, number of individuals examined and found schistosome-positive, and additional survey-specific data. The database has the potential to identify areas with no information on disease burden, foster geographical modeling over time and space, and control and monitor NTDs.
Chronic helminth infections, which affect about one third of the world's population, can lead to a Th2 immune shift and an immunoregulatory milieu, potentially suppressing Th1 immunity necessary for controlling Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) infection. A study was conducted using cotton rats, the natural host for the filarial nematode Litomosoides sigmodontis, to determine the impact of chronic helminth infections on MTB. Two months after MTB challenge, spleen cell proliferation and interferon gamma production were similar between co-infected and MTB-only infected animals. However, MTB loads and lung granulomas were not increased in co-infected animals. These findings suggest that chronic filaria infections do not exacerbate MTB infection in the cotton rat model. This indicates that filaria eradication programs may not facilitate MTB control but implies that it may be possible to develop worm-derived therapies for autoimmune diseases that do not substantially increase the risk for infections.
The DEG/ENaC family of ion channels, which includes the pickpocket (ppk) channels in Drosophila melanogaster, are widely expressed in both peripheral and central nervous systems of invertebrates and vertebrates. Despite their ubiquity, the physiological functions of most DEG/ENaC family members remain unknown. However, recent research suggests that these channels may play important chemosensory roles. Specifically, the study found that the DEG/ENaC channel ppk23 is expressed in a subpopulation of sexually dimorphic gustatory-like chemosensory bristles that are distinct from those expressing feeding-related gustatory receptors. Disrupting ppk23 or inhibiting activity of ppk23-expressing neurons delayed the initiation and reduced the intensity of male courtship, and altered the behavioral response of males to the female-specific aphrodisiac pheromone 7, 11-Heptacosadiene. These findings indicate that ppk23 and the cells expressing it play an important role in the peripheral sensory system that determines sexual behavior in Drosophila. This research adds to the understanding of the complex mechanisms by which animals monitor their chemical environment and guide their behavior, and highlights the importance of ion channels in these processes.
Mitochondria, organelles found in almost all eukaryotic cells, contain a genetic system that encodes a number of protein-coding genes involved in oxidative phosphorylation. In many organisms, the number of mitochondrial tRNA genes is not sufficient to ensure mitochondrial translation, and nucleus-encoded tRNAs have to be imported from the cytosol to mitochondria. The regulation of tRNA mitochondrial import is limited in our understanding, and tRNA import can occur under certain circumstances even when mitochondrial genomes are equipped with a minimal set of tRNA genes sufficient for mitochondrial translation. The nucleus-encoded tRNAs imported into mitochondria are used in the cytosolic translation machinery, and variations between the extents of mitochondrial localization of individual nucleus-encoded tRNAs have been observed. A study on the green alga Chlamydomonas found that tRNA import cannot be rapidly regulated in response to a novel genetic context, suggesting that the steady-state levels of imported tRNAs in mitochondria result from a co-evolutive adaptation between the tRNA import mechanism and the requirements of the mitochondrial translation machinery.
Diabetes is a significant global health issue, with over 30 million adults in the US and 422 million worldwide affected. Prediabetes, which affects 84 million in the US, has an annual conversion rate of approximately 10% to type 2 diabetes. While diabetes is genetically heterogeneous, it is also physiologically diverse. Blood glucose levels are regulated by insulin and other organs, and insulin resistance or deficiency can lead to elevated blood glucose. Lifestyle interventions, including personalized dietary recommendations, have been shown to prevent or delay the onset of diabetes in prediabetic individuals. Current diagnostics for diabetes and prediabetes rely on HbA1c or single-time-point measurements of blood glucose, which may miss substantial glucose elevations and fail to account for glycemic variability. A new measure of glucose variability derived from the spectral clustering of glycemic signatures using time-series-specific distance metrics has been proposed. This method can classify individuals into different glucotypes, providing a more comprehensive, dynamic, and granular understanding of diabetes etiology, detect glucose dysregulation at earlier stages of disease, and personalize diet for optimal glucose response. Many individuals not known to be prediabetic by standard measures have high levels of postprandial glucose, and a subset of normoglycemic individuals can reach prediabetic or diabetic glucose levels following standardized meals. Therefore, a comprehensive metric of glycemic variability that encompasses all components of glucose signatures is expected to provide a more accurate understanding of diabetes etiology, detect glucose dysregulation at earlier stages of disease, and personalize diet for optimal glucose response.
EDR1 is a negative regulator of plant defense in Arabidopsis, including resistance to pathogens and ethylene-induced senescence. EDR1 negatively regulates the MKK4/MKK5-MPK3/MPK6 kinase cascade to modulate plant defense and cell death. This regulation occurs through direct interaction of EDR1 with MKK4 and MKK5, and involves the negative regulation of MKK4 and MKK5 protein levels. The N-terminal regulatory domain of EDR1 is responsible for this interaction, and may act as a scaffold protein to keep MKK4 and MKK5 in a catalytically inactive state. Alternatively, EDR1 may affect the stability of MKK4 and MKK5 directly through interactions with the 26S proteasome degradation machinery. The edr1 mutant shows enhanced resistance to pathogens, and this resistance is dependent on MKK4 and MKK5 function, providing direct genetic evidence that these kinases are key players in plant immunity responses. The kinase activity of MPK3/MPK6 can be repressed through dephosphorylation mediated by several different phosphatases and by modulation of MKK4 and MKK5 protein levels by EDR1, providing a mechanism for fine-tuning the activity of the MKK4/MKK5-MPK3/MPK6 kinase cascade in response to pathogen attack.
Infectious diseases pose a significant global healthcare problem, leading to millions of deaths each year, particularly among poor and young populations in low and middle-income countries. To develop effective control and prevention strategies, reliable computational tools are needed to understand disease dynamics and predict future cases. A study developed a computational framework based on Gaussian processes to perform spatiotemporal prediction of infectious diseases, outperforming two standard machine learning algorithms in predicting Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever cases in Turkey. Gaussian processes can capture highly complex dependencies in disease modeling scenarios, making them valuable for identifying dependencies and making more reliable predictions. This framework can significantly contribute to public health policy makers by enabling temporal, spatial, and spatiotemporal predictions, allowing for better-informed decisions on vaccine purchases, public awareness campaigns, and training programs for healthcare workers.
Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a mosquito-borne viral zoonosis in Africa and the Middle East that causes human deaths and significant economic losses due to large-scale livestock mortality and abortions. Outbreaks of RVF are sporadic and associated with seasonal and socio-economic factors. Here, a three-patch model is proposed to investigate the transmission dynamics of RVFV among ruminants with spatial movements. The findings suggest that human activities, particularly those associated with the Eid al Adha feast, and a combination of climatic factors contribute to the transmission and dispersal of the disease pathogen. Sporadic outbreaks may occur when abundant livestock are recruited into areas at risk from RVF due to the demand for the religious festival and abundant numbers of mosquitoes emerge. Numerical results present the transmission dynamics of the disease pathogen over both short and long periods, particularly during the festival time. Simulations show that when the time for festival preparation starts earlier than usual, the risk of massive disease outbreaks rises, particularly in the place where the religious ceremony will be held. A single case of RVF can rapidly spread to an epidemic when there is a co-occurrence of high densities of arthropod vectors and large numbers of susceptible individuals in a population. This co-occurrence can happen for a number of reasons, such as the combination of climatic factors that favor the growth of a vector population and human activities, such as events involving large congregations of hosts in one place, around the same time, perhaps periodically. In the case of RVFV, a vector-borne pathogen endemic in Africa and the Middle East, the co-occurrence of annual flood stages of a river that promotes high densities of disease vector mosquitoes and a religious festival, the Eid al Adha feast, at which time large numbers of livestock are driven towards the site of the feast, creates a particular periodicity of times of high potential for disease outbreaks. These two events follow different calendars, solar (365.25 days) and lunar (354.37 days), and coincide perfectly only every 33.57 years, although partial overlap occurs in other years surrounding those of perfect coincidence.
"The study assessed the spatial and temporal changes in the occurrence of human anthrax in Azerbaijan from 1984 to 2010. The results showed an annual percentage change in incidence of +11.95% from 1984 to 1995, followed by a decline of -35.24% after the initiation of livestock vaccination in 1996. The geographic distribution of reporting also shifted from the west to the east over the study period. Despite the decrease in incidence, continued control measures are needed in livestock to further mitigate the occurrence of anthrax. The study highlights the need for a ""One Health"" approach that considers the changing geographic distribution of the disease. The collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 led to profound alterations in disease management and an increase in vaccine-preventable diseases such as diphtheria. Similarly, the deterioration of public health infrastructure and new agricultural policies led to a reported increase in zoonotic diseases, such as anthrax, in the former Soviet Union. Effective control of the disease in humans is highly dependent on mitigating the disease in animals through vaccination campaigns and proper outbreak management. A ""One Health"" approach that integrates animal and human health has been shown to be effective for other zoonoses such as rabies and brucellosis. However, there is limited research on the benefits of a ""One Health"" approach for anthrax. Anthrax is a soil-borne, bacterial zoonosis that primarily occurs in herbivores and can result in significant economic losses from livestock mortality and lost worker productivity. In Azerbaijan, anthrax has a long history and is considered sporadic, although it is bordered by endemic and hyperendemic countries. A comprehensive preemptive livestock vaccination program was established in 1996, following a series of livestock anthrax outbreaks. Anthrax has recently reemerged in the Caucasus, raising concerns over the potential trans-boundary spread of the disease. Spatial and temporal analyses can aid in disease management by providing a better understanding of anthrax epidemiology."
Voltage-gated potassium (KV) channels are membrane proteins that respond to changes in membrane potential by enabling K+ ion flux across the membrane. They can be modulated by polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs), which induce channel opening by modulating the voltage-sensitivity. This provides an effective treatment for refractory epilepsy through a ketogenic diet. A study using microsecond molecular dynamics simulations found a putative PUFA binding site in the open state of the Shaker KV channel, located at the protein-lipid interface in the vicinity of the extracellular halves of the S3 and S4 helices of the voltage-sensor domain (VSD). The lipophilic PUFA tail covered a wide range of non-specific hydrophobic interactions in the hydrophobic central core of the protein-lipid interface, while the carboxylic head group displayed more specific interactions to polar/charged residues at the extracellular regions of the S3 and S4 helices, encompassing the S3-S4 linker. PUFAs have increased conformational flexibility in the polyunsaturated carbon tails compared to saturated carbon chains, which may explain the specificity of PUFA action on channel proteins. Voltage-gated ion channels are critical for propagating nerve impulses, muscle contraction, and hormone secretion, making them attractive drug targets. KV channels can be modulated by a wide variety of molecules, including PUFAs, which shift the voltage dependence of the channel to enable channel activation via a proposed electrostatic mechanism.
Cryptosporidium parvum is a protozoan parasite that causes significant disease burden among children in developing countries and can result in chronic and life-threatening enteritis in AIDS patients. However, the currently available drugs lack efficacy in treating these severe conditions. The discovery and development of novel anti-cryptosporidial therapeutics has been hampered by the poor experimental tractability of this pathogen. The genome sequencing effort has identified several new targets, including a unique inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH). A new study has developed a pipeline of tools to accelerate the in vivo screening of inhibitors of C. parvum IMPDH. They genetically engineered the related parasite Toxoplasma gondii to serve as a model of C. parvum infection and established a fluorescence-based assay of host cell proliferation and a C. parvum growth assay. These assays have been used to evaluate C. parvum IMPDH inhibitors emerging from their medicinal chemistry effort and have identified a subset of 1,2,3-triazole ethers that exhibit excellent in vivo selectivity in the T. gondii model and improved anti-cryptosporidial activity. This study provides a significant step towards the development of new chemotherapy for cryptosporidiosis.
"A genome-wide association study of tooth development in infancy was conducted among individuals from the 1966 Northern Finland Birth Cohort (NFBC1966) and the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children (ALSPAC). The study tested for associations with time to first tooth eruption and number of teeth by one year of age. Five genetic loci were identified at genome-wide significance (P<5×10−8), including KCNJ2, EDA, RAD51L1, IGF2BP1, and MSRB3. These genes have links to tooth and other organ development, and are implicated in the development of cancer. The strongest association was for SNP rs8079702, located downstream of KCNJ2, which has been implicated in Pierre Robin sequence and Andersen-Tawil syndrome, characterized by abnormalities in tooth development and craniofacial anomalies. The five top SNPs explain 2.9% of the variance of both tooth eruption time and number of teeth in the NFBC1966, and 4.2% and 4.0% of the variance in tooth eruption and number of teeth in ALSPAC. These estimates may overestimate the true values due to the ""winner's curse"". The study also identified five loci with SNPs that had P-values between 5×10−6 and 5×10−8, including rs6504340, located between the developmental regulatory genes HOXB1 and HOXB2, and SNP rs12424086, located close to the HMGA2 gene. The study found an association between a variant within the HOXB gene cluster and the requirement for orthodontic treatment due to defective occlusion by the age of 31 years. The findings could have implications for the study of other developmental and organogenic processes."
The trisomy of human chromosome 21 (Hsa21), causing Down syndrome (DS), is the most common viable human aneuploidy, while complete monosomy (M21) of Hsa21 is lethal. Only partial monosomy or mosaic monosomy of Hsa21 is seen, leading to variable physiological abnormalities with constant intellectual disability, locomotor deficits, and altered muscle tone. A new mouse model, Ts3Yah, with a tandem duplication of the Hspa13-App interval syntenic with 21q11.2-21q21.3, was created to search for dosage-sensitive genes involved in DS and M21 phenotypes. The trisomy of this region alters locomotion, muscle strength, mass, and energetic balance. The expression profiling of skeletal muscles revealed global changes in the regulation of genes implicated in energetic metabolism, mitochondrial activity, and biogenesis. These genes are downregulated in Ts3Yah mice and upregulated in Ms3Yah mice. The shift in skeletal muscle metabolism correlates with a change in mitochondrial proliferation without an alteration in the respiratory function. The reactive oxygen species (ROS) production from mitochondrial complex I decreased in Ms3Yah mice, while the membrane permeability of Ts3Yah mitochondria slightly increased. Therefore, the Hspa13-App interval controls metabolic and mitochondrial phenotypes in muscles certainly as a consequence of change in dose of Gabpa, Nrip1, and Atp5j. The copy number variation in the Hspa13-App region has a peripheral impact on locomotor activity by altering muscle function.
G protein-gated K+ channels, also known as GIRK or Kir3 channels, are crucial for regulating heartbeat and neuronal excitability and plasticity. They can be activated by Gβγ subunits derived from Gi/o proteins, and are activated to varying degrees by both neurotransmitter-evoked (Ievoked) and neurotransmitter-independent basal (Ibasal) activities. However, the relationship between Ibasal and Ievoked has been unclear. A recent study has shown that Ibasal and Ievoked are interrelated, with the extent of activation by neurotransmitter being inversely related to Ibasal. This behavior can be explained by a quantitative model of GIRK1/2 function, which accurately recapitulates Ibasal and Ievoked in Xenopus oocytes, HEK293 cells, and hippocampal neurons. The model indicates that there are consistently between 3 and 4 Gβγ dimers available for each GIRK1/2 channel, while the number of available Gαi/o decreases as the density of GIRK1/2 increases. This suggests a strong association of GIRK1/2 with Gβγ, but not Gα, and a maximal stoichiometry of 4 Gβγ but only 2 Gαi/o per one GIRK1/2 channel. These unique and unequal associations, along with the cooperative nature of GIRK gating by Gβγ, allow GIRK1/2 to act as a sensitive bidirectional detector of both Gβγ and Gα.
"The paper discusses the use of plant-pathogenic Xanthomonas bacteria, which secrete TALEs (Transcription Activator-Like Effectors) into host cells to act as transcriptional activators on plant target genes and support bacterial virulence. The authors propose a novel approach for TALE target prediction, termed PrediTALE, to identify potential virulence targets. The approach considers recent findings concerning TALE targeting, such as frame-shift binding by repeats of aberrant lengths and the flexible strand orientation of target boxes relative to the transcription start of the downstream target gene. The computational model can account for dependencies between adjacent RVD positions and is benchmarked using RNA-seq data after Xanthomonas infection in rice.The authors find an overall improvement in prediction performance compared with previous approaches and are able to predict several novel putative virulence targets. However, they also observe that no target genes are predicted by any prediction tool for several TALEs, which they term ""orphan TALEs."" They propose that one explanation for orphan TALEs is incomplete gene annotations and suggest replacing promoterome-wide by genome-wide scans for target boxes. They demonstrate that known targets from promoterome-wide scans may be recovered by genome-wide scans, whereas the latter, combined with RNA-seq data, can detect putative targets independent of existing gene annotations.Xanthomonas bacteria can infect many crop plants, including rice, and cause disease, resulting in substantial yield losses. Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae (Xoo) and Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzicola (Xoc) express TALE proteins, which function as transcription factors in infected host cells. The DNA-binding domain of TALE proteins consists of tandem repeats, with each repeat comprising approximately 34 highly conserved amino acids (except for the amino acids at position 12 and 13, which are responsible for DNA specificity). Recent studies have shown that naturally occurring TALEs may activate susceptibility (S) genes that are responsible for bacterial growth, proliferation, and disease development, as well as disease resistance (R) genes.The authors also mention that most known target boxes are directly preceded by a ‘T’, while ‘C’ and ‘A’ occur with decreasing frequencies. However, some repeats deviate from the common length of 34 AAs and have been termed aberrant repeats. These aberrant repeats may loop out of the repeat array when a TALE binds to its DNA target box, allowing for increased flexibility and binding to frame-shifted target boxes. Different Xoo and Xoc strains express different repertoires of TALEs, where a single strain may host up to 27 TALEs."
A new machine-learning algorithm called APOGEE has been developed to estimate the harmfulness of mitochondrial non-synonymous genome variations. It outperforms existing prediction methods and is designed to address the limitations of traditional methods which have shown only 60-70% agreement when considering all possible human non-synonymous variants. APOGEE provides a detailed description of its algorithm, training and test sets of variants, and classification ability. The algorithm was built using 100 sets of variants drawn randomly from a training set of 864 known mitochondrial variants and achieved better performance rates compared to other individual and meta-predictors tools. APOGEE's performance was further validated using two non-overlapping test sets, and its predictions were shown to be in line with those previously shown. The authors plan to integrate additional evolutionary measures and the impact of co-inherited missense variants in future releases of APOGEE.
Dengue virus (DENV) infection is the most common mosquito-transmitted viral infection, leading to a range of diseases from dengue fever to life-threatening dengue hemorrhagic fever and shock syndrome. Thrombocytopenia, a significant correlation with dengue severity, is a major characteristic observed in both mild and severe dengue disease. A study explored the role of DENV nonstructural protein 1 (NS1) in platelet activation and thrombocytopenia development during DENV infection. The researchers found that DENV NS1, and not Zika virus NS1, could induce P-selectin expression and phosphatidylserine exposure in human platelets, which were abolished when NS1 was depleted from the DENV supernatant. These effects were blocked in the presence of anti-NS1 F(ab')2, anti-TLR4 antibody, a TLR4 antagonist (Rhodobacter sphaeroides lipopolysaccharide, LPS-Rs), and a TLR4 signaling inhibitor (TAK242), but not polymyxin B. DENV-induced thrombocytopenia and hemorrhage were attenuated in TLR4 knockout and wild-type mice when NS1 was depleted from DENV supernatant. The binding of DENV NS1 to TLR4 on platelets can trigger its activation, which may contribute to thrombocytopenia and hemorrhage during dengue infection. DENV NS1 plays a critical role in dengue pathogenesis, both in vitro and in vivo, by enhancing DENV replication/infection, directly inducing vascular leakage, and causing cytokine release from immune cells. Relative levels of NS1 antigen in dengue patients' sera were negatively correlated with platelet count. The study suggests that DENV NS1 can directly trigger platelet activation and apoptosis through TLR4 signal transduction and enhance platelet aggregation in the presence of a subthreshold dose of ADP. These effects may contribute to platelet activation and thrombocytopenia during DENV infection.
The dynamic control loops regulating vasomotor tone of vascular smooth muscle, blood volume, and mean arterial pressure involve the arginine vasopressin (AVP) system, the atrial natriuretic peptide system (ANP), and the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). These systems regulate blood pressure by affecting vasoconstriction and blood volume. The AVP system, which involves hormones produced in the hypothalamus and released into the bloodstream, has vasoconstrictive effects and increases water permeability in the kidneys. The ANP system, which involves hormones produced in the heart in response to atrial stretching, has vasorelaxing effects. The RAAS system, which involves hormones produced in the kidneys in response to low blood pressure or low sodium chloride concentration in the tubule at the macula densa, has vasoconstrictive effects and increases production of aldosterone, which promotes sodium reabsorption in the kidneys. These systems have been analyzed using mathematical models, which reveal that they consist of negative-feedback loops that admit a single equilibrium that can either be stable or give rise to oscillatory instability. The system of dynamic control loops regulating vasomotor tone, blood volume, and mean arterial pressure can be combined with cellular-level mechanisms to form a complete system, which can be analyzed using system-theoretic and control-theoretic approaches. These analyses suggest that the physiological mechanisms regulating long-term homeostasis of blood hydraulic parameters are arranged into a complex of equivalent loop systems, consisting of candidate oscillators with a single equilibrium point. The whole system can be split into two systems displaying essentially the same functioning, an apparent redundancy that could offer alternatives for coping with accidental defaults.
Thromboembolic disease is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, with 900,000 cases per year in the USA resulting in 300,000 deaths. This paper explores the role of a fibrin cap in preventing small thrombi from developing into life-threatening events. The fibrin cap, which forms on the surface of a thrombus, is capable of stopping blood clot growth by interfering with the transport of thrombin to the thrombus surface. Thrombin is a potent platelet activator and is required for fibrin generation. By interfering with thrombin transport to the thrombus surface, the fibrin cap limits further growth.The formation of a fibrin network on the thrombus surface provides a mechanism to limit continued growth of small thrombi. The network does not provide a transport barrier for thrombin but rather a shield blocking resting platelets from approaching sites of thrombin generation. The suggested mechanism may prevent small thrombi, which frequently form as a result of activation or damage of a few endothelial cells, from growing into symptomatic occlusive clots.Experimental measurements of protein diameter distributions and fibrin network permeability were conducted using dynamic light scattering and Darcy's equation, respectively. The fibrin network permeability was found to substantially decrease as the fibrinogen concentration increased. The calculated fiber radii ranged from 150 nm to 500 nm, which is in good agreement with fiber thicknesses evaluated directly from confocal images and with previously reported values of hydrated fiber bundles of coarse gels.The diffusion coefficients and mobile fractions of thrombin and Fab IgG were obtained by fitting experimental data using Levenberg-Marquardt curve-fitting. The resulting diffusion coefficients were plotted as a function of fibrinogen concentration. The diffusion coefficient of thrombin and Fab IgG in solution in the absence of fibrinogen were found to be 1102.6 /s and 400.9 , respectively.In summary, the formation of a fibrin cap on the surface of a thrombus can prevent small thrombi from developing into life-threatening events by interfering with the transport of thrombin to the thrombus surface. The fibrin network does not provide a transport barrier for thrombin but rather a shield blocking resting platelets from approaching sites of thrombin generation. The fibrin network permeability substantially decreases as the fibrinogen concentration increases, providing a mechanism to limit continued growth of small thrombi.
In the study of iNKT cells and their role in limiting microbial growth during infection, research has shown that iNKT cells control Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) growth in a CD1d-dependent manner, but not through IL-12, IL-18, or IFNγ. The study found that iNKT cells produce GM-CSF in vitro and in vivo in a CD1d-dependent manner during Mtb infection, and that GM-CSF is both necessary and sufficient to control Mtb growth. This discovery highlights the importance of GM-CSF in T cell immunity against Mtb, and the novel mediator of iNKT cell antimicrobial activity. CD1 restricted T cells have been proposed to have a role in antimicrobial immunity, and iNKT cells have been shown to influence many different immunological conditions. iNKT cells can be activated through high affinity antigens or through a weak lower affinity self or microbial ligand in the context of costimulatory signals. However, the specific role of iNKT cells during infection and whether their activation by different pathways leads to the expression of diverse functions is still unclear. The study of iNKT cells during infection has relied heavily on mouse models that lack iNKT cells or administered αGalCer, but less is known about the physiological role of iNKT cells during infection. While it is established that iNKT cells can produce various cytokines and chemokines and have immunomodulatory effects, the direct antimicrobial role of iNKT cells for most infections is still unknown. Despite this, there is evidence that activated iNKT cells enhance host resistance to Mtb, with iNKT cells being important for neutrophil recruitment to the lung during Pseudomonas infection, and IFNγ being required for protection by iNKT cells against Streptococcus pneumoniae. Overall, the study of iNKT cells and their role in antimicrobial immunity is complex and ongoing, but the discovery of GM-CSF production as a novel iNKT cell antimicrobial effector function provides a promising direction for future research.
The opportunistic fungal pathogen Candida albicans is a common component of the human intestinal flora, and its interactions with the host play crucial roles in health and disease. A study of C. albicans genes expressed during growth within a host found that the EFH1 gene, encoding a putative transcription factor, was highly expressed during growth in the intestinal tract. However, an efh1 null mutant exhibited increased colonization of the murine intestinal tract, while an EFH1 overexpressing strain exhibited reduced colonization of the intestinal tract and oral cavity of athymic mice. The EFH1 gene regulates the level of colonizing fungi, favoring commensalism as opposed to candidiasis. Additionally, different genes are required in different host niches and the pathways that regulate gene expression during host colonization can differ from well-characterized pathways used during laboratory growth. Overall, this study highlights the complexity of C. albicans colonization and the importance of studying gene expression during growth within a host.
Immunization with irradiated sporozoites is an effective strategy against liver stages of malaria parasites, and the mechanisms underlying this protection involve prolonged antigen presentation. CD8+ T cell responses require sporozoite antigen to persist for over 8 weeks after immunization, taking place in lymphoid organs dependent on CD11c+ cells. This persistent antigen enhances the magnitude of CD8+ T cell responses, impacting the final size of memory populations, full development of memory cells, and the priming of naïve cells to become functional effector cells. These findings highlight the importance of prolonged antigen presentation in generating protective immunity against malaria liver stages. Studying irradiated Plasmodium sporozoites, which induce robust protective CD8+ T cell responses without persisting infection, can provide valuable insights into the role of antigen persistence in the absence of persisting infection.
Leishmaniasis, a public health problem in tropical countries, is a neglected disease by the World Health Organization (WHO) caused by over 20 species of protozoa from the genus Leishmania. The intracellular parasite hosts mammalian macrophages and establishes three types of infections: visceral, mucocutaneous, and cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL). Currently, 70-75% of CL cases are present in 10 tropical countries, and it causes ulcerated lesions in the skin, which can evolve to disfigurement, mutilation and allow secondary infection by bacteria. The treatment for CL relies on several drugs, including meglumine antimoniate, sodium stibogluconate, pentamidine, amphotericin B deoxycholate, liposomal amphotericin B, fluconazole, ketoconazole, miltefosine, and paromomycin. However, these drugs present side effects, require hospitalization, and have shown some reports on drug resistance. The use of nanoparticles (NPs) as carriers can overcome drug resistance, side effects, and unspecific biodistribution of microbicidal agents. In this study, the authors produced PBCAnp adsorbed with polB to evaluate its leishmanicidal effect and its viability as a functionalized antibacterial carrier. The results showed that PBCAnp had a spherical shape and a size of around 200 nm, which is adequate to enhance macrophage phagocytic activity and activation of the complement system. The D10 value is higher than 100 nm, which means that 10% of total particles are under the reported particle size value. The mean particle size and D values were higher when measured by DLS than those by NTA. PolB was incorporated in NPs by electrostatic adsorption, and the efficiency of incorporation was stable. PBCAnp-polB presented 17.7% (885 μg/mL) on t = 1 day and 16.8% (840 μg/mL) on t = 45 days. PBCAnp-polB resulted in approximately 2.4 x 105 molecules of polB per nanoparticle. The experimental drug loading for PBCAnp-polB was 10.53% as compared to a theoretical value of 8.76%. The cellulose membrane used to separate the test compartments is widely used with proteins and described as having low binding with them, in addition to having 12--14 kDa membrane pores, which are at least 12 times larger than polB (1, 023 kDa). Therefore, delayed time can be attributed to drug diffusion rate through the membrane. The release profile confirmed a sustained release of polB from NPs, adequate for prolonged antimicrobial effect. Leishmanicidal activity tests were performed in vitro with Leishmania amazonensis promastigotes. The IC50 value found for free polB was 77.1 μg/mL (59.2 μM). However, the standard drug meglumine antimoniate presented an average IC50 value of 49 to 60 μg/mL, which was measured in reference strains of the same species. It is important to note that the current model of in vitro susceptibility testing may undermine leishmanicidal efficacy since these peptides can be inactivated by fetal bovine serum and high saline concentration in culture media. PolB binding to serum also favors its cell entrance without its membrane activity; consequently, degradation can occur and aminoacids serve as nutritional molecules, which may explain the increased growth and high standard deviation of the less concentrated samples. In addition, several drugs had lower activity in extracellular Leishmania forms. PolB treatment with 10 μg/mL had similar behavior of 20 μg/mL, with no statistical difference, except for low infected counting. Therefore, increments in polB concentration were not enough to increase its leishmanicidal efficacy. As described before, a cutaneous lesion caused by Leishmania is frequently contaminated by bacteria, which can lead to a more serious secondary infection or even worse, the leishmaniasis, like Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Therefore, the microbicidal activity of the formulations was tested. The minimum inhibitory concentration used of polB and PBCAnp-polB was 2 μg/mL, in triplicate, by visual determination. All visual determinations corroborated with O. D. analysis. Incorporation of polB in NPs did not change MIC results, which is in accordance with the lack of antimicrobial activity from the carrier (at the same dilutions tested for the loaded version). Therefore, this test confirms that polB remains active and bound polB is released fast enough to maintain the 24-hour result from the polB alone.
This historical cohort study aimed to investigate the prognostic factors for death from visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in Belo Horizonte, Brazil, using data from the Reportable Disease Information System (SINAN) from 2002 to 2009. The study identified variables associated with death from VL, which were used to create a prognostic score. The prognostic score was evaluated using sensitivity, specificity, positive and negative predictive values, and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve. The study found that weakness, Leishmania-HIV co-infection, other associated infections, bleeding, jaundice, and age ≥60 years were associated with death from VL. These findings are consistent with previous studies and the Brazilian Ministry of Health. The study highlights the importance of early detection of these factors to identify vulnerable patients and reduce the lethality of the disease. The case fatality rate in Belo Horizonte is one of the highest in Brazil, and several factors, such as accessibility to health services, suspicion of VL, delayed diagnosis, treatment opportunity, clinical management, drug toxicity, comorbidities, and Leishmania population in circulation, could contribute to the unacceptable fatality rates. The study suggests that knowledge of the laboratory and clinical profiles of patients and their association with death from VL could assist in clinical management and reduce lethality. Other studies have identified various risk factors associated with lethality from VL, such as mucosal hemorrhage, jaundice, dyspnea, bacterial infections, reduced number of neutrophils and platelets, fever for more than 60 days, diarrhea, anemia, and undernutrition. Delay in diagnosis has also been associated with death from VL, and reducing delay in diagnosis could improve VL case outcomes. Overall, the study emphasizes the importance of early detection and effective measures to reduce the lethality of VL.
The Arabidopsis thaliana BAK1/SERK3 protein is a regulatory receptor-like kinase that plays crucial roles in plant growth, cell death control, and innate immunity, but is not required for ligand binding in ligand-dependent heteromers with several ligand-binding LRR-RKs. A novel allele of BAK1, bak1-5, was identified in a forward-genetic screen for elf18-insensitive mutants. The bak1-5 mutation is a single missense substitution in the 10th exon of BAK1, which leads to a C408Y change in the subdomain VIa of the cytoplasmic kinase preceding the catalytic loop. The bak1-5 mutation specifically affects the accumulation of the BAK1 protein, and bak1-5 transgenic plants are strongly impaired in flg22- and elf18-induced reactive oxygen species (ROS) burst and thus phenocopied the bak1-5 mutant. Moreover, bak1-5 is a semi-dominant allele with a dose-sensitive dominant-negative effect on the endogenous wild-type BAK1, indicating that it has a specific phenotype related to PAMP responsiveness. In contrast to the previously reported bak1-4 mutant plants, bak1-5 plants were strongly affected in all flg22 and elf18 responses measured and were more strongly impaired in PTI signaling than the null allele bak1-4, particularly with EFR-dependent responses. The bak1-5 plants were hyper-susceptible and supported bacterial multiplication to similar levels as in efr fls2 leaves upon spray-infection with Pto DC3000 COR−. The impairment of bak1-5 in bacterial resistance was further supported by the increased disease symptoms observed after spray-infection with Pto DC3000 COR−. The compromised PTI signaling capacity of bak1-5 leads to a reduced ability to launch effective defense responses culminating in hyper-susceptibility to bacteria.
A new experimental and computational approach has been developed to better understand the antiproliferative response to anticancer treatment in cancer cell populations. This approach combines time-lapse live cell microscopy and flow cytometric data to create a computer rendering of the proliferative process through the cell cycle and subsequent generations during and after treatment. The effects of treatments are modelled with modules describing the functional activity of the main pathways causing arrest, repair, and cell death in each phase. A framework modelling environment is used to apply different types of modules in each phase and test models at the complexity level justified by the available data. The method is then challenged with time-course measures taken in parallel with flow cytometry and time-lapse live cell microscopy in X-ray-treated human ovarian cancer cells, spanning a wide range of doses. This allows for the construction of the most suitable model of the treatment, including the dose-response of each effect, combining modules with a rational strategy and fitting simultaneously all data of different doses and platforms. The final model provides a complete rendering in silico of the cycling process following X-ray exposure, providing separate and quantitative measures of the dose-dependence of G1, S and G2M checkpoint activities in subsequent generations. This new approach has the potential to improve our understanding of the complexity of the antiproliferative response to anticancer treatment and inform the development of more effective therapies.
Coenzyme Q (CoQ), an essential electron carrier in the mitochondrial respiratory chain, has been implicated in a variety of human mitochondrial diseases. Its biosynthesis involves the production of polyisoprenoid diphosphate, which requires enzymes encoded by PDSS1 and PDSS2. Homozygous mutations in these genes lead to severe neuromuscular disease, with nephrotic syndrome seen in PDSS2 deficiency. A study found that a presumed autoimmune kidney disease in mice with the missense Pdss2kd/kd genotype can be attributed to a mitochondrial CoQ biosynthetic defect. The disease manifestations specifically originate in glomerular podocytes, as renal disease is seen in Podocin/cre, Pdss2loxP/loxP knockout mice but not in conditional knockouts targeted to renal tubular epithelium, monocytes, or hepatocytes. Liver-conditional B6. Alb/cre, Pdss2loxP/loxP knockout mice have no overt disease despite demonstrating undetectable CoQ9 levels, impaired respiratory capacity, and significantly altered intermediary metabolism. These findings suggest that disease manifestations of CoQ deficiency relate to tissue-specific respiratory capacity thresholds, with glomerular podocytes displaying the greatest sensitivity to Pdss2 impairment. CoQ is a benzoquinone molecule that functions as an electron carrier in the mitochondrial respiratory chain, transporting electrons from complexes I or II to complex III. In mice and humans, the polyisoprenylated side chain of CoQ is formed by polyisoprenyl diphosphate synthases, each a heterotetramer of two protein subunits encoded by Pdss1 and Pdss2 in mice and PDSS1 and PDSS2 in humans. Mutations in these genes have been associated with rare conditions of primary CoQ deficiency in humans, typically presenting with neurologic or myopathic disease that is often ameliorated with CoQ supplementation.
