Nephrotic syndrome has been seen in individuals with mutations in PDSS2 as well as COQ2. Mechanisms underlying tissue-specific disease manifestations remain unclear.
Phenotypic robustness is the ability of a phenotypic trait to remain invariant in the face of environmental or genetic perturbations, allowing maintenance of high fitness even under suboptimal conditions and facilitating adaptation under certain conditions. The genetic basis of phenotypic robustness includes mechanisms such as capacitors, molecular chaperones, and functional redundancy at the gene and systems levels. Development, a key component of phenotypic robustness, is not well understood in terms of its underlying mechanism. However, a study of three invertebrates with determinative development (Caenorhabditis elegans, Pellioditis marina, and Halocynthia roretzi) found that their determinative development is highly robust to two types of cell death, mimicking environmental or genetic disturbances. The robustness is explained by multiple nonrandom features of the cell lineages, including shallow depth, topology, early ontogenic appearances of rare cells, and non-clonality of most cell types. Simple simulations suggest that this characteristic could have arisen as an adaptation to certain disturbances in ontogenesis. This reveals general organizing principles of determinative developmental cell lineages and a conceptually new mechanism of phenotypic robustness, which have important implications for development and evolution.
EmbryoPhenomics is a high-throughput platform for phenomics in aquatic embryos, consisting of an open-source video microscope (OpenVIM) and a Python package, Embryo Computer Vision (EmbryoCV), for high-dimensional measurement of phenomic traits from video data sets. This platform enables the quantification and integration of interindividual and intraindividual temporal change in morphological, physiological, and behavioural traits with high resolution and to an unprecedented scale in a largely automated workflow. EmbryoPhenomics was demonstrated to be effective in quantifying integrated organismal responses to environmental change, using experiments assessing chronic, acute, and interactive effects of environmental stressors in two ecologically important species with different patterns of development: Radix balthica, a freshwater gastropod mollusc, and Orchestia gammarellus, a marine amphipod crustacean. OpenVIM can acquire images of large numbers of developing embryos at different temporal scales and the resultant image sequence time series can be used to visualize short-term changes in the physiology and behavior of embryos in real time throughout the course of an experiment and longer-term changes in form and function through ontogeny. EmbryoCV performs analysis and extraction of data from every image sequence acquired and these are integrated to form data sets that include morphological, behavioural, physiological, and proxy measurements. Proxy measurements include the measurement of mean pixel intensities at multiple resolutions within each frame of an image sequence to form time series signals that are subsequently analyzed to quantify energy within different temporal frequency bins. These proxy traits can be used for quantification of both holistic (lethal and sublethal classification) and specific measures (quantification and modelling of cardiac rates) of embryo health and physiology. The accuracies of measurements made by EmbryoCV were assessed via comparison with manual quantification of spatial and temporal traits equivalent to the measurements performed by EmbryoCV in a randomized subset of images from each experiment. Concordance between measurements made manually and those made by EmbryoCV was high for both spatial and temporal measurements. The EmbryoPhenomics platform can quantify integrated organismal responses to environmental change, and the resultant data can be used to model and understand the effects of different environmental factors on embryonic development. This platform has the potential to be a valuable tool for studying embryonic development and the effects of environmental change on this process.
Malaria, caused by Plasmodium parasites, is a significant public health problem with over 214 million cases and 438,000 deaths annually. While artemisinin-based combination therapies have been effective in reducing cases, artemisinin resistance threatens to undermine these gains. New therapeutics targeting different parasite developmental stages are needed. This study focuses on Plasmodium metabolism, specifically carbon metabolism in Plasmodium berghei, the malaria parasite responsible for rodent malaria.Glutamine serves as the predominant input into TCA metabolism in both asexual and sexual blood stages and is important for complete male gametogenesis. Glutamine catabolism and key reactions in intermediary metabolism and CoA synthesis are also essential for ookinete to oocyst transition in the mosquito. These findings extend our knowledge of Plasmodium metabolism and point towards possible targets for transmission-blocking intervention strategies.Glucose consumption by Plasmodium-infected RBC increases 10-fold, and these stages rely primarily on glycolysis for energy generation. Notwithstanding their dependence on glycolysis, asexual blood stages maintain a single, poorly crystalline mitochondrion and are dependent on electron transport chain (ETC) activity for the re-oxidation of inner membrane dehydrogenases and pyrimidine biosynthesis. The maintenance of the mitochondrial ETC is sustained in part by the oxidation of pyruvate and the uptake and catabolism of glutamine.In contrast to asexual blood stages, there is increasing evidence that the mosquito-infective stages of Plasmodium exhibit an increased dependence on the TCA cycle and mitochondrial metabolism. Specifically, Plasmodium gametocytes develop more complex tubular mitochondrial cristae suggestive of increased mitochondrial function. Recent genetic studies have also shown that the TCA cycle is essential for the development of P. falciparum mosquito stages, consistent with earlier work in P. berghei demonstrating that the TCA cycle and the electron transport chain are required for ookinete development and oocyst formation.Despite the essentiality of the mitochondrion, operation of the TCA cycle is not required for intra-erythrocytic growth of P. falciparum. Plasmodium spp. lack key enzymes involved in gluconeogenesis and all developmental stages are predicted to be dependent on the uptake of sugars. However, in contrast to the asexual blood stages, there is increasing evidence that the mosquito-infective stages of Plasmodium exhibit an increased dependence on the TCA cycle and mitochondrial metabolism. Little is known about the metabolic flexibility of different Plasmodium mosquito stages and the extent to which parasite metabolism impacts on the development of these stages in the mosquito vector. In this study, the authors utilized a combination of metabolomic and reverse genetic approaches to investigate the metabolic changes that occur in key insect stages of the experimentally tractable species P. berghei and the potential impact of these changes on parasite infection in the mosquito.They find that these stages are highly sensitive to disruptions in multiple pathways in central carbon metabolism, including the TCA cycle, the utilisation of glutamine as a carbon source, intermediary carbon metabolism and coenzyme A (CoA) synthesis. The strict dependency of these stages on multiple pathways in carbon metabolism opens new avenues for targeting parasite transmission. Understanding the metabolic differences between Plasmodium species and stages, as well as the impact of parasite metabolism on transmission, can inform the development of new transmission-blocking intervention strategies.
"The ability to differentiate between pulsatile and sustained signals is crucial in many biological signaling pathways, and this ability often arises from the capacity to process oscillatory signals. One common motif that underlies this signal decoding is the incoherent feedforward loop (IFFL), where an input simultaneously activates an output and an inhibitor of the output. This motif can exhibit temporal adaptation, where the system becomes desensitized to a sustained input, and this property is critical in distinguishing input signals with varying temporal profiles. This paper examines another property of IFFLs - their ability to process oscillatory signals - and finds that the kinetics of the IFFL components limit the input range for which the network can decode pulsatile dynamics. Additionally, a match between the network parameters and input signal characteristics is required for optimal ""counting"" of pulsatile dynamics. These findings illuminate one potential mechanism by which information processing occurs in natural networks and have implications for the design of synthetic gene circuits for this purpose. Furthermore, the paper highlights the importance of understanding how cells process oscillatory signals, as they are essential to the regulation of various cellular processes, from Ca(2+) signaling to coordination of cell fates. A systems-level approach reveals that negative feedback, often in conjunction with nonlinear reaction rates, is crucial for the generation of oscillations. While much is known about the mechanisms that generate oscillations, less is understood about how cells process these signals. In particular, how cells distinguish between oscillatory and sustained inputs and how encoded information is retrieved from the frequency and amplitude of oscillatory inputs remain open questions. Computational methods suggest one potential mechanism, where a critical frequency defines the bandwidth for high fidelity signal propagation for each network, and this capacity can be changed with an increased oscillation amplitude or with increased kinetic rates. Despite the ubiquity of oscillations in biology, much work remains to be done in understanding how cells process these signals."
Scrub typhus is a serious febrile illness in rural Southeast Asia, caused by the obligate intracellular bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted through Leptotrombidium mite bites. However, research on O. tsutsugamushi's cell biology and pathogenicity lags behind other human pathogens due to its obligate intracellular nature. A study aimed to improve methods for quantification, propagation, purification, and long-term storage of O. tsutsugamushi, including developing a standardized assay for accurate and reliable quantitative information about bacterial viability. This assay would help analyze the effects of various treatments on bacterial viability and quantify growth under different growth conditions. The researchers decided on a qPCR-based assay specific to O. tsutsugamushi's 47kDa Htra single copy gene to measure bacterial copy numbers. A single time point was chosen to represent the number of viable bacteria and the degree of intracellular growth. They validated that bacterial copy number after 7 days is roughly proportional to the number of bacteria added, establishing a single post-infection time point to accurately compare conditions for bacterial treatment and growth. This study addresses the need for improved techniques in handling O. tsutsugamushi, contributing to both cell biology research and clinical diagnostic research.
The study investigated the safety and efficacy of the anti-helminthic drug praziquantel (PZQ) in treating schistosome-infected children aged 1-5 years, a group currently excluded from schistosome control programs due to lack of safety data. The study found that PZQ treatment significantly reduced schistosome infection levels in this age group, with a 99% egg reduction rate and 92% cure rate, comparable to the efficacy in 6-10 year olds. Mild side effects were reported in 3.8% of the children, similar to those observed in older children. These findings suggest that PZQ treatment is as safe and efficacious in children aged 1-5 years as it is in older children, supporting the inclusion of younger children in schistosome control programs.Schistosomiasis is a prevalent parasitic disease in tropical and subtropical countries, affecting approximately 107 million people, with children carrying the heaviest burden of infection. Current control programs recommend regular de-worming of school-aged children, but exclude pre-school children due to lack of safety data and the belief that they have low infection rates. However, studies have shown high infection prevalence and morbidity in this age group, making them both at risk of infection and a potential reservoir for the parasite.The study was conducted in Zimbabwe, where S. haematobium is endemic, and involved 104 children aged 1-5 years and 435 children aged 6-10 years. The children were treated with PZQ and infection levels, cure rates, and side effects were compared between the two age groups. The study found that PZQ treatment significantly reduces infection levels and has similar efficacy rates in both age groups. Mild side effects were reported in 3.8% of the younger children and 13.3% of the older children, similar to those observed in previous studies.The findings of this study have important implications for schistosomiasis control programs. The inclusion of younger children in these programs is crucial for breaking the transmission cycle and reducing the overall disease burden. The safety and efficacy of PZQ in young children support its use in this age group. However, further studies are needed to assess the long-term safety and impact of PZQ treatment in young children, as well as the feasibility and cost-effectiveness of including this age group in control programs.In conclusion, this study provides important data on the safety and efficacy of PZQ treatment in young children with schistosomiasis, supporting their inclusion in control programs. Further research is needed to optimize and expand these efforts to achieve sustainable control and elimination of this prevalent and debilitating disease.
Oncogenic mutations in the small GTPase Ras contribute to around 30% of human cancers, but Ras mutations alone are not sufficient for tumorigenesis. To identify cooperating cancer-relevant signaling pathways, a genome-wide, functional screen was conducted in Drosophila, revealing multiple novel, evolutionarily-conserved pathways controlling Ras-driven epithelial tumorigenesis. Human gene orthologs of the fly hits were significantly downregulated in thousands of primary tumors, indicating novel prognostic markers for human epithelial tumors. Of the top 100 candidate tumor suppressor genes, 80 were validated in secondary Drosophila assays, identifying many known cancer genes and multiple novel candidate genes that cooperate with Ras-driven tumorigenesis. Low expression of the confirmed hits significantly correlated with the KRASG12 mutation status and poor prognosis in pancreatic cancer. One of the novel top 80 candidate cancer genes, the Tetraspanin family member Tsp29Fb, was mechanistically characterized and found to regulate EGFR signaling, epithelial architecture, and restrain tumor growth and invasion. This functional Drosophila screen uncovers multiple novel and evolutionarily conserved epithelial cancer genes and confirms Tsp29Fb as a key regulator of EGFR/Ras-induced epithelial tumor growth and invasion.
Meiotic drivers are alleles that manipulate gametogenesis to increase their representation in the progeny, often at the expense of other alleles. They impose a fitness cost, leading to the evolution of suppressors. Here, the wtf gene family in Schizosaccharomyces pombe has been investigated, and it was discovered that wtf13 is a meiotic driver, killing spores that do not inherit it. A diffusible poison and a spore-specific antidote are generated. Another wtf gene, wtf18-2, arising spontaneously in the lab, suppresses wtf1
A study has been conducted to predict gene expression levels in unseen human individuals based on their genetic variation using a new algorithm. The algorithm was trained using expression and genotype data of a set of individuals and tested on unseen individuals from different populations. The algorithm's predictions were found to be robust and in agreement between training and test sets. The study also showed that incorporating genomic annotations and functional features into the algorithm improved the predictions. Genes that were successfully predicted had higher expression and more variability across individuals. The algorithm can be used to predict some of the expression variation among human individuals with a low false positive rate using only their genotype data. The study also highlights the potential of using additional features such as trans-acting SNPs to further improve the predictions. Overall, the study provides a concrete means by which some of the expression variation among human individuals can be predicted with high accuracy using only their genotype data.
This study uses a dynamical-model based Bayesian inference approach to investigate the cause of competitive suppression of an avirulent clone of Plasmodium chabaudi (AS) by a virulent clone (AJ) in immuno-deficient and competent mice. The study finds that the ratio of background loss rate of merozoites to invasion rate of mature RBCs needs to be clone-specific to predict the data. This difference is largest in immuno-competent mice and smallest in immuno-deficient mice, explaining why competitive suppression is alleviated in immuno-deficient mice. The study concludes that the innate immune response clearing merozoites is the most likely mediator of competitive interactions between virulent and avirulent clones. However, the study suggests that future refinement of the model may lead to the discovery of other competitive mechanisms. Overall, understanding the competition between strains is essential to understand the evolution of virulence and drug resistance in malarial infections.
"The ODIRA model proposes that a specific replication error can generate interstitial, inverted triplications in genomes, specifically at pre-existing short, interrupted, inverted repeats. This error involves the ligation of leading and lagging nascent strands to create ""closed"" forks, which can then form a hairpin-capped linear duplex. This duplex can then replicate in vivo to create an inverted, dimeric plasmid that can integrate into the genome, creating an inverted triplication without loss of distal chromosomal sequences. The authors test this model using in vitro and in vivo approaches in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae and find support for the proposed replication error and its downstream consequences on chromosome structure. The ODIRA model can also explain the generation of human de novo inverted amplicons, making it a valuable tool for understanding the origins of interstitial, inverted CNVs that are important in human health and evolution. Overall, eukaryotic genomes are surprisingly plastic, and various mechanisms, including homologous and non-homologous recombinational events, errors in replication, and models such as ODIRA, contribute to this plasticity."
The article discusses the role of alternative translation initiation in the response of mammalian cells to stress, specifically in the context of viral infection and the anti-viral response. The authors use influenza virus as a model system to study this phenomenon and find that viral infection and the anti-viral response alter sites of translation initiation, leading to the production of novel immune epitopes. Specifically, the authors identify a truncated version of the viral neuraminidase protein that is expressed on the cell surface during influenza virus infection, is enzymatically active, and is conserved in most N1 viral lineages. The authors also find that the subset of host transcripts induced by the anti-viral response is enriched for alternate initiation sites. Additionally, the authors perform evolutionary analyses and find evidence for selection against non-canonical initiation at CUG codons in influenza virus lineages that have adapted to mammalian hosts. Overall, the study provides new insights into the role of alternative translation initiation in the cellular response to viral infection and highlights the evolutionary forces that shape this process.
Enteric bacterial pathogens, including Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC), can cause foodborne diseases with significant economic and health burden, such as severe bloody diarrhea and kidney disease. EHEC uses a type III secretion system (T3SS) to inject virulence proteins into host cells and disrupt their normal function, leading to diarrheal disease and bacterial transmission. However, the mechanisms by which these effectors bind to host proteins and disrupt host cell functions are not fully understood. In a study, the E. coli O157:H7 nleH1 and nleH2 genes, which encode T3SS effectors, were found to bind to the human ribosomal protein S3 (RPS3), a subunit of NF-κB transcriptional complexes. NleH1 and NleH2 co-localized with RPS3 in the cytoplasm but not in cell nuclei. The N-terminal region of both NleH1 and NleH2 was required for binding to the N-terminus of RPS3, and their binding was independent of kinase activity. NleH1, but not NleH2, reduced the nuclear abundance of RPS3 without altering the p50 or p65 NF-κB subunits or affecting the phosphorylation state or abundance of the inhibitory NF-κB chaperone IκBα. NleH1 repressed the transcription of a RPS3/NF-κB-dependent reporter plasmid, but not RPS3-independent reporters. In contrast, NleH2 stimulated RPS3-dependent transcription, as well as an AP-1-dependent reporter. These findings suggest that NleH may disrupt host innate immune responses by binding to a cofactor of host transcriptional complexes, providing new insights into the mechanisms of bacterial effector-mediated disruption of host innate immunity.
The paper presents a new probabilistic method called Feature Motif Models (FMMs) for modeling transcription factor (TF)-DNA interactions, which uses sequence features to represent TF binding specificities, where each feature may span multiple positions. The authors develop the mathematical formulation of the model and devise an algorithm for learning its structural features from binding site data. They also develop a discriminative motif finder, which discovers de novo FMMs that are enriched in target sets of sequences compared to background sets. They evaluate their approach on synthetic data and on the widely used TF chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) dataset of Harbison et al., and show that FMMs explain TF binding significantly better than PSSMs. The authors apply their algorithm to high-throughput TF ChIP data from mouse and human and reveal sequence features that are present in the binding specificities of mouse and human TFs. The FMM learning and motif finder software are available at <http://genie.weizmann.ac.il/>.Precise control of gene expression lies at the heart of nearly all biological processes, and much effort has been devoted to detecting TF-DNA binding specificities using traditional methodologies and high-throughput technologies. However, distilling the TF binding specificity from these assays remains a great challenge. The most common computational approaches start by defining sets of genes that are potentially coregulated and then attempt to identify regulatory elements by searching for common motifs in the promoter regions of the genes in each group. Recently, Eden et al. developed a discriminative motif finder that is well suited for finding motifs in a ChIP-chip experiment. Their method combines the search for a cutoff that defines the positive set with the search for a motif that discriminates the positive set from the rest of the chip probes.The paper by Peer et al. focuses on the limitation of the PSSM representation, which assumes that the binding specificities of TFs are position-independent, and proposes a novel approach called feature motif models (FMMs) for modeling TFBS motifs. The approach is based on describing the set of sequence properties, or features, that are relevant to the TF-DNA interactions. Each feature is assigned a statistical weight, representing the degree of its importance to the TF-DNA interaction, and the overall strength of a TFBS can then be computed by summing the contribution of all of its constituent features. The authors argue that this formulation captures the essence of the TF-DNA interaction more explicitly than PSSMs and other previous approaches. They also show that their approach can naturally represent complex and distant dependencies efficiently, thereby overcoming a limitation of other models that have been proposed.The authors validate their approach by learning FMMs from synthetic and real aligned TFBS data, and devise a novel motif finder algorithm that finds motifs in a set of unaligned sequences. They demonstrate the benefits of using FMMs instead of PSSMs as a basic building block of a motif finder, which represents TF binding motifs. Finally, they present insights that they gained from learning FMMs for two human TFs, CTCF and c-MYC.In summary, the paper presents a novel probabilistic method for modeling TF-DNA interactions, which uses sequence features to represent TF binding specificities, and show that it explains TF binding significantly better than PSSMs. The FMM learning and motif finder software are available to the research community, which could help to reveal sequence features that are present in the binding specificities of TFs in mouse and human.
The adrenergic α2C receptor (ADRA2C) is an inhibitory modulator of the sympathetic nervous system, and its expression is lower in humans and chimpanzees than in other primates. This difference is due to positive selection for regulatory changes in the gene during chicken domestication and a decrease in neuronal expression in humans and chimpanzees. This decrease in expression is due to the presence of repressive histone modification and DNA methylation in the gene's promoter region. Additionally, two variants (DHS2.v1 and DHS2.v2) within a binding motif for neuron-restrictive silencer factor (NRSF) have been found to increase binding affinity and repress ADRA2C expression. These variants are fixed or near-fixed in the present-day human population, and are predicted to increase binding affinity for NRSF. CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing experiments have shown that these genomic regions possess enhancer activity that is significantly lower with the derived allele than with the ancestral allele. The derived sequences are fixed or near-fixed at both sites in the present-day human population. Additionally, there is evidence of recent positive selection for lower neuronal ADRA2C expression in humans, indicated by low levels of nucleotide diversity, negative Tajima's D values, and strong integrated haplotype score (iHS) signals at the DHS2 locus. These findings suggest that there has been selective pressure for enhanced sympathetic nervous activity in the evolution of humans and chimpanzees.
The C4 photosynthetic pathway, which has evolved independently over 60 times in monocotyledonous and dicotyledonous plants, is a remarkable example of convergent evolution. It increases productivity by approximately 50% in tropical and subtropical areas through alterations to leaf anatomy, cell biology, and biochemistry. A recent study used a new informatics framework to compare gene expression in two independent C4 lineages, Cleome gynandra and Zea mays, whose last common ancestor diverged 140 million years ago. The study found a core molecular signature associated with leaf and photosynthetic maturation that is likely shared by angiosperm species derived from the last common ancestor of the monocotyledons and dicotyledons. Additionally, homologous transcription factors are used to induce C4 photosynthesis and maintain the cell-specific gene expression required for the pathway to operate in both species. These findings suggest that deep evolutionary comparisons of gene expression can reveal novel insights into the molecular convergence of highly complex phenotypes and that parallel evolution of trans-factors underpins the repeated appearance of C4 photosynthesis. This has implications for identifying regulators and targeting transcription factors shared by independent C4 lineages for engineering the C4 pathway into C3 crops such as rice.
In 2013-2016, an unprecedented epidemic of Ebola virus (EBOV) occurred in West Africa, with cases spreading to Europe and North America. A case study of a Health Care Worker (HCW) infected with EBOV in Sierra Leone and treated in Italy provides insights into the virus's behavior in the respiratory tract. Longitudinal analysis of the HCW's samples showed that EBOV's positive and negative RNA persisted in the lower respiratory tract even after viral clearance from plasma, suggesting local replication. This study, published in the journal Viruses, highlights the need for further investigation to understand the clinical significance of EBOV replication and shedding in the respiratory tract and its potential role in human-to-human transmission.EBOV, a negative-sense RNA virus, caused the largest viral hemorrhagic fever epidemic in West Africa from December 2013 to January 2016. The virus spread to Europe and North America, and several patients received care in these regions. In particular, two patients were treated at the National Institute for Infectious Diseases (INMI) in Rome, Italy. The second patient, a HCW who worked in a treatment center in Sierra Leone, presented with fever, cough, and a delayed febrile thrombocytopenic syndrome with pericardial effusion. Chest X-ray revealed basal mild interstitial lung involvement.The study compared the levels of EBOV negative sense genomic RNA (neg-RNA) and positive sense RNA (pos-RNA), including both mRNAs and antigenomic RNAs, as indicators of viral replication in clinical samples from the HCW. The results showed that EBOV viremia peaked in the first days of hospital admission and declined after the administration of Mil77. However, total EBOV RNA in sputum peaked at day 6 and remained high up to day 9. Neg-RNA and pos-RNA were present in sputum samples at concentrations 2-3 Log higher than neg-RNA and pos-RNA values in plasma.The study's findings have implications for understanding the potential role of the respiratory compartment in EBOV replication in humans. The authors suggest that further investigation is needed to understand the clinical significance of EBOV replication and shedding in the respiratory tract and its potential role in human-to-human transmission. It is crucial to continue studying EBOV replication and shedding in different body compartments to develop effective intervention strategies and understand the virus's transmission dynamics fully.
A study was conducted to investigate the role of different domains of the glycoprotein precursor (GPC) of Candid#1 (Cd#1) vaccine strain of Junin virus (JUNV) in the attenuation of Machupo virus (MACV), a related virus that causes Bolivian hemorrhagic fever. Previously, a recombinant MACV (rMACV) with the glycoprotein of Cd#1 (rMACV/Cd#1-GPC) was found to be attenuated and protective in mice. In this study, several rMACVs expressing different domains of Cd#1 GPC were rescued and characterized. The rMACVs displayed different levels of attenuation and immunogenicity in mice. The results suggest that each domain of GPC plays an indispensable role in the full attenuation and immunogenicity of rMACV/Cd#1 GPC. The findings of this study may contribute to the development of effective vaccines and treatments for arenaviral hemorrhagic fevers.
Centromeric histone 3 variant, CENH3, is crucial for sister chromatid segregation during mitosis and meiosis. A study aimed to understand CENH3 functional constraints by complementing a null allele in Arabidopsis with various mutant alleles, each inducing a single amino acid change in conserved residues of the histone fold domain. Many transgenic missense lines displayed wild-type growth and fertility on self-pollination but exhibited post-zygotic death and uniparental inheritance when crossed with wild-type plants. This failure of centromeres marked by these missense mutations in the histone fold domain of CENH3 resembles the genome elimination syndromes described with chimeric CENH3 and CENH3 from diverged species. A single point mutation is sufficient to generate a haploid inducer, providing a simple one-step method for identifying non-transgenic haploid inducers in existing mutagenized collections of crop species. This method's simplicity and non-transgenic nature make it an attractive tool for haploid production in crops, which could accelerate trait mapping and plant breeding.
The role of alternative splicing in self-renewal, pluripotency, and tissue lineage specification of human embryonic stem cells (hESCs) is largely unknown. To address this, researchers modified the H9 hESC line to allow for the selection of pluripotent hESCs and cardiac progenitors using neomycin and puromycin resistance, respectively. Exon-level microarray expression data from undifferentiated hESCs and cardiac and neural precursors were used to identify splice isoforms with cardiac-restricted or common cardiac/neural differentiation expression patterns. These splice events corresponded to the pathways of cytoskeletal remodeling, RNA splicing, muscle specification, and cell cycle checkpoint control, as well as genes with serine/threonine kinase and helicase activity. A new program, AltAnalyze, was used to identify novel changes in protein domain and microRNA binding site architecture that were predicted to affect protein function and expression. These changes included an enrichment of splice isoforms that oppose cell-cycle arrest in hESCs and that promote calcium signaling and cardiac development in cardiac precursors. The findings suggest potential mechanisms that may influence lineage commitment and hESC maintenance at the level of specific splice isoforms and microRNA regulation.
Trehalose, a disaccharide found in various organisms, is crucial for the viability and virulence of several fungal, helminthic, and bacterial pathogens, including Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M. tuberculosis). This pathogen has three potential pathways for trehalose biosynthesis: OtsA-OtsB2, TreY-TreZ, and TreS. However, only the OtsA-OtsB2 and TreY-TreZ pathways are involved in trehalose production, with the OtsA-OtsB2 pathway being the dominant one. In this pathway, trehalose-6-phosphate (T6P) synthase OtsA generates T6P from glucose-6-phosphate and ADP/UDP-glucose, which is then dephosphorylated by T6P phosphatase OtsB2 into trehalose.OtsB2 is essential for M. tuberculosis growth, and its inhibition leads to T6P accumulation, which is toxic and triggers self-poisoning of cells. This accumulation upregulates more than 800 genes, primarily due to increased RNA stability from enhanced neutralization of toxins with ribonuclease activity. Blocking T6P production in a ΔotsA mutant eliminates OtsB2 essentiality. OtsB2's role in virulence has been shown in various pathogens, although it is not strictly required for viability in normal in vitro culture conditions like other organisms. In M. tuberculosis, a conditional otsB2 mutant was generated to assess the viability in a mouse infection model and the basis of OtsB2 essentiality.To test otsB2 essentiality, gene deletion was attempted in both wild-type and merodiploid strains. While the endogenous otsB2 gene was easily deleted in the merodiploid strain, gene deletion in the wild-type strain was unsuccessful, confirming otsB2's genetic essentiality. A conditional gene silencing system was then developed, resulting in a conditional mutant (c-otsB2-tet-on mutant) whose growth was strictly dependent on the presence of anhydrotetracycline (ATc). Silencing OtsB2 in this mutant resulted in a moderate killing of approximately 1.5 logs within 7 days. Trehalose supplementation could not prevent growth inhibition upon otsB2 silencing, proving that the lack of the pathway end product is not the basis of OtsB2 essentiality.T6P accumulation during otsB2 silencing was found to be toxic for M. tuberculosis, and inactivating the T6P synthase gene otsA in M. tuberculosis and generating an unmarked gene deletion mutant (ΔotsA (u)) abolished otsB2 essentiality. Exogenous T6P did not cause growth inhibition of M. tuberculosis WT or aggravate growth inhibition of the c-otsB2-tet-on mutant at low ATc concentrations. Deletion of the T6P phosphatase gene in various yeasts and filamentous fungi results in T6P accumulation; however, these fungal mutants could tolerate this phosphosugar relatively well and remained viable, unlike M. tuberculosis.
Chagas' disease, a life-threatening illness affecting 11-18 million people, is caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi and currently has limited treatments available. A promising new target for chemotherapeutic intervention is the essential T. cruzi proline racemase enzyme (TcPR), which catalyzes the stereoinversion of L- and D-proline and is critical for the intracellular differentiation of the parasite. Recent studies have shown that TcPR is also a potent host B-cell mitogen, contributing to parasite persistence and immune system evasion. The characterization of the conformational states of TcPR, which is necessary for understanding the molecular basis of the mitogenic B-cell response and developing new structure-based drug discovery, is inaccessible by standard molecular dynamics simulations. However, advanced accelerated molecular dynamics has been used to extend the effective simulation time and capture large-scale motions of functional relevance, revealing open TcPR conformations and transient binding pockets. The results of this study provide new insights for future drug discovery for Chagas' disease.
The iKO system is a versatile and efficient method for the reversible and inducible regulation of gene expression in mice, allowing for the target gene to be turned on and off at will by treating the mice with doxycycline. This system combines two genetically modified mouse lines: a KO line with a tetracycline-dependent transactivator replacing the endogenous target gene, and a line with a tetracycline-inducible cDNA of the target gene inserted into a tightly regulated genomic locus. This system allows for the high-throughput, large-scale, and cost-effective production of iKO mice, and can easily incorporate other techniques and adapt to a wide range of applications. The iKO system has been successfully used in a proof-of-concept study with the apolipoprotein E (ApoE) gene, demonstrating reversible switching of ApoE transcription, plasma cholesterol levels, and atherosclerosis progression and regression. This method addresses the common problem with traditional gene inactivation methods, where the gene of interest is usually mutated throughout the animal's life, leading to embryonic or neonatal lethality, developmental abnormalities, or compensatory adjustments that make it difficult to elucidate the function of the gene of interest.
"A study was conducted to analyze the genetic response of the placental environment to infection by two strains of the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, which causes Chagas disease and can be transmitted from mother to fetus. The two strains used were K98, a clone of the non-lethal myotropic CA-I strain (TcI), and VD, isolated from a case of congenital infection (TcVI). The study found that the ""Secretory Granule"" pathway was down-regulated in both infected groups, while ""Innate Immune Response"" and ""Response to Interferon-gamma"" were up-regulated in the VD infection but not in K98. Metabolic processes, transcription, and macromolecular transport were down-regulated in infected placentas, while certain signaling pathways had opposite regulation in VD and K98 groups. The VD strain showed a stronger tropism to the placental organ, suggesting living parasites. The study suggests that a strong immune response, parasite genotype-dependent, is developed in the placental environment to control infection and prevent congenital transmission. Congenital infection of T. cruzi remains a public health problem, and the different genotypes of T. cruzi may play an important role in congenital infection. Further studies are needed to understand the potential role of T. cruzi genotypes on pregnancy and congenital infection."
Sindbis virus (SINV) is a mosquito-borne virus that causes polyarthritis and rash, known as Ockelbo disease in Sweden and Pogosta disease in Finland. It occurs mainly in tropical and subtropical countries, but regularly reoccurring outbreaks have been reported in northern Europe, specifically in a 7-year cycle. However, this hypothesis is based solely on reported human cases, and an objective marker for outbreaks is needed. A study was conducted to evaluate mosquito abundance and SINV prevalence in vector mosquitoes from an endemic area in central Sweden. The study found that in 2002, the year of the hypothesized outbreak, there were significantly increased infection rates in both enzootic and bridge-vector mosquitoes. Sequence analysis showed that all isolates belonged to the SINV genotype I (SINV-I), and a local maintenance of four SINV-I clades in the River Dalälven floodplains over the years was revealed. The findings suggest that increased SINV-I prevalence in vector mosquitoes constitutes the most valuable outbreak marker for further scrutinizing the hypothesized seven-year cycle of SINV-I outbreaks and the mechanisms behind. SINV-I and WNV are ecologically similar, and mosquito surveillance and virus detection in mosquitoes have been suggested as the most reliable and cost-effective method for early WNV outbreak detection. In northern Europe, the first cases of SINV infections were observed in 1967 in Sweden and 1974 in Finland. A seven-year cycle of human SINV infections in northern Europe has been suggested, but the reporting of SINV cases appears to vary and the regulatory change in 1995 indicates that the authorities’ demand influences the reporting. Therefore, there is a need for an objective marker of SINV activity for further studies on the periodicity of outbreaks and for understanding the causes.
The neural circuits employ various strategies to encode information, and the interaction and integration of these mechanisms are not well understood. The locust olfactory system, where dense, transiently synchronized spike trains across ensembles of antenna lobe (AL) neurons are transformed into a sparse representation in the mushroom body (MB), is a well-studied preparation for investigating the interaction of multiple coding mechanisms. A form of plasticity may control and tune synaptic weights of inputs to the MB to ensure the specificity of KCs' responses to familiar or meaningful odors. Plasticity at the synapses between the AL and the MB efficiently regulates the delicate tuning necessary to selectively filter the intense AL oscillatory output and condense it to a sparse representation in the MB. Activity-dependent plasticity drives the observed specificity, reliability, and expected persistence of odor representations, suggesting a role for plasticity in information processing. This model makes a testable prediction about synaptic plasticity at AL-MB synapses. The oscillatory activity reflected in electroencephalogram (EEG) and local field potential (LFP) recordings has been associated with sensory processing and cognitive states in humans. The biophysical and network mechanisms underlying oscillatory activity in the brain have been well characterized and involve periodic coherent synchronization of neuronal assemblies. In the antenna lobe (AL) of the locust, oscillatory synchronization is a feature of population coding. During the presentation of an odorant, transiently synchronized, evolving ensembles of neurons are formed and together participate in the encoding of the odor. The significance of the AL's odor oscillatory coding scheme can be best understood by examining postsynaptic units that read the oscillatory output. In insects, these follower units include neurons in the mushroom body (MB), a structure known to be involved in the storage and retrieval of memory representations. A form of activity-dependent plasticity between AL and MB may provide the necessary fine-tuning for ensemble selection in the MB and enable the appropriate selection of coherent oscillatory signals, fundamental for reading the information contained across synchronized PN spike trains.
The Stockholm Atherosclerosis Gene Expression (STAGE) study aimed to identify functionally associated genes important for Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) using whole-genome expression profiles from multiple organs. The study used a two-way clustering approach, and analyzed a compendium of 278 global gene-expression profiles from five CAD-relevant tissues isolated during coronary artery bypass grafting. The results showed that there are groups of functionally associated genes (rather than individual genes) of importance for CAD and these groups of genes act in isolation in each tissue or across several tissues. The study identified an atherosclerosis module (A-module) that is important for atherosclerosis development and is genetically enriched with CAD risk by 1.8-fold. The A-module, together with LDB2, merits further attention in CAD research. Mapping of the human genome has led to new technologies for studying complex diseases such as CAD from a functional genomic perspective, and these technologies, combined with systems biology analyses, will pave the way for a more detailed understanding of the complexity underlying common disorders, leading to advancements in molecular diagnostics for early identification of disease and to identify central disease pathways for therapies tailored to specific disease mechanisms.
Molecular genetic studies in the circadian model organism Synechococcus have shown that the KaiC protein, a central component of the circadian clock in cyanobacteria, is involved in activating and repressing its own gene transcription. During a 24-hour period, KaiC hexamers go through different phospho-states during daytime. However, it is unclear which phospho-state of KaiC promotes kaiBC expression and which opposes transcriptional activation. A recent study analyzed various combinations of positive and negative transcriptional feedback regulation by introducing a combined TTFL/PTO model. Only a particular two-loop feedback mechanism out of 32 tested was able to reproduce existing experimental observations, including the effects of knockout or overexpression of kai genes. Threonine and double phosphorylated KaiC hexamers activate kaiBC transcription, while unphosphorylated KaiC hexamers suppress it. The model simulations suggest that the peak expression ratio of the positive and negative component of kaiBC expression is the main factor for how the different two-loop feedback models respond to removal or overexpression of kai genes. These findings contribute to a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying circadian rhythms in cyanobacteria and may have implications for understanding similar processes in other organisms.
The study investigates the distribution of HIV-2 reservoirs in antiretroviral-naive HIV-2 infected individuals from the ANRS-CO5 cohort. The study found that HIV-2 DNA was undetectable in monocytes from all individuals and was quantifiable in TTM from 4 individuals (median: 2.25 log10 copies/106 cells) but in TCM from only 1 individual (1.75 log10 copies/106 cells). HIV-2 DNA levels in PBMCs positively correlated with those in TTM (r = 0.66, p = 0.01) but not TCM. HIV-2 reactivation was observed in the cells from only 3 individuals. The CCR5 co-receptor was distributed similarly in cell populations from individuals and donors. TCM had a lower expression of CXCR6 transcripts (p = 0.002) than TTM confirmed by FACS analysis, and a higher expression of TRIM5 transcripts (p = 0.004). These findings suggest that the low HIV-2 reservoirs differ from HIV-1 reservoirs by the lack of monocytic infection and a limited infection of TCM associated with a lower expression of a potential alternative HIV-2 co-receptor, CXCR6 and a higher expression of a restriction factor, TRIM5. These findings shed new light on the low pathogenicity of HIV-2 infection, suggesting mechanisms close to those reported in other models of attenuated HIV/SIV infection models.
The Attentional Routing Circuit (ARC) is a neurally detailed, spiking neuron model that provides a unified explanation of various attentional effects and their underlying mechanisms in the cortex. It explains shrinking and shifting, but not amplitude changes of spatial receptive field (RF) profiles, increase of tuning curve gain without sharpening, and response gain effects in neuronal contrast-response functions. The model is implemented in spiking neurons and defines the relationship of attentional modulation across multiple cortical areas, quantitatively comparing it to physiological data and making specific, testable predictions. ARC utilizes top-down feedback signals for selective routing of attended visual stimuli in cortex, and defines this process at multiple levels, from a large scale network comprising multiple hierarchical cortical areas, to the laminar microcircuitry of cortical columns, and to the attentional modulation of single cells. The model begins with pulvinar projecting a global control signal that coarsely encodes the size and position of the attentional target to cortical control neurons. Local control signals specify the width and centre of the local Gaussian routing function for individual columns. Feedback projections from higher cortical areas terminate in layer-I upon the apical dendrites of layer-V intrinsically bursting (IB) pyramidal cells, relaying to dendrites in layer-I of the preceding area in the hierarchy and to the dendrites of nearby layer-VI pyramidal cells in the same column. Layer-V neurons determine the size of the target's representation in V4 and minimize the loss of information by having as many columns encode information from the target as possible, not more than encode the target in V1. Layer-V neurons compute the position of the target's representation in V4 and shift it to the centre of each level, taking advantage of the Gaussian sensitivity profile of visual cortical neurons. V4 columns will perform selective routing if the target spans more V1 columns or if its position is within columns of the target's centre in V4. Control neurons compute and project local control signals to visually responsive layer-IV neurons in their column, which receive inputs from a single dimension for contrast. Nonlinear dendrites gate feedforward visual signals based on local control signals, offering a significant computational advantage over classical point neuron models. Dendritic nonlinearities can be exploited to perform selective routing, significantly reducing the number of cells needed. The synaptic weights of layer-IV nonlinear dendritic subunits serve to approximate the routing function and determine the RF location from which visual signals should be selectively processed, modulating the gain of visual signals from input columns throughout its RF. The ARC model uses these computations between each level in an identical manner, employing 1400 spiking neurons per column to compute all of the described functions.
In a study of over 11,000 individuals, including both cases with atrial fibrillation (AF) and controls, no significant associations were found between AF and common genetic variants, including those located in coding regions. The study also examined the relationship between AF and rare genetic variants, but again, no significant associations were found. These findings suggest that large-effect coding variation is not the primary mechanism underlying AF, and that large sample sizes or populations enriched for large genetic effects may be necessary to identify biologically meaningful coding variation underlying AF. Future research should integrate both coding and noncoding variation, such as through whole genome sequencing, in order to better understand the genetic contributions to AF. It is important to note that the study was predominantly comprised of individuals of European ancestry, and therefore the findings may not be generalizable to other ancestral groups. Additionally, the study had limited power to assess the role of many coding variants, particularly due to the challenges of classifying missense variants as pathogenic or not. Overall, the study provides further evidence that coding variation is not a major contributor to AF in individuals of European ancestry.
Alveolar echinococcosis (AE) is a dangerous disease caused by Echinococcus multilocularis infections, primarily in the Northern Hemisphere. This paper analyzed data on human AE in Poland over the last two decades, using both registered cases and those from active field and laboratory surveillance. A total of 121 human cases of AE were detected, with 68.6% classified as confirmed, 13.2% as probable, and 18.2% as possible. The detection rate of AE has continuously increased, with cases occurring in patients aged 6-82 years (mean: 47.7 years). The sex ratio (M/F) was 0.86/1, and AE was fatal in 19% of patients (mean age at death: 54.1 years). Seventy-six cases were diagnosed in an advanced stage of the disease, and in all cases, the liver was the primary location of AE. Thirty patients had a spread of the disease to other organs. Ninety-four patients were treated with albendazole, and 73 underwent surgical operations, including 15 liver transplantations.The study indicates that AE is an emerging disease in Poland, which is the fourth country in Europe with over 120 cases detected. The results also highlight the need for a wider national program for implementing screening in the highest AE risk areas with efforts to increase public awareness of the possibility of contracting E. multilocularis and train primary care physicians in recognizing the risk of AE. Moreover, an early detection of this disease is crucial for effective treatment and reducing its fatality rate.
The study investigates the molecular mechanism of the zinc-sensing zinc uptake regulator (Zur) protein in Escherichia coli and its role in regulating genes in response to changes in zinc availability. The research reveals that Zur represses gene expression by binding to two adjacent dimers that essentially encircle the core element of each of the Zur-regulated promoters. The binding is cooperative and requires a pair of asymmetric salt bridges between Arg52 and Asp49' that connect otherwise independent dimers. The study also identifies a new member of the Zur-regulon, pliG, and demonstrates its direct regulation by Zur in a zinc-responsive manner. The pliG promoter forms stable complexes with either one or two Zur dimers with significantly less protein-DNA cooperativity than observed at other Zur regulon promoters. The study also finds that the number of Fur-family dimers that bind within any given promoter varies significantly and that the thermodynamic profile of the Zur-DNA interactions directly correlates with the physiological response at different promoters. The research highlights the importance of zinc in colonization by both beneficial enteric bacterial species and infection by pathogenic microorganisms, and the role of metalloregulatory proteins in responding to changes in metal concentration in the immediate environment. The study provides a comprehensive view of differential expression patterns in the Zur regulon and demonstrates the predictive value of a combined structure/thermodynamic/bioinformatic approach in identifying new Zur-regulated genes.
Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a vector-borne zoonotic disease that causes significant morbidity and mortality in ruminants. In 2008-2009, an outbreak of RVF affected the entire Madagascar island, including the Anjozorobe district located in the Madagascar highlands. An entomological survey found no evidence of Aedes mosquitoes, which are responsible for transmitting RVF, in this area. Additionally, there was an overall low abundance of mosquitoes due to unfavorable climatic conditions during winter. No serological or virological signs of infection were observed in wild terrestrial mammals, suggesting an absence of a wild RVF virus (RFVV) reservoir. However, a three-year serological and virological follow-up in cattle showed a recurrent RVFV circulation. A spatial deterministic discrete-time metapopulation model was used to understand the key determinants of this unexpected recurrent transmission. The model incorporated a low level RVFV winter vector-borne transmission and a direct transmission between animals when viraemic cows calve. Predictions from the model satisfactorily reproduced field observations, with 84% of cattle infections attributed to vector-borne transmission, and 16% to direct transmission. These results appeared robust according to the sensitivity analysis. Interweaving between agricultural works in rice fields, seasonality of vector proliferation, and cattle exchange practices could be a key element for understanding RVFV circulation in this area of Madagascar highlands.
In the past century, human movement and globalization of trade have led to the establishment of invasive mosquito species in new geographic locations, with significant environmental, economic, and health consequences. The Asian tiger mosquito, Aedes albopictus, is an invasive and aggressive daytime-biting mosquito that poses a major public health threat in its expanding range. A study used 13 nuclear microsatellite loci and mitochondrial COI sequences to understand the historical and contemporary movements of Ae. albopictus in the Indo-Pacific region and characterize its population structure. Approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) was employed to test competing historical routes of invasion of Ae. albopictus within the Southeast (SE) Asian/Australasian region. The analysis showed that Ae. albopictus was most likely introduced to New Guinea via mainland SE Asia, before colonizing the Solomon Islands via either Papua New Guinea or SE Asia. The recent incursion into northern Australia’s Torres Strait Islands was chiefly from Indonesia. The study provides evidence of a recently colonized population (the Torres Strait Islands) that has undergone rapid temporal changes in its genetic makeup, which could be the result of genetic drift or represent a secondary invasion from an unknown source. The species' genetic structure in the region tends to favor a dispersal pattern driven mostly by human movements. The study's importance lies in its more widespread sampling distribution of the species’ native range, revealing more spatial population structure than previously shown and presenting the most probable invasion history of this species in the Australasian region using ABC analysis.
This study investigated the impact of Schistosoma mansoni (S. mansoni) infection on the physical health and quality of life of 572 schoolchildren in Tanzania. The prevalence of S. mansoni infection was 58.7%, with higher intensities in girls. Most infections were light, but 16.4% of the children had heavy infections. There was no association between S. mansoni prevalence or intensities and anthropometry, anemia, or liver or spleen pathology. However, infected children had a significantly lower score in emotional PedsQL, a measure of quality of life, compared to uninfected children. In multivariable regression analyses, S. mansoni infection, along with age, haemoglobin, and VO2 max, were significant predictors for emotional PedsQL. The study suggests that S. mansoni infection has a significant effect on the emotional dimension of quality of life, but not on physical fitness. The authors recommend refining tools to measure schistosome-related morbidity to focus on aspects of quality of life affected by the infection. Schistosomiasis is a major public health problem in Sub-Saharan Africa, with over 80% of cases in the region, including 19 million cases in Tanzania. The study highlights the need for interventions to control and prevent the spread of schistosomiasis in this region.
Leptospirosis is a worldwide zoonosis caused by the spirochete Leptospira, with wild rodents such as the brown rat being the main reservoirs. A study was conducted to compare the effects of subcutaneous and mucosal inoculation routes to the reference intraperitoneal route during Leptospira infection in adult rats. The results showed that Leptospira infection was asymptomatic using each inoculation route and caused similar antibody production regardless of renal colonization. The observed renal colonization rates were 8 out of 8 rats, 5 out of 8 rats and 1 out of 8 rats for the intraperitoneal, mucosal and subcutaneous inoculation routes, respectively. Therefore, mucosal inoculation was found to be more efficient for renal colonization associated with urinary excretion than the subcutaneous route and induced a slower-progressing infection than the intraperitoneal route. This knowledge can help understand the infection modalities in rats and improve the investigation of infection kinetics in future studies.
Sepsis is a severe and potentially life-threatening condition that can cause organ dysfunction and failure. Currently, there are limited treatment options available for sepsis, making it a significant global health concern. A new study has identified a novel role for Annexin A2 (AnxA2) in inhibiting the pro-inflammatory response during sepsis. In a cecal ligation and puncture (CLP) sepsis model, mice without the AnxA2 gene (anxa2-/- mice) had increased pro-inflammatory cytokines and neutrophil infiltration, but decreased bacterial clearance and animal survival. Additionally, AnxA2 deficiency led to increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) and IL-17A. The study found that cysteine 9 of AnxA2 was the most important amino acid for the regulation of ROS levels, which is responsible for elevated IL-17A levels and subsequently exaggerated inflammatory response. Depletion of IL-17 via CRISPR/Cas9 KO strategy down-regulated inflammation and conferred protection against sepsis in anxa2-/- mice. These findings reveal a previously undemonstrated function for AnxA2 in inflammatory response in polymicrobial sepsis models via an AnxA2-ROS-IL-17 axis, providing insight into the regulation of pathophysiology of sepsis.
HIV-1 infection of macrophages plays a significant role in the progression of AIDS, and the underlying mechanisms of HIV-1 infection in monocyte-derived macrophages (MDMs) are not well understood. Researchers have found that polyinosine-polycytidylic acid (poly(I:C)) and bacterial lipopolysaccharide (LPS), ligands for Toll-like receptors (TLR) 3 and TLR4, decrease HIV-1 infection in MDMs. However, the specific mechanisms by which this occurs are not fully understood. In this study, researchers aimed to understand the role of TLR3 and TLR4 in suppressing HIV-1 infection in MDMs.The researchers found that poly(I:C) and LPS stimulation of MDMs suppressed infection by CCR5-using, macrophage-tropic HIV-1 and by vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein-pseudotyped HIV-1 virions. However, TLR2, TLR7, or TLR9 agonists only partially reduced infection. The suppression of infection did not correlate with differential effects on CD4 or CCR5 expression, type I interferon induction, or production of pro-inflammatory cytokines or β-chemokines. Integrated pro-viruses were readily detected in unstimulated, TLR7- and TLR9-stimulated cells, but not in TLR3- or TLR4-stimulated MDMs, suggesting an alteration of post-entry, pre-integration events.Microarray analysis and quantitative reverse transcription (RT)-PCR revealed increased microRNA (miR) -155 levels in MDMs upon TLR3/4- but not TLR7-stimulation. A miR-155 specific inhibitor partially restored infectivity in poly(I:C)-stimulated MDMs, while ectopic miR-155 expression remarkably diminished HIV-1 infection in primary MDMs and cell lines. Furthermore, poly(I:C)-stimulation and ectopic miR-155 expression did not alter detection of early viral RT products but both resulted in an accumulation of late RT products and in undetectable or extremely low levels of integrated pro-viruses and 2-LTR circles. Reduced mRNA and protein levels of several HIV-1 dependency factors involved in trafficking and/or nuclear import of pre-integration complexes (ADAM10, TNPO3, Nup153, LEDGF/p75) were found in poly(I:C)-stimulated and miR-155-transfected MDMs, and a reporter assay suggested they are authentic miR-155 targets.In conclusion, the study provides evidence that miR-155 exerts an anti-HIV-1 effect by targeting several HIV-1 dependency factors involved in post-entry, pre-integration events, leading to severely diminished HIV-1 infection. These findings have important implications for understanding the role of miR-155 in the immune response to HIV-1 infection and suggest that miR-155 may be a potential target for the development of HIV-1 therapeutics.
The growth of embryonic stems in plants, also known as hypocotyls, is influenced by external photoperiod and the internal circadian clock, with maximum growth rates occurring at specific times of the day. A study investigating the molecular mechanisms controlling this growth found that a group of plant hormone-associated genes are coexpressed at the time of day when hypocotyl growth rate is maximal, and this expression correlates with overrepresentation of a cis-acting element (CACATG) in phytohormone gene promoters. Using circadian clock and light signaling mutants, the study showed that both internal coincidence of phytohormone signaling capacity and external coincidence with darkness are required to coordinate wild-type growth. The circadian clock indirectly controls growth by permissive gating of light-mediated phytohormone transcript levels to the proper time of day, allowing for temporal integration of hormone pathways for seasonal and shade-appropriate growth regulation. This temporal integration of hormone pathways allows plants to fine-tune phytohormone responses for optimal body plan in a particular environment. Phytohormone levels vary over the course of the day, and the circadian clock and light/dark cycles interact to control daily hypocotyl growth through the activity of transcription factors such as phytochrome interacting factor 4 (PIF4) and PIF5. However, the mechanisms defining the relationship between the circadian clock, light signaling, and phytohormone-controlled growth remain unclear. Organisms have evolved circadian clocks with internal periods of about 24 hours that allow synchrony with their external environment, and plants with circadian period lengths that match that of their environment display enhanced fitness. A temporal integration of a transcriptional component of the phytohormone pathways could be part of the specificity and redundancy in how the circadian clock indirectly controls growth by maintaining light signaling during the early part of the evening, ensuring that peak phytohormone transcript abundance coincides with the end of the dark period. This findings provide a framework for understanding how seedlings transition from dark-dependent to light-dependent growth after germination and respond appropriately to both acute and long-term changes in the light environment.
RNA interference (RNAi) technologies have been suggested for insect control, including for vectors of Chagas disease such as Rhodnius prolixus. A sustainable approach for vector control involves modifying the insect microbiota to deliver RNAi molecules to the gut. In this context, Escherichia coli HT115 (DE3) expressing dsRNA for the Rhodnius heme-binding protein (RHBP) and catalase (CAT) were fed to nymphs and adult triatomine stages. RHBP is an egg protein and CAT is an antioxidant enzyme expressed in all tissues and stages. Feeding with E. coli HT115 (DE3) resulted in systemic and temporal RNAi effects. Concentrations above 3.35 × 107 CFU/mL led to significant RHBP and CAT gene knockdown in nymphs and adults. Mortality rates of first instars increased by 24-30% after feeding on RHBP and CAT bacteria. Molting rates were reduced by 100% in first instars and 80% in third instars fed bacteria producing RHBP or CAT dsRNA. Oviposition was reduced by 43% (RHBP) and 84% (CAT), and embryogenesis was arrested in 16% (RHBP) and 20% (CAT) of laid eggs. Feeding females with the natural symbiont Rhodococcus rhodnii transformed to express RHBP-specific hairpin RNA reduced RHBP expression by 89% and reduced oviposition. Therefore, modifying the insect microbiota to induce systemic RNAi in R. prolixus may result in a paratransgenic strategy for sustainable vector control. Oral delivery of dsRNA has been proposed as a method to control insect pests and diseases transmitted by mosquitoes. Similar strategies have been explored for termites, fruit flies, flour beetles, pea aphids, tobacco hornworms, and honeybees, with variable efficacy, suggesting that each species and gene may behave differently. Nonetheless, these studies suggest that oral delivery of dsRNA may provide a method to control disease vectors.
Fever during pregnancy can be dangerous for both the mother and the fetus, and in the past, malaria was a leading cause of death for pregnant women in refugee camps on the Thai-Burmese border. However, the incidence of malaria has been significantly reduced by artemisinin combination therapy. The causes of fever during pregnancy in these areas are not well documented, and pregnant women with fever were invited to participate in a study where they received comprehensive clinical and laboratory screens. The study found that arthropod-borne and zoonotic diseases accounted for nearly half of all febrile illnesses in pregnant women, with scrub and murine typhus being important causes of fever associated with poor pregnancy outcomes. Once malaria, pyelonephritis, and acute respiratory infections were excluded, one-third of the remaining febrile infections were caused by rickettsia or leptospirosis. The study concludes that febrile pregnant women who do not have malaria, pyelonephritis, or respiratory tract infections should be treated with azithromycin, which is effective against typhus and leptospirosis. A better understanding of the causes of fever in pregnancy in resource-poor populations is needed to reduce maternal and neonatal morbidity and mortality.
A study investigating the relationship between maternal age and recombination rate in humans analyzed over 600,000 markers in a panel of 69 French-Canadian pedigrees, revealing recombination events in 195 maternal meioses. The study found a significant decrease in recombination rates with advancing maternal age, particularly in the middle section of chromosomal arms and near subtelomeric regions, likely driven by chromosome-specific effects. This decline in recombination rate may increase the risk of chromosomal non-disjunction and aneuploidy in older women. These findings suggest a model where the protective effect of recombination against non-disjunction becomes less efficient with advancing maternal age for certain chromosomes.
A new experimental immunization strategy has been developed to induce innate memory in macrophages, resulting in complete protection against secondary challenge even in the absence of adaptive immune cells. This strategy involves the use of an in vivo fungal vaccine model that delivers interferon-γ (IFN-γ), which has been shown to protect against disease in vaccinated B cell-deficient mice and CD4+/CD8+ T cell-depleted mice. Further investigation revealed that protective immunity is achieved through the establishment of antigen-specific innate memory-like responses in macrophages, resulting in enhanced antigen-specific cytokine recall responses and increased STAT1 binding to promoter regions of genes associated with protective anti-fungal immunity. These findings highlight the potential of developing vaccines that enhance innate immune responses as a promising approach for protecting immunocompromised individuals against diseases that target this population.
Polycomb repressive complexes (PRCs) are crucial for transcriptional repression and developmental regulation in both plants and animals. In plants, different PRC components cause overlapping and unique phenotypic defects, but the molecular mechanisms determining their target specificity and functional diversity are not well understood. A recent study quantitatively compared changes of H3K27 tri-methylation in Arabidopsis mutants deprived of various key PRC components. The study found that CURLY LEAF (CLF), a major catalytic subunit of PRC2, coordinates with different members of PRC1 in suppressing distinct plant developmental programs. The expression of flower development genes is repressed in seedlings preferentially via a non-redundant role of CLF, which specifically associates with LIKE HETEROCHROMATIN PROTEIN1 (LHP1). In contrast, the expression of embryo development genes is repressed by PRC1-catalytic core subunits AtBMI1 and AtRING1 in common with PRC2-catalytic enzymes CLF or SWINGER (SWN). This context-dependent role of CLF corresponds well with the change in H3K27me3 profiles and is associated with differential co-occupancy of binding motifs of transcription factors (TFs), including MADS box and ABA-related factors.The study suggests that different combinations of PRC members distinctively regulate different developmental programs, and their target specificity is modulated by specific TFs. The evolutionarily conserved Polycomb group proteins (PcGs) are the major epigenetic machinery regulating differentiation and development. PcGs mediate repression by establishing and maintaining epigenetic modifications surrounding target genes. In both plants and animals, PcGs are classified into two major multi-protein complexes, PRC1 and PRC2, which participate in transcriptional repression by catalyzing H3K27 tri-methylation and H2A ubiquitination, respectively. Depletion of various PcG components in plants leads to varied developmental defects, and the functional specificity of PcGs is established through several mechanisms.The majority of PcG components are ubiquitously expressed and do not have sequence-specific DNA recognition properties. Members of PcGs generally have functional redundancy and diversity, and it is difficult to distinguish the specific effect of individual members. Plants are advantageous for studying the effect of PcGs in development since most plant PcG mutants are viable, while animal development is generally vulnerable to PcG mutations. Previous efforts in genetic dissection of PcG functions provide important clues as to the specialized functions of PcG members. For example, CURLY LEAF (CLF) and SWINGER (SWN) are two highly similar enzymatic subunits of the PRC2 complex and play redundant roles in plant development as double mutants. However, this redundancy is partial, as SWN cannot rescue the phenotypic defects upon loss of CLF, including early flowering and curly leaf.Similarly, lack of either AtRING1 or AtBMI1, the core catalytic factors of PRC1, leads to depression of embryonic traits in seedlings, while only the atring1a atring1b double mutant displays severely fused flower phenotypes. Additionally, LHP1, a PRC1 component capable of interacting with both PRC1 components AtBMI1 and AtRING1 in vitro, displays some similar phenotypic defects to those of the PRC2 mutant clf and co-purifies with the PRC2 complex. Studies on different loci have led to different conclusions on the interplay between PRC1 and PRC2, including their orders of recruitment into the corresponding complexes. It seems that different PcGs tend to repress specific gene sets with distinct functions. However, target genes and the mechanisms of specificity for different PcGs are not sufficiently characterized, particularly from a genome-wide point of view.Multiple mechanisms have been proposed in Arabidopsis to explain the target specificity of PcGs, including specific recruitment of PcGs by diverse strategies for transcription repression and selective displacement of PcGs by some transcription factors for transcription de-repression during developmental transitions. However, most of these proposed mechanisms are based on studies of some specific genes without an overview
"The study focuses on the active site of RNA polymerase II, specifically the ""trigger loop"" (TL) that is crucial for substrate selection, catalysis, and translocation. The researchers examined nearly all TL single variants of Saccharomyces cerevisiae RNA polymerase II using a structural genetics approach that combines structural and phenotypic data for high-resolution dissection of transcription mechanisms and their evolution. They identified three mutant classes with distinct distributions among TL residues, associated with transcription defects or various stresses. Mutations disrupting an intra-TL hydrophobic pocket resulted in pocket disruption and increased catalysis. Genetic interactions support the contribution of the funnel and bridge helices to TL dynamics. This approach provides a framework for understanding the mechanisms of other essential yeast proteins. The TL is highly conserved, and its mutations can cause fitness defects and alterations in transcription elongation rates, making it a potential target for regulation."
Rabies is a deadly CNS disease in mammals, caused by the rabies virus (RV), a neurotropic lyssavirus from the rhabdoviridae family. RV is typically transmitted by scratches or bites from rabid animals, resulting in the dissemination of virions into skin and muscle tissue. After initial infection of cells at the infection site, RV enters axon terminals and migrates by retrograde axonal transport into the CNS, where it causes a lethal encephalopathy. The incubation period can vary from days to years. While it is known that RV spreads from the infection site to the CNS via retrograde transport within the neuronal network, a potential hematogenous spread from the site of infection directly to the brain after accidental spill over into the vascular system has been suggested but its relevance is unknown. To investigate this, mice were inoculated with the dog-associated RV DOG4 or the silver-haired bat-associated RV SB, either intramuscularly or intravenously. The progression of clinical signs of rabies and the spread of the virus from the infection site to the brain were monitored using immunohistochemistry and quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction. The results showed that hematogenous spread of SB can lead to a fatal encephalopathy through direct retrograde invasion of the CNS at the neurovascular interface of the hypothalamus-hypophysis system. This alternative mode of virus spread has implications for the post-exposure prophylaxis of rabies, particularly with silver-haired bat-associated RV.
The H1N1 subtype of influenza A virus has caused significant morbidity and mortality in humans, with notable epidemics of unusual severity in the 1940s and 1950s. A study using 71 complete genome sequences of H1N1 viruses from 1918 to 2006 found that segmental reassortment has played an important role in its genomic evolution.
