The transmission and distribution of these viruses are influenced by factors affecting host populations, with landscape structure playing a significant role. A study in the Atlantic Forest of South America used 283 rodent capture records and geographically weighted models to investigate the relationship between hantavirus host proportions and landscape structure. The study found that hantavirus host proportions were more positively influenced by landscape diversity than by a particular habitat or agricultural matrix type. Local small mammal diversity positively influenced known pathogenic hantavirus host proportions, indicating that habitat plasticity may be more important for these hosts than competition with native forest dwelling species. The study also found that non-defaunated areas can be hotspots for hantavirus disease outbreaks, with sugarcane and tree plantations correlating with higher proportions of rodent hosts. These findings suggest that disease surveillance must be reinforced in the southern and southeastern regions of the biome where the highest predicted hantavirus host proportion and levels of vulnerability spatially match. The study highlights the complex rodent community dynamics and interactions with human disease, providing important insights for developing effective hantavirus surveillance and control strategies.
BCL2 family proteins, including pro-survival proteins like BCLXL, BH3-only proteins, and BAX/BAK proteins, control mitochondria-mediated apoptosis to maintain cell homeostasis by eliminating damaged and infected cells. This study investigated the role of BCL2 proteins during apoptosis in cells infected with flaviviruses, such as Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), Dengue virus (DENV), and Zika virus (ZIKV). The results showed that cell survival upon flavivirus infection depended on BCLXL due to the suppression of MCL1 expression, another pro-survival protein. Treatment with BCLXL inhibitors and deficient BCLXL gene expression induced BAX/BAK-dependent apoptosis in infected cells. Flavivirus infection reduced cellular protein synthesis, including short-half-life proteins like MCL1. BCLXL inhibition increased phagocytosis of virus-infected cells by macrophages, suppressing viral dissemination and chemokine production. Haploinsufficiency of the BCLXL gene and administration of BH3 mimetic compounds increased survival rate and suppressed inflammation during JEV infection. Therefore, BCLXL plays a crucial role in the survival of cells infected with flaviviruses and may provide a novel antiviral target. Flaviviruses, belonging to the Flaviviridae family, are internalized into dendritic cells and keratinocytes, activating and inducing visceral and central nervous system diseases. Infection with flaviviruses induces apoptosis, necrosis, pyroptosis, and necroptosis, including RIPK3-mediated cell death and IL-1β production and pyroptosis in DENV and HCV infections. BCL2 family proteins, specifically BH3-only proteins, regulate mitochondria-mediated apoptosis. Small molecule inhibitors have been developed for cancer therapy, targeting BCL2, BCLXL, and BCLW, with therapeutic uses for 17p-deleted chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
The global economic impact of canine rabies has been estimated to be significant, with Asia bearing a disproportionate burden due to high levels of human deaths and rates of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), but low investment in preventative dog vaccination. A study focused on Vietnam estimated the economic burden of canine rabies over a ten-year period (2005-2014) using data from personal interviews, published literature, reports, and primary data collection. The study incorporated direct and indirect costs of rabies in dogs, livestock, and humans, including PEP-related costs, dog vaccination efforts, livestock losses, and disability-adjusted life years (DALYs). Over the ten-year study period, the total economic impact of canine rabies in Vietnam was over $719 million, with 92% of impacts attributed to PEP-related costs. Canine rabies created between 36,560 and 45,700 DALYs, measured in years of life lost (YLL). A total of 914 human deaths were reported over the study period. Deaths/100,000 people were 0.11, which is lower than the reported level for Asian countries. The cost per dog vaccinated was $1.75 USD. The results indicate that canine rabies impacts in Vietnam are consistent with the burden elsewhere reported in Asia, with large expenditures on PEP and very small investments in dog vaccination. Canine rabies is an economically unique zoonosis, as most of its associated costs do not result from illness in the infected individual but rather are the consequences of human deaths and efforts to prevent the disease in humans, livestock, and companion animals.
The Type II Secretion System (T2SS) is a molecular machine in bacteria that secretes fully-folded protein substrates across the outer membrane, aided by the secretin pore formed by an integral multimeric outer membrane protein. Three distinct forms of T2SSs can be identified based on the sequence characteristics of their secretin pores. Detailed comparative analysis of two of these, the Klebsiella-type and Vibrio-type, reveals differences in their pilotins, which mediate transport and assembly into the outer membrane. AspS, a novel pilotin from Vibrio cholerae, is functionally equivalent but structurally unrelated to other bacterial pilotins, demonstrating convergent evolution. AspS binds to a specific targeting sequence in Vibrio-type secretins, enhancing the kinetics of secretin assembly. Homologs of AspS are found in all Vibrio species and some strains of Escherichia and Shigella that have acquired a Vibrio-type T2SS. Bacterial outer membranes incorporate proteins of at least three well-characterized architectures: β-barrel proteins, lipoproteins, and secretins. Lipoproteins are inserted into the outer membrane by the receptor LolB after being ferried across the periplasm by factors of the Lol machinery, while secretins are integral proteins that assemble to form multimeric secretion channels in the outer membrane. In the case of the T2SS, the secretin multimer in the outer membrane docks onto a platform of inner membrane proteins that energize its function in the selection and/or secretion of substrate proteins across the outer membrane into the external milieu.
Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by pathogenic Leptospira spp., typically transmitted to humans through water contaminated by infected animals. The bacteria can persist in freshwater or soil and enter the host through skin abrasions or mucous membranes, causing symptoms such as jaundice, renal failure, and pulmonary hemorrhage. The disease has a significant impact on public health and agriculture worldwide.In this study, the functional roles of transmembrane outer membrane proteins OmpL36, OmpL37, and OmpL47 in Leptospira infection were investigated. The results showed that OmpL37 binds specifically to host tissue components, including human skin and aorta elastin, fibrinogen, fibrinogen fragment D, and plasma fibronectin. The binding of OmpL37 to skin elastin is specifically enhanced by rabbit antiserum for OmpL37, suggesting the involvement of OmpL37 in leptospiral binding to elastin and the possibility that host-generated antibodies may promote rather than inhibit the adherence of leptospires to elastin-rich tissues. OmpL37 is also recognized by acute and convalescent leptospirosis patient sera and by Leptospira-infected hamster sera, and its protein is detected in pathogenic Leptospira serovars but not in saprophytic Leptospira.These findings suggest that OmpL37 is a novel elastin-binding protein of pathogenic Leptospira that may be promoting attachment of Leptospira to host tissues. The elucidation of novel mediators of host-pathogen interaction, such as OmpL37, is important for the discovery of virulence factors involved in the pathogenesis of leptospirosis and the development of diagnostic and protective antigens for the disease.
A few broadly neutralizing antibodies have been isolated from HIV-1 infected individuals that recognize epitopes in the membrane proximal external region (MPER) of gp4
A longitudinal study was conducted in three hyperendemic onchocerciasis foci in Mali and Senegal, where annual or six-monthly ivermectin treatment had been given for 15 to 17 years, to assess residual levels of infection and transmission after stopping treatment. The study found that in two of the sites, the prevalence of microfilaria and vector infectivity rate were zero 3 to 4 years after the last treatment. In the third site, where infection levels were comparatively high before stopping treatment, there was also a consistent decline in infection and transmission to very low levels 3 to 5 years after stopping treatment. All infection and transmission indicators were below postulated thresholds for elimination. The study has established the proof of principle that onchocerciasis elimination with ivermectin treatment is feasible in at least some endemic foci in Africa, and the results have been instrumental in the current evolution from onchocerciasis control to elimination in Africa. Onchocerciasis control in Africa is currently nearly exclusively based on large-scale treatment with ivermectin, and the African Programme for Onchocerciasis Control (APOC) and the Onchocerciasis Control Programme in West Africa (OCP) have been established to support the establishment of community-directed treatment with ivermectin (CDTi) in all areas where onchocerciasis is a public health problem. These programs have been successful in ensuring sustained high treatment coverage and by the year 2010, some 75 million people at risk were treated annually with ivermectin in the APOC countries. The study was conducted in three onchocerciasis endemic foci along the River Bakoye in Mali, the River Gambia in Senegal, and the River Faleme on the border of the two countries. Skin snip surveys, transmission monitoring, and entomological evaluations were conducted in these areas. The results showed a declining trend in infection and transmission levels after the last treatment. In two sites, the prevalence of microfilaria and vector infectivity rate were zero 3 to 4 years after the last treatment. In the third site, there was also a consistent decline in infection and transmission to very low levels 3 to 5 years after stopping treatment. The study has established the proof of principle that onchocerciasis elimination with ivermectin treatment is feasible in at least some endemic foci in Africa.
The common cold is caused by human rhinovirus (HRV), a non-enveloped virus of the picornavirus family, which includes poliovirus and foot-and-mouth disease virus. During HRV cell entry, the small myristoylated capsid protein VP4 is released and interacts with the cell membrane, delivering the viral RNA genome into the cytoplasm. A study produced recombinant C-terminal histidine-tagged human rhinovirus VP4 and showed that it can induce membrane permeability in liposome model membranes by forming a multimeric membrane pore, allowing for the transfer of the single-stranded RNA genome. The membrane permeability induced by VP4 was comparable to permeability induced by infectious virions. This finding provides a model system for exploring VP4 as a novel antiviral target for the picornavirus family. Understanding the mechanisms used by non-enveloped viruses like HRV to deliver their genomes into cells is crucial for the development of new antiviral measures, as there is currently no vaccine or licensed drug to prevent or reduce HRV infection.
Francisella tularensis, the causative agent of tularemia, is a highly infectious Gram-negative bacterium and a select agent designated by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. F. tularensis subspecies novicida (Fn) lipid A has a similar structure to human clinical isolates of F. tularensis, and three enzymes responsible for its carbohydrate modifications were identified. Mutants lacking galactosamine (flmF2) or galactosamine/mannose (flmK) addition to their lipid A were attenuated in mice. These mutants provided protection against challenge with wild-type (WT) Fn when administered either pulmonary or subcutaneously. Infection with the flmK mutant induced higher levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines, including TNF-α, MIP-2, and IL-6, which are mediated by the MyD88 signaling pathway. MyD88−/− mice, which lack a critical adaptor protein in the TLR signaling pathway, were susceptible to flmK mutant infection. The findings suggest that the ability of the flmK mutant to activate pro-inflammatory cytokine/chemokine production and innate immune responses mediated by the MyD88 signaling pathway may be responsible for its attenuation and the induction of protective immunity.
Ribosome assembly cofactors, including the ribosome-associated GTPases (RA-GTPase) widely conserved across all domains of life, coordinate ribosome assembly. In Staphylococcus aureus, the RA-GTPase Era, though non-essential, is crucial for 30S ribosomal subunit assembly and rRNA processing, particularly at suboptimal temperatures. Era interacts with the 16S rRNA endonuclease YbeY and DEAD-box RNA helicase CshA. Both Era and CshA are required for growth at suboptimal temperatures and rRNA processing, and they interact with the (p) ppGpp synthetase RelSau, impacting their respective activities. In its GTP-bound form, Era acts as a hub protein on the ribosome, directing enzymes involved in rRNA processing/degradation and ribosome subunit assembly to their site of action. The stringent response of S. aureus impedes this activity, causing a slowed growth phenotype during this stress response pathway.
In this study, the role of nitric oxide synthases (NOS) in the pathogenesis of Anthrax lethal toxin (LT) was investigated. The research found that neuronal nitric oxide synthase (nNOS) deficiency in mice caused increased sensitivity to LT, while deficiencies in the other two NOS enzymes (iNOS and eNOS) had no effect on LT-mediated mortality. This increased sensitivity of nNOS−/− mice was independent of macrophage sensitivity to toxin or cytokine responses. Histopathological analyses showed that LT induced architectural changes in heart morphology of nNOS−/− mice, with rapid appearance of novel inter-fiber spaces but no associated apoptosis of cardiomyocytes. LT-treated WT mice had no histopathology observed at the light microscopy level. Electron microscopic analyses of LT-treated mice, however, revealed striking pathological changes in the hearts of both nNOS−/− and WT mice, varying only in severity and timing. Endothelial/capillary necrosis and degeneration, inter-myocyte edema, myofilament and mitochondrial degeneration, and altered sarcoplasmic reticulum cisternae were observed in both LT-treated WT and nNOS−/− mice. Furthermore, multiple biomarkers of cardiac injury (myoglobin, cardiac troponin-I, and heart fatty acid binding protein) were elevated in LT-treated mice very rapidly and reached concentrations rarely reported in mice. Cardiac protective nitrite therapy and allopurinol therapy did not have beneficial effects in LT-treated mice. Surprisingly, the potent nitric oxide scavenger, carboxy-PTIO, showed some protective effect against LT. Echocardiography on LT-treated mice indicated an average reduction in ejection fraction following LT treatment in both nNOS−/− and WT mice, indicative of decreased contractile function in the heart. The heart was identified as an early target of LT in mice and nNOS was discussed to have a protective role against LT-mediated cardiac damage.
Parasitic nematodes infect over 1 billion people worldwide, causing significant disease burden. However, understanding of their biology has been limited by the lack of genetic intervention tools, particularly the ability to generate targeted gene disruptions and mutant phenotypes. The CRISPR-Cas9 system has been used in various organisms for targeted mutagenesis, but not in parasitic nematodes due to challenges such as low tolerance for exogenous DNA or protein, labor-intensive and low-efficiency delivery methods, and inaccessibility of host-dwelling life stages. The human-parasitic threadworm Strongyloides stercoralis is a powerful model for studying parasitic nematode biology, with a free-living generation that can be used for transgenesis techniques adapted from Caenorhabditis elegans. Researchers have now developed a method for introducing CRISPR-Cas9-mediated gene disruptions in S. stercoralis, resulting in nematodes with motility defects. This breakthrough enables future studies of gene function in these medically relevant but previously genetically intractable parasites, which may lead to the development of novel targeted therapies for human-parasitic nematode control.
The phenomenon of ribosome drop-off, or premature translational abandonment, is a crucial factor in translational accuracy and nutrient starvation responses during protein translation. It can significantly affect protein expression efficiency under stress conditions such as amino acid starvation or tRNA depletion. A mathematical model is presented that describes the effects of ribosome drop-off on ribosome density along the mRNA and the concomitant protein synthesis rate. The model shows that ribosome premature termination can lead to non-intuitive ribosome density profiles, such as a ribosome density that increases from the 5’ to the 3’ end. The effects of ribosome drop-off on the translation rate are mRNA-specific, and the model predicts that mRNAs which present ribosome queues are much less affected by ribosome drop-off than those which do not. Among those mRNAs that do not present ribosome queues, resilience to drop-off correlates positively with the elongation rate, so that sequences using fast codons are expected to be less affected by ribosome drop-off. This is consistent with genome-wide analysis of S. cerevisiae, which reveals that under favorable growth conditions, mRNAs coding for proteins involved in the translation machinery are highly resilient to ribosome drop-off. In physiological conditions, the translation rate of mRNAs coding for regulatory, stress-related proteins is less resilient to ribosome drop-off. This model allows for the analysis of variations in the translational efficiency of individual mRNAs by accounting for the full range of known ribosome behaviors and explains mRNA-specific variations in ribosome density emerging from ribosome profiling studies.
The World Health Organization's (WHO) current strategy for addressing soil-transmitted helminth (STH) infections in children focuses on morbidity control through routine deworming of school and pre-school aged children. However, due to continued transmission occurring in persistent reservoirs of infection in untreated individuals and the environment, this strategy may need to be continued for extended periods. There is discussion about accelerating the interruption of transmission using alternative mass drug administration (MDA) strategies. A study called DeWorm3 is currently underway to test the feasibility of interrupting STH transmission. The study follows three years of high treatment coverage with two years of surveillance. A stochastic, individual-based simulation model is employed to evaluate if criteria to determine whether transmission interruption is unlikely can be defined at earlier timepoints. The model simulates core aspects of the DeWorm3 community-based cluster-randomized trial, comparing a control arm (annual treatment of children alone with MDA) with an intervention arm (community-wide biannual treatment with MDA). Simulations were run for each scenario for both Ascaris lumbricoides and hookworm. The analyses suggest that all clusters should be assessed for transmission interruption after two years of surveillance, unless transmission interruption can be effectively ruled out through evidence of low treatment coverage. However, models suggest a tight range of homogenous prevalence estimates following high coverage MDA across clusters which do not allow for discrimination between bounce back or transmission interruption within 24 months following cessation of MDA. STH remain prevalent in sub-Saharan Africa, Asia, and South America, and if interruption of transmission can be achieved, cost savings will be observed in countries that can phase out STH MDA programs. The possibility of broadening treatment coverage to include adults for STH is being investigated, with the goal of interrupting STH transmission beyond 2020 using MDA alone.
A study in mice was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of a conjugate cholera vaccine (OSP:TThc) made from Vibrio cholerae O1 Ogawa O-specific polysaccharide (OSP) and recombinant tetanus toxoid heavy chain fragment (TThc). The study found that mice immunized with OSP:TThc with or without adjuvant developed significant IgG antibody responses targeting OSP and LPS following a single immunization, while mice receiving un-conjugated OSP with or without immunoadjuvant did not develop such responses. Additionally, administration of OSP:TThc and adjuvant induced memory B cell responses targeting OSP and resulted in 95% protective efficacy in a mouse lethality cholera challenge model. The study suggests that a cholera conjugate vaccine could assist in inducing long-term protective immunity, especially in young children who respond poorly to polysaccharide antigens.Cholera is a severe dehydrating diarrheal illness caused by organisms Vibrio cholerae O1 or O139 serogroup organisms, affecting 3-5 million people each year and killing approximately 100,000 annually. The current global cholera pandemic is caused by organisms Vibrio cholerae O1, El Tor, with the prevalent serotype fluctuating between Ogawa and Inaba. Protection against cholera is serogroup specific and serogroup specificity is largely determined by the O-specific polysaccharide (OSP) of lipopolysaccharide (LPS) of V. cholerae.The study used V. cholerae O1 El Tor Ogawa strain X25049 and wild-type classical V. cholerae O1 classical Ogawa strain O395 for vaccine preparation and immunological assays. LPS was recovered from X25049 and OSP-core was derived from LPS. As a carrier protein, recombinant tetanus toxoid heavy chain fragment (TThc) was used. OSP-core was conjugated to TThc using 3, 4-dimethoxy-3-cyclobutene-1, 2-dione as a crosslinker. Conjugation efficiency was 32% and the antigen/TThc ratio was 6.4∶1. A corresponding conjugate was made of OSP: bovine serum albumin (BSA) for use in immunologic assays.The study used dmLT, a double mutant derivative of Escherichia coli heat labile toxin, as an immunoadjuvant. Mice were immunized intramuscularly with OSP:TThc or OSP with or without dmLT. Mice immunized with OSP:TThc with adjuvant developed the highest anti-OSP IgG responses, while mice receiving OSP:TThc alone or with immunoadjuvant developed low-level vibriocidal responses. No significant IgA anti-OSP or anti-LPS antibody responses developed in any group.The memory B-cell assays after the third round of immunization showed that mice immunized with conjugate vaccine and adjuvant had a significant increase in anti-OSP IgG specific memory B cells, compared to mice immunized with adjuvant alone (95% survival at 36 hours; 95% protection; P<0.0001).In conclusion, the study demonstrated that a cholera conjugate vaccine containing OSP recovered from V. cholerae is protectively immunogenic and induces anti-OSP memory B cell responses in mice. The study suggests that anti-OSP responses may be a prime mediator of protective immunity against cholera. Protective immunity to cholera is serogroup specific, and previous infection with V. cholerae O1 provides no protection against O139 and vice versa. Currently, two oral killed cholera vaccines are WHO-prequalified and commercially available. Following two doses, these vaccines are 40-85% effective for 6-60 months. However, the level of response and duration of protection is particularly decreased in children younger than 5 years of age. The study suggests that a cholera conjugate vaccine could assist in inducing long-term protective immunity, especially in young children who respond poorly to polysaccharide antigens.
Bacterial-fungal interactions have significant physiologic and medical implications, particularly in the gut which hosts trillions of microorganisms. A study using a neutropenic mouse model found that the fungus Candida albicans inhibits the virulence of the bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa by suppressing its pyochelin and pyoverdine gene expression, which are critical for iron acquisition and virulence. Heat-killed C. albicans had no effect, while C. albicans secreted proteins directly inhibited P. aeruginosa pyoverdine and pyochelin expression and its virulence in mice. This fungal inhibition of bacterial effectors is a novel observation, demonstrating that fungi can modulate bacterial virulence in the intestine. This finding validates the use of mammalian model systems to explore the complexities of polymicrobial, polykingdom infections to identify new therapeutic targets for preventing microbial disease.
The EM virus, which is a mutated form of the WT virus, can evade CD8+ T cell recognition in HIV-1 or SIV infection. However, the EM virus is often less replication-fit than the WT virus. Reversion to WT virus upon transmission to a naïve host and lower viral load in vivo in HIV-1 infection has been observed. The rate and timing of reversion are variable, with faster reversion seen in inocula with higher proportions of WT virus. A study of SIV and SHIV viruses in pigtail macaques found that inocula with ≥10% WT virus resulted in immediate and rapid outgrowth of WT virus within 7 days, while inocula with smaller proportions of WT sequence had a delayed or slow pattern of reversion. This delayed pattern was associated with significantly lower viral loads. The diversity of the infecting inoculum determines the timing of reversion, which in turn predicts the outcome of infection. The fitness costs of escape mutations contribute to partial viral control even when the epitope is not recognized. The rate of reversion from EM to WT in vivo is highly variable and is impacted by factors such as the particular CD8 T cell epitope, target cell availability, prior vaccination, the presence of compensatory mutations, the MHC of the donor and recipient, and timing of appearance of the mutation. The high mutation rate of HIV and strong immune selection pressure exerted by CD8+ T lymphocytes leads to the frequent selection of EM virus, but these mutations also incur a fitness cost. Reversion from EM to WT virus in HIV-infected humans and SIV-infected macaques following transmission to naïve hosts that lack the appropriate MHC alleles to recognize the epitope concerned has been observed.
A study of yeast strains from Evolution Canyon (EC) in Israel found that some strains have an extremely high tolerance to the heavy metal cadmium, primarily due to an enhanced function of the metal efflux pump PCA1. Mutations in the promoter sequence, rather than the coding region, are responsible for this enhancement. These mutations are conserved and functionally important in other yeast species, representing an ancestral type that has diverged in most Saccharomyces cerevisiae populations. This selective sweep in yeast populations was driven by a tradeoff in metal resistance. Adaptation to novel or adverse environments can be complicated for organisms as mutations beneficial for survival in one environment may impose a cost under other conditions. Understanding how cells adapt to these environments can provide insights into pathway or functional network flexibility. Experimental evolution and molecular approaches have been used to discover and characterize adaptive mutations in microorganisms, including those related to metal resistance. In this study, a weak PCA1 allele spread to most S. cerevisiae populations, suggesting a tradeoff between metal resistance and fitness under conditions where cadmium is low or absent.
Gastric cancer (GC) is the second leading cause of global cancer mortality, and is characterized by a high degree of heterogeneity in the deregulation of various oncogenic pathways. A study identified three major oncogenic pathways (proliferation/stem cell, NF-κB, and Wnt/β-catenin) that were deregulated in the majority (>70%) of gastric cancers. Patient stratification by oncogenic pathway combinations showed significant survival differences, suggesting that pathway interactions play an important role in influencing disease behavior. Individual GCs can be taxonomized by oncogenic pathway activity into biologically and clinically relevant subgroups. Predicting pathway activity by expression signatures allows the study of multiple cancer-related pathways interacting simultaneously in primary cancers, at a scale not currently achievable by other platforms. This research highlights the potential of using oncogenic pathway activation as a genomic taxonomy for GC, and the importance of considering pathway interactions in understanding and treating the disease.
Stress-induced DNA duplex destabilization (SIDD) is a process that affects the behavior of each base pair in DNA, and the sites susceptible to SIDD cannot be identified by local sequence attributes alone. Negative DNA superhelicity can destabilize specific genomic regions, and changes in the level of superhelicity can strongly affect regulatory events. SIDD analysis has been used to predict sites that are susceptible to strand separation under negative superhelical stress in the Escherichia coli K12 genome. It was found that strongly destabilized sites occur preferentially in intergenic regions that are either known or inferred to contain promoters, but rarely occur in coding regions. Further analysis has shown that genes grouped in different functional categories have characteristic SIDD properties in their upstream flanks. Specifically, strong SIDD sites are statistically significantly overrepresented in the upstream regions of genes encoding transcriptional regulators, particularly in those that directly respond to physiological and environmental stimuli. The presence of these SIDD sites in the upstream regions of genes functioning in transcription suggests that they are involved in transcriptional responses to environmental changes. This association of SIDD sites with upstream regions of genes functioning in transcription is observed in 38 of 43 genomes of free-living bacteria, but in only four of 18 genomes of endosymbionts or obligate parasitic bacteria. These results suggest that SIDD sites are active and necessary participants in superhelically mediated regulatory mechanisms governing changes in the global pattern of gene expression in prokaryotes in response to physiological or environmental changes.
High-mobility group (HMG) B proteins are eukaryotic DNA-binding proteins that play a crucial role in global genomic functions and the control of genes involved in specific developmental or metabolic pathways. These proteins are characterized by the HMG-box functional motif and are widely found in various organisms, including the filamentous ascomycete Podospora anserina, which contains 12 HMG-box genes. Of these, four have been previously characterized as mating-type genes that control fertilization and development of the fruit-body, while another encodes a factor involved in mitochondrial DNA stability. Systematic deletion analysis of the eight remaining uncharacterized HMG-box genes in P. anserina revealed that none were essential for viability, but that seven were involved in the sexual cycle. Two HMG-box genes, PaHMG5 and PaHMG9, have striking features: PaHMG5 is a pivotal activator of mating-type genes, while PaHMG9 is a repressor of hyphal anastomoses and other stationary phase phenomena. Transcriptional analyses indicate that PaHMG5 is at the hub of a network of several HMG-box factors that regulate mating-type genes and mating-type target genes, as well as fertility genes that are not regulated by mating-type transcription factors. HMG-box genes are conserved across different species, including fungi and mammals, and play a critical role in sexual reproduction. This conserved function is illustrated by the mating-type genes and their upstream regulatory factor forming a module of HMG-box genes analogous to the SRY/SOX9 module in mammals. Overall, HMG-box genes are crucial transcriptional regulators involved in diverse cellular processes, including sex determination, transcription, genomic stability, and the three R's (replication, recombination, and DNA repair).
The 2013-2016 West African Ebola virus disease (EVD) epidemic was unprecedented, with over 10,000 survivors documented. Prior to this epidemic, limited data was available on the persistence of Ebola virus in survivors’ body fluids and its potential risks for transmission. In response, an observational cohort study was rapidly implemented in Sierra Leone to investigate the presence of EBOV in semen and other body fluids of EVD survivors. The study was conducted in two phases, with the first phase initiated within five months of initial protocol discussions and assessed persistence of EBOV RNA in semen of 100 adult men. The second phase assessed the persistence of virus in multiple body fluids of 120 men and 120 women. This study informed national and global guidelines in real time and demonstrated the need to implement semen testing programs among EVD survivors. Strong community engagement and international partnerships were crucial in the study’s implementation. The study’s findings highlighted the need for adequate resources to be rapidly made available to answer critical research questions during a public health emergency. This study not only provided critical data on EBOV persistence in body fluids, but also serves as a model for future research during public health emergencies caused by poorly characterized diseases.
The bacterial chemotaxis sensory system has evolved to respond to specific stimuli properties and reliably transmit this information through biochemical pathways. An experimentally well-characterized sensory system should provide valuable information about the statistics of the stimuli. Based on in vivo FRET experiments of the bacterial chemotaxis sensory system, the study predicts the chemical gradients chemotactic E. coli cells typically encounter in their natural environment. To predict average gradients, the study reevaluates Weber's law, Weber-Fechner law, and fold-change detection (FCD) and obtains full distributions of gradients using information theory and simulations, considering limitations of information transmission from both cell-external and internal noise. The results show exponentially distributed gradients, leading to log-normal stimuli and maximal drift velocity. The study provides a first step towards deciphering the chemical nature of complex, experimentally inaccessible cellular microenvironments, such as the human intestine. Bacteria live in complex chemical microenvironments shaped by nutrient supply and depletion. Commensal bacteria in our intestines have vital roles in breaking down undigested food and increasing resistance against colonization by pathogens. However, the chemical gradients microorganisms in the gut typically encounter are not well understood. The study exploits accumulated knowledge about the sensory systems of microorganisms, which have evolved to detect typical stimuli relevant to the organism, to predict typical stimuli such as concentration gradients. Information theory, quantitative dose-response curves from in vivo FRET measurements, and measurements and simulations of swimming bacteria are used to demonstrate predicting distributions of typical gradients of chemoattractant aspartate E. coli likely encounters in its physiological microenvironment. The study maximizes mutual information, implying maximizing the alignment of cell trajectories with the gradient (chemotactic index) and hence the drift velocity of cells swimming up the gradient. The approach is a first step towards the prediction of typical chemical environments of bacteria, shaped by cellular communities and dynamic turnover of nutrients, which are difficult to determine experimentally but are biomedically highly important for gut metabolism, tissue homeostasis, and disease development in the gastrointestinal tract.
"Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) are vital for a lifetime supply of blood cells, and their long-term function is dependent on their self-renewal capacity. However, recent studies suggest that the lifespan of HSCs is predetermined and HSC-intrinsic, challenging the initial belief that HSCs are immortal. This raises the question of what controls the lifespan of HSCs within the same animal, exposed to the same environment. A new model based on reliability theory suggests that the lifespan of HSCs is determined by preprogrammed differences in repair capacity. This model, which was tested through clonal repopulation experiments and computational-mathematical modeling, found that the repopulation failure kinetics of each HSC are largely anti-persistent or mean-reverting processes. Failure rates increase during population-wide division events and are counteracted and decreased by repair processes. However, a slow increase in the mean failure rate of self-renewal leads to rapid clonal extinction, suggesting that the repair capacity of HSCs is self-limiting. The lifespan of each HSC depends on the amplitudes and frequencies of fluctuations in the failure rate kinetics. Shorter and longer-lived HSCs differ significantly in their pre-programmed ability to dissipate perturbations. These findings suggest that the lifespan of HSCs is determined by preprogrammed differences in repair capacity. Adult tissue stem cells, such as HSCs, are distinguished from mature cells by their ability to generate all mature cell-types of a particular tissue (multi-potency). To generate mature cells, HSCs differentiate into cells of lower potency. The reliability with which HSCs can transfer their identity and maintain self-renewal upon proliferation has been of keen interest to the field. However, the questions of whether daughter HSCs are ""as good as old"" after self-renewal, how often individual HSCs can self-renew, and what controls the fidelity of self-renewal remain incompletely understood. Despite their extensive self-renewal capacity, HSCs were initially thought to be immortal. However, when HSCs were examined on the clonal level, extensive heterogeneity in lifespan was revealed. A detailed analysis of a large panel of HSCs showed that the lifespan of individual HSCs is mathematically predictable from few initial values of their repopulation kinetic. HSCs with lifespans from 10 to nearly 60 months were found side-by-side in the same donor, indicating that the lifespan is pre-determined on the level of each HSC. The population dynamics of HSCs predict that the molecular machinery which preserves self-renewal will ultimately fail. Hypotheses have been developed to identify and explain how HSCs limit their lifespan. The generation-age hypothesis states that for every cell division, an HSC loses some quality that is referred to as ""stemness."" Hayflick's hypothesis predicts that the probability that somatic cells produce viable daughter cells which can themselves divide decreases as the number of divisions increases. Telomere shortening, which can be caused by progressive telomere shortening, has been suggested to explain a limited lifespan of HSCs. However, HSCs and other stem cells express telomerase, an enzyme that repairs telomere damage and preserves genomic integrity. Mice that have been homozygously ablated for telomerase activity show only mild effects, and declining telomerase expression has been suggested to act in conjunction with the high stressor load imposed by co-morbidities affecting transplant patients. Oxidative stress has been proposed to be a damaging force acting on the long-term repopulating capacity of HSCs. The corresponding restoring force is provided by Forkhead box class O (FoxO) transcription factors. Different sources of self-renewal failures could be causally co-dependent. Alongside genome stability, the preservation of epigenetic patterning is an important prerequisite for reliably producing functional daughter HSCs upon self-renewal. It has been suggested that both maintenance and de novo methylation is needed to maintain epigenetic stability. Expression levels of DNA methyltransferases responsible for maintenance (DNMT1) and de novo methylation (DNMT3a and DNMT3b) could be important for restoring HSC multi-potency. Quantitative work has suggested that small failures may accumulate over time in the DNMT1 pathways leading to the loss of maintenance methylation and, ultimately, epigenetic stability. However, these mechanisms and hypotheses do not explain how HSCs with different lifespans co-exist in a single host. It has been suggested that HSCs preserve their functional integrity over long periods of time by alternating between two states, called resting or quiescent, and active. This idea poses that intermittent transitions to quiescence provide the time needed to minimize the detrimental effects of repeated DNA replication and other stresses on the HSC population as a whole. Mathematically, the lifespan of populations has been addressed in manufacturing, engineering, actuarial and biological applications of reliability theory. Reliability theory was first developed as a quality control tool to predict the time-to-failure, the manufacturing term for lifespan, of manufactured goods to determine warranty times. However, when examined"
A study on intestinal helminths, which infect around one-third of the world's population, revealed that antibodies and alternatively activated macrophages (AAM) play a crucial role in protective immunity against these parasites. Antibodies trap tissue-migrating helminth larvae and prevent tissue necrosis following challenge infection, while AAMs express wound-healing associated genes, including Arginase-1, which impairs larval motility. The antibody-induced expression of Arginase-1 occurs independently of IL-4Rα signaling, indicating a novel IL-4Rα-independent mechanism of alternative macrophage activation. This antibody-dependent and IL-4Rα-independent mechanism mediates anti-helminth immunity and prevents tissue disruption caused by migrating larvae. Intestinal helminths, particularly nematodes such as Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichuria, or Necator americanus, cause severe pathology and impaired responsiveness to vaccines in humans. Approximately 2 billion people are infected with intestinal nematodes, with the most severe infections often found in school children. Although such infections can be treated by chemotherapy, worm burdens typically reach pretreatment levels within 6 months, and drug-resistant helminths present a pressing problem for livestock and human populations. Therefore, understanding host immunity is imperative for developing effective vaccines against intestinal nematodes.
A new, non-intrusive method has been developed to visualize chromosome dynamics during the earlier steps of homologous recombination (HR) for repairing DNA double strand breaks (DSB), using protein oligomerization instead of operator multiplicity to form visible foci. This method was used to analyze resection in single living cells after HO cleavage of the MAT locus on Saccharomyces cerevisiae chromosome III. The study revealed transient confinement of the damaged chromatin region during the very early steps of resection and a 10-minute period of commitment to HR in a yku70 mutant, which defines the time when the Ku complex is protecting the DNA ends and preventing HR. This new DNA-labelling and -targeting method will be widely applicable to fine-scale analysis of genome organization, dynamics and function in normal and pathological contexts. DSBs are a major threat to chromosome integrity and cell survival, and cells meet it by launching repair programs consisting of the enzymatic restoration of the DNA and of appropriate chromatin remodelling and checkpoint activation. HR is initiated by DNA end processing, during which the Mre11-Rad50-Xrs2/Nbs1 complex (MRX/MRN) and Sae2/CTIP generate short 3′-ssDNA tails that then serve as the substrate for extensive resection by Exo1 exonuclease or Sgs1-Dna2 helicase/endonuclease. The role of chromatin mobility in DSB repair has been investigated almost exclusively in relation to the homology search step that follows resection. Changes in chromatin mobility accompanying resection itself have received little attention. Assessing DSB processing in single cells demands that we can distinguish cells that have incurred a break and are resecting from those that have not. A new DNA-labelling tool has been developed to identify budding yeast cells that undergo resection following a single HO endonuclease cut. This tool is based on the kinetochore-like nucleoprotein complexes that activate mitotic segregation in bacteria, and has enabled identification and analysis of cells undergoing resection following a single HO endonuclease cut, revealing a distinct phase of confinement of chromatin neighboring the DSB early in the resection period.
A study used stochastic agent-based models to estimate the rate of reinoculation and frequency of reinfections of Chagas disease in humans. The models were fitted to epidemiological data from Argentinean rural villages where mixed infections by different genotypes of T. cruzi reach 56% in humans. The best model predicted 0.032 (0.008-0.042) annual reinfections per individual, with 98.4% of them occurring in the chronic phase. The risks of reinfection during the typically long chronic stage of the disease stand around 14% (4%-18%) and 60% (21%-70%) after 5 and 30 years, with most individuals being re-infected 1-3 times overall. These low rates are better explained by the weak efficiency of the stercorarian mode of transmission than a highly efficient adaptive immune response.
A study on dengue virus (DENV) infections in school-aged Thai children has shown that pre-existing immune responses to DENV can influence the clinical outcome of subsequent infection. Blood samples were collected from a cohort of children who later experienced a subclinical DENV infection or developed dengue illness. Pre-infection peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) were stimulated with DENV, and the secretion of 30 cytokines was measured. It was found that PBMC from children who later developed symptomatic DENV infection had higher levels of IL-15 and MCP-1, and IL-6 was produced by PBMC from all subjects who subsequently developed symptomatic infection. On the other hand, IL-12, IL-2R, MIP-1α, RANTES, GM-CSF, and TNFα were significantly lower in PBMC from subjects with symptomatic infection. These findings suggest that pre-existing immune responses can influence the clinical outcome of DENV infection, with higher levels of some cytokines being associated with symptomatic infection and higher levels of other cytokines being associated with subclinical infection. Understanding these immunological correlations in the context of natural DENV infection may be useful for evaluating immune responses to dengue vaccines.
"In the Drosophila wing disc, the classical morphogen Hedgehog (Hh) forms an extracellular gradient that organizes patterning along the anterior-posterior axis and specifies at least three different domains of gene expression. However, a direct correspondence between the borders of these patterns and Hh concentration thresholds has not been demonstrated. A study provides evidence that the interpretation of Hh signaling depends on the history of exposure to Hh and proposes that a single concentration threshold is sufficient to support multiple outputs. Mathematical modeling predicts that at steady state, only two domains can be defined in response to Hh, suggesting that the boundaries of two or more gene expression patterns cannot be specified by a static Hh gradient. Computer simulations suggest that a spatial ""overshoot"" of the Hh gradient occurs, i.e., a transient state in which the Hh profile is expanded compared to the Hh steady-state gradient. Through a temporal examination of Hh target gene expression, the patterns initially expand anteriorly and then refine, providing in vivo evidence for the overshoot. The Hh gene network architecture suggests that this overshoot results from the Hh-dependent up-regulation of the receptor, Patched (Ptc). These results support a model in which Hh gradient dynamics, resulting from Ptc up-regulation, play an instructional role in the establishment of patterns of gene expression. Morphogens, such as Hh, control patterning by acting at a distance to regulate gene expression in a concentration-dependent manner, and their gradients are often considered static or with largely ignored transient dynamics. However, recent studies have highlighted the importance of morphogen gradient dynamics in supporting differential gene expression. The Hh gradient in the Drosophila wing disc exhibits a transient overshoot, a dynamic behavior likely due to the gene network architecture, resulting from Hh-dependent up-regulation of Ptc. This overshoot is necessary to specify more than two domains of gene expression in the system. The hypotheses that the Hh gradient at steady state is insufficient to generate more than two states, the formation of the gradient exhibits a transient overshoot, and that the overshoot is necessary to specify more than two domains of gene expression in the system are experimentally testable and supported by in vivo experimentation. Overall, the dynamic behavior of morphogen gradients plays a crucial role in patterning and specifying distinct gene expression domains."
A new mouse mutation, Lightweight (Lwt), was discovered in a forward mutagenesis screen using N-ethyl-N-nitrosourea and a sensitized genetic background to identify enhancers of dopaminergic neurotransmission. The Lwt mutation is a nonsense mutation in the mouse homolog of the C. elegans unc-79 gene, resulting in a premature stop codon. Lwt heterozygotes are mildly hyperactive, have altered responses to ethanol and inhaled anesthetics, and weigh less than wild-type littermates. The lighter weight is due to a larger proportion of body weight as lean mass and a smaller proportion as body fat. Lwt heterozygotes also consume similar amounts of food and water but accumulate less fat than +/+ mice. Additionally, Lwt/+ mice are hypersensitive to the sedative effects of ethanol and have altered acute locomotor activation produced by ethanol. The response to inhaled anesthetics is also altered, with a significant resistance to isoflurane-induced anesthesia. Furthermore, Lwt/+ animals exhibited a higher preference for ethanol and consumed more ethanol, particularly at higher concentrations, in a two-bottle choice paradigm. The Lightweight mutation is not due to a polymorphism in the D2 strain but instead is responsible for the observed phenotypes. These findings suggest a novel conserved pathway that might influence alcohol-related behaviors in humans.
The Anopheles gambiae immune response against Plasmodium falciparum, the etiological agent of human malaria, has been identified as a source of potential anti-Plasmodium genes and mechanisms to control the malaria transmission cycle. One such mechanism is the Imd pathway, which has potent anti-P. falciparum activity. Silencing the expression of caspar, a negative regulator of the Imd pathway, or over-expressing rel2, an Imd pathway-controlled NFkappaB transcription factor, confers a resistant phenotype on A. gambiae mosquitoes that involves an array of immune effector genes. However, unexplored features of this powerful mechanism that may be essential for the implementation of a malaria control strategy still remain. Using RNA interference to singly or dually silence caspar and other components of the Imd pathway, the genes participating in the anti-Plasmodium signaling module regulated by Caspar have been identified, each of which represents a potential target to achieve over-activation of the pathway. The Imd pathway is most potent against the parasite's ookinete stage, yet also has reasonable activity against early oocysts and lesser activity against late oocysts. Caspar silencing alone is sufficient to induce a robust anti-P. falciparum response even in the relative absence of resident gut microbiota. The Imd pathway components and regulated effectors TEP1, APL1, and LRIM1 have been established as relevant in parasite infection intensity-dependent defense, thereby shedding light on the relevance of laboratory versus natural infection intensity models. These results highlight the physiological considerations that are integral to a thoughtful implementation of Imd pathway manipulation in A. gambiae as part of an effort to limit the malaria transmission cycle, and they reveal a variety of previously unrecognized nuances in the Imd-directed immune response against P. falciparum. Malaria remains one of the world's most devastating infectious diseases, and its successful control will require a multifaceted approach involving a combination of multiple strategies. A multitude of potential methods to prevent mosquito-to-human transmission exist, including several based on manipulating the mosquito's immune response. In fact, such an immune response is responsible for one of the most dramatic reductions in the parasite population during the Plasmodium life-cycle: a log-fold loss in parasite numbers as ookinetes cross the mosquito's midgut cells and develop into oocysts. This drop in parasite number is due, at least in part, to an effective cellular and systemic anti-Plasmodium immune assault. Boosting the mosquito's immune response to a level that would fully eliminate this already vulnerable parasite stage could effectively terminate the malaria transmission cycle. Immune signaling pathways are key regulators of insect immune defenses and are therefore attractive candidates for genetic modification to create a mosquito with an immune response that overwhelms the parasite. Although the Toll and Jak-Stat pathways control immune attacks that limit the development of P. berghei, P. falciparum, and/or P. vivax, the immune deficiency (Imd) signaling pathway has emerged as the most effective pathway in terms of activity against the human malaria parasite.
BMMSCs, or bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells, have been considered promising in treating fibrotic diseases, including chemical- or physical-induced pulmonary fibrosis. However, a study investigated the anti-fibrotic potential of BMMSCs in an experimental model of lung fibrosis by infecting mice with Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. The results showed that late infusion of BMMSCs into mice infected with P. brasiliensis did not have any anti-fibrotic effect. Instead, the interaction between BMMSCs and the fungus promoted collagen expression and tissue remodeling. Specifically, histological analysis showed an increase of granulomatous inflammatory areas in BMMSCs-treated mice. Additionally, a significant increase of fibrocytes count, soluble collagen, and collagen-3α1, TGF-β3, MMP-8, and MMP-15 genes expression were observed in those mice. However, when combined therapy BMMSCs/ITC was used, there was a decrease of TIMP-1 and MMP-13 gene expression in infected mice. Furthermore, human fibroblasts stimulated with HLS from infected and BMMSCs-transplanted mice showed a higher expression of collagen I.In summary, the study found that late infusion of BMMSCs into mice infected with P. brasiliensis did not have any anti-fibrotic effect, possibly because their interaction with the fungus promotes collagen expression and tissue remodeling. However, when combined therapy BMMSCs/ITC was used, there was a decrease of TIMP-1 and MMP-13 gene expression in infected mice. These findings suggest that the use of BMMSCs alone may not be effective in treating fibrotic diseases caused by P. brasiliensis and that further research is needed to determine the optimal use of BMMSCs in fibrotic diseases.
A recent study investigating the geographical expansion of Phlebotomine vectors of Leishmania infantum in the Mediterranean subregion found that ongoing climate changes have contributed to the expansion. The activity of sand flies in these regions is typically seasonal, and phenological data sets can serve as a baseline for continuing investigations on sand fly population dynamics that may impact future scenarios of leishmaniasis transmission. The study, conducted in 2011-2013, involved a consortium of partners from eight Mediterranean countries and entailed entomological investigations in sites where L. infantum transmission had been recently reported. The investigations resulted in the description of seasonal dynamics of over 56,000 sand flies belonging to L. infantum vector species throughout a wide geographical area, including Portugal, Spain, Italy, France, Greece, Cyprus, and Turkey. The study found variations in the time of sand fly appearance/disappearance and seasonal densities in each site, with a common pattern of nocturnal females' activity and a 3-modal trend for P. tobbi in Cyprus representing a novel finding for a L. infantum vector. The potential exposure to L. infantum in the Mediterranean subregion was found to be associated with a regular bell-shaped density curve having a wide peak center encompassing the July-September period, and density waves of adults occurred earlier and were more frequent in southern territories. Overall, the study provides important insights into the seasonal dynamics of L. infantum vectors in the Mediterranean region, which can inform future monitoring and control efforts.
Scrub typhus is a life-threatening disease in the Asia-Pacific region, caused by the intracellular bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi. This bacterium primarily infects endothelial cells but can also replicate in monocytes, altering the expression of over 4,500 genes and inducing apoptosis. Monocytes exposed to O. tsutsugamushi exhibit features of M1 polarization, a process characterized by increased expression of type I interferon, interferon-stimulated genes, and M1-associated cytokines. These in vitro findings are consistent with genetic changes observed in mononuclear cells from scrub typhus patients. Proper diagnosis of scrub typhus remains challenging due to its nonspecific initial symptoms and the lack of an effective prophylactic vaccine. Further study of the interaction between O. tsutsugamushi and monocytes may provide new diagnostic tools and insights into the pathogenesis of scrub typhus.
Ants, like many animals, use visual memory to navigate through complex environments, but how their small brains achieve this is unclear. The mushroom body neuropils have been identified as a crucial memory circuit in the insect brain, and a spiking neural model of this circuit originally developed for fruit flies has been shown to account for the ability of desert ants to rapidly learn visual routes through natural environments. The model's key computational principles include one-shot learning of sparse codes, enabling the theoretical storage capacity of the ant mushroom body to be estimated at hundreds of independent images. The spatial memory that underlies navigational behavior in insects is a controversial issue, and it is possible that insects use path integration, landmark and/or panoramic visual memories, or a combination of these, for navigation. A potential navigation mechanism for insects is the familiarity algorithm, in which an animal compares its current visual experience to all memories ever stored while following a path integration vector homewards. This algorithm has been shown to replicate many features of ant route following and can produce similar search strategies to ants in visual homing paradigms. A variation of this algorithm could potentially be implemented in the mushroom body circuit of the ant brain. However, it should be noted that parsimony in computational terms does not necessarily map to simplicity with respect to the underlying neural architecture, and little is known about the neural implementation of navigational space in insects. Visual processing in the ant brain has not been extensively studied, but anatomically, ants have typical apposition compound eyes with a large visual field and low visual resolution. Visual signals pass through the optic lobe and then directly or indirectly to several other brain regions, including the mushroom bodies. The mushroom body neuropils have a large number of Kenyon cells, whose dendrites form the calyx and whose axons run in parallel through the pedunculus and then bifurcate to form the α and β lobes. The extent of visual input to the mushroom body is significantly greater in ants and other hymenoptera than for many other insects. There is increasing evidence that the mushroom body may play a role in visual learning and navigation in insects. A neural network model of the ant mushroom body has been shown to be sufficient for learning the association of non-elemental olfactory stimulus patterns to a reinforcement signal, and a similar mechanism could potentially be used for visual learning and route following in ants.
In the ongoing battle between plants and microbial pathogens, plants have developed sophisticated defense mechanisms, while pathogens have evolved equally sophisticated means of avoiding host defense. Plants rely on an innate immune system, lacking an adaptive immune system. The plant innate immune system can detect microbial pathogens directly by recognizing microbe-associated molecular patterns or detect general damage or modification caused by microbial pathogens. Plants have a flexible developmental program that allows them to produce new organs as needed, providing them with the ability to replace damaged organs. A system to study pathogen-triggered leaf abscission in Arabidopsis has been developed, where cauline leaves infected with the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas syringae abscise as part of the defense mechanism. The abscission response is triggered by effectors, with the threshold model regulating cauline leaf defense. Minor infections are handled by limiting bacterial growth, while severe infections result in cauline leaves being shed. Salicylic acid (SA) likely plays a crucial role in the defense response, as genes necessary for SA-mediated defense are also necessary for the full leaf shedding defense response. This study highlights the significance of shedding diseased organs, enabling plants to eliminate disease sources that may spread to healthy tissue and demonstrates that Arabidopsis uses leaf abscission as a defense mechanism against bacterial infection.
The detection of image motion direction begins in the retina, with starburst amacrine cells (SACs) playing a significant role. SACs generate larger dendritic Ca2+ signals when motion is from their somata towards their dendritic tips than for motion in the opposite direction. This direction selectivity (DS) persists even in the presence of GABA and glycine receptor antagonists, suggesting that inhibitory network interactions are not essential. The presence of harmonics in the electrical responses to expanding and contracting circular wave visual stimuli indicates nonlinearity, which is likely due to the activation of voltage-gated channels. Ca2+ changes in SAC dendrites evoked by voltage steps and monitored by two-photon microscopy suggest that the distal dendrite is tonically depolarized relative to the soma, due in part to resting currents mediated by tonic glutamatergic synaptic input. Compartmental modeling supports the conclusion that dendritic DS in SACs can be computed by the dendrites themselves, relying on voltage-gated channels and a dendritic voltage gradient, which provides the spatial asymmetry necessary for direction discrimination. The retina's ability to detect the direction of image motion is vital for the trajectory prediction of moving objects and providing information about motion relative to the environment.
The number of pathogens required to infect a host, known as the infective dose, varies dramatically among pathogen species and is dependent on the mode of action of the molecules used for infection. Pathogens using locally acting molecules require a lower infective dose compared to those using distantly acting molecules. However, pathogens with distantly acting immune modulators may be more virulent due to a larger number of cells in the inoculums, causing more harm to host cells. These predictions were tested using data on 43 human pathogens, and it was found that pathogens using local action have lower infective doses but are not less virulent than those using distant action. Virulence was negatively correlated with infective dose and higher in pathogens infecting wounded skin, compared with those ingested or inhaled. This study highlights the importance of mechanistic details in explaining variation in parasite traits such as infective dose and virulence.
Schistosomes are parasitic flatworms causing schistosomiasis, a disease affecting around 200 million people, mainly in underprivileged regions. Schistosoma mansoni is the most experimentally tractable schistosome species. Although there is growing interest in microRNAs (miRNAs) in trematodes, little is known about their role in developmental processes. In this study, the authors used a bioinformatics tool called Sylamer to analyze the 3’-UTRs of transcripts differentially expressed between the juvenile and adult stages of S. mansoni. The results showed that the miR-277/4989 family target sequence was the only one significantly enriched in the transition from juvenile to adult worms. A novel miRNA, sma-miR-4989, was also identified, and its proximal genomic location to sma-miR-277 suggests that they form a miRNA cluster. Further, the authors found that the expression of sma-miR-277/4989 miRNAs was up-regulated in adults while their predicted targets were characterized by significant down-regulation in paired adult worms but remained largely undisturbed in immature females. The study suggests that sma-miR-277/4989 might play a dominant role in post-transcriptional regulation during development of juvenile worms and indicate an important role in the sexual development of female schistosomes.
A study conducted over five years in a cave inhabited by horseshoe bats in Yunnan, China, discovered 15 new strains of SARS-related coronaviruses (SARSr-CoV). These strains were highly diverse in the S gene, ORF3, and ORF8 regions and showed high genetic similarity to SARS-CoV in the N-terminal domain and receptor-binding domain of the S1 gene, ORF3, and ORF8 region. The strains were more closely related to SARS-CoV in the non-structural protein genes ORF1a and 1b compared to those detected elsewhere. Recombination analysis showed evidence of frequent recombination events within the S gene and around the ORF8 between these SARSr-CoVs. The direct progenitor of SARS-CoV may have originated after sequential recombination events between the precursors of these SARSr-CoVs. Cell entry studies demonstrated that three newly identified SARSr-CoVs with different S protein sequences are all able to use human ACE2 as the receptor, further exhibiting the close relationship between strains in this cave and SARS-CoV. This work provides new insights into the origin and evolution of SARS-CoV and highlights the necessity of preparedness for future emergence of SARS-like diseases. SARS is a severe emerging viral disease with high fatality, exhibiting fever, headache, and severe respiratory symptoms including cough, dyspnea, and pneumonia. SARS-CoV, the causative agent, has been previously assigned to group 2b CoV and is now a member of the lineage B of genus Betacoronavirus in the family Coronaviridae. It shares similar genome organization with other coronaviruses but exhibits a unique genomic structure which includes a number of specific accessory genes, including ORF3a, 3b, ORF6, ORF7a, 7b, ORF8a, 8b, and 9b.
The current method for controlling soil-transmitted helminth (STH) infections in humans involves mass drug treatments in endemic areas, primarily in children, using benzimidazole and imidothiazole drugs. However, there is a need to monitor drug efficacy due to the development of resistance in livestock roundworms to these drugs. The faecal egg count reduction test (FECRT) is used to detect the emergence of resistance in human STHs, but recent evidence suggests that density dependent fecundity in hookworms can impact FECRT data. This phenomenon, which shows dynamic properties in response to drug treatment, can lead to an increase in egg output in surviving female worms after treatment, resulting in an underestimation of drug efficacy. This impact can vary within groups of people involved in FECRTs, and the potential for underestimation will depend on the ability of worms within particular hosts to increase their egg output. To improve the measurement of relative drug efficacy, it is important to ensure a consistent degree of underestimation in groups of people involved in separate FECRTs. This can be partly achieved by omitting cases with the heaviest infections from a FECRT, as these cases may have the greatest potential to increase their egg output upon removal of density dependent constraints. The potential impact of worm reproductive biology on the utility of the FECRT as a resistance detection tool highlights the need to develop new drug resistance monitoring methods. These methods should examine direct drug effects on isolated worms with in vitro phenotypic assays or changes in worm genotypes.Sources:[1] Brooker, S., Bethony, J., Albonico, M., Fenwick, A., and Hotez, P. The development of mammalian lungs is a complex process involving branching morphogenesis, which is regulated by numerous factors including cell surface and extracellular matrix molecules. A study found that heparan sulfate (HS) synthetase Ext1 is critical for lung morphogenesis as epithelial deletion of Ext1 resulted in expanded branching tips and reduced branching number, associated with several mesenchymal developmental defects. The mutant lungs also showed reduced levels of SHH signaling activity and increased FGF signaling activity, suggesting a cell non-autonomous mechanism. The study highlights the epithelial HS as a key player for dictating SHH signaling critical for lung morphogenesis.Lung development is a multi-step and fine-tuned process starting from the emergence of the lung primordium at embryonic day (E) 9.5 in the foregut endoderm. The lung buds undergo morphogenic changes to generate a tree-like structure until E16.5, regulated by interactions of signaling pathways in the epithelium and mesenchyme. The distal signaling center is marked by the expression of fibroblast growth factor (FGF) 10 in the mesenchyme, which serves as a chemoattractive cue for epithelium outgrowth. Sonic Hedgehog (SHH) produced in the epithelium is required for mesenchymal development and negatively regulates Fgf10 expression, leading to a focal Fgf10 expression pattern in the intertubular mesenchyme to facilitate the formation of new epithelial buds.HS are linear polysaccharide chains synthesized by the glycosyltransferase exostosin (EXT) 1/2 complex, attached to core proteins to form Heparan Sulfate Proteoglycans (HSPGs). HS chains exhibit a wide spectrum of binding affinity to growth factors and are widely involved in mammalian organogenesis. Despite the critical roles of HS in lung development, limited studies have unveiled the role of HS in lung development. Mice deficient in N-deacetylase/N-sulfotransferase-1 (NDST1) had disrupted BMP signaling and displayed a lung atelectasis associated with differentiation defects. Mice lacking Hs6st1 display postnatal changes in lung with no major organogenesis defects. These results indicated a spatial-temporal regulation of lung development by HS sulfation patterns.To further understand the role of HS in mammalian lung development, a conditional model to deplete the HS chains in all HSPGs would provide new insights into the general roles of HS in mammalian lung development. A study used a Shhcre mouse line to conditionally ablate Ext1 gene in the developing mouse lung epithelium and found that epithelial HS is required for lung branching morphogenesis by maintaining SHH signaling activity. Loss of Ext1 resulted in a failure in separation of esophagus and trachea, malformation of cartilage rings, reduced proliferation activity, and reduced phosphorylation of ERK, suggesting a reduced FGF signaling. These findings uncovered a critical regulatory role of epithelial HS in directing epithelial-mesenchymal interaction during lung branching by proper control of SHH-FGF signaling. However, the lack of rescue of branching number by SAG treatment suggested that epithelial inactivation of Ext1 may have pleiotropic effects on other signaling pathways that affect lung branching. The study also suggested that epithelial HS directly or indirectly modulates canonical WNT signaling in developing lung, however, the reduction of canonical WNT signaling may only play a minor role in branching or synergize with other dysregulated signaling pathways to contribute to some aspects of the developmental defects of Ext1 mutant lungs.
Paired-end sequencing is a key technique for assessing genome rearrangements and structural variation on a genome-wide scale, particularly useful for detecting copy-neutral rearrangements such as inversions and translocations which are common in cancer and can produce novel fusion genes. A formula for the probability of a fusion gene's existence in a cancer genome given a collection of paired-end sequences from this genome is derived, and used to compute fusion gene probabilities in several breast cancer samples, accurately predicting fusion genes with a relatively small number of fragments of large size. The ability to detect fusion genes depends on the distribution of gene lengths, and different parameters of a sequencing strategy impact breakpoint detection, breakpoint localization, and fusion gene detection. These results will be useful in calibrating future cancer sequencing efforts, enabling the discovery of new fusion genes that might provide tumor-specific biomarkers or drug targets, as recurrent translocations and their resulting fusion genes occur in various tumors including solid tumors. Whole genome paired-end sequencing approaches allow for a genome-wide survey of all potential fusion genes and other rearrangements in a tumor, with advantages over transcript or protein profiling in cancer studies. Theoretical and practical considerations for assessing cancer genome organization using paired-end sequencing approaches are addressed, deriving a formula for the probability of fusion between a pair of genomic regions given the set of all mapped clones and the empirical distribution of clone lengths, useful for prioritizing follow-up experiments to validate fusion genes. The probability of detecting fusion genes with the least amount of sequencing is maximized, depending on multiple factors including the number and length of end-sequenced clones, the length of genes that are fused, and possible errors in breakpoint localization. High throughput sequencing strategies enable the detection of an extremely high probability of breakpoint detection with a very low number of reads, and localize the breakpoints of these rearrangements to intervals of less than 300 bp in a single run of the machine.
Chemotaxis, the ability of cells to move towards or away from chemical gradients, is a fundamental process in many biological systems. It is mediated by separable but interrelated processes: motility, gradient sensing, and polarization. A mathematical model was developed to describe these processes in terms of reaction-diffusion equations, which are implemented in separate modules for excitable network, local excitation-global inhibition, and a cytoskeleton-dependent polarity module. The excitable network module accounts for random migration, while the local excitation-global inhibition module biases the direction of excitability in response to combinations of uniform stimuli and gradients. The cytoskeleton-dependent polarity module allows unstimulated cells to move persistently and contributes to distinct sensitivity between the front and back of cells in gradients. The model can recreate most of the behaviors of chemotactic cells and can simulate changes in cellular morphology using a mechanical model of the cell cortex implemented in the level set framework. By varying the strengths of various feedback loops in the model, cellular behaviors similar to those of genetically altered cell lines can be obtained. Overall, this model provides a comprehensive framework for understanding the complex process of chemotaxis.
TDRD6 is a male germ line-specific protein essential for chromatoid body structure, elongated spermatid development, and male fertility. It interacts with the key protein arginine methyl transferase PRMT5, which supports splicing, and associates with spliceosomal core protein SmB in an arginine methylation dependent manner. In Tdrd6-/- diplotene spermatocytes, PRMT5 association with SmB and arginine dimethylation of SmB are much reduced, impairing the assembly of spliceosomes and leading to increased levels of U5 snRNPs and decreased numbers of SMN-positive bodies and Cajal bodies. Transcriptome analysis revealed high numbers of splicing defects such as aberrant usage of intron and exons as well as aberrant representation of splice junctions. This study demonstrates a novel function of TDRD6 in spliceosome maturation and mRNA splicing in prophase I spermatocytes. Spermatogenesis is the process of generating haploid male gametes required for sexual reproduction in higher eukaryotes, and features unique chromosome properties and behavior such as the pairing of homologous chromosomes and formation of the synaptonemal complex in pachytene. Prophase I is the longest phase of meiosis, and TDRD6 is expressed only from mid prophase I spermatocytes onwards and localizes to the chromatoid bodies. It interacts with MVH, MILI and MIWI, and loss of TDRD6 results in mis-localization of ChB components MVH and MIWI. In the absence of TDRD6, the ChB architecture is impaired and spermiogenesis is arrested at the round-to-elongated spermatid stage. TDRD6 functions in distinct RNA pathways during spermatogenesis, and a male germ cell-specific pathway of spliceosome assembly.
The transmission and persistence of bacterial colonies in a host play a significant role in host health, serving as a reservoir that transmits to other hosts and from which invasive strains emerge. Understanding the rates of acquisition and clearance of colonizing populations is crucial in studying colonization dynamics. Research has traditionally used whole genome sequencing to determine genetic distance between isolates to infer the relationship between them. However, this approach has limitations as it may not accurately account for the diversity of the underlying within-host evolving population, time intervals between consecutive measurements, and uncertainty in the estimated acquisition and clearance rates.
