To address these limitations, a fully Bayesian model has been developed that provides probabilities of whether two strains should be considered the same, allowing for the determination of bacterial clearance and acquisition from genomes sampled over time. This method explicitly models within-host variation using population genetic simulation, and the inference is done using a combination of Approximate Bayesian Computation (ABC) and Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC). The method was validated with simulations and demonstrated its use in practice by analyzing a collection of methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) isolates from a large recently completed longitudinal clinical study. The use of this Bayesian statistical framework allows for rigorous quantification of uncertainty, explicit statement of modeling assumptions, and straightforward utilization of multiple data sources. This method for identifying strains with explicit assessment of uncertainty will enable studies of the characteristics that impact colonization in the presence and absence of interventions.
The shoot apical meristem (SAM) is responsible for generating all aerial parts of plants through the activity of populations of stem cells called meristems. The SAM is a highly organized structure with a central zone for maintaining the meristem and a peripheral zone capable of initiating new organ primordia. The young organs are usually initiated in highly ordered spiraled or whorled patterns, a phenomenon called phyllotaxy, which varies among plant species and growth conditions. Auxin, a key hormone, plays a crucial role in primordium formation and is actively transported throughout the plant from cell to cell by carriers located at the cell plasma membranes. PIN proteins, which facilitate auxin efflux, often accumulate on one particular side of the cell, suggesting that auxin is evacuated preferentially via that side. The coherent behavior of PIN proteins in cell populations is essential for phyllotaxy. A flux-based polarization hypothesis proposes that any small flux between two cells in the system will reinforce itself by increasing the local amount of PIN, thus initiating a positive feedback loop. Computational modelling supports this hypothesis, showing that a flux-based polarization mechanism can explain auxin transport at the shoot meristem and provide a unifying concept for the control of auxin distribution in the plant. Further experiments are required to distinguish between flux-based polarization and other hypotheses.
The search for diagnostic biomarkers for visceral leishmaniasis (VL) has been aided by the increasing number of high-quality sequenced genomes and freely available bioinformatic tools. These tools can be combined with wet lab experiments for a rational search for improved, point-of-care diagnostic tests. Previous research has shown the potential of IgG1 as a biomarker for monitoring clinical status in rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs), but the use of a crude lysate antigen (CLA) as a capturing antigen can lead to variability in results. By identifying specific antigens to replace the CLA, more robust RDTs can be developed. Immunoblots and mass spectrometry have been used to identify L. donovani protein bands detected by IgG1 from VL patients, and in silico algorithms have been used to map linear epitopes and screen for evidence of constitutive protein expression and the presence of antigenic domains. The most promising candidate was tested in RDT prototypes using VL and nonendemic healthy control patient sera, and showed sensitivity and specificity supporting its use as a diagnostic marker. This approach of combining comparative genomics, in silico algorithms, and wet lab experiments can be applied to the development of more robust IgG1 RDTs for monitoring clinical status in VL.
A study of 317 patients with cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) from Syria, Pakistan, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, Ethiopia, and Iran found that 18.2% of cases had caseating granulomas, which is usually associated with mycobacterial infections such as tuberculosis (TB). This unusual finding can complicate the diagnosis of CL in endemic and non-endemic regions, especially with international travel and immigrants from non-endemic areas. The study found that cases of CL with caseating granulomas had a slower healing process compared to those without, with no association with specific species or age groups. This may be due to worse host immune response or more aggressive Leishmania strains. The study emphasizes the importance of considering CL in the differential diagnosis for cases with caseating granulomas in endemic regions, and the need for further research to understand the mechanisms that lead to caseating granulomas in CL.
Type 2 diabetes is a complex disease caused by the combination of insulin resistance and inadequate insulin secretion, and is associated with obesity. The risk of developing type 2 diabetes is heritable, and numerous associations between single nucleotide polymorphisms and the diabetes risk in humans have been identified. However, the functional consequences of these SNPs at the molecular, cellular, and physiological level are not well understood. Obese mouse strains carrying the Lepob (ob) or the Lepdb (db) mutation have been valuable models for the study of the pathophysiology and genetics of type 2 diabetes. The diabetic phenotype in these strains is conferred by the background strain, and it is assumed that lean mice may carry diabetogenic and/or diabetes-protecting alleles. Quantitative trait loci (QTL) for obesity and hyperglycaemia have been separated in outcross experiments of New Zealand Obese (NZO) mice and lean strains, proving the concept that diabetes is the result of a combination of adipogenic and diabetogenic alleles.In this study, the researchers focused on a QTL (Nidd/SJL) on distal chromosome 4 that aggravated and accelerated diabetes in an outcross population of NZO with the lean SJL strain. This QTL exhibited high LOD scores for the trait blood glucose and reproducibly doubled the prevalence of diabetes in a NZOxSJL backcross population. The researchers used interval-specific congenic introgression to identify a critical interval of distal chromosome 4 (2.1 Mbp) that confers the diabetic phenotype. Analysis of the 10 genes in the critical interval revealed a striking allelic variance of Zfp69 encoding zinc finger domain transcription factor 69. A retrotransposon (IAPLTR1a) in intron 3 of Zfp69 was found to disrupt the gene in NZO and C57BL/6J mice, while the diabetogenic SJL, NON, and NZB alleles generated a normal mRNA. The diabetogenic Zfp69SJL allele produced hyperglycaemia, reduced gonadal fat, and increased plasma and liver triglycerides when combined with the B6 . V-Lepob background. mRNA levels of the human orthologue of Zfp69, ZNF642, were significantly increased in adipose tissue from patients with type 2 diabetes. These findings suggest that Zfp69 is the most likely candidate for the diabetogenic effect of Nidd/SJL, and that retrotransposon IAPLTR1a contributes substantially to the genetic heterogeneity of mouse strains. Expression of the transcription factor in adipose tissue may play a role in the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes.
The differentiation of mammalian cells, specifically within the vertebrate hematopoietic system, is controlled by the concerted action of signalling pathways and transcriptional regulatory networks. However, predicting the exact cell differentiation from specific signals and transcriptional factors is still a daunting challenge. This is particularly true for T helper (Th) cells, which have many branching differentiation pathways and cell types. In this study, the researchers proposed an integrated model of the regulatory network and signalling pathways controlling Th cell differentiation, with a focus on the core control of this process. They used a qualitative, logical formalism to perform extensive dynamical analyses and cope with the size and complexity of the resulting network. Through simulations, they identified stable states corresponding to canonical Th1, Th2, Th17 and Treg subtypes, but also found that these coexist with other hybrid cell types that co-express combinations of Th1, Th2, Treg and Th17 markers in an environment-dependent fashion. The logical analysis highlights the nature of these cell types and their relationships to canonical Th subtypes. The model can be used to explore novel differentiation pathways in silico. The precise roles of the different molecular species involved in the regulation of T cell differentiation are sparsely known, and the extended logical formalism is a discrete modelling framework well adapted to biological systems where available information is qualitative. This framework allows for the modeling of a regulatory network in terms of a regulatory graph, where nodes represent regulatory components and arcs represent interactions between these components. Logical rules are then defined for each regulatory component to specify its target activity level according to the levels of its regulators. The state transition graph is then used to describe the dynamical behaviour of the system, with attractors corresponding to potential asymptotical behaviours, either stable states or cyclical components. The asynchronous dynamical analysis of increasingly large regulatory graphs can be very challenging due to the exponential growth of the state transition graphs, but this can be addressed by reducing the model by removing intermediate components and preserving a number of dynamical properties of the original model. The logical framework also allows for the analysis of the dynamical roles of the regulatory circuits embedded in a regulatory graph, with positive circuits enabling the existence of alternative differentiated cell lineages. A comprehensive logical model was built by integrating a large set of documented molecular actors and interactions, with the resulting model available in the model repository linked to the GINsim website. Simulations are then performed to determine how naive cells can differentiate into specialized cells, depending on local environments, and how these differentiated cells respond to environmental changes.
The binding of transcription factors (TFs), which regulate gene expression during animal development, occurs at thousands of genomic regions, with quantitative differences in binding mediating their activity. While we can now identify TF-DNA affinities and genome-wide distribution, the forces determining where, when, and to what extent they bind remain unclear. A thermodynamic model of TF binding was used to evaluate the impact of different biophysical forces on the binding of five Drosophila melanogaster TFs involved in early embryonic anterior-posterior patterning. The model, incorporating DNA sequence, protein-DNA affinities, cooperativity, competition, and spatial patterning, dramatically improved in vivo binding predictions when incorporating experimental measurements of genome-wide DNA accessibility. This restricted predictions to regions of open chromatin, correlating well with known target genes. The results suggest that combining experimentally determined chromatin accessibility data and simple computational models can accurately predict the binding landscape of animal TFs. In vivo crosslinking studies show that animal TFs bind to many DNA regions throughout the genome, with many strong binding events at functional cis regulatory modules and many thousands of other genomic regions bound at lower levels, not apparent functionally. The mechanisms proposed for these complex, quantitative patterns of factor occupancy include: (1) competitive inhibition of binding at DNA regions that overlap sites occupied by other sequence-specific factors, nucleosomes, and chromatin-associated proteins, and (2) direct and indirect cooperative interactions between factors bound at physically proximal sites that increase their affinity at those sites. However, the extent of each mechanism's influence on the overall pattern of factor binding in vivo remains unclear. Therefore, a model was established to predict the levels of factor occupancy and quantify the contribution of various factor-targeting forces, using gHMMs, allowing efficient integration of forces that influence transcription factor binding. The model, trained on in vitro TF-DNA binding affinities and in vivo binding measurements, provided a quantitative measure of transcription factor binding, overcoming the limitation of Markovian property of gHMMs through a sampling procedure.
In developmental biology, understanding the mechanisms that regulate organ growth is a major concern, as this knowledge can help explain both physiological and pathological processes, such as cancer. The E protein family of basic helix-loop helix (bHLH) transcription factors and their inhibitors, the Id proteins, regulate cell proliferation in metazoans. The activity of these factors is often deregulated in cancerous cells. In Drosophila, the E protein orthologue Daughterless (Da) and Id orthologue Extramacrochaetae (Emc) control proliferation in epithelial cells during development. Specifically, during the G2/M transition, Emc regulates cell proliferation via Da by controlling the activity of the Cdc25 phosphatase, string. The ectopic expression of string in cells with reduced levels of Emc or high levels of Da can rescue the proliferative defects seen in these mutant cells, and Da acts as a transcriptional repressor of string. This mechanism defines how Emc controls cell proliferation by regulating the activity of Da, which transcriptionally represses string. Cell proliferation is a critical event in organ formation, and it is regulated by multiple cellular signals. During development, individual cells interpret these signals to determine whether to continue proliferating or to induce cell cycle arrest and initiate differentiation. The basic Helix-Loop-Helix (bHLH) family of transcription factors are key regulatory molecules that control multiple developmental processes in species from yeast to humans. In metazoans, bHLH proteins orchestrate cell cycle control, cell lineage commitment, and cell differentiation. Dimerization of the HLH domain allows these proteins to form homo- or heterodimers, while their basic domain is responsible for their capacity to bind to DNA. The bHLH proteins are classified into different categories according to their function, distribution, and DNA-binding properties. The E protein family is a group of class I bHLH factors, and they are believed to serve as cell cycle effectors, although this function remains controversial due to the diversity of cell cycle-specific target genes identified for E proteins. The functional redundancy between the members of these two families has also complicated the study of their influence on cell proliferation. In Drosophila, the interaction between Da and Emc, the only representatives of classes I and V, is a determinant of cell fate decisions in different developmental contexts and is necessary to maintain a proliferative state during organ development. The regulatory network between Da and Emc is evolutionarily conserved, and changes in the expression of emc by different extracellular signals modulate the levels of Da. Emc can bind directly to Da, and elimination of Emc promotes an increase in Da homodimers. In vertebrates, Id2 is thought to bind to the retinoblastoma tumor suppressor protein (pRB), abolishing its growth-suppressor activity. The role of da in regulating proliferation has not been studied in depth, but both emc and da are required for the G2/M transition in the cell cycle in Drosophila.
A comprehensive quantitative analysis pipeline was developed to identify key proteins in specific pathways, discover protein-protein interactions, and infer signaling networks using interventional phosphoproteome data. The pipeline, customized for phosphoproteome data, includes phosphopeptide meta-analysis, correlation network analysis, and causal relationship discovery. It was applied to interventional experiments using SILAC technique with kinase-dead mutations in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, identifying 5 high-confidence and 19 hub proteins involved in stress responses and filamentous growth. Four of the predicted proteins presented differential invasive growth, validating the approach. This pipeline provides a systematic way for discovering signaling networks using interventional phosphoproteome data and can suggest candidate proteins for further investigation, applicable to other interventional studies via different experimental platforms. Reversible phosphorylation plays a crucial role in signal transduction and the regulation of cell growth and development. However, few signaling networks have been completely delineated. Quantitative phosphoproteomics is an emerging tool for large-scale determination of relative phosphorylation levels. The pipeline includes phosphopeptide meta-analysis, correlation network analysis, and causal relationship discovery to identify key proteins in specific pathways, discover protein-protein interactions, and infer signaling networks. It was applied to interventional experiments using SILAC technique with kinase-dead mutations in Saccharomyces cerevisiae and successfully identified 5 high-confidence and 19 hub proteins involved in stress responses and filamentous growth. Four of the predicted proteins presented differential invasive growth, validating the approach. This pipeline provides a systematic way for discovering signaling networks using interventional phosphoproteome data and can suggest candidate proteins for further investigation, applicable to other interventional studies via different experimental platforms.
The evolution of heteromorphic sex chromosomes has resulted in the development of two types of chromosome-specific regulation: dosage compensation and meiotic sex chromosome inactivation (MSCI). Dosage compensation equalizes X chromosome gene expression between males and females, while MSCI transcriptionally silences the X (or Z) during meiosis in the germline. In Drosophila melanogaster males, X chromosome-wide dosage compensation is absent from most of the germline and there is no evidence for X chromosome-specific inactivation during meiosis. However, a premeiotic chromosomal difference in expression is observed where autosomal spermatogenesis-specific promoters have reduced expression when inserted on the X chromosome. This X-autosome difference in transgene expression cannot be explained by the absence of dosage compensation, suggesting a previously unrecognized mechanism limits expression from the X during spermatogenesis in Drosophila. These findings have implications for patterns of genome evolution and speciation in Drosophila.
"Citrobacter rodentium is a mouse pathogen used to model human diarrheal infections caused by Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) and Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC). These pathogens form intimate epithelium-adherent microcolonies, also known as ""attachment/effacement"" (A/E) lesions, which must be dynamic and able to self-renew by continuous re-infection of the rapidly regenerating epithelium. A study focused on the earliest events in C. rodentium infection found that all colonic epithelial A/E microcolonies are clonal bacterial populations, and their establishment within the first 18 hours of infection shapes the ongoing intestinal geography and severity of infection. Mechanistically, induced resistance to A/E lesion de-novo formation is mediated by TLR-MyD88/Trif-dependent signaling and is induced specifically by virulent C. rodentium in a virulence gene-dependent manner. This demonstrates that the establishment phase of C. rodentium pathogenesis in vivo is restricted to a very short window of opportunity that determines both disease geography and severity. EPEC and EHEC remain important causes of human diarrhea and mortality worldwide."
The researchers have developed a new method to estimate the overlap between two populations, which can be used in various fields such as ecology and genomic epidemiology. This method is designed to provide unbiased and accurate estimates of population overlap even when only a fraction of each population is sampled. The method is specifically useful in the study of the malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum, particularly in analyzing the diversity of its var genes. Var genes are important in the parasite's virulence and duration of infection. However, traditional methods of estimating var gene repertoire overlap are prone to bias due to subsampling. The new method uses Bayesian inference to model the stochastic process of sampling and provides a natural framework for computing the uncertainty of its estimates. The method can also be used for study planning by quantifying the tradeoff between sampling effort and uncertainty. The new method is demonstrated to provide more accurate estimates of var gene repertoire overlap compared to traditional methods.
Eukaryotic protein kinases (EPKs) are crucial for various cellular functions through phosphorylating targeted protein substrates using a highly conserved catalytic core. The catalytic core undergoes open, intermediate, and closed conformations in the active state, which is not well understood. However, recent studies using cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA) as a model with biochemical, biophysical, and computational techniques have identified intramolecular interactions that regulate the active state mechanics. These interactions include a salt bridge between a lysine from the β3-strand and a glutamate from the αC-helix, an electrostatic interaction between the phosphorylated activation loop and αC-helix, and an ensemble of hydrophobic residues from the Regulatory spine and Shell. Interestingly, the β3-lysine, previously thought to be essential for phosphoryl transfer, is not required for this process but is essential for the active state mechanics. EPKs, discovered in 1943, with functional elucidation in 1956, share a highly conserved catalytic core that mediates the transfer of the γ-phosphate of ATP to a protein substrate. PKA, discovered in 1968, has been the prototype for understanding EPK structure and function. EPKs are involved in almost all biological processes and have been associated with numerous human diseases, making them key candidates for therapeutic intervention.
American Samoa, a US territory in the South Pacific, has a population of around 55,000 people and has been conducting mass drug administration (MDA) for lymphatic filariasis (LF) elimination from 2000 to 2006. In 2016, a study was conducted to compare the effectiveness of school-based Transmission Assessment Surveys (TAS) and community-based surveys for post-MDA surveillance. The school-based TAS targeted children aged 6-7 years, while the community-based survey targeted individuals aged ≥8 years. Blood samples were collected to test for circulating filarial antigen (CFA) using the Alere Filariasis Test Strip.The school-based TAS identified nine antigen-positive children, with an overall adjusted CFA prevalence of 0.7% (95% CI: 0.3--1.8). Of the nine positive children, one was microfilaraemic. The community-based survey identified 102 antigen-positive people, with an overall adjusted CFA prevalence of 6.2% (95% CI: 4.5--8.6). Adjusted village-level prevalence ranged from 0--47.1%. CFA prevalence increased with age and was higher in males. Of 86 antigen-positive community members from whom slides were prepared, 22 (25.6%) were microfilaraemic.The study found that school-based TAS had limited sensitivity (range 0--23.8%) and negative predictive value (range 25--83.3%) but had high specificity (range 83.3--100%) and positive predictive value (range 0--100%) for identifying villages with ongoing transmission. The community-based survey identified antigen-positive individuals of all ages and foci of high antigen prevalence. Both surveys confirmed recrudescence of LF transmission.In conclusion, while school-based TAS is logistically simpler and enables sampling of a larger proportion of the target population, it may not provide a good indication of the overall CFA prevalence in older age groups and is not sensitive at identifying foci of ongoing transmission. Community-based surveys, although operationally more challenging, provide more detailed information on estimates of community-level CFA prevalence, highlight foci of high prevalence, and identify Ag- and Mf-positive people who are capable of perpetuating transmission. Therefore, a combination of both school-based and community-based surveys is recommended for post-MDA surveillance to confirm the elimination of LF.
The zebrafish is a commonly used model organism, but the process of sex determination in this species is not well understood. Sex determination in domesticated zebrafish is polygenic and can be influenced by environmental factors, as well as the requirement of germ cells for female sex determination. A recent study has found that oocytes are required for the maintenance of the differentiated female state in adult zebrafish. The study reports a novel role for Bmp15 in maintaining adult female sex differentiation in zebrafish. Females deficient in Bmp15 begin development normally but switch sex during the mid- to late- juvenile stage and become fertile males. The function of Bmp15 in female sex maintenance is likely linked to the regulation of estrogen biosynthesis via promoting the development of estrogen-producing granulosa cells in the oocyte follicle. Primary sex determination in wild zebrafish is regulated by a ZZ/ZW genetic system, but in domesticated zebrafish, it relies on a polygenic system that is strain-dependent. Even in wild strains where the W chromosome is necessary for female primary sex determination, a fraction of ZW individuals develop as males. This shows that while a dominant sex-determining chromosome can strongly influence the outcome of sex determination in zebrafish, it is not an absolute prerequisite. In some species of fish, systems other than dominant sex-determining loci can influence or override a genetic sex-determining strategy. Zebrafish are classified as juvenile hermaphrodites as all fish initially produce early-stage oocytes, regardless of their eventual sex. Oocytes are required for primary female sex determination and are also required throughout adult life to maintain the female sex. The study found that oocytes produce a signal that functions to stabilize female-specific gene expression within early somatic gonad cells during the primary sex determination phase of development as well as to maintain the female differentiated state in adults.
Hox genes are crucial for controlling morphogenetic diversity along the anterior-posterior body axis of animals by regulating distinct sets of target genes. Individual Hox proteins control cell diversification and pattern formation in a highly localized manner due to their high-regulatory specificity. This specificity is achieved through cooperation with other transcription factors to activate or repress their target genes in a context-specific manner. A study analyzing the regulation of the cell death gene reaper (rpr) by the Hox protein Deformed (Dfd) found that local activation of rpr expression in the anterior part of the maxillary segment is achieved through a combinatorial interaction of Dfd with at least eight functionally diverse transcriptional regulators on a minimal enhancer. This combinatorial interaction of Hox proteins and other transcriptional regulators on small regulatory elements is responsible for the spatio-temporal expression of Hox targets. The regulation of rpr by Dfd is highly complex, with Dfd having activating and repressing activity even when acting on a small regulatory element. A total of 16 transcription factors were identified to affect Dfd-dependent rpr expression, with seven of them having a significant effect. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the spatio-temporal precision of Hox target gene regulation.
The genetic requirements for defense responses of an autoactive mutant of the Arabidopsis coiled-coil (CC)-NB-LRR protein, ADR1-L2, were studied. ADR1-L2 functions upstream of salicylic acid (SA) accumulation in several defense contexts and can act as a “helper” to transduce specific microbial activation signals from “sensor” NB-LRRs. This helper activity does not require an intact P-loop. However, in the context of unregulated runaway cell death (rcd) in an lsd1 mutant, ADR1-L2 function is P-loop dependent. The autoactive missense mutation, ADR1-L2D484V, leads to dwarfed plants with increased disease resistance and constitutively high SA levels. The morphological phenotype and signaling from ADR1-L2D484V are also P-loop dependent, suggesting canonical activation of this NB-LRR protein. The genetic requirements for ADR1-L2D484V activity resemble those that regulate an SA-gradient-dependent signal amplification of defense and cell death signaling initially observed in the absence of LSD1. ADR1-L2D484V autoactivation signaling is controlled by both EDS1 and SA in separable, but linked pathways. Overall, these findings suggest an SA-dependent feedback regulation loop that includes ADR1-L2, providing insight into the complex immune signaling of plants.
In Arabidopsis, MORC6, a member of the Arabidopsis MORC family of proteins, mediates transcriptional silencing through heterochromatin condensation. MORC6 physically interacts with SUVH9, a SU ( VAR ) 3-9 protein involved in recruiting Pol V to methylated chromatin regions. This interaction suggests that MORC6 may be functionally related to the RdDM pathway. While MORC6 does not significantly contribute to DNA methylation at most SUVH2/9 target loci (Class II), it does contribute to DNA methylation at a small subset of SUVH2/9 target loci (Class I). Specifically, MORC6 is responsible for DNA methylation at 527 Class I SUVH2/9 target loci, while being dispensable for DNA methylation at 5987 Class II loci. These findings suggest that MORC6 has a role in DNA methylation at a small subset of RdDM target loci. Additionally, MORC6 forms a complex with its two close homologs, MORC1 and MORC2, and may function redundantly in DNA methylation at Class II hypo-DMRs. A morc1 mutation introduced by the CRISPR/CAS9 system was used to generate a morc1/2/6 triple mutant, but DNA methylation was not reduced at four class II loci even in the morc1/2/6 triple mutant. Overall, the MORC family proteins contribute to DNA methylation only at a small subset of RdDM target loci and the transcription of both transposable elements (TEs) and genes is affected in suvh2/9 and morc6 mutants, with a significant overlap in co-up-regulated TEs.
Hsp90, a molecular stress-response chaperone, can buffer underlying genetic variation and its function is crucial for the robustness of the wild-type phenotype. In zebrafish, mild perturbation of Hsp90 function during critical developmental stages can uncover cryptic genetic variants, leading to variable penetrance and expressivity of developmental anomalies. This is supported by the observation of previously unobserved specific developmental anomalies in zebrafish following partial inhibition of Hsp90 function. These phenotypes were manifestations of underlying cryptic genetic variation and depended on the strain used and the developmental stage at which the Hsp90 inhibitor was administered. Hsp90 inhibition can also modify the severity of some, but not all, already characterized developmental anomalies. Molecular studies show that in the presence of Hsp90 inhibition, one of the mutant proteins studied is rapidly decreased, while its WT allele is largely unaffected, providing a molecular model for Hsp90 modulation of phenotype at the organismal level. Hsp90 protein function is required at all times in eukaryotic cells and is specifically inhibited by compounds like geldanamycin or radicicol, which compete with ATP for the nucleotide-binding pocket, disrupting Hsp90 activity. Hsp90 inhibitors have been proposed for amelioration of protein-aggregation-associated neurodegenerative diseases. Increased binding affinity of Hsp90 inhibitors to mutated protein complexes preferentially sensitizes them to Hsp90 inhibition, allowing differential killing of malignant versus normal cells, which is exploited in cancer treatment.
Protein modification plays a crucial role in various biological processes in living organisms, with amino-terminal acetylation being a common protein modification found throughout the tree of life. This co-translational modification occurs at the N-terminus of a nascent polypeptide chain, often after the removal of the initiating methionine residue. While the enzymes and protein complexes involved in these processes have been extensively studied, the biological function of N-terminal modification events remains largely unknown.To identify common principles of N-terminal acetylation, a study analyzed the amino-terminal peptides from proteins extracted from Drosophila Kc167 cells. They detected over 1,200 mature protein N-termini and found that N-terminal acetylation occurs in insects with a similar frequency as in humans. The researchers identified the ( X ) PX rule as the sole true determinant for N-terminal acetylation, preventing acetylation under all circumstances. This rule can be used to genetically engineer a protein to study the biological relevance of the presence or absence of an acetyl group, providing a generic assay to probe the functional importance of N-terminal acetylation.N-terminal acetylation occurs during protein synthesis, combining two consecutive events: the removal of the N-terminal methionine by methionine aminopeptidases and the acetylation of the amino-terminus by N-terminal acetyl transferases (NATs). In eukaryotes, both processes usually take place co-translationally on the nascent polypeptide chain. The N-terminal region of a protein defines its acetylation status, although sequence specificities of the different NAT complexes do not always correlate with acetylation events, suggesting that additional factors, such as amino acid sequence patterns or the secondary structure of the protein's N-terminus, may play a role.The study identified 124 previously unknown alternative translation initiation sites and/or splice variants, revealing that amino-terminal acetylation is a common event in Drosophila. A protein's acetylation state strongly correlates with the presence of certain functional protein domains, and a proline at position one or two of a nascent protein prevents N-terminal acetylation under all circumstances. The researchers propose that by applying the ( X ) PX rule in similar ways in other species, the function of N-terminal acetylation can now be generically studied.
The ability of RNA polymerase (RNAP) III to efficiently recycle from termination to reinitiation is crucial for abundant tRNA production during cellular proliferation, development, and cancer. Understanding the unique termination mechanisms used by RNAP III and its link to high transcription output is incomplete. A study using S. pombe and two tRNA-mediated suppression systems identified 122 point mutation mutants of Rpc1, the largest subunit of RNAP III, with gain-and loss-of termination phenotypes. These mutants cluster in the active center bridge helix and trigger loop, as well as the pore and funnel, indicating involvement of the RNA cleavage domain of the C11 subunit in termination. An increased elongation rate was demonstrated for a multiple-isolate mutant, supporting a kinetic coupling model in which elongation rate is inversely related to termination efficiency. The mobile elements of the RNAP III active center, including C11, are key determinants of termination, and some of the mutations activate RNAP III for overall transcription. Similar mutations in spontaneous cancer suggest this as an unforeseen mechanism of RNAP III activation in disease. The conserved core structures of multisubunit RNA polymerases in all domains of life synthesize different RNAs, and the RNAP active center has a catalytic site at one end of an 8–9 bp RNA:DNA hybrid binding cavity. The catalytic mechanism relies on two mobile elements, the bridge helix and trigger loop, which position substrate and promote forward movement by a ratchet-like mechanism.
A new method has been developed to predict SH2-mediated protein-protein interactions using the structure of SH2-phosphopeptide complexes and the FoldX algorithm. This method performs similarly to experimentally derived consensus sequences and substitution matrices at predicting known in vitro and in vivo targets of SH2 domains. The predictions lead to a new hypothesis for the role of SH2 domains in signaling and can be used to derive biologically relevant testable hypotheses. The method can predict whether a protein-phosphopeptide complex will be disrupted or not by dephosphorylation and can be used to predict the energetics of phosphorylated residues. The performance of the structure-based calculations in the prediction of in vitro protein-phosphopeptide binding specificity is similar to experimental methods based on peptide libraries. FoldX can predict in vitro binding of phosphopeptides to SH2 domains with an area under the ROC curve of 0.70±0.03 (p-value 3.1⋅10−11). The performance of FoldX is similar to experimental methods based on peptide libraries in the prediction of SH2-mediated in vivo interactions, with an area under the ROC curve of 0.80±0.02 (p-value 4.5⋅10−25) for the FoldX predictions. The final goal of the work is to make useful predictions of SH2-mediated protein-protein interactions by filtering for sites known to be phosphorylated or predicted to be phosphorylated and within a disordered region. The area under the ROC curve for prediction of SH2 target proteins increases from 0.79±0.02, (p-value 9.2⋅10−26) for the unfiltered FoldX predictions to 0.93±0.02, (p-value 7.9⋅10−53) for the filtered predictions. FoldX improves the performance of the phosphorylation/secondary structure filter, supporting the combined use of both prediction methods.
The abnormal accumulation of the microtubule-associated protein tau into toxic oligomers and amyloid deposits is a primary pathology in tauopathies, with Alzheimer's disease being the most common. Intrinsically disordered proteins like tau are rich in proline residues that regulate their secondary structure and aggregation propensity. The orientation of proline residues is regulated by cis/trans peptidyl-prolyl isomerases (PPIases), among which cyclophilin 40 (CyP40) has been identified as a PPIase that dissolves tau amyloids in vitro. CyP40 interacts with tau at sites rich in proline residues, and its PPIase activity is necessary for its disaggregation activity. CyP40 can also interact with and disaggregate other aggregating proteins that contain prolines. A unique structural property of CyP40 may permit disaggregation to occur in an energy-independent manner. This study highlights the potential of CyP40 as a novel human protein disaggregase and its capacity to dissolve intracellular amyloids, which could be exploited to mitigate disease pathogenesis in neurodegenerative disorders.
Heterocyst differentiation in cyanobacteria filaments is a prime example of cellular differentiation and pattern formation in multicellular organisms, which is facilitated by a genetic circuit that responds to nitrogen deprivation. A systems biology approach has been employed to understand the principles of heterocyst pattern formation, by formulating the essential dynamical ingredients of the genetic circuit of a single cyanobacterium into a set of differential equations. This approach allows for the study of the behavior of a single cyanobacterium under different external conditions, emulating nitrogen deprivation, and simulating the dynamics of cyanobacteria filaments by coupling their respective genetic circuits via molecular diffusion. The study reveals that diffusion and noisy external conditions are crucial for the formation and sustainment of heterocyst patterns in cyanobacteria filaments, recapitulating the main features of heterocyst pattern formation as observed experimentally. The mathematical modeling of differentiation processes and their associated pattern formation demands an integrative approach combining tools from statistical mechanics and the theory of dynamical systems.
The Community Directed Treatment with Ivermectin (CDTI) program has significantly improved the fight against onchocerciasis, or river blindness, in Africa. However, in Cameroon, after over 15 years of mass treatment, onchocerciasis prevalence remains above the non-transmission threshold in certain regions. This study aimed to examine the potential association between people's beliefs, perceptions of the CDTI program, and their adherence to ivermectin in three Cameroonian health districts. Results showed that adherence to ivermectin was lower in Yabassi (40.7%) compared to Bafang and Bafia (55.0% and 48.8%, respectively). Among factors related to program perceptions and disease representations, perceptions of the program were most determinant in adherence to ivermectin. Misconceptions about onchocerciasis transmission, such as the lack of hygiene and the belief that onchocerciasis is caused by high sugar intake, were still prevalent. Perceptions of ivermectin distribution campaigns were more strongly associated with adherence than education/sensitization during the implementation of the CDTI program. To improve adherence, local health authorities should strive to better involve communities and encourage community distributors' work.
This study combined SNP and DNA methylation data with protein biomarker measurements for cancer, inflammation, and cardiovascular disease to investigate the relationship between genetic and epigenetic variation and biomarker levels. The study incorporated data from 121 protein biomarkers, 470,000 genomic positions, and over 10 million SNPs in epigenome-wide association study (EWAS) and genome-wide association study (GWAS) analyses. Researchers identified 124 and 45 loci associated with biomarkers in EWAS and GWAS, respectively, and found that most GWAS loci were cis-regulatory, while most EWAS loci were located in trans. Additionally, eleven EWAS loci were associated with multiple biomarkers. While some cis-regulatory SNPs for biomarkers appeared to have an effect on DNA methylation levels, cis-regulatory SNPs for DNA methylation were not observed to affect biomarker levels. Overall, the study's findings suggest that protein biomarker and DNA methylation levels are associated at numerous loci in the genome, likely reflecting underlying patterns of genetic variants or environmental exposures. While epigenetic modifications are associated with disease development, the causality of these associations remains uncertain, and further research is necessary to determine the role of epigenetic alterations in disease pathogenesis and heritability.
Natural Killer (NK) cells are important anti-viral effectors in Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) infection, but how VZV affects NK cell function is unclear. This study found that VZV impairs NK cell responses to target cell stimulation in vitro, affecting both cytotoxic and cytokine responses. This was dependent on direct contact between NK cells and VZV-infected inoculum cells. Both VZV-infected and uninfected NK cells exposed to virus in culture were inhibited. The inhibition of NK cell function was due to VZV paralyzing NK cells from responding, as indicated by NK cells still being capable of releasing cytotoxic granules when the stimulation signal bypassed receptor/ligand interactions and early signalling. VZV infection also inhibited NK cell production of IFN-γ and TNF cytokines, while HSV-1, a closely related virus, demonstrated a similar capacity to render NK cells unresponsive to target cell stimulation but differentially targeted cytokine production compared to VZV. These findings reveal a previously unreported strategy for VZV to manipulate the immune response.
Apparent motion (AM) is an illusory motion percept that can be induced when two stimuli are alternately presented at different locations. While some studies suggest that AM activates neurons in early visual cortex (V1) tuned to locations along the AM path, other studies have failed to find such activation. Behavioral studies have reported impaired perception of stimuli along the AM path, suggesting that AM-related activation in V1 interferes with the perception of physical stimuli. However, AM masking can also be explained by predictive coding models, which suggest that responses to stimuli presented on the AM path are suppressed when they match the spatio-temporal prediction of a stimulus moving along the path. In the present study, the authors used computational modeling to investigate the effects of AM on early visual processing. They found that AM-related activation in early visual cortex is too small to cause masking or to be perceived as motion, and that strong suppression of early sensory responses best explains the observed masking effects. These findings support the theoretical framework of predictive coding, which emphasizes the role of predictive signals in reducing prediction error and suppressing sensory signals that can be expected based on the higher-level hypothesis.
The HTLV-1 oncoprotein Tax plays a critical role in CD4+ T cell transformation by promoting cell proliferation and survival, mainly through permanent activation of the NF-κB pathway and induction of many NF-κB target genes. However, the molecular mechanism by which Tax activates the IKK complex, a key player in the NF-κB pathway, is not well understood due to the blending of primary Tax-induced IKK activation events and secondary IKK activation events induced by cytokines secreted by the primary Tax-induced IKK-NF-κB activation events. To dissect the essential cellular components for primary IKK activation by Tax, a cell-free system was reconstituted and it was found that Tax is a putative E3 ubiquitin ligase that, together with UbcH2, UbcH5c, or UbcH7, catalyzes the assembly of free unanchored mixed-linkage polyUb chains. These free mixed-linkage polyUb chains are then responsible for direct IKK activation by binding to the NEMO subunit of IKK. This study reveals the biochemical function of Tax in the process of IKK activation, which utilizes the minimal cellular ubiquitination components for NF-κB activation.
The establishment success of alien species is consistently determined by the number of individuals introduced to found a population, known as propagule pressure. A Bayesian meta-analytical review of a broad range of taxa and life histories, from invertebrates to long-lived trees and terrestrial and aquatic vertebrates, found a positive mean effect of propagule pressure on establishment success across all hypotheses tested. However, establishment success most critically depends on propagule pressures in the range of 10-100 individuals. Heterogeneity in effect size was primarily associated with different analytical approaches, with some evidence of larger effect sizes in animal rather than plant introductions. Studies conducted at spatial scales where data can be directly measured, such as experimental approaches, produced larger effect sizes compared to global surveys and those that are observational, likely due to data inconsistencies and errors. Proxies for components of propagule pressure, such as the number of individuals released, are often used due to difficulties in directly measuring propagule pressure, but these are expected to produce relatively weaker effect sizes compared to direct measures from observational or experimental studies. Overall, alien populations founded by more individuals are more likely to establish, and this relationship is clearly positive across all subsets of data analyzed. The rate at which establishment probability increases with incremental increases in the size of the founding population is remarkably consistent across experimental studies, and management needs to reduce alien species releases to very low levels to have confidence that establishment is unlikely.
Interleukin-17A (IL-17) is a cytokine that plays a significant role in chronic inflammation and host defense. It is implicated in the production of pro-inflammatory mediators, including IL-8, GM-CSF, and IL-6, by attenuating the decay of encoding mRNAs. The mRNA decay of these mediators depends on proteins (AUBPs) that target AU-rich elements in the 3′-untranslated region and facilitate either mRNA decay or stabilization. AUBPs and the target mRNA assemble in a novel ribonucleoprotein complex in the presence of microRNA16 (miR16), leading to the degradation of the target mRNA. IL-17 attenuates miR16 expression and promotes the binding of stabilizing AUBPs over that of destabilizing AUBPs, reducing mRNA decay. Since AUBPs affect expression of about 8% of the human transcriptome and miR16 is widely expressed, IL-17 may impact many other cellular processes. Additionally, IL-17 has been shown to synergize with TNF-α in IL-8 protein production by human lung epithelial-like NCI-H292 cells and human primary bronchial epithelial cells, primarily by attenuation of IL-8 mRNA degradation. The AUBPs KHSRP, TTP and AUF-1 have been implicated in IL-8 mRNA degradation, and TTP and KHSRP promote degradation of IL-8 mRNA. In contrast, AUF-1 protects IL-8 mRNA from degradation and enhances IL-8 mRNA expression. Knockdown of AUF-1 reduces IL-8 mRNA expression by 80-90% in cells exposed to TNF-α plus IL-17 or TNF-α alone. IL-17 promotes the contribution of AUF-1 to IL-8 protein expression. IL-17 changes the conformation of the complex between IL-8 mRNA, miR16 and the AUBPs, and both IL-8 mRNA and miR16 co-purify with these immuno-purified preparations, indicating a core complex that binds various AUBPs, miR16 and target mRNAs. Co-incubation with an anti-TTP antibody super-shifted some IL-8 probe, suggestive of a TTP-IL-8 mRNA complex in which TTP was accessible to anti-TTP. Failure to detect miR16 in this super-shifted material may indicate its absence, but may also be due to lack of sensitivity. These findings suggest an intricate interplay between the various AUBPs and miR16 in regulating IL-8 production, which also differs between cells exposed to TNF-α or TNF-α plus IL-17. In cells exposed to TNF-α, in which there is a profound IL-8 mRNA degradation, IL-8 mRNA is bound predominantly by KHSRP, TTP and miR16, which promote IL-8 mRNA degradation. In cells exposed to TNF-α plus IL-17, most IL-8 mRNA is bound to AUF-1 with no miR16 associated, which inhibits IL-8 mRNA degradation. Therefore, IL-17 changes the relative contribution of the AUBPs and miR16.
In Uganda, both chronic and acute forms of Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) are prevalent, with acute HAT traditionally restricted to the southeast and chronic HAT to the northwest, although this is changing. Acute HAT has been spreading rapidly to new districts, linked to the movement of infected cattle following restocking. Cattle act as long-term reservoirs of human infective trypanosomes, posing a significant risk to human health. A study was conducted in Kaberamaido and Dokolo Districts to examine the relationship between human T. b. rhodesiense infection and human infective and non-human T. brucei s. l. circulating in cattle at the village level. The study found that cattle from case villages had significantly higher odds of T. brucei s. l. infection and T. b. rhodesiense than those from non-case villages. Cattle age also had a significant effect on the likelihood of T. brucei s. l. infection. These findings highlight the importance of understanding the relationship between infected cattle and infected individuals to respond appropriately to the risk posed by animals infected with human pathogens in a village setting. The continuing northward spread of Rhodesian sleeping sickness in Uganda raises the prospect of an overlap between Rhodesian and Gambian foci, which would complicate diagnosis and treatment. Surveillance of animal trypanosomiasis has been suspended in Uganda due to budgetary restrictions and decentralization of veterinary services, making it difficult to calculate the true burden and impact of HAT.
The NSL complex, which contains the MOF protein, is a major histone H4 lysine 16-specific acetyltransferase in mammals and Drosophila. In Drosophila, the NSL complex is involved in the regulation of both X-chromosomal and autosomal genes as part of the MSL and NSL complexes, respectively. While the function of the MSL complex in dosage compensation is well understood, the role of the NSL complex in gene regulation is not well characterized. To gain insight into the function of the NSL complex, a comprehensive ChIP-seq analysis of four NSL complex members was performed in Drosophila melanogaster. The analysis revealed that the majority of NSL-bound genes are constitutively expressed across different cell types and are characterized by an increased abundance of the histone modifications H4K16ac, H3K4me2, H3K4me3, and H3K9ac in gene promoter regions. These genes also have a well-defined nucleosome free region and broad transcription initiation patterns. Furthermore, both NSL proteins, NSL1 and NSL3, are required for efficient recruitment of RNA polymerase II (Pol II) to NSL target gene promoters. The observed Pol II reduction coincides with compromised binding of TBP and TFIIB to target promoters, indicating that the NSL complex is required for optimal recruitment of the pre-initiation complex on target genes. Genes that undergo the most dramatic loss of Pol II upon NSL knockdowns tend to be enriched in DNA Replication–related Element (DRE). These findings show that the MOF-containing NSL complex acts as a major regulator of housekeeping genes in flies by modulating initiation of Pol II transcription.
Researchers have created transgenic mice carrying D4Z4 arrays from an FSHD1 allele and a control allele to study Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy (FSHD), a muscular dystrophy caused by decreased epigenetic repression of the D4Z4 macrosatellite repeats and ectopic expression of DUX4. The mice recapitulate important epigenetic and DUX4 expression attributes seen in patients, making them a valuable animal model for FSHD. FSHD is caused by D4Z4 repeat contraction-dependent or -independent chromatin relaxation in somatic tissues, leading to low levels of DUX4 mRNA expression in skeletal muscle. The mice show high DUX4 expression levels in the germline, incomplete epigenetic repression in somatic tissue, and FSHD-specific variegated DUX4 expression in sporadic muscle nuclei associated with D4Z4 chromatin relaxation. DUX4 is able to activate similar functional gene groups in mouse muscle cells as it does in human muscle cells. These transgenic mice are a useful resource to study the molecular mechanisms underlying FSHD and to test new therapeutic intervention strategies.
A malaria vaccine candidate, Apical Membrane Antigen-1 (AMA1), has shown to induce protection but only against parasite strains closely related to the vaccine. Overcoming this problem requires understanding the structural basis of cross-strain invasion inhibition. A vaccine containing four diverse allelic proteins (AMA1 Quadvax or QV) elicited polyclonal rabbit antibodies that inhibited the invasion of various vaccine and non-vaccine strains of P. falciparum. QV induced higher levels of broadly inhibitory antibodies compared to a strain-specific, monovalent, 3D7 AMA1 vaccine. This was associated with increased conserved face and domain-3 responses and reduced domain-2 response. Inhibitory monoclonal antibodies (mAb) raised against the QV reacted with a novel cross-reactive epitope at the rim of the hydrophobic trough on domain-1, which mapped to the conserved face of AMA1 and encompassed the 1e-loop. These mAbs were more potent than previously characterized AMA1-inhibitory mAbs and inhibited AMA1 binding to its ligand RON2. Despite the availability of effective drugs, malaria mortality remains a global health and economic concern, with increasing drug resistance to front-line antimalarials. A vaccine that prevents the disease or reduces the parasite burden is urgently needed. Human anti-malarial antibodies can inhibit invasion, and antigens that induce invasion inhibitory antibodies are primary candidates for vaccine development. AMA1 is a promising vaccine candidate, with anti-AMA1 antibodies inhibiting the invasion of merozoites into red blood cells, and inhibitory activity correlating with protection in non-human primate malaria models. However, inhibitory AMA1 antibodies are highly strain-dependent, and vaccination with a yeast-derived bivalent mixture of 3D7 and FVO alleles did not enhance inhibition against non-vaccine strains. Synthesized as an 83 kDa trans-membrane protein, native AMA1 undergoes maturation to a 66 kDa form, which then translocates to the merozoite surface. During the invasion process, AMA1 undergoes proteolytic shedding to yield 48 and 44 kDa soluble forms. Once on the merozoite surface, the 66 kDa AMA1 form interacts with the parasite RON proteins, which are integrated into the host cell membrane. The understanding of the biological role of AMA1 during invasion has prompted researchers to target the AMA1-RON2 interaction for vaccine development.
The asymmetric division of cells, which involves the unequal distribution of cell fate determinants and cell size, is a crucial process in many organisms. This asymmetry is often achieved through the displacement of the mother cell's mitotic spindle to an asymmetric position within the cell before cytokinesis. While the molecular mechanisms behind spindle displacement have begun to be elucidated, the precise timing of this process is not well understood. A recent study in the Caenorhabditis elegans zygote found that the anaphase-promoting complex (APC), its activator Cdc20/Fizzy, its degradation target cyclin, and cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) comprise a previously unrecognized timer for spindle displacement. The APC and Cdc20/Fizzy delay spindle displacement, while inactivating CDK in prometaphase causes the spindle to displace early. This delay ensures that the spindle does not begin to move until it is fully assembled. This is the first demonstration of a link between the cell cycle and asymmetric cell division in an animal cell. The mitotic spindle is displaced at a similar stage of mitosis during asymmetric cell divisions in diverse systems, suggesting that this link between the cell cycle and asymmetric cell division may be evolutionarily conserved.
High-altitude regions, which lie above 2,500 meters sea level, pose severe challenges to human habitation due to reduced ambient oxygen tension caused by decreased barometric pressure, a condition known as high-altitude hypoxia. The Andean Altiplano and the Tibetan Plateau are two high-altitude regions where humans have lived for millennia, leading to unique circulatory, respiratory, and hematological adaptations. While these physiological responses have been well-studied, the genetic basis underlying these adaptations remains unclear. A genome scan identified genes showing evidence of adaptation to hypoxia in both Andean and Tibetan populations. These populations exhibit largely distinct genetic adaptations, with both showing evidence of positive natural selection in different genes or gene regions. However, the EGLN1 gene, known to be important in cellular oxygen sensing, shows evidence of positive selection in both Tibetans and Andeans, albeit with different patterns of variation. The results suggest that several key HIF-regulatory and targeted genes are responsible for adaptation to high altitude in Andeans and Tibetans, with multiple chromosomal regions implicated in the response to selection. These findings provide a basis for future genotype/phenotype association studies necessary to confirm the role of selection-nominated candidate genes and gene regions in adaptation to altitude.
Inverted DNA repeats (IRs) near a double-strand break (DSB) in DNA can lead to genomic instabilities by channeling repair from accurate pathways to break-induced replication (BIR) pathways. This occurs due to the formation of unusual DNA structures when IRs are present in single-stranded DNA resulting from DSB resection. IRs can form two types of unusual DNA structures, determined by the length of the spacer separating them. IRs separated by a long (1-kb) spacer are predominantly involved in inter-molecular single-strand annealing (SSA) leading to the formation of inverted dimers, while IRs separated by a short (12-bp) spacer participate in intra-molecular SSA, leading to the formation of fold-back (FB) structures. Both of these structures interfere with accurate DSB repair by gene conversion and promote genomic destabilization. Different protein complexes are involved in processing FBs containing short (12-bp) versus long (1-kb) single-stranded DNA loops. Given the high abundance of IRs in the human genome, this research may contribute to the understanding of IR-mediated genomic destabilization associated with human disease.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an opportunistic pathogen that can cause both acute and chronic infections in susceptible hosts, with chronic infections thought to be caused by bacterial biofilms. A study was conducted to develop an animal model for studying P. aeruginosa biofilm infections in Drosophila melanogaster. The researchers found that at 24 hours post oral infection, P. aeruginosa biofilms localized to and were visualized in dissected Drosophila crops, with a characteristic aggregate structure and an extracellular matrix composed of DNA and exopolysaccharide. P. aeruginosa cells recovered from in vivo grown biofilms had increased antibiotic resistance relative to planktonically grown cells. In vivo biofilm formation was dependent on expression of the pel exopolysaccharide genes. The pelB::lux mutant failed to form biofilms and was significantly more virulent than PAO1, while a hyperbiofilm strain (PAZHI3) demonstrated significantly less virulence than PAO1. Biofilm formation was associated with induction of antimicrobial peptide gene expression, while infection with the non-biofilm forming strain pelB::lux resulted in decreased AMP gene expression in the fly. This research provides novel insights into host-pathogen interactions during P. aeruginosa oral infection of Drosophila and highlights the use of Drosophila as an infection model that permits the study of P. aeruginosa biofilms in vivo.
The vasopressin receptor 1a gene (Avpr1a) shows significant variation in expression patterns both within and between species, which is responsible for differences in vasopressin-mediated social behaviors. While previous research suggested that both the proximal 5' flanking region and a polymorphic microsatellite element within that region of the vole Avpr1a gene are associated with variation in V1a receptor (V1aR) distribution and behavior, neither has been causally linked. A study using homologous recombination in mice revealed that proximal 5' flanking sequences have a modest contribution to species differences in V1aR distribution and confirmed that variation in V1aR distribution affects stress-coping in the forced swim test. The study also demonstrated that the vole Avpr1a microsatellite structure affects Avpr1a expression in the amygdala, thalamus, and hippocampus, mirroring some of the inter- and intra-species differences observed in central V1aR patterns in voles. This study provides the first direct evidence that polymorphic microsatellite elements near behaviorally relevant genes can contribute to diversity in brain gene expression profiles, offering a mechanism for generating behavioral diversity both at the individual and species level. However, the study suggests that many features of species-specific expression patterns are mediated by elements outside of the immediate 5' flanking region of the gene. Overall, this research highlights the complexity of genomic mechanisms that contribute to phenotypic diversity across species and among individuals within a species, particularly in behavioral traits.
In B cells, transcription of the switch (S) regions of immunoglobulin genes generates R-loops, which are targeted by AID, leading to class switch recombination (CSR) and translocations with c-MYC, contributing to Burkitt's lymphomas. In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, R-loops formed co-transcriptionally in THO mutants trigger genome instability and facilitate deamination by human AID. A yeast chromosomal system was developed to analyze chromosomal rearrangements in both wild-type and THO mutants, demonstrating that AID acts in yeast at heterologous S and c-MYC transcribed sequences, leading to double-strand breaks (DSBs) and translocations via Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ). AID-induced translocations were strongly enhanced in yeast THO null mutants, consistent with the idea that AID-mediated DSBs depend on R-loop formation. This study provides new insights into the role of mRNP biogenesis in preventing genome rearrangements and the mechanism of AID-mediated genome instability, highlighting the conserved factors and pathways required for AID-mediated DNA lesions leading to DSBs responsible for NHEJ-dependent genome rearrangements and CSR in both yeast and mammalian B cells.
In Escherichia coli, the coordination of cell division and chromosome replication is crucial for producing viable offspring. It was traditionally thought that this coordination is achieved through the precise positioning of the cell division apparatus relative to the nucleoids. However, recent studies have shown that cells lacking proper positioning of their cell division planes can still propagate. These studies have also characterized how these cells partition their chromosomes into daughter cells during asymmetric divisions. Quantitative time-lapse imaging has shown that the DNA translocase, FtsK, can pump as much as 80% (3.7 Mb) of the chromosome from one daughter compartment to another at an average rate of 1700±800 bp/s. The majority of DNA movement occurs at the latest stages of cell division, after the cell division protein ZipA has already dissociated from the septum and the septum has closed to a narrow channel. These findings suggest that the narrow constriction is necessary for effective translocation of DNA by FtsK. While much is known about FtsK interactions with DNA at the atomic and molecular scales, there is limited understanding of how FtsK functions in partitioning DNA in the cellular context when it is attached to the divisome. Recent studies have shown that FtsK is involved in the ordered segregation of the replication terminus region of the E. coli chromosome, and appears to be the fastest known DNA processing machine in vitro, with pumping rates ranging from 5 kb/s at 20°C to 16 kb/s at 37°C. However, in vitro assays have shown that periods of fast pumping are interrupted by spontaneous reversals and dissociations from DNA. FtsK is able to displace and sometimes bypass many DNA binding proteins, but its interactions with DNA in the cellular context when it is attached to the divisome are not well understood.
Epitope-based vaccines (EVs) have a wide range of applications, from therapeutic to prophylactic approaches, and from infectious diseases to cancer. The development of an EV is based on the knowledge of target-specific antigens from which immunogenic peptides, called epitopes, are derived. However, due to regulatory, economic, and practical concerns, the number of epitopes that can be included in an EV is limited. Additionally, the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) binding these epitopes is highly polymorphic, making the optimal selection of these epitopes an important and interesting optimization problem. A mathematical framework based on integer linear programming (ILP) has been presented to address this problem, which allows the formulation of various flavors of the vaccine design problem and the efficient identification of optimal sets of epitopes. This ILP approach outperforms other strategies and has been shown to be flexible and effective in selecting a set of epitopes that is most likely to elicit a broad and potent immune response while considering common immunological requirements. The use of EVs has numerous advantages, including safety, ease of production, analytical control, and distribution, and is applicable in personalized vaccination. Recent studies have shown the success of EVs in preclinical and clinical trials for various cancers and infectious diseases. The design of an EV entails the critical step of epitope selection, which is usually made on a case-by-case basis, considering key properties such as overall immunogenicity, mutation tolerance, population coverage, antigen coverage, and antigen processing. Various methods, both experimental and computational, have been used to determine the relevant attributes of each candidate, but the final choice of the set of epitopes is typically performed manually. In this work, an integer linear programming approach is proposed to find a provably optimal set of epitopes for an EV, considering various quality criteria such as population coverage, antigen coverage, and overall immunogenicity. This approach outperforms other methods and is flexible enough to account for personalized vaccines.
HIV-1, the virus responsible for AIDS, is predominantly transmitted from men to women through vaginal intercourse via virus-containing semen deposited on the cervico-vaginal mucosa. Semen contains various biological factors, including cytokines, that can impact HIV-1 transmission. One such cytokine is IL-7, which is elevated in the seminal plasma of HIV-1-infected individuals. In an ex vivo study using human cervico-vaginal tissue, IL-7 was found to enhance HIV-1 replication, promote the proliferation of CD4+ T cells, and prevent apoptosis of these cells. This pro-viral role of IL-7 was observed with various HIV-1 strains and primary isolates, irrespective of viral inoculum dilution or the addition of seminal fluid. These findings suggest that high levels of seminal IL-7 during early-stage HIV-1 infection may contribute to the survival and local expansion of HIV-1-infected cells in the cervico-vaginal mucosa, thereby promoting the dissemination of the virus.
RNA interference (RNAi) plays a crucial role in controlling arbovirus infections in mosquitoes, with two RNAi pathways involved: the PIWI-interacting RNA (piRNA) and exogenous short interfering RNA (exo-siRNA) pathways. The exo-siRNA pathway is considered the primary mosquito antiviral response mechanism. In Aedes aegypti-derived cells, Zika virus (ZIKV) induces the production of ZIKV-specific siRNAs, which are loaded into the exo-siRNA pathway effector protein Argonaute 2 (Ago2). However, the knockdown of Ago2 does not enhance virus replication, while a Dcr2-knockout cell line shows enhanced ZIKV replication, indicating the exo-siRNA pathway's antiviral role. The piRNA pathway, although suggested to be antiviral, has only been shown to involve Piwi4, which does not bind piRNAs. Instead, Piwi4 is involved in the control of alphavirus, bunyavirus, and ZIKV replication. The ZIKV capsid (C) protein amplifies the replication of an alphavirus-based reporter system, but it does not display exo-siRNA pathway inhibition like the yellow fever virus (YFV) C protein. These findings contribute to understanding the specific arbovirus-vector interaction, which may support efforts to understand the rapid spread of this virus.
Sporotrichosis is a subcutaneous mycosis with a worldwide distribution, but it is highly endemic in Latin America. Historically, sporotrichosis has been attributed to a single species, Sporothrix schenckii, but recent taxonomic analyses have led to the identification of four new species in the Sporothrix complex. In Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, sporotrichosis is largely occurring via transmission from infected cats to humans, and the main purpose of this study was to investigate a possible association between manifestations of sporotrichosis in Rio de Janeiro and the different genomic species of S. schenckii sensu lato. A cross-sectional study was performed in 50 patients with different clinical forms of sporotrichosis, and their isolates were studied by phenotypic and genotypic methods. The findings suggest that Sporothrix species are linked to different clinical manifestations of sporotrichosis and that S. brasiliensis is effectively treated with oral itraconazole. S. brasiliensis was associated with disseminated cutaneous infection without underlying disease, hypersensitivity reactions, and mucosal infection, whereas patients with S. schenckii presented with less severe and more often localized disease. Additionally, S. brasiliensis-infected patients required shorter durations of itraconazole compared to individuals with S. schenckii. This study highlights the importance of understanding the clinical implications of recent advances in the molecular taxonomy of Sporothrix.
A series of studies have indicated that a larger portion of the mammalian genome is transcribed than previously thought, but the quantity and nature of these additional transcripts remains unclear. To assess the quantity and composition of transcripts in PolyA+ RNA from human and mouse tissues, data from single- and paired-end RNA-Seq and tiling arrays was analyzed. The results showed that RNA-Seq identifies many fewer transcribed regions outside known exons and ncRNAs compared to tiling arrays. Most nonexonic seqfrags are in introns, and the majority of intergenic seqfrags in RNA-Seq data are near known genes, consistent with alternative cleavage and polyadenylation site usage, promoter- and terminator-associated transcripts, or new alternative exons. Most remaining seqfrags correspond to either single reads that display characteristics of random sampling from a low-level background or several thousand small transcripts present at higher levels, which also tend to display sequence conservation and originate from regions with open chromatin. While there are bona fide new intergenic transcripts, their number and abundance is generally low in comparison to known exons. Therefore, the genome is not as pervasively transcribed as previously reported.
A combined computational and experimental method was developed to increase the thermal stability of the flavin mononucleotide based fluorescent protein Bacillus Subtilis YtvA LOV domain by 31 degrees Celsius, thus extending its applicability in thermophilic systems. The method includes five steps: single mutant computer screening to identify thermostable mutant candidates, experimental evaluation to confirm positive selections, computational redesign around the thermostable mutation regions, experimental reevaluation, and multiple mutations combination. This simple and effective method can be applied to other important proteins where other methods have difficulties, providing a new tool to improve protein thermostability. Protein stability is crucial for its application in biotechnology, and currently, there are three main protein engineering methods: directed evolution, sequence consensus, and rational design. Each of these methods has its strengths and weaknesses and has been used to improve protein thermostability with some success. However, predicting the stability increase for a specific protein is challenging, and many computational screening methods have been developed with high efficiency but moderate accuracy. A more recent study using an alchemical free energy method to study point mutation effects on the thermostability of a barnase demonstrated much better accuracy. The free energy method utilizes a well-defined structure to model the mutational effect on the folded state and a small peptide to model the effect on the unfolded state, providing a rigorous way to calculate the free energy change caused by a point mutation. This method is computationally more expensive than quick screening methods but provides a more accurate prediction of protein thermostability.
A study was conducted in the Panama Canal watershed, specifically on Barro Colorado Island, to investigate the sand fly species' diversity and their infection status of both Leishmania and Wolbachia pipientis. The study aimed to determine the phylogenetic relationships of the sand fly species and identify the presence of disease-causing parasites and bacteria. The researchers collected and analyzed 437 sand flies, representing 17 Lutzomyia and 2 Brumptomyia species. The findings revealed five man-biting species, including Lu. panamensis, Lu. trapidoi, Lu. olmeca, Lu. gomezi, and Lu. carrerai thula, accounting for over 61% of the individuals collected.Neighbor-joining analysis of CO1 sequence separated the genera Brumptomyia and Lutzomyia and unambiguously assigned 43 individuals to 13 morphological species. The analysis also suggested the presence of two cryptic or misdiagnosed species within the group of 16 morphologically determined Lutzomyia species. Both Maximum Likelihood (ML) and Bayesian Inference (BI) trees placed the 16 Lutzomyia species into two apparently deep clades. The Leishmania infected species, Lu. trapidoi and Lu. gomezi, occurred isolated within separate, well-supported clades in both BI and ML trees. The prevalence of Leishmania ranged from 0% in 18 species to 26.3% in Lu. gomezi and 43.3% in Lu. trapidoi.Wolbachia infections were found in two species, Lu. trapidoi and Lu. vespertilionis. The prevalence of Wolbachia ranged from 0% in 17 species to 53.3% in Lu. trapidoi and 68.8% in Lu. vespertilionis. Three Wolbachia strains were identified in the study, with Lu. trapidoi individuals uniformly infected with a single Wolbachia strain. The study also found that Wolbachia MLST is preferred over the surface-protein (WSP) for characterizing Wolbachia strains.In summary, the study identified 19 sand fly species in the Panama Canal watershed, with five man-biting species accounting for over 61% of the individuals collected. The Leishmania parasite was found in two species, Lu. trapidoi and Lu. gomezi, while Wolbachia bacteria were found in Lu. trapidoi and Lu. vespertilionis. The study underscores the importance of understanding the phylogenetic relationships and infection status of sand fly species to mitigate the impact of diseases transmitted by these insects.
Human Cytomegalovirus (HCMV) establishes lifelong latency in the host, with sporadic reactivation that is important for sero-prevalence. However, reactivation in immune-compromised transplant recipients or late-stage AIDS sufferers causes significant morbidity and mortality. HCMV establishes latency in hematopoietic cells of the bone marrow and reactivates upon differentiation and/or stimulation of these cells, augmented by inflammatory cytokine signalling. ERK-MAPK signalling, activated by diverse ligands, promotes nuclear translocation and phosphorylation of target proteins, including transcription factors and histone proteins that may have roles in HCMV immediate early gene expression regulation. A study found that CREB binding to the MIEP is necessary for recruiting the kinase activity of MSKs to initiate chromatin remodelling at the MIEP required for HCMV reactivation.
