RNA was prepared from PPD-stimulated PBMC from vaccinated-protected, vaccinated-unprotected, and unvaccinated control cattle prior to M. bovis challenge, and global gene expression was determined by RNA-seq. The study found that 668 genes were differentially expressed in vaccinated-protected cattle compared with vaccinated-unprotected and unvaccinated control cattle. Cytokine-cytokine receptor interaction was the most significant pathway related to this dataset with IL-22 expression identified as the dominant surrogate of protection besides INF-γ. The expression of these candidate genes identified by RNA-seq was evaluated by RT-qPCR in an independent set of PBMC samples from BCG vaccinated and unvaccinated calves, confirming the importance of IL-22 as a predictor of vaccine efficacy. The study suggests that the identification of predictive biomarkers would greatly facilitate the development of a vaccine against bTB, and that BCG remains the prototype vaccine against which to judge the efficacy of any novel vaccine strategies.
Non-centrosomal microtubule organizing centers (ncMTOCs) are present in most differentiated cells, but the regulation of microtubule organization and dynamics by these structures is largely unknown. A tissue-specific degradation system was optimized to test the role of the essential centrosomal microtubule nucleators γ-TuRC and AIR-1/Aurora A at the apical ncMTOC in Caenorhabditis elegans embryonic intestinal epithelial cells. The core γ-TuRC component GIP-1/GCP3 is required to recruit other γ-TuRC components to the apical ncMTOC, while AIR-1 and MZT-1 are specifically required to recruit γ-TuRC to the centrosome but not to the apical ncMTOC. Surprisingly, microtubules remain robustly organized at the apical ncMTOC upon γ-TuRC and AIR-1 co-depletion and upon depletion of other known microtubule regulators. However, loss of GIP-1 removes a subset of dynamic EBP-2/EB1-marked microtubules, and the remaining dynamic microtubules grow faster. These results suggest that different MTOCs use discrete proteins for their function and that the apical ncMTOC is composed of distinct populations of γ-TuRC-dependent and -independent microtubules that compete for a limited pool of resources.
Human genomes are characterized by their diploid nature, with one set of chromosomes inherited maternally and one set inherited paternally. However, most human sequencing initiatives do not directly delineate the nucleotide content of the maternal and paternal copies of the 23 chromosomes. A comparison of 11 different methods for phasing human genomes using the publicly available Genome-In-A-Bottle (GIAB) phased version of the NA12878 genome as a gold standard found that a hybrid or combined approach provides a fast and efficient way to produce highly accurate phase-resolved individual human genomes. This approach leverages population-based phasing using the SHAPEIT software suite, either genome-wide sequencing read data or parental genotypes, and a large reference panel of variant and haplotype frequencies. The use of parental genotype data within a population-based phasing strategy can provide a ten-fold reduction in phasing errors. Whole genome sequencing of individual human genomes has been made possible by advances in DNA sequencing technology, but issues remain due to inherent limitations in current sequencing technologies. Understanding how cis and trans combinations of variants impact phenotypic expression is crucial in human biology and depends critically on having phase information, i.e., knowing the unique nucleotide content of each of the two chromosomes making up the 23 pairs. Most genome sequencing strategies do not segregate the nucleotide content of each copy of a homologous chromosome pair and identify nucleotides at each position of a genome, recording each SNV position as having either one copy of a non-reference nucleotide and one copy of a reference nucleotide, two copies of a non-reference nucleotide, two copies of the 'reference' nucleotide, or two different non-reference nucleotides. Phase information is only relevant for heterozygous loci, i.e., where there is a difference in the nucleotide content of homologous chromosome pair. Obtaining phase (haplotype) information is often non-trivial. There are a number of very important genetically-mediated phenomena for which characterization depends critically on phase information. Strategies for obtaining phase information include elaborate laboratory protocols, de novo assembly computational methods, and population haplotype frequency information. By far the most straightforward strategy for obtaining phase information from genome sequencing involves sequencing the parents (and/or other relatives) of an individual whose genome is to be phased. This way, Mendel’s laws can be used to essentially observe which variants were inherited from each of the parents. However, even with parental sequence information there are problems that can plague obtaining phase information.
Type-III protein secretion systems are used by gram-negative pathogens for the secretion of flagellar components and virulence effectors. The flagellar type-III secretion system (fT3SS) is composed of a cytoplasmic and inner-membrane export apparatus, which is responsible for the translocation of proteins across the inner membrane. The fT3SS is assembly initiated in the cytoplasmic membrane and consists of the integral membrane proteins FlhB, FlhA, FliO, FliP, FliQ and FliR. A cytoplasmic ATPase complex composed of the FliI, FliH and FliJ proteins is functionally associated with the fT3SS. It was previously thought that ATP hydrolysis was the energy source for type-III secretion, but it has been shown that the proton motive force (PMF) is essential for flagellar type-III secretion. ATP hydrolysis may energize chaperone release and secretion substrate unfolding, while the FliHIJ proteins are involved in localizing the ATPase/secretion substrate complexes to the vicinity of the export gate and facilitating FliI hexamer ring formation. In this study, it was demonstrated that type-III protein secretion can efficiently occur in the absence of ATPase activity in both flagellar and virulence-associated T3SS. The authors isolated and characterized spontaneous suppressor mutants that assemble flagella in a ΔfliHI genetic background and identified candidates for genes that could account for the motile suppression phenotypes, including the clpXP operon, ATP synthase structural genes, and a set of flagellar genes that included a negative regulatory gene of the flagellar-specific transcription factor σ28. The deletion of these genes and the flgM anti-σ28 factor, or a FlgM-resistant σ28 mutant, raised motility levels in various fliHIJ deletion backgrounds. An artificial induction of an additional PMF-draining system counteracted the suppressor phenotype of the atpA deletion of various fliHIJ deletion mutants in a motility assay. The type-III secretion apparatus is a PMF-powered protein exporter and increased PMF due to the atpA deletion provided additional energy to overcome the requirement of the flagellar ATPase complex for flagellar assembly. Deletion mutants of fliI, fliHI and fliHIJ were non-flagellated, but the absence of atpA in a fliHI deletion mutant increased the frequency of flagella formation. The authors concluded that a 20% increase in PMF substantially enhances fT3SS export capability and bypasses the FliHIJ ATPase requirement for flagellar function.
Bistability, which refers to the coexistence of two stable equilibria in a dynamical system, is crucial in many cellular processes such as signal transduction, cell fate specification, cell cycle regulation, apoptosis, and competence development. It has been observed in various cell biological networks, including the Cdc2 activation circuit in Xenopus egg extracts and the lactose utilization network in E. coli. Mathematical tools such as bifurcation theory can be used to determine if a network is bistable, but because the dynamical behavior of a network depends on the values of the system parameters (e.g., reaction rates), and the number of parameters required for an accurate description of even simple systems is typically large and uncertain, new bistable circuit architectures tend to be identified only slowly and on a network-by-network basis. Chemical reaction network theory (CRNT), which gives conditions for the existence, multiplicity, and stability of steady states in systems of nonlinear ODEs derived from mass-action kinetics, offers a novel framework for the rapid identification of network topologies with the capacity for bistability.In a study, the authors applied CRNT to reaction network models representing a broad class of small gene regulatory networks (GRNs) consisting of two transcription factor (TF)-coding genes and their associated proteins. They identified 36,771 bistable GRN architectures out of a total of 40,680. Approximately 40% of the bistable systems were confirmed as such using existing computational tools, with the remainder identified through the novel concept of network ancestry. Despite its large size, the entire two-gene bistable network family can be understood as descended from a set of only eleven minimal bistable networks, that is, bistable networks that do not contain within them a smaller bistable subnetwork and, as a consequence, are rendered monostable by the removal of one or more network reactions. The authors demonstrated how a general theoretical survey of this kind has unique predictive power to identify bistable modules in organisms that have not been fully explored from a functional genomics perspective. The study highlights the potential of parameter-free modeling in simplifying the study of complex regulatory networks, understanding network evolution, and designing new synthetic biological circuits.In summary, bistability plays a crucial role in many essential biological functions, and CRNT offers a powerful tool for the rapid identification of network topologies with the capacity for bistability. A comprehensive in silico survey of more than 40,000 simple networks that can be formed by two transcription factor-coding genes and their associated proteins found that there exist reaction rate constants leading to bistability in ∼90% of these GRN models. The study identified 36,771 bistable GRN architectures out of a total of 40,680 and demonstrated that the capacity for switch-like behavior in GRNs arises with relative ease and is not easily lost through network evolution.
Orofacial clefting is a common birth defect with both genetic and environmental causes, and it can be syndromic or non-syndromic. While the genetic etiology of orofacial clefting is not fully understood, a study has identified mutations in the HYAL2 gene as a cause of syndromic orofacial clefting. HYAL2 encodes hyaluronidase 2, which degrades extracellular hyaluronan, a critical component of the developing heart and palatal shelf matrix. Transfection assays showed that gene mutations destabilize the molecule, reducing HYAL2 protein levels. Consistent with the clinical presentation in affected individuals, investigations of Hyal2-/- mice revealed craniofacial abnormalities, including submucosal cleft palate, cor triatriatum sinister, and hearing loss. These findings suggest that HYAL2 and hyaluronan turnover are essential for normal human and mouse development, and they define the first molecular cause of human cor triatriatum sinister. However, the majority of orofacial cleft cases are of unknown molecular cause, and both environmental influences and non-coding or regulatory genomic regions may play a role. Further studies are needed to fully understand the genetic etiology of this heterogeneous condition.
In the inner ear, sound detection by hair cells requires tip links between stereocilia, which are interconnected by mechanosensory hair bundles. These tip links are formed by cadherin 23 (CDH23) and protocadherin 15 (PCDH15) proteins, with PCDH15 at the lower end and CDH2
Dengue virus is a leading cause of arboviral disease, resulting in an estimated 100 million symptomatic infections annually. The virus can cause a range of clinical manifestations, from dengue fever (DF) to the more severe and life-threatening dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF). A study using mass spectrometry-based metabolomic profiling on sera from adult DF and DHF patients in the critical and recovery phases of infection identified 29 differentially expressed metabolites between DF and DHF during the critical phase. These include bile acids, purines, acylcarnitines, phospholipids, and amino acids. Bile acids were observed at up to 5-fold higher levels in DHF patients compared to DF patients and were significantly correlated with higher levels of aspartate transaminase and alanine transaminase, indicating liver injury in DHF. Uric acid, a major antioxidant in the blood, was observed at 1.5-fold lower levels in DHF patients, suggesting decreased capacity of endogenous antioxidant defense and elevated oxidative stress in DHF patients. In the recovery phase, the levels of eight metabolites were still significantly higher or lower in DHF patients, indicating potential prolonged adverse impact on the liver due to DENV infection in DHF patients. The study's results provide insights into the different host and DENV interactions between DF and DHF, and advance our understanding of the mechanisms of DHF pathogenesis, alluding to possible novel therapeutic targets for dengue management.
A study of the purine nucleotide metabolic pathway in the parasitic protozoan Trypanosoma brucei, which causes African trypanosomiasis, has identified and characterized guanosine 5’-monophosphate reductase (GMPR). This enzyme catalyzes the deamination of GMP to IMP and plays a crucial role in maintaining the balance of intracellular purine nucleotide concentration. The T. brucei GMPR was found to be localized in glycosomes and has a unique insertion of a tandem repeat of the cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) domain, which is absent in mammalian and bacterial GMPRs. The recombinant protein of T. brucei GMPR showed distinct enzymatic characteristics and affinities for both GMP and NADPH compared to its mammalian counterparts. The addition of monovalent cations such as K+ and NH4+ increased the GMPR activity of T. brucei, while none of the mammalian GMPRs were affected by these cations. The monophosphate form of the purine nucleoside analog ribavirin inhibited T. brucei GMPR activity, though mammalian GMPRs showed no or little inhibition by it. The inhibitory effect of ribavirin on the proliferation of trypanosomes in a dose-dependent manner suggests the potential of developing a new therapeutic agent against African trypanosomiasis.
Sodium channel blockers are crucial for controlling electrical excitability in cells, used for treating epileptic seizures, cardiac arrhythmia, and providing short-term pain relief. Developing next-generation drugs that specifically target one of the nine types of voltage-gated sodium channels requires a better understanding of how current channel blockers work. This study utilizes the recent crystal structure of the bacterial voltage-gated sodium channel NavAb to determine drug-binding positions and understand how these drugs enter resting channels. The researchers found that benzocaine and phenytoin have two primary binding sites in the pore, characterized by non-specific, hydrophobic interactions: one just above the activation gate, and one at the entrance to the lateral lipid-filled fenestrations. Both drugs can pass through the fenestrations into the lipid with minimal energy barriers, suggesting this can represent the long-posited hydrophobic entrance route for neutral drugs. Simulations highlight the importance of specific residues in directing drugs into and through the fenestration and in forming the drug-binding sites. This study contributes to the development of subtype-selective Nav channel blockers, which could lead to a new range of clinical applications and a decrease in side effects.
MyD88-mediated signaling plays a crucial role in protecting the host against intestinal bacterial infections. While it is known that MyD88-deficient mice are highly susceptible to various bacterial infections, the specific contribution of MyD88 in protecting the host in different immune and non-immune cell types during intestinal infection is not well understood. A study using a mouse knock-in model with cell type-specific reactivation of functional MyD88 expression in MyD88-deficient mice investigated the importance of MyD88 in specific cell types during intestinal infection. The results showed that functional MyD88 signaling in CD11c+ cells was sufficient to activate intestinal dendritic cells and induce early group 3 innate lymphoid cell response as well as the development of colonic Th17/Th1 cells in response to infection with C. rodentium. Restricting MyD88 signaling to several other cell types, including macrophages, T cells or ILC3 did not induce efficient intestinal immune responses upon infection. However, the functional expression of MyD88 in intestinal epithelial cells was also partially protective during intestinal infection, associated with enhanced epithelial barrier integrity and increased expression of the antimicrobial peptide RegIIIγ and the acute phase protein SAA1 by epithelial cells. In conclusion, MyD88 signaling in DC and IEC is both essential and sufficient to induce a full spectrum of host responses upon intestinal infection with C. rodentium.
Onchocerciasis, or river blindness, is a parasitic disease caused by the filarial worm Onchocerca volvulus, affecting millions of people in Africa. The disease is transmitted through the bite of infected blackflies and can lead to visual impairment, blindness, skin lesions, and severe itching. Large-scale control programs have been implemented to eliminate the disease, including the Onchocerciasis Control Programme in West Africa and the African Programme for Onchocerciasis Control (APOC). These programs have led to a decline in the prevalence of infection, and some areas have even eliminated the disease.To determine whether transmission of the disease has been interrupted and mass treatment can stop, an immunodiagnostic test is used to detect human IgG4 antibodies in the blood to the Onchocerca volvulus-specific antigen Ov16. The relationship between post-mass drug administration (MDA) Ov16 antibody prevalence in children and the duration and coverage of MDA, the mf prevalence in the population, and the probability that onchocerciasis is eventually eliminated has been explored through mathematical modeling.The ONCHOSIM model was extended to include information on the Ov16 antibody serostatus of simulated individuals. The model was used to study trends in Ov16 antibody prevalence and to explore how it is related to local transmission conditions, the duration and coverage of mass treatment, test characteristics, mf prevalence, and the probability that the infection is eventually eliminated. The results showed that both the microfiladermia prevalence in the population aged 5 years and above and the Ov16 antibody prevalence in children under 10 declined with increasing duration of MDA. The association between either of these indicators and the model-predicted probability of elimination was found to depend on baseline endemicity levels, assumptions regarding the trigger of seroconversion, and diagnostic test characteristics.In conclusion, a better understanding of the dynamics of Ov16 antibody responses is required for accurate interpretation of seroprevalence data and more precise estimation of the endpoint for MDA. The endpoint will be dependent on baseline endemicity levels, which should be taken into account in guidelines for defining when to stop MDA. Traditional diagnostic tests for onchocerciasis, such as skin snip microscopy, have disadvantages such as invasiveness and low sensitivity. Therefore, current guidelines recommend the use of entomological evaluation by O-150 polymerase chain reaction (pool screen) testing in blackflies and Ov16 serology testing in children less than 10 years of age for assessing whether mass drug administration can safely be stopped or for verifying that elimination has indeed been interrupted after a post-treatment surveillance period. A new rapid diagnostic test (RDT) for detection of IgG4 against Ov16 has recently been developed as a practical, convenient, and standardized alternative for use in the field. However, the guidelines advise against using the RDT, which first needs to be validated more extensively. It is suggested that the guidelines should be revised by 2020 on the basis of new evidence.
"Prions, the agents responsible for transmissible spongiform encephalopathies, are mainly composed of PrPSc, an abnormal conformer of the host protein PrPC. PrPSc can exist in both PK-sensitive and PK-resistant forms, and prion replication occurs by seeded aggregation. Prion populations exhibit Darwinian evolution, as they are subject to ""mutations"" that give rise to heterogeneity and allow selective amplification of prions in different environments. Brain-derived 22L prions can infect R33 cells and are swa resistant, but after propagation in PK1 cells for several generations, they become R33-incompetent and swa sensitive. However, when swa-sensitive 22L prions are propagated in PK1 cells in the presence of the drug, the prion population becomes swa resistant. Similarly, RML prions acquired quinacrine resistance in mice and yeast prions resistance to epigallocatechin-3-gallate. In some RML-infected PK1-derived cell lines, the swa-sensitive prion populations contain a low level of variants, which can be selected in the presence of the drug to yield swa-resistant RML populations, suggesting that some cell line-dependent feature is responsible for the distinct behavior of some PK1 subclones. In summary, propagation of prions in the presence of an inhibitory drug can cause the selection of drug-resistant prions and even the emergence of stable variants that propagate more efficiently in the presence of the drug, likely due to conformational changes of the abnormal prion protein."
The study of metabolism's potential for innovation involves analyzing an extensive genotype-phenotype map of metabolic systems. The authors constructed an exhaustive genotype-phenotype map for a space of 1015 metabolisms, encoding all possible subsets of 51 reactions in central carbon metabolism. They used flux balance analysis to predict the viability of these metabolisms on 10 different carbon sources, giving rise to 1024 potential metabolic phenotypes. Although viable metabolisms with any one phenotype comprise a tiny fraction of genotype space, their absolute numbers exceed 109 for some phenotypes. The authors discovered that metabolisms with any one phenotype typically form a single network of genotypes that extends far or all the way through metabolic genotype space. The minimal distance of genotype networks associated with different phenotypes is small, such that one can reach metabolisms with novel phenotypes – viable on new carbon sources – through one or few genotypic changes.This research has implications for understanding evolution and the relationship between genotype and phenotype. Attempts to understand this relationship have played a pivotal role in the history of genetics and evolutionary biology. Insights from this study can help uncover and predict the relationship between genotypes and complex phenotypes, furthering the goals of systems biology. An ideal genotype-phenotype map would cover all possible genotypes, but the entire space of a system's genotypes is usually too vast to study. Exhaustive genotype-phenotype mapping using computational approaches is possible only in small systems, such as short hydrophobic polar (HP) model proteins folding on square and cubic lattices, short RNA sequences folding into planar secondary structures, and small gene regulatory networks.In summary, this study provides valuable insights into metabolism's potential for innovation through an exhaustive genotype-phenotype map, leveraging the principles of central carbon metabolism's interconnected biochemical pathways, such as glycolysis, gluconeogenesis, the pentose-phosphate pathway, and the tricarboxylic acid cycle. The findings emphasize the importance of understanding genotype-phenotype maps for predicting evolutionary potential and limitations of an evolving system.
The population genetics of the triatomine species complex, Triatoma dimidiata, were analyzed in Chiapas, Mexico, at landscape and sub-regional scales, and across the Mexican Neotropics at a regional scale. The phylogeography of the complex was also re-analyzed across its complete geographic range. Two fragments of the ND4 gene were analyzed to avoid bias from differential haplogroup specificity. The study found that the lowest genetic diversity of T. dimidiata occurred where there was greatest historical anthropic modification, and where T. cruzi infection prevalence was significantly highest. Haplogroups 1 and 3 had a significantly higher prevalence of T. cruzi infection, while haplogroup 2 had a lower than expected prevalence. The study also found a significant difference in DTUI and DTUVI infection frequencies in haplogroups 1 and 3, but not in haplogroup 2. All haplogroups from the Mexican Neotropics had moderate to high haplotype diversity, while greatest genetic differentiation was between haplogroups 1 and 3. The divergence of the complex from the most recent common ancestor (MRCA) was estimated to be between 0.97 MYA and 0.85 MYA for ND4A and both concatenated fragments, respectively, with primary divergence from the MRCA of haplogroups 2 and 3. The study supports previous ecological niche evidence for the complex's origin surrounding the Tehuantepec Isthmus and provides evidence for recent divergence of three primary dimidiata haplogroups, with differential T. cruzi infection frequency and DTU specificity, important components of vector capacity.
HFRS is a rodent-borne disease in China, primarily caused by the Hantaan and Seoul viruses, and transmitted to humans through aerosolized viral particles in rodent urine, feces, and saliva. The disease is most prevalent in China, where it is a significant public health concern. A study was conducted in Chenzhou, a HFRS hotspot, to identify environmental risk factors for rodent-to-human transmission. The study found that cultivated land represented the highest risk for HFRS incidence and that spatial heterogeneity of the disease was influenced by rodent community composition, which was associated with local environmental conditions. Therefore, future work should focus on preventing HFRS in moist, warm environments, where rodents are more prevalent.
Costello Syndrome (CS) can be caused by activating mutations in the HRAS proto-oncogene, with the most common mutation being c. 34G>A (p. Gly12Ser). However, other less frequent mutations such as c. 35G>T (p. Gly12Val) have been observed in CS, but are usually associated with a more severe, early lethal phenotype. A study of a 12-year-old boy with attenuated CS found a heterozygous c. 35_36GC>TG germline mutation, which was predicted to result in p. Gly12Val. This mutation caused pronounced exon 2 skipping, resulting in an attenuated phenotype. The mutation disrupted the formation of constitutively active p. Gly12Val HRAS and created a strong hnRNPF/H binding ESS, which inhibited inclusion of exon 2. This vulnerability of HRAS exon 2 splicing can be exploited by employing splice switching oligonucleotides (SSOs) to induce HRAS exon 2 skipping, providing a potential new mechanism for knocking out oncogenic HRAS in cancer treatment. Overall, this study highlights the importance of mutations affecting HRAS exon 2 splicing in determining both the severity of CS and the potential for cancer development.
M6A RNA methylation, the most abundant modification on mRNAs, plays crucial roles in various biological processes, with METTL3 as a key factor in its formation. However, the in vivo functions of METTL3 and m6A modification in mammalian development are unclear. This study reveals that specific inactivation of Mettl3 in the mouse nervous system causes severe developmental defects in the brain, including cerebellar hypoplasia, drastically enhanced apoptosis of newborn cerebellar granule cells (CGCs), and extended RNA half-lives and aberrant splicing events, leading to dysregulation of transcriptome-wide gene expression and premature CGC death. These findings highlight the critical role of METTL3-mediated m6A in regulating the development of the mammalian cerebellum and the potential role of m6A in neural plasticity and brain function.
"In embryonic stem (ES) cells, the transcription factors OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG are essential for maintaining the cells' capacity to differentiate into any cell type of the developing embryo. These transcription factors interact to regulate gene expression, and their binding is associated with the presence of the transcriptional co-activator Mediator, H3K27ac, and increased expression of nearby genes. Comparison of mouse and human ES cells shows that while less than 5% of individual binding events for OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG are shared between species, about 15% of combinatorial binding events and 53-63% of combinatorial binding events at enhancers active in early development are conserved. This suggests that the combination of OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG binding is critical for transcription in ES cells and plays an important role in embryogenesis by binding at conserved early developmental enhancers. The fast evolutionary rewiring of regulatory networks mainly affects individual binding events, while ""gene regulatory hotspots"" that are bound by multiple factors and active in multiple tissues throughout early development are under stronger evolutionary constraints. ES cells are unique in vitro cellular model system to study early embryogenesis, and the transcription factors OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG play a key role in maintaining the pluripotent state of these cells. The combinatorial binding of these transcription factors is associated with increased expression of nearby genes and is linked with the transcriptional co-activator Mediator and active histone modifications. The majority of loci bound by these transcription factors are at distant regulatory elements, and combinatorial binding is a more sensitive indicator for Mediator co-localization than individual binding events. Mediator bound loci are functionally different from loci without Mediator binding, as they are strongly enriched in H3K27ac and show specific binding at distant regulatory elements. Combinatorial binding identifies enhancers in embryonic stem cells, while Mediator co-localization determines their activity. Binding of Oct4, Sox2 and Nanog frequently occurs near developmental genes and is associated with up-regulation of nearby genes after differentiation. The majority of loci bound by these transcription factors together with Med1 or Med12 are likely to act as enhancers in embryonic stem cells. However, the function of loci near inactive genes is unclear, and some of these regulatory elements are in a poised state. Poised enhancers have been identified in embryonic stem cells by unique chromatin modification signatures, but this is the first evidence for active participation of Oct4, Sox2 and Nanog in this poised state."
The t(8;21) translocation, found in approximately 10-15% of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) cases, results in the formation of the AML1/ETO oncogenic transcription factor due to a reciprocal translocation involving chromosomes 8 and 21. This fusion protein interferes with the function of its wild-type counterpart, AML1, and recruits co-repressor complexes to DNA, leading to the inhibition of transcription of crucial hematopoiesis-related genes. The AML1/ETO fusion protein has been shown to interact with other transcription factors, particularly E-proteins, and co-localize with AML1 and HEB on many of its regulated targets. Genome-wide chromatin immunoprecipitation and expression profiling have identified AML1/ETO-dependent transcriptional regulation, with the fusion protein preferentially binding to DNA regions occupied by the wild-type AML1 transcription factor without necessarily displacing it. The E-protein HEB re-localizes to AML1/ETO binding regions, and its protein level is increased in both primary cells and cell lines expressing AML1/ETO. These findings suggest a major role for the functional interaction of AML1/ETO with AML1 and HEB in transcriptional regulation determined by the fusion protein.
The study investigates the role of the Leishmania donovani (Ld) histone acetyltransferase HAT2 in regulating gene expression and the cell cycle. The researchers found that HAT2 is constitutively nuclear and acetylates histone H4K10 in vitro and in vivo. HAT2 is essential for cell survival, and its depletion leads to growth and cell cycle defects, poor survival in host cells, and downregulation of cyclins CYC4 and CYC9. The researchers also discovered that CYC4 and CYC9 have their own specific promoters, which are activated in a cell-cycle dependent manner, and that this second tier of regulation is more sensitive to H4K10 acetylation levels. The study presents the first data pointing to cell cycle-specific activation of promoters in trypanosomatids, uncovering new facets of gene regulation in this parasite family. Histone post-translational modifications, including acetylation, play a crucial role in regulating nuclear processes by altering chromatin structure or serving as flags recognized by specific proteins. The study of histone PTMs in Leishmania species is of particular interest due to the emergence of drug-resistant strains and the risks of dual HIV-Leishmania infection. While histone PTMs have not been globally identified in Leishmania species, they are likely to carry the same repertoire of modifications as Trypanosoma species. The enzymes that mediate histone acetylation, HATs, are divided into two categories: those that acetylate histones prior to nucleosomal deposition (Type B HATs) and those that typically acetylate nucleosomal histones (Type A HATs). Four MYST-family (Type A) HATs were annotated in the Leishmania whole genome sequences. LdHAT3 and LdHAT4 have been found to acetylate H4K4 and H4K14, respectively, and are essential for histone deposition and UV-induced DNA damage repair. TbHAT1 and TbHAT2 have been found to be essential, while TbHAT3 facilitates DNA repair at internal sites within chromosomes. The study investigates the role of the Leishmania donovani MYST-family histone acetyltransferase HAT2 and found that it carries the core catalytic acetyltransferase domain and is constitutively nuclear. LdHAT2-FLAG had autoacetylation activity and targeted the N-terminus of histone H4. In vitro biochemical assays revealed that H4K10 was the primary target of LdHAT2-mediated histone acetylation. H4K10 acetylation was maintained at all stages of Leishmania and was detected only in the nucleus at all stages of the cell cycle. RNAi-mediated knockdown of genes cannot be carried out in Leishmania, so the researchers attempted to create HAT2 genomic knockout. However, repeated efforts to obtain HAT2-nulls failed, suggesting that LdHAT2 is essential to cell survival. LdHAT2 mediates H4 acetylation at K10 residue in vivo, and its depletion leads to slow growth, increased generation time, and delay in navigating S and G2/M phases. The survival of HAT2-depleted parasites within host cells was also impaired. Ectopic expression of HAT2 only partially rescued the heterozygous knockout phenotype when survival within host macrophages was examined. The researchers analyzed the expression of cyclins that govern the transition from G1 through S phase in LdHAT2-hKO cells and found that CYC4 expression was downregulated to ~0.6 of wild type levels. Episomal expression of CYC4 only partially rescued the growth defects of LdHAT2-hKO cells, and ectopic expression of CYC4 in Ld1S-hyg cells had no impact on growth. CYC4 expression had a limited impact on cell cycle progression of LdHAT2-hKO cells, but the cells still displayed delayed navigation through G2/M back into G1. HAT2 depletion was impacting an additional branch of cell cycle regulation. The Leishmania donovani ortholog of T. brucei CYC9 was significantly downregulated in HAT2-depleted cells. Ectopic expression of CYC9-FLAG in these cells alleviated G2/M (and/or cytokinesis) defects to the same extent as by ectopic expression of HAT2-eGFP. CYC9 down regulation was accompanied by post-mitotic defects linked to delay in cytokinesis, and thus delayed re-entry into G1. CYC9 expression alleviated survival defects to the same extent as did ectopic expression of HAT2-eGFP. The study provides new insights into the regulation of gene expression and the cell cycle in Leishmania and highlights the importance of HAT2 in mediating cell survival and parasite propagation within host macrophages.
"A study investigating the problem of inferring others' time-varying intentions during social transactions applied computational modeling to behavioral data from an economic game. The game involved 16 pairs of volunteers, with one assigned as ""player"" and the other as ""adviser,"" and was structured such that the adviser's incentives to provide helpful or misleading information varied in time. Using a meta-Bayesian modeling framework, it was found that the players' behavior was best explained by the deployment of hierarchical learning, inferring on the volatility of the advisers' intentions to optimize their predictions about the validity of their advice. Volatility estimates affected the trial-by-trial variability of decisions, with participants relying on their estimates of advice accuracy for making choices when they believed that the adviser's intentions were presently stable. The model of the players' inference predicted the players' interpersonal reactivity index (IRI) scores, explicit ratings of the advisers' helpfulness, and the advisers' self-reports on their chosen strategy. The results suggest that humans employ hierarchical generative models to infer on the changing intentions of others, use volatility estimates to inform decision-making in social interactions, and integrate estimates of advice accuracy with non-social sources of information. The Bayesian framework presented here can quantify individual differences in these mechanisms from simple behavioral readouts and may prove useful in future clinical studies of maladaptive social cognition."
Scrub typhus is a mite-borne disease endemic in Asia, typically found in rural areas but increasingly observed in urban settings, such as Seoul, South Korea. This study identified 88 cases of indigenous urban scrub typhus in Seoul from 2010-2013, with possible infection sites including mountainous areas, city parks, residential vicinities, and riversides. Chigger mites, primarily Helenicula miyagawai and Leptotrombidium scutellare, were found to be infected with Orientia tsutsugamushi. Patients with urban scrub typhus showed milder clinical features, such as low APACHE II scores and complication rates. This study emphasizes the need for considering urban scrub typhus as a differential diagnosis in febrile diseases in endemic areas and highlights the importance of vector control and surveillance in urban settings.
RNA interference (RNAi) is a gene regulatory mechanism that involves sequence-specific recruitment of Ago proteins to mRNA target molecules by small RNA (sRNA) co-factors. The stability of sRNA molecules is regulated in part by Hen1-mediated methylation of their 3′ ends. In Caenorhabditis elegans, the HENN-1 protein, a homolog of the HEN1 methyltransferase, has differential effects on the 26G and 21U RNA pathways, which employ methylated sRNA molecules. In the germline, stability of 21U RNAs, the C. elegans piRNAs, is mildly affected by loss of methylation, and introduction of artificial 21U target RNA does not further destabilize non-methylated 21U RNAs. However, most 26G RNAs display reduced stability and respond to loss of HENN-1 by displaying increased 3′-uridylation frequencies. Within the 26G RNA class, specifically ERGO-1-bound 26G RNAs are modified by HENN-1, while ALG-3/ALG-4-bound 26G RNAs are not. Global gene expression analysis of henn-1 mutants reveals mild effects, including down-regulation of many germline-expressed genes. These findings refine our understanding of endogenous RNAi in C. elegans and the roles for Hen1 like enzymes in these pathways. RNA silencing pathways are sequence-specific mechanisms that act in gene regulation and genome protection, and are characterized by the involvement of an Ago protein that derives its sequence specificity from a bound sRNA molecule. Ago proteins have a characteristic domain structure and sRNA molecules can be formed through several biochemical routes. HEN1 is a methyltransferase that methylates sRNAs on the 2′hydroxyl group of their 3′ terminal nucleotide, and is important for piRNA biogenesis. HEN1 activity has been linked with piRNA biogenesis and sRNAs with 3′ end methylation are protected from non-templated addition of uridine residues, which can trigger degradation of sRNAs. In C. elegans, a large number of endogenous RNA silencing (endoRNAi) pathways have been identified, each being characterized by specific types of Ago proteins and their bound sRNA cofactors. Two endogenous primary sRNA classes in C. elegans that have been described to date, 26G and 21U RNAs, are 2′O-methylated. The C. elegans HEN1 homologue, HENN-1, is required for 21U and 26G RNA methylation in vivo and is expressed rather ubiquitously, with strong expression in the germline and embryos. HENN-1 is present in a complex of roughly 150 kDa and is not a stable interaction partner of PRG-1 and is not required for PRG-1 stability and localization. Loss of Hen1 activity has been shown to impair Piwi pathway activity in Tetrahymena, flies, and zebrafish, accompanied by a reduction in piRNA levels. However, 21U RNA levels do not seem to be affected significantly in henn-1 mutant animals.
Glycosylation, a post-translational modification that enriches protein complexity and function, is extensively involved in various physiological and pathological processes. Over half of all known proteins are modified by covalently bound glycans, which significantly affect protein function. However, contrary to polypeptides, they are not directly encoded by genes, and the complex processes that regulate their assembly are poorly understood. A recent study examining 2,705 individuals in three population cohorts found that common variants in the Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 1α (HNF1α) and fucosyltransferase genes FUT6 and FUT8 influence N-glycan levels in human plasma. The research reveals a new role for HNF1α as a master transcriptional regulator of multiple stages in the fucosylation process, which has implications for the regulation of immunity, embryonic development, protein folding, and several diseases, including cancer, coronary heart disease, and metabolic and inflammatory disorders. Fucose, a particular interest in protein glycosylation, has two structural features that distinguish it from other mammalian six-carbon monosaccharides and plays important roles in various biological processes. The regulation of fucosylation pathways and the upstream mechanisms controlling fucose metabolism are largely unknown. Further investigation is required to understand the genetic regulation of glycosylation fully and the impact of genetic variants on fucosylation in health and disease.
Centromeres, which connect chromosomes to spindles, are crucial genome features. The connection is made through a large multifunctional kinetochore complex that binds DNA, binds microtubules, and regulates the timing of anaphase. Centromeres are identified by a histone H3 variant known as Centromeric Histone H3 (CENH3). CENH3 is assembled relatively late in the cell cycle by specialized CENH3 nucleosome assembly factors. Centromere protein C (CENPC), a DNA binding protein, has a key role in centromere recognition and maintenance. CENPC is required to target CENH
The study found that genetic variants associated with birth weight (BW), childhood obesity (CO), and childhood BMI (CBMI) are significantly enriched for placental eQTLs (expressional quantitative trait loci), with 6.76, 4.83, and 2.26 folds, respectively. Placental eQTLs contribute significantly to both anthropometry outcomes at birth (BW) and childhood phenotypes (CO/CBMI), while eQTLs of adult tissues do not. Eight, six, and one transcripts colocalized with BW, CO and CBMI risk loci, respectively, all of which are protein-coding genes. These findings suggest that placental transcription in utero plays a crucial role in determining postnatal body size, indicating new possibilities for therapeutic interventions to prevent childhood obesity. BW is influenced by both fetal and maternal factors and is consistently associated with future risk of adult metabolic diseases including T2D and cardiovascular disease. CO has emerged as an important health problem worldwide, with 1 in 3 children afflicted with overweight or obesity, and is associated with diseases later in life including T2D, hypertension, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and dyslipidemia. The placenta, situated at the maternal-fetal interface, is a key organ for fetal growth and development. The study leveraged the Rhode Island Child Health Study and reported the first placenta expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) profile based on a large sample size, discovering over 3,000 cis- and trans-eQTLs. GWAS of BW, CO, and CBMI have identified multiple genome-wide significant loci, with 60 and 15 fetal loci associated with BW and CBMI, respectively. These genome-wide significant variants are likely to affect these phenotypes through regulation of gene expression. An eQTL analysis provides a profile of significant associations between transcription levels of a gene and genetic polymorphisms, with cis-eQTLs being close to the gene and trans-eQTLs being distant. Integrative genomics applied to eQTLs can mine GWAS risk loci datasets to discover underlying mechanisms linking genetic variants to diseases. Recent methods like COLOC, SMR, MetaXcan, and TWAS have shown superior ability to identify causal genes of genetic risk loci compared to earlier integrative analysis. In this study, the authors compared placenta eQTLs with 7 STARNET adult tissue eQTLs and applied COLOC and MetaXcan analyses on placenta eQTLs integrated with GWAS data.
Post Kala-azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL) is a chronic but non-life threatening disease, often overlooked despite its relevance in the context of Visceral Leishmaniasis (VL) elimination. There is no standard guideline for PKDL diagnosis and treatment. A study in Malda district, West Bengal, aimed to determine disease burden, compare diagnostic tools, and observe lesion regression after treatment. Prevalence of PKDL was 27.5% among antibody positives, with 88.46% sensitivity for PCR-based diagnosis. Majority of cases had persistent skin lesions post-treatment, which gradually disappeared within 6-12 months. Two cases showed lesion reappearance 1.5 years after miltefosine treatment. Active mass surveys and PCR-based diagnosis are crucial for PKDL detection and elimination of VL. A well-designed study with a larger sample size is needed to establish the absence of parasites in PKDL patients post-treatment and to determine treatment duration for different PKDL patients.Leishmaniasis, a poverty-related neglected tropical disease, significantly impacts global health. PKDL, a sequel of leishmaniasis, develops in 10-20% of VL patients in India, and 50-60% in Sudan. PKDL is characterized by skin rashes caused by L. donovani. Unlike VL, PKDL is not life-threatening, but its cosmetic implications often prevent patients from seeking medical care, allowing the parasite to persist in the population. PKDL patients can serve as a reservoir for VL transmission, posing a significant challenge in eliminating VL.The Indian subcontinent aimed to eliminate VL by 2015, but PKDL remains an obstacle. The WHO recommends miltefosine and SSG for PKDL treatment, but there is no standardized protocol, and diagnosis remains challenging. The PCR-based molecular diagnostic method has the potential to overcome these challenges.In the study conducted in Malda district, West Bengal, house-to-house surveys were conducted to collect demographic data and detect anti-leishmanial antibodies in individuals. Among the 160 antileishmanial antibody-positive individuals, 26 were confirmed PKDL cases, with a prevalence rate of 16.25%. Additionally, 15 cases with similar lesions were identified but tested negative for antileishmanial antibodies and PCR.Slit skin smears from all 41 patients with skin lesions were negative for acid-fast bacilli. Parasite demonstration had a sensitivity rate of 15.38%, while PCR detected parasitic DNA in 88.46% of cases. Among the 26 PKDL cases, 14 were male, 12 were female, and the age ranged from 5 to 42 years. Macular and papular lesions were observed in 23 cases, while polymorphic lesions were found in three cases.All 26 PKDL cases underwent monthly examinations during treatment and follow-ups for 1.5 years post-treatment. Among the miltefosine-treated patients, nausea and vomiting were recorded but managed symptomatically. Biochemical parameters showed no significant changes during therapy.Although this study does not provide a comprehensive summary due to its complex content, it highlights the importance of addressing PKDL in the context of VL elimination, emphasizing the need for accurate diagnosis, effective treatment, and regular follow-up.
Bacteria, including Streptococcus pneumoniae, can develop genetic programs to face various stresses that challenge their growth and survival. One such program is competence, which enables genetic transformation, a significanthorizontal gene transfer process. Competence development in S. pneumoniae is synchronized within the whole cell population through an exported signaling Competence Stimulating Peptide (CSP). A new study found that competence shift in the population relies on a self-activated cell fraction that arises via a growth time-dependent mechanism. The CSP remains bound to cells during this event, and the rate of competence development corresponds to the propagation of competence by contact between activated and quiescent cells. The membrane protein ComD retains the CSP, limiting its free diffusion in the medium. Competence initiator cells originate stochastically in response to stress, forming a distinct subpopulation that then transmits the CSP by cell-cell contact. This two-step cell-contact sensing mechanism was validated by measuring competence development during co-cultivation of strains with altered capacity to produce or respond to CSP.
The human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV16) L2 protein acts as a chaperone for the viral genome (vDNA) to traffic from endosomes to the trans-Golgi network (TGN) and eventually the nucleus, where HPV replication occurs. A novel assay using bacterial biotin ligase BirA fused to L2 (L2-BirA) was developed to monitor L2 translocation, which depends on the compartmentalization of a specific BirA enzyme-substrate reaction. The assay showed that L2 translocation is directly correlated to substrate biotinylation, which can be detected by western blotting and neutravidin staining. Inhibition of cellular processes and factors essential for L2/vDNA trafficking to the TGN, including furin, endosome acidification, cyclophilins, and γ-secretase, potently block L2 translocation. Mitotic entry is sufficient for L2 translocation to occur, and translocation coincides with mitosis in synchronized cells. During the onset of mitosis, vDNA moves rapidly from the TGN to a pericentriolar region before associating with mitotic host chromosomes during prometaphase, ensuring infection of both daughter cells. Translocation is blocked in three different mutants of the newly defined chromatin binding region of L2, suggesting a functional link between the ability to bind chromatin and L2/vDNA translocation. The findings suggest that chromatin binding of L2 in prometaphase is a necessary prerequisite for translocation of L2/vDNA across limiting membranes.
"The article discusses a method for measuring the relative transmissibility or ""transmission fitness"" of one strain of a pathogen compared to another. This is done using data from ""competitive mixtures"" experiments, where animals are co-infected with a mixture of two strains and the mixture is observed over time and multiple generations of transmission. The authors demonstrate the approach using data from influenza experiments in ferrets. The ability to accurately measure the relative transmissibility of different strains is important in several contexts, including the emergence of antigenically novel strains, the potential impact of interventions such as the use of neuraminidase inhibitors, and the spread of drug-resistant strains. The mathematical framework introduced in the article also provides an estimate for the size of the transmitted inoculum. The method can be applied to other viral and bacterial pathogens and is demonstrated using data from ferret transmission studies. The authors suggest how to optimize experimental design for assessment of transmissibility and note that the framework has wide applicability in influenza research and can be used to estimate both the transmission fitness of a new strain of interest and the transmitted inoculum size. The article also discusses the uncertainties inherent in the data source due to experimental procedures and the need to consider each source of uncertainty in the data on its merits. The method accurately recovers the relative transmission fitness of strain compared to strain and can be used in experiment design to ensure that studies are sufficiently powered to provide estimates of a specified precision for the transmission fitness. The authors suggest potential improvements in competitive-mixtures experimental design, such as the use of multiple donor ferrets and regular sampling to tie down as closely as possible the strain proportion in both donor and recipient at the time of transmission. They also suggest improvements to the mathematical framework, such as probing the effects of the Poisson nature of the transmission process and accounting for re-assortment of strains during the within-host dynamics in both the donor and recipient."
The study reveals that BBX21, a B-box (BBX) protein involved in photomorphogenesis, also plays a crucial role in ABA (abscisic acid) signaling. BBX21 negatively regulates ABI5 expression, a key player in ABA control of seed germination, by interfering with HY5 (elongated hypocotyl 5) binding to the ABI5 promoter. BBX21 may act upstream of several ABI genes and HY5 in the ABA signaling pathway. Hy5 mutants displayed reduced ABA sensitivity during germination, and hy5 bbx21 double mutants exhibited ABA insensitivity during germination, indicating that hy5 is epistatic to bbx21 and that the ABA insensitivity of bbx21 during seed germination is dependent on a functional HY5 protein. BBX21 negatively regulates the expression of ABI3 and ABI5 under both mock and ABA treatments, but this regulation mainly occurs in the Col background. The physical interaction between BBX21 and HY5 prevents HY5 from binding to the ABI5 promoter, thereby negatively regulating ABI5 expression.
The Mediator complex, associated with RNA polymerase II, has essential roles in transcription and is well-conserved in eukaryotes. Previous research on the role of Mediator in model yeasts Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Schizosaccharomyces pombe has shown its functions in stress responses and cell wall dynamics. A recent study explored the functions of Mediator in the human pathogen Candida albicans and found that it shares some roles with S. cerevisiae and S. pombe, such as functions in stress responses and a role of Med31 in the expression of genes regulated by the activator Ace2. However, the C. albicans Mediator also has additional roles in the transcription of genes associated with virulence, such as genes related to morphogenesis and gene families enriched in pathogens, such as the ALS adhesins. Med31, Med20, and Srb9/Med13 contribute to key virulence attributes of C. albicans, filamentation, and biofilm formation; and ALS1 is a biologically relevant target of Med31 for development of biofilms. Med31 affects virulence of C. albicans in the worm infection model. The roles of Med31 and Srb9/Med13 in the expression of the genes encoding cell wall adhesins are different between S. cerevisiae and C. albicans, suggesting that Mediator subunits regulate adhesion in a distinct manner between these two fungal species.
Bacteria in biofilms exhibit higher antibiotic tolerance than planktonic bacteria, which is due in part to the unique cellular state and genetic determinants of the biofilm. A study using Pseudomonas aeruginosa MPAO1 in biofilm and planktonic growth conditions found that large sets of mutations contribute to antibiotic tolerance predominantly in the biofilm or planktonic setting. The study used a complex, heterogeneous mutant population and recapitulated natural biofilm behaviors, including the emergence of quorum sensing-deficient mutants. The results indicate a substantial contribution of the cellular state to antibiotic tolerance of biofilms and provide a foundation for the development of novel therapeutics against P. aeruginosa biofilm-associated infections. Bacteria in biofilms are generally more tolerant of antimicrobial agents, and P. aeruginosa biofilms are a major cause of morbidity in cystic fibrosis patients and nosocomial infections. Tobramycin, an aminoglycoside, is commonly prescribed to combat P. aeruginosa infections in cystic fibrosis patients. However, during the course of treatment, the drug's efficacy typically decreases as adaptive mutations accumulate, leading to the emergence of hyper-tolerant mutants. Factors that contribute to aminoglycoside tolerance in P. aeruginosa have been studied, including oxidative phosphorylation, lipopolysaccharide (LPS) composition, cyclic di-guanosine monophosphate (c-di-GMP) levels, quorum sensing, and membrane permeability. However, the connection between biofilms and antibiotic tolerance remains incomplete, and more research is needed to fully understand the genetic components and mechanisms involved.
The article discusses the challenges of analyzing biological systems, which often have numerous interacting components and lack sufficient information about their essential dynamics. Model selection algorithms can help identify appropriate models for these systems, but many algorithms are limited by the need for preselected models or exhaustive searches of the total model space. To address this, the authors developed an algorithm that can perform model selection on complex systems and search large model spaces dynamically, using local and non-local search methods. The algorithm was tested and validated using simulated data and was shown to be flexible for handling different model structures. It was then used to analyze experimental data on the cell proliferation dynamics of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells cultured under different conditions. The results indicated dynamical changes within the proliferation potential of cells that were reduced within tissue-like 3D ex vivo cultures compared to suspension. The algorithm's flexibility in handling various model structures makes it applicable to a wide range of biological problems and a useful tool for the data-oriented evaluation of complex model spaces. Experiments often involve time-resolved measurements of individual components of a biological system, and revealing the most appropriate systematic representation to describe the connectivity and dynamical interactions of these individual components based on such measurements is a major challenge. Mathematical models in combination with information criteria, such as the Akaike information criterion, can be used to evaluate the ability of different hypotheses in describing the experimental data. However, complex data structures and large numbers of different components can result in numerous possible descriptions of their systematic interactions, making it challenging to test each possibility individually. Therefore, computational algorithms are needed to efficiently search large model spaces to provide the best systematic description of experimentally observed dynamics. The authors developed a Flexible and dynamic Algorithm for Model Selection (FAMoS) that can handle complex and large model spaces and is applicable to a variety of mathematical model structures. The algorithm was tested and validated using simulated data and was shown to be efficient and flexible for handling different model structures. It was then applied to the analysis of experimental data on the proliferation dynamics of T cells within different environments and was able to reveal heterogeneous proliferation dynamics that were influenced by the culture conditions.
The National Program for Chagas disease was implemented in Bolivia in 2006, leading to a significant decrease in infections through vector control. A treatment regimen of benznidazole (BNZ) was started in seropositive school-age children living in certified vector control areas. A 12-month follow-up study was conducted, and it was found that approximately 73 of 103 seropositive children complied with BNZ, with three interruptions due to side effects. To evaluate each individual’s treatment efficacy, cPCR and qPCR values during the final 6 months of the follow-up period were observed. It was found that 11% of children showed both cPCR (+) and qPCR (+), 42% were cPCR (-) but qPCR (+), and 47% were cPCR (-) and qPCR (-). IL-17A showed significantly higher levels in seropositive children before the treatment compared to age-matched seronegative children and significantly decreased to the normal level one-year after. Plasma levels of IL-17A might be a bio-marker for detecting persistent infection of T. cruzi and its chronic inflammation. Chagas disease is a parasitic disease caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, affecting seven million people worldwide, mainly in Latin America. It is transmitted through blood-sucking triatomine bugs, blood transfusions, vertical transmission, organ transplantation, contaminated food, or laboratory accidents. The treatment options for Chagas disease are nifurtimox and benznidazole, which are effective as anti-parasitic for T. cruzi but have prolonged regimens and undesirable side effects. A patient is considered cured of chronic T. cruzi if the “negativization” of two different serological assays is achieved, but current serological assays are difficult to use as monitoring tools during the first year of post-treatment, especially in chronic cases. PCR is an alternative method for the early evaluation of infection and treatment efficacy in different settings in Latin America and Spain. However, the fluctuations of circulating T. cruzi in chronic Chagas disease patients might affect PCR sensitivity, and sampling at different time points of the follow-up may be needed. A molecular strategy to quantify T. cruzi DNA in peripheral blood samples as quantitative real-time PCR (qPCR) is a key tool for monitoring parasitological response during follow-up of the treatment in chronic Chagas disease patients.
Neisseria meningitidis, the primary cause of bacterial meningitis, has a genome rich in repetitive DNA, including the Correia element, a transposon occupying almost 2% of the genome. Research identified eight subtypes of the Correia element, with four distinct end types and strong promoters encoded by two of the ends. The strongest promoter's activity is influenced by a polymorphism (Y128) at the right end. Correia elements have been found to drive transcription of adjacent genes and express small non-coding RNAs. The Correia element may contribute to phase variation in meningococcus through recombinational class switching between elements and natural transformation. This variability allows for potentially widespread effects within the population, influencing meningococcal physiology and the disease's progression.
In Aspergillus spp., LaeA and VeA are proteins that coordinate secondary metabolism and differentiation in response to light signals. Their orthologs, ChLae1 and ChVel1, were identified in the maize pathogen Cochliobolus heterostrophus, which produces a variety of secondary metabolites, including the T-toxin. T-toxin production is increased in the dark and is reduced in Chlae1 and Chvel1 mutants in dark conditions. Overexpression of ChLAE1 and ChVEL1 leads to increased T-toxin production. ChLae1 and ChVel1 also play roles in oxidative stress tolerance, sexual development, aerial hyphal growth, and negatively control asexual development and expression of melanin biosynthesis genes. The extracellular siderophore-associated NPS6 gene, critical for cellular management of the essential nutrient iron, is not controlled by A. nidulans LaeA and VeA orthologous proteins in C. heterostrophus. Melanin biosynthesis is essential for survival of C. heterostrophus in the field, and its biosynthesis is positively regulated by the ortholog of VeA in Mycosphaerella graminicola. In C. heterostrophus, ChLAE1 and ChVEL1 play roles in T-toxin production and virulence in response to light conditions, and also positively regulate oxidative stress tolerance, sexual development, and aerial hyphal growth, and negatively control asexual development and expression of melanin biosynthesis genes. Expression of the NPS6 gene is unaffected in Chlae1 or Chvel1 mutants.
Bacterial Nav channels have been recently X-rayed, and molecular dynamics simulations of ion permeation through these channels correspond to many electrophysiological properties of eukaryotic channels. However, the mechanism of functional asymmetry in bacterial Nav channels is not well understood. To address this, a study combined non-equilibrium simulation data with two-dimensional equilibrium unperturbed landscapes using umbrella sampling and Weighted Histogram Analysis Methods for multiple ions traversing the selectivity filter of bacterial NavAb channel. This approach provided new insight into the mechanism of selective ion permeation in bacterial Nav channels. Non-equilibrium simulations indicate that two or three extracellular K+ ions can block the entrance to the selectivity filter of NavAb in the presence of applied forces in the inward direction but not in the outward direction. The block state occurs in an unstable local minimum of the equilibrium unperturbed free-energy landscape of two K+ ions that can be ‘locked’ in place by modest applied forces. In contrast, three Na+ ions move favorably through the selectivity filter together as a unit in a loose “knock-on” mechanism of permeation in both inward and outward directions, and there is no similar local minimum in the two-dimensional free-energy landscape of two Na+ ions for a block state. The useful work predicted by the non-equilibrium simulations that is required to break the K+ block is equivalent to large applied potentials experimentally measured for two bacterial Nav channels to induce inward currents of K+ ions. These results highlight the importance of including non-equilibrium factors in simulations to provide detailed information about mechanisms of ion selectivity that is missing from mechanisms derived from either crystal structures or equilibrium unperturbed free-energy landscapes.
This study compared the spread of rabies virus in the nervous systems of dogs with furious and paralytic rabies. The researchers found that the virus spread more quickly in the brains of dogs with the furious form of the disease than in those with the paralytic form. They also found that the virus spread more slowly in the cellular processes (part of nerve cells) in dogs with paralytic rabies than in those with the furious form. The researchers suggest that this difference in the speed of viral propagation may be due to host-specific differences in intracellular virus transport, which could be mediated by cytokines. Rabies is a deadly viral disease that affects the nervous system of humans and animals. It is typically transmitted through the bite of an infected animal and is almost always fatal once symptoms appear. The two main forms of the disease in dogs are furious and paralytic rabies, which are characterized by aggression and paralysis, respectively. While the symptoms of these two forms of the disease are well-known, the underlying mechanisms that cause these differences are not well understood. This study aimed to compare the spread of the rabies virus in the nervous systems of dogs with furious and paralytic rabies in order to better understand the pathogenesis of these clinical forms of the disease.
In this study, the role of insulator or enhancer-blocking elements in the regulation of transcription and their prevention of inappropriate enhancer/promoter interaction is explored. The zinc-finger protein CTCF is identified as an enhancer-blocking factor in vertebrates and is recently characterized in Drosophila. The study aims to identify CTCF binding sites within representative regions of the Drosophila genome, including the 3-Mb Adh region, the Bithorax complex (BX-C), and the Antennapedia complex. Chromatin immunopurification coupled with genomic microarray analysis is used to locate CTCF binding sites, which map precisely to the known insulator elements Mcp, Fab-6, and Fab-8 in the BX-C. Other CTCF binding sites correlate with boundaries of regulatory domains, allowing the identification of additional presumptive insulator elements, Fab-2, Fab-3, and Fab-4. The study suggests that the functioning of these insulators involves a common CTCF-dependent mechanism. The comparison of CTCF sites with characterized Polycomb target sites and histone modification provides support for the domain model of BX-C regulation. CTCF is directly associated with all known or predicted insulators in the BX-C, indicating a common CTCF-dependent mechanism for their functioning. The study also highlights the significance of CTCF in vertebrate insulators and its potential role in human disease. Overall, this study provides new insights into the regulation of transcription by CTCF and its role in insulator elements, which is critical for understanding gene regulation and its impact on human disease.
Molecular recognition is a fundamental process in biochemistry, with enzymes undergoing conformational changes upon substrate binding for efficient catalysis. A study on the slow, tight-binding inhibitor-enzyme system of actinonin-peptide deformylase (PDF) provides a detailed mechanism for an induced-fit process at an atomic resolution. Crystal structures of the initial open state and final closed state, along with several intermediate mimics, were solved. Ligand-induced reshaping of a hydrophobic pocket drives closure of the active site, followed by additional binding interactions leading to the final complex. This induced-fit mechanism is involved in a number of enzymes and is crucial for understanding enzyme-inhibitor interactions and developing therapeutics. Flexibility around the active site is central to molecular biochemistry, with three classic models describing the formation of the ligand-enzyme complex. The slow, tight-binding inhibition exhibited by actinonin involves a two-step mechanism, with the initial rapid formation of a non-covalent enzyme-inhibitor complex followed by a slower step leading to a more stable complex. Actinonin, a natural product with antibiotic activity, mimics the structure of PDF's natural substrates in their transition state, systematically exhibiting slow-binding inhibition behavior. Structural, biocomputing, and enzymatic analyses reveal that the free enzyme is in an open conformation, and actinonin induces transition into a closed conformation. This induced-fit model is supported by kinetic analyses, with the closed form being fully compatible with the observed data. In conclusion, understanding the induced-fit mechanism of actinonin on Arabidopsis thaliana PDF1B provides insights into the inhibitory mechanism of actinonin and its role in efficient catalysis.
The thalamus is the primary gateway that relays sensory information to the cerebral cortex. A single recipient cortical cell receives input from multiple principal relay cells of the thalamus, while each thalamic cell integrates feedback from the cortex. Despite the significant influence of this functional loop, it is often overlooked during sensory processing. A study, using dynamic-clamp techniques in thalamic slices in vitro, combined theoretical and experimental approaches to implement a realistic hybrid retino-thalamo-cortical pathway, mixing biological cells and simulated circuits. The study found that the transfer efficiency of sensory input transmission depends on three key features: (i) the number of thalamocortical cells involved in the many-to-one convergence from thalamus to cortex, (ii) the statistics of the corticothalamic synaptic bombardment, and (iii) the level of correlation imposed between converging thalamic relay cells. The study revealed that the retinocortical signal transfer efficiency increases when the level of correlation across thalamic cells decreases, suggesting that the transfer efficiency of relay cells could be selectively amplified when they become simultaneously desynchronized by the cortical feedback. This network regulation mechanism could direct an attentional focus to specific thalamic subassemblies and select the appropriate input lines to the cortex according to the descending influence of cortically-defined “priors.” The thalamic input is influenced by corticofugal feedback, which plays a key role in controlling the global gain and filtering features of sensory thalamic relays. The cortex has the ability to gate the thalamic transfer of sensory inputs via “on-line modulation” of the transfer efficiency of TC neurons through the contextual synaptic bombardment originating from the CT input. However, the cellular mechanisms underlying the functional impact of the CT feedback are poorly understood, and the activity patterns originating from projections of cortical layer 6 remain a major mystery. The study aimed to model the top-down cortical input as a configurable activity pattern transmitted by excitatory and inhibitory synapses for which they have fully explored the parameter space. The working hypothesis is that the CT synaptic bombardment is able to modulate the transfer efficiency of specific TC neurons, not only at the single-cell level but also at the population-level by controlling the contextual correlations in membrane potential fluctuations within subgroups of TC relay cells. The study explores the functional impact of higher order interactions arising between multiple TC neurons, both in computer models and in the slice.
The study reports the genetic evidence for the crucial role of the putative DNA demethylase NMAD-1 in regulating meiosis in C. elegans. The nmad-1 mutants have reduced fertility due to defects in prophase I of meiosis, leading to reduced embryo production and an increased incidence of males caused by defective chromosomal segregation. The nuclear staging, cohesin complex mislocalization, chromosome condensation, fusion, and loss are disrupted in nmad-1 mutants. NMAD-1 binds to multiple proteins regulating DNA repair and replication, including topoisomerase TOP-2, and co-localizes with TOP-2 on chromatin. The majority of TOP-2 binding to chromatin depends on NMAD-1. The study suggests that NMAD-1 functions at DNA replication sites to regulate DNA replication and repair during meiosis. DNA methylation has been implicated in various biological roles, including self-versus-nonself recognition, DNA damage response, genomic imprinting, X-chromosome inactivation, transposon suppression, and transcription. RNA methylation has been implicated in regulating translation initiation, RNA stability, localization, and function. However, the extent and diversity of recognized DNA and RNA methylation changes have expanded with new and more sensitive detection technologies. The AlkB family of dealkylating enzymes demethylates a diverse repertoire of methylated DNA and RNA in various species. NMAD-1 is a dealkylating enzyme in C. elegans that demethylates 6mA and the DNA damage modification 3mC on DNA. The level of 6mA on DNA has been shown to increase globally in response to mitochondrial stress and to mark genes important for stress response. However, the 6mA in DNA is difficult to measure and is less abundant than previously thought due to contamination with bacterial DNA and the inability of current sequencing methods to accurately identify 6mA. Therefore, it is still uncertain whether NMAD-1 functions in vivo as a 6mA and 3mC DNA demethylase. Nonetheless, the study investigated the role of NMAD-1 by characterizing nmad-1 mutant worms and found that nmad-1 deficiency leads to infertility due to errors in the maternal lineage and maternal NMAD-1 dealkylating activity.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a ubiquitous pathogen that can cause disability in newborns and serious clinical diseases in immunocompromised patients. It has a large genome with enormous coding potential and can infect a wide range of human cells due to its complicated glycoprotein complexes. Although multiple host cellular receptors interacting with viral glycoproteins have been reported, the mechanism of HCMV infection remains unclear. A study has identified adipocyte plasma membrane-associated protein (APMAP) as a novel modulator active in the early stage of HCMV infection. APMAP is necessary for HCMV infection in both epithelial cells and fibroblasts, and its ectopic expression in refractory cells promotes HCMV infection. APMAP may participate in HCMV infection through interaction with gH/gL containing glycoprotein complexes at low pH and mediate nucleus translocation of tegument pp65. The results suggest that APMAP functions as a modulator promoting HCMV infection in multiple cell types and is an important player in the complex HCMV infection mechanism. HCMV is aDOUBLE DNA virus that can infect various human cell types, including epithelial, endothelial, fibroblast, hepatocytes, neurons, parenchyma cells, and mononuclear cells. It has a large genome that can encode more than 160 proteins, with about 70 viral proteins incorporated into the mature viral particle. HCMV infection can cause significant morbidity and mortality in immunocompromised patients and can lead to congenital infections with disabilities such as mental retardation, loss of hearing or sight, microcephaly, and psychomotor dysfunction. Despite close to five decades of effort, no vaccine against HCMV has been licensed, and antiviral drugs such as ganciclovir and valganciclovir have adverse effects and concerns of viral resistance. Therefore, an effective preventive vaccine and new potent drugs against HCMV infection are urgently needed.
