A study analyzed both types of recombinant molecules in sperm DNA at six active hotspots and looked for disparity in the transmission of allelic variants indicative of any cis-acting influences. The study identified a novel form of biased transmission exclusive to the noncrossover class of recombinants at two hotspots, which presumably arises through differences between crossovers and noncrossovers in heteroduplex formation and biased mismatch repair. This form of biased gene conversion is not predicted to influence hotspot activity but does constitute a powerful and previously undetected source of recombination-driven meiotic drive that may affect thousands of recombination hotspots throughout the human genome. Intriguingly, at both of the hotspots described, this drive favors strong (G/C) over weak (A/T) base pairs, as predicted from the well-established correlations between high GC content and recombination activity in mammalian genomes.
A high confidence human protein-protein association network was built upon the integration of chemical toxicology and systems biology, revealing uncharacterized connections between compounds and diseases, and predicting which compounds may be risk factors for human health. This computational systems chemical biology model can also identify unexpected potential associations between chemicals and proteins. The network has been used to identify protein targets for various chemicals such as di-ethylhexyl-phthalate, 2, 3, 7, 8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin, pirinixic acid, and permethrine. The chemical-protein associations are supported through recent published studies. Humans are exposed to diverse hazardous chemicals daily, and the potential effect of these environmental compounds on human health is a major concern. The network can be used to predict both high level associations (linking chemical exposures to diseases) and more detailed associations (linking chemicals to proteins). The network performed well compared to other protein-protein interaction networks and revealed both known as well as many novel surprising connections between chemicals and diseases or proteins.
Cortical sensory neurons, including those in the primary auditory cortex, are commonly characterized by their receptive fields, which describe the linear relationship between a stimulus and a neuron's response. However, receptive fields do not capture the complex network dynamics in which neurons are embedded. By fitting a nonlinear feedforward network model (a network receptive field) to cortical responses to natural sounds, it was found that primary auditory cortical neurons have a much larger sensitive spectrotemporal domain than indicated by their standard receptive fields. The network receptive field, a simplified network consisting of 1-7 sub-receptive fields, consistently better predicts neural responses to auditory stimuli than the standard receptive fields. The network receptive field reveals separate excitatory and inhibitory sub-fields with different nonlinear properties, and the interaction of the sub-fields gives rise to important operations such as gain control and conjunctive feature detection. These conjunctive effects, where neurons respond only if several specific features are present together, enable increased selectivity for particular complex spectrotemporal structures and may constitute an important stage in sound recognition. Therefore, fitting auditory cortical neural responses with feedforward network models expands on simple linear receptive field models, revealing key nonlinear aspects of cortical processing while remaining easy to interpret in a physiological context. This modeling approach provides new insights into the neural computations underlying perception.
Intracellular circadian clocks, composed of clock genes acting in transcription-translation feedback loops, drive global rhythmic expression of the mammalian transcriptome, allowing an organism to anticipate the momentum of the day. A novel clock-perturbing peptide was used to establish the critical role of casein kinase (CK)-2-mediated circadian BMAL1-Ser90 phosphorylation (BMAL1-P) in regulating central and peripheral core clocks. Subsequent analysis revealed that CRY, as a repressor for protein kinase, mediates periodic binding of CK2β to BMAL1, inhibiting BMAL1-Ser90 phosphorylation by CK2α. FAD binding domain of CRY1, two C-terminal BMAL1 domains, and particularly BMAL1-Lys537 acetylation/deacetylation by CLOCK/SIRT1, are critical for CRY-mediated BMAL1–CK2β binding. This forms a dual negative-feedback model in which a CRY-dependent CK2-driven posttranslational BMAL1–P-BMAL1 loop is an integral part of the core clock oscillator. Mammalian circadian systems orchestrate various metabolic, physiological, and behavioral rhythms through intracellular clockworks present in the suprachiasmatic nuclei and virtually all other cells and tissues. The core oscillator consists of transcription factors operating in transcriptional-translational feedback loops, driving rhythmic expression of approximately 10% of the mammalian transcriptome. The BMAL1–CLOCK heterodimer is the primary genome-wide driver for clock genes and clock-controlled output genes via E-box containing promoters. CRY-PER complexes, facilitated by CLOCK-mediated BMAL1 acetylation, repress the expression of E-box clock-controlled genes, accounting for the negative limb of the circadian feedback loop.
"Bile, a fluid consisting of bile salts, cholesterol, proteins, and electrolytes, is produced by the liver and aids in fat digestion, vitamin absorption, cholesterol elimination, and waste product removal. Its primary bile salts, derived from cholesterol, have antibacterial properties, disrupting membranes, denaturing proteins, and damaging DNA. Salmonella enterica, an antibacterial-resistant pathogen, survives in the bile-laden gallbladder using various strategies, including lumen escape, biofilm formation on gallstones, and planktonic cell survival in the gallbladder. While inhibition of bacterial growth by bile salts often involves bacterial death, Salmonella can adapt to grow at higher bile salt concentrations through previous growth in sublethal concentrations. This adaptation, observed in the laboratory, may be relevant during Salmonella colonization of the hepatobiliary tract. Genetic and biochemical analysis in E. coli and S. enterica has identified cell functions and mechanisms involved in bile resistance, with mutations that cause bile sensitivity often resulting in virulence attenuation in the mouse model of S. enterica infection. Bile resistance factors in Salmonella and other enteric species include envelope barriers, outer and cytoplasmic membranes, efflux pump systems, genes of multiple antibiotic resistence (mar) and PhoPQ regulons, and DNA repair functions. Wild type Salmonella bile resistance can be increased by growth in sublethal concentrations of bile, a phenomenon called ""adaptation,"" which may be relevant during Salmonella colonization of the hepatobiliary tract. Batch Salmonella cultures contain cells that show high levels of bile resistance without previous adaptation, a phenomenon called ""preadaptation,"" involving mutation in specific loci or activation of bile resistance responses in a subpopulation of bacterial cells."
The E. coli chromosome is compacted into 400-500 supercoiled domains by both active and passive mechanisms, including transcription and DNA-protein association. Prophage Mu is organized as a stable domain, bounded by the proximal location of Mu termini L and R, and dependent on a strong gyrase site, the Mu L end, MuB protein, and E. coli nucleoid proteins IHF, Fis and HU. This Mu domain was observed at two different chromosomal locations tested and is proposed to confer transposition readiness to Mu by fostering topological requirements of the reaction and the proximity of Mu ends. Bacterial chromatin is spatially organized and condensed ~1000 fold to fit inside a bacterial cell. The E. coli chromatin is organized in a series of negatively supercoiled loops, segregated by dynamic domain barriers and compacted by several nucleoid-associated proteins (NAPs) including HU, IHF, Fis and H-NS. Supercoiling plays a vital role in compacting the chromosome, and a proper degree of supercoiling is crucial for all DNA-related processes. Transposable phage Mu is a temperate phage that integrates into essentially random locations on the E. coli chromosome. Transposition from mini-Mu plasmids in vitro requires DNA supercoiling for formation of a high-order transpososome within which the two Mu ends are interwound and synapsed. Supercoiling is inferred to be similarly important in vivo where Mu end pairing during replicative transposition additionally requires a centrally located gyrase binding site SGS. This site is the strongest such site studied and is found only in Mu-like prophages. Highly processive supercoiling by gyrase bound at the SGS has been proposed to propagate a supercoiled loop, with SGS at the apex, assisting transposase-mediated synapsis of Mu ends at the base.
This study investigates the use of Primaquine (PQ) to prevent Plasmodium vivax (Pv) relapses and clear mature gametocytes of P. falciparum (Pf), reducing post-treatment transmission. Children in Papua New Guinea received radical cure with Chloroquine, Artemether-Lumefantrine, and either PQ or placebo. Blood samples were collected over 8 months and analyzed for gametocyte carriage. PQ treatment reduced the incidence of Pv gametocytes by 73%, comparable to its effect on blood-stage infections. 92% of Pv and 79% of Pf gametocyte-positive infections were asymptomatic. Pv and Pf gametocyte positivity and density were associated with high blood-stage parasite densities. Mixed-species infections had reduced odds for gametocyte carriage compared to single-species infections. First infections after blood-stage and placebo treatment, likely caused by a relapsing hypnozoite, were equally likely to carry gametocytes than first infections after PQ treatment, likely caused by an infective mosquito bite. Pv relapses and new infections are associated with similar levels of gametocytaemia, highlighting the importance of effective anti-hypnozoite treatment for efficient control of Pv. ClinicalTrials.gov NCT02143934.
The Rho family of GTPases, including RhoA, Rac, and Cdc42, control actin organization during various cellular responses such as migration, cytokinesis, and endocytosis. Although these GTPases have different downstream effects on actin remodeling, they all target the plasma membrane and are activated by GTP binding. The details of GTPase cycling between the membrane and cytosol are crucial to the upstream regulation of these biochemical switches. A modeling framework has been developed to analyze experimental data for these systems, revealing details of GDI-mediated cycling and helping distinguish between GDI-dependent and -independent mechanisms. This analysis can also be used to assess how targeted modifications may compensate for altered GTPase-GDI balance in disease scenarios. The activity of RhoA, Cdc42, and Rac1 is controlled by spatial localization, nucleotide binding, and binding to Rho guanine nucleotide dissociation inhibitor (GDI). The spatial localization of these GTPases is important for activation by membrane-bound guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEF), which promote GTPase release of GDP and binding to GTP; the GTP state activates and/or recruits effectors at the membrane, producing the downstream actin-mediated cellular response. The GTPase activating proteins (GAP) bind to the active GTPases and promote conversion of the nucleotide GTP into GDP, inactivating the GTPase. Binding to GDI promotes relocation of the GTPases from the membrane to the cytosol, inhibits interaction with effectors and inhibits exchange between GDP and GTP bound states. The interactions between GDIs and GTPases can be regulated, modulating the cycling for spatial and temporal localization. The delivery and removal of GTPases from the membrane may also be independent of GDI.
Monitoring and evaluation (M&E) programs are used to collect data for assessing the impact of current interventions on achieving the World Health Organization (WHO) goals of morbidity control and elimination of schistosomiasis as a public health problem. Prevalence and intensity of infection data are typically collected from school-aged children (SAC), but adults are also likely to be infected. A mathematical model was used to investigate the impact of the age distribution of infection on the recommended coverage levels of preventive chemotherapy (PCT) required to achieve WHO goals. The model found that for moderate prevalence regions, treating SAC only may achieve the WHO goals, but for high prevalence regions with a high burden of infection in adults, adult treatment is required. Therefore, the optimal treatment strategy for a defined region requires consideration of the burden of infection in adults, and accurate and detailed data are required from M&E programs. The importance of collecting prevalence and intensity of infection data from a broader age-range, including adults, at baseline and throughout the treatment program is highlighted. Additional epidemiological data such as individual longitudinal adherence to treatment should also be collected in M&E programs.
Temporal Lobe Epilepsy (TLE) is a common neurological disorder characterized by disruptive seizures, with many drug-resistant cases considered for resective surgery. A study using a computational model of epilepsy applied to patient-specific structural connectivity derived from diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) of 22 individuals with left TLE and 39 healthy controls aimed to predict surgical outcomes. The model validated patient-control differences in simulated seizure onset time and location, and performed in silico surgical resections. Results showed that patients tended to transit from non-epileptic to epileptic states more often than controls. Seizure starting points were frequently in left hemisphere temporal and subcortical regions, with additional involvement of contralateral and frontal locations. The model predicted that patient-specific surgery may lead to better outcomes than current clinical procedures. This study provides a step towards patient-specific computational modeling of epilepsy surgery to inform treatment strategies.
Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) is associated with several diseases including Kaposi's sarcoma and certain lymphomas. The virus encodes several genes with oncogenic potential, including vIRF-1, which has the ability to bind and inhibit various pro-apoptotic proteins. Viral chemokines, such as vCCL-1 and vCCL-2, have been shown to induce signal transduction leading to the repression of Bim, a pro-apoptotic protein, thereby promoting virus replication. Immunofluorescence analysis of Bim expression in HHV-8 lytically infected endothelial cells revealed that Bim was largely sequestered in the nuclei, rather than the cytoplasm, in cells supporting lytic reactivation. Further investigation showed that vIRF-1, specifically, induced nuclear translocation of Bim, leading to its inactivation. This vIRF-1-mediated Bim nuclear translocation plays a crucial role in the pro-replication and anti-apoptotic activity of vIRF-1. Disrupting vIRF-1 interaction with Bim specifically has been shown to inhibit Bim-induced cell death and inhibit virus replication. These findings suggest that vIRF-1 and vIRF-1:Bim interaction are effective mediators of apoptotic inhibition during lytic replication and are important for establishing conditions conducive to efficient virus production. Further research into the specific inhibition of vIRF-1:Bim interaction may provide a means to inhibit virus replication specifically and for therapeutic benefit.
The αVβ6 integrin, which is predominantly expressed in lung epithelial cells, plays a crucial role in maintaining lung homeostasis and modulating acute lung injury (ALI) through mechanisms that are not yet fully understood. During influenza infection, the upregulation of β6 is involved in disease pathogenesis. Mice lacking the β6 subunit (β6 KO) have increased survival during influenza infection due to limited viral spread into the alveolar spaces, resulting in reduced ALI. This is attributed to the activation of lung interferon response caused by the absence of β6, which gives the host an advantage in controlling viral spread. The protective phenotype of β6 KO mice is reversed by the administration of exogenous TGF-β or elimination of the type I interferon receptor, indicating that αVβ6 controls a communication system between lung epithelia and immune cells through a TGF-β-dependent mechanism. The β6 integrin also plays a critical role during other respiratory infections such as Sendai virus and bacterial pneumonia. Transient inhibition of αVβ6 represents a potential therapy for the management of acute lung injury.
Leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania (Viannia) braziliensis, is a significant public health issue in the Americas, with cutaneous and mucosal forms. The Leishmanin Skin Test (LST) is a supportive diagnostic tool based on delayed type hypersensitivity responses to Leishmania antigens. A retrospective analysis of 733 individuals evaluated for their first episode of tegumentary leishmaniasis in Argentina (2006-2015) was conducted to assess LST's usefulness in diagnosis. LST showed a high correlation with smear results (Kappa index agreement 0.76, p <0.001) and comparable sensitivity across age groups. Lesions older than 21 days-old correlated with positive results for both smear and LST. The study supports the clinical use of LST as a diagnostic complement for American Cutaneous Leishmaniasis across all age groups, especially in endemic areas, with further research needed for standardization and adequate utilization protocols. Leishmaniasis, caused by L. (V.) braziliensis, affects millions of people in high-burden countries, with cutaneous and mucosal forms. LST, based on delayed type hypersensitivity responses, is a supportive diagnostic tool. A retrospective analysis of 733 individuals in Argentina (2006-2015) found a high correlation between LST and smear results (Kappa index agreement of 0.76, p <0.001) and comparable sensitivity across age groups. Lesions older than 21 days-old correlated with positive results for both smear and LST. The study supports LST's clinical use as a diagnostic complement for American Cutaneous Leishmaniasis in endemic areas, with further research needed for standardization and adequate utilization protocols.
Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified over 40 loci associated with increased risk of coronary artery disease (CAD), but the causal mechanisms behind most of these loci are unknown. Recent studies suggest that many causal GWAS variants affect disease risk through altered transcriptional regulation in disease-relevant cell types. In this study, the authors investigated changes in transcriptional regulation during a key pathophysiological event in CAD, the environmental lipid-induced transformation of macrophages to lipid-laden foam cells. They used a combination of open chromatin mapping with formaldehyde-assisted isolation of regulatory elements (FAIRE-seq) and enhancer and transcription factor mapping using chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP-seq) in primary human macrophages before and after exposure to atherogenic oxidized low-density lipoprotein (oxLDL), with resultant foam cell formation. OxLDL-induced foam cell formation was associated with changes in a subset of open chromatin and active enhancer sites that strongly correlated with expression changes of nearby genes. OxLDL-regulated enhancers were enriched for several transcription factors including C/EBP-beta, which has no previously documented role in foam cell formation. Variants at CAD-associated loci, including rs72664324 in an oxLDL-induced enhancer at the PPAP2B locus, were significantly enriched in the subset of chromatin sites altered by oxLDL exposure. These results demonstrate a genetic mechanism contributing to CAD risk at the PPAP2B locus and highlight the value of studying epigenetic changes in disease processes involving pathogenic environmental stimuli.
In an effort to eliminate trachoma as a public health issue, the World Health Organization (WHO) recommends the implementation of the SAFE strategy in districts where the prevalence of the active trachoma sign trachomatous inflammation--follicular (TF) in 1-9-year-olds is 10% or greater. This strategy includes the implementation of the A (antibiotics), F (facial cleanliness), and E (environmental improvement) components. However, many endemic countries have a large number of districts with TF prevalences between 5-9%, and it is not practical to conduct sub-district level surveys in these areas due to resource constraints. A study was conducted in 8 Malawi districts with baseline TF prevalences of 5-9% to determine the impact of administering one round of azithromycin mass drug administration (MDA) to the entire district, achieving mean coverage of ~80%. The results showed that each of the 18 evaluation units had a TF1-9 prevalence of less than 5%. This suggests that one round of azithromycin MDA with ~80% coverage can reduce TF prevalence to less than 5% in Malawi districts with TF of 5-9%. Further evidence is needed to support this approach in other areas.
Nucleotide-binding domain leucine-rich repeat (NLR) protein complexes in plants and humans sense infections and trigger robust immune responses, including programmed cell death (PCD), reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, and transcriptional reprogramming. Six Arabidopsis Ca2+-dependent protein kinases (CPKs) have been identified as mediating bifurcate immune responses activated by NLR proteins RPS2 and RPM1. The dynamics of differential CPK1/2 activation by pathogen effectors controls the onset of cell death, while sustained CPK4/5/6/11 activation directly phosphorylates a specific subgroup of WRKY transcription factors for transcriptional reprogramming crucial for NLR-dependent restriction of pathogen growth. CPK1/2/4/11 phosphorylate plasma membrane-resident NADPH oxidases for ROS production. Functional genomic screens and biochemical genetic studies have revealed the specific and redundant roles of CPKs in NLR signaling events, including CPK4/5/6/11 in orchestrating immune gene expression, CPK1/2/4/11 in ROS production, and CPK1/2/5/6/ in PCD. Different CPKs are engaged in diverse immune responses via phosphorylation and activation of different substrates in distinct subcellular compartments. A functional genomic screen identified a specific subgroup of WRKY transcription factors that act synergistically with CPKs in primary NLR signaling. Sustained activation of CPK4/5/6/11 phosphorylates WRKY8/28/48 for transcriptional reprogramming of immune genes, whereas CPK1/2/4/11 phosphorylate NADPH oxidases for ROS production and contribute to PCD. Overall, this study reveals bifurcate NLR signaling mechanisms through specific, overlapping, and prolonged actions of CPKs in concert with distinct substrates in multiple subcellular compartments.
Schistosoma sp., a type of parasitic infection, impacts over 500 million individuals in 77 countries, with a higher prevalence in sub-Saharan Africa. Its incidence has risen due to factors like increased irrigation projects, shifts from nomadic to sedentary lifestyles, and ineffective control programs. However, less than 0.5% of Schistosoma sp. studies have attempted to predict spatial and temporal distributions, essential for public health programs in developing countries. This article discusses a study conducted in the Niono district of Mali, utilizing general-purpose exponential smoothing methods for S. haematobium time-series forecasts. These methods, within a state-space framework, accommodate seasonal and inter-annual fluctuations, providing reasonable accuracy for forecasts. This could aid in managing and assessing S. haematobium transmission and intervention impact in the district and potentially in other Sahel regions.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) has a complex relationship with the cell cycle of its host cells. The viral tegument protein pp150 restrains the onset of viral gene expression in the S/G2 phase of the cell cycle, preventing infection in those phases when cyclin A-CDK is active. This allows the virus to synchronize its replication with the cell cycle, restricting it to the G0/G1 phase where cyclin A-CDK is inactive. The early viral gene product pUL21a maintains the status of low cyclin A2-CDK activity by targeting cyclin A for proteasomal degradation. This synchronization strategy is important for the productive replication cycle of HCMV, and without it, the virus may enter mitosis too early, leading to chromosomal damage and cell death. HCMV's synchronization strategy is similar to that of human papillomavirus (HPV), where two RXL motif-containing cyclin A interactors, E1 and E1@E4, regulate the start of viral replication and prevent the onset of mitosis. Both HCMV and HPV have evolved similar strategies to best synchronize their life cycle with the host cell cycle, providing stable conditions for virus growth and arresting the cell cycle in interphase.
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease, causing progressive degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. Approximately 10% of ALS cases are familial, while the remaining 90% are sporadic. Although genetic studies in familial ALS have been informative, the cause of ALS in approximately 30% of familial cases and in the majority of sporadic cases remains unknown. A recent study aimed to identify novel variants linked to ALS by performing targeted sequencing of 169 known and candidate ALS disease genes in 242 sporadic ALS cases and 129 matched controls. The study found a significant enrichment in novel and rare variants in cases versus controls, indicating that they are likely identifying disease-associated mutations. This study highlights the utility of next generation sequencing techniques and rare variant analysis tools to provide insight into the genetic etiology of a heterogeneous sporadic disease. Additionally, the study of sporadic ALS cases, which represent an underutilized resource for genetic information about ALS, can provide valuable information about the genetic architecture of ALS. Further research is needed to fully understand the genetic basis of ALS and to develop effective treatments for this debilitating disease.
The role of Interleukin-6 (IL-6) in cell-mediated immunity, specifically in the development of T cell memory to respiratory viruses, is not yet fully understood. However, recent studies have shown that IL-6 is an important regulator of T cell proliferation and survival, and is abundant during infection with influenza virus. Researchers analyzed virus-specific T cell activity in both wild type and IL-6 deficient mice and found that CD4+ but not CD8+ T cell memory is critically dependent upon IL-6. This effect of IL-6 includes its ability to suppress CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells (Treg), thereby facilitating the activity of virus-specific memory CD4+ T cells. These studies reveal a critical role for IL-6 in ensuring, within the timeframe of an acute infection with a cytopathic virus, that antigen-specific Tregs have no opportunity to down-modulate the immune response, thereby favoring pathogen clearance and survival of the host. Further studies into the generation of anti-viral immunity are needed, especially in the face of emerging new strains of influenza virus. A consideration of how cytokines modulate cellular immune responses will facilitate a better understanding of the interplay between such pathogens and the immune system and provide a rationale for enhancing vaccine efficacy.
Dnmt2 of the Dnmt2 family functions as a DNA and tRNA methyltransferase, but knowledge about its protein interactions is limited, making it difficult to understand its role and biological significance. A study has identified enolase as a Dnmt2-binding protein through a yeast two-hybrid screen. Enolase, which catalyzes the conversion of 2-PG to PEP, has both cytoplasmic and nuclear localization in the parasite Entamoeba histolytica. The study found that enolase acts as a Dnmt2 inhibitor, and this inhibitory activity is antagonized by 2-PG, suggesting that glucose metabolism controls the non-glycolytic function of enolase. Glucose starvation drives enolase to accumulate within the nucleus, leading to the formation of additional enolase-E. histolytica DNMT2 homolog (Ehmeth) complex and a significant reduction of the tRNAAsp methylation in the parasite. The crucial role of enolase as a Dnmt2 inhibitor was demonstrated in E. histolytica expressing a nuclear localization signal (NLS)-fused-enolase. These results establish enolase as the first Dnmt2 interacting protein and highlight an unexpected role of a glycolytic enzyme in the modulation of Dnmt2 activity.
Mosquito-borne pathogens, such as Chikungunya virus, are transmitted to humans through the saliva of mosquitoes during blood feeding. A new study finds that mosquito saliva contains exogenous microRNAs (miRNAs), which are non-coding RNAs that regulate gene expression. This is the first time exogenous miRNAs have been identified in hematophagous arthropod saliva. The researchers discovered 103 miRNAs in mosquito saliva, 31 of which had not been previously identified. Several of these miRNAs were expressed only in Chikungunya-infected mosquitoes, and five of them were tested for their potential to regulate Chikungunya infection, demonstrating their functional role in the transmission and establishment of infection during blood feeding on the host. Mosquitoes are significant public health concern due to their ability to transmit a variety of emerging and re-emerging arboviruses. The presence of mosquito saliva can have a profound effect on the transmission efficiency, pathogen establishment, and disease development. The study of miRNAs in mosquitoes has shown that they play a role in blood digestion, egg development, immune gene regulation, and altered expression in mosquitoes infected with parasites. However, miRNA profiles in mosquito saliva have not been investigated previously. This study aimed to detect and identify miRNAs in the saliva of Ae. aegypti and Ae. albopictus mosquitoes via deep sequencing, and found a total of 103 mature miRNAs, 31 of which were potential novel miRNAs. Fifty-nine and 30 known miRNAs were upregulated in Ae. aegypti and Ae. albopictus CHIKV-infected saliva, respectively, indicating the possible functional importance of these miRNAs in CHIKV dissemination and transmission in the host.
Mitochondria contain an independently maintained genome that encodes several proteins required for cellular respiration. Deletions in the mitochondrial genome have been identified, which cause several maternally inherited diseases and are associated with certain cancers and neurological disorders. These deletions may result from recombination events, and the maintenance and repair of mtDNA are not well understood compared to nuclear DNA. Nuclear DNA repair proteins, such as Rad51p, Rad52p, and Rad59p, localize to mitochondria and contribute to mtDNA repair. A study investigating the contribution of these proteins in mtDNA repair found that both Rad51p and Rad59p are localized to the matrix of the mitochondria and bind directly to mitochondrial DNA. Loss of these three proteins decreases the rate of spontaneous deletion events and impairs the repair of induced mtDNA DSBs. Overall, understanding the mechanisms of mitochondrial mutagenesis and repair is crucial as stability of the mitochondrial genome is required for the survival of most eukaryotic cells and mutations in the mitochondrial genome cause metabolic defects that underlie multiple diseases.
This systematic review aimed to determine the association between social determinants of health and Group A Streptococcal (GAS) infection, acute rheumatic fever (ARF), and rheumatic heart disease (RHD), as well as evaluate the impact of interventions targeting these determinants. The study included 90 articles, representing 91 individual studies, of which 50.5% were poor in quality. A total of 57.1% and 50% of studies reported positive associations between socioeconomic factors and risk of GAS infection and ARF/RHD, respectively. Crowding and socioeconomic status were significantly associated with GAS infection and ARF/RHD, while other determinants such as income, dwelling characteristics, education, employment, and nutrition showed mixed results. Overall, the literature examining the role of social determinants in GAS infection, ARF, and RHD lacked quality, and more interventional studies are needed to establish a clear association and inform preventive strategies.
The PhoQ/PhoP system, a well-studied bacterial signaling network with an architecture found in many two-component systems, controls transcription of a large set of genes in response to various environmental conditions. A single point mutation in the histidine kinase PhoQ results in a striking change in the properties of the circuit. This mutation, which produces a T281R substitution in PhoQ, results in bistability with mutants persisting in morphologically distinct OFF and ON states for many generations. The bistable phenotype comes at a fitness cost, as the mutant has a lower fitness in stationary phase cultures in rich medium compared to the off state. The wild-type PhoQ/PhoP system responds to external stimulus in a graded manner, while the mutant exhibits bimodal distribution of phenotypes and phenotypic hysteresis. The mutation also results in a surge in transcription upon activation and gives rise to a broad distribution of PhoP-regulated transcription in a population of E. coli cells. In vitro experiments have demonstrated that PhoQ (T281R) is a poorer kinase compared to PhoQ (WT), and growth-mediated dilution is the dominant mechanism for reduction in concentrations of the stable proteins PhoP, PhoQ and PhoP-P in the absence of a specific phosphatase. The PhoQ/PhoP network can exhibit bistability at low kinase rates, resulting from positive feedback (transcriptional autoregulation) and the presence of two non-linearities. The bistability results from the low kinase activity and the absence of phosphatase activity of the PhoQ (T281R) mutant. Slow growth histories or high [Mg2+] are sufficient for en masse conversion of OFF cells to ON, a deterministic conversion from OFF to ON state termed “priming”. The bistable system can be considered irreversible, meaning that a population of ON cells cannot be deterministically turned OFF. However, individual ON cells can still transition to the OFF state in the bistable regime because of stochastic fluctuations.
Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis (PAM) is a rare and devastating infection caused by the free-living amoeba Naegleria fowleri, with a high mortality rate and no established success in treatment. The absence of economic incentives for the pharmaceutical industry to develop anti-PAM drugs has led to a reliance on drug repurposing as a cost-effective strategy. A potential target for drug repurposing is the sterol 14-demethylase (CYP51) enzyme, which is essential for the survival of N. fowleri and shares similarities with fungal orthologues. This similarity raises the possibility of repurposing anti-mycotic drugs and optimizing their usage for the treatment of PAM. A recent study has investigated the impact of anti-fungal azole drugs on sterol biosynthesis and viability of cultured N. fowleri trophozoites, identified the endogenous CYP51 substrate, and analyzed the interactions between the recombinant CYP51 target and conazoles by UV-vis spectroscopy and x-ray crystallography. The results validate CYP51 as a potentially 'druggable' target in N. fowleri and conazole drugs as candidates for assessment in the animal model of PAM.
The study of parasitic nematodes, which infect nearly 2 billion people and cause diseases ranging from anemia to cognitive deficits, is crucial in understanding the mechanisms behind protective immunity. Nematode parasites trigger a type 2 immune response via IL-4Rα, but the role of IL-4Rα in maintaining this response is unclear. A recent study used a strain of mice with tamoxifen-inducible IL-4Rα gene deletion to show that sustained IL-4Rα expression is required for the maintenance of type 2 immune responses and protective immunity following interruption after polarization with Nippostrongylus brasiliensis primary infection. Additionally, temporal deletion of IL-4Rα prior to secondary infection enhanced recall of type 2 immune responses and clearance of parasites. This novel function for IL-4Rα is distinct from its role in immune polarization, and has implications for the development of anti-nematode vaccines and understanding the maintenance of type 2 immune responses.
Bartonella bacteria, known to cause various human infections and found in numerous mammals, likely originated as an environmental bacterium and insect commensal before infecting mammals. Rodents and domestic animals serve as the primary reservoirs for most Bartonella genotypes affecting humans. Human movements and actions impact wildlife disease, with over 60% of emerging infectious diseases transmitted from animals to humans. Bartonella bacteria are an exception in tracing zoonotic potential and potential impacts on native hosts due to their high prevalence in various animals. The study constructed global phylogenies of Bartonella from both 16s rRNA genes and citrate synthase (gltA) to determine the evolutionary history, patterns of host switching, geographic constraint, and spillover into humans or from human commensals into wild species. Research was conducted under appropriate permits and approved by the Stanford University Administrative Panel on Laboratory Animal Care. Sequences were downloaded from Genbank, and metadata were confirmed by examining the cited publications. Sequences were aligned, refined, and reduced for redundancy. Bayesian phylogenies were constructed for the 540 bp fragment and the 277 bp fragment, testing two models for the phylogenetic hypothesis based on the 540 bp fragment. The study found that Bartonella most likely originated in the environment and guts of insects, infecting mammals approximately 79 million years ago. Twice, Bartonella has infected mammals from these environmental samples, which are basal to the main clade of mammal-associated Bartonella. Bartonella are generally highly host-specific, but the study observed a number of host shifts in the large phylogenetic hypothesis. Of 19 spillovers into humans, seven were from rodent clades, two from bats, one from rabbits, one from roe deer, and four from cats and dogs. Four genotypes were of uncertain origin, including B. bacilliformis, B. ancashensis, B. quintana, and B. tamiae.
The long noncoding RNA MALAT1 is upregulated in cancer tissues and is involved in hyper-proliferation, but the underlying mechanism is poorly understood. MALAT1 levels are regulated during the normal cell cycle and modulate the expression of cell cycle genes, required for G1/S and mitotic progression. Its depletion leads to activation of p5
Juvenile hormone (JH) is a key hormone that regulates insect development, metamorphosis, and reproduction. Methoprene-tolerant (Met), a JH receptor, has been shown to mediate JH action during metamorphosis and vitellogenesis. However, the molecular basis for JH's role in promoting adult reproduction has not been fully elucidated. In a recent study, researchers found that JH stimulates DNA replication and increases ploidy in the fat body of migratory locusts to facilitate vitellogenesis. This is achieved through the JH-receptor complex acting on Mcm4 and Mcm7, two genes in the DNA replication pathway. Knockdown of Mcm4 or Mcm7 inhibited de novo DNA synthesis and polyploidization, resulting in reduced vitellogenin mRNA levels and impaired oocyte maturation and ovarian growth. Met directly regulates the transcription of Mcm4 and Mcm7 by binding to upstream consensus sequences with E-box or E-box-like motifs. These findings provide insight into JH-dependent polyploidy and vitellogenesis.
"The ""Treatment of Early Neuropathy in Leprosy"" (TENLEP) trial was designed to determine how prednisolone treatment best prevents permanent nerve function impairment (NFI) in leprosy patients. This study focused on a clinical trial where patients were randomized to receive either a 20-week or 32-week prednisolone course to test if a longer treatment duration would be more effective in restoring and improving recent clinical neuropathy (<6 months onset). The trial involved leprosy patients between 15 and 60 years of age with any recent peripheral NFI. The primary outcome was the proportion of patients with restored or improved nerve function as measured by MFT and/or VMT at 78 weeks.The trial included 868 patients, of whom 432 were randomized to the 20-week arm and 439 to the 32-week arm. However, seven patients were excluded from the final analyses due to missing baseline MFT assessments or not meeting the inclusion criteria. The intake and distribution of patient characteristics per research center were similar between the two groups, with sensory function being more often impaired than motor function at baseline.The trial treatment period was completed by 65.5% of the patients in the 20-week arm and 66.7% of those in the 32-week arm. Complete follow-up data until week 78 were collected for 82% of the patients in the 20-week arm and 75% of those in the 32-week arm. The last observation carried forward method was used to handle missing data of patients lost to follow-up.The proportion of patients with restored or improved nerve function at week 78 was almost similar in both groups: 78.1% in the 20-week arm and 77.5% in the 32-week arm (p = 0.821). There were no significant differences between the two groups in secondary outcomes such as individual nerves, impairment counts, RSS, SALSA-scale and P-scale scores between baseline and week 78, SAEs, and the proportion of patients needing additional prednisolone. However, there was a significantly higher proportion of Serious Adverse Events (SAEs) in the longer treatment arm (p = 0.04).In conclusion, a 20-week course of prednisolone is as effective as a 32-week course in improving and restoring recent clinical NFI in leprosy patients. Therefore, 20 weeks is the preferred initial treatment duration for leprosy neuropathy."
The Rocky Mountain elk (Cervus elaphus nelsoni) and the European Red Deer (Cervus elaphus scoticus) use distinct types of sound communication during the mating season, with the elk producing loud, high-frequency bugles and the red deer producing loud, low-frequency roars. These sounds are the result of the interaction between anatomy, physiology, and biomechanics of the larynx and vocal tract. A finite element model of the larynx and a wave propagation model of the vocal tract have been used to understand the physiology of this system. The models show that low-frequency sounds, like those of the red deer, are related to overall body size, while high-frequency sounds, like those of the elk, may signal muscular strength and endurance. The elk's high-frequency bugle is achieved through large muscular effort and high lung pressure, resulting in a more intense sound. Glottal efficiency is higher in elk, indicating an advantage of high-pitched signaling. The dichotomy between low-frequency and high-frequency calls is not always related to body size, as larger male mammals can use high-pitched vocalization for display. The production of high-frequency calls, such as those of the elk, requires a large and stiff ligament, which can be operated at its mechanical limits and requires significant muscular effort to maintain.
Chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by high-throughput sequencing (ChIP-seq) is a powerful technique for large scale profiling of transcription factor binding and chromatin modifications, and is replacing ChIP-chip as the preferred approach for mapping transcription-factor binding sites and chromatin modifications. The state of the art for analyzing ChIP-seq data relies on using only reads that map uniquely to a relevant reference genome. However, this can lead to the omission of up to 30% of alignable reads. A study describes a general approach for utilizing reads that map to multiple locations on the reference genome by allocating multi-reads as fractional counts using a weighted alignment scheme. This approach leads to detection of novel peaks that are not otherwise identifiable with uni-reads and improves detection of peaks in mappable regions. Peaks from multi-read analysis have similar characteristics to peaks that are identified by uni-reads except that the majority of them reside in segmental duplications. Overall, this study establishes that multi-reads can be of critical importance for studying transcription factor binding in highly repetitive regions of genomes with ChIP-seq experiments.
The World Health Organization (WHO) has set targets for the control or elimination of neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) by 2020, as reinforced by the 2
The widely accepted notion in neuroscience is that neurons with higher selectivity carry more information about external sensory inputs. However, a study on the auditory cortex found that high-selectivity neurons respond to a narrow range of sensory inputs, but the neural population conveys similar information about sound input across two temporal response epochs, with the amount of information encoded being almost completely dependent on the total number of population spikes in the read-out window. Contrary to the prevailing theory, the sustained response epoch, which has more selective neurons, conveys similar information about sound input as the onset response epoch. This suggests a novel principle of sensory encoding potentially shared widely among multiple sensory systems. The study highlights the importance of understanding the collective behavior of neural populations instead of focusing on individual neurons for a comprehensive understanding of sensory information processing in the brain.
In persistent viral infections like the one caused by the clone 13 (cl13) isolate of the lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCMV), T cell responses need to be maintained over a longer period of time to control viral replication and avoid viral spreading. While inhibitory signals limiting T cell activity during chronic viral infection have been well-studied, less is known about the stimulatory signals that allow maintenance of anti-viral T cells. The co-stimulatory molecule OX40 is critical for controlling LCMV cl13 infection. Anti-viral T cells express high levels of OX40 in the presence of their cognate antigen and T cells lacking the OX40 receptor fail to accumulate sufficiently. The emergence of T cell dependent germinal center responses and LCMV-specific antibodies are also impaired in the absence of OX40. OX40-deficient mice fail to control LCMV clone 13 infection over time, highlighting the importance of this signaling pathway during persistent viral infection. OX40 signaling has the ability to promote long-term survival of T cells, and its importance might be more prominent in the context of viral persistence. In persistent LCMV cl13 infection, OX40 shapes both the CD4 and CD8 T cell response, and OX40-deficient mice are incapable of controlling viral replication.
"Convergent evolution, or the development of similar traits in species that do not share a recent common ancestor, is powerful evidence for the ""robust repeatability thesis"" in evolution. This theory suggests that the evolution of animals can be explained by the comparative selective advantage of evolutionary survivors over their inferior counterparts. In contrast, the ""radical contingency thesis"" argues that early patterns of animal evolution were generated by a selection process unrelated to the comparative fitnesses of the selected lineages.One example of convergent evolution can be observed in the swimming patterns of a diverse group of aquatic animals, including invertebrates and vertebrates from three different phyla. These animals swim by undulating elongated fins while keeping their body relatively rigid, a method that has evolved independently at least eight times. This swimming pattern, known as median/paired fin swimming, is characterized by an optimal specific wavelength (OSW) of approximately twenty times the mean amplitude (ã) of movement. This OSW maximizes the force generated by the body, resulting in a more efficient swimming motion.The OSW has been observed in a wide range of species, from small invertebrates to large fish, and is independent of the size of the fin. It is also insensitive to changes in key kinematic variables such as frequency and amplitude, as well as to changes in fin geometry such as height and shape. This suggests that once an elongated fin species has arisen, it may be costly to depart from the OSW. However, the majority of swimmers are not elongated fin species, and it is unclear why slower forms of swimming exhibited by median/paired fin animals would emerge and thrive despite the prevalence of body/caudal fin swimming in ancestral species.One possible explanation is that median/paired fin swimming is a low speed, low cost of transport specialization. The lower amplitudes of fin movement possible in median/paired fin swimmers, compared to the high power axial musculature used in body/caudal fin swimmers, result in a lower energetic cost of transport. This makes median/paired fin swimming an advantage in certain ecological contexts, despite the prevalence of body/caudal fin swimming in ancestral species.In summary, convergent evolution in the form of the OSW in median/paired fin swimming is evidence for the robust repeatability of evolution. This OSW, which has evolved independently at least eight times, is an efficient swimming pattern that maximizes thrust and is insensitive to changes in key fin movement parameters. The emergence of this trait in elongated fin species is likely to provide a selective advantage in certain ecological contexts."
The development of the cerebral cortex requires strict control of cell proliferation and differentiation, with neural stem cells (NSCs) in the ventricular zone (VZ) undergoing symmetrical divisions to expand the cell population and asymmetrical divisions to generate neurons and intermediate progenitor cells. Chromosome assembly and segregation during mitosis in NSCs rely on condensin I and II, two different types of condensin complexes. A study using mouse models with conditional knockouts (cKO) of condensin I and II subunits found that both complexes are essential for NSC divisions and survival, with individual depletions leading to distinct mitotic defects. NSCs depleted of condensin II display hyperclustering of pericentric heterochromatin and nucleoli, indicating a critical role for condensin II in establishing interphase nuclear architecture. These defects are carried over to postmitotic neurons. The study provides insight into the intricate balancing acts of the two condensin complexes during cortical development.
Schistosoma mansoni, a pathogenic parasite to humans, is a member of Schistosomatidae family which consists of over 20,000 hermaphroditic trematode species that have evolved gonochorism. Sex determination in schistosomes occurs through a female heterogametic system, but phenotypic sexual dimorphism is not apparent until after infection of the vertebrate definitive host, and gonad maturation occurs even later, after pairing. The molecular mechanisms that trigger sexual differentiation in these species are unknown, and in vivo studies on developing schistosomulum stages are lacking. To study the molecular basis of sex determination and sexual differentiation in schistosomes, a RNA-seq was performed on males and females for five developmental stages: cercariae larvae, three in vivo schistosomulum stages and adults. The results showed that 7,168 genes were differentially expressed between sexes in at least one of the developmental stages, and 4,065 were functionally annotated. Transcriptome data were complemented with H3K27me3 histone modification analysis using ChIP-Seq before and after the appearance of phenotypic sexual dimorphism. The study identified candidate determinants of sexual differentiation, sex-biased players of the interaction with the vertebrate host, and different dynamic of the H3K27me3 histone mark between sexes as an illustration of sex-biased epigenetic landscapes. This research provides a valuable resource for understanding the molecular mechanisms that underlie sex determination and differentiation in S. mansoni, and it highlights the importance of studying the interplay between genetic and epigenetic regulation during sexual development in this parasitic species. As S. mansoni is pathogenic for humans, this study represents a promising source of therapeutic targets, providing not only data on the parasite development in interaction with its vertebrate host but also new insights on its reproductive function.
A study presents a method to model disagreements among experts in large-scale annotation efforts by providing each annotation with a confidence value, the posterior probability that it is correct. This approach allows computing certainty-levels for individual annotations based on annotator-specific parameters estimated from data. Two probabilistic models were developed, compared using computer simulation, and tested on a large data set generated by human annotators. The results showed that the approach significantly increased the probability of choosing the correct annotation even when all annotators disagreed. The study also introduced a corpus of 10,00
A DNA vaccine technology has been used to produce antiviral biologics, including polyclonal neutralizing antibodies, for potential use in humans against HPS (hantavirus pulmonary syndrome), caused mainly by ANDV (Andes virus) and ANDV-like viruses in South America. This vaccine technology involves the use of geese, which produce IgY and IgYΔFc antibodies that lack the properties of mammalian Fc, making them less reactogenic in humans. Geese were vaccinated with an ANDV DNA vaccine, and all developed high-titer neutralizing antibodies after the second vaccination, which were maintained for over a year. The goose-derived antibodies were found to be highly reactive to specific amino acid sequences of ANDV envelope glycoproteins and protected hamsters from lethal HPS. These findings demonstrate the potential of using the DNA vaccine/goose platform to produce a candidate antiviral biological product capable of preventing a lethal disease when administered post-exposure.
Changes in genomic DNA methylation patterns are crucial in the development of human cancers. The Dnmt3a enzyme is necessary for the establishment of normal methylation patterns, and mutations in Dnmt3a have been found in leukemias. A study using a K-ras–dependent mouse lung cancer model found that deletion of Dnmt3a promotes tumor progression, indicating that Dnmt3a might suppress tumor development by stabilizing DNA methylation patterns. Whole-genome bisulfite sequencing was used to characterize the methylomes of Dnmt3a wildtype and Dnmt3a-deficient mouse lung tumors. The results showed that profound global methylation changes occur in K-ras–induced lung cancer, with Dnmt3a wild-type tumors characterized by large hypomethylated domains and Dnmt3a-deficient tumors showing a uniformly hypomethylated genome. Further data analysis revealed that Dnmt3a is required for efficient maintenance methylation of active chromosome domains and that Dnmt3a-deficient tumors show moderate levels of gene deregulation in these domains. These results uncover conserved features of cancer methylomes and define the role of Dnmt3a in maintaining DNA methylation patterns in cancer.
A study in songbirds has discovered a spatial and temporal organization of the premotor cortical microcircuit that supports sparse sequences of neural activity, which are important for generating various forms of learned behavior. The study utilized multi-channel electrophysiology and calcium imaging to reveal that neural activity in premotor cortex is inhomogeneous in time and space, and that a mesoscopic dynamical pattern underlies the generation of the neural sequences controlling song. Specifically, basal-ganglia–projecting excitatory neurons fire at a specific phase of a local 30 Hz network rhythm, creating a mesoscopic length scale in the premotor cortical area HVC. This length scale is similar to those reported in calcium imaging of cortex in behaving rodents, primate motor control, and human speech, suggesting that these may be core properties of motor cortical microcircuits across species. The study also found that the spatial organization of cellular activity has been considered irrelevant in dynamical models of the HVC network, but experimental studies suggest that HVC activity is spatially organized. However, temporal correlations between inhibition and excitation have been ignored in the models, despite the fact that excitatory and inhibitory neurons are known to be interconnected in HVC. Overall, the study highlights the importance of considering spatial and temporal correlations in models of HVC network and the need for further research in this area.
The genetic regulation of aging and lifespan has been studied through the use of model organisms such as C. elegans, where it has been shown that insulin/IGF-1/daf-2 signaling can more than double the lifespan of an animal. This regulation occurs during adulthood and involves the insulin-signaling pathway negatively regulating the forkhead (FOXO) transcription factor DAF-16. This regulation of lifespan through an insulin-like signaling cascade is conserved in flies and mice. In C. elegans, germline proliferation negatively regulates lifespan through a DAF-16 and KRI-1 mediated signal, while the somatic gonad promotes lifespan extension. Caloric restriction (CR) has also been shown to extend lifespan across species, and in C. elegans the sir-2.1 and let-363 genes regulate lifespan via CR. CR can increase lifespan at any time in flies, while mutations in the mitochondrial electron transport system can increase lifespan in worms. However, mutations in the ubiquinone biosynthesis gene clk-1 do not further increase the longevity phenotype from CR. Genome-wide RNAi screens have identified potential regulators of lifespan in C. elegans, but these screens may not identify essential genes that cause lethality or developmental pleiotropies. A recent study identified 64 genes that, when inactivated postdevelopmentally by RNAi, increase adult lifespan. These genes are highly conserved from yeast to humans and are involved in pathways such as insulin-signaling, stress adaptation, metabolism, and reproduction. These findings suggest that essential genes that function in postreproductive longevity control should be under natural selection at prereproductive stages and provide a new set of genes for studying the mechanisms of lifespan regulation.
A study investigating appendage regeneration in zebrafish fins has identified a temperature-sensitive allele of the extracellular matrix component laminin beta 1a (lamb1a) that blocks fin regeneration. The lamb1a gene is sharply induced in a subset of epithelial cells after fin amputation and is required to establish and maintain a polarized basal epithelial cell layer. This is necessary for the expression of morphogenetic factors shha and lef1, basolateral positioning of phosphorylated Igf1r, patterning of new osteoblasts, and regeneration of bone. By contrast, lamb1a function is dispensable for juvenile body growth, homeostatic adult tissue maintenance, repair of split fins, or renewal of genetically ablated osteoblasts. These findings reveal transient induction of lamb1a in epithelial cells as a key, growth factor-guided step in formation of a signaling-competent regeneration epidermis. Interestingly, mammals have a limited ability to regenerate complex structures like limbs, heart, or central nervous system tissue, while teleost fish and urodele amphibians can regenerate major appendages, spinal cord, retina, brain, kidney, and the heart. The study of appendage regeneration in zebrafish fins has identified three prominent phases: 1) wound healing; 2) blastema formation; and 3) regenerative outgrowth and patterning. The wound epithelium becomes multilayered and acquires a layer of cuboidal basal epithelial cells over the next hours to days, maturing into a structure commonly referred to as the wound or regeneration epidermis, which expresses markers of developmental signaling pathways, including many secreted factors. Previous studies have shown that fgf20a and igf2b ligand genes are induced within hours of fin amputation in mesenchymal cells, and perturbation of Fgf signaling via a mutation in the fgf20a ligand gene or of Igf signaling by receptor inhibition disrupts formation of the regeneration epidermis and subsequent bone regeneration. However, the mechanisms by which these pathways define the morphology and signaling activities of the regeneration epidermis have not been addressed. The current study used forward genetics to identify a critical role for laminin beta 1a (lamb1a), one of two paralogs encoding a Laminin beta 1 extracellular matrix component, in zebrafish fin regeneration. Laminin is a critical node between growth factor signals and formation of the regeneration epidermis in an amputated vertebrate appendage.
Linear mixed models (LMMs) have gained popularity for modeling population substructure and relatedness in genome-wide association studies. This approach builds on earlier methods from animal breeding and human genetics literature, and assumes a genetic correlation between individuals. LMMs have been adapted for use with samples of unknown or uncertain relationship, with kinship coefficients estimated from genome-wide genotype data. Several software packages have been developed to implement LMMs, including EMMAX, GenABEL, FaST-LMM, TASSEL, and GEMMA. A comparison of these implementations, using a genome-wide association study of visceral leishmaniasis in 348 Brazilian families, found strong concordance between the results from different LMM approaches and success in controlling the genome-wide error rate. The choice of LMM implementation should be based on considerations such as speed and ease-of-use, as power and type I error considerations do not provide a clear distinction between the different approaches. LMMs have been proposed as alternatives to principal component-based approaches for adjusting population substructure and have shown to perform well in comparison to competing approaches.
The development of new drugs for Chagas disease is a priority due to the limited effectiveness and toxicity of currently available medications that are only effective against the acute phase of the disease. A whole-cell-based assay for high throughput screening of compounds that inhibit infection of mammalian cells by Trypanosoma cruzi trypomastigotes has been optimized and used to screen a 2000-compound chemical library. Three hits, PCH1, NT1, and CX1, were selected for their high activity against T. cruzi and low toxicity to host cells. These three compounds have different mechanisms of action on intracellular proliferation of T. cruzi amastigotes. CX1 has strong trypanocidal activity, an essential characteristic for the development of drugs against the chronic stage of Chagas disease. NT1 has a trypanostatic effect, while PCH1 affects parasite division. These compounds also show high activity against intracellular T. cruzi from the Y strain and against the related kinetoplastid species Leishmania major and L. amazonensis. Two additional compounds, PCH6 and CX2, were selected based on their chemical similarity to PCH1 and CX1, respectively. These compounds have IC50 values of 2 nM, which is approximately 100 times lower than those of the medicines used in patients against T. cruzi. These results provide new candidate molecules for the development of treatments against Chagas disease and leishmaniasis.
"A novel diagnostic approach for molecular xenomonitoring of filarial parasites in mosquitoes has been developed, utilizing a rapid, NaOH-based DNA extraction methodology combined with a portable, battery-powered PCR platform and a test strip-based DNA detection assay. This ""Backpack PCR"" methodology provides a cheaper and equipment-minimizing diagnostic option that can be transported to the field and implemented in minimal resource settings. It can be adapted to the detection of W. bancrofti and other mosquito-transmitted pathogens. The platform has been proven to be effective in detecting B. malayi DNA from extracted mosquito pools, providing sensitive and genus-specific detection, and eliminating reliance on expensive instrumentation without compromising sensitivity or specificity of detection. The field-ready system should increase the feasibility of molecular xenomonitoring within B. malayi-endemic locations and provides a proof-of-concept for the development of a parallel assay for the detection of W. bancrofti."
Elastomeric proteins, such as elastin, resilin, abductin, spider dragline silks, and wheat gluten, are self-assembling proteins that provide extensibility and elastic recoil. They have evolved independently and are composed of alternating hydrophobic and cross-linking domains. The hydrophobic domains, which are rich in repetitive sequences, provide elasticity and drive the self-assembly process, while the cross-linking domains help stabilize the polymer. Studies on the impact of domain architecture on polymer assembly and integrity have shown that the relative length and number of elastomeric and cross-linking domains significantly impact the morphology and structural integrity of the resultant polymeric structure. For example, highly connected polymers were constructed from asymmetric rods consisting of relatively large cross-linking elements interspersed with smaller elastomeric domains. Understanding the relationships between the supramolecular organization of elastomeric proteins and their mechanical properties can guide the rational design of novel elastomeric-peptides. Mesoscale methods, such as the modified Diffusion-Limited Aggregation (DLA) algorithm, can be used to simulate the self-assembly of elastomeric proteins and explore the impact of different configurations of elastomeric and cross-linking elements on the morphology and stability of the assembled polymer. These simulations provide insights into the molecular basis for the evolution of elastomeric proteins and help guide the rational design of novel elastomeric-peptides.
"Ebolaviruses, highly lethal zoonotic pathogens, have longer genomes than most other non-segmented negative-strand RNA viruses due to long 5′ and 3′ untranslated regions (UTRs) in the seven viral transcriptional units. However, specific functions have not been assigned to these UTRs. A study using reporter assays showed that the Zaire ebolavirus (EBOV) 5′-UTRs lack internal ribosomal entry site function but differentially regulate cap-dependent translation when placed upstream of a GFP reporter gene. The 5′-UTR derived from the viral polymerase (L) mRNA strongly suppresses translation of GFP compared to a β-actin 5′-UTR. The L 5′-UTR is one of four viral genes to possess upstream AUGs (uAUGs), and ablation of each uAUG enhanced translation of the primary ORF (pORF), most dramatically in the case of the L 5′-UTR. The L uAUG is sufficient to initiate translation, is surrounded by a ""weak"" Kozak sequence and suppresses pORF translation in a position-dependent manner. Under conditions where eIF2α is phosphorylated, the presence of the uORF maintains translation of the L pORF, indicating that the uORF modulates L translation in response to cellular stress. Mutating two nucleotides outside of previously-defined protein coding and cis-acting regulatory sequences in the L uAUG attenuated virus growth to titers 10-100-fold lower than a wild-type virus in Vero and A549 cells. The mutant virus also exhibited decreased viral RNA synthesis as early as 6 hours post-infection and enhanced sensitivity to the stress inducer thapsigargin. These findings identify novel mechanisms by which EBOV regulates its polymerase expression, demonstrate their relevance to virus replication and identify a potential therapeutic target."
Genome instability plays a critical role in various biological processes and diseases, particularly cancer. A new method was developed for precise genome-wide mapping of blunt-ended DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) in human chromosomes, revealing non-random fragmentation and DSB hot spots. These hot spots are scattered along chromosomes and delimit protected 50–250 kb DNA domains. About 30% of the domains, called forum domains, possess coordinately expressed genes and specifically bind PARP1 and HNRNPA2B1 proteins at the forum domain termini. This novel type of gene regulation, coordinated transcription or silencing of gene clusters delimited by DSB hot spots, provides insights into chromosomal architecture and specific chromosomal regions at DSBs. Furthermore, the data suggest that unknown chromosomal regulatory mechanisms may be involved in replication, transcription, and DSB formation in various normal cell types and could be affected in cancer cells, leading to massive genomic rearrangements.
This study focused on the infection of Trypanosomatidae in bats in two areas of the Atlantic Forest in Rio de Janeiro state, Reserva Ecológica de Guapiaçu (REGUA) and Estação Fiocruz Mata Atlântica (EFMA), and assessed whether trypanosomatid diversity is influenced by bat diversity and the degree of preservation. The study found no influence of the level of preservation on bat species richness, with similar chiropterofauna and a higher abundance of two common fruit-eating bat species in the tropics. Of the 181 bat specimens analyzed, 13% were infected by trypanosomatids, with no significant difference between the two areas. Trypanosoma dionisii was the most frequently detected parasite, followed by T. cruzi DTUs TcI and TcIV, and Trypanosoma sp. Mixed infections and a new host record for T. dionisii were also observed. The study confirmed that bats from the Atlantic Forest of Rio de Janeiro state harbor a great diversity of trypanosomatids and maintain trypanosomatid diversity in this sylvatic environment. The findings emphasize the importance of studying local biodiversity and the potential public health implications of these parasites.
Ixodes ricinus ticks, the most common vector of diseases to humans and animals in Europe, can transmit a wide range of bacteria, viruses, and parasites, with many ticks co-infected with multiple pathogens. A study of 267 I. ricinus female ticks from the French Ardennes found that 45% were infected with at least one pathogen, with the most prevalent being Lyme disease spirochetes (21.7%), Bartonella henselae (17.6%), and Rickettsia of the spotted fever group (16.8%). The high prevalence of these pathogens and the potential for co-transmission to humans or animals pose significant concerns for public and animal health. Additionally, tick symbionts, which can affect tick biology and potentially interact with pathogens, were also prevalent, with 100% of ticks carrying at least one microorganism and up to eight different microorganisms in a single tick. The study's findings highlight the importance of considering co-infections and symbionts in tick-borne disease research and prevention efforts.
Hematopoietic stem cell lineage choices are determined by genetic networks, including the erythroid-myeloid lineage decision governed by a genetic switch involving the genes PU.1 and GATA-1. These genes are primed at low expression levels prior to lineage commitment, and their molecular circuitry is crucial to understanding not only hematopoiesis but also developmental systems in general. A computational model was developed to explain the mechanism of this genetic switch, which includes a cofactor regulated and recruited by one of the master genes to bind to the antagonistic partner for bistability and switch-like behavior. This switch interacts with another mutually antagonistic pair, FOG-1, which inherits the state of its upstream master genes and further reinforces the decision. Perturbing the feedback between the master regulators and downstream targets suggests potential reprogramming strategies. This genetic switch example highlights the significance of regulating cooperativity through cofactor recruitment in lineage commitment studies.
Enterococcus faecalis, a commensal bacterium often found in the gastrointestinal tract and environment, can become opportunistic pathogens causing hospital-acquired infections. These infections can be difficult to treat due to antibiotic resistance and biofilm formation. One factor contributing to E. faecalis pathogenesis is resistance to the host innate immune system, including high resistance to lysozyme. This resistance is mediated by a complex network of transcriptional regulators and genes such as oatA, pgdA, dltA, and sigV, which inhibit lysozyme's enzymatic and cationic antimicrobial peptide activities.To identify novel genes involved in E. faecalis resistance to lysozyme, transposon mutagenesis was performed in a quadruple mutant (oatA/pgdA/dltA/sigV) deficient in known lysozyme resistance genes. This led to the identification of a locus called the enterococcal polysaccharide antigen (EPA) variable region, which is responsible for EPA decorations. These decorations contribute to resistance towards charged antimicrobials and underpin virulence in the zebrafish model of infection by conferring resistance to phagocytosis. Specifically, EPA decoration reduces the negative charge of teichoic acids, inhibiting the cationic antimicrobial peptide activity of lysozyme, and affects peptidoglycan composition, impairing cell envelope integrity. Moreover, epa mutants display increased susceptibility to antimicrobials targeting the cell envelope, such as SDS, polymyxin B, nisin, and sodium cholate. Overall, these findings indicate that EPA decoration plays a crucial role in E. faecalis resistance to antimicrobials and virulence, revealing a new target for developing novel treatment strategies against E. faecalis infections.
The papers discussed aim to understand the transcriptional programs in complex organisms, focusing on human systems. Transcriptional regulation is carried out by transcription factors (TFs) and microRNA (miRNA), which can act as activators or repressors at the transcriptional or post-transcriptional level, respectively. With the advancement of high-throughput technologies, large-scale expression profiling of long and small RNAs, genome-wide interrogation of TF occupancy, and DNA methylation have become widely available through consortia such as ENCODE and TCGA. These data provide an opportunity to develop computational models that effectively integrate heterogeneous data from multiple platforms and reveal insights into transcriptional regulation.Previous studies have explored the topology of TF-miRNA coregulatory networks, integrated TF-binding signals with miRNA regulatory networks, and employed supervised machine-learning methods to predict mRNA expression using TF-binding data. However, these studies have limitations, such as not considering both TF and miRNA regulations simultaneously or not incorporating valuable non-binary TF binding data.To address these issues, the authors propose a two-stage regression framework, RACER (Regression Analysis of Combined Expression Regulation), which integrates data from both TCGA and ENCODE. RACER first infers sample-specific TF activities using ENCODE TF binding data derived from a generic cell-line and then uses the estimated regulatory activities to infer miRNA/TF-gene regulatory relationships across samples. This approach has been applied to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) data, demonstrating superior statistical power in detecting known or confidence TF/miRNA-gene interactions compared to alternative models.The study identified 18 prominent (post-) transcriptional regulators, including 16 TFs and 2 miRNAs, whose inferred activities consistently cluster based on cytogenetic risk groups. Among these, the authors propose a novel role for a recently identified miRNA hsa-miR-548p in AML pathogenesis due to its significant target gene enrichments for leukemia-related pathways and its inferred interaction with another prominent feature regulator, YY1, whose perturbed expression has been implicated in AML development. Additionally, they identified a potential prognostic marker using the inferred TF activities of C-Fos, which has been previously shown to have oncogenic activity and is frequently overexpressed in tumour cells.In summary, the authors provide a novel framework that successfully integrates the TCGA and ENCODE data in revealing AML-specific regulatory programs at the global level, providing insights into the condition-specific transcription programs in complex organisms.
The fungal kingdom is vast and diverse, with RNA silencing pathways that function in genome protection and are involved in pathogenicity, development, and antiviral defense. Fungal viruses, or mycoviruses, are widespread and can have debilitating effects on their host, making them a potential tool for controlling fungal plant pathogens. In the ascomycete fungus Colletotrichum higginsianum, knock-out mutants affecting genes for three RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RDR), two Dicer-like (DCL), and two Argonaute (AGO) proteins were generated to investigate the role of RNA silencing. The greatest effects on RNA populations were observed in the Δdcl1, Δdcl1Δdcl2, and Δago1 strains, where a previously uncharacterized dsRNA mycovirus, Colletotrichum higginsianum non-segmented dsRNA virus 1 (ChNRV1), was derepressed. Phylogenetic analyses showed a close relationship between ChNRV1 and members of the segmented Partitiviridae family. Immunoprecipitation of small RNAs associated with AGO1 showed abundant loading of 5’U-containing viral siRNA. Further analysis revealed that the conidiation and spore morphology defects in the Δdcl1 strain were primarily caused by ChNRV1. Therefore, RNA silencing involving ChDCL1 and ChAGO1 in C. higginsianum is proposed to function as an antiviral mechanism against ChNRV1.
In male meiosis, the phosphorylation of H2AX (γH2AX) occurs in three waves during meiotic prophase I, initiated by ATM at leptonema and ATR at zygonema and pachynema. MOF, a major HAT for histone H4 lysine 16 (H4K16), is involved in all three waves of H2AX phosphorylation expansion. In the absence of MOF, MDC1 recruitment and MSCI are disturbed, and RAD51 foci persist in Mof cKO spermatocytes, indicating defects in DSB repair and the formation of crossovers. MOF is differentially expressed in mouse tissues with much higher expression in testes than other organs, and it is highly expressed in meiotic and post-meiotic cells.
