Male mice with germ cell-specific Mof deletion (Mof cKO) have very small testes, a significantly decreased ratio of testis to body weight, and a functional role in spermatogenesis. Testes from adult Mof cKO mice exhibited a marked decrease in the diameter of seminiferous tubules and the number of germ cells, with many tubules showing arrest at the primary spermatocyte stage, and a few tubules lacking meiotic cells. Immunofluorescence ( IF ) staining of testicular sections for VASA indicated massive germ cell loss in Mof cKO testes, and meiotic progression is disturbed with a significantly higher ratio of leptotene to zygotene spermatocytes and lower ratio of pachytene spermatocytes. The sperm count in epididymides of Mof cKO mice also dropped to about 10% of that in control animals, indicating that MOF plays an important role in the maintenance and development of germ cells at different stages, especially those in meiotic prophase I.
"The article discusses the role of human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 (HTLV-1) in the development of T-cell leukemia, specifically adult T-cell leukemia (ATL). The study uses a ""Human Immune System"" (HIS) Rag2-/-γc-/- mouse model, which is infected with HTLV-1. The results show that the virus integrates into the thymocytes of the mice, leading to alterations in human T-cell development and an increase in the number of mature single-positive CD4+ and CD8+ cells at the expense of immature and double-positive thymocytes. These alterations are correlated with the proviral load and are accompanied by the activation of human lymphocytes and the expression of NF-kB dependent genes, such as bfl-1, an anti-apoptotic gene. The study also notes the development of hepato-splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and lymphoma/thymoma in the infected mice. The authors conclude that the HIS Rag2-/-γc-/- animal model is useful for studying the initial steps of the leukemogenic process induced by HTLV-1. The study also highlights the potential of the HTLV-1 Tax protein in perturbing T-cell development and contributing to malignant progression."
The study focuses on the outcomes of an integrated control program for schistosomiasis, a parasitic trematodiasis, in Al Jabalain locality of White Nile State, Sudan, from 2009 to 2011. The project's major target group was 78,615 primary school students. The program included mass chemotherapy, health education, and construction of a drinking water supply facility. The overall prevalence for S. haematobium and S. mansoni at baseline was 28.5% and 0.4%, respectively. After the project, the prevalence of S. haematobium infection was reduced by more than 50% to 13.5% (95% CI=0.331-0.462). A higher reduction in prevalence was observed among girls, those with moderately infected status, and residents in rural areas. After health education, increased awareness about schistosomiasis was observed. A drinking water facility was constructed at Al Hidaib village, where the infection rate was reduced more compared to that in a neighboring village. However, there was no significant change in the prevalence of S. mansoni infection. The project resulted in approximately 200,000 subjects receiving either praziquantel therapy, health education, or clean water supply. To consolidate the achievements of this project, continuous implementation of the integrated intervention is required.
Nipah virus (NiV) is a highly pathogenic paramyxovirus that causes fatal encephalitis in humans and is classified as a Biosafety Level 4 (BSL4) pathogen. The matrix (M) protein of NiV, which mediates viral assembly and budding, was found to transit from the nucleus to the cytoplasm and the plasma membrane during live NiV infection. A bipartite nuclear localization signal (NLS) and a leucine-rich nuclear export signal (NES) in NiV-M were identified, and mutations in these signals impaired its nuclear-cytoplasmic trafficking and abolished NiV-M budding. A highly conserved lysine residue in the NLS served dual functions in mediating nuclear import and as a potential site for monoubiquitination which regulates nuclear export of the protein. Proteasome inhibitors, such as bortezomib, reduced viral titers with an IC50 of 2.7 nM, opening up the possibility of using an “off-the-shelf” therapeutic against acute NiV infection.
The infection process of viruses involves the transfer of their genetic material across a cellular membrane and into the appropriate cellular compartment. However, the mechanisms of this process, particularly for non-enveloped animal viruses, are not well understood due to technical difficulties and uncertainties in distinguishing productive and non-productive pathways. A study using poliovirus (PV) as a model system combined an imaging assay and an infectivity-based assay to characterize the early events in PV infection. The results showed that PV binds to receptors on the cell surface and enters the cell through a clathrin-, caveolin-, flotillin-, and microtubule-independent, but tyrosine kinase- and actin-dependent, endocytic mechanism. Genome release occurs immediately after internalization from vesicles or tightly sealed membrane invaginations located within 100-200 nm of the plasma membrane. This contradicts previous beliefs that PV directly breaks the plasma membrane barrier or relies on endocytosis to deliver its genome into the cell. Mechanistic understandings of viral entry may lead to new therapies for combating viral infection and provide new insights into fundamental cellular functions.
Dengue fever is a significant public health issue in Cambodia, particularly for children, and is prevalent in the study province of Kampong Cham. The National Dengue Control Program (NDCP) focuses on distributing temephos and insecticide spraying, with health education delivered through various means, such as at health clinics, during village outreach activities, and in schools. However, adherence to preventive activities is partial, and the translation of knowledge to practice varies. School-based education can be an important complement to community education, as demonstrated in Puerto Rico and Thailand where primary school programs have increased children's knowledge of and participation in dengue prevention and control. However, a study in the Philippines showed that students had good knowledge but limited participation in source reduction activities. Health belief and behavioral change models have been used to develop educational materials, but little work has been done on the mode of delivery or effectiveness of routine programs. Factors such as adequate funds, technical and human capacity, cooperation between health centers and village networks, and strategies for overcoming adverse physical conditions are necessary for effective outreach. Political commitment and the availability of educational resources also impact outreach activities. Despite the challenges, health education has the potential to improve knowledge and practices related to dengue prevention and control in Cambodia.
Filarial nematodes cause significant and debilitating diseases in both humans and animals, with over 150 million people affected by filarial infections such as lymphatic filariasis and onchocerciasis. Diagnosing these infections is challenging due to various developmental stages occupying different tissues in hosts. Currently available diagnostic tests have limitations, such as low sensitivity or specificity, and inability to predict adult worm burden or viability. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are small non-protein-coding RNAs that play regulatory roles in gene expression and have been found in human fluids and mammalian cell culture medium. Circulating miRNAs are involved in intercellular communication and have potential as diagnostic and prognostic biomarkers in various conditions.Recent studies have investigated circulating miRNAs from nematode parasites, including filarial nematodes. In Dirofilaria immitis (canine heartworm)-infected dog plasma, over 200 candidate nematode miRNAs were identified using deep-sequencing and bioinformatics analysis. Of these, two miRNA candidates (miR-71 and miR-34) were found to distinguish infected samples from uninfected samples. Similarly, 21 candidate miRNAs were detected in Onchocerca volvulus-infected human serum. These parasite-derived circulating miRNAs offer a promising avenue for improving filarial diagnostics. However, the correlation between miRNA copy numbers and microfilaraemia is not straightforward due to potential imprecision in mf counts and the unknown number of adult worms present in host circulation. Further studies are needed to better understand the role and potential utility of these parasite-derived miRNAs in filarial diagnostics and therapeutics.
The Src-family of nonreceptor tyrosine kinases are large allosteric enzymes that play a crucial role in cellular signaling, regulating cell growth and proliferation. These kinases can switch between different inactive and active states in response to intracellular or extracellular signals. The Src kinase domain is composed of an N-terminal lobe (N-lobe) and a C-terminal lobe (C-lobe), with the active site located between the two lobes. The kinase's conformation changes upon activation, and the central activation-loop (A-loop) controls accessibility to the active site. In the inactive state, the A-loop is compact and blocks the active site, while in the active state, the A-loop changes conformation, allowing access to the active site. A coarse-grained model of the catalytic domain was constructed using experimental structures for the two stable states, and simulations were run to study the dynamics of conformational transitions in kinase activation. The model suggests that there exist two parallel pathways for the activation of Src kinase, one of which the conformational switching is coupled with local unfolding of the N-lobe of the catalytic domain. This simplified model is a first step toward understanding the thermodynamics and kinetics of conformational activation of the catalytic domain.
F1 lethality in hybrid offspring from crosses between diverged parents is a target of speciation research, with F1 lethality observed in interploidy crosses between diploid and tetraploid individuals of the same genotype due to dosage-sensitive incompatibility, playing a role in polyploid speciation. In Arabidopsis thaliana, a single large-effect QTL, DR. STRANGELOVE 1 (DSL1), and two QTL with epistatic relationships to DSL1 affecting the rate of postzygotic lethality via expression in the maternal sporophyte were identified. DSL1 is located in an interval encoding the maternal effect transcription factor TTG2, with ttg2 loss-of-function mutations in maternal parents suppressing the F1 lethality caused by paternal excess interploidy crosses. The frequency of cellularization in the endosperm is similarly affected by both natural variation and ttg2 loss-of-function mutants, indicating a rapid evolution of F1 lethality in polyploids. Postzygotic lethality of the hybrid offspring functions as a barrier driving or reinforcing speciation.
Bats and rodents are crucial reservoirs of numerous emerging infectious diseases, with research focusing predominantly on viral pathogens. However, bacterial zoonoses in these hosts remain understudied. This study comparatively examines the host-pathogen coevolution of Bartonella spp. and Leptospira spp., two bacterial pathogens with significant impacts on public health, in bats and rodents. The study utilizes published genetic data to generate maximum likelihood and Bayesian phylogenies for hosts and bacteria, and tests for coevolutionary congruence using ParaFit, PACO, and Jane. The results indicate that Bartonella spp. have coevolved significantly with both bat and rodent hosts, while Leptospira spp. in bats lack such congruence. The study also finds that Leptospira in bats has the greatest number of host switches per parasite, while Bartonella and rodent host associations have the fewest. These variable coevolutionary patterns are attributed to disease-specific transmission and host ecology. Understanding the coevolutionary patterns and frequency of host-switching events between bacterial pathogens and their hosts is essential for predicting spillover between mammal reservoirs and ultimately to humans.
Undulatory swimmers, like fish, move through the water using deformation kinematics caused by muscle contractions or fluid forces. A fundamental issue is whether complex muscle forcing is required to create these deformation kinematics. A study using a forced damped oscillation framework applied to a chain-link model for undulatory swimming shows that simple forcing patterns can trigger complex deformation kinematics leading to movement. Both active and passive swimming lead to deformation kinematics, which in turn cause translational motion. The frequency of muscle activation relative to the natural frequency of the damped oscillator is important for the emergent deformation characteristics of the body. These results are confirmed by computational fluid dynamics simulations. Prior research on the optimal value of stiffness for maximum speed is explained. Overall, the study shows that relatively simple forcing patterns can trigger complex deformation kinematics leading to movement in undulatory swimmers.
Genetic recombination between pathogens derived from humans and livestock can result in novel pathogen strains, as demonstrated by the influenza pandemic H1N1/09, which was a result of a reassortment of swine, avian, and human influenza A viruses. In this study, researchers investigated the potential for genetic recombination between subspecies of the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma brucei from humans and animals to generate new strains of the human pathogen T. b. rhodesiense (Tbr), which is responsible for sleeping sickness in East Africa. The researchers found that the SRA gene, which confers human infectivity in Tbr, can be transferred into new genetic backgrounds by sexual reproduction between Tbr and Tbb, creating new strains of the human pathogen Tbr. This has implications for the epidemiology of HAT in East Africa, as new strains of the human pathogen Tbr are being generated continuously by recombination with the much larger pool of animal-infective trypanosomes, posing a risk for future outbreaks of HAT. Microbial genetic recombination can lead to the creation of pathogen strains with novel phenotypes and can accelerate the spread of drug resistance. This highlights the importance of monitoring and understanding the genetic recombination of pathogens to prevent potential outbreaks and limit the spread of drug resistance.
Diabetes is caused by dysfunction of beta-cells in the islets of Langerhans, affecting insulin secretion and glucose homeostasis. Gap junction-mediated electrical coupling between beta-cells coordinates a pulsatile secretory response to elevated glucose and suppresses insulin secretion at basal glucose levels. A critical number of inexcitable cells can rapidly suppress overall islet response due to gap junction coupling. In Neonatal Diabetes Mellitus (NDM), a monogenic form of diabetes, gap junction coupling exacerbates islet dysfunction caused by mutations in KCNJ11 and ABCC8 genes, encoding Kir6.2 and SUR1 subunits of the KATP channel. Reductions in gap junction coupling allow progressively greater glucose-stimulated calcium and insulin secretion following expression of ATP-insensitive KATP channels. Stochastic noise plays a significant role in the recoveries predicted by a computational model of islet electrical activity. The islet functions as a multicellular system, with complex interactions between cellular elements determining overall system behavior. Understanding such systems is complicated by the action of cellular coupling, system architecture, and cellular heterogeneity. While the function of a multicellular system depends on the characteristics of its constituent cells, changes in the behavior of individual cells can often lead to unexpected changes in system behavior. Many diseases, including diabetes, arise through genetic variations that impact molecular and cellular function. Network theory can be used to distinguish network structure and cellular behavior to understand how distinct functions can emerge from coupled systems. The islets of Langerhans are small micro-organs consisting of primary cellular elements of insulin-secreting beta-cells. Death or dysfunction of beta-cells and a reduction or absence of insulin secretion is the main cause of diabetes. Beta-cells are excitable, and glucose-stimulated insulin secretion is driven by electrical activity. The islets of Langerhans exhibit complex multicellular behavior, with β-cells electrically coupled by Connexin36 (Cx36) gap junction channels. Gap junction coupling coordinates calcium oscillations under elevated glucose and suppresses insulin secretion under basal glucose. In NDM, mutations in the KCNJ11 and ABCC8 genes often result in reduced sensitivity to ATP and increased open channel stability, thereby limiting electrical activity and insulin secretion. Sulfonylurea therapy inhibits KATP channels, effectively treating many NDM patients with KCNJ11 and ABCC8 mutations. However, some NDM patients with specific KCNJ11 and ABCC8 mutations do not respond to sulfonylureas and require life-long insulin therapy.
"In this study, the authors address the challenge of predicting the dynamic behavior of a large network based on the behavior of its individual components, a problem commonly encountered in systems and synthetic biology. The ability to accurately predict the behavior of a network from its components is hindered by context-dependent behavior, caused in part by retroactivity. Retroactivity is a phenomenon similar to loading, influencing the dynamic performance of a module when connected to other modules. The authors present a framework for analyzing gene transcription networks that accounts for retroactivity. They introduce three retroactivity matrices that encode a module's key properties: internal, scaling, and mixing retroactivity. These matrices can be computed from macroscopic parameters such as dissociation constants and promoter concentrations and the modules' topology. These matrices allow for the prediction of how loading will affect the behavior of an arbitrary interconnection of modules. The authors provide a metric determining a module's robustness to interconnection with other modules, aiding in the design of synthetic systems and the evaluation of natural networks' modularity. This research contributes to the development of models that capture retroactivity's effects, enabling the accurate prediction of temporal dynamics in regulatory networks. The authors focus on a single module without inputs and describe how retroactivity among nodes affects its dynamics. A model approximating the isolated module dynamics is presented, and implications for negative autoregulation, combinatorial regulation, and the activator-repressor clock are discussed. The internal retroactivity of a module describes how retroactivity among nodes within a module affects its isolated module dynamics. The internal retroactivity, representing the rate of change of total (free and bound) TFs, describes how ""stiff"" the module is against changes in total TF concentrations due to loading applied by internal connections. The authors determine how the dynamics of a module change when it is inserted into its context, extending the model to account for external TFs as inputs. The external retroactivity of a module captures the phenomenon by which external TFs force internal TFs to bind/unbind, and the main result of this section describes how the context of a module affects the module's dynamics due to retroactivity. The authors introduce the scaling and mixing retroactivity, which describe the loading that the context applies on the module and the ""mixing"" of the dynamics of the module and that of its context, respectively. These matrices provide insight into the physical meaning of retroactivity, enabling the analysis of the effects of interconnection on a module's dynamics."
The pseudoautosomal region (PAR) is a short region of homology between the mammalian X and Y chromosomes that is crucial for proper disjunction of X and Y chromosomes in male meiosis. PAR1, the PAR in humans, has an exceptionally high male crossover rate, which is 17-fold higher than the genome-wide average. This is necessary for achieving recombination in a short genomic segment, and PRDM9, a protein that localizes virtually all crossovers in the autosomes, is involved in this process. However, recent research in mice suggests that crossovers in PAR may be mediated independently of PRDM9. A study using African-American pedigrees constructed the most fine-scale genetic map containing directly observed crossovers to date and found that PRDM9 does localize peaks of recombination in the human PAR1. This region is a far more rapid and intense driver of sequence evolution in PAR1 than it is on the autosomes, and PAR1 hotspot activities differ significantly among human populations. Additionally, PAR1 hotspot positions have changed between human and chimpanzee, with no evidence of sharing among the hottest hotspots. These genetic maps will aid research on this vital and fascinating region of the genome.
During muscle differentiation, myoblasts stop proliferating and fuse to form multinucleated myotubes, accompanied by the activation of muscle-specific genes and repression of cell cycle-associated genes. The b-HLH family of myogenic transcription factors, such as MyoD, and MEF2 factors, play key roles in controlling muscle-specific gene expression. Histone post-translational modifications, including methylation, are critical in regulating the expression of genes associated with them. In muscle differentiation, H3K27 methylation inhibits muscle differentiation, while H3K27 demethylation participates in the activation of muscle-specific loci during differentiation. H3K9 methylation also plays a role in Myog repression, ensuring that cells do not differentiate prematurely.JMJD2A, a member of the Jumonji domain-containing demethylases that demethylates H3K9 and H3K36, has been suggested to act as both a co-activator and co-repressor. However, its role in muscle differentiation remains unclear. In this study, a new isoform of JMJD2A, lacking the N-terminal demethylase domain (ΔN-JMJD2A), was identified and found to be upregulated during myoblast differentiation into myotubes. ΔN-JMJD2A acts as a transcriptional co-activator for genes involved in skeletal muscle differentiation and binds directly to the Myog promoter, regulating H3K9 methylation and promoting Myog expression and myotube differentiation.Knockdown of both isoforms of JMJD2A impairs differentiation, myosin heavy chain (MHC) expression, and myogenin expression, while a siRNA against only the full-length isoform has no effect. Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) shows that JMJD2A binds to the Myog promoter specifically in differentiating cells and that this binding correlates with demethylation of H3K9me2 and transcriptional activation of the gene. The Myog promoter is a direct target of the ΔN-JMJD2A isoform, and other potential target genes of ΔN-JMJD2A remain to be identified.In summary, the induction of the ΔN-JMJD2A isoform is crucial for muscle differentiation. By directing the removal of repressive chromatin marks at the Myog promoter, it promotes transcriptional activation of the Myog gene and thus contributes to initiation of muscle-specific gene expression, highlighting the importance of histone methylation and demethylation in muscle differentiation.
The Guinea Worm Eradication Programme (GWEP), established in 1986 by WHO, The Carter Center (TCC), UNICEF, and CDC, has significantly reduced Guinea Worm Disease (GWD) from an estimated 3.5 million cases in 21 countries in 1986 to 25 cases in four countries in 2016. GWD, a Neglected Tropical Disease (NTD) caused by the parasitic worm Dracunculus medinensis, mostly affects impoverished communities in remote and marginalized areas of sub-Saharan Africa. Despite the success, the global eradication of GWD still requires certification by WHO of the absence of transmission in all countries.This study examines the cost-effectiveness of GWEP during the end game when the number of cases is low, and the cost per case is higher than at any other time. The researchers estimate the total cost of GWEP implementation, pre-certification, and certification stages from 1986-2030 and compare it with two alternative scenarios: doing nothing (no intervention since 1986) and control (only surveillance and outbreak response during 2016-2030). The study reports the cost per case averted, cost per disability-adjusted life year (DALY) averted, and cost per at-risk life year averted.The study finds that GWEP cost an estimated US$ 11 (95% uncertainty interval, 4.70-12.49) per case averted in the period 1986-2030. The pre-certification and certification phases can cost as much as US$ 0.0041 and US$ 0.0015 per capita per year. The cost per DALY averted by the GWEP is estimated at US$ 222 (118--372) in 1986-2030. The GWEP is probably more cost-effective than control by the year 2030. The GWEP is certainly more cost-effective than control if willingness to pay for one year of life lived without the risk of GWD exceeds US$ 0.10.In conclusion, the study suggests that GWEP remains a cost-effective intervention in reducing GWD cases, even if the economic costs are two times as high as financial costs estimated for the period to 2020. However, whether the GWEP turns out to be the most cost-effective alternative in the period beyond 2015 depends on the time horizon. Nonetheless, from the perspective of the number of years of life lived without the risk of GWD, a case can be made more easily for finishing the end game, including certification of the absence of transmission.
The carboxy-terminal domain of the BBK32 protein from Borrelia burgdorferi sensu stricto, termed BBK32-C, binds and inhibits the initiating serine protease of the human classical complement pathway, C1r. This study investigated the function of BBK32 orthologues of the Lyme-associated Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato complex, specifically BAD16 from B. afzelii strain PGau and BGD19 from B. garinii strain IP90. BAD16-C exhibits BBK32-C-like activities in all assays tested, while BGD19-C has reduced in vitro complement inhibitory activities relative to BBK32-C or BAD16-C. Site-directed mutagenesis revealed that three residue positions in BBK32-C, targeted in the BXK32-C chimera, are surface-exposed and potentially relevant in C1r binding and inhibition. BBK32-C only recognized C1r fragments containing the serine protease domain. These structure-function studies improve understanding of how BBK32 recognizes and inhibits C1r and provide new insight into complement evasion mechanisms of Lyme-associated spirochetes of the B. burgdorferi sensu lato complex. B. burgdorferi sensu lato are the leading arthropod-borne infectious agents in the Northern hemisphere and are capable of hematogenous dissemination. Complement evasion is crucial for their survival and persistence in immunocompetent hosts. Lyme-associated spirochetes have evolved mechanisms to evade complement detection and activation. For example, B. burgdorferi sensu lato species encode up to five distinct proteins that bind to and recruit factor H to the bacterial surface, thereby hijacking its complement protective activities. Additionally, distinct borrelial proteins specifically block the formation of the membrane attack complex, recruit host plasminogen and degrade complement components, or bind directly to other complement components. In total, nearly a dozen B. burgdorferi sensu lato proteins have been identified with specific complement inhibitory activities.
The human fungal pathogen Candida albicans undergoes morphological and transcriptional adaptation in the switch from commensalism to pathogenicity. While previous gene-knockout studies have identified many factors involved in this transformation, the regulation of these factors remains unclear. Investigating morphogenetic control by post-translational phosphorylation has revealed the Fkh2 transcription factor as a regulatory target of both Cdc28 and the cell wall biosynthesis kinase Cbk1. Fkh2 has a diverse pool of phospho-isoforms in stationary phase yeast cells, and its phosphorylation profile is transformed for a short window during hyphal induction before reverting to the yeast profile. This transformation does not occur in fresh medium supporting yeast growth. Mass spectrometry and mutational analyses identified residues phosphorylated by Cdc28 and Cbk1, and substitution of these residues with non-phosphorylatable alanine altered the yeast phosphorylation profile and abrogated the characteristic transformation to the hyphal profile. The hyphal phosphorylation profile is required for the expression of genes involved in pathogenesis, host interaction, and biofilm formation. Fkh2 interacts with the chromatin modifier Pob3 in a phosphorylation-dependent manner, providing a possible mechanism by which the phosphorylation of Fkh2 regulates its specificity. Therefore, a novel cell cycle-independent phospho-regulatory event has been discovered that subverts a key component of the cell cycle machinery to a role in the switch from commensalism to pathogenicity.
Trypanosoma brucei, a parasitic trypanosomatid, has both de novo and salvage routes for pyrimidine nucleotide biosynthesis, making it independent of external pyrimidines for growth. However, recent research shows that thymidine kinase (TK), a salvage enzyme thought to be redundant, is essential for the parasite's growth and infectivity. Contrary to previous understanding, TK is required for thymine nucleotide synthesis from either de novo or salvage pathways. This reliance on TK in the absence of dCMP deaminase (DCTD) may be a shared vulnerability among trypanosomatids, presenting an opportunity for developing a single drug to target a diverse group of pathogenic single-celled eukaryotes. T. brucei causes Human African trypanosomiasis, a disease with high mortality and limited treatment options due to drug resistance and administration challenges. New drugs are badly needed, and understanding the unique features of the protozoan pyrimidine pathway could lead to innovative therapeutic approaches.
In prokaryotic gene expression, translation initiation typically involves the interaction between the ribosome and an mRNA sequence called the Shine-Dalgarno sequence. However, many genes lack this sequence, and the mechanism of start codon recognition in these cases is unclear. Researchers conducted genome-wide searches in various prokaryotic groups and found that mRNAs without a Shine-Dalgarno sequence tend to have less structure in their translation initiation region and show a minimum of mRNA folding at the start codon. Experiments using reporter gene constructs in bacteria support this finding. Additionally, AUG start codons are usually found in single-stranded regions, while internal AUG codons are typically in structured regions of the mRNA. These results suggest that the local absence of RNA secondary structure is necessary and sufficient to initiate Shine-Dalgarno-independent translation, providing a plausible mechanism for how the correct translation initiation site is recognized in the absence of a ribosome-binding site.
In a study of patients with visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in Bihar, India, treated with liposomal amphotericin B (Ambisome) as first-line treatment, it was found that the development of post-Kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL) was infrequent and there were no predictive risk factors. Of the 8311 patients treated for VL, 0.3% returned with symptoms of PKDL, with a median time to development of 1.2 years following treatment. The time to developing PKDL was significantly shorter with Ambisome than in a subset of patients previously treated with sodium stibogluconate for VL. The study concludes that the risk of PKDL following treatment with Ambisome is low, but patients should be counseled about the possibility of developing symptoms within a shorter time frame compared to other treatments.
Chagas disease is a significant public health issue in South America, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi and transmitted by the insect Triatoma infestans. The main prevention method is controlling the insect vectors; however, these vectors have been re-emerging in certain areas. A study was conducted in northwest Argentina to understand the reinfestation dynamics of T. infestans after community-wide insecticide spraying. The study compared different methods of estimating the probabilities of bug establishment and found that more new bug populations become established from May to November than from November to May. The seasonal increase in bug establishment coincides with a seasonal increase in dispersal distance. The probability of new bug establishment increases with increasing time since last detected infestation. These results highlight important gaps in the current understanding of T. infestans ecology. Experiments are necessary to close these gaps and increase the efficiency of vector control. Additionally, a detailed knowledge of the spatio-temporal pattern of repeated insecticide application is necessary for developing an optimal spraying strategy. Analyzing field data that cover both the spatial range of T. infestans dispersal and the temporal range of T. infestans population recovery is crucial. This knowledge can help in effectively controlling the transmission of Chagas disease.
A study was conducted to understand the genesis of diseases caused by polyomaviruses in humans and to guide the development of viral diagnostics, therapeutics, and preventative measures. The study focused on Simian virus 40 (SV40), a polyomavirus able to infect humans and the only one with a small animal model amenable to mechanistic studies of early steps in viral pathogenesis. SV40 is known to establish persistent infections and induce tumors under certain conditions. The study used Syrian golden hamsters as the animal model and inoculated them with two wild-type strains of SV40 and mutants unable to produce SV40 miRNAs derived from each WT strain. The results showed that all four viruses were efficient at establishing persistent infections and SV40 had a broad tissue tropism, with infected tissues including liver, kidney, spleen, lung, and brain. Liver and kidney contained higher viral DNA loads than other tissues, and kidneys were the preferred site for long-term persistent infection. The study provided the first evidence of expression and function of SV40 microRNA in vivo and identified broad tissue tropism for SV40 in vivo in hamsters. Viral microRNA dampened viral DNA levels in tissues infected by SV40 strains with simple or complex regulatory regions. However, the absence of viral miRNA had no effect on replication of the virus in tissue culture. Wild-type and microRNA-negative mutants of SV40 showed similar rates of transformation of mouse cells in vitro and tumor induction in weanling hamsters in vivo.
A comprehensive examination of mammalian positively selected genes (PSGs) was conducted using six high-coverage genome assemblies of eutherian mammals, resulting in the identification of over 400 genes with significant evidence of positive selection. These PSGs were enriched for roles in defense/immunity, chemosensory perception, and reproduction, with several specific functions and pathways also enriched. A novel Bayesian analysis indicated that most PSGs have switched multiple times between positive selection and nonselection, suggesting that positive selection is often episodic. PSGs were expressed at significantly lower levels and in a more tissue-specific manner than non-PSGs, with enrichment in the spleen, testes, liver, and breast but not in brain-specific genes. This study provides additional evidence for widespread positive selection in mammalian evolution and new genome-wide insights into the functional implications of positive selection.
Staphylococcus aureus, a pathogen that colonizes mammalian skin and mucosal surfaces, forms biofilms that are difficult to eradicate due to their high resistance to host immune response and chemotherapy. A study discovered a novel extracellular fibril structure in S. aureus biofilms grown in rich media, which has amyloid-like properties and is composed of small peptides called phenol soluble modulins (PSMs). These fibers play a crucial role in biofilm integrity, as mutants unable to produce PSMs were susceptible to biofilm disassembly by matrix degrading enzymes and mechanical stress. Soluble PSM peptides disperse biofilms, while polymerized peptides do not, suggesting that the aggregation of PSMs into amyloid fibers modulates their biological activity in biofilms.
Chagas disease, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, affects around six million people in more than 20 countries, mainly in Latin America. Monitoring parasite persistence in infected individuals is crucial to control the disease and evaluate treatments. Routine screening is achieved through serological assays, but PCR testing has limitations due to the low and fluctuating parasitic load in circulating blood. A new antibody profiling assay has been developed to assess parasite persistence based on waning antibodies following spontaneous or therapy-induced clearance of the infection. A multiplex serology assay with fifteen optimized T. cruzi antigens was used to evaluate antibody diversity in 1654 serum samples from chronic Chagas patients. Specific antibody response (Ab3) showed a strong correlation with T. cruzi parasite persistence as determined by T. cruzi PCR positive results. High and sustained Ab3 signal was associated with PCR positivity in untreated patients, while a significant decline in Ab3 signals was observed in BZN-treated patients who cleared parasitemia based on blood PCR results. Ab3 is a new surrogate biomarker that strongly correlates with parasite persistence in chronic and benznidazole-treated Chagas patients, likely induced and maintained by tissue-based and shed parasites. This simple immunoassay measurement of Ab3 could be beneficial for monitoring the infectious status of seropositive patients. Chagas disease, or American Trypanosomiasis, is a neglected illness by the World Health Organization that affects over six million people worldwide. It is caused by the protozoan parasite T. cruzi, transmitted by a Triatome vector with a large reservoir territory spanning from Argentina/Chile to the southern part of the United States. The disease may also be transmitted through blood transfusion, congenitally, or by oral route. Different clinical forms of Chagas disease exist, with patients in the acute phase being generally symptom-free or having mild, non-specific symptoms. Following this acute infection period, the infection generally progresses to chronic phases, with a small proportion of spontaneously resolved infections. The majority of chronic Chagas disease patients remain in the indeterminate form, defined as asymptomatic persistent infection that can last for decades. However, about 30% of patients eventually develop life-threatening cardiac and/or digestive symptoms requiring complex clinical management and specific treatments. Two drugs are currently available to treat acute or chronic Chagas infection, but their efficacy is difficult to evaluate, particularly during the chronic/indeterminate phase. The main criterion to establish treatment success is the reversion of the conventional serology from positive to negative status in association with negative results on parasitological tests. During the acute phase, both drugs have shown successful clinical, parasitological, and serological treatment outcomes. However, during the late chronic phase, the serological cure rate with BZN is estimated to be between 8% and 40%. The treatment efficacy for adult patients in the chronic phase is still controversial and difficult to estimate. Nonetheless, it is generally agreed that BZN-treatment contributes to decreasing the parasitic load, resulting in a decline in antibody titers and consequently is likely to improve clinical outcomes if applied early in the chronic phase of the infection. Several other factors also affect the drug success rate, including the genotype of the parasite, the age of the patients, the interval between infection and start of treatment, and the clinical stage of the disease when therapy is given. The treatment causes many side effects, including dermatitis, digestive manifestations, hypersensitivity reactions, and polyneuropathy. For these reasons, the risk-benefit ratio between adverse events and expected benefits is taken into account for patients with or at risk for cardiac and/or digestive complications. In the absence of specific clinical signs, several techniques have been proposed to evaluate the treatment efficacy of Chagas disease, including serological assays and detection of the parasite in blood by PCR. Among these techniques, PCR has shown promising results for assessment of anti-parasitic therapy failure but not therapy efficacy.
The Chikungunya virus (CHIKV) is a re-emerging arthropod-transmitted virus that causes fever and severe joint and muscle pain, with a substantial fraction of patients experiencing chronic musculoskeletal pain for months to years after the initial infection. However, the mechanisms promoting chronic CHIKV disease are not well understood. While replicating virus has not been detected in joint-associated tissues of patients with persistent arthritis, viral RNA can be detected months after acute infection. A study using a recombinant CHIKV that expresses Cre recombinase (CHIKV-3ʹ-Cre) found that this virus replicated in myoblasts and fibroblasts and induced arthritis during the acute phase in mice, as well as chronic disease with persistent viral RNA and chronic myositis and synovitis similar to wild-type virus. Infection of tdTomato reporter mice with CHIKV-3ʹ-Cre resulted in a population of tdTomato+ cells that persisted for at least 112 days, predominantly as myofibers and dermal and muscle fibroblasts. Treatment with an antibody against Mxra8, a host receptor for CHIKV, reduced the number of tdTomato+ cells in the chronic phase and diminished the levels of chronic viral RNA, implicating these tdTomato+ cells as the reservoir of chronic viral RNA. This CHIKV-3ʹ-Cre and tdTomato reporter mouse system is a useful tool for studying CHIKV pathogenesis in the acute and chronic stages of disease. A study using a recombinant CHIKV that expresses Cre recombinase (CHIKV-3ʹ-Cre) found that this virus replicated in myoblasts and fibroblasts and induced arthritis during the acute phase in mice, as well as chronic disease with persistent viral RNA and chronic myositis and synovitis similar to wild-type virus. Recent studies have used dimensionality reduction methods to understand the relationship between the multi-dimensional structure of neural population activity and brain function. However, it is unclear how these results generalize to recordings with larger numbers of neurons and trials or how they relate to the underlying network structure. This study applies factor analysis to recordings in the visual cortex of non-human primates and to spiking network models that self-generate irregular activity through a balance of excitation and inhibition. The study found that the scaling properties of networks with non-clustered and clustered connectivity differed, and that in vivo recordings were more consistent with the clustered network. Additionally, recordings from tens of neurons were sufficient to identify the dominant modes of shared variability that generalize to larger portions of the network. These findings can help guide the interpretation of dimensionality reduction outputs in regimes of limited neuron and trial sampling and help relate these outputs to the underlying network structure.
The studies discussed highlight the significant role of bacterial quorum sensing (QS) signals, particularly the Pseudomonas aeruginosa QS-regulated molecule 2-amino acetophenone (2-AA), in mediating immunomodulation and host-pathogen interactions. 2-AA modulates host immune responses in a way that increases the host's ability to cope with this pathogen, as seen in mice treated with 2-AA prior to infection having a 90% survival rate compared to 10% in non-pretreated infected mice. 2-AA stimulation activates key innate immune response pathways but attenuates immune response activation upon pretreatment, most likely by upregulating anti-inflammatory cytokines, leading to a transcriptionally regulated block of c-JUN N-terminal kinase (JNK) and NF-κB activation.Bacterial quorum sensing plays a crucial role in host-pathogen interactions, with bacterial and host factors engaging in an antagonistic interplay that determines the outcome of the infection. Secreted microbial products, including many virulence factors, play a critical role in this interplay. QS regulates these products, which are crucial for infecting mammals, through a cell density-dependent communication system achieved through the production and regulation of low-molecular-weight, excreted signal molecules.In the case of P. aeruginosa, QS systems control the gene expression of many virulence factors through three QS systems: LasR, RhlR, and MvfR (PqsR). These systems regulate the production of various virulence factors critical for infecting mammals and modulate inflammation and immune responses in mammals. The 3-oxo-C12-HSL signal molecule, for instance, inhibits dendritic cell and T-cell activation, promotes apoptosis, and inhibits the ability of macrophages and monocytes to respond to a range of Toll-like receptor (TLR) agonists through disruption of NF-κB signaling.Overall, the studies emphasize the importance of QS in host-pathogen interactions and the complex role of QS-regulated excreted molecules in modulating host immune responses. Understanding these interactions can provide insights into developing novel therapeutic strategies for combating bacterial infections.
Mammalian genomes consist of numerous active and fossilized retroelements, and the obligatory integration of retroelements allows hosts to domesticate these elements for their own use, leading to significant genomic innovations. One such domesticated gene is L1TD1, which is derived nearly entirely from a LINE-1 (L1) retroelement and is widely known for its role in pluripotency maintenance in humans. However, the origin and evolution of L1TD1 reveal that it has undergone positive selection during primate and mouse evolution and has been repurposed for a potential role in genome defense. L1TD1 has been recurrently selected for functional novelty and has been lost or pseudogenized multiple times during mammalian evolution, suggesting its role in genome defense and pluripotency maintenance is not universal across all mammalian lineages. Retroelements, including L1TD1, have had a profound impact on mammalian genomes, shaping them over millions of years and occasionally driving dramatic episodes of adaptation through the generation of genetic novelty. While retroelement activity is rarely beneficial, individual transposition events can lead to significant adaptations. Furthermore, repetitive elements have often been co-opted as transcriptional regulatory elements, and protein-coding genes derived from retroelement- and retrovirus- sequences have been preserved for their beneficial activities in the host genome. For example, envelope genes from ancient retroviruses have been preserved for their membrane-fusing and immunosuppressive activities in the placenta, while other domesticated retroelement-derived genes have evolved for genome defense against L1 elements and have been incorporated into pluripotency maintenance in some lineages. These examples highlight the critical role of retroelement gene domestication in fundamental aspects of mammalian biology and the adaptability of these domesticated genes in different lineages.
YbeY is a highly conserved protein that plays key roles in both processing of the critical 3' end of 1
A study on the assortativity signatures of human transcription factor networks (TFNs) was conducted using DNaseI-seq data from 41 distinct cell and tissue types. The study revealed a common assortativity signature among the TFNs, which consists of greater-than-expected out-in and out-out assortativity, and expected in-out and in-in assortativity. Perturbation analyses of TFN models demonstrated a significant influence of the assortativity signature on the robustness of a TFN's gene expression phenotypes. The study found that out-out assortativity is the most important of the four components of the assortativity signature in driving this robustness in TFN models that approach the high edge density of human TFNs. This is consistent with earlier theoretical results that showed the relationship between this type of assortativity and robustness. Overall, the study suggests that degree assortativity provides an additional structural source of robustness in biological networks and that human TFNs share an assortativity signature that confers such robustness.
In a study conducted on anesthetized adult rats, the activity of up to 74 neurons was recorded in the somatosensory barrel cortex using large-scale multi-electrode arrays in response to whisker stimuli that varied in location and frequency. Neurons were classified as inhibitory (INH) or excitatory (EXC) based on their extracellular spike waveforms. The study found that individual INH neurons in granular and infra-granular layers were better at discriminating between restricted sets of stimuli compared to EXC neurons. Ensembles of INH cells provided as much information about the stimuli as comparable ensembles containing the most informative EXC neurons, but with less redundancy. This suggests that a consortium of INH neurons dominates the information conveyed to the neocortical network, efficiently processing incoming sensory activity. These results add to the understanding of the role of the inhibitory system in orchestrating cortical activity. The study also found that L4 INH neurons, which are the major cortical target of the lemniscal pathway, presented high levels of evoked activity at low stimulation frequencies and had higher precision and lower adaptation at higher frequency stimulation compared to L4 EXC neurons. Overall, INH cells conveyed more information than EXC cells and were faster and more informative in discriminating stimulus location. These findings have implications for the understanding of the mechanisms employed by populations of cortical INH neurons in encoding sensory stimuli and in shaping structured network activity.
Synthetic biology aims to reprogram living cells to perform new functions for various applications, with initial work focusing on transcription factors but more recently shifting to regulatory RNAs due to their high programmability. However, functional circuits using only regulatory RNAs are limited. A new study reports the engineering of a fundamental arithmetic logic unit (ALU) based on de novo riboregulation to sum two bits of information encoded in molecular concentrations within a living cell. The system uses post-transcriptional control to switch on tightly silenced genes with small RNAs and allosteric transcription factors to sense molecular signals. This result demonstrates the potential of regulatory RNAs in synthetic biology and paves the way for engineering more complex RNA-based biocomputers using this designer circuit as a building block. This development is important as it brings us closer to the realization of smart cells that can make appropriate decisions after processing signals from the medium, with potential applications in diagnostic bacteria for clinical use.
Cytosolic 5′-nucleotidase II (cN-II) is an enzyme that regulates the intracellular nucleotide pools within the cell by catalyzing the dephosphorylation of 6-hydroxypurine nucleoside 5′-monophosphates. High level of cN-II expression is correlated with abnormal patient outcome when treated with cytotoxic nucleoside analogues. A study was conducted to identify the specific role of cN-II in the resistance phenomenon observed during cancer therapy by screening a class of chemical compounds, ribonucleoside phosphonates, as potential cN-II inhibitors. These compounds incorporate a chemically and enzymatically stable phosphorus-carbon linkage instead of a regular phosphoester bond. Six compounds were predicted as better ligands than the natural substrate of cN-II, inosine 5′-monophosphate (IMP). The binding strength of these compounds was explained by an impressive number of van der Waals contacts, highlighting the decisive role of three cN-II residues that are Phe 157, His 209 and Tyr 210. Docking predictions were confirmed by experimental measurements of the nucleotidase activity in the presence of the three best available phosphonate analogues, which were shown to induce a total inhibition of the cN-II activity at 2 mM. This study emphasizes the importance of the non-hydrolysable phosphonate bond in the design of new competitive cN-II inhibitors and the crucial hydrophobic stacking promoted by three protein residues. Nucleotidase activity was first described in 1934, and cN-II belongs to the haloacid dehalogenase (HAD) superfamily, with a specific reaction mechanism that requires the formation of a phosphoenzyme intermediate. The enzyme's activity can be regulated by several allosteric ligands such as ATP, ADP, 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate, dinucleosides polyphosphate or diadenosine tetraphosphate (activators) and inorganic phosphate (inhibitor). cN-II has several unique aspects, such as a complex regulation and substrate selectivity for IMP and GMP. The active form of cN-II is a homotetramer and its activity can be regulated by several allosteric ligands. Recently, a structural explanation was proposed for the allosteric regulation by an effector such as ATP, which induces a disorder-to-order transition of helix A. Aside from maintaining balanced nucleoside levels in the cell, cytoplasmic 5′-nucleotidases are likely to play an important role in the activity of nucleoside analogues used as antiviral or anticancer agents. There are several clinical evidences of a correlation between cN-II mRNA expression or activity in cancer cells and the outcome of patients treated with cytotoxic nucleoside analogues. In the case of acute myeloid leukemia, treatment involving cytarabine (ara-C) leads to a worse patient outcome when cN-II is highly expressed. This effect may be explained by tissue-specificity concerns or by variants at the NT5C2 locus gene encoding for cN-II. A high number of single nucleotide polymorphisms were found to be directly associated to cN-II expression and ara-C cytotoxicity or sensitivity in AML patients receiving the related chemotherapy. Another example of the implication of cN-II has been described in bone marrow cells of patients with high risk myelodysplastic syndrome. A correlation between clinical outcome of patients with B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia treated with cladribine or fludarabine and their ratio of activities between dCK and cN-II has also been reported. The inhibition of cN-II expression by siRNA in astrocytoma cells was shown to induce cell death. These results suggest that cN-II is directly involved in the cytotoxicity of nucleoside analogues and that the modulation of cN-II could be an attractive strategy to influence the activity of cytotoxic nucleoside analogues or to directly induce cell death in cancer cells.
A study published in 2012 reported the detection of prion infectivity in colostrum and milk from sheep incubating natural scrapie. This is the first evidence of the presence of prions in mammary secretions from scrapie-affected ewes. The study found consistent levels of infectivity in colostrum and milk from sheep incubating scrapie, with the highest per milliliter infectious titre measured being equivalent to that contained in 6 µg of a terminally scrapie-affected ewe's posterior brain stem. The prion infectivity was present in milk and colostrum from ewes with and without mammary gland lesions. The abnormal PrP was detected in lacteal ducts and mammary acini in ewes harboring mammary ectopic lymphoid follicles that developed as a result of Maedi lentivirus infection. The study also found that the infectivity could be recovered in the cellular, cream, and casein-whey fractions of milk and colostrum. The infectious titre in colostrum and milk samples was estimated to range between 100, 1 and 101, 6 ID50/ml. The study suggests that both colostrum and milk from small ruminants incubating TSE could contribute to the animal TSE transmission process, either directly or through the presence of milk-derived material in animal feedstuffs. It also raises concerns regarding the risk to humans of TSE exposure associated with milk products from ovine and other TSE-susceptible dairy species.
An Ebola virus disease (EVD) outbreak began in Liberia in March 2014 and ended in January 2016, resulting in over 11,000 deaths in 10 countries, including 4,809 in Liberia. EVD is a severe illness in humans caused by the Ebola virus, with symptoms such as fever, hemorrhage, myalgia, and diarrhea. It is transmitted through contact with infected wildlife or body fluids of patients. In Liberia, data on 16,370 laboratory samples tested between April 4, 2014 and March 29, 2015 was analyzed, with 3,897 confirmed EVD cases (positive for Ebola virus RNA) identified. There were significant differences in sex, age, and place of residence between confirmed and suspected cases that tested negative for Ebola virus RNA. Age and place of residence were risk factors for death due to the disease. The case fatality rate of confirmed cases decreased from 80% to 63% during the study period. These findings can help support future investigations and understanding of the outbreak in Liberia.
The enzyme tyrosinase (EC 1.14.18.1) catalyzes the conversion of phenol to the corresponding ortho-quinone through hydroxylation and oxidation reactions. It contains a dinuclear copper center in its active site, which takes three redox forms: deoxy (Cu(I)-Cu(I)), oxy (Cu(II)-O22--Cu(II)), and met (Cu(II)-Cu(II)). The met form is the resting enzymatic form, while the oxy form catalyzes the conversion of phenol and catechol substrates to ortho-quinones. The S. castaneoglobisporus tyrosinase met form is a dimer of two copper-depleted subunits, with each subunit containing a binuclear copper center. In the crystal structure of the S. castaneoglobisporus tyrosinase met form, each copper ion is coordinated by three histidine residues, with a bridging water molecule between them. However, in the oxy form, the water molecule is replaced by a peroxide ion, which binds to the copper ions in a side-on bridging mode. In the crystal structure of the tyrosinase-caddie complex, the Tyr98 residue of the caddie protein is present in the active-site pocket of tyrosinase, and its side chain forms hydrogen bonds with Wat2 and Wat3. In the met2 form, the Tyr98 residue is converted to dopaquinone, which stimulates the aggregation of the caddie protein and the dissociation of tyrosinase from the complex. Reaction intermediates, such as μ-η2:η2-peroxo-dicopper (II) and Cu(II)-dopasemiquinone, were able to be trapped, indicating that the Tyr98 residue is converted to dopaquinone through these intermediates. The crystal structures of tyrosinase at different stages of the reaction were determined to visualize the process in the tyrosinase reaction toward the caddie Tyr98 residue. The crystal structures were cryo-trapped after the aerobic soaking of the crystal of met2-tyrosinase complexed with the caddie protein in a buffer containing CuSO4 and NH2OH for a given time at 25°C. The results showed that the tyrosinase may be suitable to take a flexible bent-butterfly structure in the oxy form to allow the conformational change during the reaction.
In the process of eukaryotic ribosome biogenesis, the early steps of the production of the large ribosomal subunit are the least understood. The first precursor to the yeast large ribosomal subunit, the first pre-60S particle, contains 30 assembly factors (AFs), including 8 RNA helicases. One of these helicases, Dbp6p, is essential for the normal accumulation of the first pre-60S pre-ribosomal particle in S. cerevisiae. Dbp6p associates with a complex of four AFs, namely Npa1p, Npa2p, Nop8p, and Rsa3p, prior to their incorporation into the 90S pre-ribosomal particles. Npa1p forms the backbone of the complex and is essential for the insertion of the Dbp6p helicase within 90S pre-ribosomal particles. Npa1p and Dbp6p function in the formation and/or clustering of root helices of large subunit rRNAs which creates the core of the large ribosomal subunit RNA structure. The Dbp6p helicase and the Npa1p complex play key roles in the compaction of the central core of 25S rRNA and the control of snoRNA-pre-rRNA interactions. Dbp6p, Dbp7p, Dbp9p, and Prp43p, which belong to the family of RNA helicases, are likely to play crucial roles in pre-rRNA folding and compaction events during large subunit ribosomal proteins assembly. Nop8p, Dbp6p, and Rsa3p form a complex associated with 90S and early pre-60S pre-ribosomal particles and are recruited within 90S pre-ribosomal particles, remain present within the earliest pre-60S particles containing the 27SA2 pre-rRNA and dissociate from 27SB-containing pre-60S particles. Npa1p, Npa2p, Nop8p, Dbp6p, and Rsa3p can form one or several complexes, with which Dbp6p interacts but such association is magnesium sensitive.
The ability to adapt to a changing world is crucial for survival, and is achieved through the updating of beliefs in response to unexpected events that signal potential environmental change. This belief updating is driven by prediction errors, which are the difference between predicted and actual outcomes. The degree to which each prediction error influences existing beliefs is determined by the learning rate. Recent studies have examined the computational mechanisms by which various environmental factors determine the impact of new outcomes on existing beliefs, but the brain mechanisms involved in this process are still largely unknown. However, recent research suggests that the catecholamine systems, specifically norepinephrine (NE) and dopamine (DA), are well-positioned to regulate learning rate based on environmental change. This research provides converging evidence for a causal role of the human catecholamine systems in learning-rate regulation as a function of environmental change. The study found that the P3 component of the EEG, an electrophysiological index of outcome-evoked phasic catecholamine release in the cortex, predicted learning rate and formally mediated the effect of prediction-error magnitude on learning rate. P3 amplitude also mediated the effects of two computational variables, capturing the unexpectedness of an outcome and the uncertainty of a preexisting belief, on learning rate. A pharmacological manipulation of catecholamine activity affected learning rate following unanticipated task changes, in a way that depended on participants’ baseline learning rate. These findings highlight the importance of the catecholamine systems in the regulation of learning rate and the ability to adapt to a changing environment.
Infectious diseases continue to pose a significant challenge to humanity, with the World Health Organization reporting millions of deaths each year due to communicable diseases. To monitor and surveillance these diseases, various strategies have been developed, including disease-specific surveillance, syndromic surveillance, and event-based surveillance. These strategies utilize a variety of data sources, including notifiable diseases reports, microbiology orders reports, and data from Point-Of-Care (POC) laboratories. POC laboratories, which are on-site laboratories equipped to perform a wide variety of rapid diagnostic tests, have become increasingly important in monitoring and diagnosing infectious diseases, particularly in developing countries where access to conventional laboratories may be limited.In the rural Saloum region of Senegal, two POC laboratories have been successfully implemented and have been used to test over 2,500 patients for 15 different pathogens. A homemade syndromic surveillance system called EPIMIC has been implemented to monitor infectious diseases using data produced by these POC laboratories. The implementation of EPIMIC in Senegal allowed for the real-time monitoring of the number of samples tested and positives performed every week, as well as the percentage of positivity for each test. When the number of tested samples, positive samples, or percentage of positiveness exceeded predetermined thresholds, alarms were automatically emitted by EPIMIC. This allowed for the rapid detection and response to potential outbreaks.The implementation of EPIMIC in Senegal was successful in identifying alarms for various pathogens, including Plasmodium falciparum, Rickettsia spp, and Borrelia spp. The system was able to detect numerous true epidemiological events without heavy human and economic resources, demonstrating its scalability and versatility. Additionally, the system was fully automated for the collection, anonymisation, and analysis of data, and for the production of a simple Microsoft PowerPoint activity report. This improvement considerably decreased the level of complexity to use the software and facilitated on-site investigations of validated abnormal events.In conclusion, the implementation of EPIMIC in Senegal using data routinely produced by two POC laboratories in rural villages has been successful in monitoring and surveillance infectious diseases. The system was able to detect numerous true epidemiological events and provided valuable information on the local epidemiology of emerging pathogens. The use of POC laboratories and syndromic surveillance systems, such as EPIMIC, are crucial in the ongoing effort to monitor and control infectious diseases, especially in developing countries where access to conventional laboratories may be limited.
This study investigates the role of cellular architecture in intercellular communication and calcium signaling in endothelial cells. The study found that the structural arrangement of endothelial cells affected their ability to collectively signal and respond to histamine stimulation. Specifically, cells in self-assembled and microengineered networks, but not individual cells or monolayers, exhibited calcium oscillations in response to histamine. The calcium oscillation was dependent on the number of neighboring cells coupled via gap junctional intercellular communication (GJIC), and attenuated the histamine-induced cytoskeletal reorganization and cell contraction. The study suggests that endothelial cells can sense and respond to chemical stimuli according to the vascular architecture via collective calcium signaling.Calcium signaling is a universal second messenger that mediates a wide range of dynamic cell functions, such as exocytosis, contraction, transcription, and proliferation. The study found that histamine, known to induce calcium signaling and cell contraction in endothelial cells, induced calcium oscillations in a much larger portion of cells in self-assembled capillary-like networks and plasma lithography microengineered cell networks. The occurrence rate of calcium oscillation was significantly reduced when endothelial cells in capillary-like networks and hexagonal cell networks were pretreated with a gap junction blocker, 18-β-glycyrrhetinic acid (18β-GA), indicating the architecture-dependent calcium oscillation is GJIC dependent.A computational model was used to study the mechanisms of architecture-dependent calcium oscillation and the effect of calcium diffusion and coupling current on calcium dynamics. The computational model captured the essence of calcium dynamics observed in the experiment, supporting its use for investigating the architecture-dependent calcium signaling. The computational simulation captured the architecture-dependent calcium signaling observed in the experiment, with individual cells not exhibiting calcium oscillations and most cells exhibiting calcium oscillation in linear chain coupled cells. When the cells were connected in an array and coupled to each other, the calcium oscillations vanished in all of the cells, similar to the experimental observation. The computational model also predicted that the calcium dynamics are sensitive to the number of cells coupled.In summary, this study has demonstrated that cellular architecture plays a significant role in GJIC-mediated collective calcium signaling. The study found that cells in capillary-like networks and hexagonal cell networks display short calcium pulses and oscillations after histamine treatment, unlike monolayers and individual cells that exhibit prolonged cytosolic calcium response. The calcium oscillation was dependent on GJIC and attenuated the histamine-induced cytoskeletal reorganization and cell contraction. The study highlights the importance of considering cellular architecture in the understanding of calcium signaling and its functional implications in diverse vascular structures.
Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is the primary cause of lower respiratory tract disease in infants and young children, and continues to be a significant cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The RSV surface protein G has been identified as a major target for vaccine development due to its ability to generate a broad antibody response following infection. In a previous study, it was shown that a whole genome-fragment phage display library (GFPDL) expressing linear and conformational epitopes from RSV bound 100-fold more phages within the attachment protein (G) following primary RSV infection in infants. These G-reactive epitopes spanned the N- and C-termini of G ectodomain, as well as the central conserved domain (CCD). In a more recent study, the immunogenicity and protective efficacy of all RSV-G antigenic sites identified following primary RSV infection were evaluated using recombinant E. coli expressed G ectodomain (REG), CCD-deleted G ectodomain (REG ΔCCD), N- and C-terminal G subdomains, and antigenic site peptides. The REG ΔCCD, N- and C-terminal subdomains and peptides generated antibody titers in rabbits and mice that bound to fully glycosylated Recombinant Mammalian expressed G ectodomain (RMG) and intact RSV virion particles but minimal in vitro neutralization titers compared with the intact G ectodomain. Vaccinated mice challenged intranasally with RSV-A2 Line 19F showed significantly reduced viral replication in both the nasal cavity and lungs compared to unimmunized controls, and control of viral loads post-RSV challenge correlated with serum antibody binding to the virus particles. These findings suggest that multiple protective sites in RSV G protein outside of the CCD could contribute to the development of a bacterially produced unglycosylated G protein as a safe and protective vaccine against RSV disease. Further research is necessary to fully understand the complex immune response to RSV and the role of G protein in protective immunity.
During embryonic development, genetic cues control neuronal diversity, with intrinsic transcriptional cascades determining neuronal sub-type cell fate, and target cells providing input for specific neuronal cell fates through retrograde signals. These retrograde signals act as survival and differentiation cues for neurons. In Drosophila, a BMP signal from target cells activates the FMRFa gene in Tv4 neurons of the ventral nerve cord, and a recent study found that brr2 and Prp8, encoding components of the U5 subunit of the spliceosome, play crucial roles in controlling the expression of the FMRFa neuropeptide specifically in six neurons of the VNC (Tv4 neurons). Brr2 controls this expression through two independent mechanisms: proper axonal pathfinding to the target tissue to receive the BMP ligand, and proper RNA splicing of two genes in the BMP pathway, the thickveins (tkv) gene encoding a BMP receptor subunit, and the Medea gene encoding a co-Smad. These findings highlight the importance of post-transcriptional modulations in controlling the identity of individual cells during neural specification processes. Additionally, splicing mechanisms play an essential role in generating cellular diversity during development, including alternate splicing, which plays a major part in the generation of protein variation and regulatory elements specific to certain cell types or tissues.
In order to maintain a diverse range of SCF complexes, the abundance of F-box proteins, a key component of SCF ubiquitin ligases (CRLs), must be tightly controlled. Misregulation of substrate receptor components, particularly for the largest class of CRLs, the SCF ligases, has been associated with numerous diseases including cancer. A key mechanism controlling F-box protein abundance is autocatalytic ubiquitylation by intact SCF complex followed by proteasome-mediated degradation. However, a study on the yeast Met30 F-box protein has identified an additional pathway for regulation. This pathway involves ubiquitylation and degradation of Met30 that is dissociated from Skp1, and requires the cullin component Cdc53/Cul1 but is independent of the other central SCF component Skp1. This non-canonical degradation pathway is critical for chromosome stability and effective defense against heavy metal stress, and is assigned important biological functions to a sub-complex of cullin-RING ligases that comprises Cdc53/Rbx1/Cdc34, but is independent of Skp1. This demonstrates that cullin-RING ligases can have functions independent of their adaptor component Skp1, and adds to the understanding of how cells maintain F-box protein homeostasis.
Kinesin-3 motors, specifically KIF1A, are responsible for the transport of synaptic vesicles and other membrane-bound organelles in neuronal cells. In the absence of cargo, these motors are kept inactive to prevent futile ATP hydrolysis and motility. The current model suggests that KIF1A is monomeric in the inactive state and becomes active through concentration-driven dimerization on the cargo membrane. However, recent studies have found that both native and expressed KIF1A proteins are dimeric in the inactive state, contradicting the previous model. The researchers propose that KIF1A motors are autoinhibited by two distinct inhibitory mechanisms, rather than being activated by cargo-induced dimerization. The researchers also found that KIF1A motors can undergo one-dimensional diffusion along the microtubule lattice, and only dimeric motors undergo ATP-dependent processive motility. This finding suggests that KIF1A may be uniquely suited to use both diffuse and processive motility to drive long-distance transport in neuronal cells. In summary, these findings challenge the current model of KIF1A motor regulation and highlight the importance of understanding the regulation of kinesin motors in enabling the transport of the correct cargo to the proper cellular destination at the relevant time.
A study was conducted to investigate the regulation of seed metabolism and estimate the natural variability in metabolites of tomato introgression lines (ILs) grown in two harvest seasons. Factorial ANOVA confirmed the presence of 30 metabolite quantitative trait loci (mQTL) with the genotypic background being the main factor for metabolic polymorphism. The ILs showed greater phenotypic plasticity than the M82 cultivar. Broad-sense estimate of heritability suggested that the mode of inheritance of metabolite traits in the seed differed from that in the fruit. Correlation-based metabolic network analysis showed that the seed network displayed tighter interdependence of metabolic processes than the fruit. Amino acids in the seed metabolic network played a central hub-like role in the topology of the network. Six exceptionally highly co-regulated amino acids, Gly, Ser, Thr, Ile, Val, and Pro, were identified, reflecting the extensive redundancy of the regulation underlying seed metabolism. The study highlights the added value of integrating metabolic network analysis with mQTL mapping. Tomatoes are one of the most important crops worldwide, used mainly for human consumption, and constitute the best-studied fruit-bearing model organism. The domestication of tomato has led to the erosion of its genetic variability, leading to the loss of valuable traits. Strategies based on the exploitation of natural variation are being employed to reintroduce the lost genetic variation into cultivated species. The study used a set of 76 ILs, each carrying a small chromosomal portion of a distant relative within the chromosomal background of the domesticated tomato. Seeds harvested from two consecutive seasons of all 76 ILs and of M82 were subjected to GC-MS analysis for metabolic profiling. The findings are discussed with respect to recent advances in the regulation of plant metabolism. The study aimed to identify potential QTL involved in the regulation of metabolites in the tomato seed and mapped 354 significant changes in metabolite content, represented on the IL map by a color code referring to the different compound classes. The IL map suggests that a distinct group of amino acids (Gly, Ile, Pro, Ser, Val, Thr) are co-localized onto particular introgressions, indicating a shared regulatory mechanism for TCA cycle intermediates. Most variability in sugar levels was observed to be subject to seasonal influence. The study confirmed 30 out of the 46 previously suggested mQTL by the genotype term (IL), the interaction term (season * IL), or both (IL+season * IL). The analysis indicated the genotype as the major factor controlling metabolite content, with the IL factor exhibiting the most extensive impact on the variance of the dataset. The study calculated the coefficient of variation (CV) on the background of the seed and of the fruit, showing greater phenotypic plasticity in the introgressed background than in that of M82. The H2 bar plot revealed a positive skewness in the distribution pattern of the fruit values, while seed values displayed a near-normal distribution. Intriguingly, six occurrences (traits) exceeding 0.5 were scored in the background of the seed population, whereas none of the H2 values in the background of the fruit population exceeded 0.5. The patterns observed suggest greater broad-sense heritability of metabolic abundance in the seed than in the fruit.
Vibrio cholerae, a Gram-negative bacterial pathogen, causes cholera, a severe diarrheal disease in humans. The bacterium has been found to colonize both aquatic environments, such as the chitinous exoskeletons of zooplankton, and the human gastrointestinal tract. A protein called GbpA (GlcNAc binding protein A) has been identified as a key factor in this colonization process.
