GbpA has been shown to bind to N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) containing carbohydrates, such as chitin, and is secreted by the type 2 secretion system.Structural studies have revealed that GbpA has an unusual, elongated four-domain structure, with structural homology to chitin binding domains in domains 1 and 4. The protein has been found to bind to GlcNAc oligosaccharides, and structure-guided GbpA truncation mutants have shown that domains 1 and 4 of GbpA interact with chitin in vitro. In vivo complementation studies have further shown that domain 1 is crucial for mucin binding and intestinal colonization. Domains 2 and 3 of GbpA have been found to bind to the V. cholerae surface. Mouse virulence assays have shown that only the first three domains of GbpA are required for colonization.These results suggest that GbpA provides structural and functional modular interactions between V. cholerae, intestinal epithelium, and chitinous exoskeletons. The ability of GbpA to bind to both chitin and mucin indicates that it plays a crucial role in the initial stages of V. cholerae colonization in both aquatic environments and the human gastrointestinal tract. The finding that only the first three domains of GbpA are required for colonization suggests that the protein may be a viable target for the development of cholera vaccines and therapies.
Chronic pulmonary tuberculosis (PTB) is a complex disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) and claimed the lives of 1.7 million people in 2016. The disease is more severe and drug-resistant strains are increasingly prevalent, making it a major global health concern. The BCG vaccine is the only available vaccine, but it is not effective in preventing new infection and reactivation in adults. The CD4+ T cell compartment plays a crucial role in immunity to TB, and Th1 effector cytokines, such as IFNγ and IL-12, are particularly important. Treg cells are responsible for suppressing Teff cell proliferation and cytokine expression, and maintaining an efficacious anti-TB Teff response is dependent on counter-regulation by Treg cells. In PTB, Treg cells expand early in Mtb infection and play a role in delaying the generation of IFNγ producing CD4+ Teff cells, but their role in the chronic phase of TB is less clear. A study found that Treg cells from PTB patients suppress heterologous IGRA-ve Teff cells as efficiently as allogeneic/autologous Teff cells, but the capacity of competent Treg cells from IGRA-ve subjects to suppress Teff of PTB patients was significantly compromised. On the other hand, Treg cells from PTB patients suppress heterologous IGRA-ve Teff cells as efficiently as allogeneic/autologous Teff cells. These findings suggest that despite having functional Treg cells similar to that of IGRA-ve controls, PTB patients have Teff cells that are resistant to Treg mediated suppression. Recent studies show expansion of HLA-DR+ and CD38+ CD4+ T cells in PTB and HIV-TB co-infection. Elevated HLA-DR on CD4+ T cells was found to positively correlate with TB disease risk in BCG vaccinated infants. On memory Teff cells, the most striking difference was in the frequency of HLA-DR expressing cells, with PTB subjects having a 2-2.6 fold higher median frequency compared to that of IGRA-ve controls or IGRA+ve individuals. In contrast, CD38+ and PD-1+ Teff frequencies did not vary significantly between the clinical groups. These findings suggest that elevated expression of HLA-DR alone on Teff cells is sufficient for discriminating PTB from healthy controls and treated individuals. The fraction of HLA-DR+ Teff cells in PTB, representing activated Teff, may contribute to resistance to Treg-mediated suppression. HLA-DR+ cells were therefore depleted from the Teff cell pool of TB patients by cell sorting, and depletion of HLA-DR+ cells restored suppression in cells from PTB subjects.
In this study, the researchers investigated the effect of post-translational modifications of PrPC on the fidelity of strain propagation in prion infection. They used transgenic mice lacking the PrP GPI signal sequence on a PrP null background (tgGPI− mice) and inoculated them with different prion strains. They found that RML and ME7 prions propagated in tgGPI− mice developed novel cell tropisms and had higher levels of proteinase K-resistant PrPSc (PrPres) than in wild-type brain. When ME7 prions were returned to wild-type mice, they recovered their original properties, but RML prions had given rise to a novel prion strain, SFL, which remained unchanged after three passages in wild-type mice. The researchers propose that the two conformations are separated by a high activation energy barrier which is abrogated in tgGPI− mice. Additionally, the study found that using the sandwich assay for the quantitation of PrPres revealed unusually high levels of PrPres in RML and ME7 prions propagating in GPI− mice, likely due to greater stability of extracellular as compared to intracellular PrPres.
The BMP signaling pathway is conserved across species and has a crucial role in dorsal-ventral axis patterning during embryonic development. In Drosophila, BMP signaling is regulated by the Mad transcription factor and opposed by the Brinker repressor. In this study, researchers used Drosophila embryos as a model to investigate the BMP-responsive transcriptional network underpinning dorsal ectoderm differentiation during dorsal-ventral axis patterning. They combined RNA-seq with Mad and Brinker ChIP-seq and found multiple new BMP target genes, including positive and negative regulators of EGF signaling. They discovered that EGF signaling negatively regulates embryonic BMP-responsive transcription, and the BMP gene network has a self-regulating property that balances its activity with the antagonistic EGF signaling pathway for correct patterning. Additionally, they identified key roles for the Zelda and Zerknüllt transcription factors in establishing the resulting expression domain and found widespread binding of insulator proteins to the Mad and Brinker-bound genomic regions. The findings highlight the complexity of the BMP pathway and its regulation, which is critical for proper embryonic development. The study's findings are relevant to BMP signal interpretation in vertebrates and contribute to understanding the role of BMP signaling in embryonic development.
"In Tunisia, the prevalence of zoonotic cutaneous leishmaniasis (ZCL) caused by Leishmania major has been increasing and spreading from the south-west to central regions. A study was conducted to analyze the evolution and population dynamics of L. major in human isolates from Tunisian governorates where ZCL is endemic (Gafsa, Kairouan, and Sidi Bouzid) by using multi-locus microsatellite typing and F-statistics and Bayesian model-based approach. The results showed that the genetic patterns of 2008-2012 isolates from the three governorates indicate that L. major populations did not spread gradually from the south to the center of Tunisia. Human activities, reservoir dynamics, and environmental changes may explain the disease progression. The study provides new insights into the evolution and spread of L. major in Tunisia and highlights the importance of continuous monitoring of the parasite flow between geographically and temporally distinct populations. ZCL, also known as ""Le Bouton de Gafsa,"" is a typical model of emerging and reemerging zoonosis and has been endemic in the Gafsa region for many years. The disease has spread to other governorates, including Kairouan and Sidi Bouzid, causing substantial morbidity due to chronic skin ulcers and psychological effects of disfigurement. The majority of L. major strains isolated in Tunisia belong to the MON-25 zymodeme. The study aimed to analyze the spatio-temporal organization of L. major in the three main endemic areas of ZCL in Tunisia (Gafsa, Kairouan, and Sidi Bouzid governorates) by using a multi-locus microsatellite typing approach and population genetic statistical methods. The study used human isolates collected in the three governorates between 2008 and 2012 and identified the parasites as L. major by sequence analysis of the gene encoding RNA polymerase II in combination with the MLEE technique. The study found that the genotypic diversity of L. major was high in these three areas, and unique genotypes and original microsatellite profiles were identified in the isolates. The intraspecific genetic diversity (Hs) was highest in the Gafsa and lowest in the Sidi Bouzid isolates, and the allelic richness (A) and the mean observed heterozygosity (Ho) decreased progressively from Gafsa to Sidi Bouzid. The mean expected heterozygosity (He) values were much higher than the Ho values in all three populations, indicating a deficit in heterozygosity in all three populations. The FST values, which are used as a measure of genetic differentiation between populations, were significantly different between the GF2008-2012 and SBZ2008-2012 isolates and between the GF2008-2012 and KR2008-2012 isolates. The Bayesian model-based clustering analysis implemented in STRUCTURE indicated that the dataset could be organized in four or two clusters. For K = 2, 92% of L. major isolates from Gafsa, 10% from Kairouan, and 38% from Sidi Bouzid were included in one of the inferred clusters, indicating that the three populations were not genetically distinct."
The study conducted in Kenya focused on the impact of different interventions on helminth infections in HIV-infected adults. The study found that deworming is effective in reducing the probability of helminth infections, but with the exception of safe flooring, WASH (water, sanitation, and hygiene) offers minimal additional benefit in reducing the probability of infection. However, WASH does appear to significantly reduce infection prevalence in adults who are not treated with chemotherapy. The study also found that mass drug administration (MDA) for controlling helminth infections is influenced by treatment coverage, prevalence and intensity of different helminth species, drug susceptibility, and socio-behavioral patterns that influence infection and re-infection rates. Other strategies, including WASH interventions, may be needed to reduce the risk of reinfection and ultimately to break transmission of schistosomiasis and STH. Data from a meta-analysis of water and hygiene protective measures suggest that drinking treated water, soap use, and wearing shoes were associated with approximately 45-60% lower odds of infection. Access to and utilization of sanitation facilities is also associated with significant reductions in the prevalence of all three major STH infections. Despite these associations, data from randomized trials evaluating the impact of WASH interventions have demonstrated minimal or no benefit in reducing STH prevalence or intensity in children. Integrating WASH and MDA strategies may be a promising approach to eliminating disease transmission, however, data are limited.
Lectin-like bacteriotoxic proteins, specifically LlpABW from Pseudomonas putida, are able to kill closely related bacterial species, including several phytopathogens, by a mechanism that remains unknown. The crystal structure of LlpABW reveals it has an architecture of two monocot mannose-binding lectin (MMBL) domains and a C-terminal β-hairpin extension. The C-terminal MMBL domain (C-domain) has a mannose-binding site, and mutational analysis shows that an intact sugar-binding pocket in this domain is crucial for bactericidal activity. The N-terminal MMBL domain (N-domain) lacks a functional mannose-binding site but determines target specificity. Bacteriocins, including LlpABW, are a diverse group of protein toxins used by bacteria to inhibit competitors. Pseudomonas species produce R- and F-type pyocins, which attach to specific lipopolysaccharide moieties or dock onto surface-exposed targets, causing depolarization of the cytoplasmic membrane or nucleic acid degradation, respectively. LlpABW represents a class of Pseudomonas-specific antibacterial proteins not related to any known bacteriocin. Additional llpA-like genes encoding functional bacteriocins have been identified in the biocontrol strain Pseudomonas fluorescens Pf-5 and the phytopathogen Pseudomonas syringae pv. syringae 642, as well as in two Xanthomonas pathovars. The LlpA branch occupies a unique position among MMBL-domain proteins and has the capacity to kill bacterial cells with bacteriocin-like specificity.
In Bacillus subtilis, sporulation involves two cells that follow separate but coordinately regulated developmental programs. The forespore, the future spore, is located within the mother cell. The regulation of the forespore transcription factor σG, which acts at a late stage of sporulation, has been unclear. It has been discovered that σG activity requires eight mother-cell proteins encoded in the spoIIIA operon and the forespore protein SpoIIQ. Several of the SpoIIIA proteins share similarity with components of specialized secretion systems. The SpoIIIA proteins and SpoIIQ form a multimeric complex that spans the two membranes surrounding the forespore and are required to maintain forespore integrity. In the absence of these proteins, the forespore develops large invaginations and collapses. This maintenance of forespore integrity does not require σG, indicating that forespore collapse is not a result of the failure to activate σG. These results support a model in which the SpoIIIA-SpoIIQ proteins form a novel secretion apparatus that allows the mother cell to nurture the forespore, thereby maintaining forespore physiology and σG activity during spore maturation. This is important in the context of cell-cell communication, which plays a key role in coordinating gene expression during spore formation and the development of multi-cellular organisms, microbial pathogenesis, and communities of microorganisms.
A genome-wide association study was conducted on a combined sample of 2,191 bipolar disorder (BD) cases and 1,434 controls, using genotype data from the GAIN and TGEN initiatives. Although no genome-wide significant associations were detected, there was evidence of an association between the power to detect effects and evidence for replication (P=1.5×10−7). When considering the development and application of a multilocus schizophrenia-based genetic risk 'score' across many SNPs, a probable polygenic basis for BD was indicated. A strong association was found between power to detect a SNP based on association statistics observed in one study and replication in another study. This relationship was assessed in a way that allows for the assessment of collections of SNPs in defined genomic regions to test hypotheses about the nature of genetic variation mediating BD susceptibility. Within BD, SNPs near exons exhibited a greater probability of replication, supporting an enrichment of reproducible associations near functional regions of genes. These results suggest that there is likely common genetic variation associated with BD near exons (±10 kb) that could be identified in larger studies. Additionally, this approach provides a framework for assessing the potential for replication when combining results from multiple studies.
A study has been conducted to understand the determinants of cancer proliferation and to find new anti-cancer drug targets by employing a computational approach. This approach aims to quantify the association between the expression levels of genes and growth rate measurements across 60 cancer cell lines, assigning each gene a cancer Proliferation Index (cPI). The study found that genes essential in cancer gene knockdown screens exhibit significant positive cPI values, while tumor suppressors exhibit significant negative cPI values. Cell cycle, DNA replication, splicing, and protein production-related processes are positively associated with cancer proliferation, while cellular migration is negatively associated with it. A comparison of genes' non-cancerous proliferation indices (nPI) across 224 lymphoblastoid cell lines revealed marked differences between cancerous and non-cancerous proliferation, highlighting genes in the translation and spliceosome machineries as selective cancer proliferation-associated proteins. A cross-species comparison revealed that cancer proliferation resembles that of microorganisms, while non-cancerous proliferation does not. Combining cancerous and non-cancerous proliferation signatures leads to enhanced prediction of patient outcome and gene essentiality in cancer. Overall, these results suggest that understanding the inherent difference between cancerous and non-cancerous proliferation determinants may contribute to the future development of novel cancer-specific anti-proliferative drugs.
Cystic echinococcosis (CE) is a zoonotic infection caused by the larval stage of the tapeworm Echinococcus granulosus, affecting humans who act as intermediate hosts. It is endemic in several regions including Europe, North and East Africa, India, China, Indonesia, and the Southern Cone of the Americas. The heart is involved in less than 2% of CE cases, and endovascular extracardiac CE is even rarer. A retrospective case series of 11 patients with cardiac and/or endovascular CE, followed-up over a period of 15 years (1995-2009), is reported. The main clinical manifestations included thoracic pain or dyspnea, although 2 patients were asymptomatic. Cysts were located mostly in the right atrium and inferior vena cava. Nine patients underwent cardiac surgery and nine received long-term antiparasitic treatment. The case series highlights that cardiovascular CE is associated with a high risk of potentially lethal complications and should be included in the differential diagnosis of cardiovascular disease in patients from endemic areas. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to improve outcomes in these patients.
TirS, a TIR mimic from Staphylococcus aureus, plays a crucial role in the bacterium's virulence and innate immune evasion. Found within staphylococcal chromosomal cassettes (SCC) containing the fusC gene for fusidic acid resistance, TirS inhibits TLR signaling and the NF-kB pathway, reducing the expression of inflammatory mediators. In mouse models, skin lesions induced by the tirS-mutant are larger than those caused by wild-type and restored strains, with lower neutrophil and macrophage activity. Epidemiological studies show a selective advantage for SCCmec elements with SCC fusC/tirS, linking two key traits determining the success and spread of bacterial infections. TirS is a TIR homolog protein carried by a mobile genetic element conferring resistance to antibiotics, suggesting a potential selective advantage and contributing to the ability of S. aureus to survive and establish a critical population size.
The evolution of organisms can be driven by spatial and temporal changes in gene expression. This is seen in the embryos of lower and higher Diptera, where the ancient extraembryonic envelope composed of amnion and serosa in mosquitoes is reduced to the single amnioserosa in fruit flies. A study was conducted to investigate whole-genome changes in gene expression underlying differences in the embryonic morphologies of the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, and the malaria mosquito, Anopheles gambiae. The researchers used transcriptional datasets collected during the embryonic development of both species and found that many orthologous gene pairs could be clustered based on the presence of coincident discordances in their temporal expression profiles. One such cluster contained genes expressed specifically in the mosquito serosa, which is redeployed later in development at the time of cuticle synthesis. Additionally, there is a striking difference in the temporal expression of a subset of maternal genes, with maternal transcripts that exhibit a sharp reduction at the time of the maternal-zygotic transition in Drosophila displaying sustained expression in the Anopheles embryo. The researchers propose that gene clustering by local temporal discordance can be used for the de novo identification of the gene batteries underlying morphological diversity. This study provides a conceptual and computational framework for cross-organismal temporal alignments and comparisons of species-specific transcriptional datasets, and the resulting heatmaps of discordant gene clusters identified distinctive patterning properties in Dipteran embryos, including the organization of extra-embryonic tissues and the maternal-zygotic transition. The study also suggests that the heatmaps and alignments of gene expression datasets obtained with the time warping algorithm suggest a near linear relationship in their embryonic development, with a subtle deviation from linearity at stage 9, presumably shortly after serosa completion in Anopheles. The removal of serosal genes from the datasets did not result in change in the automatic alignment path, suggesting that this time point may indeed represent temporarily local slow down of gene expression programs in Anopheles embryo proper compared to Drosophila.
A study was conducted to investigate the presence of Haemophilus ducreyi and Treponema pallidum subsp. pertenue, which cause leg ulcers in children in Africa and the Pacific Region, on asymptomatic people, flies, and household linens in an endemic setting. The study was carried out in rural villages of Lihir Island, Papua New Guinea, during a yaws elimination campaign. The study found that 21% of asymptomatic participants had H. ducreyi-PCR positivity and 1% had T. p. pertenue-PCR positivity. The study also demonstrated skin colonization of H. ducreyi in 12% of cultures obtained from asymptomatic participants. Moreover, 90% of flies tested had H. ducreyi DNA and 50% had T. p. pertenue DNA. Additionally, 33% of bed sheets sampled had H. ducreyi DNA and 17% had T. p. pertenue DNA. This is the first time that H. ducreyi DNA and colonization, as well as T. p. pertenue DNA, has been demonstrated in flies and on fomites. The ubiquity of H. ducreyi in the environment is a contributing factor to the spread of the organism. The study highlights the need for further research to understand the role of asymptomatic carriage, flies, and fomites in the transmission and persistence of H. ducreyi and T. p. pertenue in endemic areas.
Bioinformatics is a crucial part of many biomedical and healthcare careers, although there is no agreement on what the knowledge base for this field entails or how to best provide it. The International Society of Computational Biology (ISCB) Education Committee's Curriculum Task Force has developed a set of core bioinformatics competencies to address this issue, targeting various user personas and training programs. These competencies have been refined through a multi-year process of community engagement and are being applied in diverse training contexts. The need for bioinformatics education is immense, with different audiences requiring varying skills and knowledge. The ISCB Education Committee’s Curriculum Task Force has further refined these competencies and presented use cases illustrating their application in various bioinformatics education and training programs globally.The use cases presented in the report are grouped into three categories: complete degree programs, supplements to existing degree programs, and training resources outside the context of specific degree programs. These use cases demonstrate the value of the competencies in defining, refining, or assessing bioinformatics training mechanisms. The Task Force's efforts to develop and refine a set of core competencies for bioinformatics training have sought to assist educators by providing a conceptual framework for sharing experiences, identifying best practices, and addressing divergent needs and expectations.Although the core competencies are not a prescription for specific curricula or curricular standards, they provide a basis for the community of bioinformatics educators to draw upon common experiences in designing, refining, and evaluating their training programs. Moving forward, the Task Force plans to detail its guidelines in a manner similar to the CourseSource framework and provide explicit mappings between the competencies and existing frameworks, such as CourseSource, NHS clinical bioinformatics, Edison data science, and ABET. The ultimate goal is to map courses to competencies for each of the personas in the ISCB competency framework, with examples already available for life scientists, clinical practitioners, and data scientists, among others.
The infectious form of many parasitic nematodes, including those causing significant diseases in humans and substantial agricultural losses, is a developmentally arrested third-stage larva (L3i). The life cycle of the parasitic nematode Strongyloides stercoralis includes both parasitic and free-living forms, making it possible to study the mechanisms of L3i arrest and activation using this species. The free-living nematode Caenorhabditis elegans has a developmentally arrested larval form, the dauer, whose formation is controlled by four pathways: cGMP signaling, IIS, TGFβ signaling, and DA ligands that regulate a nuclear hormone receptor. It has been hypothesized that homologous pathways are present in S. stercoralis and are involved in L3i arrest and activation. To test this, a deep-sequencing study of the polyadenylated transcriptome of S. stercoralis was conducted, generating over 2.3 billion paired-end reads from seven developmental stages. Genes encoding cGMP pathway components were found to be coordinately up-regulated in L3i, and genes encoding IIS ligands and TGFβ ligands were also identified, with several having abundance profiles suggesting involvement in L3i development. However, putative DA biosynthetic genes did not appear to be coordinately regulated in L3i development. These findings suggest that while dauer pathway genes are present in S. stercoralis and may play a role in L3i development, there are significant differences between the two species. Understanding the mechanisms governing L3i development may lead to novel treatment and control strategies.
Bacterial genotoxins, specifically Colibactin and Cytolethal Distending Toxin (CDT), are frequently involved in digestive cancers and can lead to nuclear remodeling. This remodeling includes the formation of deep cytoplasmic invaginations in the nucleus of giant cells, known as the Nucleoplasmic Reticulum (NR). These structures have been observed in vitro and in vivo in mice infected with Helicobacter and in cell cultures treated with Colibactin and CDT-secreting bacteria. The NR contains ribosomes, proteins involved in mRNA translation, polyadenylated RNA, and the main components of the mCRD involved in mRNA turnover. They are active sites of mRNA translation and are associated with a high degree of ploidy, involving MAPK and calcium signaling. The NR is a dynamic and transient structure that protects the cell until the genotoxic stress is relieved. The findings suggest that bacterial genotoxins-induced NR could be a privileged gateway for selected mRNA to be preferentially transported therein for local translation. These discoveries offer new insights into the context of NR formation, which not only appears in response to therapies-induced DNA damage but also earlier in response to genotoxic bacteria.
Leprosy, a chronic infectious disease, can cause facial deformation, including maxillary changes. While saddle nose is well-known, maxillary regression is also a significant issue. In this study, researchers used 3D-CT imaging to evaluate maxillary bone deformation in former leprosy patients and control subjects. They found that three former patients with lepromatous leprosy had marked atrophy of the maxilla, consistent with paleopathological findings. The 3D-CT imaging allowed for precise measurement and calculation of bone defects, which could aid in reconstructive surgery. This study confirmed the presence of maxillary regression in living patients with leprosy, highlighting the need for fundamental corrective treatments for facies leprosa or rhinomaxillary syndrome.
The auditory system faces the challenge of identifying behaviorally relevant sounds in the presence of background noise, and an elegant solution to this problem is for the auditory system to represent sounds in a noise-invariant fashion. This can be achieved by neurons adapting to stimulus statistics, as a major effect of background noise is to alter the statistics of the sounds reaching the ear. A study investigated the extent of neuronal adaptation to the mean and contrast of auditory stimulation as one ascends the auditory pathway. They recorded neuronal responses in the inferior colliculus and primary fields of the auditory cortex of anaesthetized ferrets and compared these responses with a sophisticated model of the auditory nerve. They found that the strength of both forms of adaptation increases as one ascends the auditory pathway. Additionally, populations that show the strongest adaptation to stimulus statistics are also the most noise-tolerant, suggesting that the increase in adaptation to sound statistics from auditory nerve to midbrain to cortex is an important stage in the construction of noise-invariant sound representations in the higher auditory brain. Overall, this study suggests that neural adaptation to stimulus statistics is a neural mechanism for the construction of noise-invariant representations.
Network analysis has become a powerful tool, providing new insights into cellular behavior, with heat shock used as a model of cellular dynamics. The protein-protein interaction network (interactome) of S. cerevisiae, a well-characterized organism, has been used to study the reorganization of the yeast interactome during stress. The major finding of the study is that heat shock induces a significant decrease in both the overlaps and connections of yeast interactome modules, resulting in a partial disintegration of the global organization of the yeast interactome. This change may be a general mechanism occurring in many types of stresses and other complex systems, such as single proteins, social networks, and ecosystems. The study of the yeast interactome under heat shock provides a model of a general, system-level adaptation mechanism to environmental changes.
Chagas disease, a neglected chronic condition prevalent in Latin America and caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, results in high morbidity and mortality rates. Cardiac complications, including arrhythmias, are common in Chagas cardiomyopathy. Although amiodarone has been widely used to manage ventricular arrhythmias in Chagas cardiomyopathy, its efficacy and safety have not been comprehensively evaluated. A systematic review of studies assessing amiodarone's effect on patients with Chagas cardiomyopathy was conducted. Nine studies, including three before-after studies, five case series, and one randomized controlled trial, were included in the review. The review found that amiodarone reduced ventricular tachycardia episodes, ventricular premature beats, and the incidence of ventricular couplets in 24-hour Holter monitoring. However, amiodarone was associated with several side effects, including corneal microdeposits, gastrointestinal events, sinus bradycardia, dermatological events, and drug discontinuation. The quality of evidence ranged from moderate to very low. Therefore, while amiodarone is effective in reducing ventricular arrhythmias in Chagas cardiomyopathy, its use should be balanced with potential benefits and harms at the individual level. Further studies are needed to establish the drug's effect on hard endpoints such as sudden death and hospitalization.
Seasonality is a crucial factor in infectious diseases, including arboviruses spread by mosquitoes such as dengue, chikungunya, and Zika. These diseases are influenced by climatic or environmental factors like temperature and rainfall, as well as human behavioral time trends such as school year schedules, holidays, and weekday-weekend patterns. A study was conducted using medical record data from patients diagnosed with dengue fever at two hospitals in rural Ecuador between 2009-2016 to determine the short- and long-term seasonal patterns of dengue fever, as well as the effect of day of the week and public holidays. The study found that dengue fever diagnoses were more likely on Tuesdays and Thursdays and less likely on Saturdays and Sundays. Public holidays, except for the day after Christmas, were not significant predictors of dengue fever diagnoses. School schedules did not impact dengue diagnoses in school-aged children. Climate factors such as monthly total precipitation, an interaction between total precipitation and monthly absolute minimum temperature, an interaction between total precipitation and monthly precipitation days, and a three-way interaction between minimum temperature, total precipitation, and precipitation days were significant predictors of dengue fever diagnoses. This study provides important insights into local disease prevention efforts, public health planning, and global and regional models of dengue fever trends.
In the ongoing battle against viral infections, scientists are constantly seeking solutions to protect against a diverse range of viral threats, many of which lack effective vaccines or treatment strategies. A recent study has uncovered a promising approach to boost innate immunity, providing broad-spectrum antiviral protection. This novel method involves transgenic expression of a viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRP) in mammalian cells.Researchers found that transgenic mice expressing a picornavirus RdRP exhibited life-long, heightened activation of the innate immune system, leading to dramatic upregulation of 80 interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs). This powerful antiviral state, mediated by MDA5 and MAVS, conferred profound resistance to various lethal viral challenges without triggering harmful autoimmunity or chronic inflammation. Human cell models mirrored these results, with the RdRP inducing an analogous ISG network and a strict block to HIV-1 infection.The RdRP-induced antiviral mechanism operates independently of the adaptive immune system and does not rely on secondary structure within the RdRP mRNA. Instead, it functions at the protein level and requires RdRP catalysis. Notably, lifelong massive ISG elevations in RdRP mice did not result in any adverse health effects or shortened lifespans.These findings suggest that a highly augmented MDA5-mediated activation state can be a well-tolerated configuration of the innate immune system, providing a foundation for augmenting innate immunity to achieve broad-spectrum antiviral protection. The success of this approach could pave the way for novel strategies to enhance innate immunity and safeguard against an array of viral threats.
The effective population size (Ne) is a critical factor in viral evolution, influencing the strength of genetic drift and the frequency of co-infection by multiple genotypes. However, experimental estimates of Ne for different plant viruses have provided varying results. The Independent Action Hypothesis (IAH) proposes that each virion has a probability of infection and acts independently during the infection process, with Ne being dose-dependent. While the IAH has not been tested for a plant virus, a study using Tobacco etch virus (TEV) variants with GFP or mCherry fluorescent markers, in Nicotiana tabacum and Capsicum annuum plants, found that the number of primary infection foci increased linearly with dose, following a Poisson distribution, and that Ne was dose-dependent for this plant RNA virus. The study highlights the importance of considering dose effects when comparing Ne estimates for different viruses and suggests that independent action may be a common characteristic in viral infection processes. However, the study also notes the need for further examination of the IAH's applicability to RNA viruses and other pathosystems.
The paper proposes Sparse Bayesian Regression models for eQTL mapping within individual tissues and across tissues, demonstrating increased power in revealing the true complexity of the eQTL landscape at the systems-level. The method, when tested on a set of 2,000 genes in four tissues, identified a two-eQTL model (cis/trans) for the Hopx gene that was experimentally validated and not detected by conventional approaches. The method showed common genetic regulation of gene expression across four tissues for ~27% of transcripts, providing a >5 fold increase in eQTLs detection compared to single tissue analyses at a 5% FDR level. These findings offer a new opportunity to uncover complex genetic regulatory mechanisms controlling global gene expression, with broad application to analysis of multiple intermediate and whole-body phenotypes in various model systems and humans. Despite the advancements in integrated transcriptional profiling and linkage mapping studies, few methods have addressed the problem of jointly performing an analysis of gene expression across tissues combined with multivariate analysis of a large number of genetic control points. Statistical methods for multiple QTL analyses have followed current developments of sparse regression methods designed to address the large p, small n paradigm. In the eQTL context, regularisation methods have been proposed for single and multiple phenotypes, but interpretability of the genetic effects and adequate characterisation of uncertainty are crucial. The Bayesian variable selection (BVS) approach addresses these concerns and offers additional insights for eQTL studies. The paper implements a new Bayesian variable selection method for multivariate mapping of single or multiple outcomes, demonstrating the ability to identify substantially more cis- and trans-effects than commonly used single marker eQTL methods for the same FDR level and enabling efficient identification of genetic regulation across multiple tissue types.
A mathematical model of proteins regulating extrinsic apoptosis was constructed using mass-action kinetics, with reactions represented as ordinary differential equations (ODEs). The model, named EARM v1.0, contains 58 species, 40 additional species, 28 reactions, and 70 nonzero rate constants. EARM v1.0 consists of four subcircuits, including a lumped-parameter representation of receptor binding by TNF or TRAIL, an enzyme cascade, a mitochondrial feed-forward pathway, and a positive feedback loop. Simplifications were made to reduce the number of species and free parameters. Experiments using HeLa cells exposed to TRAIL revealed a variable-delay, snap-action switching behavior in which C3* activity remained low for a period before rapidly rising to a plateau, leading to cell death. Flow cytometry data showed that TRAIL treatment led to a bimodal distribution of cPARP signals, reflecting rapid and complete PARP cleavage at the single-cell level. Simulation of experimental procedures revealed that varying the mean values of Ts, Td, or f in the synthetic trajectories allowed for the quantification of mean and variance of Ts, Td, and f. When experimental live-cell, flow cytometry, and immunoblot data from HeLa cells exposed to TRAIL were merged, excellent quantitative agreement in death dynamics was observed. Quantitative models of apoptosis must account for the overall efficiency, dose-dependence, length of Td, rapidity of Ts, and the independence of Ts and Td. EARM v1.0 was adjusted to minimize the difference between simulated trajectories and experimental data, demonstrating that efficient snap-action cleavage of effector caspase substrates absolutely requires the mitochondrial feed-forward pathway. In summary, the EARM v1.0 model provides a useful tool for understanding the mechanisms of extrinsic apoptosis and has important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for diseases such as cancer and autoimmunity.
During pregnancy, the placenta protects the fetus from the mother's immune response and pathogens. However, some bacterial pathogens like Listeria monocytogenes have evolved mechanisms to breach this barrier. The protein InlP, secreted by L. monocytogenes, specifically binds to human afadin, a protein associated with cell-cell junctions. The binding of InlP to afadin allows L. monocytogenes to exert traction stresses on deformable substrates and form actin-rich protrusions from the basal face of polarized epithelial monolayers. This process is necessary for the bacterium to cross such monolayers and reach the fetal side of the placenta. InlP's interaction with afadin is crucial for this transcytosis, as mutants lacking InlP or with a specific in-frame deletion in inlP show a decrease in transcytosis. Afadin deletion in the host cells does not rescue the transcytosis defect, indicating that InlP targets cytosolic afadin specifically to promote L. monocytogenes transcytosis. Understanding the mechanisms behind the feto-maternal barrier's protection and how pathogens like L. monocytogenes breach it is essential for developing effective strategies to prevent and treat infections during pregnancy.
Treponema pallidum ssp. pallidum, the bacterium that causes syphilis, is a chronic multistage disease with an estimated 8 million new cases per year. A study was conducted to investigate the T. pallidum proteome profile during infection using complementary mass spectrometry techniques, including multidimensional peptide separation and protein identification via MALDI-TOF/TOF and ESI-LTQ-Orbitrap tandem mass spectrometry. The study identified a total of 6033 peptides, corresponding to 557 unique T. pallidum proteins at a high level of confidence, representing 54% of the predicted proteome. This is the most comprehensive description of the global T. pallidum proteome to date, providing valuable insights into in vivo T. pallidum protein expression and paving the way for improved understanding of the pathogenicity of this enigmatic organism. The study found that a low correlation (r = 0.26) was found between previous microarray signal data and protein abundance, highlighting the need for further study in this area.
"Protein Kinase A (PKA) is a major receptor for the secondary messenger cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) in eukaryotes. The cAMP binds to two tandem cAMP-binding domains (CBD-A and -B) within the regulatory subunit of PKA (R), releasing the activity of the catalytic subunit (C). While CBD-A in RIα is required for PKA inhibition and activation, CBD-B functions as a ""gatekeeper"" domain that modulates the control exerted by CBD-A. Preliminary evidence suggests that CBD-B dynamics are critical for its gatekeeper function. A study using Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) investigated the two-domain construct RIα (91–379) in its apo, cAMP2, and C-bound forms. The results support a double conformational selection model in which each apo CBD dynamically samples both active and inactive states independently of the adjacent CBD within a nearly degenerate free energy landscape. Binding of cAMP eliminates this degeneracy, as it selectively stabilizes the active conformation within each CBD and inter-CBD contacts. The inter-CBD interface is indispensable for full activation of PKA as it occludes C-subunit recognition sites within CBD-A. The two structurally homologous cAMP-bound CBDs exhibit marked differences in their residual dynamics profiles, supporting the notion that conservation of structure does not necessarily imply conservation of dynamics. PKA is a major receptor for cAMP, and in higher eukaryotes, it is utilized by a wide variety of extracellular stimuli to control intra-cellular responses such as regulation of the immune system and cell proliferation."
The study of the interferon (IFN)-stimulated gene 15 (ISG15) reveals that it encodes one of the most abundant proteins induced by IFN, and its expression is associated with antiviral immunity. The proteomes of ISG15-/- and ISG15+/+ bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDM) were compared after vaccinia virus (VACV) infection, and the results showed that mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) were pathways altered in ISG15-/- BMDM treated with IFN. ISG15-dependent mechanisms regulate mitochondrial respiration, ATP, and reactive oxygen species (ROS) production. ISG15 depletion results in a significant change in macrophage polarization, with infected ISG15-/- macrophages showing a robust proinflammatory cytokine expression pattern typical of an M1 phenotype, but a clear blockade of nitric oxide (NO) production and arginase-1 activation. Following IFN treatment, NO release is higher in ISG15+/+ macrophages than in ISG15-/- macrophages, concomitant with a decrease in viral titer. ISG15-/- macrophages are permissive for VACV replication following IFN treatment. ISG15 governs the dynamic functionality of mitochondria, specifically, OXPHOS and mitophagy, broadening its physiological role as an antiviral agent. ISG15 is an IFN α/β-induced ubiquitin-like protein that exists in two distinct states, as a free molecule or conjugated to lysine residues of target proteins. ISGylation has been shown to occur in a cotranslational process favoring modification of viral proteins in infected cells, which in turn obstructs virus assembly or function. ISG15 expression has been shown to disrupt the process of virus-budding via different mechanisms. ISG15 has essential immune functions, but not in antiviral immunity in humans. ISG15 has been shown to play an important role in vaccinia virus (VACV) infection and the regulation of macrophage responses. ISG15-/- macrophages display reduced activation, phagocytic capacity, and programmed cell death in response to VACV infection.
The Vpu protein of HIV-1 has two functions in the replication of the virus: degrading its cellular receptor CD4 and enhancing viral particle release. Vpu undergoes phosphorylation at the serine 61 (S61) residue, which is adjacent to the βTrCP-binding motif. This phosphorylation event triggers Vpu degradation by a βTrCP-independent process. The degradation of Vpu decreases the efficiency of Vpu-mediated release of HIV-1 virions. The controlled degradation of Vpu may contribute to the balance between efficient HIV-1 dissemination and preservation of the reservoir of infected cells. Vpu differentially affects βTrCP-mediated degradation events, which occur at different phases of the cell cycle. The amount of Vpu varies depending on cycle progression, and its expression is reduced in nocodazole-treated cells. Inhibition of proteasome activity by MG132 strongly increases the amount of Vpu in nocodazole-treated cells. The pools of wild-type and mutant Vpu are decreased to a similar extent by nocodazole-induced mitotic arrest, suggesting that βTrCP is not responsible for Vpu degradation. The reduction of Vpu expression in nocodazole-treated cells is due to a mitotic arrest rather than an indirect effect induced by microtubules or Golgi-targeting drugs. A new phosphorylation event of Vpu takes place in mitosis, and substitution of serine 61 into alanine within the Vpu2/6 mutant precludes the appearance of the slow migrating form seen in nocodazole-treated cells. Vpu phosphorylation on serine 61 provides the signal that triggers Vpu degradation in mitotic cells. The Vpu S61A mutant strongly accumulates in cells and coimmunoprecipitates very efficiently with endogenous βTrCP, and accordingly, strongly stabilizes β-catenin. Introduction of Vpu S61Q mutation in the NL4–3 provirus extends the half-life of the Vpu protein, and Vpu-mediated CD4 degradation is not affected by mutation of Vpu serine 61. HIV-1 encoding the S61 Vpu mutant is released much more abundantly from HeLa cells than the wild-type virus. The Vpu S61 mutation does not affect the infectivity of the viral particles. Vpu degradation occurs via a βTrCP-independent pathway and is triggered by phosphorylation of the S61 residue. The regulated degradation process of Vpu predominantly occurs in early mitosis, and the phosphorylation of Vpu serine 61 is the triggering event for subsequent Vpu degradation.
The researchers developed two hypotheses to explain how tissue patterning is coordinated with whole-body development to ensure proper tissue development under various conditions. The first hypothesis is that tissue patterning is tightly coordinated with whole-body development over time, while the second hypothesis is that tissue patterning aligns at developmental milestones. To distinguish between these hypotheses, the researchers studied the wing imaginal discs of Drosophila larvae, using a staging scheme based on the expression of canonical patterning genes, which they linked to three whole-body developmental events: moult, larval wandering, and pupariation. They found that the expression pattern in the wing disc always aligned at moult and pupariation, indicating that these key developmental events represent milestones. However, between these milestones, the progression of pattern showed greater variability in response to changes in temperature and alterations in physiology. The data also showed that discs from wandering larvae showed greater variability in patterning stage, suggesting that wandering is not a developmental milestone. These findings suggest that tissue patterning remains robust against environmental and physiological perturbations by aligning at developmental milestones. This work provides important insights into how the development of individual tissues is coordinated with the body as a whole.
In fungal hyphae, early endosomes are crucial for both endocytosis and long-distance transport of various cargoes, including mRNA and protein complexes. However, the interplay between these seemingly distinct trafficking processes is not well understood. This study reveals that the ESCRT regulator, Did2, coordinates endosomal transport in Ustilago maydis fungal hyphae. Loss of Did2 leads to defects in vacuolar targeting, less processive long-distance transport, and abnormal shuttling of early endosomes. Late endosomal protein Rab7 and vacuolar protease Prc1 exhibit increased shuttling on these aberrant endosomes, indicating defects in endosomal maturation and identity. Molecular motors fail to attach efficiently, resulting in disturbed processive movement, and the endosomal mRNP linker protein Upa1 is hardly present on endosomes, leading to defects in long-distance mRNA transport. Therefore, the ESCRT regulator Did2 coordinates precise maturation of endosomes, providing the correct membrane identity for efficient endosomal long-distance transport. Endocytosis is a fundamental mechanism in eukaryotic cells, required for regulating important cellular processes such as establishing cell polarity at the plasma membrane. After internalization, membrane proteins are sorted into early endosomes, which mature to late endosomes before being targeted to the lysosome/vacuole. Essential components of endosomal maturation include the ESCRT complex, a highly conserved multi-protein complex. The ESCRT machinery plays a crucial role in membrane remodelling, forming intraluminal vesicles within endosomes and sorting endocytosed transmembrane proteins for degradation in the lysosome/vacuole.
Riboswitches are genetic elements that regulate gene expression in bacteria and other organisms by binding specific ligands, leading to changes in conformation that affect transcription or translation. The adenine riboswitches of Bacillus subtilis and Vibrio vulnificus provide an example of this regulation, but with important differences. The B. subtilis pbuE riboswitch controls transcription and requires co-transcriptional binding of adenine, while the V. vulnificus add riboswitch controls translation and can bind adenine after transcription is completed. The pbuE riboswitch functions through a kinetic regime, with regulation dependent on the rate of transcription, while the add riboswitch operates under a thermodynamic regime. These differences highlight the importance of the nature of gene regulation control in riboswitch regulatory mechanisms, and the crucial role of transcription in riboswitch regulation. While many genetic expression studies have historically focused on transcriptional regulation, recent research has shown the importance of post-transcriptional regulation and riboswitches. Riboswitches are cellular sensors that modulate gene expression through various factors, such as temperature, small metabolites, and uncharged tRNAs, and can regulate transcription, translation, mRNA processing and mRNA splicing. They are composed of two modular domains, an aptamer involved in ligand binding and an expression platform that modulates gene expression. Despite their important differences, the pbuE and add adenine riboswitches bind the same ligand but employ different regulation mechanisms to positively modulate gene expression. Understanding the regulatory mechanisms of these and other riboswitch representatives will provide valuable insights into the intricacies of riboswitch regulation.
In both Escherichia coli and Vibrio cholerae, transcription initiation involving a 2-4 nt oligoribonucleotide primer, known as primer-dependent initiation (PDI), is a widely prevalent mechanism for gene expression during the stationary phase of growth. A recent study has established a physiological role for PDI in E. coli as a regulatory mechanism that modulates biofilm formation. The study also demonstrated, using high-throughput sequencing of RNA 5′ ends (5′ RNA-seq), that PDI occurs in V. cholerae and follows a pattern similar to that in E. coli. In particular, PDI is preferentially apparent at promoters carrying the sequence T-1A+1 or G-1G+1, and its occurrence is growth phase-dependent. The PDI-dependent increase in bhsA expression that occurs during stationary phase in E. coli contributes to biofilm formation, revealing a specific role for PDI as a regulatory mechanism that modulates biofilm growth. The study also found that a more sensitive 5′ RNA-seq protocol identified the occurrence of PDI in V. cholerae, with a pattern similar to that in E. coli. The findings highlight the importance of PDI in the regulation of gene expression and cell physiology in both E. coli and V. cholerae.
In both mammals and plants, an imbalance in parental genome dosage can disrupt embryo growth and may contribute to reproductive isolation between emerging new species. Increased dosage of maternal genomes represses growth, while an increased dosage of paternal genomes has the opposite effect. This phenomenon is linked to the expression of imprinted genes, which are activated by a single parental allele. A parental conflict theory proposes that imprinted genes encoding maternal growth inhibitors and paternal growth enhancers directly mirror parental genome imbalances. However, this hypothesis has not been directly tested. In Arabidopsis, genome dosage imbalance deregulates the expression of imprinted genes FERTILIZATION INDEPENDENT SEED2 (FIS2) and FLOWERING WAGENINGEN (FWA), as well as MEDEA (MEA) and PHERES1 (PHE1). These genes are controlled by DNA methylation and histone methylation, respectively. The changes in PHE1 and MEA expression cannot be fully accounted for by fluctuations in FIS2 expression, indicating that parental genome dosage imbalance deregulates imprinting using mechanisms independent from known regulators of imprinting. Overall, the complexity of the network of regulations between expressed and silenced alleles of imprinted genes activated in response to parental dosage imbalance does not support simple models derived from the parental conflict hypothesis. Increased maternal dosage is expected to increase the level of expression of the active maternal allele of FIS2 and FWA, while the global level of expression of these genes should not be affected by an increased dosage of inactive paternal alleles. However, measurements of the expression of FIS2, a maternally expressed imprinted gene silenced by DNA methylation, indicate that parental genome dosage imbalance did not affect transcription globally and did not affect regulators of DNA methylation, which control imprinting. The expression of these two genes is also not imprinted. The experiments showed that parental genome dosage imbalance down-regulates FIS2 expression irrespective of its genomic context. Increased paternal genome dosage down-regulates FIS2 expression likely through a distinct mechanism, possibly due to an increased paternal dosage of a paternally expressed imprinted inhibitor of FIS2 or from the activity of yet unidentified cis-elements. Loss of FIS2 imprinting was not restricted to RLD 2n X Col 4n crosses, indicating that increased paternal dosage decreases the overall expression of FIS2 while both parental alleles become expressed. Such rather paradoxical effect is difficult to interpret. Parental genome dosage imbalance perturbs imprinting through interactions between imprinted genes and other unidentified regulators. At least two out of four genes studied, MEA and FIS2, lost imprinting as a result of dosage imbalance, indicating that increasing the dosage of the silenced allele of an imprinted gene causes the removal of the imprinting marks on the silenced allele.
"A study discussed in the text has developed a method to reverse-engineer network architectures, or ""virtual brains,"" based on EEG/MEG recordings of neural activity. These recordings typically exhibit oscillations of specific frequencies over a non-oscillatory background, which appear as evenly spaced frequency bands on a logarithmic scale. The researchers used mathematical techniques to reconstruct network architectures that generate characteristic dynamics of actual brains, including spindles and sharp waves. They found that all reconstructed networks, including those modeled after diseased brains, display similar topological features and dynamics. The complexity of the network was found to be a good indicator of brain fitness, with virtual brains modeling diseased states displaying lower complexity than those modeling normal neural function. This approach has the potential to provide insights into the neurobiology of health and disease."
The study analyzes the population structure of 1,374 unrelated Hispanic individuals from the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA) cohort, using 60,000 SNPs selected for minimal linkage disequilibrium. The analysis reveals four genetic subgroups that align with self-identified heritage, primarily representing Central/South America, the Dominican Republic and Cuba, Mexico, and Puerto Rico. The first two principal components (PCs) of ancestry display strong population stratification across the Hispanic cohort, with the first PC separating individuals of Mexican versus Caribbean origin and the second PC reflecting admixture of Caucasian and African ancestry. The third and fourth PCs further separate Puerto Rican and Central/South American subjects into two distinct groups, with the population structure aligning with a South-to-North geographic location of Native American samples. The study also performs genetic association analysis of triglycerides for selected SNPs in the LPL and TRIB1 gene regions, previously reported in GWAS of triglycerides in Caucasians but unconfirmed in Hispanic populations. The analysis provides statistically significant evidence for genetic association and demonstrates the importance of considering population substructure and genetic heterogeneity in genetic association studies performed in the United States Hispanic population.
The Elongator complex, involved in transcription elongation and modification of tRNAs, has been found to have a role in transcriptional silencing, genome stability, and DNA repair. Elp3, the catalytic subunit of the Elongator complex, is required for silencing of reporter genes at the chromosome VIIL telomere and at the HMR locus, and cells lacking Elp3 are sensitive to DNA replication inhibitor hydroxyurea (HU) and the damaging agent methyl methanesulfonate (MMS). Elp3 is also required for S-phase progression in the presence of HU. Epistatic analysis shows that the elp3Δ mutant exacerbates the MMS sensitivity of cells lacking histone chaperones Asf1, CAF-1 and the H3 lysine 56 acetyltransferase Rtt109. The Elongator complex interacts with the DNA replication and DNA repair protein PCNA, and PCNA binds to the Elongator complex both in vivo and in vitro. These results suggest a novel role for the intact Elongator complex in transcriptional silencing and maintenance of genome stability, and it does so in a pathway linked to the DNA replication and DNA repair protein PCNA. Chromatin, an organized complex of proteins and DNA in eukaryotic cells, is regulated by diverse means to govern cellular processes including gene transcription, DNA replication and DNA repair. Histones that form the core components of nucleosomes are modified post-translationally by acetylation, methylation, phosphorylation and ubiquitination. Distinct modifications of histones can either alter chromatin structure and/or recruit proteins to chromatin to impact a specific cellular process. Histone chaperones facilitate DNA replication and gene transcription processes by binding to histones for nucleosome assembly and/or disassembly. Chromatin can be remodeled by ATP dependent chromatin remodeling machines. Emerging evidence suggests that histone modifications, nucleosome assembly and chromatin remodeling coordinate to regulate chromatin structures during gene transcription, DNA replication and DNA repair and other cellular processes.
A knowledge-based service providing highly precise and organized biomedical information requires the manual curation of relevant publications, which is usually done through a query-based process called document triage. However, this method often has unsatisfactory precision and recall, and manually generating optimal queries is difficult. A machine-learning assisted triage method has been proposed to address this issue. This method uses deep learning models based on convolutional neural networks, trained on previously curated publications from UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot and the NHGRI-EBI GWAS Catalog, to classify and rank new publications for curation. This machine-assisted triage method outperforms current query-based triage methods, improving efficiency and enriching curated content. It achieved a precision 1.81 and 2.99 times higher than that obtained by the current query-based triage methods of UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot and the GWAS Catalog, respectively, without compromising recall. This method allows human curators to focus on more challenging tasks, improving the quality of knowledge bases.
The KCNJ2-encoded Kir2.1 channels, which are strongly expressed in both atria and ventricles, are responsible for the cardiac inward rectifier potassium current (IK1), which stabilizes the resting membrane potential and contributes to the terminal repolarization of both atrial and ventricular action potentials. Loss-of-function of Kir2.1 channels has been implicated in the Andersen-Tawil syndrome, while gain-of-function KCNJ2 mutations are potentially life-threatening, underlying variant 3 of the short QT syndrome (SQT3) and familial atrial fibrillation (AF). SQT3 is characterized by an abbreviated QT interval, tall and peaked T waves, and loss of rate-adaptation of the QT interval, and has been associated with increased risk of ventricular and atrial arrhythmias and of sudden cardiac death. This study aimed to evaluate and compare the influence of the SQT3 D172N and E299V Kir2.1 mutations on atrial repolarisation and susceptibility to re-entrant excitation, using heterogeneous, multi-scale models of human atrial electrophysiology. The study found that the D172N and E299V mutations produced distinct effects on IK1 and APD shortening, decreased wavelength of re-entry (WL) for re-entry through a reduction in ERP and CV, and altered stability of re-entrant excitation waves in 2D and 3D tissue models. Combined block of IK1 and IKr was effective in terminating re-entry associated with heterozygous D172N conditions, whereas IKr block alone may be a safer alternative for the E299V mutation. Combined inhibition of IKr and IKur produced a synergistic anti-arrhythmic effect in both forms of SQT3. The study provides mechanistic insights into atrial proarrhythmia with SQT3 Kir2.1 mutations and highlights possible pharmacological strategies for management of SQT3-linked AF.
Chagas disease, caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, is a complex systemic disease endemic in Central and South America, with an estimated 7.7 million infected individuals in 2005. However, 20% of the Latin American population is still at risk of infection, and there are 300,000 infected individuals living in the United States. The disease is classically transmitted by hematophagous triatomine insects, but vector-independent forms of transmission such as blood transfusions, organ transplantation, ingestion of contaminated food or drinks, and congenital transmission are becoming more common, particularly in developed countries. Chronic infection with T. cruzi can lead to three symptomatic forms: cardiac, digestive, or cardiodigestive, with the cardiac form being the most severe and frequent, affecting 20-30% of infected individuals. In a recent study, researchers aimed to investigate if adipose tissue-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (ASC) could alter the course of Chagas disease and attenuate pathology in a mouse model of chagasic cardiomyopathy. ASC were injected intraperitoneally at 3 days post-infection, and the results showed that ASC injection resulted in a significant reduction in blood parasitemia, which was followed by a decrease in cardiac tissue inflammation, parasitism, and fibrosis at 30 dpi. At the same time point, analyses of cytokine release in cells isolated from the heart and exposed to T. cruzi antigens indicated an anti-inflammatory response in ASC-treated animals. The study suggests that the injection of ASC early after T. cruzi infection prevents right ventricular remodeling through the modulation of immune responses, thus promoting a lymphoid organ response to the parasite that promotes the control of parasite burden while protecting the heart from damage due to improved control of inflammation in ASC-treated mice.
Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by Leishmania parasites that reside in specialized compartments in mammalian cells called parasitophorous vacuoles (LPVs). These LPVs share characteristics with late endocytic pathway compartments, including acidification and the presence of molecules such as LAMP1 and cathepsins. However, there are still many uncertainties about the composition of LPVs. Some studies have shown that molecules typically found in secretory pathway compartments, such as calnexin and SNAREs, are also present on LPVs and are functionally relevant to their biogenesis.A small molecule called Retro-2cycl, which disrupts the retrograde transport machinery in mammalian cells, has been shown to block retrograde transport-dependent phenomena, such as polyomavirus cellular infection and Shiga toxin trafficking in cells. Retro-2cycl and its analogs, DHQZ 36 and DHQZ 36.1, have been found to limit Leishmania amazonensis infection in macrophages at lower concentrations than Retro-2cycl. These analogs have also been shown to reverse Leishmania-induced suppression of IL-6 release by infected cells after LPS activation and to kill Leishmania parasites in axenic cultures, which is a desirable attribute for any drug to treat Leishmania infections. These studies validate and extend the published structure-activity relationship analyses of Retro-2cycl and suggest that pharmacological intervention in protein transport could be a viable strategy for the treatment of Leishmania.
The nucleosome, the fundamental unit of genomic organization, is believed to play a central role in regulating gene transcription in eukaryotic cells. It is comprised of an octameric protein core wrapped by ~147 bp of DNA. Nucleosomes can be positioned either statistically or specifically within the genome, influenced by factors such as chromatin remodeling enzymes or the basal affinity of DNA for a nucleosome. A study by Whitehouse et al. used a computational method to evaluate the nucleosome sensitivity for a transcription factor over a given stretch of the genome, focusing on the Acute Myeloid Leukemia-1a (AML-1a) transcription factor. AML-1a, a regulator of immune gene expression, was identified as potentially sensitive to nucleosomal regulation within the mouse Ly49 gene family.The Ly49 genes, which encode receptors on natural killer (NK) and other immune cells, are of interest due to their stochastic expression and the role they play in distinguishing healthy cells from cancer or virus-infected cells. By analyzing MNase-Seq data from RMA cells, which naturally express only Ly49A, the researchers found a specific depletion of nucleosomes at AML-1a binding sites in the expressed Ly49A when compared to the other, silent Ly49 genes. This suggests that nucleosome-based regulation contributes to the expression of Ly49 genes.This method of predicting nucleosome sensitivity could aid in dissecting the regulatory role of nucleosomes in general, as understanding the complex regulatory network of histone modifications and nucleosome steric effects on DNA accessibility is essential for comprehending gene expression regulation. The researchers propose that certain necessary transcription factor binding sites within the Ly49 promoters or the enhancer may be sensitive to the steric effects of nucleosome coverage, leading to variations in Ly49 expression. The study of nucleosome positioning and its interaction with transcription factor binding sites in the Ly49 gene family provides valuable insights into transcriptional regulation by nucleosomes.
The cell cycle and genome duplication are regulated by cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs), with CDK activation depending on phosphorylation of their T-loop by a CDK-activating kinase (CAK). In animals, the only known CAK for CDK2 and CDK1 is cyclin H-CDK7, which is constitutively active. However, the critical activation step for CDK2 and CDK1 is dephosphorylation of inhibitory sites by Cdc25 phosphatases rather than unrestricted T-loop phosphorylation. CDK4 and CDK6, activated by D-type cyclins, are master integrators of mitogenic/oncogenic signaling cascades and are crucial for various oncogenic transformation processes. A CDK4/6 inhibitor is being tested in clinical trials for various chemotherapy-resistant cancers. CDK4/6 activity is deregulated in many human tumors, and specific CDK7 inhibition has been shown to reveal a crucial but partly indirect CDK7 involvement in phosphorylation/activation of CDK4 and CDK6, the existence of CDK4-activating kinase(s) other than CDK7, and novel CDK7-dependent positive feedbacks mediated by p21 phosphorylation to sustain CDK4 activation, pRb inactivation, and restriction point passage. CDK4/6 inhibitors have shown promise in preclinical models and in patients, and further research is needed to fully understand the complex regulation of CDK4/6 activation and its potential as a therapeutic target in cancer treatment.
DUET, a PHD finger protein in Arabidopsis, plays a crucial role in male meiosis. It is specifically expressed during the diplotene stage of meiosis and localizes to euchromatin, where it binds H3K4me2 but not H3K9me2. The mutation of DUET results in cytoplasmic collapse of meiocytes, delayed progression, formation of dyads and triads, absence of pollen, and cytokinesis, chromosome segregation, and cell cycle regulation defects during meiosis II. The DUET PHD finger specifically binds H3K4me2, and this interaction is critical for its function. In meiosis II, DUET is required for cellular organization, microtubule organization, and chromatid segregation. DUET affects gene expression, and its expression is specifically required for JAS expression, which plays a role in meiosis II spindle organization. Additionally, DUET is required for TDM1 expression, which is involved in meiotic cell cycle transitions. Overall, DUET is a transcriptional regulator that plays a critical role during male meiosis in plants.
Fragile X-associated tremor/ataxia syndrome (FXTAS) is a late-onset neurodegenerative disorder primarily affecting male premutation carriers of the Fragile X Mental Retardation 1 (FMR1) gene, which has a trinucleotide repeat expansion of CGG in the 5' untranslated region. Previous studies found that Fragile X rCGG repeats can cause neurodegeneration and that the rCGG repeat-binding proteins Pur α and hnRNP A2/B1 can modulate rCGG-mediated neuronal toxicity. A recent study aimed to explore the role of Pur α further in rCGG-mediated neurodegeneration using a proteomic approach and identified more than 100 proteins that interact with Pur α. Of particular interest is Rm62, the Drosophila ortholog of p68 RNA helicase, which could modulate rCGG-mediated neurodegeneration. The study found that rCGG repeats decreased the expression of Rm62 posttranscriptionally, leading to the nuclear accumulation of Hsp70 transcript and other mRNAs involved in stress and immune responses. These findings suggest that abnormal nuclear accumulation of these mRNAs, likely as a result of impaired nuclear export, could contribute to FXTAS pathogenesis.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a paradigm organism for the study of biofilms, forms environmentally and clinically relevant biofilms that are matrix-encased communities of bacteria. The extracellular polymeric substance (EPS) of P. aeruginosa biofilms is a mix of polysaccharides, nucleic acids, and proteins, with the Psl exopolysaccharide being required for bacterial cells to adhere to a substratum and maintain biofilm structure. Psl appears to be composed of mannose, galactose, rhamnose, glucose, and trace amounts of xylose, although its precise biochemical structure has not been determined. A thorough understanding of the biofilm matrix ultra-structure is critical for the rational design of inhibitors that could prevent the numerous clinical and environmental complications associated with biofilms. In a study, Psl-specific lectin staining followed by confocal scanning laser microscopy (CLSM) was used to visualize Psl on the surface of cells and within the EPS matrix. The results show a helical pattern of Psl staining on the bacterial cell surface at the biofilm initiation stage, which is essential for formation of the Psl matrix and the initiation of a biofilm. The Psl matrix was visualized in real time during a biofilm developmental cycle, revealing how the matrix forms and encases the bacterial cells in the biofilm and on a surface and how the matrix changes structure to maintain biofilm architecture during development. Using double staining methodologies, it was shown that the eDNA and Psl matrices do not overlap, but appear to coordinate activities to maintain the biofilm structure. It was proposed that, like higher organisms, P. aeruginosa can utilize programmed cell death and autolysis to degrade the Psl matrix in the center of microcolonies to free ‘the seeds of biofilm’ for future dispersal. Cellulase, which targets β-1, 3 or β-1, 4-linked glucans, can free Psl from the bacterial cell surface without degrading the major Psl polymer and cellulase-digested Psl is able to adhere with a substratum. This data suggests that β-1, 3 or β-1, 4-linked glucose may be the monosaccharide that links Psl to the bacterial surface. Cellulase treatment dramatically reduces biofilm development under flow conditions, indicating that the surface association of Psl is essential for P. aeruginosa to initiate a biofilm.
Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is a lethal malignancy with poor prognosis and limited treatment options. Patient-derived xenografts (PDX) and patient-derived organoids (PDO) are promising preclinical models for PDAC, offering the potential to recapitulate the molecular heterogeneity of PDAC and validate patient-specific therapeutic sensitivities. However, a comprehensive assessment of the molecular heterogeneity of PDX and PDO models and their comparison with matched human tumors at the whole genome level has not been thoroughly addressed.To address this, a study conducted a comprehensive assessment of the genetic landscape of 16 whole-genome pairs of tumors and matched PDX, from primary PDAC and liver metastasis, including a unique cohort of 5 'trios' of matched primary tumor, PDX, and PDO. The study developed a pipeline to score concordance between PDAC models and their paired human tumors for genomic events, including mutations, structural variations (SV), and copy number variations (CNV). The results showed that tumor-model comparisons of mutations displayed single-gene concordance across major PDAC driver genes, but relatively poor agreement across the greater mutational load. Genome-wide and chromosome-centric analysis of structural variation (SV) events highlights previously unrecognized concordance across chromosomes that demonstrate clustered SV events. However, polyploidy presented a major challenge when assessing copy number changes, and ploidy-corrected copy number states suggest good agreement between donor-model pairs.In conclusion, while PDXs and PDOs may serve as tractable and transplantable systems for probing the molecular properties of PDAC, these models may best serve selective analyses across different levels of genomic complexity. Overall, the findings indicate that PDX and PDO successfully recapitulate primary and metastatic disease at the level of simple somatic mutations mainly in driver genes, but not across the greater expanse of annotated mutations. Disease model fidelity is not readily retained when assessing structural variation (SV) events, but clustering of large SV events across particular chromosomes of the tumors is retained in matching disease models. The work demonstrates stable consistency of ploidy-corrected copy number states between donor-model pairs, but underscores a major concern regarding ploidy changes when tumors are implanted into their respective models.
A large genome-wide association study (GWAS) was conducted in East Asian women to identify novel genetic susceptibility loci for breast cancer. The study included 19,091 cases and 20,606 controls of East-Asian descent, including Chinese, Korean, and Japanese women. After analyzing 690,947 SNPs in 2,918 cases and 2,324 controls, the study evaluated 5,365 SNPs for replication in 3,972 cases and 3,852 controls, and further evaluated the top 22 SNPs in up to 17,423 additional subjects. The study found strong evidence for a novel breast cancer susceptibility locus near the TGF-β activated kinase (TAB2) gene in chromosome 6q25.1, represented by rs9485372, which was associated with breast cancer risk with a P-value of 3.8×10−12 in the combined analysis of all samples. The study also identified two possible susceptibility loci located in the ESR1 gene and 11q24.3, respectively. These findings provide important insights into the genetic factors that contribute to breast cancer risk in East Asian women.
Cryptococcal meningitis, caused by the fungus Cryptococcus neoformans (Cn), is a significant cause of mortality in HIV-positive patients, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa.
